    
Our
Mutual
Friend
Charles
Dickens
  
1864
<EOS>
-
-1865
  
<EOS>
Information
about
the
source
                     
Book
the
First
.
<EOS>
The
Cup
and
the
Lip
.
                                     
<EOS>
ON
THE
LOOK
OUT
.
 
<EOS>
In
these
times
of
ours
,
though
concerning
the
exact
year
there
is
no
need
to
be
precise
,
a
boat
of
dirty
and
disreputable
appearance
,
with
two
figures
in
it
,
floated
on
the
Thames
,
between
Southwark
Bridge
which
is
of
iron
,
and
London
Bridge
which
is
of
stone
,
as
an
autumn
evening
was
closing
in
.
  
<EOS>
The
figures
in
this
boat
were
those
of
a
strong
man
with
ragged
grizzled
hair
and
a
sun
-
browned
face
,
and
a
dark
girl
of
nineteen
or
twenty
,
sufficiently
like
him
to
be
recognizable
as
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
The
girl
rowed
,
pulling
a
pair
of
sculls
very
easily
;
the
man
,
with
the
rudder
-
lines
slack
in
his
hands
,
and
his
hands
loose
in
his
waistband
,
kept
an
eager
look
out
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
net
,
hook
,
or
line
,
and
he
could
not
be
a
fisherman
;
his
boat
had
no
cushion
for
a
sitter
,
no
paint
,
no
inscription
,
no
appliance
beyond
a
rusty
boathook
and
a
coil
or
rope
,
and
he
could
not
be
a
waterman
;
his
boat
was
too
crazy
and
too
small
to
take
in
cargo
for
delivery
,
and
he
could
not
be
a
lighterman
or
river
-
carrier
;
there
was
no
clue
to
what
he
looked
for
,
but
he
looked
for
something
,
with
a
most
intent
and
searching
gaze
.
<EOS>
The
tide
,
which
had
turned
an
hour
before
,
was
running
down
,
and
his
eyes
watched
every
little
race
and
eddy
in
its
broad
sweep
,
as
the
boat
made
slight
head
-
way
against
it
,
or
drove
stern
foremost
before
it
,
according
as
he
directed
his
daughter
by
a
movement
of
his
head
.
<EOS>
She
watched
his
face
as
earnestly
as
he
watched
the
river
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
the
intensity
of
her
look
there
was
a
touch
of
dread
or
horror
.
  
<EOS>
Allied
to
the
bottom
of
the
river
rather
than
the
surface
,
by
reason
of
the
slime
and
ooze
with
which
it
was
covered
,
and
its
sodden
state
,
this
boat
and
the
two
figures
in
it
obviously
were
doing
something
that
they
often
did
,
and
were
seeking
what
they
often
sought
.
<EOS>
Half
savage
as
the
man
showed
,
with
no
covering
on
his
matted
head
,
with
his
brown
arms
bare
to
between
the
elbow
and
the
shoulder
,
with
the
loose
knot
of
a
looser
kerchief
lying
low
on
his
bare
breast
in
a
wilderness
of
beard
and
whisker
,
with
such
dress
as
he
wore
seeming
to
be
made
out
of
the
mud
that
begrimed
his
boat
,
still
there
was
business
-
like
usage
in
his
steady
gaze
.
<EOS>
So
with
every
lithe
action
of
the
girl
,
with
every
turn
of
her
wrist
,
perhaps
most
of
all
with
her
look
of
dread
or
horror
;
they
were
things
of
usage
.
  
<EOS>
"
Keep
her
out
,
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
Tide
runs
strong
here
.
<EOS>
Keep
her
well
afore
the
sweep
of
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Trusting
to
the
girl
's
skill
and
making
no
use
of
the
rudder
,
he
eyed
the
coming
tide
with
an
absorbed
attention
.
<EOS>
So
the
girl
eyed
him
.
<EOS>
But
,
it
happened
now
,
that
a
slant
of
light
from
the
setting
sun
glanced
into
the
bottom
of
the
boat
,
and
,
touching
a
rotten
stain
there
which
bore
some
resemblance
to
the
outline
of
a
muffled
human
form
,
coloured
it
as
though
with
diluted
blood
.
<EOS>
This
caught
the
girl
's
eye
,
and
she
shivered
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
ails
you
?
"
said
the
man
,
immediately
aware
of
it
,
though
so
intent
on
the
advancing
waters
;
"
I
see
nothing
afloat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
red
light
was
gone
,
the
shudder
was
gone
,
and
his
gaze
,
which
had
come
back
to
the
boat
for
a
moment
,
travelled
away
again
.
<EOS>
Wheresoever
the
strong
tide
met
with
an
impediment
,
his
gaze
paused
for
an
instant
.
<EOS>
At
every
mooring
-
chain
and
rope
,
at
every
stationary
boat
or
barge
that
split
the
current
into
a
broad
-
arrow
-
head
,
at
the
offsets
from
the
piers
of
Southwark
Bridge
,
at
the
paddles
of
the
river
steamboats
as
they
beat
the
filthy
water
,
at
the
floating
logs
of
timber
lashed
together
lying
off
certain
wharves
,
his
shining
eyes
darted
a
hungry
look
.
<EOS>
After
a
darkening
hour
or
so
,
suddenly
the
rudder
-
lines
tightened
in
his
hold
,
and
he
steered
hard
towards
the
Surrey
shore
.
  
<EOS>
Always
watching
his
face
,
the
girl
instantly
answered
to
the
action
in
her
sculling
;
presently
the
boat
swung
round
,
quivered
as
from
a
sudden
jerk
,
and
the
upper
half
of
the
man
was
stretched
out
over
the
stern
.
  
<EOS>
The
girl
pulled
the
hood
of
a
cloak
she
wore
,
over
her
head
and
over
her
face
,
and
,
looking
backward
so
that
the
front
folds
of
this
hood
were
turned
down
the
river
,
kept
the
boat
in
that
direction
going
before
the
tide
.
<EOS>
Until
now
,
the
boat
had
barely
held
her
own
,
and
had
hovered
about
one
spot
;
but
now
,
the
banks
changed
swiftly
,
and
the
deepening
shadows
and
the
kindling
lights
of
London
Bridge
were
passed
,
and
the
tiers
of
shipping
lay
on
either
hand
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
now
that
the
upper
half
of
the
man
came
back
into
the
boat
.
<EOS>
His
arms
were
wet
and
dirty
,
and
he
washed
them
over
the
side
.
<EOS>
In
his
right
hand
he
held
something
,
and
he
washed
that
in
the
river
too
.
<EOS>
It
was
money
.
<EOS>
He
chinked
it
once
,
and
he
blew
upon
it
once
,
and
he
spat
upon
it
once
,
---
"
for
luck
,
"
he
hoarsely
said
---
before
he
put
it
in
his
pocket
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lizzie
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
girl
turned
her
face
towards
him
with
a
start
,
and
rowed
in
silence
.
<EOS>
Her
face
was
very
pale
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
hook
-
nosed
man
,
and
with
that
and
his
bright
eyes
and
his
ruffled
head
,
bore
a
certain
likeness
to
a
roused
bird
of
prey
.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
that
thing
off
your
face
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
put
it
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
!
<EOS>
and
give
me
hold
of
the
sculls
.
<EOS>
I
'll
take
the
rest
of
the
spell
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
no
,
father
!
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
indeed
.
<EOS>
Father
!
<EOS>
---
I
can
not
sit
so
near
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
moving
towards
her
to
change
places
but
her
terrified
expostulation
stopped
him
and
he
resumed
his
seat
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
hurt
can
it
do
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
None
,
none
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
not
bear
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
my
belief
<EOS>
you
hate
the
sight
of
the
very
river
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
---
I
do
not
like
it
,
father
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
if
it
was
n't
your
living
!
<EOS>
As
if
it
was
n't
meat
and
drink
to
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
these
latter
words
the
girl
shivered
again
,
and
for
a
moment
paused
in
her
rowing
,
seeming
to
turn
deadly
faint
.
<EOS>
It
escaped
his
attention
,
for
he
was
glancing
over
the
stern
at
something
the
boat
had
in
tow
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
be
so
thankless
to
your
best
friend
,
Lizzie
?
<EOS>
The
very
fire
that
warmed
you
when
you
were
a
babby
,
was
picked
out
of
the
river
alongside
the
coal
barges
.
<EOS>
The
very
basket
that
you
slept
in
,
the
tide
washed
ashore
.
<EOS>
The
very
rockers
that
I
put
it
upon
to
make
a
cradle
of
it
,
I
cut
out
of
a
piece
of
wood
that
drifted
from
some
ship
or
another
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
took
her
right
hand
from
the
scull
it
held
,
and
touched
her
lips
with
it
,
and
for
a
moment
held
it
out
lovingly
towards
him
;
 
then
,
without
speaking
,
she
resumed
her
rowing
,
as
another
boat
of
similar
appearance
,
though
in
rather
better
trim
,
came
out
from
a
dark
place
and
dropped
softly
alongside
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
luck
again
,
Gaffer
?
<EOS>
"
said
a
man
with
a
squinting
leer
,
who
sculled
her
and
who
was
alone
.
<EOS>
"
I
know'd
<EOS>
you
was
in
luck
again
,
by
your
wake
as
you
come
down
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
replied
the
other
,
drily
.
"
<EOS>
So
you
're
out
,
are
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
pardner
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
now
a
tender
yellow
moonlight
on
the
river
,
and
the
new
comer
,
keeping
half
his
boat
's
length
astern
of
the
other
boat
,
looked
hard
at
its
track
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
says
to
myself
,
"
he
went
on
,
"
<EOS>
directly
you
hove
in
view
,
Yonder
's
Gaffer
,
and
in
luck
again
,
by
George
if
he
ai
n't
!
<EOS>
Scull
it
is
,
pardner
---
<EOS>
do
n't
fret
yourself
---
<EOS>
I
did
n't
touch
him
.
<EOS>
"
This
was
in
answer
to
a
quick
impatient
movement
on
the
part
of
Gaffer
:
the
speaker
at
the
same
time
unshipping
his
scull
on
that
side
,
and
laying
his
hand
on
the
gunwale
of
Gaffer
's
boat
and
holding
to
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
had
touches
enough
not
to
want
no
more
,
as
well
as
<EOS>
I
make
him
out
,
Gaffer
!
<EOS>
Been
a
knocking
about
with
a
pretty
many
tides
,
ai
n't
he
pardner
?
<EOS>
Such
is
my
out
-
of
-
luck
ways
,
you
see
!
<EOS>
He
must
have
passed
me
when
he
went
up
last
time
,
for
I
was
on
the
lookout
below
bridge
here
.
<EOS>
I
a'most
think
you
're
like
the
wulturs
,
pardner
,
and
scent
'em
out
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
spoke
in
a
dropped
voice
,
and
with
more
than
one
glance
at
Lizzie
who
had
pulled
on
her
hood
again
.
<EOS>
Both
men
then
looked
with
a
weird
unholy
interest
at
the
wake
of
Gaffer
's
boat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Easy
does
it
,
betwixt
us
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
take
him
aboard
,
pardner
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
other
.
<EOS>
In
so
surly
a
tone
that
the
man
,
after
a
blank
stare
,
acknowledged
it
with
the
retort
:
  
"
---
Arn't
been
eating
nothing
as
has
disagreed
with
you
,
have
you
,
pardner
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
yes
,
I
have
,
"
said
Gaffer
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
swallowing
too
much
of
that
word
,
Pardner
.
<EOS>
I
am
no
pardner
of
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Since
when
was
you
no
pardner
of
mine
,
Gaffer
Hexam
Esquire
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Since
you
was
accused
of
robbing
a
man
.
<EOS>
Accused
of
robbing
a
live
man
!
"
said
Gaffer
,
with
great
indignation
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
if
I
had
been
accused
of
robbing
a
dead
man
,
Gaffer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
   
COULDN'T
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Could
n't
you
,
Gaffer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
Has
a
dead
man
any
use
for
money
?
<EOS>
Is
it
possible
for
a
dead
man
to
have
money
?
<EOS>
What
world
does
a
dead
man
belong
to
?
"
<EOS>
Tother
world
.
<EOS>
What
world
does
money
belong
to
?
<EOS>
This
world
.
<EOS>
How
can
money
be
a
corpse
's
?
<EOS>
Can
a
corpse
own
it
,
want
it
,
spend
it
,
claim
it
,
miss
it
?
<EOS>
Do
n't
try
to
go
confounding
the
rights
and
wrongs
of
things
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
worthy
of
the
sneaking
spirit
that
robs
a
live
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
---
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
you
wo
n't
.
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
.
<EOS>
You
've
got
off
with
a
short
time
of
it
for
putting
your
hand
in
the
pocket
of
a
sailor
,
a
live
sailor
.
<EOS>
Make
the
most
of
it
and
think
yourself
lucky
,
but
do
n't
think
after
that
to
come
over
me
with
your
pardners
.
<EOS>
We
have
worked
together
in
time
past
,
but
we
work
together
no
more
in
time
present
nor
yet
future
.
<EOS>
Let
go
.
<EOS>
Cast
off
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gaffer
!
<EOS>
If
you
think
to
get
rid
of
me
this
way
---
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
If
I
do
n't
get
rid
of
you
this
way
,
I
'll
try
another
,
and
chop
you
over
the
fingers
with
the
stretcher
,
or
take
a
pick
at
your
head
with
the
boat
-
hook
.
<EOS>
Cast
off
!
<EOS>
Pull
you
,
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
Pull
home
,
since
you
wo
n't
let
your
father
pull
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
shot
ahead
,
and
the
other
boat
fell
astern
.
<EOS>
Lizzie
's
father
,
composing
himself
into
the
easy
attitude
of
one
who
had
asserted
the
high
moralities
and
taken
an
unassailable
position
,
slowly
lighted
a
pipe
,
and
smoked
,
and
took
a
survey
of
what
he
had
in
tow
.
<EOS>
What
he
had
in
tow
,
lunged
itself
at
him
sometimes
in
an
awful
manner
when
the
boat
was
checked
,
and
sometimes
seemed
to
try
to
wrench
itself
away
,
though
for
the
most
part
it
followed
submissively
.
<EOS>
A
neophyte
might
have
fancied
that
the
ripples
passing
over
it
were
dreadfully
like
faint
changes
of
expression
on
a
sightless
face
;
but
Gaffer
was
no
neophyte
and
had
no
fancies
.
   
<EOS>
THE
MAN
FROM
SOMEWHERE
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
were
bran
-
new
people
in
a
bran
-
new
house
in
a
bran
-
new
quarter
of
London
.
<EOS>
Everything
about
the
Veneerings
was
spick
and
span
new
.
<EOS>
All
their
furniture
was
new
,
all
their
friends
were
new
,
all
their
servants
were
new
,
their
plate
was
new
,
their
carriage
was
new
,
their
harness
was
new
,
their
horses
were
new
,
their
pictures
were
new
,
they
themselves
were
new
,
they
were
as
newly
married
as
was
lawfully
compatible
with
their
having
a
bran
-
new
baby
,
and
if
they
had
set
up
a
great
-
grandfather
,
he
would
have
come
home
in
matting
from
the
Pantechnicon
,
without
a
scratch
upon
him
,
French
polished
to
the
crown
of
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
For
,
in
the
Veneering
establishment
,
from
the
hall
-
chairs
with
the
new
coat
of
arms
,
to
the
grand
pianoforte
with
the
new
action
,
and
upstairs
again
to
the
new
fire
-
escape
,
all
things
were
in
a
state
of
high
varnish
and
polish
.
<EOS>
And
what
was
observable
in
the
furniture
,
was
observable
in
the
Veneerings
---
the
surface
smelt
a
little
too
much
of
the
workshop
and
was
a
trifle
stickey
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
an
innocent
piece
of
dinner
-
furniture
that
went
upon
easy
castors
and
was
kept
over
a
livery
stable
-
yard
in
Duke
Street
,
Saint
James
's
,
when
not
in
use
,
to
whom
the
Veneerings
were
a
source
of
blind
confusion
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
this
article
was
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
Being
first
cousin
to
Lord
Snigsworth
,
he
was
in
frequent
requisition
,
and
at
many
houses
might
be
said
to
represent
the
dining
-
table
in
its
normal
state
.
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
,
for
example
,
arranging
a
dinner
,
habitually
started
with
Twemlow
,
and
then
put
leaves
in
him
,
or
added
guests
to
him
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
the
table
consisted
of
Twemlow
and
half
a
dozen
leaves
;
sometimes
,
of
Twemlow
and
a
dozen
leaves
;
sometimes
,
Twemlow
was
pulled
out
to
his
utmost
extent
of
twenty
leaves
.
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
on
occasions
of
ceremony
faced
each
other
in
the
centre
of
the
board
,
and
thus
the
parallel
still
held
;
for
,
it
always
happened
that
the
more
Twemlow
was
pulled
out
,
the
further
he
found
himself
from
the
centre
,
and
the
nearer
to
the
sideboard
at
one
end
of
the
room
,
or
the
window
-
curtains
at
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
it
was
not
this
which
steeped
the
feeble
soul
of
Twemlow
in
confusion
.
<EOS>
This
he
was
used
to
,
and
could
take
soundings
of
.
<EOS>
The
abyss
to
which
he
could
find
no
bottom
,
and
from
which
started
forth
the
engrossing
and
ever
-
swelling
difficulty
of
his
life
,
was
the
insoluble
question
whether
he
was
Veneering
's
oldest
friend
,
or
newest
friend
.
<EOS>
To
the
excogitation
of
this
problem
,
the
harmless
gentleman
had
devoted
many
anxious
hours
,
both
in
his
lodgings
over
the
livery
stable
-
yard
,
and
in
the
cold
gloom
,
favourable
to
meditation
,
of
Saint
James
's
Square
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
Twemlow
had
first
known
Veneering
at
his
club
,
where
Veneering
then
knew
nobody
but
the
man
who
made
them
known
to
one
another
,
who
seemed
to
be
the
most
intimate
friend
he
had
in
the
world
,
and
whom
he
had
known
two
days
---
the
bond
of
union
between
their
souls
,
the
nefarious
conduct
of
the
committee
respecting
the
cookery
of
a
fillet
of
veal
,
having
been
accidently
cemented
at
that
date
.
<EOS>
Immediately
upon
this
,
Twemlow
received
an
invitation
to
dine
with
Veneering
,
and
dined
:
the
man
being
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
Immediately
upon
that
,
Twemlow
received
an
invitation
to
dine
with
the
man
,
and
dined
:
<EOS>
Veneering
being
of
the
party
.
<EOS>
At
the
man
's
were
a
Member
,
an
Engineer
,
a
Payer
-
off
of
the
National
Debt
,
a
Poem
on
Shakespeare
,
a
Grievance
,
and
a
Public
Office
,
who
all
seemed
to
be
utter
strangers
to
Veneering
.
<EOS>
And
yet
immediately
after
that
,
Twemlow
received
an
invitation
to
dine
at
Veneerings
,
expressly
to
meet
the
Member
,
the
Engineer
,
the
Payer
-
off
of
the
National
Debt
,
the
Poem
on
Shakespeare
,
the
Grievance
,
and
the
Public
Office
,
and
,
dining
,
discovered
that
all
of
them
were
the
most
intimate
friends
Veneering
had
in
the
world
,
and
that
the
wives
of
all
of
them
(
who
were
all
there
)
were
the
objects
of
Mrs.
Veneering
's
most
devoted
affection
and
tender
confidence
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
it
had
come
about
,
that
Mr.
Twemlow
had
said
to
himself
in
his
lodgings
,
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
:
"
I
must
not
think
of
this
.
<EOS>
This
is
enough
to
soften
any
man
's
brain
.
"
<EOS>
---
and
yet
was
always
thinking
of
it
,
and
could
never
form
a
conclusion
.
  
<EOS>
This
evening
the
Veneerings
give
a
banquet
.
<EOS>
Eleven
leaves
in
the
Twemlow
;
fourteen
in
company
all
told
.
<EOS>
Four
pigeon
-
breasted
retainers
in
plain
clothes
stand
in
line
in
the
hall
.
<EOS>
A
fifth
retainer
,
proceeding
up
the
staircase
with
a
mournful
air
---
as
who
should
say
,
"
Here
is
another
wretched
creature
come
to
dinner
;
such
is
life
!
"
<EOS>
---
  
announces
,
"
Mits
-
ter
Twemlow
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
welcomes
her
sweet
Mr.
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Veneering
welcomes
his
dear
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
does
not
expect
that
Mr.
Twemlow
can
in
nature
care
much
for
such
insipid
things
as
babies
,
but
so
old
a
friend
must
please
to
look
at
baby
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
You
will
know
the
friend
of
your
family
better
,
Tootleums
,
"
says
Mr.
Veneering
,
nodding
emotionally
at
that
new
article
,
"
when
you
begin
to
take
notice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
then
begs
to
make
his
dear
Twemlow
known
to
his
two
friends
,
Mr.
Boots
and
Mr.
Brewer
---
and
clearly
has
no
distinct
idea
which
is
which
.
  
<EOS>
But
now
a
fearful
circumstance
occurs
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mis
-
ter
and
Mis
-
sis
Podsnap
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
says
Mr.
Veneering
to
Mrs.
Veneering
,
with
an
air
of
much
friendly
interest
,
while
the
door
stands
open
,
"
the
Podsnaps
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
too
,
too
smiling
large
man
,
with
a
fatal
freshness
on
him
,
appearing
with
his
wife
,
instantly
deserts
his
wife
and
darts
at
Twemlow
with
:
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
So
glad
to
know
you
.
<EOS>
Charming
house
you
have
here
.
<EOS>
I
hope
we
are
not
late
.
<EOS>
So
glad
of
this
opportunity
,
I
am
sure
!
"
  
<EOS>
When
the
first
shock
fell
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Twemlow
twice
skipped
back
in
his
neat
little
shoes
and
his
little
silk
stockings
of
a
bygone
fashion
,
as
if
impelled
to
leap
over
a
sofa
behind
him
;
but
the
large
man
closed
with
him
and
proved
too
strong
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
,
"
says
the
large
man
,
trying
to
attract
the
attention
of
his
wife
in
the
distance
,
"
have
the
pleasure
of
presenting
Mrs.
Podsnap
to
her
host
.
<EOS>
She
will
be
,
"
in
his
fatal
freshness
he
seems
to
find
perpetual
verdure
and
eternal
youth
in
the
phrase
,
"
she
will
be
so
glad
of
the
opportunity
,
I
am
sure
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
meantime
,
Mrs.
Podsnap
,
unable
to
originate
a
mistake
on
her
own
account
,
because
Mrs.
Veneering
is
the
only
other
lady
there
,
does
her
best
in
the
way
of
handsomely
supporting
her
husband
's
,
by
looking
towards
Mr.
Twemlow
with
a
plaintive
countenance
and
remarking
to
Mrs.
Veneering
in
a
feeling
manner
,
firstly
,
that
she
fears
he
has
been
rather
bilious
of
late
,
and
,
secondly
,
that
the
baby
is
already
very
like
him
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
questionable
whether
any
man
quite
relishes
being
mistaken
for
any
other
man
;
but
,
Mr.
Veneering
having
this
very
evening
set
up
the
shirt
-
front
of
the
young
Antinous
(
in
new
worked
cambric
just
come
home
)
,
is
not
at
all
complimented
by
being
supposed
to
be
Twemlow
,
who
is
dry
and
weazen
and
some
thirty
years
older
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
equally
resents
the
imputation
of
being
the
wife
of
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
As
to
Twemlow
,
he
is
so
sensible
of
being
a
much
better
bred
man
than
Veneering
,
that
he
considers
the
large
man
an
offensive
ass
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
complicated
dilemma
,
Mr.
Veneering
approaches
the
large
man
with
extended
hand
and
,
smilingly
assures
that
incorrigible
personage
that
he
is
delighted
to
see
him
:
who
in
his
fatal
freshness
instantly
replies
:
  
"
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
to
say
that
I
can
not
at
this
moment
recall
where
we
met
,
but
I
am
so
glad
of
this
opportunity
,
I
am
sure
!
"
  
<EOS>
Then
pouncing
upon
Twemlow
,
who
holds
back
with
all
his
feeble
might
,
he
is
haling
him
off
to
present
him
,
as
Veneering
,
to
Mrs.
Podsnap
,
when
the
arrival
of
more
guests
unravels
the
mistake
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
,
having
re
-
shaken
hands
with
Veneering
as
Veneering
,
he
re
-
shakes
hands
with
Twemlow
as
Twemlow
,
and
winds
it
all
up
to
his
own
perfect
satisfaction
by
saying
to
the
last
-
named
,
"
Ridiculous
opportunity
---
but
so
glad
of
it
,
I
am
sure
!
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,
Twemlow
having
undergone
this
terrific
experience
,
having
likewise
noted
the
fusion
of
Boots
in
Brewer
and
Brewer
in
Boots
,
and
having
further
observed
that
of
the
remaining
seven
guests
four
discreet
characters
enter
with
wandering
eyes
and
wholly
decline
to
commit
themselves
as
to
which
is
Veneering
,
until
Veneering
has
them
in
his
grasp
;
---
Twemlow
having
profited
by
these
studies
,
finds
his
brain
wholesomely
hardening
as
he
approaches
the
conclusion
that
he
really
is
Veneering
's
oldest
friend
,
when
his
brain
softens
again
and
all
is
lost
,
through
his
eyes
encountering
Veneering
and
the
large
man
linked
together
as
twin
brothers
in
the
back
drawing
-
room
near
the
conservatory
door
,
and
through
his
ears
informing
him
in
the
tones
of
Mrs.
Veneering
that
the
same
large
man
is
to
be
baby
's
godfather
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dinner
is
on
the
table
!
"
  
<EOS>
Thus
the
melancholy
retainer
,
as
who
should
say
,
"
Come
down
and
be
poisoned
,
ye
unhappy
children
of
men
!
"
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
,
having
no
lady
assigned
him
,
goes
down
in
the
rear
,
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
.
<EOS>
Boots
and
Brewer
,
thinking
him
indisposed
,
whisper
,
"
<EOS>
Man
faint
.
<EOS>
Had
no
lunch
.
<EOS>
"
But
he
is
only
stunned
by
the
unvanquishable
difficulty
of
his
existence
.
  
<EOS>
Revived
by
soup
,
Twemlow
discourses
mildly
of
the
Court
Circular
with
Boots
and
Brewer
.
<EOS>
Is
appealed
to
,
at
the
fish
stage
of
the
banquet
,
by
Veneering
,
on
the
disputed
question
whether
his
cousin
Lord
Snigsworth
is
in
or
out
of
town
?
<EOS>
Gives
it
that
his
cousin
is
out
of
town
.
"
<EOS>
At
Snigsworthy
Park
?
"
Veneering
inquires
.
"
At
Snigsworthy
,
"
Twemlow
rejoins
.
<EOS>
Boots
and
Brewer
regard
this
as
a
man
to
be
cultivated
;
and
Veneering
is
clear
that
he
is
a
remunerative
article
.
<EOS>
Meantime
the
retainer
goes
round
,
like
a
gloomy
Analytical
Chemist
:
always
seeming
to
say
,
after
"
Chablis
,
sir
?
"
  
---
"
You
would
n't
if
you
knew
what
it
's
made
of
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
great
looking
-
glass
above
the
sideboard
,
reflects
the
table
and
the
company
.
<EOS>
Reflects
the
new
Veneering
crest
,
in
gold
and
eke
in
silver
,
frosted
and
also
thawed
,
a
camel
of
all
work
.
<EOS>
The
Heralds
'
College
found
out
a
Crusading
ancestor
for
Veneering
who
bore
a
camel
on
his
shield
(
or
might
have
done
it
if
he
had
thought
of
it
)
,
and
a
caravan
of
camels
take
charge
of
the
fruits
and
flowers
and
candles
,
and
kneel
down
to
be
loaded
with
the
salt
.
<EOS>
Reflects
Veneering
;
 
forty
,
wavy
-
haired
,
dark
,
tending
to
corpulence
,
sly
,
mysterious
,
filmy
---
a
kind
of
sufficiently
well
-
looking
veiled
-
prophet
,
not
prophesying
.
<EOS>
Reflects
Mrs.
Veneering
;
<EOS>
fair
,
aquiline
-
nosed
and
fingered
,
not
so
much
light
hair
as
she
might
have
,
gorgeous
in
raiment
and
jewels
,
enthusiastic
,
propitiatory
,
conscious
that
a
corner
of
her
husband
's
veil
is
over
herself

man
from
Somewhere
.
<EOS>
Being
a
boy
of
fourteen
,
cheaply
educating
at
Brussels
when
his
sister
's
expulsion
befell
,
it
was
some
little
time
before
he
heard
of
it
---
probably
from
herself
,
for
the
mother
was
dead
;
but
that
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
Instantly
,
he
absconded
,
and
came
over
here
.
<EOS>
He
must
have
been
a
boy
of
spirit
and
resource
,
to
get
here
on
a
stopped
allowance
of
five
sous
a
week
;
 
but
he
did
it
somehow
,
and
he
burst
in
on
his
father
,
and
pleaded
his
sister
's
cause
.
<EOS>
Venerable
parent
promptly
resorts
to
anathematization
,
and
turns
him
out
.
<EOS>
Shocked
and
terrified
boy
takes
flight
,
seeks
his
fortune
,
gets
aboard
ship
,
ultimately
turns
up
on
dry
land
among
the
Cape
wine
:
small
proprietor
,
farmer
,
grower
---
whatever
you
like
to
call
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
juncture
,
shuffling
is
heard
in
the
hall
,
and
tapping
is
heard
at
the
dining
-
room
door
.
<EOS>
Analytical
Chemist
goes
to
the
door
,
confers
angrily
with
unseen
tapper
,
appears
to
become
mollified
by
descrying
reason
in
the
tapping
,
and
goes
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
he
was
discovered
,
only
the
other
day
,
after
having
been
expatriated
about
fourteen
years
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
Buffer
,
suddenly
astounding
the
other
three
,
by
detaching
himself
,
and
asserting
individuality
,
inquires
:
"
How
discovered
,
and
why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
To
be
sure
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
for
reminding
me
.
<EOS>
Venerable
parent
dies
.
"
  
<EOS>
Same
Buffer
,
emboldened
by
success
,
says
:
"
When
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
other
day
.
<EOS>
Ten
or
twelve
months
ago
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Same
Buffer
inquires
with
smartness
,
"
What
of
?
"
<EOS>
But
herein
perishes
a
melancholy
example
;
being
regarded
by
the
three
other
Buffers
with
a
stony
stare
,
and
attracting
no
further
attention
from
any
mortal
.
  
<EOS>
"
Venerable
parent
,
"
Mortimer
repeats
with
a
passing
remembrance
that
there
is
a
Veneering
at
table
,
and
for
the
first
time
addressing
him
---
"
dies
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
gratified
Veneering
repeats
,
gravely
,
"
dies
;
"
and
folds
his
arms
,
and
composes
his
brow
to
hear
it
out
in
a
judicial
manner
,
when
he
finds
himself
again
deserted
in
the
bleak
world
.
  
<EOS>
"
His
will
is
found
,
"
says
Mortimer
,
catching
Mrs.
Podsnap
's
rocking
-
horse
's
eye
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
dated
very
soon
after
the
son
's
flight
.
<EOS>
It
leaves
the
lowest
of
the
range
of
dust
-
mountains
,
with
some
sort
of
a
dwelling
-
house
at
its
foot
,
to
an
old
servant
who
is
sole
executor
,
and
all
the
rest
of
the
property
---
which
is
very
considerable
---
to
the
son
.
<EOS>
He
directs
himself
to
be
buried
with
certain
eccentric
ceremonies
and
precautions
against
his
coming
to
life
,
with
which
I
need
not
bore
you
,
and
that
's
all
---
except
---
"
and
this
ends
the
story
.
  
<EOS>
The
Analytical
Chemist
returning
,
everybody
looks
at
him
.
<EOS>
Not
because
anybody
wants
to
see
him
,
but
because
of
that
subtle
influence
in
nature
which
impels
humanity
to
embrace
the
slightest
opportunity
of
looking
at
anything
,
rather
than
the
person
who
address
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
Except
that
the
son
's
inheriting
is
made
conditional
on
his
marrying
a
girl
,
who
at
the
date
of
the
will
,
was
a
child
of
four
or
five
years
old
,
and
who
is
now
a
marriageable
young
woman
.
<EOS>
Advertisement
and
inquiry
discovered
the
son
in
the
man
from
Somewhere
,
and
at
the
present
moment
,
he
is
on
his
way
home
from
there
 
---
no
doubt
,
in
a
state
of
great
astonishment
---
to
succeed
to
a
very
large
fortune
,
and
to
take
a
wife
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Podsnap
inquires
whether
the
young
person
is
a
young
person
of
personal
charms
?
<EOS>
Mortimer
is
unable
to
report
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
inquires
what
would
become
of
the
very
large
fortune
,
in
the
event
of
the
marriage
condition
not
being
fulfilled
?
<EOS>
Mortimer
replies
,
that
by
special
testamentary
clause
it
would
then
go
to
the
old
servant
above
mentioned
,
passing
over
and
excluding
the
son
;
also
,
that
if
the
son
had
not
been
living
,
the
same
old
servant
would
have
been
sole
residuary
legatee
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
has
just
succeeded
in
waking
Lady
Tippins
from
a
snore
,
by
dexterously
shunting
a
train
of
plates
and
dishes
at
her
knuckles
across
the
table
;
when
everybody
but
Mortimer
himself
becomes
aware
that
the
Analytical
Chemist
is
,
in
a
ghostly
manner
,
offering
him
a
folded
paper
.
<EOS>
Curiosity
detains
Mrs.
Veneering
a
few
moments
.
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
,
in
spite
of
all
the
arts
of
the
chemist
,
placidly
refreshes
himself
with
a
glass
of
Madeira
,
and
remains
unconscious
of
the
document
which
engrosses
the
general
attention
,
until
Lady
Tippins
(
who
has
a
habit
of
waking
totally

)
,
having
remembered

is
,
and
recovered

,

:
"
Falser
man
than
Don
Juan
<EOS>
;
why
do

you
take
the
note
from
the
Commendatore
?
"
<EOS>
Upon

,
the

advances

under

of
Mortimer
,
who

,
and

:
  
"
What
's
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
Analytical
Chemist
bends
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"
says
Mortimer
.
  
<EOS>
Analytical
Chemist
again

and

.
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
stares
at
him
,
and
unfolds

paper
.
<EOS>
Reads
it
,
reads
it
twice
,
<EOS>
turns

over
to
look
at

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
This
arrives
in
an

,
"
says
Mortimer

,

round

:
"
this

of
the
story
of
the
identical

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Already
married
?
<EOS>
"
one

.
  
<EOS>
"
Declines
to

?
"
<EOS>
another

.
  
<EOS>
"
Codicil
among
the
dust
?
"
<EOS>
another

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,
"

;
"
remarkable

,
you
are

.
<EOS>
The
story
is
completer
and
rather
more

than
I
supposed
.
<EOS>
Man
's
drowned
!
"
   
<EOS>
ANOTHER
MAN
.
 
<EOS>
As
the
disappearing
skirts
of
the
ladies
ascended
the
Veneering
stair
-
case
,
Mortimer
,
following
them
forth
from
the
dining
-
room
,
turned
into
a
library
of
bran
-
new
books
,
in
bran
-
new
bindings
liberally
gilded
,
and
requested
to
see
the
messenger
who
had
brought
the
paper
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
boy
of
about
fifteen
.
<EOS>
Mortimer
looked
at
the
boy
,
and
the
boy
looked
at
the
bran
-
new
pilgrims
on
the
wall
,
going
to
Canterbury
in
more
gold
frame
than
procession
,
and
more
carving
than
country
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whose
writing
is
this
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mine
,
sir
,
"
  
"
Who
told
you
to
write

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
father
,
Jesse
Hexam
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

he
who
found
the
body
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
your
father
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy

,

as

in

,

,

,
"
He
gets
his

along

shore
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

far
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
which
far
?
;
asked
the
boy
,
upon

guard
,
and
again
upon

road
to
Canterbury
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
your
father
's
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
goodish
stretch
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
come
up
in
a
cab
,
and
the
cab
's
waiting
to
be
paid
.
<EOS>
We
could
go
back
in
it
before
you
paid

,

.
<EOS>
I
went
first
to
your
office
,
according

of
the
papers
found
in
the

,
and
there
I
see
nobody
but
a
chap
of
about
my
age
who
sent

on
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
curious
mixture
in
the
boy
,
of
uncompleted
savagery
,
and
uncompleted
civilization
.
<EOS>
His
voice
was
hoarse
and
coarse
,
and
his
face
was
coarse
,
and
his
stunted
figure
was
coarse
;
but
he
was
cleaner
than
other
boys
of
his
type
;
and
his
writing
,
though
large
and
round
,
was
good
;
and
he
glanced
at
the
backs
of
the
books
,
with
an
awakened
curiosity
that
went
below
the
binding
.
<EOS>
No
one
who
can
read
,
ever
looks
at
a
book
,
even
unopened
on
a
shelf
,
like
one
who
can
not
.
  
<EOS>
"
Were
any

taken
,

,
boy
,

it
was
possible

restore
life
?
"
<EOS>
Mortimer

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
n't

,

.
<EOS>
Pharaoh
's

that

,
ai

.

,

.

"

Halloa

"
  
<EOS>
"
Read

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

"
  
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
"
She
ai

,

<EOS>
them

.

<EOS>
The

Eugene
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

'm

,

!
"

,

<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Eugene

;

,

<EOS>

,

"

been
loudly
,
while
they
looked
at
the
silent
sight
they
came
to
see
---
and
there
through
the
merits
of
the
case
as
summed
up
by
the
Abbot
.
<EOS>
No
clue
to
how
body
came
into
river
.
<EOS>
Very
often
was
no
clue
.
<EOS>
Too
late
to
know
for
certain
,
whether
injuries
received
before

death
;
one

opinion
said
,
before
;
other
excellent
surgical
opinion
said
,
after
.
<EOS>
Steward
of
ship
in
which

,
had

round

,
and

identity
.
<EOS>
Likewise

clothes
.
<EOS>
And

,
you

,
you
had

,

.
<EOS>
How

had

on

ship
,
'

in

?
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Probably

upon

.
<EOS>
Probably

a

,

.
<EOS>
Inquest

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

---

,
"

Inspector

<EOS>

It

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

.

Mr.

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
  
<EOS>

,
could
n't

.
<EOS>
If
a
murder
,
anybody

.
<EOS>
Burglary
or
pocket

picking
wanted
'

.
<EOS>
Not

,
murder
.
<EOS>
We
were
all

up

.
<EOS>
Had

,

.
<EOS>
Might

,

Stomach

.
<EOS>
If

,
rum

.
<EOS>
But

rum

.
<EOS>
Pity

;

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
girl

,

her

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

you
and
me
,
Charley
,
when
father
was
away
at
work
and
locked
us
out
,
for
fear

should

or
fall
out
of
window
,
sitting

the
door
-
sill
,
sitting
on
other
door
-
steps
,
sitting

of

river
,
wandering
about
to

through

.
<EOS>
You
are
rather
heavy
to
carry
,
Charley
,
and
I
am
often
obliged
to
rest
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
we
are
sleepy
and
fall
asleep
together
in
a
corner
,
sometimes
we
are
very
hungry
,
sometimes
we
are
a
little
frightened
,
but
what
is
oftenest
hard
upon
us
is
the
cold
.
<EOS>
You
remember
,
Charley
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
remember
,
"
said
the
boy
,
pressing
her
to
him
twice
or
thrice
,
"
that
I
snuggled
under
a
little
shawl
,
and
it
was
warm
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
it
rains
,
and
we
creep
under
a
boat
or
the
like
of
that
:
sometimes
it
's
dark
,
and
we
get
among
the
gaslights
,
sitting
watching
the
people
as
they
go
along
the
streets
.
<EOS>
At
last
,
up
comes
father
and
takes
us
home
.
<EOS>
And
home
seems
such
a
shelter
after
out
of
doors
!
<EOS>
And
father
pull
my
shoes
off
,
and
dries
my
feet
at
the
fire
,
and
has
me
to
sit
by
him
while
he
smokes
his
pipe
long
after
you
are
abed
,
and
I
notice
that
father
's
is
a
large
hand
but
never
a
heavy
one
when
it
touches
me
,
and
that
father
's
is
a
rough
voice
but
never
an
angry
one
when
it
speaks
to
me
.
<EOS>
So
,
I
grow
up
,
and
little
by
little
father
trusts
me
,
and
makes
me
his
companion
,
and
,
let
him
be
put
out
as
he
may
,
never
once
strikes
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
listening
boy
gave
a
grunt
here
,
as
much
as
to
say
"
But
he
strikes
me
though
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Those
are
some
of
the
pictures
of
what
is
past
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Cut
away
again
,
"
said
the
boy
,
"
and
give
us
a
fortune
-
telling
one
;
a
future
one
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
There
am
I
,
continuing
with
father
and
holding
to
father
,
because
father
loves
me
and
I
love
father
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
so
much
as
read
a
book
,
because
if
I
had
learned
,
father
would
have
thought
I
was
deserting
him
,
and
I
should
have
lost
my
influence
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
the
influence
I
want
to
have
,
I
can
not
stop
some
dreadful
things
I
try
to
stop
,
but
I
go
on
in
the
hope
and
trust
that
the
time
will
come
.
<EOS>
In
the
meanwhile
I
know
that
I
am
in
some
things
a
stay
to
father
,
and
that
if
I
was
not
faithful
to
him
he
would
---
in
revenge
-
like
,
or
in
disappointment
,
or
both
---
go
wild
and
bad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
us
a
touch
of
the
fortune
-
telling
pictures
about
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
passing
on
to
them
Charley
,
"
said
the
girl
,
who
had
not
changed
her
attitude
since
she
began
,
and
who
now
mournfully
shook
her
head
;
"
the
others
were
all
leading
up
.
<EOS>
There
are
you
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Where
am
I
,
Liz
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Still
in
the
hollow
down
by
the
flare
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
seems
to
be
the
deuce
-
and
-
all
in
the
hollow
down
by
the
flare
,
"
said
the
boy
,
glancing
from
her
eyes
to
the
brazier
,
which
had
a
grisly
skeleton
look
on
its
long
thin
legs
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
are
you
,
Charley
,
working
your
way
,
in
secret
from
father
,
at
the
school
;
and
you
get
prizes
;
and
you
go
on
better
and
better
;
 
and
you
come
to
be
a
<EOS>
---
what
was
it
<EOS>
you
called
it
when
you
told
me
about
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
Fortune
-
telling
not
know
the
name
!
"
<EOS>
cried
the
boy
,
seeming
to
be
rather
relieved
by
this
default
on
the
part
of
the
hollow
down
by
the
flare
.
<EOS>
"
Pupil
-
teacher
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
come
to
be
a
pupil
-
teacher
,
and
you
still
go
on
better
and
better
,
and
you
rise
to
be
a
master
full
of
learning
and
respect
.
<EOS>
But
the
secret
has
come
to
father
's
knowledge
long
before
,
and
it
has
divided
you
from
father
,
and
from
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
it
has
n't
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
it
has
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
I
see
,
as
plain
as
plain
can
be
,
that
your
way
is
not
ours
,
and
that
even
if
father
could
be
got
to
forgive
your
taking
it
(
which
he
never
could
be
)
,
that
way
of
yours
would
be
darkened
by
our
way
.
<EOS>
But
I
see
too
,
Charley
---
"
  
"
Still
as
plain
as
plain
can
be
,
Liz
?
"
asked
the
boy
playfully
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Still
.
<EOS>
That
it
is
a
great
work
to
have
cut
you
away
from
father
's
life
,
and
to
have
made
a
new
and
good
beginning
.
<EOS>
So
there
and
I
,
Charley
,
left
alone
with
father
,
keeping
him
as
straight
as
I
can
,
watching
for
more
influence
than
I
have
,
and
hoping
that
through
some
fortunate
chance
,
or
when
he
is
ill
,
or
when
---
I
do
n't
know
what
---
I
may
turn
him
to
wish
to
do
better
things
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
said
you
could
n't
read
a
book
,
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
Your
library
of
books
is
the
hollow
down
by
the
flare
,
I
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
very
glad
to
be
able
to
read
real
books
.
<EOS>
I
feel
my
want
of
learning
very
much
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
But
I
should
feel
it
much
more
,
if
I
did
n't
know
it
to
be
a
tie
between
me
and
father
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Hark
!
<EOS>
Father
's
tread
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
being
now
past
midnight
,
the
bird
of
prey
went
straight
to
roost
.
<EOS>
At
mid
-
day
following
he
reappeared
at
the
Six
Jolly
Fellowship
-
Porters
,
in
the
character
,
not
new
to
him
,
of
a
witness
before
a
Coroner
's
Jury
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
,
besides
sustaining
the
character
of
one
of
the
witnesses
,
doubled
the
part
with
that
of
the
eminent
solicitor
who
watched
the
proceedings
on
behalf
of
the
representatives
of
the
deceased
,
as
was
duly
recorded
in
the
newspapers
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
watched
the
proceedings
too
,
and
kept
his
watching
closely
to
himself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Julius
Handford
having
given
his
right
address
,
and
being
reported
in
solvent
circumstances
as
to
his
bill
,
though
nothing
more
was
known
of
him
at
his
hotel
except
that
his
way
of
life
was
very
retired
,
had
no
summons
to
appear
,
and
was
merely
present
in
the
shades
of
Mr.
Inspector
's
mind
.
  
<EOS>
The
case
was
made
interesting
to
the
public
,
by
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
's
evidence
touching
the
circumstances
under
which
the
deceased
,
Mr.
John
Harmon
,
had
returned
to
England
;
exclusive
private
proprietorship
in
which
circumstances
was
set
up
at
dinner
-
tables
for
several
days
,
by
Veneering
,
Twemlow
,
Podsnap
,
and
all
the
Buffers
:
who
all
related
them
irreconcilably
with
one
another
,
and
contradicted
themselves
.
<EOS>
It
was
also
made
interesting
by
the
testimony
of
Job
Potterson
,
the
ship
's
steward
,
and
one
Mr.
Jacob
Kibble
,
a
fellow
-
passenger
,
that
the
deceased
Mr.
John
Harmon
did
bring
over
,
in
a
hand
-
valise
with
which
he
did
disembark
,
the
sum
realized
by
the
forced
sale
of
his
little
landed
property
,
and
that
the
sum
exceeded
,
in
ready
money
,
seven
hundred
pounds
.
<EOS>
It
was
further
made
interesting
,
by
the
remarkable
experiences
of
Jesse
Hexam
in
having
rescued
from
the
Thames
so
many
dead
bodies
,
and
for
whose
behoof
a
rapturous
admirer
subscribing
himself
<EOS>
"
A
friend
to
Burial
"
(
perhaps
an
undertaker
)
,
sent
eighteen
postage
stamps
,
and
five
"
Now
Sir"s
to
the
editor
of
the
Times
.
  
<EOS>
Upon
the
evidence
adduced
before
them
,
the
Jury
found
,
That
the
body
of
Mr.
John
Harmon
had
been
discovered
floating
in
the
Thames
,
in
an
advanced
state
of
decay
,
and
much
injured
;
and
that
the
said
Mr.
John
Harmon
had
come
by
his
death
under
highly
suspicious
circumstances
,
though
by
whose
act
or
in
what
precise
manner
there
was
no
evidence
before
this
Jury
to
show
.
<EOS>
And
they
appended
to
their
verdict
,
a
recommendation
to
the
Home
Office
(
which
Mr.
Inspector
appeared
to
think
highly
sensible
)
,
to
offer
a
reward
for
the
solution
of
the
mystery
.
<EOS>
Within
eight
-
and
-
forty
hours
,
a
reward
of
One
Hundred
Pounds
was
proclaimed
,
together
with
a
free
pardon
to
any
person
or
persons
not
the
actual
perpetrator
or
perpetrators
,
and
so
forth
in
due
form
.
  
<EOS>
This
Proclamation
rendered
Mr.
Inspector
additionally
studious
,
and
caused
him
to
stand
meditating
on
river
-
stairs
and
causeways
,
and
to
go
lurking
about
in
boats
,
putting
this
and
that
together
.
<EOS>
But
,
according
to
the
success
with
which
you
put
this
and
that
together
,
you
get
a
woman
and
a
fish
apart
,
or
a
Mermaid
in
combination
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Inspector
could
turn
out
nothing
better
than
a
Mermaid
,
which
no
Judge
and
Jury
would
believe
in
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
,
like
the
tides
on
which
it
had
been
borne
to
the
knowledge
of
men
,
the
Harmon
Murder
---
as
it
came
to
be
popularly
called
---
  
went
up
and
down
,
and
ebbed
and
flowed
,
now
in
the
town
,
now
in
the
country
,
now
among
palaces
,
now
among
hovels
,
now
among
lords
and
ladies
and
gentlefolks
,
now
among
labourers
and
hammerers
and
ballast
-
heavers
,
until
at
last
,
after
a
long
interval
of
slack
water
it
got
out
to
sea
and
drifted
away
.
   
<EOS>
THE
R.
WILFER
FAMILY
.
 
<EOS>
Reginald
Wilfer
is
a
name
with
rather
a
grand
sound
,
suggesting
on
first
acquaintance
brasses
in
country
churches
,
scrolls
in
stained
-
glass
windows
,
and
generally
the
De
Wilfers
who
came
over
with
the
Conqueror
.
<EOS>
For
,
it
is
a
remarkable
fact
in
genealogy
that
no
<EOS>
De
Any
ones
ever
came
over
with
Anybody
else
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
the
Reginald
Wilfer
family
were
of
such
commonplace
extraction
and
pursuits
that
their
forefathers
had
for
generations
modestly
subsisted
on
the
Docks
,
the
Excise
Office
,
and
the
Custom
House
,
and
the
existing
R.
Wilfer
was
a
poor
clerk
.
<EOS>
So
poor
a
clerk
,
though
having
a
limited
salary
and
an
unlimited
family
,
that
he
had
never
yet
attained
the
modest
object
of
his
ambition
:
which
was
,
to
wear
a
complete
new
suit
of
clothes
,
hat
and
boots
included
,
at
one
time
.
<EOS>
His
black
hat
was
brown
before
he
could
afford
a
coat
,
his
pantaloons
were
white
at
the
seams
and
knew
before
he
could
buy
a
pair
of
boots
,
his
boots
had
worn
out
before
he
could
treat
himself
to
new
pantaloons
,
and
,
by
the
time
he
worked
round
to
the
hat
again
,
that
shining
modern
article
roofed
-
in
an
ancient
ruin
of
various
periods
.
  
<EOS>
If
the
conventional
Cherub
could
ever
grow
up
and
be
clothed
,
he
might
be
photographed
as
a
portrait
of
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
His
chubby
,
smooth
,
innocent
appearance
was
a
reason
for
his
being
always
treated
with
condescension
when
he
was
not
put
down
.
<EOS>
A
stranger
entering
his
own
poor
house
at
about
ten
o'clock
P.M.
might
have
been
surprised
to
find
him
sitting
up
to
supper
.
<EOS>
So
boyish
was
he
in
his
curves
and
proportions
,
that
his
old
schoolmaster
meeting
him
in
Cheapside
,
might
have
been
unable
to
withstand
the
temptation
of
caning
him
on
the
spot
.
<EOS>
In
shot
,
he
was
the
conventional
cherub
,
after
the
supposititious
shoot
just
mentioned
,
rather
grey
,
with
signs
of
care
on
his
expression
,
and
in
decidedly
insolvent
circumstances
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
shy
,
and
unwilling
to
own
to
the
name
of
Reginald
,
as
being
too
aspiring
and
self
-
assertive
a
name
.
<EOS>
In
his
signature
he
used
only
the
initial
R.
,
and
imparted
what
it
really
stood
for
,
to
none
but
chosen
friends
,
under
the
seal
of
confidence
.
<EOS>
Out
of
this
,
the
facetious
habit
had
arisen
in
the
neighbourhood
surrounding
Mincing
Lane
of
making
christian
names
for
him
of
adjectives
and
participles
beginning
with
<EOS>
R.
Some
of
these
were
more
or
less
appropriate
:
as
Rusty
,
Retiring
,
Ruddy
,
Round
,
Ripe
,
Ridiculous
,
Ruminative
;
others
,
derived
their
point
from
their
want
of
application
:
as
Raging
,
Rattling
,
Roaring
,
Raffish
.
<EOS>
But
,
his
popular
name
was
Rumty
,
which
in
a
moment
of
inspiration
had
been
bestowed
upon
him
by
a
gentleman
of
convivial
habits
connected
with
the
drug
-
market
,
as
the
beginning
of
a
social
chorus
,
his
leading
part
in
the
execution
of
which
had
led
this
gentleman
to
the
Temple
of
Fame
,
and
of
which
the
whole
expressive
burden
ran
:
   
"
Rumty
iddity
,
row
dow
dow
,
  
Sing
toodlely
,
teedlely
,
bow
wow
wow
.
<EOS>
"
Thus
he
was
constantly
addressed
,
even
in
minor
notes
on
business
,
as
"
Dear
Rumty
;
"
in
answer
to
which
,
he
sedately
signed
himself
,
"
Yours
truly
,
R.
Wilfer
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
clerk
in
the
drug
-
house
of
Chicksey
,
Veneering
,
and
Stobbles
.
<EOS>
Chickesey
and
Stobbles
,
his
former
masters
,
had
both
become
absorbed
in
Veneering
,
once
their
traveller
or
commission
agent
:
who
had
signalized
his
accession
to
supreme
power
by
bringing
into
the
business
a
quantity
of
plate
-
glass
window
and
French
-
polished
mahogany
partition
,
and
a
gleaming
and
enormous
door
-
plate
.
  
<EOS>
R.
Wilfer
locked
up
his
desk
one
evening
,
and
,
putting
his
bunch
of
keys
in
his
pocket
much
as
if
it
were
his
peg
-
top
,
made
for
home
.
<EOS>
His
home
was
in
the
Holloway
region
north
of
London
,
and
then
divided
from
it
by
fields
and
trees
.
<EOS>
Between
Battle
Bridge
and
that
part
of
the
Holloway
district
in
which
he
dwelt
,
was
a
tract
of
suburban
Sahara
,
where
tiles
and
bricks
were
burnt
,
bones
were
boiled
,
carpets
were
beat
,
rubbish
was
shot
,
dogs
were
fought
,
and
dust
was
heaped
by
contractors
.
<EOS>
Skirting
the
border
of
this
desert
,
by
the
way
he
took
,
when
the
light
of
its
kiln
-
fires
made
lurid
smears
on
the
fog
,
R.
Wilfer
sighed
and
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
me
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
"
what
might

<EOS>

kind

a
widow
,
and
never
having
been
married
!
<EOS>
And
the
idea
of
being
as
poor
as
ever
after
all
,
and
going
into
black
,
besides
,
for
a
man
I
never
saw
,
and
should
have
hated
---
as
far
as
he
.
<EOS>
was
concerned
---
if
I
had
seen
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
young
lady
's
lamentations
were
checked
at
this
point
by
a
knuckle
,
knocking
at
the
half
-
open
door
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
The
knuckle
had
knocked
two
or
three
times
already
,
but
had
not
been
heard
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
?
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
in
her
Act
-
of
-
Parliament
manner
.
<EOS>
"
Enter
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
gentleman
coming
in
,
Miss
Bella
,
with
a
short
and
sharp
exclamation
,
scrambled
off
the
hearth
-
rug
and
massed
the
bitten
curls
together
in
their
right
place
on
her
neck
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
servant
girl
had
her
key
in
the
door
as
I
came
up
,
and
directed
me
to
this
room
telling
me
I
was
expected
.
<EOS>
I
am
afraid
I
should
have
asked
her
to
announce
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Wifler
.
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
.
<EOS>
Two
of
my
daughters
.
<EOS>
R.
W.
this
is
the
gentleman
who
has
taken
your
first
-
floor
,
He
was
so
good
as
to
make
an
appointment
for
to
-
night
,
when
you
would
be
at
home
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
dark
gentleman
.
<EOS>
Thirty
at
the
utmost
.
<EOS>
An
expressive
,
one
might
say
handsome
,
face
.
<EOS>
A
very
bad
manner
.
<EOS>
In
the
last
degree
constrained
,
reserved
,
diffident
,
troubled
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
were
on
Miss
Bella
for
an
instant
,
and
then
looked
at
the
ground
as
he
addressed
the
master
of
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
Seeing
that
I
am
quite
satisfied
,
Mr.
Wilfer
,
with
the
rooms
,
and
with
their
situation
,
and
with
their
price
<EOS>
,
I
suppose
a
memorandum
between
us
of
two
or
three
lines
,
and
a
payment
down
,
will
bind
the
bargain
?
<EOS>
I
wish
to
send
in
furniture
without
delay
.
"
  
<EOS>
Two
or
three
times
during
this
short
address
,
the
cherub
addressed
had
made
chubby
motions
towards
a
chair
.
<EOS>
The
gentleman
now
took
it
,
laying
a
hesitating
hand
on
a
corner
of
the
table
,
and
with
another
hesitating
hand
lifting
the
crown
of
his
hat
to
his
lips
,
and
drawing
it
before
his
mouth
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman
,
R.
W.
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
"
proposes
to
take
your
apartments
by
the
quarter
.
<EOS>
A
quarter
's
notice
on
either
side
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
mention
,
sir
,
"
insinuated
the
landlord
,
expecting
it
to
be
received
as
a
matter
of
course
,
"
the
form
of
a
reference
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
returned
the
gentleman
,
after
a
pause
,
"
that
a
reference
is
not
necessary
;
neither
,
to
say
the
truth
,
is
it
convenient
,
for
I
am
a
stranger
in
London
.
<EOS>
I
require
no
reference
from
you
,
and
perhaps
,
therefore
,
you
will
require
none
from
me
.
<EOS>
That
will
be
fair
on
both
sides
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I
show
the
greater
confidence
of
the
two
,
for
I
will
pay
in
advance
<EOS>
whatever
you
please
,
and
I
am
going
to
trust
my
furniture
here
.
<EOS>
Whereas
,
if
you
were
in
embarrassed
circumstances
 
---
this
is
merely
supposititious
---
"
  
Conscience
causing
R.
Wilfer
to
colour
,
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
from
a
corner
<EOS>
(
she
always
got
into
stately
corners
)
came
to
the
rescue
with
a
deeptoned
"
Per
-
fectly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
---
Why
then
I
---
might
lose
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
observed
R.
Wilfer
,
cheerfully
,
"
money
and
goods
are
certainly
the
best
of
references
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
think
they
are
the
best
,
pa
?
"
asked
Miss
Bella
,
in
a
low
voice
,
and
without
looking
over
her
shoulder
as
she
warmed
her
foot
on
the
fender
.
  
<EOS>
"
Among
the
best
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
thought
,
myself
,
it
was
so
easy
to
add
the
usual
kind
of
one
,
"
said
Bella
,
with
a
toss
of
her
curls
.
  
<EOS>
The
gentleman
listened
to
her
,
with
a
face
of
marked
attention
,
though
he
neither
looked
up
nor
changed
his
attitude
.
<EOS>
He
sat
,
still
and
silent
,
until
his
future
landlord
accepted
his
proposals
,
and
brought
writing
materials
to
complete
the
business
.
<EOS>
He
sat
,
still
and
silent
,
while
the
landlord
wrote
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
agreement
was
ready
in
duplicate
(
the
landlord
having
worked
at
it
like
some
cherubic
scribe
,
in
what
is
conventionally
called
a
doubtful
,
which
means
a
not
at
all
doubtful
,
Old
Master
)
,
it
was
signed
by
the
contracting
parties
,
Bella
looking
on
as
scornful
witness
.
<EOS>
The
contracting
parties
were
R.
Wilfer
,
and
John
Rokesmith
Esquire
.
  
<EOS>
When
it
came
to
Bella
's
turn
to
sign
her
name
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
who
was
standing
,
as
he
had
sat
,
with
a
hesitating
hand
upon
the
table
,
looked
at
her
stealthily
,
but
narrowly
.
<EOS>
He
looked
at
the
pretty
figure
bending
down
over
the
paper
and
saying
,
"
Where
am
I
to
go
,
pa
?
<EOS>
Here
,
in
this
corner
?
"
He
looked
at
the
beautiful
brown
hair
,
shading
the
coquettish
face
;
he
looked
at
the
free
dash
of
the
signature
,
which
was
a
bold
one
for
a
woman
's
;
and
then
they
looked
at
one
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
Much
obliged
to
you
,
Miss
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Obliged
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
given
you
so
much
trouble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Signing
my
name
?
<EOS>
Yes
,
certainly
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
your
landlord
's
daughter
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
there
was
nothing
more
to
do
but
pay
eight
sovereigns
in
earnest
of
the
bargain
,
pocket
the
agreement
,
appoint
a
time
for
the
arrival
of
his

and

,

,
Mr.
Rokesmith
did
that
as
awkwardly
as
it
might
be
done
,
and
was
escorted
by
his
landlord
to
the
outer
air
.
<EOS>
When
R.
Wilfer
returned
,
candlestick
in
hand
,
to
the
bosom
of
his
family
,
he
found
the
bosom
agitated
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pa
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
we
have
got
a
Murderer
for
a
tenant
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pa
,
"
said
Lavinia
,
"
we
have
got
a
Robber
,
"
  
"
To
see
him
unable
for
his
life
to
look
anybody
in
the
face
!
"
said
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
There
never
was
such
an
exhibition
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dears
,
"
said
their
father
,
"
he
is
a
diffident
gentleman
,
and
I
should
say
particularly
so
in
the
society
of
girls
of
your
age
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
,
our
age
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Bella
,
impatiently
,
"
What
's
that
got
to
do
with
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Besides
,
we
are
not
of
the
same
age
:
---
which
age
?
"
demanded
Lavinia
.
  
<EOS>
"
Never
you
mind
,
Lavvy
,
"
retorted
Bella
;
"
you
wait
till
you
are
of
an
age
to
ask
such
questions
.
<EOS>
Pa
,
mark
my
words
!
<EOS>
Between
Mr.
Rokesmith
and
me
,
there
is
a
natural
antipathy
and
a
deep
distrust
;
 
and
something
will
come
of
it
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
and
girls
,
"
said
the
cherub
-
patriarch
,
"
between
Mr.
Rokesmith
and
me
<EOS>
,
there
is
a
matter
of
eight
sovereigns
,
and
something
for
super
shall
come
of
it
,
if
you
'll
agree
upon
the
article
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
a
neat
and
happy
turn
to
give
the
subject
,
treats
being
rare
in
the
Wilfer
household
,
where
a
monotonous
appearance
of
Dutch
-
cheese
at
ten
o'clock
in
the
evening
had
been
rather
frequently
commented
on
by
the
dimpled
shoulders
of
Miss
Bella
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
modest
Dutchman
himself
seemed
conscious
of
his
want
of
variety
,
and
generally
came
before
the
family
in
a
state
of
apologetic
perspiration
.
<EOS>
After
some
discussion
on
the
relative
merits
of
veal
-
cutlet
,
sweetbread
,
and
lobster
,
a
decision
was
pronounced
in
favour
of
veal
-
cutlet
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
then
solemnly
divested
herself
of
her
handkerchief
and
gloves
,
as
a
preliminary
sacrifice
to
preparing
the
frying
-
pan
,
and
R.
W.
himself
went
out
to
purchase
the
viand
.
<EOS>
He
soon
returned
,
bearing
the
same
in
a
fresh
cabbage
-
leaf
,
where
it
coyly
embraced
a
rasher
of
ham
.
<EOS>
Melodious
sounds
were
not
long
in
rising
from
the
frying
-
pan
on
the
fire
,
or
in
seeming
,
as
the
firelight
danced
in
the
mellow
halls
of
a
couple
of
full
bottles
on
the
table
,
to
play
appropriate
dance
-
music
.
  
<EOS>
The
cloth
was
laid
by
Lavvy
.
<EOS>
Bella
,
as
the
acknowledged
ornament
of
the
family
,
employed
both
her
hands
in
giving
her
hair
an
additional
wave
while
sitting
in
the
easiest
chair
,
and
occasionally
threw
in
a
direction
touching
the
supper
:
as
,
"
Very
brown
,
ma
;
"
or
,
to
her
sister
,
"
Put
the
saltcellar
straight
,
miss
,
and
do
n't
be
a
dowdy
little
puss
.
"
  
<EOS>
Meantime
her
father
,
chinking
Mr.
Rokesmith
's
gold
as
he
sat
expectant
between
his
knife
and
fork
,
remarked
that
six
of
those
sovereigns
came
just
in
time
for
their
landlord
,
and
stood
them
in
a
little
pile
on
the
white
tablecloth
to
look
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hate
our
landlord
!
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
observing
a
fall
in
her
father
's
face
,
she
went
and
sat
down
by
him
at
the
table
,
and
began
touching
up
his
hair
with
the
handle
of
a
fork
.
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
the
girl
's
spoilt
ways
to
be
always
arranging
the
family
's
hair
---
perhaps
because
her
own
was
so
pretty
,
and
occupied
so
much
of
her
attention
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
deserve
to
have
a
house
of
your
own
;
do
n't
you
,
poor
pa
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
deserve
it
better
than
another
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
I
,
for
one
,
want
it
more
than
another
,
"
said
Bella
,
holding
him
by
the
chin
,
as
she
stuck
his
flaxen
hair
on
end
,
"
and
<EOS>
I
grudge
this
money
going
to
the
Monster
that
swallows
up
so
much
,
when
we
all
want
---
Everything
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
say
(
as
you
want
to
say
;
 
I
know
you
want
to
say
so
,
pa
)
`
`
that
's
neither
reasonable
nor
honest
,
Bella
,
"
"
then
I
answer
,
`
`
Maybe
not
,
pa
---
very
likely
---
<EOS>
but
it
's
one
of
the
consequences
of
being
poor
,
and
of
thoroughly
hating
and
detesting
to
be
poor
,
and
that
's
my
case
.
"
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
look
lovely
,
pa
;
 
why
do
n't
you
always
wear
your
hair
like
that
?
<EOS>
And
here
's
the
cutlet
!
<EOS>
If
it
is
n't
very
brown
,
ma
,
I
ca
n't
eat
it
,
and
must
have
a
bit
put
back
to
be
done
expressly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
However
,
as
it
was
brown
,
even
to
Bella
's
taste
,
the
young
lady
graciously
partook
of
it
without
reconsignment
to
the
frying
-
pan
,
and
also
,
in
due
course
,
of
the
contents
of
the
two
bottles
:
whereof
one
held
Scotch
ale
and
the
other
rum
.
<EOS>
The
latter
perfume
,
with
the
fostering
aid
of
boiling
water
and
lemon
-
peel
,
diffused
itself
throughout
the
room
,
and
became
so
highly
concentrated
around
the
warm
fireside
,
that
the
wind
passing
over
the
house
roof
must
have
rushed
off
charged
with
a
delicious
whiff
of
it
,
after
buzzing
like
a
great
bee
at
that
particular
chimneypot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pa
,
"
said
Bella
,
sipping
the
fragrant
mixture
and
warming
her
favourite
ankle
;
"
when
old
Mr.
Harmon
made
such
a
fool
of
me
(
not
to
mention
himself
,
as
he
is
dead
)
,
what
do
you
suppose
he
did
it
for
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Impossible
to
say
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
As
I
have
told
you
times
out
of
number
since
his
will
was
brought
to
light
,
I
doubt
if
I
ever
exchanged
a
hundred
words
with
the
old
gentleman
.
<EOS>
If
it
was
his
whim
to
surprise
us
,
his
whim
succeeded
.
<EOS>
For
he
certainly
did
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
was
stamping
my
foot
and
screaming
,
when
he
first
took
notice
of
me
;
was
I
?
"
said
Bella
,
contemplating
the
ankle
before
mentioned
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
stamping
your
little
foot
,
my
dear
,
and
screaming
with
your
little
voice
,
and
laying
into
me
with
your
little
bonnet
,
which
you
had
snatched
off
for
the
purpose
,
"
returned
her
father
,
as
if
the
remembrance
gave
a
relish
to
the
rum
;
"
you
were
doing
this
one
Sunday
morning
when
I
took
you
out
,
because
I
did
n't
go
the
exact
way
you
wanted
,
when
the
old
gentleman
,
sitting
on
a
seat
near
,
said
,
`
`
<EOS>
That
's
a
nice
girl
;
that
's
a
very
nice
girl
;
a
promising
girl
!
"
<EOS>
"
And
so
you
were
,
my
dear
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
he
asked
my
name
,
did
he
,
pa
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
he
asked
your
name
,
my
dear
,
and
mine
;
and
on
other
Sunday
morning
,
when
we
walked
his
way
,
we
saw
him
again
,
and
---
  
<EOS>
and
really
that
's
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
that
was
all
the
rum
and
water
too
,
or
,
in
other
words
,
as
R.
W.
delicately
signified
that
his
glass
was
empty
,
by
throwing
back
his
head
and
standing
the
glass
upside
down
on
his
nose
and
upper
lip
,
it
might
have
been
charitable
in
Mrs.
Wilfer
to
suggest
replenishment
.
<EOS>
But
that
heroine
briefly
suggesting
"
Bedtime
"
instead
,
the
bottles
were
put
away
,
and
the
family
retired
;
she
cherubically
escorted
,
like
some
severe
saint
in
a
painting
,
or
merely
human
matron
allegorically
treated
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
by
this
time
to
-
morrow
,
"
said
Lavinia
when
the
two
girls
were
alone
in
their
room
,
"
we
shall
have
Mr.
Rokesmith
here
,
and
shall
be
expecting
to
have
our
throats
cut
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
stand
between
me
and
the
candle
for
all
that
,
"
 
retorted
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
another
of
the
consequences
of
being
poor
!
<EOS>
The
idea
of
a
girl
with
a
really
fine
head
of
hair
,
having
to
do
it
by
one
flat
candle
and
a
few
inches
of
looking
-
glass
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
caught
George
Sampson
with
it
,
Bella
,
bad
as
your
means
of
dressing
it
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
low
little
thing
.
<EOS>
Caught
George
Sampson
with
it
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
talk
about
catching
people
,
miss
,
till
your
own
time
for
catching
---
as
you
call
it
---
comes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
has
come
,
"
muttered
Lavvy
,
with
a
toss
of
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
say
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Bella
,
very
sharply
.
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
say
,
miss
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lavvy
declining
equally
to
repeat
or
to
explain
,
Bella
gradually
lapsed
over
her
hair
-
dressing
into
a
soliloquy
on
the
miseries
of
being
poor
,
as
exemplified
in
having
nothing
to
put
on
,
nothing
to
go
out
in
,
nothing
to
dress
by
,
only
a
nasty
box
to
dress
at
instead
of
a
commodious
dressing
-
table
,
and
being
obliged
to
take
in
suspicious
lodgers
.
<EOS>
On
the
last
grievance
as
her
climax
,
she
laid
great
stress
---
and
might
have
laid
greater
,
<EOS>
had
she
known
that
if
Mr.
Julius
Handford
had
a
twin
brother
upon
earth
,
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
was
the
man
.
   
<EOS>
BOFFIN
'S
BOWER
.
 
<EOS>
Over
against
a
London
house
,
a
corner
house
not
far
from
Cavendish
Square
,
a
man
with
a
wooden
leg
had
sat
for
some
years
,
with
his
remaining
foot
in
a
basket
in
cold
weather
,
picking
up
a
living
on
this
wise
:
---
<EOS>
Every
morning
at
eight
o'clock
,
he
stumped
to
the
corner
,
carrying
a
chair
,
a
clothes
-
horse
,
a
pair
of
trestles
,
a
board
,
a
basket
,
and
an
umbrella
,
all
strapped
together
.
<EOS>
Separating
these
,
the
board
and
trestles
became
a
counter
,
the
basket
supplied
the
few
small
lots
of
fruit
and
sweets
that
he
offered
for
sale
upon
it
and
became
a
foot
-
warmer
,
the
unfolded
clothes
-
horse
displayed
a
choice
collection
of
halfpenny
ballads
and
became
a
screen
,
and
the
stool
planted
within
it
became
his
post
for
the
rest
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
All
weathers
saw
the
man
at
the
post
.
<EOS>
This
is
to
be
accepted
in
a
double
sense
,
for
he
contrived
a
back
to
his
wooden
stool
,
by
placing
it
against
the
lamp
-
post
.
<EOS>
When
the
weather
was
wet
,
he
put
up
his
umbrella
over
his
stock
in
trade
,
not
over
himself
;
when
the
weather
was
dry
,
he
furled
that
faded
article
,
tied
it
round
with
a
piece
of
yarn
,
and
laid
it
cross
-
wise
under
the
trestles
:
where
it
looked
like
an
unwholesomely
-
forced
lettuce
that
had
lost
in
color
and
crispness
what
it
had
gained
in
size
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
established
his
right
to
the
corner
,
by
imperceptible
prescription
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
varied
his
ground
an
inch
,
but
had
in
the
beginning
diffidently
taken
the
corner
upon
which
the
side
of
the
house
gave
.
<EOS>
A
howling
corner
in
the
winter
time
,
a
dusty
corner
in
the
summer
time
,
an
undesirable
corner
at
the
best
of
times
.
<EOS>
Shelterless
fragments
of
straw
and
paper
got
up
revolving
storms
there
,
when
the
main
street
was
at
peace
;
and
the
water
-
cart
,
as
if
it
were
drunk
or
short
-
sighted
,
came
blundering
and
jolting
round
it
,
making
it
muddy
when
all
else
was
clean
.
  
<EOS>
On
the
front
of
his
sale
-
board
hung
a
little
placard
,
like
a
kettle
-
holder
,
bearing
the
inscription
in
his
own
small
text
:
  
<EOS>
Errands
gone
 
On
with
fi
Delity
By
 
Ladies
and
Gentlemen
 
<EOS>
I
remain
 
Your
humble
Servt
:
 
Silas
Wegg
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
only
settled
it
with
himself
in
course
of
time
,
that
he
was
errand
-
goer
by
appointment
to
the
house
at
the
corner
(
though
he
received
such
commissions
not
half
a
dozen
times
in
a
year
,
and
then
only
as
some
servant
's
deputy
)
,
but
also
that
he
was
one
of
the
house
's
retainers
and
owed
vassalage
to
it
and
was
bound
to
leal
and
loyal
interest
in
it
.
<EOS>
For
this
reason
,
he
always
spoke
of
it
as
"
Our
House
,
"
and
,
though
his
knowledge
of
its
affairs
was
mostly
speculative
and
all
wrong
,
claimed
to
be
in
its
confidence
.
<EOS>
On
similar
grounds
he
never
beheld
an
inmate
at
any
one
of
its
windows
but
he
touched
his
hat
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
he
knew
so
little
about
the
inmates
that
he
gave
them
names
of
his
own
invention
:
as
"
Miss
Elizabeth
,
"
"
Master
George
,
"
"
Aunt
Jane
,
"
"
Uncle
Parker
"
---
having
no
authority
whatever
for
any
such
designations
,
but
particularly
the
last
---
to
which
,
as
a
natural
consequence
,
he
stuck
with
great
obstinacy
.
  
<EOS>
Over
the
house
itself
,
he
exercised
the
same
imaginary
power
as
over
its
inhabitants
and
their
affairs
.
<EOS>
He
had
never
been
in
it
,
the
length
of
a
piece
of
fat
black
water
-
pipe
which
trailed
itself
over
the
area
-
door
into
a
damp
stone
passage
,
and
had
rather
the
air
of
a
leech
on
the
house
that
had
"
taken
"
wonderfully
;
but
this
was
no
impediment
to
his
arranging
it
according
to
a
plan
of
his
own
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
great
dingy
house
with
a
quantity
of
dim
side
window
and
blank
back
premises
,
and
it
cost
his
mind
a
world
of
trouble
so
to
lay
it
out
as
to
account
for
everything
in
its
external
appearance
.
<EOS>
But
,
this
once
done
,
was
quite
satisfactory
,
and
he
rested
persuaded
,
that
he
knew
his
way
about
the
house
blindfold
:
from
the
barred
garrets
in
the
high
roof
,
to
the
two
iron
extinguishers
before
the
main
door
---
which
seemed
to
request
all
lively
visitors
to
have
the
kindness
to
put
themselves
out
,
before
entering
.
  
<EOS>
Assuredly
,
this
stall
of
Silas
Wegg
's
was
the
hardest
little
stall
of
all
the
sterile
little
stalls
in
London
.
<EOS>
It
gave
you
the
face
-
ache
to
look
at
his
apples
,
the
stomach
-
ache
to
look
at
his
oranges
,
the
toothache
to
look
at
his
nuts
.
<EOS>
Of
the
latter
commodity
he
had
always
a
grim
little
heap
,
on
which
lay
a
little
wooden
measure
which
had
no
discernible
inside
,
and
was
considered
to
represent
the
penn'orth
appointed
by
Magna
Charta
.
<EOS>
Whether
from
too
much
east
wind
or
no
---
it
was
an
easterly
corner
---
the
stall
,
the
stock
,
and
the
keeper
,
were
all
as
dry
as
the
Desert
.
<EOS>
Wegg
was
a
knotty
man
,
and
a
close
-
grained
,
with
a
face
carved
out
of
very
hard
material
,
that
had
just
as
much
play
of
expression
as
a
watchman
's
rattle
.
<EOS>
When
he
laughed
,
certain
jerks
occurred
in
it
,
and
the
rattle
sprung
.
<EOS>
Sooth
to
say
,
he
was
so
wooden
a
man
that
he
seemed
to
have
taken
his
wooden
leg
naturally
,
and
rather
suggested
to
the
fanciful
observer
,
that
he
might
be
expected
---
if
his
development
received
no
untimely
check
---
to
be
completely
set
up
with
a
pair
of
wooden
legs
in
about
six
months
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
was
an
observant
person
,
or
,
as
he
himself
said
,
"
took
a
powerful
sight
of
notice
.
"
<EOS>
He
saluted
all
his
regular
passers
-
by
every
day
,
as
he
sat
on
his
stool
backed
up
by
the
lamp
-
post
;
and
on
the
adaptable
character
of
these
salutes
he
greatly
plumed
himself
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
to
the
rector
,
he
addressed
a
bow
,
compounded
of
lay
deference
,
and
a
slight
touch
of
the
shady
preliminary
meditation
at
church
;
to
the
doctor
,
a
confidential
bow
,
as
to
a
gentleman
whose
acquaintance
with
his
inside
he
begged
respectfully
to
acknowledge
;
before
the
Quality
he
delighted
to
abase
himself
;
and
for
Uncle
Parker
,
who
was
in
the
army
(
at
least
,
so
he
had
settled
it
)
,
he
put
his
open
hand
to
the
side
of
his
hat
,
in
a
military
manner
which
that
angry
-
eyed
buttoned
-
up
inflammatory
-
faced
old
gentleman
appeared
but
imperfectly
to
appreciate
.
  
<EOS>
The
only
article
in
which
Silas
dealt
,
that
was
not
hard
,
was
gingerbread
.
<EOS>
On
a
certain
day
,
some
wretched
infant
having
purchased
the
damp
gingerbread
-
horse
(
fearfully
out
of
condition
)
,
and
the
adhesive
bird
-
cage
,
which
had
been
exposed
for
the
day
's
sale
,
he
had
taken
a
tin
box
from
under
his
stool
to
produce
a
relay
of
those
dreadful
specimens
,
and
was
going
to
look
in
at
the
lid
,
when
he
said
to
himself
,
pausing
:
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Here
you
are
again
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
words
referred
to
a
broad
,
round
-
shouldered
,
one
-
sided
old
fellow
in
mourning
,
coming
comically
ambling
towards
the
corner
,
dressed
in
a
pea
over
-
coat
,
and
carrying
a
large
stick
.
<EOS>
He
wore
thick
shoes
,
and
thick
leather
gaiters
,
and
thick
gloves
like
a
hedger
's
.
<EOS>
Both
as
to
his
dress
and
to
himself
,
he
was
of
an
overlapping
rhinoceros
build
,
with
folds
in
his
cheeks
,
and
his
forehead
,
and
his
eyelids
,
and
his
lips
,
and
his
ears
;
but
with
bright
,
eager
,
childishly
-
inquiring
,
grey
eyes
,
under
his
ragged
eyebrows
,
and
broad
-
brimmed
hat
.
<EOS>
A
very
odd
-
looking
old
fellow
altogether
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
you
are
again
,
"
repeated
Mr.
Wegg
,
musing
.
"
<EOS>
And
what
are
you
now
?
<EOS>
Are
you
in
the
Funns
,
or
where
are
you
?
<EOS>
Have
you
lately
come
to
settle
in
this
neighbourhood
,
or
do
you
own
to
another
neighbourhood
?
<EOS>
Are
you
in
independent
circumstances
,
or
is
it
wasting
the
motions
of
a
bow
on
you
?
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
I
'll
speculate
!
<EOS>
I
'll
invest
a
bow
in
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Which
Mr.
Wegg
,
having
replaced
his
tin
box
,
accordingly
did
,
as
he
rose
to
bait
his
gingerbread
-
trap
for
some
other
devoted
infant
.
<EOS>
The
salute
was
acknowledged
with
:
  
"
Morning
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Morning
!
<EOS>
Morning
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
"
Calls
me
Sir
!
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
to
himself
.
<EOS>
"
He
wo
n't
answer
.
<EOS>
A
bow
gone
!
"
<EOS>
)
  
<EOS>
"
Morning
,
morning
,
morning
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
Appears
to
be
rather
a
'
arty
old
cock
,
too
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
as
before
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
morning
to
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember
me
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
asked
his
new
acquaintance
,
stopping
in
his
amble
,
one
-
sided
,
before
the
stall
,
and
speaking
in
a
pouncing
way
,
though
with
great
good
-
humour
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
noticed
you
go
past
our
house
,
sir
,
several
times
in
the
course
of
the
last
week
or
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
house
,
"
repeated
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Meaning
---
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
nodding
,
as
the
other
pointed
the
clumsy
forefinger
of
his
right
glove
at
the
corner
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Now
,
what
,
"
pursued
the
old
fellow
,
in
an
inquisitive
manner
,
carrying
his
knotted
stick
in
his
left
arm
as
if
it
were
a
baby
,
"
what
do
they
allow
you
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
job
work
that
I
do
for
our
house
,
"
returned

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
As
to
the
amount

strain
upon
the
intellect
now
.
<EOS>
Was
you
thinking
at
all
of
poetry
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
inquired
,
musing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
it
come
dearer
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
come
dearer
,
"
Mr.
Wegg
returned
.
<EOS>
"
For
when
a

to

night

,
it
is
but
right
he
should
expect
to

for

.
"
  
"
To

Wegg

"

"
I

,

so
fur

:
---

<EOS>
Boffin

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But

,

,
I
should
ask

so
fur
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
Silas
,

<EOS>
Left

,

subsided

,

of

-

,
and

with

.
<EOS>
Also
,

he
still

,

down

,

retiring

of

Boffin
.
<EOS>
But
,
profound
gravity
sat
enthroned
on

's
countenance
.
<EOS>
For
,
while
he
considered
within
himself
that
this
was
an
old
fellow
of
rare

,
that
this
was
an
opportunity
to
be
improved
,
and
that
here
might
be
money
to
be
got
beyond
present

,
still
he
compromised

by
no

that
his
new
engagement
was
at

out
of
his

,
or
involved

least

of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
would
even
have
picked

should

his
deep

with

eight

.
<EOS>
His

was
unusual
,

,

,

,
but
because

in

.
<EOS>
And
herein
he
ranged
with
that
very
numerous

of
impostors
,
who
are
quite
as

keep

,

.
  
<EOS>
A

;

of

.
<EOS>
It

,

,
<EOS>
insomuch

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

's

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
Presently
,
Edward

at

,
and

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

"
Supper
,
Eddard
!
"
<EOS>
and

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Pushing

,
which
stood
ajar
,

looked
into

space
where
certain

rose
high
against

,
and
where

to
the
Bower
was
indicated
,
as

showed
,
between

set

.
<EOS>
A
white
figure

along

,
proved

nothing

than
Mr.
Boffin
,
easily
attired
for
the
pursuit
of

,
in
an
undress

of
short

-

.
<EOS>
Having
received
his
literary
friend
with
great

,

to
the
interior
of
the
Bower
and
there

to
Mrs.
Boffin
:
---
a
stout
lady
of
a
rubieund
and

aspect
,
dressed
(
to
Mr.
Wegg
's

)
in
a
low
evening
-
dress
of
sable

,
and
a
large
black

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Boffin
,
Wegg
,
"
said

,
"
is
a
highflyer
at
Fashion
.
<EOS>
And
her
make
is
such
,
that
she
does
it
credit
.
<EOS>
As
to
myself
,
I
ai
n't
yet

Fash'nable

.
<EOS>
Henerietty
,
old
lady
<EOS>
,

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
sure
I
hope

'll

both

,
"
said

Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
queerest
of
rooms
,
fitted
and
furnished
more
like
a

tap
-
room
than
anything
else
within
the
ken
of
Silas
Wegg
.
<EOS>
There
were
two

by

fire
,
one

of

,
with
a

before

.
<EOS>
On
one

,

eight

were
ranged
flat
,
in

row
,
like

;
on
the
other
,
certain
squat
case
-

Wegg

.
<EOS>
On

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Facing

between

,

,

,

,

devoted

Boffin
.
<EOS>
They

that

.
<EOS>
There

;

,

reaching

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

also
noticed
,

,
that
,

such

as

,
there

best

a

likewise

.
<EOS>

large

,

;

;

,

:
who
,

Commodious
,

,

"

.

,

;

's

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

read
on
by
rote
and

,

:

,

,

,

,

that

Good

,

"
To
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Commodious
,
"

,

,

:
"

fights

,

-
five

,

!
<EOS>
As

,

lions
is
turned
into
the
same
wild
-
beast
-
show
all
at

!
<EOS>
As

,
Commodious
,
in
another
character
,
kills

all
off

a

!
<EOS>
As

,
Vittle

(
and

)

'

<EOS>
Wegg

easy
,
but
upon
-
my
-
soul

a
old

myself
these
are
scarers
.
<EOS>
And
even
now
that

is

,
I
do

our

.
"

half

many

.
<EOS>
But
I
'm

!
"
   
<EOS>
CUT
ADRIFT
.
 
<EOS>
The
Six
Jolly
Fellowship
-
Porters
,
already
mentioned
as
a
tavern
of
a
dropsical
appearance
,
had
long
settled
down
into
a
state
of
hale
infirmity
.
<EOS>
In
its
whole
constitution
it
had
not
a
straight
floor
,
and
hardly
a
straight
line
;
but
it
had
outlasted
,
and
clearly
would
yet
outlast
,
many
a
better
-
trimmed
building
,
many
a
sprucer
public
-
house
.
<EOS>
Externally
,
it
was
a
narrow
lopsided
wooden
jumble
of
corpulent
windows
heaped
one
upon
another
as
you
might
heap
as
many
toppling
oranges
,
with
a
crazy
wooden
verandah
impending
over
the
water
;
 
indeed
the
whole
house
,
inclusive
of
the
complaining
flag
-
staff
on
the
roof
,
impended
over
the
water
,
but
seemed
to
have
got
into
the
condition
of
a
faint
-
hearted
diver
who
has
paused
so
long
on
the
brink
that
he
will
never
go
in
at
all
.
  
<EOS>
This
description
applies
to
the
river
-
frontage
of
the
Six
Jolly
Fellowship
-
Porters
.
<EOS>
The
back
of
the
establishment
,
though
the
chief
entrance
was
there
,
so
contracted
that
it
merely
represented
in
its
connexion
with
the
front
,
the
handle
of
a
flat
iron
set
upright
on
its
broadest
end
.
<EOS>
This
handle
stood
at
the
bottom
of
a
wilderness
of
court
and
alley
:
which
wilderness
pressed
so
hard
and
close
upon
the
Six
Jolly
Fellowship
-
Porters
as
to
leave
the
hostelry
not
an
inch
of
ground
beyond
its
door
.
<EOS>
For
this
reason
,
in
combination
with
the
fact
that
the
house
was
all
but
afloat
at
high
water
,
when
the
Porters
had
a
family
wash
the
linen
subjected
to
that
operation
might
usually
be
seen
drying
on
lines
stretched
across
the
reception
-
rooms
and
bed
-
chambers
.
  
<EOS>
The
wood
forming
the
chimney
-
pieces
,
beams
,
partitions
,
floors
and
doors
,
of
the
Six
Jolly
Fellowship
-
Porters
,
seemed
in
its
old
age
fraught
with
confused
memories
of
its
youth
.
<EOS>
In
many
places
it
had
become
gnarled
and
riven
,
according
to
the
manner
of
old
trees
;
 
knots
started
out
of
it
;
and
here
and
there
it
seemed
to
twist
itself
into
some
likeness
of
boughs
.
<EOS>
In
this
state
of
second
childhood
,
it
had
an
air
of
being
in
its
own
way
garrulous
about
its
early
life
.
<EOS>
Not
without
reason
was
it
often
asserted
by
the
regular
frequenters
of
the
Porters
,
that
when
the
light
shone
full
upon
the
grain
of
certain
panels
,
and
particularly
upon
an
old
corner
cupboard
of
walnut
-
wood
in
the
bar
,
you
might
trace
little
forests
there
,
and
tiny
trees
like
the
parent
tree
,
in
full
umbrageous
leaf
.
  
<EOS>
The
bar
of
the
Six
Jolly
Fellowship
-
Porters
was
a
bar
to
soften
the
human
breast
.
<EOS>
The
available
space
in
it
was
not
much
larger
than
a
hackney
-
coach
;
but
no
one
could
have
wished
the
bar
bigger
,
that
space
was
so
girt
in
by
corpulent
little
casks
,
and
by
cordial
-
bottles
radiant
with
fictitious
grapes
in
bunches
,
and
by
lemons
in
nets
,
and
by
biscuits
in
baskets
,
and
by
the
polite
beer
-
pulls
that
made
low
bows
when
customers
were
served
with
beer
,
and
by
the
cheese
in
a
snug
corner
,
and
by
the
landlady
's
own
small
table
in
a
snugger
corner
near
the
fire
,
with
the
cloth
everlastingly
laid
.
<EOS>
This
haven
was
divided
from
the
rough

by
a

and
a
half

door
,
with
a
leaden
sill
upon
it
for
the

of
resting
your
liquor
;
but
,
over
this
half
-
door
the
bar
's

so
gushed
forth
,
that
,
albeit
customers
drank
there
standing
,
in
a
dark

draughty
passage
where
they
were
shouldered
by
other
customers
passing
in
and
out
,
they
always
appeared
to
drink
under
an
enchanting

that
they
were
in
the
bar
itself
.
  
<EOS>
For

rest
,
both
the
tap
and

of

Six
Jolly
Fellowship
-
Porters
gave
upon
the
river
,
and
had

regular

,

,

,

that

,

,

<EOS>
The

a

,

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
It

room

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Charley
dear
,
except
,
be
good
,
and
get
learning
,
and
only
think
of
some
things
in
the
old
life
here
,
as
if
you
had
dreamed
them
in
a
dream
last
night
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
my
Darling
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Though
so
young
,
she
infused
into
these
parting
words
a
love
that
was
far
more
like
a
mother
's
than
a
sister
's
,
and
before
which
the
boy
was
quite
bowed
down
.
<EOS>
After
holding
her
to
his
breast
with
a

,
he
took
up
his
bundle
and
darted
out
at
the
door
,
with
an
arm

.
  
<EOS>
The
white
face
of
the
winter
day
came
sluggishly
on
,
veiled
in
a
frosty
mist
;
and
the
shadowy
ships
in
the
river
slowly
changed
to
black
substances
;
and
the
sun
,
blood
-
red
on
the
eastern

behind
dark
masts
and
yards
,
seemed
filled
with
the
ruins
of
a
forest
it
had
set
on
fire
.
<EOS>
Lizzie
,
looking
for
her
father
,
saw
him
coming
,
and
stood
upon
the
causeway
that
he
might
see
her
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
nothing
with
him
but
his
boat
,
and
came
on
apace
.
<EOS>
A
knot
of
those
amphibious
human
-
creatures
who
appear
to
have
some
mysterious
power
of
extracting
a
subsistence
out
of
tidal
water
by
looking
at
it
,
were
gathered
together
about
the
causeway
.
<EOS>
As
her
father
's
boat
grounded
,
they
became
contemplative
of
the
mud
,
and
dispersed
themselves
.
<EOS>
She
saw
that
the
mute
avoidance
had
begun
.
  
<EOS>
Gaffer
saw
it
,
too
,
in
so
far
as
that
he
was
moved
when
he
set
foot
on
shore
,
to
stare
around
him
.
<EOS>
But
,
he
promptly
set
to
work
to
haul

his
boat
,
and
make

fast
,
and
take
the
sculls
and
rudder
and

out
of
her
.
<EOS>
Carrying
these
with
Lizzie
's

,
he
passed
up
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sit
close
to
the

,
father
,
dear
,

.
<EOS>
It
's
all
ready
for
cooking
,
and
only
been
waiting

.
<EOS>
You
must
be
frozen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Lizzie
,
I
ai
n't
of
a
glow
;
that
's
certain
.
<EOS>
And
my
hands
seemed
nailed
through
to

.
<EOS>
See

are
!
"
<EOS>
Something

,

,

;
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my

.
<EOS>
Lay

,

.
<EOS>
---
  
<EOS>
Where

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

;

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>

"

,

"

,

---
<EOS>
Ai

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Eat

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Father
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

"
Unnat'ral

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
---

Unnat'ral

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
---

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
father
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Let

,

.
<EOS>
His
own
father
ai

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
His

,

,

unnat'ral

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
With

,

,

,

at

.
<EOS>
As

would

with

to

nothing

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's

.
<EOS>
He

than

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

,
and

he

.
<EOS>
Now

aloof

.
<EOS>
They

,
`
`
Here

the
man
as
ai
n't

for
his
own
son
!
"
<EOS>
"
Lizzie
---
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
,

stopped

.
<EOS>
Looking
at

he
saw
her
,
with
a

quite

,

against

,

her
hands

.
  
<EOS>
"
Father
,
do

!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
Put

!
"
  
<EOS>
He

at

;
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Father
,
it
's
too

.
<EOS>
O

it
down
,

it
down
!
"
  
<EOS>
Confounded
by

and

,
he

,
and
stood

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's

you
,
Liz
?
<EOS>
Can

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
father
,
no
;
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

I

?
"
  
"
Nothing
,
dear
father
.
<EOS>
On
my
knees
,
I
am
certain
,
in
my
heart
and
soul
<EOS>
I
am
certain
,
nothing
!
<EOS>
But
it
was
too
dreadful
to
bear
;
for
it
looked
---
<EOS>
"
her
hands
covering
her
face
again
,
"
O
it
looked
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
it
look
like
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
recollection
of
his
murderous
figure
,
combining
with
her
trial
of
last
night
,
and
her
trial
of
the
morning
,
caused
her
to
drop
at

,
without

.
  
<EOS>
He
had
never
seen
her
so
before
.
<EOS>
He
raised
her
with
the

,
calling
her
the
best
of
daughters
,
and
"
my
poor
pretty
creetur
,
"
and
laid
her

upon

,
and
tried
to
restore
her
.
<EOS>
But

,
he
laid
her
head
gently
down

,
got
a

and
placed
it
under
her
dark
hair
,
and
sought
on
the
table
for
a

of

.
<EOS>
There
being
none
left
,
he
hurriedly
caught
up
the
empty
bottle
,
and
ran
out
at
the

.
  
<EOS>
He
returned
as

as
he
had
gone
,
with
the

still
empty
.
<EOS>
He
kneeled
down
by

,
took
her
head
on

arm
,
and
moistened
her
lips
with
a
little
water
into
which
he
dipped
his

:
saying
,

,
as
he
looked

,
now
over
this

,
now
over

:
  
"
<EOS>
Have
we
got

pest
in
