?
<EOS>
Is
there
summ'at
deadly
sticking
to
my
clothes
?
<EOS>
What
's
let
loose
upon
us
?
<EOS>
Who
loosed
it
?
"
   
<EOS>
MR
.
<EOS>
WEGG
LOOKS
<EOS>
AFTER
HIMSELF
.
 
<EOS>
Silas
Wegg
,
being
on
his
road
to
the
Roman
Empire
,
approaches
it
by
way
of
Clerkenwell
.
<EOS>
The
time
is
early
in
the
evening
;
the
weather
moist
and
raw
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
finds
leisure
to
make
a
little
circuit
,
by
reason
that
he
folds
his
screen
early
,
now
that
he
combines
another
source
of
income
with
it
,
and
also
that
he
feels
it
due
to
himself
to
be
anxiously
expected
at
the
Bower
.
<EOS>
"
Boffin
will
get
all
the
eagerer
for
waiting
a
bit
,
"
says
Silas
,
screwing
up
,
as
he
stumps
along
,
first
his
right
eye
,
and
then
his
left
.
<EOS>
Which
is
something
superfluous
in
him
,
for
Nature
has
already
screwed
both
pretty
tight
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
get
on
with
him
as
I
expect
to
get
on
,
"
Silas
pursues
,
stumping
and
meditating
,
"
it
would
n't
become
me
to
leave
it
here
.
<EOS>
It
would
n't
be
respectable
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Animated
by
this
reflection
,
he
stumps
faster
,
and
looks
a
long
way
before
him
,
as
a
man
with
an
ambitious
project
in
abeyance
often
will
do
.
  
<EOS>
Aware
of
a
working
-
jeweller
population
taking
sanctuary
about
the
church
in
Clerkenwell
,
Mr.
Wegg
is
conscious
of
an
interest
in
,
and
a
respect
for
,
the
neighbourhood
.
<EOS>
But
,
his
sensations
in
this
regard
halt
as
to
their
strict
morality
,
as
he
halts
in
his
gait
;
for
,
they
suggest
the
delights
of
a
coat
of
invisibility
in
which
to
walk
off
safely
with
the
precious
stones
and
watch
-
cases
,
but
stop
short
of
any
compunction
for
the
people
who
would
lose
the
same
.
  
<EOS>
Not
,
however
,
towards
the
"
shops
"
where
cunning
artificers
work
in
pearls
and
diamonds
and
gold
and
silver
,
making
their
hands
so
rich
,
that
the
enriched
water
in
which
they
wash
them
is
bought
for
the
refiners
;
---
not
towards
these
does
Mr.
Wegg
stump
,
but
towards
the
poorer
shops
of
small
retail
traders
in
commodities
to
eat
and
drink
and
keep
folks
warm
,
and
of
Italian
frame
-
makers
,
and
of
barbers
,
and
of
brokers
,
and
of
dealers
in
dogs
and
singing
-
birds
.
<EOS>
From
these
,
in
a
narrow
and
a
dirty
street
devoted
to
such
callings
,
Mr.
Wegg
selects
one
dark
shop
-
window
with
a
tallow
candle
dimly
burning
in
it
,
surrounded
by
a
muddle
of
objects
vaguely
resembling
pieces
of
leather
and
dry
stick
,
but
among
which
nothing
is
resolvable
into
anything
distinct
,
save
the
candle
itself
in
its
old
tin
candlestick
,
and
two
preserved
frogs
fighting
a
small
-
sword
duel
.
<EOS>
Stumping
with
fresh
vigour
,
he
goes
in
at
the
dark
greasy
entry
,
pushes
a
little
greasy
dark
reluctant
side
-
door
,
and
follows
the
door
into
the
little
dark
greasy
shop
.
<EOS>
It
is
so
dark
that
nothing
can
be
made
out
in
it
,
over
a
little
counter
,
but
another
tallow
candle
in
another
old
tin
candlestick
,
close
to
the
face
of
a
man
stooping
low
in
a
chair
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
nods
to
the
face
,
"
Good
evening
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
face
looking
up
is
a
sallow
face
with
weak
eyes
,
surmounted
by
a
tangle
of
reddish
-
dusty
hair
.
<EOS>
The
owner
of
the
face
has
no
cravat
on
,
and
has
opened
his
tumbled
shirt
-
collar
to
work
with
the
more
ease
.
<EOS>
For
the
same
reason
he
has
no
coat
on
:
only
a
loose
waistcoat
over
his
yellow
linen
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
are
like
the
over
-
tried
eyes
of
an
engraver
,
but
he
is
not
that
;
his
expression
and
stoop
are
like
those
of
a
shoemaker
,
but
he
is
not
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
Mr.
Venus
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
remember
?
"
  
<EOS>
With
slowly
dawning
remembrance
,
Mr.
Venus
rises
,
and
holds
his
candle
over
the
little
counter
,
and
holds
it
down
towards
the
legs
,
natural
and
artificial
,
of
Mr.
Wegg
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
!
"
<EOS>
he
says
,
then
.
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wegg
,
you
know
,
"
that
gentleman
explains
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
says
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Hospital
amputation
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Just
so
,
"
says
Mr.
Wegg
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
yes
,
"
quoth
Venus
.
"
How
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
Sit
down
by
the
fire
,
and
warm
your
---
your
other
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
little
counter
being
so
short
a
counter
that
it
leaves
the
fireplace
,
which
would
have
been
behind
it
if
it
had
been
longer
,
accessible
,
Mr.
Wegg
sits
down
on
a
box
in
front
of
the
fire
,
and
inhales
a
warm
and
comfortable
smell
which
is
not
the
smell
of
the
shop
.
<EOS>
"
For
that
,
"
Mr.
Wegg
inwardly
decides
,
as
he
takes
a
corrective
sniff
or
two
,
"
is
musty
,
leathery
,
feathery
,
cellary
,
gluey
,
gummy
,
and
,
"
with
another
sniff
,
"
as
it
might
be
,
strong
of
old
pairs
of
bellows
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
tea
is
drawing
,
and
my
muffin
is
on
the
hob
,
Mr.
Wegg
;
 
will
you
partake
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
being
one
of
Mr.
Wegg
's
guiding
rules
in
life
always
to
partake
,
he
says
he
will
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
little
shop
is
so
excessively
dark
,
is
stuck
so
full
of
black
shelves
and
brackets
and
nooks
and
corners
,
that
he
sees
Mr.
Venus
's
cup
and
saucer
only
because
it
is
close
under
the
candle
,
and
does
not
see
from
what
mysterious
recess
Mr.
Venus
produces
another
for
himself
,
until
it
is
under
his
nose
.
<EOS>
Concurrently
,
Wegg
perceives
a
pretty
little
dead
bird
lying
on
the
counter
,
with
its
head
drooping
on
one
side
against
the
rim
of
Mr.
Venus
's
saucer
,
and
a
long
stiff
wire
piercing
its
breast
.
<EOS>
As
if
it
were
Cock
Robin
,
the
hero
of
the
ballad
,
and
Mr.
Venus
were
the
sparrow
with
his
bow
and
arrow
,
and
Mr.
Wegg
were
the
fly
with
his
little
eye
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
dives
,
and
produces
another
muffin
,
yet
untoasted
;
 
taking
the
arrow
out
of
the
breast
of
Cock
Robin
,
he
proceeds
to
toast
it
on
the
end
of
that
cruel
instrument
.
<EOS>
When
it
is
brown
,
he
dives
again
and
produces
butter
,
with
which
he
completes
his
work
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
,
as
an
artful
man
who
is
sure
of
his
supper
by
-
and
-
bye
,
presses
muffin
on
his
host
to
soothe
him
into
a
compliant
state
of
mind
,
or
,
as
one
might
say
,
to
grease
his
works
.
<EOS>
As
the
muffins
disappear
,
little
by
little
,
the
black
shelves
and
nooks
and
corners
begin
to
appear
,
and
Mr.
Wegg
gradually
acquires
an
imperfect
notion
that
over
against
him
on
the
chimney
-
piece
is
a
Hindoo
baby
in
a
bottle
,
curved
up
with
his
big
head
tucked
under
him
,
as
though
he
would
instantly
throw
a
summersault
if
the
bottle
were
large
enough
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
deems
Mr.
Venus
's
wheels
sufficiently
lubricated
,
Mr.
Wegg
approaches
his
object
by
asking
,
as
he
lightly
taps
his
hands
together
,
to
express
an
undesigning
frame
of
mind
:
  
"
<EOS>
And
how
have
I
been
going
on
,
this
long
time
,
Mr.
Venus
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
bad
,
"
says
Mr.
Venus
,
uncompromisingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
<EOS>
Am
I
still
at
home
?
"
<EOS>
asks
Wegg
,
with
an
air
of
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Always
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
would
seem
to
be
secretly
agreeable
to
Wegg
,
but
he
veils
his
feelings
,
and
observes
,
"
Strange
.
<EOS>
To
what
do
you
attribute
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
replies
Venus
,
who
is
a
haggard

man
,
speaking
in
a
weak
voice
of
querulous
complaint
,
"
to
what
to
attribute
it
,
Mr.
Wegg
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
work
you
into
a
miscellaneous
one
,
nohow
.
<EOS>
Do
what
I
will
,
you
ca
n't
be
got
to
fit
.
<EOS>
Anybody
with
a
passable
knowledge
would
pick

out
at

,
and
say
,
---
`
`
No
go
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
match
!
"
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
Well
,
but
hang
it
,
Mr.
Venus
,
"
Wegg
expostulates
with
some

,
"
that
ca
n't
be
personal
and
peculiar
in
me
.
<EOS>
It
must
often
happen
with
miscellaneous
ones
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
ribs
(
I
grant
you
)
always
.
<EOS>
But
not
else
.
<EOS>
When
I
prepare
a
miscellaneous
one
,
I
know
beforehand
that
I
ca
n't
keep
to
nature
,
and
be
miscellaneous
with
ribs
,
because
every
man
has
his
own
ribs
,
and
no
other
man
's
will

;
but
elseways
I
can
be
miscellaneous
.
<EOS>
I
have
just
sent
home
a
Beauty
---
a
perfect
Beauty
---
to
a
school
of
art
.
<EOS>
One
leg
Belgian
,
one
leg
English
,
and
the
pickings

eight
other
people
in

.
<EOS>
Talk
of
not
being
qualified
to
be
miscellaneous
!
<EOS>
By
rights
you
ought
to
be
,
Mr.
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Silas
looks
as
hard
at
his
one
leg
as
he
can
in
the
dim
light
,
and
after
a

sulkily
opines
"
that
it
must
be
the
fault

the
other

.
<EOS>
Or
how
do
you
mean
to
say

comes

?
<EOS>
"
he
demands

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
it
comes
about
.
<EOS>
Stand
up
a
minute
.
<EOS>
Hold
the
light
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
takes
from
a
corner
by
his
chair
,
the
bones
of
a
leg
and
foot
,
beautifully
pure
,
and
put
together

.
<EOS>
These
he
compares
with
Mr.
Wegg
's
leg
;
that

looking
on
,
as

he

-

.
"
<EOS>
No
,
I
do
n't

how
it
is
,
but
so

.
<EOS>
You
have
got
a
twist
in
that
bone
,
to
the
best
of
my
belief
.
<EOS>
I
never
saw
the
likes
of
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
having
looked

at
his
own

,
and

at
the
pattern
with
which
it
has
been
compared
,
makes
the
point
:
  
"
I
'll
bet
a
pound
that
ai
n't
an
English
one
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
An
easy

,
when
we
run
so
much
into
foreign
!
<EOS>
No
,
it
belongs

that
French

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

nods

a
point
of
darkness
behind
Mr.
Wegg
,
the
latter
,
with

,
looks
round
for
"
that
French

,
"
 
whom
he
at
length

to
be
represented
(
in

)
by
his
ribs
only
,
standing
on
a
shelf
in
another
corner
,
like
a
piece
of
armour
or
a

stays
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"
says
Mr.
Wegg
,
with
a
sort
of
sense
of
being
introduced
;
 
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
you
were
all
right
enough
in
your
own

,
but
I
hope
no
objections
will
be
taken
to
my
saying
that
the
Frenchman
was
never
yet
born
as
I
should
wish
to
match
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
moment
the
greasy
door
is
violently
pushed
inward
,
and
a
boy
follows
it
,
who
says
,
after
having
let
it
slam
:
  
<EOS>
"
Come
for
the
stuffed
canary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
three
and
ninepence
,
"
returns
Venus
;
"
have
you
got
the
money
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
produces
four
shillings
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
,
always
in
exceedingly
low
spirits
and
making
whimpering
sounds
,
peers
about
for
the
stuffed
canary
.
<EOS>
On
his
taking
the
candle
to
assist
his

,
Mr.
Wegg
observes
that
he
has
a
convenient
little
shelf
near

,
exclusively
appropriated
to
skeleton
hands
,
which
have
very
much
the
appearance
of
wanting
to
lay
hold
of
him
.
<EOS>
From
these
Mr.
Venus
rescues
the
canary
in
a
glass
case
,
and
shows
it
to
the
boy
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
he
whimpers
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
animation
!
<EOS>
On
a
twig
,
making
up
his
mind
to
hop
!
<EOS>
Take
care
of
him
;
he
's
lovely
specimen
.
<EOS>
---
  
<EOS>
And
three
is
four
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
gathers
up
his
change
and
has
pulled
the
door
open
by
a
leather
strap
nailed
to
it
for

,
when
Venus
cries
out
:
  
"
Stop
him
!
<EOS>
Come
back
,
you
young
villain
!
<EOS>
You
've
got
a
tooth
among
them
halfpence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
was
I
to
know
I
'd

?
<EOS>
You
giv

me
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
none
of
your
teeth
;
I
've

of
my
own
.
"
<EOS>
So

boy
pipes
,
as

selects
it
from

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
sauce
me
,
in

,
"
Mr.

.
<EOS>
"
Do

because

I
'm

.
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
It
dropped

,

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
There

two
in

.
<EOS>
Molars
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,

,
"

,
"

call

?
"
  
<EOS>
To

Mr.
Venus
only

,
shaking

shock

,

,
"
Do

sauce
me
,
in
the
wicious
pride
of
your
youth
;
do
n't
hit
me
,
because
you

I
'm
down
.
<EOS>
You
've
no
idea
how
small
you
'd
come
out
,

I

articulating
of
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
This

seems
to
have
its

on

boy
,
for

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
me
,

!
"

,

,

,
"
the
world
that
appeared

flowery
has
ceased

blow
!
<EOS>
You
're
casting

,
Mr.
Wegg
.
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
My

's

.
<EOS>
A
Wice
.
<EOS>
Tools
.
<EOS>
Bones
,
warious
.
<EOS>
Skulls
,

.
<EOS>
Preserved

.
<EOS>
African

.
<EOS>
Bottled

,
warious
.
<EOS>
Everything

,

.
<EOS>
The

ones
a
-

.
<EOS>
What

,

.
<EOS>
Say
,

.
<EOS>
Cats
.
<EOS>
Articulated

.
<EOS>
Dogs
.
<EOS>
Ducks
.
<EOS>
Glass

,
warious
.
<EOS>
Mummied

.
<EOS>
Dried

,
warious
.
<EOS>
Oh
,

!
<EOS>
That
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
so

as
that

these

objects
seemed
to
come
forward
obediently
when
they
were
named
,
and
then
retire
again
,
Mr.
Venus
despondently

,
"
<EOS>
Oh
dear
me
,
dear
me
!
"
<EOS>
resumes
his
seat
,
and
with
drooping

upon
him
,
falls
to
pouring
himself
out
more
tea
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
am
I
?
"
asks
Mr.
Wegg
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
somewhere
in
the
back
shop
across
the
yard
,
sir
;
and
speaking
quite
candidly
,
I
wish
I
'd
never
bought
you
of
the
Hospital
Porter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
look
here
,
what
did
you
give
for
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
replies
Venus
,
blowing
his
tea
:
his
head
and
face
peering
out
of
the
darkness
,
over
the

of
it
,
as
if
he
were
modernizing
the
old
original
rise
in
his
family
:
"
you
were
one
of
a
warious
lot
,
and
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Silas
puts
his
point
in
the
improved
form
of
"
What
will
you
take
for
me
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
replies
Venus
,
still
blowing
his
tea
,
"
I
'm
not
prepared
,
at
a
moment
's
notice
,
to
tell
you
,
Mr.
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
!
<EOS>
According
to
your
own
account
I
'm
not
worth
much
,
"
 
Wegg
reasons
persuasively
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
for
miscellaneous
working
in
,
I
grant
you
,
Mr.
Wegg
;
but
you
might
turn
out
valuable
yet
,
as
a
---
"
<EOS>
here
Mr.
Venus
takes
a
gulp
of
tea
,
so
hot
that
it
makes
him
choke
,
and
sets
his
weak

watering
;
"
as
a
Monstrosity
,
if
you
'll

me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Repressing
an
indignant
look
,
indicative
of
anything
but
a
disposition

MR

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
I
took
the
liberty
of
following
you
,
trying

make

,

went

lawyer
's
.
<EOS>
Then
I

came

.
<EOS>
"
  
(
"
Do
n't
quite
sound
like
skittles
,
nor
yet
country

,
nor
yet
jewellery
,
"
thought

Boffin
,
"
but
there
's
no

.
"
<EOS>
)
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

object

,
I

little

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

---
which
is
more

---
what

,
I
answer
,
I
have
been
strongly

,
that
you
are
a
man
of
rectitude

,
with

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
information
is
true
of
Mrs.
Boffin
,
anyhow
,
"
was
Mr.
Boffin
's

,
as
he

new

.
<EOS>
There
was
something
repressed
in
the

man
's

,
and
he

with

---
though

,

,
of
Mr.
Boffin
's

---
and
he

.
<EOS>
But
his
words
came

,
and
his

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
add
,
I
can

the

says
of
you
---
that
you
are
quite

Fortune
,
and
not

<EOS>
---
I
trust

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
"
How

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
How

?
"
)
  
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>

"

?
"

,

<EOS>
"
Your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said

Boffin
,

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Or
,
"

,

"

your
man

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
two

---
any

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin

quality
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

---

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>

"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
All

"

"

<EOS>
My

<EOS>
I

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Odder

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
anticipated

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
Professionally

,

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

Harmoon

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
MR
.
<EOS>
AND
MRS
.
BOFFIN
IN
CONSULTATION
.
 
<EOS>
Betaking
himself
straight
homeward
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
without
further
let
or
hindrance
,
arrived
at
the
Bower
,
and
gave
Mrs.
Boffin
(
in
a
walking

of
black

and
feathers
,
like
a
mourning
coach
-
horse
)
<EOS>
an
account
of
all
he
had
said
and
done
since
breakfast
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
brings
us
round
,
my
dear
,
"
he
then

,
"
to
the
question
we
left

:
<EOS>
namely
,
whether

's
to
be
any
new

-
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
'll

,
Noddy
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
smoothing

,
"
I
wan't
Society
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fashionable
Society
,
my
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Boffin
,
laughing
with
the

of
a
child
.
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
It
's
no
good
my
being
kept
here
like
Wax
-
Work
;
is

now
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
People
have
to
pay
to
see
Wax
-
Work
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
her
husband
,
"
whereas
(
though
you
'd
be
cheap
at
the
same
money
)
<EOS>
the
neighbours
is
welcome
to
see
you
for
nothing
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
do
n't
answer
,
"
said
the
cheerful
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
When
we
worked
like
the
neighbours
,
we
suited
one
another
.
<EOS>
Now
we
have
left
work
off
,
we
have
left
off
suiting
one
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
,
do
you
think
of
beginning
work
again
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
hinted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Out
of
the
question
!
<EOS>
We
have
come
into
a
great
fortune
,
and
we
must
do
what
's
right
by
our
fortune
;
we
must
act
up
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,
who
had
a
deep
respect
for
his
wife
's
intuitive
wisdom
,
replied
,
though
rather
pensively
:
"
<EOS>
I
suppose
we
must
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
never
been
acted
up
to
yet
,
and
,
consequently
,
no
good
has
come
of
it
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
True
,
to
the
present
time
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
assented
,
with
his
former
pensiveness
,
as

took

.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
good
may
be
coming
of
it
in
the
future
time
.
<EOS>
Towards
which
,
what
's
your
views
,
old

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
,
a
smiling
creature
,
broad
figure
and
simple

nature
,
with
her

folded
in
her

,
and
with

,

to
expound
her
views
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
a
good
house
in
a
good
neighbourhood
,
good
things
about
us
,
good

,
and
good

.
<EOS>
I
say
,
live
like
our
means
,
without

,
and
be
happy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
say
be
happy
,
too
,
"
assented
the
still
pensive
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Lor
-
a
-
mussy
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Boffin
,
laughing
and
clapping
her
hands
,
and
gaily
rocking
herself
to
and
fro
,
"
when
I
think
of
me
in
a
light

and

,
with

to
the
wheels
---
"
  
"
Oh
!
you
was
thinking
of
that
,
was
you
,
my
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
!
"
cried
the
delighted
creature
.
"
<EOS>
And
with
a
footman
up
behind
,
with
a
bar
across
,
to
keep
his
legs
from
being
poled
!
<EOS>
And
with
a
coachman
up
in
front
,
sinking
down
into
a
seat
big
enough
for
three
of
him
,
all
covered
with
upholstery
in
green
and
white
!
<EOS>
And
with
two
bay
horses
tossing
their
heads
and
stepping
higher
than
they
trot
long
-
ways
!
<EOS>
And
with
you
and
me
leaning
back
inside
,
as
grand
as
ninepence
!
<EOS>
Oh
-
h
-
h
-
h
My
!
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
ha
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
clapped
her
hands
again
,
rocked
herself
again
,
beat
her
feet
upon
the
floor
,
and
wiped
the
tears
of
laughter
from
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
,
my
old
lady
,
"
inquired
Mr.
Boffin
,
when
he
also
had
sympathetically
laughed
:
"
what
's
your
views
on
the
subject
of
the
Bower
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shut
it
up
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
part
with
it
,
but
put
somebody
in
it
,
to
keep
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Any
other
views
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Noddy
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
coming
from
her
fashionable
sofa
to
his
side
on
the
plain
settle
,
and
hooking
her
comfortable
arm
through
his
,
"
<EOS>
Next
I
think
---
and
I
really
have
been
thinking
early
and
late
 
---
of
the
disappointed
girl
;
her
that
was
so
cruelly
disappointed
,
you
know
,
both
of
her
husband
and
his
riches
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
we
might
do
something
for
her
?
<EOS>
Have
her
to
live
with
us
?
<EOS>
Or
something
of
that
sort
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ne
-
ver
once
thought
of
the
way
of
doing
it
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr.
Boffin
,
smiting
the
table
in
his
admiration
.
<EOS>
"
What
a
thinking
steamingein
this
old
lady
is
.
<EOS>
And
she
do
n't
know
how
she
does
it
.
<EOS>
Neither
does
the
ingein
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
pulled
his
nearest
ear
,
in
acknowledgment
of
this
piece
of
philosophy
,
and
then
said
,
gradually
toning
down
to
a
motherly
strain
:
"
Last
,
and
not
least
,
I
have
taken
a
fancy
.
<EOS>
You
remember
dear
little
John
Harmon
,
before
he
went
to
school
?
<EOS>
Over
yonder
across
the
yard
,
at
our
fire
?
<EOS>
Now
that
he
is
past
all
benefit
of
the
money
,
and
it
's
come
to
us
,
I
should
like
to
find
some
orphan
child
,
and
take
the
boy
and
adopt
him
and
give
him
John
's
name
,
and
provide
for
him
.
<EOS>
Somehow
,
it
would
make
me
easier
,
I
fancy
.
<EOS>
Say
it
's
only
a
whim
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
I
do
n't
say
so
,
"
interposed
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
but
deary
,
if
you
did
---
"
  
"
I
should
be
a
Beast
if
I
did
,
"
her
husband
interposed
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
as
much
as
to
say
you
agree
?
<EOS>
Good
and
kind
of
you
,
and
like
you
,
deary
!
<EOS>
And
do
n't
you
begin
to
find
it
pleasant
now
,
"
said
Mrs
,
.
<EOS>
Boffin
,
once
more
radiant
in
her
comely
way
from
head
to
foot
,
and
once
more
smoothing
her
dress
with
immense
enjoyment
,
"
do
n't
you
begin
to
find
it
pleasant
already
,
to
think
that
a
child
will
be
made
brighter
,
and
better
,
and
happier
,
because
of
that
poor
sad
child
that
day
?
<EOS>
And
is
n't
it
pleasant
to
know
that
the
good
will
be
done
with
the
poor
sad
child
's
own
money
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
<EOS>
and
it
's
pleasant
to
know
that
you
are
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
said
her
husband
,
"
and
it
's
been
a
pleasant
thing
to
know
this
many
and
many
a
year
!
<EOS>
"
It
was
ruin
to
Mrs.
Boffin
's
aspirations
,
but
,
having
so
spoken
,
they
sat
side
by
side
,
a
hopelessly
Unfashionable
pair
.
  
<EOS>
These
two
ignorant
and
unpolished
people
had
guided
themselves
so
far
on
in
their
journey
of
life
,
by
a
religious
sense
of
duty
and
desire
to
do
right
.
<EOS>
Ten
thousand
weaknesses
and
absurdities
might
have
been
detected
in
the
breasts
of
both
;
<EOS>
ten
thousand
vanities
additional
,
possibly
,
in
the
breast
of
the
woman
.
<EOS>
But
the
hard
wrathful
and
sordid
nature
that
had
wrung
as
much
work
out
of
them
as
could
be
got
in
their
best
days
,
for
as
little
money
as
could
be
paid
to
hurry
on
their
worst
,
had
never
been
so
warped
but
that
it
knew
their
moral
straightness
and
respected
it
.
<EOS>
In
its
own
despite
,
in
a
constant
conflict
with
itself
and
them
,
it
had
done
so
.
<EOS>
And
this
is
the
eternal
law
.
<EOS>
For
,
Evil
often
stops
short
at
itself
and
dies
with
the
doer
of
it
;
but
Good
,
never
.
  
<EOS>
Through
his
most
inveterate
purposes
,
the
dead
Jailer
of
Harmony
Jail
had
known
these
two
faithful
servants
to
be
honest
and
true
.
<EOS>
While
he
raged
at
them
and
reviled
them
for
opposing
him
with
the
speech
of
the
honest
and
true
,
it
had
scratched
his
stony
heart
,
and
he
had
perceived
the
powerlessness
of
all
his
wealth
to
buy
them
if
he
had
addressed
himself
to
the
attempt
.
<EOS>
So
,
even
while
he
was
their
griping
taskmaster
and
never
gave
them
a
good
word
,
he
had
written
their
names
down
in
his
will
.
<EOS>
So
,
even
while
it
was
his
daily
declaration
that
he
mistrusted
all
mankind
---
and
sorely
indeed
he
did
mistrust
all
who
bore
any
resemblance
to
himself
---
  
<EOS>
he
was
as
certain
that
these
two
people
,
surviving
him
,
would
be
trustworthy
in
all
things
from
the
greatest
to
the
least
,
as
he
was
that
he
must
surely
die
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
sitting
side
by
side
,
with
Fashion
withdrawn
to
an
immeasurable
distance
,
fell
to
discussing
how
they
could
best
find
their
orphan
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
suggested
advertisement
in
the
newspapers
,
requesting
orphans
answering
annexed
description
to
apply
at
the
Bower
on
a
certain
day
;
but
Mr.
Boffin
wisely
apprehending
obstruction
of
the
neighbouring
thoroughfares
by
orphan
swarms
,
this
course
was
negatived
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
next
suggested
application
to
their
clergyman
for
a
likely
orphan
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
thinking
better
of
this
scheme
,
they
resolved
to
call
upon
the
reverend
gentleman
at
once
,
and
to
take
the
same
opportunity
of
making
acquaintance
with
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
In
order
that
these
visits
might
be
visits
of
state
,
Mrs.
Boffin
's
equipage
was
ordered
out
.
  
<EOS>
This
consisted
of
a
long
hammer
-
headed
old
horse
,
formerly
used
in
the
business
,
attached
to
a
four
-
wheeled
chaise
of
the
same
period
,
which
had
long
been
exclusively
used
by
the
Harmony
Jail
poultry
as
the
favourite
laying
-
place
of
several
discreet
hens
.
<EOS>
An
unwonted
application
of
corn
to
the
horse
,
and
of
paint
and
varnish
to
the
carriage
,
when
both
fell
in
as
a
part
of
the
Boffin
legacy
,
had
made
what
Mr.
Boffin
considered
a
neat
turn
-
out
of
the
whole
;
and
a
driver
being
added
,
in
the
person
of
a
long
hammer
-
headed
young
man
who
was
a
very
good
match
for
the
horse
,
left
nothing
to
be
desired
.
<EOS>
He
,
too
,
had
been
formerly
used
in
the
business
,
but
was
now
entombed
by
an
honest
jobbing
tailor
of
the
district
in
a
perfect
Sepulchre
of
coat
and
gaiters
,
sealed
with
ponderous
buttons
.
  
<EOS>
Behind
this
domestic
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
took
their
seats
in
the
back
compartment
of
the
vehicle
:
which
was
sufficiently
commodious
,
but
had
an
undignified
and
alarming
tendency
,
in
getting
over
a
rough
crossing
,
to
hiccup
itself
away
from
the
front
compartment
.
<EOS>
On
their
being
descried
emerging
from
the
gates
of
the
Bower
,
the
neighbourhood
turned
out
at
door
and
window
to
salute
the
Boffins
.
<EOS>
Among
those
who
were
ever
and
again
left
behind
,
staring
after
the
equipage
,
were
many
youthful
spirits
,
who
hailed
it
in
stentorian
tones
with
such
congratulations
as
"
Nod
-
dy
Bof
-
fin
!
"
<EOS>
"
Bof
-
fin
's
mon
-
ey
!
"
<EOS>
"
Down
with
the
dust
,
Bof
-
fin
!
"
and
other
similar
compliments
.
<EOS>
These
,
the
hammer
-
headed
young
man
took
in
such
ill
part
that
he
often
impaired
the
majesty
of
the
progress
by
pulling
up
short
,
and
making
as
though
he
would
alight
to
exterminate
the
offenders
;
a
purpose
from
which
he
only
allowed
himself
to
be
dissuaded
after
long
and
lively
arguments
with
his
employers
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
the
Bower
district
was
left
behind
,
and
the
peaceful
dwelling
of
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvery
was
gained
.
<EOS>
The
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
's
abode
was
a
very
modest
abode
,
because
his
income
was
a
very
modest
income
.
<EOS>
He
was
officially
accessible
to
every
blundering
old
woman
who
had
incoherence
to
bestow
upon
him
,
and
readily
received
the
Boffins
.
<EOS>
He
was
quite
a
young
man
,
expensively
educated
and
wretchedly
paid
,
with
quite
a
young
wife
and
half
a
dozen
quite
young
children
.
<EOS>
He
was
under
the
necessity
of
teaching
and
translating
from
the
classics
,
to
eke
out
his
scanty
means
,
yet
was
generally
expected
to
have
more
time
to
spare
than
the
idlest
person
in
the
parish
,
and
more
money
than
the
richest
.
<EOS>
He
accepted
the
needless
inequalities
and
inconsistencies
of
his
life
,
with
a
kind
of
conventional
submission
that
was
almost
slavish
;
and
any
daring
layman
who
would
have
adjusted
such
burdens
as
his
,
more
decently
and
graciously
,
would
have
had
small
help
from
him
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
ready
patient
face
and
manner
,
and
yet
with
a
latent
smile
that
showed
a
quick
enough
observation
of
Mrs.
Boffin
's
dress
,
Mr.
Milvey
,
in
his
little
book
-
room
---
charged
with
sounds
and
cries
as
though
the
six
children
above
were
coming
down
through
the
ceiling
,
and
the
roasting
leg
of
mutton
below
were
coming
up
through
the
floor
---
listened
to
Mrs.
Boffin
's
statement
of
her
want
of
an
orphan
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
said
Mr.
Milvey
,
"
that
you
have
never
had
a
child
of
your
own
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Never
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
like
the
Kings
and
Queens
in
the
Fairy
Tales
,
I
suppose
you
have
wished
for
one
?
"
  
<EOS>
In
a
general
way
,
yes
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Milvey
smiled
again
,
as
he
remarked
to
himself
,
"
Those
kings
and
queens
were
always
wishing
for
children
.
<EOS>
"
It
occurring
to
him
,
perhaps
,
that
if
they
had
been
Curates
,
their
wishes
might
have
tended
in
the
opposite
direction
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"
he
pursued
,
"
we
had
better
take
Mrs.
Milvey
into
our
Council
.
<EOS>
She
is
indispensable
to
me
.
<EOS>
If
you
please
,
I
'll
call
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
Mr.
Milvey
called
,
"
Margaretta
,
my
dear
!
"
and
Mrs.
Milvey
came
down
.
<EOS>
A
pretty
,
bright
little
woman
,
something
worn
by
anxiety
,
who
had
repressed
many
pretty
tastes
and
bright
fancies
,
and
substituted
in
their
stead
,
schools
,
soup
,
flannel
,
coals
,
and
all
the
week
-
day
cares
and
Sunday
coughs
of
a
large
population
,
young
and
old
.
<EOS>
As
gallantly
had
Mr.
Milvey
repressed
much
in
himself
that
naturally
belonged
to
his
old
studies
and
old
fellow
-
students
,
and
taken
up
among
the
poor
and
their
children
with
the
hard
crumbs
of
life
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
my
dear
,
whose
good
fortune
you
have
heard
of
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Milvey
,
with
the
most
unaffected
grace
in
the
world
,
congratulated
them
,
and
was
glad
to
see
them
.
<EOS>
Yet
her
engaging
face
,
being
an
open
as
well
as
a
perceptive
one
,
was
not
without
her
husband
's
latent
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Boffin
wishes
to
adopt
a
little
boy
,
my
dear
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Milvey
,
looking
rather
alarmed
,
her
husband
added
:
  
"
<EOS>
An
orphan
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
said
Mrs.
Milvey
,
reassured
for
her
own
little
boys
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
was
thinking
,
Margaretta
,
that
perhaps
old
Mrs.
Goody
's
grandchild
might
answer
the
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
my
dear
Frank
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
that
would
do
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
no
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
smiling
Mrs.
Boffin
,
feeling
it
incumbent
on
her
to
take
part
in
the
conversation
,
and
being
charmed
with
the
emphatic
little
wife
and
her
ready
interest
,
here
offered
her
acknowledgments
and
inquired
what
there
was
against
him
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
,
"
said
Mrs.
Milvey
,
glancing
at
the
Reverend
Frank
"
---
<EOS>
and
I
believe
my
husband
will
agree
with
me
when
he
considers
it
again
---
that
you
could
possibly
keep
that
orphan
clean
from
snuff
.
<EOS>
Because
his
grandmother
takes
so
many
ounces
,
and
drops
it
over
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
he
would
not
be
living
with
his
grandmother
then
,
Margaretta
,
"
 
said
Mr.
Milvey
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Frank
,
but
it
would
be
impossible
to
keep

from
Mrs.
Boffin
's
house
;
and
the
more
there
was
to
eat

there
,
the
oftener
she
would
go
.
<EOS>
And
she
is
an

woman
.
<EOS>
I
hope

's
not

to
remember
that
last
Christmas
Eve
<EOS>
she
drank
eleven

of
tea
,
and
grumbled
all

time
.
<EOS>
And
she
is
not
a
grateful
woman
,
Frank
.
<EOS>
You
recollect
her
addressing
a

outside
this
house
,
about
her

,
when
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
Would
little
Harrison
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
Frank
!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

no

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
<EOS>
but

Boffin

like
an
orphan

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
true
again
,
"
said

Milvey
,

.
<EOS>
"
If

girl

---
"
  
"
But
,

,

Boffin

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

Milvey
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tom
Bocker
is

boy
"
(
thoughtfully
)
.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

;

's

,

,
"
that
's

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

"

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
At

,

you
so

,

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
To

!
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
We

,
I

"

Milvey
,

"

"
over

.
<EOS>
And

---

.
"
  
<EOS>
Accordingly
,

,

.
<EOS>
Then
,

took

"

"

.
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
both

were

if

,

,
in

;
and
so

with

and
good

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
old

,
"

,

:
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

,

,
that
to

Wilfer
's
was

than

,
on

of
getting
into
that

;
three

bell
producing
no
external

,
though
each
was
attended
by
audible

of

and

within
.
<EOS>
At

fourth

---
vindictively

by
the
hammer
-
headed
young
man
 
---
Miss
Lavinia
appeared
,
emerging
from
the
house
in
an
accidental

,
with
a
bonnet
and
parasol
,
as
designing
to
take

.
<EOS>
The
young

was
astonished
to

at
the

,
and
expressed

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
's
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
!
"
<EOS>
growled

hammer
-
headed
young
man
through

,
and
at

shaking

,
as
if

were
on

in

;
"
they
've

here

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
!
<EOS>
"
returned

man
,

.
  
<EOS>
Miss

tripped

to

,

down

,

,

.
"
Please

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Our

.
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
's

,

Bella
's

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.

Boffin
<EOS>
,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
Strained

's

,

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
<EOS>
Miss.
"
  
"

---

Ma

.
"
  
<EOS>
Excited

of

's

,

's

,

George
Sampson
's

.
  
<EOS>
After

,
which

,

,

for
blindman
's

,

Boffin

of
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
majestically

,
and
with
a

in

side
:
which
was
her
company

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
"
said

Wilfer
,
after

,
and
as

under

,

,
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
To

,

,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,

,
"
of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

,
"

,

,
"
you

"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon

,
"
said

Wilfer
.
"
<EOS>
'
Twere
unjust
to
visit
upon
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
a

which
was
doubtless
a
dispensation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
These
words
were
rendered
the
more

a

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
fairly
meant
,
I
am
sure
,
"
remarked

honest
Mr.
Boffin
;
 
"
Mrs.
Boffin
and
me
,
ma'am
,
are
plain
people
,
and
we
do
n't
want
to
pretend

,

:

.
<EOS>
Consequently
,
we
make

call
to

,
that
we
shall

your
daughter
's

,

daughter

in

.
<EOS>
In

,
we

,

sharing

a
going

.
<EOS>
We

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

!
"
said

Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
<EOS>
Let
's
be
comfortable
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
bent

in

her

,
and

:
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Which

I

understand
<EOS>
is

Boffin

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
<EOS>
"
the

Mrs.
Boffin
put

.
"
<EOS>
Naturally
,
Miss
Bella
,
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
-
h
!
"
said

Wilfer
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
Bella
is
accessible
and
shall

.
"
<EOS>
Then
opening

door
a
little

,

with

outside
it
,
the
good
lady
made
the

,
"
Send
Miss
Bella
to
me
!
"
<EOS>
Which
proclamation
,
though
grandly
formal
,
and
one
might
almost
say

,
to
hear
,
was
in
fact

with
her

reproachfully

on
that
young
lady
in
the
flesh
---
and
in
so
much
of
it
that
she
was
retiring
with

into
the
small
closet
under
the
stairs
,
apprehensive
of
the
emergence
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
avocations
of
R.
W.
,
my

,
"
Mrs.
Wilfer
explained
,
on

,
"
keep
him
fully

in
the
City
at
this
time
of
the
day
,
or
he
would
have
had
the
honor
of
participating
in
your
reception
beneath

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
pleasant
premises
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
cheerfully
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
sir
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
correcting
him
,
"
it
is
the
abode
of
conscious
though
independent
Poverty
.
"
  
<EOS>
Finding
it
rather
difficult
to
pursue
the
conversation
down
this
road
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
sat
staring
at
mid
-
air
,
and
Mrs.
Wilfer
sat
silently
giving
them
to
understand
that
every
breath
she
drew
required
to
be
drawn
with
a
self
-
denial
rarely
paralleled
in
history
,
until
Miss
Bella
appeared
:
whom
Mrs.
Wilfer
presented
,
and
to
whom
she
explained
the
purpose
of
the
visitors
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
obliged
to
you
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Miss
Bella
,
coldly
shaking
her
curls
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
doubt
if
I
have
the
inclination
to
go
out
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Bella
!
"
Mrs.
Wilfer
admonished
her
;
"
Bella
,
you
must
conquer
this
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
do
what
your
Ma
says
,
and
conquer

,
my
dear
,
"
urged
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
because
we
shall
be
so
glad
to
have
you
,
and
because
you
are
much
too
pretty
to
keep
yourself
shut
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
that
,
the
pleasant
creature
gave
her
a
kiss
,
and
patted
her
on
her
dimpled
shoulders
;
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
sitting
stiffly
by
,
like
a
functionary
presiding
over
an
interview
previous
to
an
execution
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
going
to
move
into
a
nice
house
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
who
was
woman
enough
to
compromise

Boffin
on
that

,
when
he
could
n't
very
well

;
"
and
we
are

<EOS>
A
MARRIAGE
CONTRACT
.
 
<EOS>
There
is
excitement
in

.
<EOS>
The
mature
young
lady
is
going
to
be
married
(
powder
and
all
)
to
the
mature
young
gentleman
,
and
she
is
to
be
married
from
the
Veneering
house
,
and
the
Veneerings
are
to
give
the
breakfast
.
<EOS>
The
Analytical
,
who
objects
as
a
matter
of
principle
to
everything
that
occurs
on
the
premises
,
necessarily
objects
to
the
match
;
but
his
consent
has
been
dispensed
with
,
and
a
spring
-
van
is
delivering
its
load
of
greenhouse
plants
at
the
door
,
in
order
that
to
-
morrow
's
feast
may
be
crowned
with
flowers
.
  
<EOS>
The
mature
young
lady
is
a
lady
of
property
.
<EOS>
The
mature
young
gentleman
is
a
gentleman
of
property
.
<EOS>
He
invests
his
property
.
<EOS>
He
goes
,
in
a
condescending
amateurish
way
,
into
the
City
,
attends
meetings
of
Directors
,
and
has
to
do
with
traffic
in
Shares
.
<EOS>
As
is
well
known
to
the
wise
in
their
generation
,
traffic
in
Shares
is
the
one
thing
to
have
to
do
with
in
this
world
.
<EOS>
Have
no
antecedents
,
no
established
character
,
no
cultivation
,
no
ideas
,
no
manners
;
have
Shares
.
<EOS>
Have
Shares
enough
to
be
on
Boards
of
Direction
in
capital
letters
,
oscillate
on
mysterious
business
between
London
and
Paris
,
and
be
great
.
<EOS>
Where
does
he
come
from
?
<EOS>
Shares
.
<EOS>
Where
is
he
going
to
?
<EOS>
Shares
.
<EOS>
What
are
his
tastes
?
<EOS>
Shares
.
<EOS>
Has
he
any
principles
?
<EOS>
Shares
.
<EOS>
What
squeezes
him
into
Parliament
?
<EOS>
Shares
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
never
of
himself
achieved
success
in
anything
,
never
originated
anything
,
never
produced
anything
?
<EOS>
Sufficient
answer
to
all
;
Shares
.
<EOS>
O
mighty
Shares
!
<EOS>
To
set
those
blaring
images
so
high
,
and
to
cause
us
smaller
vermin
,
as
under
the
influence
of
henbane
or
opium
,
to
cry
out
,
night
and
day
,
"
Relieve

,

,

,
only

rank

,
and
fatten
on

"
!
  
<EOS>
While
the
Loves

have

this

,
which
is
to

kindled
to
-
morrow
,
Mr.
Twemlow
has
suffered
much
in

.
<EOS>
It
would

that
both
the
mature
young

and
the
mature
young

must

Veneering
's

.
<EOS>
Wards
of

,

?
<EOS>
Yet

,

.
<EOS>
Veneering
has
been
in

,

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
  
<EOS>
So
,

,

's
,

,

,

;

low
,

over

livery

,

,

most

.
<EOS>
For
,

once

,

,

(
as

)
,

(

)
,

money
,
but
had
married
him
for
love
,
he
and
she
would
have
been
happy
(
which
they
would

been
)
,
and
that
she
has
a
tenderness
for
him
still
(
whereas
her
toughness
is
a
proverb
)
.
<EOS>
Brooding

fire
,
with

in

,
and

,

.
"
<EOS>
No
Adorable
to
bear

here
!
<EOS>
"
thinks

.
"
<EOS>
No
Adorable
at
the
club
!
<EOS>
A
waste
,
a
waste
,
a
waste
,
my
Twemlow
!
"
<EOS>
And
so
drops
asleep
,
and
has
galvanic

all
over

.
  
<EOS>
Betimes
next
morning
,
<EOS>
that
horrible
old
Lady
Tippins
(

,

"

what
?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Why

?
"

<EOS>
She

Whereabout

She

,

,

<EOS>
If

<EOS>

"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

!

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
But
,

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

What

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
whereof

"

<EOS>
Another

,

.
<EOS>
They

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
In

,

<EOS>
In

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
So

---
<EOS>
all

,

sociably
 
---

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

Tippins
,

---

,

---

,

.
  
<EOS>
All

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

Mr.
and

Lammle
on

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
have
walked
for

,
and
one

see
by

that

,

,

;
for
,

sand

,
and
the

has

.
<EOS>
As
if

were
of

family

,

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

me
,

,
Sophronia
---
"
  
Thus
he
begins
after
a

,
when
Sophronia
flashes

,
and
turns
upon
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
put
it
upon
me
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
ask
you
,
do
you
mean
to
tell
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
falls
silent
again
,
and
they
walk
as

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
opens
her
nostrils
and
bites
her
under
-
lip
;
Mr.
Lammle
takes
his
gingerous
whiskers
in
his
left
hand
,
and
,
bringing
them
together
,
frowns
furtively
at
his
beloved
,
out
of
a
thick
gingerous
bush
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
I
mean
to
say
!
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
after
a
time
repeats
,
with
indignation
.
<EOS>
"
Putting
it
on
me
!
<EOS>
The
unmanly
disingenuousness
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
stops
,
releases
his
whiskers
,
and
looks
at
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
haughtily
replies
,
without
stopping
,
and
without
looking
back
.
<EOS>
"
The
meanness
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
is
at
her
side
again
in
a
pace
or
two
,
and
he
retorts
,
"
That
is
not
what
you
said
.
<EOS>
You
said
disingenuousness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
if
I
did
?
"
  
"
There
is
no
`
`
if
"
"
in
the
case
.
<EOS>
You
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
,
then
.
<EOS>
And
what
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
of
it
?
"
says
Mr.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Have
you
the
face
to
utter
the
word
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
face
,
too
!
"
replied
Mrs.
Lammle
,
staring
at
him
with
cold
scorn
.
<EOS>
"
Pray
,
how
dare
you
,
sir
,
utter
the
word
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
did
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
this
happens
to
be
true
,
Mrs.
Lammle
is
thrown
on
the
feminine
resource
of
saying
,
"
I
do
n't
care
what
you
uttered
or
did
not
utter
.
"
  
<EOS>
After
a
little
more
walking
and
a
little
more
silence
,
Mr.
Lammle
breaks
the
latter
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
proceed
in
your
own
way
.
<EOS>
You
claim
a
right
to
ask
me
do
I
mean
to
tell
you
.
<EOS>
Do
I
mean
to
tell
you
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
you
are
a
man
of
property
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
married
me
on
false
pretences
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
be
it
.
<EOS>
Next
comes
what
you
mean
to
say
.
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
to
say
you
are
a
woman
of
property
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
married
me
on
false
pretences
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
were
so
dull
a
fortune
-
hunter
that
you
deceived
yourself
,
or
if
you
were
so
greedy
and
grasping
that
you
were
over
-
willing
to
be
deceived
by
appearances
,
is
it
my
fault
,
you
adventurer
?
"
<EOS>
the
lady
demands
,
with
great
asperity
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
asked
Veneering
,
and
he
told
me
you
were
rich
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Veneering
!
"
<EOS>
with
great
contempt
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
what
does
Veneering
know
about
me
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
he
not
your
trustee
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
trustee
,
but
the
one
you
saw
on
the
day
when
you
fraudulently
married
me
.
<EOS>
And
his
trust
is
not
a
very
difficult
one
,
for
it
is
only
an
annuity
of
a
hundred
and
fifteen
pounds
.
<EOS>
I
think
there
are
some
odd
shillings
or
pence
,
if
you
are
very
particular
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
bestows
a
by
no
means
loving
look
upon
the
partner
of
his
joys
and
sorrows
,
and
he
mutters
something
;
but
checks
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Question
for
question
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
turn
again
,
Mrs.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
What
made
you
suppose
me
a
man
of
property
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
made
me
suppose
you
so
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
will
deny
that
you
always
presented
yourself
to
me
in
that
character
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
asked
somebody
,
too
.
<EOS>
Come
,
Mrs.
Lammle
,
admission
for
admission
.
<EOS>
You
asked
somebody
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
asked
Veneering
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
Veneering
knew
as
much
of
me
as
he
knew
of
you
,
or
as
anybody
knows
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
After
more
silent
walking
,
the
bride
stops
short
,
to
say
in
a
passionate
manner
:
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
will
forgive
the
Veneerings
for
this
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Neither
will
I
,
"
returns
the
bridegroom
.
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
they
walk
again
;
she
,
making
those
angry
spirts
in
the
sand
;
he
,
dragging
that
dejected
tail
.
<EOS>
The
tide
is
low
,
and
seems
to
have
thrown
them
together
high
on
the
bare
shore
.
<EOS>
A
gull
comes
sweeping
by
their
heads
,
and
flouts
them
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
golden
surface
on
the
brown
cliffs
but
now
,
and
behold
they
are
only
damp
earth
.
<EOS>
A
taunting
roar
comes
from
the
sea
,
and
the
farout
rollers
mount
upon
one
another
,
to
look
at
the
entrapped
impostors
,
and
to
join
in
impish
and
exultant
gambols
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
pretend
to
believe
,
"
Mrs.
Lammle
resumes
,
sternly
,
"
when
you
talk
of
my
marrying
you
for
worldly
advantages
,
that
it
was
within
the
bounds
of
reasonable
probability
that
I
would
have
married
you
for
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Again
there
are
two
sides
to
the
question
,
Mrs.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
pretend
to
believe
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
first
deceive
me
and
then
insult
me
!
"
<EOS>
cries
the
lady
,
with
a
heaving
bosom
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
originated
nothing
.
<EOS>
The
double
-
edged
question
was
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
mine
!
"
<EOS>
the
bride
repeats
,
and
her
parasol
breaks
in
her
angry
hand
.
  
<EOS>
His
colour
has
turned
to
a
livid
white
,
and
ominous
marks
have
come
to
light
about
his
nose
,
as
if
the
finger
of
the
very
devil
himself
had
,
within
the
last
few
moments
,
touched
it
here
and
there
.
<EOS>
But
he
has
repressive
power
,
and
she
has
none
.
  
<EOS>
"
Throw
it
away
,
"
he
coolly
recommends
as
to
the
parasol
;
"
you
have
made
it
useless
;
you
look
ridiculous
with
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Whereupon
she
calls
him
in
her
rage
,
"
A
deliberate
villain
,
"
and
so
casts
the
broken
thing
from
her
as
that
it
strikes
him
in
falling
.
<EOS>
The
finger
-
marks
are
something
whiter
for
the
instant
,
but
he
walks
on
at
her
side
.
  
<EOS>
She
bursts
into
tears
,
declaring
herself
the
wretchedest
,
the
most
deceived
,
the
worst
-
used
,
of
women
.
<EOS>
Then
she
says
that
if
she
had
the
courage
to
kill
herself
,
she
would
do
it
.
<EOS>
Then
she
calls
him
vile
impostor
.
<EOS>
Then
she
asks
him
,
why
,
in
the
disappointment
of
his
base
speculation
,
he
does
not
take
her
life
with
his
own
hand
,
under
the
present
favourable
circumstances
.
<EOS>
Then
she
cries
again
.
<EOS>
Then
she
is
enraged
again
,
and
makes
some
mention
of
swindlers
.
<EOS>
Finally
,
she
sits
down
crying
on
a
block
of
stone
,
and
is
in
all
the
known
and
unknown
humours
of
her
sex
at
once
.
<EOS>
Pending
her
changes
,
those
aforesaid
marks
in
his
face
have
come
and
gone
,
now
here
now
there
,
like
white
stops
of
a
pipe
on
which
the
diabolical
performer
has
played
a
tune
.
<EOS>
Also
his
livid
lips
are
parted
at
last
,
as
if
he
were
breathless
with
running
.
<EOS>
Yet
he
is
not
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
get
up
,
Mrs.
Lammle
,
and
let
us
speak
reasonably
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
sits
upon
her
stone
,
and
takes
no
heed
of
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Get
up
,
I
tell
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Raising
her
head
,
she
looks
contemptuously
in
his
face
,
and
repeats
,
<EOS>
"
You
tell
me
!
<EOS>
Tell
me
,
forsooth
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
affects
not
to
know
that
his
eyes
are
fastened
on
her
as
she
droops
her
head
again
;
but
her
whole
figure
reveals
that
she
knows
it
uneasily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Enough
of
this
.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
<EOS>
Get
up
.
"
  
<EOS>
Yielding
to
his
hand
,
she
rises
,
and
they
walk
again
;
but
this
time
with
their
faces
turned
towards
their
place
of
residence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Lammle
,
we
have
both
been
deceiving
,
and
we
have
both
been
deceived
.
<EOS>
We
have
both
been
biting
,
and
we
have
both
been
bitten
.
<EOS>
In
a
nut
-
shell
,
there
's
the
state
of
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
sought
me
out
---
"
  
"
Tut
!
<EOS>
Let
us
have
done
with
that
.
<EOS>
We
know
very
well
how
it
was
.
<EOS>
Why
should
you
and
I
talk
about
it
,
when
you
and
I
ca
n't
disguise
it
?
<EOS>
To
proceed
.
<EOS>
I
am
disappointed
and
cut
a
poor
figure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
no
one
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Some
one
---
<EOS>
and
I
was
coming
to
you
,
if
you
had
waited
a
moment
.
<EOS>
You
,
too
,
are
disappointed
and
cut
a
poor
figure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
An
injured
figure
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
now
cool
enough
,
Sophronia
,
to
see
that
you
ca
n't
be
injured
without
my
being
equally
injured
;
and
that
therefore
the
mere
word
is
not
to
the
purpose
.
<EOS>
When
I
look
back
,
I
wonder
how
I
can
have
been
such
a
fool
as
to
take
you
to
<EOS>
so
great
an
extent
upon
trust
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
when
I
look
back
---
"
the
bride
cries
,
interrupting
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
when
you
look
back
,
you
wonder
how
you
can
have
been
 
---
you
'll
excuse
the
word
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Most
certainly
,
with
so
much
reason
.
"
  
"
---
Such
a
fool
as
to
take
me
to
<EOS>
so
great
an
extent
upon
trust
.
<EOS>
But
the
folly
is
committed
on
both
sides
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
get
rid
of
you
;
 
you
can
not
get
rid
of
me
.
<EOS>
What
follows
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shame
and
misery
,
"
the
bride
bitterly
replies
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
A
mutual
understanding
follows
,
and
I
think
it
may
carry
us
through
.
<EOS>
Here
I
split
my
discourse
(
give
me
your
arm
,
Sophronia
)
,
into
three
heads
,
to
make
it
shorter
and
plainer
.
<EOS>
Firstly
,
it
's
enough
to
have
been
done
,
without
the
mortification
of
being
known
to
have
been
done
.
<EOS>
So
we
agree
to
keep
the
fact
to
ourselves
.
<EOS>
You
agree
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
it
is
possible
,
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Possible
!
<EOS>
We
have
pretended
well
enough
to
one
another
.
<EOS>
Ca
n't
we
,
united
,
pretend
to
the
world
?
<EOS>
Agreed
.
<EOS>
Secondly
,
we
owe
the
Veneerings
a
grudge
,
and
we
owe
all
other
people
the
grudge
of
wishing
them
to
be
taken
in
,
as
we
ourselves
have
been
taken
in
.
<EOS>
Agreed
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
Agreed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
come
smoothly
to
thirdly
.
<EOS>
You
have
called
me
an
adventurer
,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
So
I
am
.
<EOS>
In
plain
uncomplimentary
English
,
so
I
am
.
<EOS>
So
are
you
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
So
are
many
people
.
<EOS>
We
agree
to
keep
our
own
secret
,
and
to
work
together
in
furtherance
of
our
own
schemes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
schemes
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Any
scheme
that
will
bring
us
money
.
<EOS>
By
our
own
schemes
,
I
mean
our
joint
interest
.
<EOS>
Agreed
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
answers
,
after
a
little
hesitation
,
"
I
suppose
so
.
<EOS>
Agreed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Carried
at
once
,
you
see
!
<EOS>
Now
,
Sophronia
,
only
half
a
dozen
words
more
.
<EOS>
We
know
one
another
perfectly
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
tempted
into
twitting
me
with
the
past
knowledge
that
you
have
of
me
,
because
it
is
identical
with
the
past
knowledge
that
I
have
of
you
,
and
in
twitting
me
,
you
twit
yourself
,
and
I
do
n't
want
to
hear
you
do
it
.
<EOS>
With
this
good
understanding
established
between
us
,
it
is
better
never
done
.
<EOS>
To
wind
up
all
:
---
You
have
shown
temper
today
,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
betrayed
into
doing
so
again
,
because
I
have
a
Devil
of
a
temper
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
the
happy
pair
,
with
this
hopeful
marriage
contract
thus
signed
,
sealed
,
and
delivered
,
repair
homeward
.
<EOS>
If
,
when
those
infernal
finger
-
marks
were
on
the
white
and
breathless
countenance
of
Alfred
Lammle
,
Esquire
,
they
denoted
that
he
conceived
the
purpose
of
subduing
his
dear
wife
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
,
by
at
once
divesting
her
of
any
lingering
reality
or
pretence
of
self
-
respect
,
the
purpose
would
seem
to
have
been
presently
executed
.
<EOS>
The
mature
young
lady
has
mighty
little
need
of
powder
,
now
,
for
her
downcast
face
,
as
he
escorts
her
in
the
light
of
the
setting
sun
to
their
abode
of
bliss
.
   
<EOS>
PODSNAPPERY
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
was
well
to
do
,
and
stood
very
high
in
Mr.
Podsnap
's
opinion
.
<EOS>
Beginning
with
a
good
inheritance
,
he
had
married
a
good
inheritance
,
and
had
thriven
exceedingly
in
the
Marine
Insurance
way
,
and
was
quite
satisfied
.
<EOS>
He
never
could
make
out
why
everybody
was
not
quite
satisfied
,
and
he
felt
conscious
that
he
set
a
brilliant
social
example
in
being
particularly
well
satisfied
with
most
things
,
and
,
above
all
other
things
,
with
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
happily
acquainted
with
his
own
merit
and
importance
,
Mr.
Podsnap
settled
that
whatever
he
put
behind
him
he
put
out
of
existence
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
dignified
conclusiveness
---
not
to
add
a
grand
convenience
---
in
this
way
of
getting
rid
of
disagreeables
which
had
done
much
towards
establishing
Mr.
Podsnap
in
his
lofty
place
in
Mr.
Podsnap
's
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
know
about
it
;
I
do
n't
choose
to
discuss
it
;
I
do
n't
admit
it
!
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
had
even
acquired
a
peculiar
flourish
of
his
right
arm
in
often
clearing
the
world
of
its
most
difficult
problems
,
by
sweeping
them
behind
him
(
and
consequently
sheer
away
)
with
those
words
and
a
flushed
face
.
<EOS>
For
they
affronted
him
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
's
world
was
not
a
very
large
world
,
morally
;
no
,
nor
even
geographically
:
seeing
that
although
his
business
was
sustained
upon
commerce
with
other
countries
,
he
considered
other
countries
,
with
that
important
reservation
,
a
mistake
,
and
of
their
manners
and
customs
would
conclusively
observe
,
"
Not
English
!
"
<EOS>
when
,
Presto
!
<EOS>
with
a
flourish
of
the
arm
,
and
a
flush
of
the
face
,
they
were
swept
away
.
<EOS>
Elsewise
,
the
world
got
up
at
eight
,
shaved
close
at
a
quarterpast
,
breakfasted
at
nine
,
went
to
the
City
at
ten
,
came
home
at
half
-
past
five
,
and
dined
at
seven
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
's
notions
of
the
Arts
in
their
integrity
might
have
been

.
<EOS>
Literature
;
 
large
print
,
respectfully
descriptive
of
getting
up
at
eight
,
shaving
close
at
a
quarter
past
,
breakfasting
at
nine
,
going
to
the
City

,

,

.
<EOS>
Painting

;
models

Professors
of
getting
up
at
eight
,
shaving
close
at
a
quarter
past
,
breakfasting
at
nine
,
going
to
the
City
at
ten
,

,

.
<EOS>
Music
;
a

(
without

)
on

,
sedately

of
getting
up
at
eight
,
shaving
close
at
a

past
,

nine
,
going
to
the
City

,

,

.
<EOS>
Nothing
else

to
those
same
vagrants
the
Arts
,
on

of

.
<EOS>
Nothing
else
To
Be
---
anywhere
!
  
<EOS>
As
a
so
eminently
respectable
man
,
Mr.
Podsnap
was
sensible
of
its
being
required
of
him
to
take
Providence
under
his
protection
.
<EOS>
Consequently
he
always
knew
exactly
what
Providence
meant
.
<EOS>
Inferior
and
less
respectable
men
might
fall
short
of
that
mark
,
but
Mr.
Podsnap
was
always
up
to
it
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
very
remarkable
(
and
must
have
been
very
comfortable
)
that
what
Providence
meant
,
was
invariably
what
Mr.
Podsnap
meant
.
  
<EOS>
These
may
be
said
to
have
been
the
articles
of
a
faith
and
school
which
the
present
chapter
takes
the

of
calling
,
after
its
representative
man
,
Podsnappery
.
<EOS>
They
were
confined
within
close
bounds
,
as
Mr.
Podsnap
's
own
head
was
confined
by
his
shirt
-
collar
;
 
and
they
were
enunciated
with
a
sounding
pomp
that
smacked
of
the
creaking
of
Mr.
Podsnap
's
own

.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
Miss
Podsnap
.
<EOS>
And
this
young
rocking
-
horse
was
being
trained
in
her
mother
's
art
of
prancing
in
a

without

.
<EOS>
But
the

was
not

to
her
,
and
in
truth

was
but
an
undersized

,
with
high

,

,

,

of
nose
,
who

,

,

her

's
head
-

and
her
father
from

---
crushed
by
the
mere
dead
-
weight
of
Podsnappery
.
  
<EOS>
A
certain

Mr.

's

he

"
the
young
person
"
may
be

have

embodied
in
Miss
Podsnap
,
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
It

an

and
exacting

,
as
requiring
everything
in
the

to

to

.
<EOS>
The
question
about
everything
was
,
would

bring
a

the
young
person
?
<EOS>
And
the
inconvenience
of
the
young

was
,
that
,
according
to
Mr.
Podsnap
,
she
seemed
always
liable
to
burst
into
blushes
when
there
was
no

.
<EOS>
There
appeared

be
no
line

between
the
young

's

,
and
another
person
's
guiltiest
knowledge
.
<EOS>
Take
Mr.
Podsnap
's
word
for
it
,

,

,

,

,

all

to

of

.
  
<EOS>
The
Podsnaps
lived
in
a

angle

Portman

.
<EOS>
They
were
a
kind

people
certain
to

,

.
<EOS>
Miss
Podsnap
's

had

,

on
this

,

;
for
,
Mr.
Podsnap
's
young

was

little

,
and
had

.
<EOS>
Miss
Podsnap
's
early
views

,

.

<EOS>
Mr.

,

's

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
Hideous

Podsnap
plate
.
<EOS>
Everything
was
made
to
look
as

,

.
<EOS>
Everything

"
Here

;

;
---

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A

epergne
,

.
<EOS>

.

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
But

:

---

<EOS>
Quoi
donc
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
gentleman
with
the
lumpy

having
for

of
all
that

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

"
<EOS>
Whether

,
any

---
"

,

;
 
<EOS>
"
But
what

tokenz
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Marks
,
"

;
<EOS>
"

---
  
Traces
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Of

?
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

"
  
"

,

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our

,
"

,
"
is

.
<EOS>
Ours

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

,

,
"
Esker
,
"

<EOS>
"
It

"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
No

"
  
"
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
---
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
This

Blest
,

---

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
"

,

"

,

,

,

of
a
young

,
which
one
would
seek
in

the
Nations

.
"
  
<EOS>
Having

,
Mr.
Podsnap
's

flushed
,
as
he
thought
of
the
remote

of

being
at
all

by

of
any

;
and
,
with

,
he
put
the
rest
of
Europe
and
the
whole

Asia
,

,

nowhere
.
  
<EOS>
The
audience
were
much
edified
by
this
passage
of
words
;
and
Mr.
Podsnap
,
feeling
that
he
was
in
rather
remarkable
force
to
-
day
,
became
smiling
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Has
anything
more
been
heard
,
Veneering
,
"
he

,
"
of
the
lucky
legatee
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
more
,
"

Veneering
,
"
than
that

come

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
Veneering
was

,
for

had

upon
the
Harmon
Murder
,
and
had
turned
the
social
distinction
it
conferred
upon
him
to
the

of
making
several
dozen
of
bran
-
new
bosom
-
friends
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
such
another

hit
would
almost
have
set

up
in
that
way
to
his

.
<EOS>
So
,

himself
to
the
most
desirable
of

,
while
Mrs.
Veneering
secured
the
next
most
desirable
,
he
plunged
into
the
case
,
and
emerged
from

twenty

with
a
Bank
Director
in

.
<EOS>
In

mean
time
,
Mrs.
Veneering
had
dived
into
the
same
waters
for
a
wealthy
Ship
-
Broker
,
and
had
brought

up
,

,

.
<EOS>
Then
Mrs.
Veneering
had
to
relate
,
to

,
how
she
had
been
to
see
the
girl
,
and
how
she
was
really
pretty
,
and
(
considering
her
station
)
presentable
.
<EOS>
And
this
she
did
with
such

of

eight

and

,
that
she
happily
laid

General
Officer
,
his

and

,
and
not

which

,
but

lively
friends
within

.
  
<EOS>
Although
Mr.
Podsnap
would
in

have
highly

of
Bodies
in
rivers
as
ineligible
topics
with
reference
to
the
cheek
of
the
young

,
he
had
,
as
one

,
a

in

which

.
<EOS>
As

were

,
too
,
in

company
from
speechless

of
the
wine
-

,

paid
,
and

.
  
<EOS>
And
now
the
haunch
of
mutton
vapour
-

having
received
a
gamey

,
and
a

last

of

and

,
was
quite
ready
,
and
the

came
;
but

-

,

.
<EOS>
And
who
now

,
he

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

,
but
there

no

(
the
young

)
in

articles
of
Podsnappery
.
<EOS>
Bald

to
Mr.
Podsnap
on
the

;
sleek

,
with

,

Podsnap
and

;

,

;

.
<EOS>
All
this

and

,
poor

Miss
Podsnap
,
whose

(
if

)

in
the

of
her
mother
's

,
kept

as

,
and
appeared

be

on
many

of
the
day
.
<EOS>
It

somehow
understood
,
as
a
secret
article
in
the
state
proprieties
of
Podsnappery
that
nothing

the
day
.
<EOS>
Consequently

damsel
's
nativity

up
and

,
as

were

all

that

that

.
  
<EOS>
The
Lammles
were
so

Veneerings
that

not

from

;

,

,

---
 
certainly

one

---

,
"
Why

?
"
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

That

?
"
<EOS>

,
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

.
  
<EOS>

,

,
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
Indeed
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

Lammle
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
am

.
<EOS>
But
Ma
talks
!
"
  
<EOS>
That

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Fond

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
At

---
do

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
M
---
m
---
m
---
m
---
music
.
"
<EOS>
So

Lammle
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't

.
<EOS>
Ma

.
<EOS>
"
  
(

,

)
  
<EOS>
"
Of

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
?
<EOS>
With

?
<EOS>
Truly
,

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca

,
"

---
<EOS>

wo

My

!
<EOS>

!

<EOS>
"
No

wo

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gracious
!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

wo

,

?

<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
How

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
About

-

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
<EOS>
Ma'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

?
"

Podsnap

<EOS>
"
Then

do
n't

now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
"
said

Podsnap
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
it
is
such

thing
!
<EOS>
If
I
was
wicked
enough
---
and
strong

---
to
kill

,

should

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
was
such
an

new
view
of
the
Terpsichorean
art
as
socially
practised
,
that
Mrs.
Lammle
looked
at
her
young
friend
in
some
astonishment
.
<EOS>
Her
young
friend
sat
nervously
twiddling
her
fingers
in
a
pinioned
attitude
,
as
if
she
were
trying
to
hide
her
elbows
.
<EOS>
But
this
latter
Utopian
object
(
in
short
sleeves
)
always
appeared
to
be
the
great
inoffensive
aim
of
her
existence
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
sounds
horrid
,
do
n't
it
?
"
said
Miss
Podsnap
,
with
a
penitential
face
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
,
not
very
well
knowing
what
to
answer
,
resolved
herself
into
a
look
of
smiling
encouragement
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
is
,
and
it
always
has
been
,
"
pursued
Miss
Podsnap
,
"
such
a
trial
to
me
!
<EOS>
I
so
dread
being
awful
.
<EOS>
And
it
is
so
awful
!
<EOS>
No
one
knows
what
I
suffered
at
Madame
Sauteuse
's
,
where
I
learnt
to
dance
and
make
presentation
-
curtseys
,
and
other
dreadful
things
---
  
or
at
least
where
they
tried
to
teach
me
.
<EOS>
Ma
can
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
any
rate
,
my
love
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
soothingly
,
"
that
's
over
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
's
over
,
"
returned
Miss
Podsnap
,
"
but
there
's
nothing
gained

.
<EOS>
It
's

here
,
than

Madame

's
.
<EOS>
Ma
was
there
,
and
Ma
's
here
;
but
Pa
was
n't

,
and
company
was

,

there

.
<EOS>
Oh

's
Ma
speaking
to
the
man

!
<EOS>
Oh

's
Ma
going
up
to
somebody
!
<EOS>
Oh

's
going
to
bring

to

!
<EOS>
Oh

do
n't
,
please
do
n't
,
please
do

!
<EOS>
Oh
keep
away
,
keep
away
,
keep
away
!
"
<EOS>
These
pious

Miss
Podsnap
uttered
with
her
eyes
closed
,
and
her
head
leaning
back
against
the
wall
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
Ogre
advanced
under
the

of
Ma
,
and
Ma
said
,
"
Georgiana
,
Mr.
Grompus
,
"
and
the
Ogre
clutched
his
victim
and
bore

off
to
his
castle
in
the
top

.
<EOS>
Then
the
discreet
automaton
who
had
surveyed
his
ground
,
played
a
blossomless
tuneless
"
set
,
"
 
and
sixteen
disciples
of
Podsnappery
went
through
the
figures
of
---
  
1
,
Getting
up
at
eight
and
shaving
close
at
a
quarter

---
2
,
Breakfasting
at
nine
---
3
,
Going
to
the
City
at

---
4
,
Coming

at
half

---
5
,
Dining
at
seven
,
and
the
grand
chain
.
  
<EOS>
While

were
in
progress
,
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
(
most
loving
of
husbands
)
approached
the

of
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
(
most

of

)
,
and

,
trifled
for

with
Mrs.
Lammle
's

.
<EOS>
Slightly
in
contrast
with
this
brief
airy

,

in

's

said

on

Lammle
's

,
and
seemed

to

some

.
<EOS>
But
it
was
all
done
as
a

.
  
<EOS>
And

,

grand

,

,
and

,
two

two
,

.
<EOS>
And
herein

of
the
Ogre

was

;
for
,
that

,

Miss
Podsnap

,

to
the
utmost

of

a

an

;
 
while
his
victim
,
heading
the

of

as

,
like

,
never

.
  
<EOS>
At

,

,
Miss
Podsnap

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

,
"

<EOS>
"
That
's

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

Ma

,

<EOS>

---

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

.
<EOS>
Indeed

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.

<EOS>

.

"

,

"

!

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,
"

for

as

<EOS>
In

,

assembled

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
It
was

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

<EOS>
The

,

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Veneering
and

commended

.
<EOS>
At

a

.
  
<EOS>
The

of

intimated
that

,

.

,

"
  
<EOS>
The

?
"

The

.

.

;
as

,
"

!
<EOS>

!

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.

,
he

;

---
   
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
So

:
  
"

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

)

<EOS>

"

me
"

,
as

"
it
is
not
for
me
to
impugn
the
workings
of
Providence
.
<EOS>
I
know
better
than
that
,
I
trust
,
and
I
have
mentioned
what
the
intentions
of
Providence
are
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
"
said
Mr.
Podsnap
,
flushing
high
up
among
his
hair
-
brushes
,
with
a
strong
consciousness
of
personal
affront
,
"
the
subject
is
a
very
disagreeable
one
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
so
far
as
to
say
it
is
an
odious
one
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
one
to
be
introduced
among
our
wives
and
young
persons
,
and
I
---
<EOS>
"
He
finished
with
that
flourish
of
his
arm
which
added
more
expressively
than
any
words
,
And
I
remove
it
from
the
face
of
the
earth
.
  
<EOS>
Simultaneously
with
this
quenching
of
the
meek
man
's
ineffectual
fire
,
Georgiana
having
left
the
ambler
up
a
lane
of
sofa
,
in
a
No
Thoroughfare
of
back
drawing
-
room
,
to
find
his
own
way
out
,
came
back
to
Mrs.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
And
who
should
be
with
Mrs.
Lammle
,
but
Mr.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
So
fond
of
her
!
  
<EOS>
"
Alfred
,
my
love
,
here
is
my
friend
.
<EOS>
Georgiana
,
dearest
girl
,
you
must
like
my
husband
next
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
was
proud
to
be
so
soon
distinguished
by
this
special
commendation
to
Miss
Podsnap
's
favour
.
<EOS>
But
if
Mr.
Lammle
were
prone
to
be
jealous
of
his
dear
Sophronia
's
friendships
,
he
would
be
jealous
of
her
feeling
towards
Miss
Podsnap
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
Georgiana
,
darling
,
"
interposed
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
Towards
---
shall
I
?
---
Georgiana
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
uttered
the
name
,
with
a
delicate
curve
of
his
right
hand
,
from
his
lips
outward
.
"
<EOS>
For
never
have
I
known
Sophronia
(
who
is
not
apt
to
take
sudden
likings
)
<EOS>
so
attracted
and
so
captivated
as
she
is
by
---
<EOS>
shall
I
once
more
?
<EOS>
---
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
object
of
this
homage
sat
uneasily
enough
in
receipt
of
it
,
and
then
said
,
turning
to
Mrs.
Lammle
,
much
embarrassed
:
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
what
you
like
me
for
!
<EOS>
I
am
sure
I
ca
n't
think
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dearest
Georgiana
,
for
yourself
.
<EOS>
For
your
difference
from
all
around
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
<EOS>
That
may
be
.
<EOS>
For
I
think
I
like
you
for
your
difference
from
all
around
me
.
"
said
Georgiana
with
a
smile
of
relief
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
must
be
going
with
the
rest
,
"
observed
Mrs.
Lammle
,
rising
with
a
show
of
unwillingness
,
amidst
a
general
dispersal
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
real
friends
,
Georgiana
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Real
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
night
,
dear
girl
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
established
an
attraction
over
the
shrinking
nature
upon
which
her
smiling
eyes
were
fixed
,
for
Georgiana
held
her
hand
while
she
answered
in
a
secret
and
half
-
frightened
tone
:
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
forget
me
when
you
are
gone
away
.
<EOS>
And
come
again
soon
.
<EOS>
Good
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Charming
to
see
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
taking
leave
so
gracefully
,
and
going
down
the
stairs
so
lovingly
and
sweetly
.
<EOS>
Not
quite
so
charming
to
see
their
smiling
faces
fall
and
brood
as
they
dropped
moodily
into
separate
corners
of
their
little
carriage
.
<EOS>
But
to
be
sure
that
was
a
sight
behind
the
scenes
,
which
nobody
saw
,
and
which
nobody
was
meant
to
see
.
  
<EOS>
Certain
big
,
heavy
vehicles
,
built
on
the
model
of
the
Podsnap
plate
,
took
away
the
heavy
articles
of
guests
weighing
ever
so
much
;
and
the
less
valuable
articles
got
away
after
their
various
manners
;
and
the
Podsnap
plate
was
put
to
bed
.
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Podsnap
stood
with
his
back
to
the
drawing
-
room
fire
,
pulling
up
his
shirt
-
collar
,
like
a
veritable
cock
of
the
walk
literally
pluming
himself
in
the
midst
of
his
possessions
,
nothing
would
have
astonished
him
more
than
an
intimation
that
Miss
Podsnap
,
or
any
other
young
person
properly
born
and
bred
,
could
not
be
exactly
put
away
like
the
plate
,
brought
out
like
the
plate
,
polished
like
the
plate
,
counted
,
weighed
,
and
valued
like
the
plate
.
<EOS>
That
such
a
young
person
could
possibly
have
a
morbid
vacancy
in
the
heart
for
anything
younger
than
the
plate
,
or
less
monotonous
than
the
plate
;
or
that
such
a
young
person
's
thoughts
could
try
to
scale
the
region
bounded
on
the
north
,
south
,
east
,
and
west
,
by
the
plate
;
was
a
monstrous
imagination
which
he
would
on
the
spot
have
flourished
into
space
.
<EOS>
This
perhaps
in
some
sort
arose
from
Mr.
Podsnap
's
blushing
young
person
being
,
so
to
speak
,
all
cheek
:
whereas
there
is
a
possibility
that
there
may
be
young
persons
of
a
rather
more
complex
organization
.
  
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Podsnap
,
pulling
up
his
shirt
-
collar
,
could
only
have
heard
himself
called
"
that
fellow
"
in
a
certain
short
dialogue
,
which
passed
between
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
in
their
opposite
corners
of
their
little
carriage
,
rolling
home
!
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
are
you
awake
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Am
I
likely
to
be
asleep
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
,
I
should
think
,
after
that
fellow
's
company
.
<EOS>
Attend
to
what
I
am
going
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
attended
to
what
you
have
already
said
,
have
I
not
?
<EOS>
What
else
have
I
been
doing
all
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Attend
,
I
tell
you
,
"
(
in
a
raised
voice
)
"
to
what
I
am
going
to
say
.
<EOS>
Keep
close
to
that
idiot
girl
.
<EOS>
Keep
her
under
your
thumb
.
<EOS>
You
have
her
fast
,
and
you
are
not
to
let
her
go
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hear
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
foresee
there
is
money
to
be
made
out
of
this
,
besides
taking
that
fellow
down
a
peg
.
<EOS>
We
owe
cach
other
money
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
wineed
a
little
at
the
reminder
,
but
only
enough
to
shake
her
scents
and
essences
anew
into
the
atmosphere
of
the
little
carriage
,
as
she
settled
herself
afresh
in
her
own
dark
corner
.
   
<EOS>
THE
SWEAT
OF
AN
HONEST
MAN
'S
BROW
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
and
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
took
a
coffee
-
house
dinner
together
in
Mr.
Lightwood
's
office
.
<EOS>
They
had
newly
agreed
to
set
up
a
joint
establishment
together
.
<EOS>
They
had
taken
a
bachelor
cottage
near
Hampton
,
on
the
brink
of
the
Thames
,
with
a
lawn
,
and
a
boat
-
house
,
and
all
things
fitting
,
and
were
to
float
with
the
stream
through
the
summer
and
the
Long
Vacation
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
summer
yet
,
but
spring
;
and
it
was
not
gentle
spring
ethereally
mild
,
as
in
Thomson
's
Scasons
,
but
nipping
spring
with
an
easterly
wind
,
as
in
Johnson
's
,
Jackson
's
,
Dickson
's
,
Smith
's
,
and
Jones
's
Seasons
.
<EOS>
The
grating
wind
sawed
rather
than
blew
;
and
as
it
sawed
,
the
sawdust
whirled
about
the
sawpit
.
<EOS>
Every
street
was
a
sawpit
,
and
there
were
no
top
-
sawyers
;
every
passenger
was
an
under
-
sawyer
,
with
the
sawdust
blinding
him
and
choking
him
.
  
<EOS>
That
mysterious
paper
currency
which
circulates
in
London
when
the
wind
blows
,
gyrated
here
and
there
and
everywhere
.
<EOS>
Whence
can
it
come
,
whither
can
it
go
?
<EOS>
It
hangs
on
every
bush
,
<EOS>
flutters
in
every
tree
,
is
caught
flying
by
the
electric
wires
,
haunts
every
enclosure
,
drinks
at
every
pump
,
cowers
at
every
grating
,
shudders
upon
every
plot
of
grass
,
seeks
rest
in
vain
behind
the
legions
of
iron
rails
.
<EOS>
In
Paris
,
where
nothing
is
wasted
,
costly
and
luxurious
city
though
it
be
,
but
where
wonderful
human
ants
creep
out
of
holes
and
pick
up
every
scrap
,
there
is
no
such
thing
.
<EOS>
There
,
it
blows
nothing
but
dust
.
<EOS>
There
,
sharp
eyes
and
sharp
stomachs
reap
even
the
east
wind
,
and
get
something
out
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
wind
sawed
,
and
the
sawdust
whirled
.
<EOS>
The
shrubs
wrung
their
many
hands
,
bemoaning
that
they
had
been
over
-
persuaded
by
the
sun
to
bud
;
the
young
leaves
pined
;
the
sparrows
repented
of
their
early
marriages
,
like
men
and
women
;
the
colours
of
the
rainbow
were
discernible
,
not
in
floral
spring
,
but
in
the
faces
of
the
people
whom
it
nibbled
and
pinched
.
<EOS>
And
ever
the
wind
sawed
,
and
the
sawdust
whirled
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
spring
evenings
are
too
long
and
light
to
shut
out
,
and
such
weather
is
rife
,
the
city
which
Mr.
Podsnap
so
explanatorily
called
London
,
Londres
,
London
,
is
at
its
worst
.
<EOS>
Such
a
black
shrill
city
,
combining
the
qualities
of
a
smoky
house
and
a
scolding
wife
;
such
a
gritty
city
;
such
a
hopeless
city
,
with
no
rent
in
the
leaden
canopy
of
its
sky
;
such
a
beleaguered
city
,
invested
by
the
great
Marsh
Forces
of
Essex
and
Kent
.
<EOS>
So
the
two
old
schoolfellows
felt
it
to
be
,
as
,
their
dinner
done
,
they
turned
towards
the
fire
to
smoke
.
<EOS>
Young
Blight
was
gone
,
the
coffee
-
house
waiter
was
gone
,
the
plates
and
dishes
were
gone
,
the
wine
was
going
---
but
not
in
the
same
direction
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
wind
sounds
up
here
,
"
quoth
Eugene
,
stirring
the
fire
,
"
as
if
we
were
keeping
a
lighthouse
.
<EOS>
I
wish
we
were
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
think
it
would
bore
us
?
"
<EOS>
Lightwood
asked
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
more
than
any
other
place
.
<EOS>
And
there
would
be
no
Circuit
to
go
.
<EOS>
But
that
's
a
selfish
consideration
,
personal
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
no
clients
to
come
,
"
added
Lightwood
.
<EOS>
"
Not
that
that
's
a
selfish
consideration
at
all
personal
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
we
were
on
an
isolated
rock
in
a
stormy
sea
,
"
said
Eugene
,
smoking
with
his
eyes
on
the
fire
,
"
Lady
Tippins
could
n't
put
off
to
visit
us
,
or
,
better
still
,
might
put
off
and
get
swamped
.
<EOS>
People
could
n't
ask
one
to
wedding
breakfasts
.
<EOS>
There
would
be
no
Precedents
to
hammer
at
,
except
the
plain
-
sailing
Precedent
of
keeping
the
light
up
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
exciting
to
look
out
for
wrecks
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
otherwise
,
"
suggested
Lightwood
,
"
there
might
be
a
degree
of
sameness
in
the
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
thought
of
that
also
,
"
said
Eugene
,
as
if
he
really
had
been
considering
the
subject
in
its
various
bearings
with
an
eye
to
the
business
;
"
but
it
would
be
a
defined
and
limited
monotony
.
<EOS>
It
would
not
extend
beyond
two
people
.
<EOS>
Now
,
it
's
a
question
with
me
,
Mortimer
,
whether
a
monotony
defined
with
that
precision
and
limited
to
that
extent
,
might
not
be
more
endurable
than
the
unlimited
monotony
of
one
's
fellow
-
creatures
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
Lightwood
laughed
and
passed
the
wine
,
he
remarked
,
"
We
shall
have
an
opportunity
,
in
our
boating
summer
,
of
trying
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
An
imperfect
one
,
"
Eugene
acquiesced
,
with
a
sigh
,
"
<EOS>
but
so
we
shall
.
<EOS>
I
hope
we
may
not
prove
too
much
for
one
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,
regarding
your
respected
father
,
"
said
Lightwood
,
bringing
him
to
a
subject
they
had
expressly
appointed
to
discuss
:
always
the
most
slippery
eel
of
eels
of
subjects
to
lay
hold
of
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
regarding
my
respected
father
,
"
assented
Eugene
,
settling
himself
in
his
arm
-
chair
.
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
have
approached
my
respected
father
by
candlelight
,
as
a
theme
requiring
a
little
artificial
brilliancy
;
but
we
will
take
him
by
twilight
,
enlivened
with
a
glow
of
Wallsend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
stirred
the
fire
again
as
he
spoke
,
and
having
made
it
blaze
,
resumed
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
respected
father
has
found
,
down
in
the
parental
neighbourhood
,
a
wife
for
his
not
-
generally
-
respected
son
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
some
money
,
of
course
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
some
money
,
of
course
,
or
he
would
not
have
found
her
.
<EOS>
My
respected
father
---
let
me
shorten
the
dutiful
tautology
by
substituting
in
future
M.
R.
F.
,
which
sounds
military
,
and
rather
like
the
Duke
of
Wellington
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
an
absurd
fellow
you
are
,
Eugene
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
I
assure
you
.
<EOS>
M.
R.
F.
having
always
in
the
clearest
manner
provided
(
as
he
calls
it

"
  
"

?

.
"
  
The

pulled
his

cap
over
his
ears
with

,
and
making

more
round

than

,

,

,

so
on

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

air
,
"
returned

.
"
<EOS>
He
has
undeniable
intentions
that
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
said
little
else
as
they

.
<EOS>
He
went
on
before
them
as
an
ugly
Fate
might
have
done
,
and
they
kept
him
in
view
,
and
would
have
been

.
<EOS>
But

went
before
them
,
always
at

,
and
the

.
<EOS>
Aslant
against
the
hard
implacable
weather
and

rough

,
he
was
no
more
to

driven
back
than
hurried

,
but
held

like

Destiny
.
<EOS>
There
came
,
when
they
were
about

,

heavy

of
hail
,
which
in

minutes
pelted
the
streets
clear
,
and
whitened
them
.
<EOS>
It
made
no

to
him
.
<EOS>
A
man
's
life
being
to
be
taken
and
the
price
of
it
got
,
<EOS>
the
hailstones
to
arrest

purpose
must
lie
larger

than

.
<EOS>
He

,

in

fastmelting

that
were
mere
shapeless
holes
;
one
might
have
fancied
,
following
,
that
the
very
fashion
of

had
departed
from

.
  
<EOS>
The

by
,
and

with

,
and

up
there
made

of

.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that

swept

,
as

had

still

;
but
that

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
There

;

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

,
and
where

now

;

,

,

.
<EOS>

"

,

.
<EOS>
He

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Handing

's
.

?

.

<EOS>

.

,

;

.

.

?
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Reserve
!
"
<EOS>
Reserve

.
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>
Reserve

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

the

his

,
Lightwood

officer
what
he

?
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
replied
,
with
due
generality
and
reticence
,
that
it
was
always
more
likely
that
a

had

than

he
had
n't
.
<EOS>
That

himself
had
several

"

"
Gaffer

<EOS>
That

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
TRACKING
THE

OF

.

Bob

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
(

;

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
Rather

,

,
Eugene
(

,

.
  
<EOS>
On

,

---
not

,

,

,

's

---

;

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Under

,

's

.
<EOS>
And

had

its
position

,
and

,

where
,

he
had

,
the
lonely
girl
with
the
dark

sat

.
  
<EOS>
He
could
see
the
light
of
the
fire
shining
through

window
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
drew
him
on
to
look

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

had
come
out
with

.
<EOS>
That
part
of
the
bank
having
rank

growing
on
it
,

no

in
getting
close
,
without
any

:
it
was
but
to

of
pretty

some

and
come
upon
the
grass

the
window
.
<EOS>
He
came
to
the
window
by
that

.
  
<EOS>
She
had
no
other
light
than
the

of
the
fire
.
<EOS>
The
unkindled
lamp
stood
on
the

.
<EOS>
She
sat
on
the
ground
,
looking
at
the
brazier
,
with
her
face

.
<EOS>
There
was
a
kind

film

on
her
face
,
which
at
first
he
took
to
be
the
fitful
firelight
;
 
but
,
on
a
second
look
,
he
saw
that
she
was
weeping
.
<EOS>
A
sad
and
solitary
spectacle
,
as
shown
him
by
the
rising
and
the
falling
of
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
window
of
but
four
pieces
of
glass
,
and
was
not

;
he
chose

because
the
larger
window
near

was
.
<EOS>
It
showed
him
the
room
,
and
the
bills
upon
the
wall
respecting
the
drowned
people
starting
out
and

by

.
<EOS>
But
he
glanced
slightly
at

,
though
he
looked
long

at
her
.
<EOS>
A
deep
rich
piece
of
color
,
with
the
brown
flush
of
her

and
the
shining

of
her
hair
,
though
sad
and
solitary
,
weeping
by
the
rising
and
the
falling
of
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
She
started
up
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
so
very
still
,
that
he
felt
sure
it
was
not
he
who
had
disturbed
her
,
so
merely
withdrew
from
the
window
and
stood
near
it
in
the
shadow
of
the
wall
.
<EOS>
She
opened
the
door
,
and
said
in
an
alarmed
tone
,
"
Father
,
was
that
you
calling
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
And
again
,
"
Father
!
"
<EOS>
And
once
again
,
after
listening
,
"
Father
!
<EOS>
I
thought
I
heard
you
call
me
twice
before
!
"
  
<EOS>
No
response
.
<EOS>
As
she
re
-
entered
at
the
door
,
he
dropped
over
the
bank
and
made
his
way
back
,
among
the
ooze
and
near
the
hidingplace
,
to
Mortimer
Lightwood
:
to
whom
he
told
what
he
had
seen
of
the
girl
,
and
how
this
was
becoming
very
grim
indeed
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
the
real
man
feels
as
guilty
as
I
do
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
he
is
remarkably
uncomfortable
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Influence
of
secresy
,
"
suggested
Lightwood
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
at
all
obliged
to
it
for
making
me
Guy
Fawkes
in
the
vault
and
a
Sneak
in
the
area
both
at
once
,
"
said
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
Give
me
some
more
of
that
stuff
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
helped
him
to
some
more
of
that
stuff
,
but
it
had
been
cooling
,
and
did
n't
answer
now
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pooh
,
"
said
Eugene
,
spitting
it
out
among
the
ashes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Tastes
like
the
wash
of
the
river
.
"
  
"
Are
you
so
familiar
with
the
flavor
of
the
wash
of
the
river
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
seem
to
be
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
I
feel
as
if
I
had
been
half
drowned
,
and
swallowing
a
gallon
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Influence
of
locality
,
"
suggested
Lightwood
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
mighty
learned
to
-
night
,
you
and
your
influences
,
"
 
returned
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
How
long
shall
we
stay
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
long
do
you
think
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
could
choose
,
I
should
say
a
minute
,
"
replied
Eugene
,
"
for
the
Jolly
Fellowship
Porters
are
not
the
jolliest
dogs
I
have
known
.
<EOS>
But
I
suppose
we
are
best
here
until
they
turn
us
out
with
the
other
suspicious
characters
,
at
midnight
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Thereupon
he
stirred
the
fire
,
and
sat
down
on
one
side
of
it
.
<EOS>
It
struck
eleven
,
and
he
made
believe
to
compose
himself
patiently
.
<EOS>
But
gradually
he
took
the
fidgets
in
one
leg
,
and
then
in
the
other
leg
,
and
then
in
one
arm
,
and
then
in
the
other
arm
,
and
then
in
his
chin
,
and
then
in
his
back
,
and
then
in
his
forehead
,
and
then
in
his
hair
,
and
then
in
his
nose
;
and
then
he
stretched
himself
recumbent
on
two
chairs
,
and
groaned
;
and
then
he
started
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
Invisible
insects
of
diabolical
activity
swarm
in
this
place
.
<EOS>
I
am
tickled
and
twitched
all
over
.
<EOS>
Mentally
,
I
have
now
committed
a
burglary
under
the
meanest
circumstances
,
and
the
myrmidons
of
justice
are
at
my
heels
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
as
bad
,
"
said
Lightwood
,
sitting
up
facing
him
,
with
a
tumbled

,
after
going
through
some
wonderful
evolutions
,
in
which
his
head
had
been
the
lowest
part
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
This
restlessness
began
,
with
me
,
long
ago
.
<EOS>
All
the
time
you
were
out
,
I
felt
like
Gulliver
with
the
Lilliputians
firing
upon
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
wo
n't
do
,
Mortimer
.
<EOS>
We
must
get
into
the
air
;
we
must
join
our
dear
friend
and
brother
,
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
And
let
us
tranquillize
ourselves
by
making
a
compact
.
<EOS>
Next
time
(
with
a
view
to
our
peace
of
mind
)
we
'll
commit
the
crime
,
instead
of
taking
the
criminal
.
<EOS>
You
swear
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Certainly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sworn
!
<EOS>
Let
Tippins
look
to
it
.
<EOS>
Her
life
's
in
danger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
rang
the
bell
to
pay
the
score
,
and
Bob
appeared
to
transact
that
business
with
him
:
whom
Eugene
,
in
his
careless

,
asked
if
he
would
like
a

in
the
lime
-
trade
?
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
sir
,
no

,
"
said
Bob
.
<EOS>
"
I
've
a
good
sitiwation
here
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you

,
"

,
"
come

works
,

an

in
the

,
kiln
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
sir
,
"

Bob
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
my
partner
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
who
keeps

.
<EOS>
A
fair
day
's
wages
for
a
fair

's
work

my

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
a
very
good
'
un
it
is
,
gentlemen
,
"
said
Bob
,
receiving

,
and

with
