,
very
much
as

would
have
drawn

out

.
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
"
Mortimer
apostrophized
him
,
laughing
quite
heartily
when
they
were
alone

,
"
how
can
you
be
so
ridiculous
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
in
a
ridiculous
humour
,
"
quoth
Eugene
;
"
I
am
a
ridiculous
fellow
.
<EOS>
Everything
is
ridiculous
.
<EOS>
Come
along
!
"
  
<EOS>
It
passed
into
Mortimer
Lightwood
's
mind
that
a
change
of
some
sort
,
best
expressed
perhaps
as
an

of
all
that
was
wildest
and
most
negligent
and
reckless
in
his
friend
,
had
come
upon

in
the

-

.
<EOS>
Thoroughly
used
to
him
as
he
was
,
he
found
something
new
and
strained
in
him
that
was
for

.
<EOS>
This
passed
into
his
mind
,
and
passed
out
again
;
but
he
remembered

afterwards
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
where
she
sits
,

,
"
said
Eugene
,
when

,
roared

.
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
light
of
her
fire
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
a
peep
through

,
"
said
Mortimer
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
do
n't
!
"
<EOS>
Eugene
caught
him
by

arm
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Best
not
make
a
show
of
her
.
<EOS>
Come
to
our
honest
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
led
him
to
the
post
of
watch
,
and
they
both
dropped
down
and
crept
under
the
lee
of
the
boat
;
a
better

than
it
had
seemed
before
,
being
directly

with
the
blowing
wind
and
the
bare

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Inspector
at
home
?
"
whispered
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
,
sir
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
our
friend
of
the
perspiring
brow
is
at
the
far
corner
there
?
<EOS>
Good
.
<EOS>
Anything
happened
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
His
daughter
has
been
out
,
thinking
she
heard
him
calling
,
unless
it
was
a
sign
to

to
keep

.
<EOS>
It
might

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

have

Rule
Britannia
,
"
muttered

,
"
but
it
was
n't
.
<EOS>
Mortimer
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Here
!
"
<EOS>
(
On
the
other
side
of
Mr.
Inspector
.
)
  
"
Two
burglaries
now
,
and
a
forgery
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
this
indication
of
his
depressed
state
of
mind
,
Eugene
fell
silent
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
all
silent
for
a
long
while
.
<EOS>
As
it
got
to
be
flood
-
tide
,
and
the
water
came
nearer
to
them
,
noises
on
the
river
became
more
frequent
,
and
they
listened
more
.
<EOS>
To
the
turning
of
steam
-
paddles
to
the
clinking
of
iron
chain
,
to
the
creaking
of
blocks
,
to
the
measured
working
of
oars
,
to
the
occasional
violent
barking
of
some
passing
dog
on
shipboard
,
who
seemed
to
scent
them
lying
in
their
hidingplace
.
<EOS>
The
night
was
not
so
dark
but
that
,
besides
the
lights
at
bows
and
mastheads
gliding
to
and
fro
,
they
could
discern
some
shadowy
bulk
attached
;
and
now
and
then
a
ghostly
lighter
with
a
large
dark
sail
,
like
a
warning
arm
,
would
start
up
very
near
them
,
pass
on
,
and
vanish
.
<EOS>
At
this
time
of
their
watch
,
the
water
close
to
them
would
be
often
agitated
by
some
impulsion
given
it
from
a
distance
.
<EOS>
Often
they
believed
this
beat
and
plash
to
be
the
boat
they
lay
in
wait
for
,
running
in
ashore
;
and
again
and
again
they
would
have
started
up
,
but
for
the
immobility
with
which
the
informer
,
well
used
to
the
river
,
kept
quiet
in
his
place
.
  
<EOS>
The
wind
carried
away
the
striking
of
the
great
multitude
of
city
church
clocks
,
for
those
lay
to
leeward
of
them
;
but
there
were
bells
to
windward
that
told
them
of
its
being
One
---
Two
<EOS>
---
Three
.
<EOS>
Without
that
aid
they
would
have
known
how
the
night
wore
,
by
the
falling
of
the
tide
,
recorded
in
the
appearance
of
an
ever
-
widening
black
wet
strip
of
shore
,
and
the
emergence
of
the
paved
causeway
from
the
river
,
foot
by
foot
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
time
so
passed
,
this
slinking
business
became
a
more
and
more
precarious
one
.
<EOS>
It
would
seem
as
if
the
man
had
had
some
intimation
of
what
was
in
hand
against
him
,
or
had
taken
fright
?
<EOS>
His
movements
might
have
been
planned
to
gain
for
him
,
in
getting
beyond
their
reach
,
twelve
hours
'
advantage
?
<EOS>
The
honest
man
who
had
expended
the
sweat
of
his
brow
became
uneasy
,
and
began
to
complain
with
bitterness
of
the
proneness
of
mankind
to
cheat
him
 
---
him
invested
with
the
dignity
of
Labour
!
  
<EOS>
Their
retreat
was
so
chosen
that
while
they
could
watch
the
river
,
they
could
watch
the
house
.
<EOS>
No
one
had
passed
in
or
out
,
since
the
daughter
thought
she
heard
the
father
calling
.
<EOS>
No
one
could
pass
in
or
out
without
being
seen
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
will
be
light
at
five
,
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
,
"
and
then
we
shall
be
seen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
"
said
Riderhood
,
"
what
do
you
say
to
this
?
<EOS>
He
may
have
been
lurking
in
and
out
,
and
just
holding
his
own
betwixt
two
or
three
bridges
,
for
hours
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
make
of
that
?
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
.
<EOS>
Stoical
,
but
contradictory
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
may
be
doing
so
at
this
present
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
make
of
that
?
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
boat
's
among
them
boats
here
at
the
cause'ay
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
And
what
do
you
make
of
your
boat
?
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
if
I
put
off
in
her
and
take
a
look
round
?
<EOS>
I
know
his
ways
,
and
the
likely
nooks
he
favours
.
<EOS>
I
know
where
he
'd
be
at
such
a
time
of
the
tide
,
and
where
he
'd
be
at
such
another
time
.
<EOS>
Ai
n't
I
been
his
pardner
?
<EOS>
None
of
you
need
show
.
<EOS>
None
of
you
need
stir
.
<EOS>
I
can
shove
her
off
without
help
;
and
as
to
me
being
seen
,
I
'm
about
at
all
times
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
might
have
given
a
worse
opinion
,
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
,
after
brief
consideration
.
<EOS>
"
Try
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
a
bit
.
<EOS>
Let
's
work
it
out
.
<EOS>
If
I
want
you
,
I
'll
drop
round
under
the
Fellowships
and
tip
you
a
whistle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
might
so
far
presume
as
to
offer
a
suggestion
to
my
honorable
and
gallant
friend
,
whose
knowledge
of
naval
matters
far
be
it
from
me
to
impeach
,
"
Eugene
struck
in
with
great

,
"
it
would
be
,
that
to
tip
a
whistle
is
to
advertise
mystery
and
invite
speculation
.
<EOS>
My
honorable
and
gallant
friend
will
,
I
trust
,
excuse
me
,
as
an
independent
member
,
for
throwing
out
a
remark
which
I
feel
to
be
due
to
this
house
and
the
country
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
that
the
T'other
Governor
,
or
Lawyer
Lightwood
?
"
asked
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
For
,
they
spoke
as
they
crouched
or
lay
,
without
seeing
one
another
's
faces
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
reply
to
the
question
put
by
my
honorable
and
gallant
friend
,
"
 
said
Eugene
,
who
was
lying
on
his
back
with
his
hat
on
his
face
,
as
an
attitude
highly
expressive
of
watchfulness
,
"
I
can
have
no
hesitation
in
replying
<EOS>
(
it
not
being
inconsistent
with
the
public
service
)
<EOS>
that
those
accents
were
the
accents
of
the
T'other
Governor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
've
tolerable
good
eyes
,
ai
n't
you
,
Governor
?
<EOS>
You

All

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Three

<EOS>
THE

.
 
<EOS>
Cold

"

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
  
<EOS>
It

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
After
certain
minutes
,
and
a
few
directions
to
the
rest
to
"
ease
her
a
little
for'ard
,
"
 
and
"
now
ease
her
a
trifle
aft
,
"
and
the
like
,
he
said
composedly
,
"
All
clear
!
"
and
the
line
and
the
boat
came
free

.
  
<EOS>
Accepting
Lightwood
's

hand
to

up
,
he

put
on

,
and
said
to
Riderhood
,
"
Hand

over
those
spare
sculls
of
yours
,
and
I
'll
pull
this
in
to
the
nearest
stairs
.
<EOS>
Go
ahead
you
,
and
keep
out
in
pretty
open
water
,
that
I
may
n't
get
fouled
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
directions
were
obeyed
,
and
they
pulled
ashore
directly
;
two
in
one
boat
,
two
in
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
,
again
to
Riderhood
,
when
they
were
all
on
the
slushy

;
"
you
have
had
more
practice
in
this
than
I
have
had
,
and
ought
to

at
it
.
<EOS>
Undo
the
towrope
,
and
we
'll
help
you
haul
in
.
"
  
<EOS>
Riderhood
got
into
the
boat
accordingly
.
<EOS>
It
appeared
as
if
he
had
scarcely
had
a
moment
's

to
touch
the
rope
or
look
over
the

,
when

,
as

as
the
morning
,
and
gasped

:
  
"
By
the
Lord
,
he
's
done

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
<EOS>
"
they
all
demanded
.
  
<EOS>
He
pointed
behind
him
at
the
boat
,
and
gasped
to
that
degree
that
he
dropped
upon
the
stones
to
get
his
breath
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gaffer
's
done
me
.
<EOS>
It
's
Gaffer
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
ran
to
the
rope
,
leaving
him
gasping
there
.
<EOS>
Soon
,
the
form
of
the
bird
of
prey
,
dead
some
hours
,
lay
stretched
upon
the
shore
,
with
a
new
blast
storming
at
it
and
clotting
the
wet
hair
with
hailstones
.
  
<EOS>
Father
,
was
that
you
calling
me
?
<EOS>
Father
!
<EOS>
I
thought
I
heard
you
call
me
twice
before
!
<EOS>
Words
never
to
be
answered
,
those
,
upon
the
earth
-
side
of
the
grave
.
<EOS>
The
wind
sweeps
jeeringly
over
Father
,
whips
him
with
the
frayed
ends
of
his
dress
and
his
jagged

,
tries
to
turn
him
where
he
lies
stark
on
his
back
,
and
force
his
face
towards
the
rising
sun
,
that
he
may
be
shamed
the
more
.
<EOS>
A
lull
,
and
the
wind
is
secret
and
prying
with
him
;
lifts
and
lets
fass
a
rag
;
hides

under
another
rag
;
runs

through

and

.
<EOS>
Then
,
in
a

,
it
cruelly

.
<EOS>
Father
,
was
that
you
calling
me
?
<EOS>
Was
it
you
,
the
voiceless
and
the
dead
?
<EOS>
Was
it
you
,
thus
buffeted
as
you

in
a

?
<EOS>
Was
it
you
,
thus

unto
Death
,
with
these
flying

now
flung
upon

?
<EOS>
Why
not
speak
,
Father
?
<EOS>
Soaking
into
this
filthy
ground
as
you
lie
here
,
is
your
own
shape
.
<EOS>
Did
you
never
see
such

shape
soaked

?
<EOS>
Speak
,
Father
.
<EOS>
Speak
to
us
,
the
winds
,
the
only

left
you
!
  
<EOS>
"
Now
see
,
"
said
Mr.
Inspector

"
the

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
Plain

.

"

<EOS>
It

"

<EOS>

this

that
was
,
"

---
there
!
<EOS>
Now

,
---

this

that

,
rows

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

this

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Sometimes

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

;
---

?
"
<EOS>

---
  
<EOS>
and

line
<EOS>
round

.
<EOS>
Last

does

.
<EOS>
Worse
for

!
<EOS>
He

,
does
this

,

.
<EOS>
His

,
"
taking

,

"
get

.
<EOS>
He

's

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

anyhow
,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Now

!
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
The

tow
,

<EOS>
You

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
How

?
<EOS>
Simple

.
<EOS>
Because

's

.
<EOS>
"
The

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

<EOS>
"
If

,

"

"

;
---

,

<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
"

"

<EOS>
He

Eugene
!
<EOS>
Holloa
!
"
<EOS>
But

Eugene

.
  
<EOS>
It

broad

,
and

.
<EOS>
But
no
Eugene
was
in

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
speedily

down

,
with

,
Lightwood

if

?
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
could

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Singular

,

,
your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Can

?
"
  
<EOS>
We

,
and
we
did
.
<EOS>
In
a

.
<EOS>
We

hot

and
water
,
and
it
revived

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
having
to
Mr.
Riderhood
,

"
keeping

,
"

,

,

that

,

:

.
  
<EOS>
As
Mortimer
Lightwod
sat
before
the

,
conscious
of
drinking
brandy
and
water
then
and
there
in

,
and

,
and
lying

on

,

that
Riderhood

,
and
listening

recently

,
and

,
who

M.
R.
F.
Eugene
Gaffer

,
and
said
he
lived
at
Hailstorm
,
---

he
passed
through

of

and

,
arranged
upon
the

of
a
dozen

to

second
,

became

of
answering

of
pressing

that
had
never
been
made
to

,
and
then
turned

into
a
cough
on
beholding
Mr.
Inspector
.
<EOS>
For
,

,

,
that
that

might

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
just

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

too
<EOS>
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
After

,
in

Mr.
Inspector

,
that
the
officer

to

's
daughter

,

,
Mortimer
Lightwood
stumbled
in

to
a

-

,
called
a
cab
,
and
had
entered
the
army
and
committed
a

and
been
tried
by
court
martial
and
found
guilty
and
had
arranged

and
been
marched
out
to
be

,
before
the
door

.
  
<EOS>
Hard
work
rowing
the
cab
through
the
City
to
the
Temple
,
for
a
cup
of
from
five
to
ten
thousand
pounds
value
,
given
by
Mr.
Boffin
;
 
and
hard
work
holding
forth
at
that
immeasurable
length
to
Eugene
<EOS>
(
when
he
had
been
rescued
with
a
rope
from
the
running

)
for
making

in

!
<EOS>
But
he
offered
such
ample

,
and
was
so
very

,
that
when
Lightwood
got
out
of
the

,
he
gave

driver
a
particular
charge
to
be
careful
of
him
.
<EOS>
Which
the
driver
(
knowing
there
was
no
other
fare
left
inside
)
stared
at
prodigiously
.
  
<EOS>
In
short
,
the
night
's
work
had
so
exhausted
and
worn
out
this
actor
in
it
,
that
he
had
become
a
mere
somnambulist
.
<EOS>
He
was
too
tired
to
rest
in
his
sleep
,
until
he
was
even
tired
out
of
being
too
tired
,
and
dropped
into
oblivion
.
<EOS>
Late
in
the

he
awoke
,
and
in
some
anxiety
sent
round
to
Eugene
's
lodging
hard
by
,
to
inquire
if
he
were
up
yet
?
  
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
he
was
up
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
he
had
not
been
to
bed
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
come
home
.
<EOS>
And
here
he
was
,
close
following
on
the
heels
of
the
message
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
what
bloodshot
,
draggled
,
dishevelled
spectacle
is
this
!
"
 
<EOS>
cried
Mortimer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
my
feathers
so
very
much
rumpled
?
"
said
Eugene
,
coolly
going
up
to
the
looking
-
glass
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
rather
out
of
sorts
.
<EOS>
But
consider
.
<EOS>
Such
a
night
for
plumage
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Such
a
night
?
"
repeated
Mortimer
.
<EOS>
"
What
became
of
you
in
the
morning
?
"
  
"
My
dear
fellow
,
"
said
Eugene
,
sitting
on
his
bed
,
"
I
felt
that
we
had
bored
one
another
so
long
,
that
an
unbroken
continuance
of
those
relations
must
inevitably
terminate
in
our
flying
to
opposite
points
of
the
earth
.
<EOS>
I
also
felt
that
I
had
committed
every
crime
in
the
Newgate
Calendar
.
<EOS>
So
,
for
mingled
considerations
of
friendship
and
felony
,
I
took
a
walk
.
"
   
<EOS>
TWO
NEW
SERVANTS
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
sat
after
breakfast
,
in
the
Bower
,
a
prey
to
prosperity
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
's
face
denoted
Care
and
Complication
.
<EOS>
Many
disordered
papers
were
before
him
,
and
he
looked
at
them
about
as
hopefully
as
an
innocent
civilian
might
look
at
a
crowd
of
troops
whom
he
was
required
at
five
minutes
'
notice
to
manoeuvre
and
review
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
engaged
in
some
attempts
to
make
notes
of
these
papers
;
but
being
troubled
(
as
men
of
his
stamp
often
are
)
with
an
exceedingly
distrustful
and
corrective
thumb
,
that
busy
member
had
so
often
interposed
to
smear
his
notes
,
that
they
were
little
more
legible
than
the
various
impressions
of
itself
,
which
blurred
his
nose
and
forehead
.
<EOS>
It
is
curious
to
consider
,
in
such
a
case
as
Mr.
Boffin
's
,
what
a
cheap
article
ink
is
,
and
how
far
it
may
be
made
to
go
.
<EOS>
As
a
grain
of
musk
will
scent
a
drawer
for
many
years
,
and
still
lose
nothing
appreciable
of
its
original
weight
,
so
a
halfpenny
-
worth
of
ink
would
blot
Mr.
Boffin
to
the
roots
of
his
hair
and
the
calves
of
his
legs
,
without
inscribing
a
line
on
the
paper
before
him
,
or
appearing
to
diminish
in
the
inkstand
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
was
in
such
severe
literary
difficulties
that
his
eyes
were
prominent
and
fixed
,
and
his
breathing
was
stertorous
,
when
,
to
the
great
relief
of
Mrs.
Boffin
,
who
observed
these
symptoms
with
alarm
,
the
yard
bell
rang
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
's
that
,
I
wonder
!
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
drew
a
long
breath
,
laid
down
his
pen
,
looked
at
his
notes
as
doubting
whether
he
had
the
pleasure
of
their
acquaintance
,
and
appeared
,
on
a
second
perusal
of
their
countenances
,
to
be
confirmed
in
his
impression
that
he
had
not
,
when
there
was
announced
by
the
hammer
-
headed
young
man
:
  
"
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
indeed
!
<EOS>
Our
and
the
Wilfers
'
Mutual
Friend
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Ask
him
to
come
in
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
appeared
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
shaking
hands
with
him
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
you
're
already
acquainted
with
.
<EOS>
Well
,
sir
,
I
am
rather
unprepared
to
see
you
,
for
,
to
tell
you
the
truth
,
I
've
been
so
busy
with
one
thing
and
another
,
that
I
've
not
had
time
to
turn
your
offer
over
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
apology
for
both
of
us
:
for
Mr.
Boffin
,
and
<EOS>
for
me
as
well
,
"
 
said
the
smiling
Mrs.
Boffin
.
"
<EOS>
But
Lor
!
<EOS>
we
can
talk
it
over
now
;
 
ca
n't
us
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
bowed
,
thanked
her
,
and
said
he
hoped
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
then
,
"
resumed
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
his
hand
to
his
chin
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
Secretary
that
you
named
;
was
n't
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
Secretary
,
"
assented
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
rather
puzzled
me
at
the
time
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
and
it
rather
puzzled
me
and
Mrs.
Boffin
when
we
spoke
of
it
afterwards
,
because
(
not
to
make
a
mystery
of
our
belief
)
<EOS>
we
have
always
believed
a
Secretary
to
be
a
piece
of
furniture
,
mostly
of
mahogany
,
lined
with
green
baize
or
leather
,
with
a
lot
of
little
drawers
in
it
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
wo
n't
think
I
take
a
liberty
when
I
mention
that
you
certainly
ai
n't
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
Certainly
not
,
said
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
used
the
word
in
the
sense
of
Steward
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
as
to
Steward
,
you
see
,
"
returned
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
his
hand
still
to
his
chin
,
"
the
odds
are
that
Mrs.
Boffin
and
me
may
never
go
upon
the
water
.
<EOS>
Being
both
bad
sailors
,
we
should
want
a
Steward
if
we
did
;
but
there
's
generally
one
provided
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
again
explained
;
defining
the
duties
he
sought
to
undertake
,
as
those
of
general
superintendent
,
or
manager
,
or
overlooker
,
or
man
of
business
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
for
instance
---
come
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
in
his
pouncing
way
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
entered
my
employment
,
what
would
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
keep
exact
accounts
of
all
the
expenditure
you
sanctioned
,
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
I
would
write
your
letters
,
under
your
direction
.
<EOS>
I
would
transact
your
business
with
people
in
your
pay
or
employment
.
<EOS>
I
would
,
"
with
a
glance
and
a
half
-
smile
at
the
table
,
"
arrange
your
papers
---
<EOS>
"
  
Mr.
Boffin
rubbed
his
inky
ear
,
and
looked
at
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
And
so
arrange
them
as
to
have
them
always
in
order
for
immediate
reference
,
with
a
note
of
the
contents
of
each
outside
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
what
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
slowly
crumpling
his
own
blotted
note
in
his
hand
;
"
if
you
'll
turn
to
at
these
present
papers
,
and
see
what
you
can
make
of
'em
,
I
shall
know
better
what
I
can
make
of
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
No
sooner
said
than
done
.
<EOS>
Relinquishing
his
hat
and
gloves
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
sat
down
quietly
at
the
table
,
arranged
the
open
papers
into
an
orderly
heap
,
cast
his
eyes
over
each
in
succession
,
folded
it
,
docketed
it
on
the
outside
,
laid
it
in
a
second
heap
,
and
,
when
that
second
heap
was
complete
and
the
first
gone
,
took
from
his
pocket
a
piece
of
string
and
tied
it
together
with
a
remarkably
dexterous
hand
at
a
running
curve
and
a
loop
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
good
!
<EOS>
Now
let
us
hear
what
they
're
all
about
;
will
you
be
so
good
?
"
  
<EOS>
John
Rokesmith
read
his
abstracts
aloud
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
about
the
new
house
.
<EOS>
Decorator
's
estimate
,
so
much
.
<EOS>
Furniture
estimate
,
so
much
.
<EOS>
Estimate
for
furniture
of
offices
,
so
much
.
<EOS>
Coach
-
maker
's
estimate
,
so
much
.
<EOS>
Horse
-
dealer
's
estimate
,
so
much
.
<EOS>
Harness
-
maker
's
estimate
so
much
.
<EOS>
Goldsmith
's
estimate
,
so
much
.
<EOS>
Total
,
so
very
much
.
<EOS>
Then
came
correspondence
.
<EOS>
Acceptance
of
Mr.
Boffin
's
offer
of
such
a
date
,
and
to
such
an
effect
.
<EOS>
Rejection
of
Mr.
Boffin
's
proposal
of
such
a
date
and
to
such
an
effect
.
<EOS>
Concerning
Mr.
Boffin
's
scheme
of
such
another
date
to
such
another
effect
.
<EOS>
All
compact
and
methodical
.
  
<EOS>
"
Apple
-
pie
order
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
after
checking
off
each
inscription
with
his
hand
,
like
a
man
beating
time
.
<EOS>
"
And
whatever
you
do
with
your
ink
,
I
ca
n't
think
,
for
you
're
as
clean
as
a
whistle
after
it
.
<EOS>
Now
,
as
to
a
letter
.
<EOS>
Let
's
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
rubbing
his
hands
in
his
pleasantly
childish
admiration
,
"
let
's
try
a
letter
next
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
whom
shall
it
be
addressed
,
Mr.
Boffin
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Anyone
.
<EOS>
Yourself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
quickly
wrote
,
and
then
read
aloud
:
  
"
<EOS>
"
Mr
.
Boffin
presents
his
compliments
to
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
,
and
begs
to
say
that
he
has
decided
on
giving
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
a
trial
in
the
capacity
he
desires
to
fill
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
takes
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
at
his
word
,
in
postponing
to
some
indefinite
period
,
the
consideration
of
salary
.
<EOS>
It
is
quite
understood
that
Mr.
Boffin
is
in
no
way
committed
on
that
point
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
has
merely
to
add
,
that
he
relies
on
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
's
assurance
that
he
will
be
faithful
and
serviceable
.
<EOS>
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
will
please
enter
on
his
duties
immediately
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Now
,
Noddy
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Boffin
,
clapping
her
hands
,
"
That
is
a
good
one
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
was
no
less
delighted
;
indeed
,
in
his
own
bosom
,
he
regarded
both
the
composition
itself
and
the
device
that
had
given
birth
to
it
,
as
a
very
remarkable
monument
of
human
ingenuity
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
tell
you
,
my
deary
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
that
if
you
do
n't
close
with
Mr.
Rokesmith
now
at
once
,
and
if
you
ever
go
a
muddling
yourself
again
with
things
never
meant
nor
made
for
you
,
you
'll
have
an
apoplexy
---
besides
iron
-
moulding
your
linen
---
and
you
'll
break
my
heart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
embraced
his
spouse
for
these
words
of
wisdom
,
and
then
,
congratulating
John
Rokesmith
on
the
brilliancy
of
his
achievements
,
gave
him
his
hand
in
pledge
of
their
new
relations
.
<EOS>
So
did
Mrs.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
who
,
in
his
frankness
,
felt
that
it
did
not
become

to
have
a
gentleman
in
his
employment
five
minutes
,
without
reposing
some
confidence
in
him
,
"
you
must
be
let
a
little
more
into

,
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
I
mentioned

,
when
I
made
your

,
or
I
might
better
say
when
you

,
that
Mrs.
Boffin
's
inclinations
was
setting
in
the
way
of
Fashion
,
but
that
I
did
n't
know
how
fashionable
we
might
or
might
not
grow
.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
has
carried
the
day
,
and
we
're
going
in
neck
and
crop
for
Fashion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
rather
inferred
that
,
sir
,
"
replied
John
Rokesmith
,
"
from
the
scale
on
which
your
new
establishment
is
to
be
maintained
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
it
's
to
be
a
Spanker
.
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
my
literary
man
named
to
me
that
a
house
with
which
he
is
,
as
I
may
say
,
connected
---
in
which
he
has
an
interest
---
"
  
"
As
property
?
"
inquired
John
Rokesmith
.
"
<EOS>
Why
no
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
not
exactly
that
;
a
sort

a
family
tie
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Association
?
<EOS>
"
the
Secretary
suggested
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
.
<EOS>
Anyhow
,
he
named
to
me
that
the
house
had
a
board
up
,
`
`
This
Eminently
Aristocratic
Mansion
to
be
let
or
sold
.
"
<EOS>
"
Me
and
Mrs.
Boffin
went
to
look
at
it
,
and
finding
it
beyond
a
doubt
Eminently
Aristocratic
<EOS>
(
though
a
trifle
high
and
dull
,
which
after
all
may
be
part
of
the
same
thing
)
took
it
.
<EOS>
My
literary
man
was
so
friendly
as
to
drop
into
a
charming
piece
of
poetry
on
that
occasion
,
in
which
he
complimented
Mrs.
Boffin
on
coming
into
possession
of
---
how
did
it
go
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
replied
:
   
"
`
`
The
gay
,
the
gay
and
festive
scene
,
  
The
halls
,
the
halls
of
dazzling
light
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
That
's
it
!
<EOS>
And
it
was
made
neater
by
there
really
being
two
halls
in
the
house
,
a
front
'
<EOS>
un
and
a
back
'
un
,
besides
the
servants
'
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
dropped
into
a
very
pretty
piece
of
poetry
to
be
sure
,
respecting
the
extent
to
which
he
would
be
willing
to
put
himself
out
of
the
way
to
bring
Mrs.
Boffin
round
,
in
case
she
should
ever
get
low
in
her
spirits
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
has
a
wonderful
memory
.
<EOS>
Will
you
repeat
it
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
complied
,
by
reciting
the
verses
in
which
this
obliging
offer
had
been
made
,
exactly
as
she
had
received
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
`
`
I
'll
tell
thee
how
the
maiden
wept
,
Mrs.
Boffin
,
  
<EOS>
When
her
true
love
was
slain
ma'am
,
  
<EOS>
And
how
her
broken
spirit
slept
,
Mrs.
Boffin
,
  
And
never
woke
again
ma'am
.
  
<EOS>
I
'll
tell
thee
(
if

Boffin
)
<EOS>
how
the
steed
drew
nigh
,
  
And

;
  
<EOS>
And

,
  
I
'll

.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
Correct

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
And

"
  
<EOS>
The

evidently
to

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,

,
"

,
"
a

---

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lor
!
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

's

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

Which

<EOS>
Rokesmith

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
Thank'ee
.
<EOS>
Being

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
!
"

.
<EOS>
And

and

Boffin

.
  
<EOS>
A
gloomy
house
the
Bower
,
with
sordid
signs
on
it
of
having
been
,
through
its
long
existence
as
Harmony
Jail
,
in
miserly
holding
.
<EOS>
Bare
of
paint
,
bare
of
paper
on
the
walls
,
bare
of

,
bare
of
experience
of
human
life
.
<EOS>
Whatever
is
built
by
man
for
man
's
occupation
<EOS>
,
must
,
like
natural
creations
,
fulfil
the
intention
of
its
existence
,
or
soon
perish
.
<EOS>
This
old
house
had
wasted
more
from
desuetude
than
it
would
have
wasted
from
use
,
twenty
years
for
one
.
  
<EOS>
A
certain
leanness
falls
upon
houses
not
sufficiently
imbued
with
life
(
as
if
they
were
nourished
upon
it
)
,
which
was
very
noticeable
here
.
<EOS>
The
staircase
,
balustrades
,
and
rails
,
had
a
spare

---
an
air
of
being
denuded
to
the
bone
---
which
the
panels
of
the
walls
and
the

of
the
doors
and

also
bore
.
<EOS>
The
scanty
moveables
partook
of
it
<EOS>
;
save
for
the
cleanliness
of
the
place
,
the
dust
into
which
they
were
all
resolving
would
have
lain
thick
on
the

;
 
and
those
,
both
in
colour
and
in
grain
,
were
worn
like
old
faces
that
had
kept
much

.
  
<EOS>
The
bedroom
where
the

old
man
had
lost

,
was
left
as

.
<EOS>
There

old

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
There

,

;

with

,

;

upon

,

will

.
<EOS>
A

old

with

,

more

to

had

lost

of
colour
without

,
stood
against

.
<EOS>
A
hard

was
on

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
room
was

,
Rokesmith
,
"

Boffin
,
"
against

son
's

.
<EOS>
In

was

,

.
<EOS>
Even

,

.
<EOS>
When

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

"

"

"

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
When

,

Me

"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah

<EOS>

Poor

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

"

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.

.

<EOS>

.

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,

.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Might

,

?
"
  
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

's

,

,

:
  
"
Ay
,
ay
,

's

.
<EOS>
I

,

'em

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Still

,

.
<EOS>
There
's

;

.
<EOS>
I
ai
n't
a
scholar
in
much
,
Rokesmith
,
but
I
'm
a

.
<EOS>
I
can

Mounds
to

,

I
Know

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

?
"
  
"
Every

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

ai
n't

'm

,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
;
 
"
only

do

for

<EOS>
,

's

.
<EOS>
Ai

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
!
"

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
to

,

regular

,
"
if
I
can
make
it
comfortable
with
Wegg
,
my
affairs
will
be
going
smooth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
of
low
cunning
had
,
of
course
,
acquired
a
mastery
over
the
man
of
high
simplicity
.
<EOS>
The
mean
man
had
,
of
course
,
got
the
better
of
the
generous
man
.
<EOS>
How
long
such
conquests
last
,
is
another
matter
;
that
they
are
achieved
,
is
every
-
day
experience
,
not
even
to
be
flourished
away
by
Podsnappery
itself
.
<EOS>
The
undesigning
Boffin
had
become
so
far
immeshed
by
the
wily
Wegg
that
his
mind
misgave
him
<EOS>
he
was
a
very
designing
man
indeed
in
purposing
to
do
more
for
Wegg
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
(
so
skilful
was
Wegg
)
that
he
was
plotting
darkly
,
when
he
was
contriving
to
do
the
very
thing
that
Wegg
was
plotting
to
get
him
to
do
.
<EOS>
And
thus
,
while
he
was
mentally
turning
the
kindest
of
kind
faces
on
Wegg
this
morning
,
he
was
not
absolutely
sure
but
that
he
might
somehow
deserve
the
charge
of
turning
his
back
on
him
.
  
<EOS>
For
these
reasons
Mr.
Boffin
passed
but
anxious
hours
until
evening
came
,
and
with
it
Mr.
Wegg
,
stumping
leisurely
to
the
Roman
Empire
.
<EOS>
At
about
this
period
Mr.
Boffin
had
become
profoundly
interested
in
the
fortunes
of
a
great
military
leader
known
to
him
as
Bully
Sawyers
,
but
perhaps
better
known
to
fame
and
easier
of
identification
by
the
classical
student
,
under
the
less
Britannic
name
of
Belisarius
.
<EOS>
Even
this
general
's
career
paled
in
interest
for
Mr.
Boffin
before
the
clearing
of
his
conscience
with
Wegg
;
and
hence
,
when
that
literary
gentleman
had
according
to
custom
eaten
and
drunk
until
he
was
all
a
-
golw
,
and
when
he
took
up
his
book
with
the
usual
chirping
introduction
,
"
And
now
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
sir
,
we
'll
decline
and
we
'll
fall
!
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
stopped
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
remember
,
Wegg
,
when
I
first
told
you
that
I
wanted
to
make
a
sort
of
offer
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
get
on
my
considering
cap
,
sir
,
"
replied
that
gentleman
,
turning
the
open
book
face
downward
.
<EOS>
"
When
you
first
told
me
that
you
wanted
to
make
a
sort
of
offer
to
me
?
<EOS>
Now
let
me
think
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
(
as
if
there
were
the
least
necessity
)
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
to
be
sure
I
do
,
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
It
was
at
my
corner
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
it
was
!
<EOS>
You
had
first
asked
me
whether
I
liked
your
name
,
and
Candour
had
compelled
a
reply
in
the
negative
case
.
<EOS>
I
little
thought
then
,
sir
,
how
familiar
that
name
would
come
to
be
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
will
be
more
familiar
still
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
you
,
Mr.
Boffin
?
<EOS>
Much
obliged
to
you
,
I
'm
sure
.
<EOS>
Is
it
your
pleasure
,
sir
,
that
we
decline
and
we
fall
?
<EOS>
"
with
a
feint
of
taking
up
the
book
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
just
yet
awhile
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
I
have
got
another
offer
to
make
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
(
who
had
had
nothing
else
in
his
mind
for
several
nights
)
took
off
his
spectacles
with
an
air
of
bland
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
hope
you
'll
like
it
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
sir
,
"
returned
that
reticent
individual
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
may
prove
so
.
<EOS>
On
all
accounts
,
I
am
sure
.
"
<EOS>
(
This
,
as
a
philanthropic
aspiration
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
of
not
keeping
a
stall
,
Wegg
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
sir
,
"
replied
Wegg
,
"
that
I
should
like
to
be
shown
the
gentleman
prepared
to
make
it
worth
my
while
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
he
is
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
was
going
to
say
,
My
Benefactor
,
and
had
said
My
Bene
,
when
a
grandiloquent
change
came
over
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
not
you
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Anybody
but
you
.
<EOS>
Do
not
fear
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
that
I
shall
contaminate
the
premises
which
your
gold
has
bought
,
with
my
lowly
pursuits
.
<EOS>
I
am
aware
,
sir
,
that
it
would
not
become
me
to
carry
on
my
little
traffic
under
the
windows
of
your
mansion
.
<EOS>
I
have
already
thought
of
that
,
and
taken
my
measures
.
<EOS>
No
need
to
be
bought
out
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Would
Stepney
Fields
be
considered
intrusive
?
<EOS>
If
not
remote
enough
,
I
can
go
remoter
.
<EOS>
In
the
words
of
the
poet
's
song
,
which
I
do
not
quite
remember
:
   
Thrown
on
the
wide
world
,
doom'd
to
wander
and
roam
,
  
Bereft
of
my
parents
,
bereft
of
a
home
,
  
A
stranger
to
something
<EOS>
and
what
's
his
name
joy
,
  
<EOS>
Behold
little
Edmund
the
poor
Peasant
boy
.
 
<EOS>
---
And
equally
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
repairing
the
want
of
direct
application
in
the
last
line
,
"
behold
myself
on
a
similar
footing
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Wegg
,
Wegg
,
Wegg
,
"
remonstrated
the
excellent
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
too
sensitive
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
I
am
,
sir
,
"
returned
Wegg
,
with
obstinate
magnanimity
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
acquainted
with
my
faults
.
<EOS>
I
always
was
,
from
a
child
,
too
sensitive
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
listen
,
"
pursued
the
Golden
Dustman
;
"
hear
me
out
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
You
have
taken
it
into
your
head
that
I
mean
to
pension
you
off
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
True
,
sir
,
"
returned
Wegg
,
still
with
an
obstinate
magnanimity
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
acquainted
with
my
faults
.
<EOS>
Far
be
it
from
me
to
deny
them
.
<EOS>
I
have
taken
it
into
my
head
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
mean
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
assurance
seemed
hardly
as
comforting
to
Mr.
Wegg
,
as
Mr.
Boffin
intended
it
to
be
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
an
appreciable
elongation
of
his
visage
might
have
been
observed
as
he
replied
:
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
,
indeed
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
pursued
Mr.
Boffin
;
"
because
that
would
express
,
as
I
understand
it
,
that
you
were
not
going
to
do
anything
to
deserve
your
money
.
<EOS>
But
you
are
;
you
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr.
Wegg
,
cheering
up
bravely
,
"
is
quite
another
pair
of
shoes
.
<EOS>
Now
,
my
independence
as
a
man
is
again
elevated
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
no
longer
   
Weep
for
the
hour
,
  
<EOS>
When
to
Boffinses
bower
,
  
<EOS>
The
Lord
of
the
valley
with
offers
came
;
  
<EOS>
Neither
does
the
moon
hide
her
light
  
<EOS>
From
the
heavens
to
-
night
,
  
And
weep
behind
her
clouds
o'er
any
individual
in
the
present
Company
's
shame
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
---
Please
to
proceed
,
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Wegg
,
both
for
your
confidence
in
me
and
for
your
frequent
dropping
into
poetry
;
both
of
which
is
friendly
.
<EOS>
Well
,
then
;
my
idea
is
,
that
you
should
give
up
your
stall
,
and
that
I
should
put
you
into
the
Bower
here
,
to
keep
it
for
us
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
pleasant
spot
;
and
a
man
with
coals
and
candles
and
a
pound
a
week
might
be
in
clover
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hem
!
Would
that
man
,
sir
<EOS>
---
we
will
say
that
man
,
for
the
purposes
of
argueyment
;
"
Mr.
Wegg
made
a
smiling
demonstration
of
great
perspicuity
here
;
"
would
that
man
,
sir
,
be
expected
to
throw
any
other
capacity
in
,
or
would
any
other
capacity
be
considered

?
<EOS>
Now
let
us
(
for
the
purposes
of
argueyment
)
suppose
that
man
to
be
engaged
as
a
reader
:
say
(
for
the
purposes
of
argueyment
)
in
the

.
<EOS>
Would
that
man
's
pay
as
a
reader
in
the
evening
,
be
added
to
the
other
amount
,
which
,
adopting
your
language
,
we
will

clover
;
or
would
it
merge
into
that
amount
,
or
clover
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
I
suppose
it
would
be
added
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
would
,
sir
.
<EOS>
You
are
right
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Exactly
my
own
views
,
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Here
Wegg
rose
,
and
balancing
himself
on
his
wooden
leg
,
fluttered
over
his
prey
with
extended
hand
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,
consider
it
done
.
<EOS>
Say
no
more
,
sir
,
not
a
word
more
.
<EOS>
My
stall
and
I
are
for
ever
parted
.
<EOS>
The
collection
of
ballads
will
in
future
be
reserved
for
private
study
,
with
the
object
of
making
poetry
tributary
"
  
<EOS>
---
Wegg
was
so
proud
of
having
found
this
word
,
that
he
said
it
again
,
with
a
capital
letter
---
"
Tributary
,
to
friendship
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,
do
n't
allow
yourself
to
be
made
uncomfortable
by
the
pang
it
gives
me
to
part
from
my
stock
and
stall
.
<EOS>
Similar
emotion
was
undergone
by
my
own
father
when
promoted
for
his
merits
from
his
occupation
as
a
waterman
to
a
situation
under
Government
.
<EOS>
His
Christian
name
was
Thomas
.
<EOS>
His
words
at
the
time
(
I
was
then
an
infant
,
but
so
deep
was
their
impression
on
me
,
that
I
committed
them
to
memory
)
<EOS>
were
:
   
<EOS>
Then
farewell
my
trim
-
built
wherry
,
  
Oars
and
coat
and
badge
farewell
!
  
<EOS>
Never
more
at
Chelsea
Ferry
,
  
<EOS>
Shall
your
Thomas
take
a
spell
!
 
<EOS>
---
My
father
got
over
it
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
and
so
shall
I.
"
  
<EOS>
While
delivering
these
valedictory
observations
,
Wegg
continually
disappointed
Mr.
Boffin
of
his
hand
by
flourishing
it
in
the
air
.
<EOS>
He
now
darted
it
at
his
patron
,
who
took
it
,
and
felt
his
mind
relieved
of
a
great
weight
:
observing
that
as
they
had
arranged
their
joint
affairs
so
satisfactorily
,
he
would
now
be
glad
to
look
into
those
of
Bully
Sawyers
.
<EOS>
Which
,
indeed
,
had
been
left
over
-
night
in
a
very
unpromising
posture
,
and
for
whose
impending
expedition
against
the
Persians
the
weather
had
been
by
no
means
favourable
all
day
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
resumed
his
spectacles
therefore
.
<EOS>
But
Sawyers
was
not
to
be
of
the
party
that
night
;
for
,
before
Wegg
had
found
his
place
,
Mrs.
Boffin
's
tread
was
heard
upon
the
stairs
,
so
unusually
heavy
and
hurried
,
that
Mr.
Boffin
would
have
started
up
at
the
sound
,
anticipating
some
occurrence
much
out
of
the
common
course
,
even
though
she
had
not
also
called
to
him
in
an
agitated
tone
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
hurried
out
,
and
found
her
on
the
dark
staircase
,
panting
,
with
a
lighted
candle
in
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
,
my
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
;
I
do
n't
know
;
but
I
wish
you
'd
come
up
-
stairs
.
"
  
<EOS>
Much
surprised
,
Mr.
Boffin
went
up
stairs
and
accompanied
Mrs.
Boffin
into
their
own
room
:
a
second
large
room
on
the
same
floor
as
the
room
in
which
the
late
proprietor
had
died
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
looked
all
round
him
,
and
saw
nothing
more
unusual
than
various
articles
of
folded
linen
on
a
large
chest
,
which
Mrs.
Boffin
had
been
sorting
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
Why
,
you
're
frightened
!
<EOS>
You
frightened
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
one
of
that
sort
certainly
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
as
she
sat
down
in
a
chair
to
recover
herself
,
and
took
her
husband
's
arm
;
"
but
it
's
very
strange
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
,
my
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Noddy
,
the
faces
of
the
old
man
and
the
two
children
are
all
over
the
house
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
?
"
exclaimed
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
But
not
without
a
certain
uncomfortable
sensation
gliding
down
his
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
must
sound
foolish
,
and
yet
it
is
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
did
you
think
you
saw
them
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
that
I
think
I
saw
them
anywhere
.
<EOS>
I
felt
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Touched
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
Felt
them
in
the
air
.
<EOS>
I
was
sorting
those
things
on
the
chest
,
and
not
thinking
of
the
old
man
or
the
children
,
but
singing
to
myself
,
when
all
in
a
moment
I
felt
there
was
a
face
growing
out
of
the
dark
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
face
?
"
asked
her
husband
,
looking
about
him
:
  
"
For
a
moment
it
was
the
old
man
's
,
and
then
it
got
younger
.
<EOS>
For
a
moment
it
was
both
the
children
's
,
and
then
it
got
older
.
<EOS>
For
a
moment
it
was
a
strange
face
,
and
then
it
was
all
the
faces
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
it
was
gone
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
and
then
it
was
gone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
were
you
then
,
old
lady
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
at
the
chest
.
<EOS>
Well
;
I
got
the
better
of
it
,
and
went
on
sorting
,
and
went
on
singing
to
myself
.
<EOS>
`
`
Lor
!
"
<EOS>
"
I
says
,
`
I
'll
think
of
something
else
---
something
comfortable
---
and
put
it
out
of
my
head
.
"
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
So
I
thought
of
the
new
house
and
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
,
and
was
thinking
at
a
great
rate
with
that
sheet
there
in
my
hand
,
when
,
all
of
a

,
the
faces
seemed
to
be
hidden
in
among
the
folds
of
it
<EOS>
and
I
let
it
drop
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
it
still
lay
on
the
floor
where
it
had
fallen
,
Mr.
Boffin
picked
it
up
and
laid
it
on
the
chest
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
then
you
ran
down
stairs
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
thought
I
'd
try
another
room
,
and
shake
it
off
.
<EOS>
I
says
to
myself
,
`
`
I
'll
go
and
walk
slowly
up
and
down
the
old
man
's
room
three
times
,
from
end
to
end
,
and
then
I
shall
have
conquered
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
 
I
went
in
with
the
candle
in
my
hand
<EOS>
but
the
moment
I
came
near
the
bed
,
the
air
got
thick
with
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
With
the
faces
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
I
even
felt
that
they
were
in
the
dark
behind
the
sidedoor
,
and
on
the
little
staircase
,
floating
away
into
the
yard
.
<EOS>
Then
,
I
called
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,
lost
in
amazement
,
looked
at
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
,
lost
in
her
own
fluttered
inability
to
make
this
out
,
looked
at
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
my
dear
,
"
said
the
Golden
Dustman
,
"
I
'll
at
once
get
rid
of
Wegg
for
the
night
,
because
he
's
coming
to
inhabit
the
Bower
,
and
it
might
be
put
into
his
head
or
somebody
else
's
,
if
he
heard
this
<EOS>
and
it
got
about
,
that
the
house
is
haunted
.
<EOS>
Whereas
we
know
better
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
we
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
had
the
feeling
in
the
house
before
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
;
 
"
<EOS>
and
I
have
been
about
it
alone
at
all
hours
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
in
the
house
when
Death
was
in
it
,
and
I
have
been
in
the
house
when
Murder
was
a
new
part
of
its
adventures
,
and
I
never
had
a
fright
in
it
yet
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
wo
n't
again
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Depend
upon
it
,
it
comes
of
thinking
and
dwelling
on
that
dark
spot
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
but
why
did
n't
it
come
before
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
This
draft
on
Mr.
Boffin
's
philosophy
could
only
be
met
by
that
gentleman
with
the
remark
that
everything
that
is
at
all
,
must
begin
at
some
time
.
<EOS>
Then
,
tucking
his
wife
's
arm
under
his
own
,
that
she
might
not
be
left
by
herself
to
be
troubled
again
,
he
descended
to
release
Wegg
.
<EOS>
Who
,
being
something
drowsy
after
his
plentiful
repast
,
and
constitutionally
of
a
shirking
temperament
,
was
well
enough
pleased
to
stump
away
,
without
doing
what
he
had
come
to
do
,
and
was
paid
for
doing
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
then
put
on
his
hat
,
and
Mrs.
Boffin
her
shawl
;
and
the
pair
,
further
provided
with
a
bunch
of
keys
and
a
lighted
lantern
,
went
all
over
the
dismal
house
---
dismal
everywhere
,
but
in
their
own
two
rooms
---
from
cellar
to
cock
-
loft
.
<EOS>
Not
resting
satisfied
with
giving
that
much
chace
to
Mrs.
Boffin
's
fancies
,
they
pursued
them
into
the
yard
and
outbuildings
,
and
under
the
Mounds
.
<EOS>
And
setting
the
lantern
,
when
all
was
done
,
at
the
foot
of
one
of
the
Mounds
,
they
comfortably
trotted
to
and
fro
for
an
evening
walk
,
to
the
end
that
the
murky
cobwebs
in
Mrs.
Boffin
's
brain
might
be
blown
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
my
dear
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
when
they
came
in
to
supper
.
<EOS>
"
That
was
the
treatment
,
you
see
.
<EOS>
Completely
worked
round
,
have
n't
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
deary
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
laying
aside
her
shawl
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
not
nervous
any
more
.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
a
bit
troubled
now
.
<EOS>
I
'd
go
anywhere
about
the
house
the
same
as
ever
.
<EOS>
But
---
"
  
"
Eh
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
've
only
to
shut
my
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
what
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
then
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
speaking
with
her

closed
,
and
her
left

,
<EOS>
"
then
,
there
they
are
!
<EOS>
The
old
man
's
face
,
and
it
gets
younger
.
<EOS>
The
two
children
's
faces
,
and
they
get
older
.
<EOS>
A
face
that
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
And
then
all
the
faces
!
"
  
<EOS>
Opening
her

again
,
and
sceing
her
husband
's

,
she
leaned

to
give

the
cheek
,
and
sat
down
to
supper
,
declaring
it
to
be
the
best
face
in
the
world
.
   
<EOS>
MINDERS
AND
RE
-
MINDERS
.
 
<EOS>
The
Secretary
lost
no
time
in
getting
to
work
,
and
his
vigilance
and
method
soon
set
their
mark
on
the
Golden
Dustman
's
affairs
.
<EOS>
His
carnestness
in
determining
to
understand
the
length
and
breadth
and
depth
of
every
piece
of
work
submitted
to
him
by
his
employer
,
was
as
special
as
his
despatch
in
transacting
it
.
<EOS>
He
accepted
no
information
or
explanation
at
second
hand
,
but
made
himself
the
master
of
everything
confided
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
One
part
of
the
Secretary
's
conduct
,
underlying
all
the
rest
,
might
have
been
mistrusted
by
a
man
with
a
better
knowledge
of
men
than
the
Golden
Dustman
had
.
<EOS>
The
Secretary
was
as
far
from
being
inquisitive
or
intrusive
as
Secretary
could
be
,
but
nothing
less
than
a
complete
understanding
of
the
whole
of
the
affairs
would
content
him
.
<EOS>
It
soon
became
apparent
(
from
the
knowledge
with
which
he
set
out
)
that
he
must
have
been
to
the
office
where
the
Harmon
will
was
registered
,
and
must
have
read
the
will
.
<EOS>
He
anticipated
Mr.
Boffin
's
consideration
whether
he
should
be
advised
with
on
this
or
that
topic
,
by
showing
that
he
already
knew
of
it
and
understood
it
.
<EOS>
He
did
this
with
no
attempt
at
concealment
,
seeming
to
be
satisfied
that
it
was
part
of
his
duty
to
have
prepared
himself
at
all
attainable
points
for
its
utmost
discharge
.
  
<EOS>
This
might
---
let
it
be
repeated
---
have
awakened
some
little
vague
mistrust
in
a
man
more
worldly
-
wise
than
the
Golden
Dustman
.
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
,
the
Secretary
was
discerning
,
discreet
,
and
silent
,
though
as
zealous
as
if
the
affairs
had
been
his
own
.
<EOS>
He
showed
no
love
of
patronage
or
the
command
of
money
,
but
distinctly
preferred
resigning
both
to
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
If
,
in
his
limited
sphere
,
he
sought
power
,
it
was
the
power
of
knowledge
;
the
power
derivable
from
a
perfect
comprehension
of
his
business
.
  
<EOS>
As
on
the
Secretary
's
face
there
was
a
nameless
cloud
,
so
on
his
manner
there
was
a
shadow
equally
indefinable
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
he
was
embarrassed
,
as
on
that
first
night
with
the
Wilfer
family
;
 
he
was
habitually
unembarrassed
now
,
and
yet
the
something
remained
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
his
manner
was
bad
,
as
on
that
occasion
;
 
it
was
now
very
good
,
as
being
modest
,
gracious
,
and
ready
.
<EOS>
Yet
the
something
never
left
it
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
written
of
men
who
have
undergone
a
cruel
captivity
,
or
who
have
passed
through
a
terrible
strait
,
or
who
in
self

preservation
have
killed
a
defenceless
fellow
-
creature
,
that
the
record
thereof
has
never
faded
from
their

until
they
died
.
<EOS>
Was
there
any
such
record
here
?
  
<EOS>
He
established
a
temporary
office
for
himself
in
the
new
house
,
and
all
went
well
under
his
hand
,
with
one
singular
exception
.
<EOS>
He
manifestly
objected
to
communicate
with
Mr.
Boffin
's

.
<EOS>
Two

three

,

,

to

;
and

so

,
that
Mr.

spoke
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
,
"
the

.
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Had
he
any

to
Mr.
Lightwood
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know

.
"
  
<EOS>
Had

from

?
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

?
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Of

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Now
,

not

,
for
Lightwood
retained
no
other

than
such

still

about

,
and

arose

.
<EOS>
Many

that
might
have
travelled
to

,
now

short
at

Secretary
,
under

more

and

disposed

than

if

Young
Blight
's

.
<EOS>
This
the
Golden
Dustman
quite
understood
.
<EOS>
Even
the
matter
immediately
in
hand
was
of
very
little
moment
as
requiring
personal
appearance
on
the
Secretary
's
part
,
for
it
amounted
to
no
more
than
this
:
---
<EOS>
The
death
of
Hexam
rendering
the
sweat
of
the
honest
man
's
brow
unprofitable
,
the
honest
man
had
shufflingly
declined
to
moisten
his
brow
for
nothing
,
with
that
severe
exertion
which
is
known
in
legal
circles
as
swearing
your
way
through
a
stone
wall
.
<EOS>
Consequently
,
that
new
light
had
gone
sputtering
out
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
airing
of
the
old
facts
had
led

to
suggest

---
now

---
to

that
Mr.
Julius
Handford
to

.
<EOS>
And
all

of
Mr.
Julius
Handford
being

,
Lightwood

.
  
<EOS>
"
Does

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Still
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
It

;

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
dismissed
the
matter
with
a
nod
or
two
.
<EOS>
The
letter
was
written
,
and
next
day
Mr.
Julius
Handford
was
advertised
for
.
<EOS>
He
was
requested
to
place
himself
in
communication
with
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
,
as
a
possible
means
of
furthering
the
ends
of
justice
,
and
a

was
offered
to
any
one
acquainted
with
his
whereabout
who
would
communicate
the
same
to
the
said
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
at
his
office
in
the
Temple
.
<EOS>
Every
day
for
six
weeks
this
advertisement
appeared
at
the
head
of
all
the
newspapers
,
and
every
day
for
six
weeks
the
Secretary
,
when
he
saw
it
,
said
to
himself
,
in
the
tone
in
which
he
had
said
to
his
employer
,
---
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
it
promises
!
"
  
<EOS>
Among
his
first
occupations
the
pursuit
of
that
orphan
wanted
by
Mrs.
Boffin
held
a
conspicuous
place
.
<EOS>
From
the
earliest
moment
of
his
engagement
he
showed
a
particular
desire
to
please
her
,
and
,
knowing
her
to
have
this
object
at
heart
,
he
followed
it
up
with
unwearying
alacrity
and
interest
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Milvey
had
found
their
search
a
diffcult
one
.
<EOS>
Either
an
eligible
orphan
was
of
the
wrong
sex
(
which
almost
always
happened
)
or
was
too
old
,
or
too
young
,
or
too
sickly
,
or
too
dirty
,
or
too
much
accustomed
to
the
streets
,
or
too
likely
to
run
away
;
or
,
it
was
found
impossible
to
complete
the
philanthropic
transaction
without
buying
the
orphan
.
<EOS>
For
,
the
instant
it
became
known
that
anybody
wanted
the
orphan
,
up
started
some
affectionate
relative
of
the
orphan
who
put
a
price
upon
the
orphan
's
head
.
<EOS>
The
suddenness
of
an
orphan
's
rise
in
the
market
was
not
to
be
paralleled
by
the
maddest
records
of
the
Stock
Exchange
.
<EOS>
He
would
be
at
five
thousand
per
cent
.
<EOS>
discount
out
at
nurse
making
a
mud
pie
at
nine
in
the
morning
,
and
(
being
inquired
for
)
would
go
up
to
five
thousand
per
cent
.
<EOS>
premium
before
noon
.
<EOS>
The
market
was
"
rigged
"
in
various
artful
ways
.
<EOS>
Counterfeit
stock
got
into
circulation
.
<EOS>
Parents
boldly
represented
themselves
as
dead
,
and
brought
their
orphans
with
them
.
<EOS>
Genuine
orphan
-
stock
was
surreptitiously
withdrawn
from
the
market
.
<EOS>
It
being
announced
,
by
emissaries
posted
for
the
purpose
,
that
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Milvey
were
coming
down
the
court
,
orphan
scrip
would
be
instantly
concealed
,
and
production
refused
,
save
on
a
condition
usually
stated
by
the
brokers
as
a
"
a
gallon
of
beer
.
"
<EOS>
Likewise
,
fluctuations
of
a
wild
and
South
-
Sea
nature
were
occasioned
,
by
orphan
-
holders
keeping
back
,
and
then
rushing
into
the
market
a
dozen
together
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
uniform
principle
at
the
root
of
all
these
various
operations
was
bargain
and
sale
;
and
that
principle
could
not
be
recognized
by
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Milvey
.
  
<EOS>
At

,

the
Reverend
Frank
of
a

to

.
<EOS>
One

(
late
his

)

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
In

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
love
story
,
Miss
Wilfer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
no
;
or
I
should
n't
be
reading
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
more
about
money
than
anything
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
does
it
say
that
money
is
better
than
anything
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
"
returned
Bella
,
"
I
forget
what
it
says
,
but
you
can
find
out
for
yourself
,
if
you
like
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
it
any
more
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
took
the
book
---
she
had
fluttered
the
leaves
as
if
it
were
a
fan
---
and
walked
beside
her
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
charged
with
a
message
for
you
,
Miss
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Impossible
,
I
think
!
<EOS>
"
said
Bella
,
with
another
drawl
.
  
<EOS>
"
From
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
She
desired
me
to
assure
you
of
the
pleasure
she
has
in
finding
that
she
will
be
ready
to
receive
you
in
another
week
or
two
at
furthest
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
turned
her
head
towards
him
,
with
her
prettily
-
insolent
eyebrows
raised
,
and
her
eyelids
drooping
.
<EOS>
As
much
as
to
say
,
"
How
did
you
come
by
the
message
,
pray
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
waiting
for
an

of
telling
you
that
I
am
Mr.
Boffin
's
Secretary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
wise
as
ever
,
"
said
Miss
Bella
,
loftily
,
"
for
I
do
n't
know
what
a
Secretary
is
.
<EOS>
Not
that
it
signifies
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
at
all
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
covert

at
her

,
as
he
walked
beside
her
,
showed
him
that
she
had
not
expected
his
ready

to
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
are
you
going
to

always

,
Mr.
Rokesmith
?
<EOS>
"
she
inquired
,
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Always
?
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Very
much
there
?
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
"
drawled
Bella
,
in
a
tone
of
mortification
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
my
position
there
as
Secretary
,
will
be
very
different

yours
as

.
<EOS>
You
will
know

nothing
about

.
<EOS>
I
shall
transact

business
:
you
will
transact

.
<EOS>
I
shall
have
my
salary
to
earn
;
you
will
have
nothing
to
do
but
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Attract
,
sir
?
"
said
Bella
,
again

her
eyebrows
raised
,
and
her
eyelids

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Without
replying
on
this
point
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
went
on
.
"
<EOS>
Excuse
me
;
when
I
first
saw
you
in
your
black
dress
---
"
  
(
"
There
!
"
was
Miss
Bella
's
mental

.
<EOS>
"
What
did
I
say
to
them
at
home
?
<EOS>
Everybody
noticed
that
ridiculous
mourning
.
"
)
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
first
saw
you
in
your
black
dress
,
I
was

a
loss
to
account
for
that
distinction
between
yourself
and
your
family
.
<EOS>
I
hope
it
was
not

to
speculate
upon

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
I
am
sure
,
"
said
Miss
Bella
,
haughtily
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
ought
to
know

how
you
speculated
upon
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
inclined
his

in
a

,
and
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
Since
I
have
been
entrusted
with
Mr.
Boffin
's

,
I
have
necessarily
come
to

little

.
<EOS>
I
venture
to
remark
<EOS>
that
I
feel
persuaded
that
much
of
your
loss
may
be
repaired
.
<EOS>
I
speak
,
of
course
,
merely
of
wealth
,
Miss
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
The
loss
of
a
perfect
stranger
,
whose
worth
,
or

,
I
can
not
estimate
---
  
nor
you
either
---
is
beside
the
question
.
<EOS>
But
this
excellent
gentleman
and
lady
are
so
full
of

,
so
full

,
so

,

---
how

?
---
to
make

for
their
good

,
that
you
have
only
to
respond
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
watched
her
with
another
covert

,
he
saw
a
certain
ambitious
triumph
in
her
face
which
no
assumed

could
conceal
.
  
<EOS>
"
As
we
have
been
brought
under
one
roof
by

,
which
oddly

to
the
new

before

,
I
have

.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
consider
them
intrusive
<EOS>
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
Secretary

.
  
<EOS>
"
Really
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
I
ca
n't
say
what
I

them
,
"
returned

.
<EOS>
"
They
are
perfectly
new

,
and

founded

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
see
.
"
  
<EOS>
These
same
fields
were
opposite
the
Wilfer

.
<EOS>
The
discreet
Mrs.
Wilfer
now
looking
out

window
and
beholding
her
daughter
in
conference
with
her

,
instantly
tied

and
came

for

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been

Miss
Wilfer
,
"

,

,
"
that
I

,

,
Mr.
Boffin
's
Secretary

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

,
"
returned

,

in

,

usage
,
"
the
honor

any

Mr.
Boffin
,
and
it
is
not
for

congratulate

has

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
poor
one
enough
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
"
the
merits
of
Mr.
Boffin
may
be
highly
distinguished
---
<EOS>
may

more

than
the

of
Mrs.
Boffin
would

---
but
it
were
the
insanity
of

to
deem

worthy

better

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
.
<EOS>
I
have
also
been
telling
Miss
Wilfer
that
she
is
expected

at
the
new

in

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Having

,
"

,

,

,
"

the

of
Mrs.
Boffin
<EOS>
,
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Here

Bella

:
"
Do
n't

,
ma
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Peace
!
"

Wilfer
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
ma
,
I
am
not

be
made

.
<EOS>
Interposing
objections
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
repeated

Wilfer
,
with
a
vast

,
"
that
I
am
not
going
to
interpose
objections
.
<EOS>
If
Mrs.
Boffin
(
to
whose

no
disciple
of
Lavater
could
possibly
for

subscribe
)
,
"

"
seeks

,
I
am
content
that

be

of
a
child
of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
use
the
word
,
ma'am
,
<EOS>
I

myself
used
,
"
said
Rokesmith
,
with

,
"
when

Wilfer
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon

,
"
returned

,

,
"
but
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
about
to
say
,
"
pursued
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
who
clearly

the

of

:
"
that
when
I
use
the
term

,
I
do

that
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
excellent
lady
delivered
this
luminous

of
her
views
with
an
air
of
greatly
obliging
her
hearers
,
and
greatly
distinguishing
herself
.
<EOS>
Whereat
Miss
Bella
laughed
a
scornful
little

and
said
:
  
"
Quite
enough
about
this
,
I
am
sure
,
on
all

.
<EOS>
Have
the
goodness
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
to

love
to
Mrs.
Boffin
---
<EOS>
"
  
"
Pardon
me
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mrs.
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
"
Compliments
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Love
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Bella
,
with
a
little

of
her
foot
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
monotonously
.
"
<EOS>
Compliments
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
"
Say
Miss
Wilfer
's
love
,
and
Mrs.
Wilfer
's
compliments
,
"
the
Secretary

,
as

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
shall

to
come

.
<EOS>
The
sooner
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
One

,
Bella
,
"
said

Wilfer
,
"
before

.
<EOS>
I
trust
that
as
a
child
of
mine
you
will
ever
be
sensible
that
it
will
be
graceful
in
you
,
when
associating
with
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
upon
equal

,
to
remember
that
the
Secretary
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
as
your
father
's
lodger
,
has
a
claim
on
your
good
word
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
condescension
with
which
Mrs.
Wilfer
delivered
this
proclamation
of
patronage
,
was
as
wonderful
as
the
swiftness
with
which
the
lodger
had
lost
caste
in
the
Secretary
.
<EOS>
He
smiled
as
the
mother
retired
down
stairs
;
but
his
face
fell
,
as
the
daughter
followed
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
insolent
,
so
trivial
,
so
capricious
,
so
mercenary
,
so
careless
,
so
hard
to
touch
,
so
hard
to
turn
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
bitterly
.
  
<EOS>
And
added
as
he
went
upstairs
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
yet
so
pretty
,
so
pretty
!
"
  
<EOS>
And
added
presently
,
as
he
walked
to
and
fro
in
his
room
.
"
<EOS>
And
if
she
knew
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
knew
that
he
was
shaking
the
house
by
his
walking
to
and
fro
;
and
she
declared
it
another
of
the
miseries
of
being
poor
,
that
you
could
n't
get
rid
of
a
haunting
Secretary
,
stump
---
stump
---
<EOS>
stumping
overhead
in
the
dark
,
like
a
Ghost
.
   
<EOS>
A
DISMAL
SWAMP
.
 
<EOS>
And
now
,
in
the
blooming
summer
days
,
behold
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
established
in
the
eminently
aristocratic
family
mansion
,
and
behold
all
manner
of
crawling
,
creeping
,
fluttering
,
and
buzzing
creatures
,
attracted
by
the
gold
dust
of
the
Golden
Dustman
!
  
<EOS>
Foremost
among
those
leaving
cards
at
the
eminently
aristocratic
door
before
it
is
quite
painted
,
are
the
Veneerings
:
out
of
breath
,
one
might
imagine
,
from
the
impetuosity
of
their
rush
to
the
eminently
aristocratic
steps
.
<EOS>
One
copper
-
plate
Mrs.
Veneering
,
two
copper
-
plate
Mr.
Veneerings
,
and
a
connubial
copper
-
plate
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
,
requesting
the
honour
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
's
company
at
dinner
with
the
utmost
Analytical
solemnities
.
<EOS>
The
enchanting
Lady
Tippins
leaves
a
card
.
<EOS>
Twemlow
leaves
cards
.
<EOS>
A
tall
custard
-
coloured
phaeton
tooling
up
in
a
solemn
manner
leaves
four
cards
,
to
wit
,
a
couple
of
Mr.
Podsnaps
,
a
Mrs.
Podsnap
,
and
a
Miss
Podsnap
.
<EOS>
All
the
world
and
his
wife
and
daughter
leave
cards
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
the
world
's
wife
has
so
many
daughters
,
that
her
card
reads
rather
like
a
Miscellaneous
Lot
at
an
Auction
;
comprising
Mrs.
Tapkins
,
Miss
Tapkins
,
Miss
Frederica
Tapkins
,
Miss
Antonina
Tapkins
,
Miss
Malvina
Tapkins
,
and
Miss
Euphemia
Tapkins
;
at
the
same
time
,
the
same
lady
leaves
the
card
of
Mrs.
Henry
George
Alfred
Swoshle
,
ne
Tapkins
;
also
,
a
card
,
Mrs.
Tapkins
at
Home
,
Wednesdays
,
Music
,
Portland
Place
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
becomes
an
inmate
,
for
an
indefinite
period
,
of
the
eminently
aristocratic
dwelling
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
bears
Miss
Bella
away
to
her
Milliner
's
and
Dressmaker
's
,
and
she
gets
beautifully
dressed
.
<EOS>
The
Veneerings
find
with
swift
remorse
that
they
have
omitted
to
invite
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
One
Mrs.
Veneering
and
one
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
requesting
that
additional
honor
,
instantly
do
penance
in
white
cardboard
on
the
hall
table
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Tapkins
likewise
discovers
her
omission
,
and
with
promptitude
repairs
it
;
 
for
herself
,
for
Miss
Tapkins
,
for
Miss
Frederica
Tapkins
,
for
Miss
Antonina
Tapkins
,
for
Miss
Malvina
Tapkins
,
and
for
Miss
Euphemia
Tapkins
.
<EOS>
Likewise
,
for
Mrs.
Henry
George
Alfred
Swoshle
ne
Tapkins
.
<EOS>
Likewise
,
for
Mrs.
Tapkins
at
Home
,
Wednesdays
,
Music
,
Portland
Place
.
  
<EOS>
Tradesmen
's
books
hunger
,
and
tradesmen
's
mouths
water
,
for
the
gold
dust
of
the
Golden
Dustman
.
<EOS>
As
Mrs.
Boffin
and
Miss
Wilfer
drive
out
,
or
as
Mr.
Boffin
walks
out
at
his
jog
-
trot
pace
,
the
fishmonger
pulls
off
his
hat
with
an
air
of
reverence
founded
on
conviction
.
<EOS>
His
men
cleanse
their
fingers
on
their
woollen
aprons
before
presuming
to
touch
their
foreheads
to
Mr.
Boffin
or
Lady
.
<EOS>
The
gaping
salmon
and
the
golden
mullet
lying
on
the
slab
seem
to
turn
up
their
eyes
sideways
,
as
they
would
turn
up
their
hands
if
they
had
any
,
in
worshipping
admiration
.
<EOS>
The
butcher
,
though
a
portly
and
a
prosperous
man
,
does
n't
know
what
to
do
with
himself
,
so
anxious
is
he
to
express
humility
when
discovered
by
the
passing
Boffins
taking
the
air
in
a
mutton
grove
.
<EOS>
Presents
are
made
to
the
Boffin
servants
,
and
bland
strangers
with
business
-
cards
meeting
said
servants
in
the
street
,
offer
hypothetical
corruption
.
<EOS>
As
,
"
Supposing
I
was
to
be
favored
with
an
order
from
Mr.
Boffin
,
my
dear
friend
,
it
would
be
worth
<EOS>
my
while
"
---
to
do
a
certain
thing
that
I
hope
might
not
prove

to
your
feelings
.
  
<EOS>
But
no
one
knows
so
well
as
the
Secretary
,
who
opens

letters
,
what

is

the
man

stroke

.
<EOS>
Oh
the
varieties
of
dust
for
ocular
use
,
offered

the
gold

of

Golden

!
<EOS>
Fifty
-
seven

to

with
half
-

,

-

houses

,
seven
-
and
-

with
halfpence
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
And

,
my

<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>
Large

,

.
"
<EOS>
Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
.
<EOS>
My
Dear
Sir
,
---
Having
consented
to

the
forthcoming
Annual
Dinner
of
the
Family
Party
Fund
,
and
feeling

the

of

noble

the

supported

a
List

that
shall

the

,

to

.
<EOS>
Soliciting

favorable

14th

,
I

,
My
Dear
Sir
,
Your

Servant
,
Linseed
.
<EOS>
P.S.
<EOS>
The
Steward

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Friendly
this
,
on
the
part
of
the
Duke
of
Linseed
(
and

the

)
,
only

the
hundred
and

but

Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,
in

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,
in

,

,

Society

Middle

.
<EOS>
And
those

Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,

,

West

,

.
  
<EOS>
These
are
the
corporate
beggars
.
<EOS>
But
there
are
,
besides
,
the
individual
beggars
;
and
how
does
the
heart
of
the
Secretary
fail
him
when
he
has
to

with

!
<EOS>
And
they
must
be
coped
with
to
some

,
because
they
all
enclose
documents
(
they
call
their

documents
;
but
they
are
,
as
to
papers
deserving
the
name
,
what
minced
veal
is
to
a
calf
)
,
the
non
-
return
of
which

be

ruin
.
<EOS>
That
is
say
,
they
are
utterly
ruined
now
,
but
they
would
be
more
utterly
ruined
then
.
<EOS>
Among
these
correspondents
are
several
daughters
of
general
officers
,
long

to
every
luxury
of
life
(
except

)
,
who
little

,
when
their
gallant

waged
war
in
the
Peninsula
,
that
they

to

to

,

,
has

with

,

of
Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,
for
a
maiden

in
this
wise
,
understanding
that
he
has
such
a
heart
as
never
was
.
<EOS>
The
Secretary
learns
,
too
,
that
confidence
between
man
and
wife
would
seem
to
obtain
but
rarely
when
virtue
is
in
distress
,
so
numerous
are
the
wives
who
take

to

Mr.
Boffin
for
money
without
the
knowledge
of
their
devoted
husbands
,
who
would
never

it
;
while
,

the
other
hand
,
so
numerous
are
the
husbands
who
take
up
their
pens
to
ask
Mr.
Boffin
for
money
without
the
knowledge
of
their
devoted
wives
,
who
would
instantly
go
out
of
their
senses
if
they
had
the
least

of
the

.
<EOS>
There
are
the
inspired
beggars
,
too
.
<EOS>
These
were
sitting
,
only
yesterday
evening
,
musing
over
a
fragment
of
candle
which
must
soon
go
out
and
leave
them
in
the
dark
for
the
rest

their

,
when
surely
some
Angel

the
name
of
Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,
to
their

,
imparting
rays
of
hope
,
nay
confidence
,
to
which
they
had
long
been
strangers
!
<EOS>
Akin
to
these
are
the
suggestively
-

beggars
.
<EOS>
They
were
partaking
of
a
cold
potato
and
water
by
the
flickering
and

light
of
a
lucifer
-
match
,
in

(
rent

in

,
and

"
like

"
into

)
,

,

,
"

Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,
"
and
would

.
<EOS>
There
are
the
nobly
independent

too
.
<EOS>
These
,
in
the
days

their

,
ever

as

,
and
have
not

that
only

in

,
but
they

from
Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
;
No
,
Mr.
Boffin
<EOS>
;
the
world
may
term
it
pride
,

,
but
they

n't

;
a

,
sir
---
for

,

,

---
is

,

,
count

by

.
<EOS>
There
are
the

of

business
-
habits

.
<EOS>
These
will
make
an
end

at
a
quarter

one
   
P.M.
on
Tuesday
<EOS>
,

,

;

,

(

)

"

.
<EOS>
"
There

beggars
on

,
in

from

.
<EOS>
These

.
<EOS>
The
goal

,

,

,

,

,

,

---

,

---
they
must

,
unless
they
receive
its

Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
.
<EOS>
Less
given
to
detail
are
the
beggars
who
make

ventures
.
<EOS>
These
,
usually
to
be
addressed
in
reply
under
initials
at
a

,
inquire
in

hands
,
Dare
one
who
can
not

to
Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,
but
whose
name
might
startle
him
<EOS>
were
it
revealed
,
solicit
the
immediate

of
two
hundred
pounds
from
unexpected
riches
exercising
their
noblest
privilege
in
the
trust
of
a
common
humanity
?
  
<EOS>
In
such
a
Dismal
Swamp
does
the
new
house
stand
,
and
through
it
does
the
Secretary
daily
struggle
breast
-
high
.
<EOS>
Not
to
mention
all
the
people
alive
who
have
made
inventions
that
wo
n't
act
,
and
all
the
jobbers
who
job
in
all
the
jobberies
jobbed
;
though
these
may
be
regarded
as
the
Alligators
of
the
Dismal
Swamp
,
and
are
always
lying
by
to
drag
the
Golden
Dustman
under
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
old
house
.
<EOS>
There
are
no
designs
against
the
Golden
Dustman
there
?
<EOS>
There
are
no
fish
of
the
shark
tribe
in
the
Bower
waters
?
<EOS>
Perhaps
not
.
<EOS>
Still
,
Wegg
is
established
there
,
and
would
seem
,
judged
by
his
secret
proceedings
,
to
cherish
a
notion
of
making
a
discovery
.
<EOS>
For
,
when
a
man
with
a
wooden
leg
lies
prone
on
his
stomach
to
peep
under
bedsteads
;
and
hops
up
ladders
,
like
some
extinct
bird
,
to
survey
the
tops
of
presses
and
cupboards
;
and
provides
himself
an
iron
rod
which
he
is
always
poking
and
prodding
into
dust
-
mounds
;
the
probability
is
that
he
expects
to
find
something
.
     
<EOS>
Birds
of
A
Feather
.
 
<EOS>
OF
AN
EDUCATIONAL
CHARACTER
.
 
<EOS>
The
school
at
which
young
Charley
Hexam
had
first
learned
from
a
book
---
the
streets
being
,
for
pupils
of
his
degree
,
the
great
Preparatory
Establishment
in
which
very
much
that
is
never
unlearned
is
learned
without
and
before
book
---
was
a
miserable
loft
in
an
unsavoury
yard
.
<EOS>
Its
atmosphere
was
oppressive
and
disagreeable
;
 
it
was
crowded
,
noisy
,
and
confusing
;
half
the
pupils
dropped
asleep
,
or
fell
into
a
state
of
waking
stupefaction
;
the
other
half
kept
them
in
either
condition
by
maintaining
a
monotonous
droning
noise
,
as
if
they
were
performing
,
out
of
time
and
tune
,
on
a
ruder
sort
of
bagpipe
.
<EOS>
The
teachers
,
animated
solely
by
good
intentions
,
had
no
idea
of
execution
,
and
a
lamentable
jumble
was
the
upshot
of
their
kind
endeavours
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
school
for
all
ages
,
and
for
both
sexes
.
<EOS>
The
latter
were
kept
apart
,
and
the
former
were
partitioned
off
into
square
assortments
.
<EOS>
But
,
all
the
place
was
pervaded
by
a
grimly
ludicrous
pretence
that
every
pupil
was
childish
and
innocent
.
<EOS>
This
pretence
,
much
favoured
by
the
lady
-
visitors
,
led
to
the
ghastliest
absurdities
.
<EOS>
Young
women
old
in
the
vices
of
the
commonest
and
worst
life
,
were
expected
to
profess
themselves
enthralled
by
the
good
child
's
book
,
the
Adventures
of
Little
Margery
,
who
resided
in
the
village
cottage
by
the
mill
;
severely
reproved
and
morally
squashed
the
miller
,
when
she
was
five
and
he
was
fifty
;
divided
her
porridge
with
singing
birds
;
denied
herself
a
new
nankeen
bonnet
,
on
the
ground
that
the
turnips
did
not
wear
nankeen
bonnets
,
neither
did
the
sheep
who
ate
them
;
who
plaited
straw
and
delivered
the
dreariest
orations
to
all
comers
,
at
all
sorts
of
unseasonable
times
.
<EOS>
So
,
unwieldy
young
dredgers
and
hulking
mudlarks
were
referred
to
the
experiences
of
Thomas
Twopence
,
who
,
having
resolved
not
to
rob
(
under
circumstances
of
uncommon
atrocity
)
his
particular
friend
and
benefactor
,
of
eighteenpence
,
presently
came
into
supernatural
possession
of
three
and
sixpence
,
and
lived
a
shining
light
ever
afterwards
.
<EOS>
(
Note
,
that
the
benefactor
came
to
no
good
.
)
<EOS>
Several
swaggering
sinners
had
written
their
own
biographies
in
the
same
strain
;
it
always
appearing
from
the
lessons
of
those
very
boastful
persons
,
that
you
were
to
do
good
,
not
because
it
was
good
,
but
because
you
were
to
make
a
good
thing
of
it
.
<EOS>
Contrariwise
,
the
adult
pupils
were
taught
to
read
(
if
they
could
learn
)
out
of
the
New
Testament
;
and
by
dint
of
stumbling
over
the
syllables
and
keeping
their
bewildered
eyes
on
the
particular
syllables
coming
round
to
their
turn
,
were
as
absolutely
ignorant
of
the
sublime
history
,
as
if
they
had
never
seen
or
heard
of
it
.
<EOS>
An
exceedingly
and
confoundingly
perplexing
jumble
of
a
school
,
in
fact
,
where
black
spirits
and
grey
,
red
spirits
and
white
,
jumbled
jumbled
jumbled
jumbled
,
jumbled
every
night
.
<EOS>
And
particularly
every
Sunday
night
.
<EOS>
For
then
,
an
inclined
plane
of
unfortunate
infants
would
be
handed
over
to
the
prosiest
and
worst
of
all
the
teachers
with
good
intentions
,
whom
nobody
older
would
endure
.
<EOS>
Who
,
taking
his
stand
on
the
floor
before
them
as
chief
executioner
,
would
be
attended
by
a
conventional
volunteer
boy
as
executioner
's
assistant
.
<EOS>
When
and
where
it
first
became
the
conventional
system
that
a
weary
or
inattentive
infant
in
a
class
must
have
its
face
smoothed
downward
with
a
hot
hand
,
or
when
and
where
the
conventional
volunteer
boy
first
beheld
such
system
in
operation
,
and
became
inflamed
with
a
sacred
zeal
to
administer
it
,
matters
not
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
function
of
the
chief
executioner
to
hold
forth
,
and
it
was
the
function
of
the
acolyte
to
dart
at
sleeping
infants
,
yawning
infants
,
restless
infants
,
whimpering
infants
,
and
smooth
their
wretched
faces
;
sometimes
with
one
hand
,
as
if
he
were
anointing
them
for
a
whisker
;
sometimes
with
both
hands
,
applied
after
the
fashion
of
blinkers
.
<EOS>
And
so
the
jumble
would
be
in
action
in
this
department
for
a
mortal
hour
;
the
exponent
drawling
on
to
My
Dearerr
Childerrenerr
,
let
us
say
,
for
example
,
about
the
beautiful
coming
to
the
Sepulchre
;
and
repeating
the
word
Sepulchre
(
commonly
used
among
infants
)
five
hundred
times
,
and
never
once
hinting
what
it
meant
;
the
conventional
boy
smoothing
away
right
and
left
,
as
an
infallible
commentary
;
the
whole
hot
-
bed
of
flushed
and
exhausted
infants
exchanging
measles
,
rashes
,
whooping
-
cough
,
fever
,
and
stomach
disorders
,
as
if
they
were
assembled
in
High
Market
for
the
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
Even
in
this
temple
of
good
intentions
,
an
exceptionally
sharp
boy
exceptionally
determined
to
learn
,
could
learn
something
,
and
,
having
learned
it
,
could
impart
it
much
better
than
the
teachers
;
 
as
being
more
knowing
than
they
,
and
not
at
the
disadvantage
in
which
they
stood
towards
the
shrewder
pupils
.
<EOS>
In
this
way
it
had
come
about
that
Charley
Hexam
had
risen
in
the
jumble
,
taught
in
the
jumble
,
and
been
received
from
the
jumble
into
a
better
school
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
you
want
to
go
and
see
your
sister
,
Hexam
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
If
you
please
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
half
a
mind
to
go
with
you
.
<EOS>
Where
does
your
sister
live
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
she
is
not
settled
yet
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
I
'd
<EOS>
rather
you
did
n't
see
her
till
she
is
settled
,
if
it
was
all
the
same
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
Hexam
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bradley
Headstone
,
highly
certificated
stipendiary
schoolmaster
,
drew
his
right
forefinger
through
one
of
the
buttonholes
of
the
boy
's

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

sister
may
be
good

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do

doubt

,
Mr.
Headstone
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
say
I
doubted
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
;
you
did

say
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
Bradley
Headstone
looked
at
his
finger
again
,
took
it
out
of
the
buttonhole
and
looked
at

closer
,
bit
the
side
of

and
looked
at

again
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Hexam
,
you
will

one
of

.
<EOS>
In
good

you
are
sure
to
pass
a
creditable

and
become
one
of
us
.
<EOS>
Then
the
question
is
---
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
waited
so
long
for
the
question
,
while
the
schoolmaster
looked
at
a
new
side
of
his
finger
,
and
bit

,
and
looked
at
it
again
,
that
at
length
the
boy
repeated
:
  
"
The
question
is
,
sir
---
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
Whether
you
had
not
better
leave
well
alone
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Is
it
well
to
leave
my
sister
alone
,
Mr.
Headstone
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
say
so
,
because
I
do
not
know
.
<EOS>
I
put
it
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
ask
you
to
think

it
.
<EOS>
I
want
you
to
consider
.
<EOS>
You
know
how
well
you
are
doing
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
After
all
,
she
got
me
here
,
"
said
the
boy
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Perceiving
the
necessity
of
it
,
"
acquiesced
the
schoolmaster
,
"
and
making
up
her
mind
fully
to
the

.
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
,
with
a
return
of
that
former
reluctance
or
struggle
or
whatever
it
was
,
seemed
to
debate
with

.
<EOS>
At
length
he
said
,
raising
his

to
the
master
's

:
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
'd
come
with
me
and
see
her
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
though
she
is
not
settled
.
<EOS>
I
wish

'd
come
with
me
,
and
take
her
in
the
rough
,
and
judge
her
for

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
sure
you
would
not
like
,
"
asked
the

,
"
to
prepare
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
sister
Lizzie
,
"
said
the
boy
,
proudly
,
"
wants
no
preparing
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
What
she
is
,
she
is
,
and
shows
herself
to
be
.
<EOS>
There
's
no
pretending
about
my
sister
.
"
  
<EOS>
His
confidence
in
her
,
sat
more
easily
upon
him
than
the
indecision
with
which
he
had
twice
contended
.
<EOS>
It
was
his
better
nature
to
be
true
to
her
,
if
it
were
his
worse
nature
to
be
wholly

.
<EOS>
And
as
yet
the
better
nature
had
the
stronger
hold
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
can
spare
the
evening
,
"
said
the
schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
ready
to
walk
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
And
I
am
ready
to
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
Headstone
,
in
his
decent
black
coat
and
waistcoat
,
and
decent
white
shirt
,
and
decent
formal
black
tie
,
and
decent
pantaloons
of
pepper
and
salt
,
with
his
decent
silver
watch
in
his
pocket
and
its
decent
hair
-
guard
round
his
neck
,
looked
a
thoroughly
decent
young
man
of
six
-
and
-
twenty
.
<EOS>
He
was
never
seen
in
any
other
dress
,
and
yet
there
was
a
certain
stiffness
in
his
manner
of
wearing
this
,
as
if
there
were
a
want
of
adaptation
between
him
and
it
,
recalling
some
mechanics
in
their
holiday
clothes
.
<EOS>
He
had
acquired
mechanically
a
great
store
of
teacher
's
knowledge
.
<EOS>
He
could
do
mental
arithmetic
mechanically
,
sing
at
sight
mechanically
,
blow
various
wind
instruments
mechanically
,
even
play
the
great
church
organ
mechanically
.
<EOS>
From
his
early
childhood
up
,
his
mind
had
been
a
place
of
mechanical
stowage
.
<EOS>
The
arrangement
of
his
wholesale
warehouse
,
so
that
it
might
be
always
ready
to
meet
the
demands
of
retail
dealers
---
history
here
,
geography
there
,
astronomy
to
the
right
,
political
economy
to
the
left
---
natural
history
,
the
physical
sciences
,
figures
,
music
,
the
lower
mathematics
,
and
what
not
,
all
in
their
several
places
---
this
care
had
imparted
to
his
countenance
a
look
of
care
;
while
the
habit
of
questioning
and
being
questioned
had
given
him
a
suspicious
manner
,
or
a
manner
that
would
be
better
described
as
one
of
lying
in
wait
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
kind
of
settled
trouble
in
the
face
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
face
belonging
to
a
naturally
slow
or
inattentive
intellect
that
had
toiled
hard
to
get
what
it
had
won
,
and
that
had
to
hold
it
now
that
it
was
gotten
.
<EOS>
He
always
seemed
to
be
uneasy
lest
anything
should
be
missing
from
his
mental
warehouse
,
and
taking
stock
to
assure
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Suppression
of
so
much
to
make
room
for
so
much
,
had
given
him
a
constrained
manner
,
over
and
above
.
<EOS>
Yet
there
was
enough
of
what
was
animal
,
and
of
what
was
fiery
(
though
smouldering
)
,
still
visible
in
him
,
to
suggest
that
if
young
Bradley
Headstone
,
when
a
pauper
lad
,
had
chanced
to
be
told
off
for
the
sea
,
he
would
not
have
been
the
last
man
in
a
ship
's
crew
.
<EOS>
Regarding
that
origin
of
his
,
he
was
proud
,
moody
,
and
sullen
,
desiring
it
to
be
forgotten
.
<EOS>
And
few
people
knew
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
In
some
visits
to
the
Jumble
his
attention
had
been
attracted
to
this
boy
Hexam
.
<EOS>
An
undeniable
boy
for
a
pupil
-
teacher
;
an
undeniable
boy
to
do
credit
to
the
master
who
should
bring
him
on
.
<EOS>
Combined
with
this
consideration
,
there
may
have
been
some
thought
of
the
pauper
lad
now
never
to
be
mentioned
.
<EOS>
Be
that
how
it
might
,
he
had
with
pains
gradually
worked
the
boy
into
his
own
school
,
and
procured
him
some
offices
to
discharge
there
,
which
were
repaid
with
food
and
lodging
.
<EOS>
Such
were
the
circumstances
that
had
brought
together
,
Bradley
Headstone
and
young
Charley
Hexam
that
autumn

.
<EOS>
Autumn
,
because
full
half
a
year
had
come
and
gone
since
the
bird
of
prey
lay
dead
upon
the
river
-
shore
.
  
<EOS>
The
schools
---
for
they
were
twofold
,
as
the
sexes
---
were
down
in
that
district
of
the
flat
country
tending
to
the
Thames
,
where
Kent
and
Surrey
meet
,
and
where
the
railways
still
bestride
the
market
-
gardens
that
will
soon
die
under
them
.
<EOS>
The
schools
were
newly
built
,
and
there
were
so
many
like
them
all
over
the
country
,
that
one
might
have
thought
the
whole
were
but
one
restless
edifice
with
the
locomotive
gift
of
Aladdin
's

.
<EOS>
They
were
in
a
neighbourhood
which
looked
like
a
toy
neighbourhood
taken
in
blocks
out
of
a
box
by
a
child
of
particularly
incoherent
mind
,
and
set
up
anyhow
;
here
,
one
side
of
a
new
street
;
there
,
a
large
solitary
public
-
house
facing
nowhere
;
here
,
another
unfinished
street
already
in
ruins
;
there
,
a
church
;
here
,
an
immense
new
warehouse
;
there
,
a
dilapidated
old
country
villa
;
then
,
a
medley
of
black
ditch
,
sparkling
cucumber
-
frame
,
rank
field
,
richly
cultivated
kitchen
-
garden
,
brick
