,
arch
-
spanned
canal
,
and
disorder
of
frowziness
and
fog
.
<EOS>
As
if
the
child
had
given
the
table
a
kick
,
and
gone
to
sleep
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
even
among
school
-
buildings
,
school
-
teachers
,
and
school
-
pupils
,
all
according
to
pattern
and
all
engendered
in
the
light
of
the
latest
Gospel
according
to
Monotony
,
the
older
pattern
into
which
so
many
fortunes
have
been
shaped
for
good
and
evil
,
comes
out
.
<EOS>
It
came
out
in
Miss
Peecher
the
schoolmistress
,
watering
her
flowers
,
as
Mr.
Bradley
Headstone
walked
forth
.
<EOS>
It
came
out
in
Miss
Peecher
the
schoolmistress
,
watering
the
flowers
in
the
little
dusty
bit
of
garden
attached
to
her
small
official
residence
,
with
little
windows
like
the
eyes
in
needles
,
and
little
doors
like
the
covers
of
school
books
.
  
<EOS>
Small
,
shining
,
neat
,
methodical
,
and
buxom
was
Miss
Peecher
cherry
-
cheeked
and
tuneful
of
voice
.
<EOS>
A
little
pincushion
,
a
little
housewife
,
a
little
book
,
a
little
workbox
,
a
little
set
of
tables
and
weights
and
measures
,
and
a
little
woman
,
all
in
one
.
<EOS>
She
could
write
a
little
essay
on
any
subject
,
exactly
a
slate
long
,
beginning
at
the
left
-
hand
top
of
one
side
and
ending
at
the
right
-
hand
bottom
of
the
other
,
and
the
essay
should
be
strictly
according
to
rule
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Bradley
Headstone
had
addressed
a
written
proposal
of
marriage
to
her
,
she
would
probably
have
replied
in
a
complete
little
essay
on
the
theme
exactly
a
slate
long
,
but
would
certainly
have
replied
Yes
.
<EOS>
For
she
loved
him
.
<EOS>
The
decent
hair
-
guard
that
went
round
his
neck
and
took
care
of
his
decent
silver
watch
was
an
object
of
envy
to
her
.
<EOS>
So
would
Miss
Peecher
have
gone
round
his
neck
and
taken
care
of
him
.
<EOS>
Of
him
,
insensible
.
<EOS>
Because
he
did
not
love
Miss
Peecher
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Peecher
's
favourite
pupil
,
who
assisted
her
in
her
little
household
,
was
in
attendance
with
a
can
of
water
to
replenish
her
little
watering
-
pot
,
and
sufficiently
divined
the
state
of
Miss
Peecher
's
affections
to
feel
it
necessary
that
she
herself
should
love
young
Charley
Hexam
.
<EOS>
So
,
there
was
a
double
palpitation
among
the
double
stocks
and
double
wall
-
flowers
,
when
the
master
and
the
boy
looked
over
the
little
gate
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
fine
evening
,
Miss
Peecher
,
"
said
the
Master
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
fine
evening
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
"
said
Miss
Peecher
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
taking
a
walk
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hexam
and
I
are
going
to
take
a
long
walk
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Charming
weather
,
"
remarked
Miss
Peecher
,
"
for
a
long
walk
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Ours
is
rather
on
business
than
mere
pleasure
,
"
said
the
Master
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Peecher
inverting
her
watering
-
pot
,
and
very
carefully
shaking
out
the
few
last
drops
over
a
flower
,
as
if
there
were
some
special
virtue
in
them
which
would
make
it
a
Jack
's
beanstalk
before
morning
,
called
for
replenishment
to
her
pupil
,
who
had
been
speaking
to
the
boy
.
  
<EOS>
"

right
fist
close
before
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
scarcely
required
the
teacher
-
habit
,
to
perceive
that
the
doll
's
dressmaker
was
inclined
to
be
bitter
on
the
difference
between
herself
and
other
children
.
<EOS>
But
both
master
and
pupil
understood
it
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
Always
running
about
and
screeching
,
always
playing
and
fighting
,
always
skip
-
skip
-
skipping
on
the
pavement
and
chalking
it
for
their
games
!
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
know
their
tricks
and
their
manners
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shaking
the
little
fist
as
before
.
"
<EOS>
And
that
's
not
all
.
<EOS>
Ever
so
often
calling
names
in
through
a
person
's
keyhole
,
and
imitating
a
person
's
back
and
legs
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
know
their
tricks
and
their
manners
.
<EOS>
And
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
'd
do
,
to
punish
'em
.
<EOS>
There
's
doors
under
the
church
in
the
Square
---
black
doors
,
leading
into
black
vaults
.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
'd
open
one
of
those
doors
,
and
I
'd
cram
'em
all
in
,
<EOS>
and
then
I
'd
lock
the
door
and
through
the
keyhole
I
'd
blow
in
pepper
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
be
the
good
of
blowing
in
pepper
?
"
asked
Charley
Hexam
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
set
'em
sneezing
,
"
said
the
person
of
the
house
,
"
and
make
their
eyes
water
.
<EOS>
And
when
they
were
all
sneezing
and
inflamed
,
I
'd
mock
'em
through
the
keyhole
.
<EOS>
Just
as
they
,
with
their
tricks
and
their
manners
,
mock
a
person
through
a
person
's
keyhole
!
"
  
<EOS>
An
uncommonly
emphatic
shake
of
her
little
fist
close
before
her
eyes
,
seemed
to
ease
the
mind
of
the
person
of
the
house
;
for
she
added
with
recovered
composure
,
"
No
,
no
,
no
.
<EOS>
No
children
for
me
.
<EOS>
Give
me
grown
-
ups
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
difficult
to
guess
the
age
of
this
strange
creature
,
for
her
poor
figure
furnished
no
clue
to
it
,
and
her
face
was
at
once
so
young
and
so
old
.
<EOS>
Twelve
,
or
at
the
most
thirteen
,
might
be
near
the
mark
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
always
did
like
grown
-
ups
,
"
she
went
on
,
"
and
always
kept
company
with
them
.
<EOS>
So
sensible
.
<EOS>
Sit
so
quiet
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
prancing
and
capering
about
!
<EOS>
And
I
mean
always
to
keep
among
none
but
grown
-
ups
till
I
marry
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
I
must
make
up
my
mind
to
marry
,
one
of
these
days
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
listened
to
a
step
outside
that
caught
her
ear
,
and
there
was
a
soft
knock
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
Pulling
at
a
handle
within
her
reach
,
she
said
,
with
a
pleased
laugh
:
"
Now
here
,
for
instance
,
is
a
grown
-
up
that
's
my
particular
friend
!
"
<EOS>
and
Lizzie
Hexam
in
a
black
dress
entered
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
!
<EOS>
You
!
"
  
<EOS>
Taking
him
to
her
arms
in
the
old
way
---
of
which
he
seemed
a
little
ashamed
---
she
saw
no
one
else
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
,
there
,
Liz
,
all
right
my
dear
.
<EOS>
See
!
<EOS>
Here
's
Mr.
Headstone
come
with
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Her
eyes
met
those
of
the
schoolmaster
,
who
had
evidently
expected
to
see
a
very
different
sort
of
person
,
and
a
murmured
word
or
two
of
salutation
passed
between

.
<EOS>
She
was
a
little
flurried
by
the
unexpected
visit
,
and
the
schoolmaster
was
not
at
his
ease
.
<EOS>
But
he
never
was
,
quite
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
told
Mr.
Headstone
you
were
not
settled
,
Liz
,
but
he
was
so
kind
as
to
take
an
interest
in
coming
,
and
so
I
brought
him
.
<EOS>
How
well
you
look
!
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
seemed
to
think
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
she
,
do
n't
she
?
"
<EOS>
cried
the
person
of
the
house
,
resuming
her
occupation
,
though
the
twilight
was
falling
fast
.
<EOS>
"
I
believe
you
she
does
!
<EOS>
But
go
on
with
your
chat
,
one
and
all
:
  
`
`
<EOS>
You
one
two
three
,
  
My
com
-
pa
-
nie
,
  
<EOS>
And
do
n't
mind
me
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
   
---
pointing
this
impromptu
rhyme
with
three
points
of
her
thin
forefinger
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
expect
a
visit
from
you
,
Charley
,
"
said
his
sister
.
<EOS>
"
I
supposed
that
if
you
wanted
to
see
me
you
would
have
sent
to
me
,
appointing
me
to
come
somewhere
near
the
school
,
as
I
did
last

.
<EOS>
I
saw
my
brother
near
the
school
,
sir
,
"
to
Bradley
Headstone
,
"
because
it
's
easier
for
me
to

there
,
than
for
him
to
come
here
.
<EOS>
I
work
about
midway
between
the
two

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
see
much
of
one
another
,
"
said
Bradley
,
not
improving
in
respect
of
ease
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
<EOS>
With
a
rather
sad

of

.
<EOS>
"
Charley
always
does
well
,
Mr.
Headstone
?
"
  
"
He
could
not
do

.
<EOS>
I
regard
his

as
quite
plain

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hoped
so
.
<EOS>
I

so

.
<EOS>
So
well
done
of
you
,
Charley
dear
!
<EOS>
It

me

come
(

)
between

.
<EOS>
You

,

Headstone
?
"
  
<EOS>
Conscious

-

was

,
and
that

suggested

boy
's

aloof
from
this

,

<EOS>
face
to
face
<EOS>
,
Bradley
Headstone
stammered
:
  
"
<EOS>
Your
brother
is
very
much
occupied
,

.
<EOS>
He
has
to
work
hard
.
<EOS>
One
can
not
but
say
that
the

his

is
diverted
from
his

,
the
better
for
his

.
<EOS>
When
he
shall
have
established
himself
,
why

---
it
will

another

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
shook
her

again
,
and
returned
,
with
a
quiet
smile
:
"
I
always
advised
him
as
you
advise

.
<EOS>
Did
I
not
,
Charley
?
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
never

that
now
,
"
said
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
How
are
you
getting
on
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
I
want
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
your
own
room
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
.
<EOS>
Upstairs
.
<EOS>
And
it
's
quiet
,
and
pleasant
,
and
airy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
always
has
the
use
of
this
room
for
visitors
,
"
said
the
person
of
the
house
,
screwing
up
one
of
her
little
bony
fists
,
like
an
opera
-
glass
,
and
looking
through
it
,
with
her
eyes
and
her

in
that
quaint
accordance
.
<EOS>
"
Always
this
room
for
visitors
;
have

you
,
Lizzie
dear
?
"
  
It
happened
that
Bradley
Headstone
noticed
a
very
slight
action
of
Lizzie
Hexam
's
hand
,
as
though
it
checked
the
doll
's
dressmaker
.
<EOS>
And
it
happened
that
the
latter
noticed
him
in
the
same
instant
;
 
for
she
made
a
double
eyeglass
of
her

,
looked

him
through
it
,
and
cried
,
with

her

:
"
<EOS>
Aha
!
<EOS>
Caught
you
spying
,
did
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
might
have
fallen
out
so
,
any
way
;
but
Bradley
Headstone
also
noticed
that
immediately
after
this
,
Lizzie
,
who
had
not
taken
off
her
bonnet
,
rather
hurriedly
proposed
that
as
the
room
was
getting

they
should
go
out
into
the
air
.
<EOS>
They
went
out
;
the
visitors
saying
good
-
night
to
the
doll
's
dressmaker
,
whom

left
,
leaning

in
her

with

,
singing
to

in
a
sweet

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
saunter
on
by
the
river
,
"
said
Bradley
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
be
glad
to
talk
together
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
his
uneasy
figure
went
on
before
them
among
the
evening

,
the
boy
said
to
his
sister
,
petulantly
:
  
"
When
are
you
going
to
settle
yourself
in
some
Christian
sort
of
place
,
Liz
?
<EOS>
I
thought
you
were
going
to
do
it
before
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
well
where
I
am
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
well
where
you
are
!
<EOS>
I
am
ashamed
to

brought
Mr.
Headstone
with
me
.
<EOS>
How
came
you
to
get
into
such
company
as
that
little

's
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
chance

first
,
as
it
seemed
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
But
I
think
it
must
have
been
by

more
than
chance
,
for
that
child
<EOS>
---
You
remember
the
bills
upon
the
walls
at
home
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Confound
the
bills
upon
the
walls
at
home
!
<EOS>
I
want
to
forget
the
bills
upon
the
walls
at
home
,
and
it
would
be
better
for
you
to
do
the

,
"
grumbled

boy
.
"
<EOS>
Well
;
what
of
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
child
is
the
grandchild
of
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
What
old
man
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
The
terrible
drunken
old
man
,
in
the
list
slippers
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
asked
,
rubbing

nose
in
a

that
half

at

much
,

:
"
How
came
you
to
make

?
<EOS>
What
a
girl

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
child
's
father
is
employed
by
the
house
that
employs
me
;
that
's
how
I
came
to
know
it
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
The
father
is
like
his
own
father
,
a
weak
wretched
trembling
creature
,
falling
to
pieces
,
never
sober
.
<EOS>
But
a
good
workman
too
,
at
the
work
he
does
.
<EOS>
The
mother
is
dead
.
<EOS>
This
poor
ailing
little
creature
has
come
to
be
what
she
is
,
surrounded
by
drunken
people
from
her
cradle
---
if
she
ever
had
one
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
see
what
you
have
to
do
with
her
,
for
all
that
,
"
said
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
,
Charley
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
looked
doggedly
at
the
river
.
<EOS>
They
were
at
Millbank
,
and
the
river
rolled
on
their
left
.
<EOS>
His
sister
gently
touched
him
on
the
shoulder
,
and
pointed
to
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Any
compensation
---
restitution
---
never
mind
the
word
,
you
know
my
meaning
.
<EOS>
Father
's
grave
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
respond
with
any
tenderness
.
<EOS>
After
a
moody
silence
he
broke
out
in
an
ill

used
tone
:
  
<EOS>
"
It
'll
be
a
very
hard
thing
,
Liz
,
if
,

I
am
trying
my
best
to
get
up
in
the
world
,
you
pull
me
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
,
Charley
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
,
Liz
.
<EOS>
Why
ca
n't
you
let
bygones
be
bygones
?
<EOS>
Why
ca
n't
you
,
as
Mr.
Headstone
said
to

this
very
evening
about
another
matter
,
leave
well
alone
?
<EOS>
What

have
got
to
do
,

,
to

new

,
and
keep

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
never
look
back
?
<EOS>
Not
even
to
try
to
make

amends
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
are
such
a
dreamer
,
"
said
the
boy
,
with
his
former
petulance
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
all
very
well
when
we
sat
before
the
fire
---
when
we
looked
into
the
hollow
down
by
the

---
but
we
are
looking
into
the
real
world
,
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
we
were
looking
into
the
real

then
,
Charley
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
understand
what
you
mean
by
that
,
but
you
are
not
justified
in
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
,
as
I
raise
myself
,
to
shake
you
off
,
Liz
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
carry
you
up
with
me
.
<EOS>
That
's
what
I
want
to
do
,
and
mean
to
do
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
owe
you
.
<EOS>
I
said
to
Mr.
Headstone
this
very
evening
,
`
`
After
all
,
my
sister
got
me
here
.
"
<EOS>
"
Well
,
then
.
Do
n't
pull
me
back
,
and
hold
me
down
.
<EOS>
That
's
all
I
ask
,
and
surely
that
's
not
unconscionable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
kept
a
steadfast
look
upon
him
,
and
she
answered
with
composure
:
  
"
I
am
not
here
selfishly
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
To
please
myself
,
I
could
not
be
too
far
from
that
river
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
could
you
be
too
far
from
it
to
please
me
.
<EOS>
Let
us
get
quit
of
it
equally
.
<EOS>
Why
should
you
linger
about
it
any
more
than
I
?
<EOS>
I
give
it
a
wide
berth
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
get
away
from
it
,
I
think
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
passing
her
hand
across
her
forehead
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
purpose
of
mine
that
I
live
by
it
still
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
you
go
,
Liz
!
<EOS>
Dreaming
again
!
<EOS>
You
lodge
yourself
of
your
own
accord
in
a
house
with
a
drunken
---
tailor
,
I
suppose
---
or
something
of
the
sort
,
and
a
little
crooked
antic
of
a
child
,
or
old
person
,
or
whatever
it
is
,
and
then
you
talk
as
if
you
were
drawn
or
driven
there
.
<EOS>
Now
,
do
be
more
practical
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
been
practical
enough
with
him
,
in
suffering
and
striving
for
him
;
but
she
only
laid
her
hand
upon
his
shoulder
---
not
reproachfully
 
---
and
tapped
it
twice
or
thrice
.
<EOS>
She
had
been
used
to
do
so
,
to
soothe
him
when
she
carried
him
about
,
a
child
as
heavy
as
herself
.
<EOS>
Tears
started
to
his
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
,
Liz
,
"
drawing
the
back
of
his
hand
across
them
,
"
I
mean
to
be
a
good
brother
to
you
,
and
to
prove
that
I
know
what
I
owe
you
.
<EOS>
All
I
say
is
,
that
I
hope
you
'll
control
your
fancies
a
little
,
on
my
account
.
<EOS>
I
'll
get
a
school
,
and
then
you
must
come
and
live
with
me
,
and
you
'll
have
to
control
your
fancies
then
,
<EOS>
so
why
not
now
?
<EOS>
Now
,
say
I
have
n't
vexed
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
,
Charley
,
you
have
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
say
I
have
n't
hurt
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
n't
,
Charley
.
"
<EOS>
But
this
answer
was
less
ready
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
you
are
sure
I
did
n't
mean
to
.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
There
's
Mr.
Headstone
stopping
,
and
looking
over
the
wall
at
the
tide
,
to
hint
that
it
's
time
to
go
.
<EOS>
Kiss
me
,
and
tell
me
that
you
know
I
did

mean
to
hurt
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
told
him
so
,
and
they
embraced
,
and
walked
on
and
came
up
with
the
schoolmaster
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
we
go
your
sister
's
way
,
"
he

,
when
the
boy
told

he

.
<EOS>
And
with
his
cumbrous
and
uneasy

he
stiffly
offered
her
his
arm
.
<EOS>
Her
hand
was
just
within

,
when
she
drew

back
.
<EOS>
He
looked
round
with
a

,
as

he
thought
she
had
detected
something
that
repelled

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will

,
"
said
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
"
And
you
have
a
distance
before
you
,
and
will
walk
faster
without
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Being
by
this
time
close
to
Vauxhall
Bridge
,
they
resolved
,
in

,
to
take
that

over
the
Thames
,
and
they
left
her
:
<EOS>
Bradley
Headstone
giving
her
his
hand
at
parting
,
and
she
thanking
him
for
his
care
of
her
brother
.
  
<EOS>
The
master
and
the
pupil
walked
on
,
rapidly
and
silently
.
<EOS>
They
had
nearly
crossed
the
bridge
,
when
a
gentleman
came
coolly

,
with
a

in

,
his

,
and

behind

.
<EOS>
Something

the

of
this
person
,
and
in

air
with

,
holding
possession
of
twice
as
much

as
another
would
have
claimed
,
instantly
caught
the
boy
's
attention
.
<EOS>
As
the
gentleman
passed
,
the
boy
looked
at
him
narrowly
,
and
then
stood
still
,
looking
after
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
it
that
you
stare
after
?
"
asked
Bradley
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
!
<EOS>
"
said
the
boy
,
with
a
confused
and
pondering

upon

face
,
"
It
is
that
Wrayburn
one
!
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
Headstone
scrutinized
the
boy
as
closely
as
the
boy
had
scrutinized
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your

,
Mr.
Headstone
,
but
I
could

what

brought

here
!
"
  
<EOS>
Though

---
at

---

,
and
that
the
same
perplexed

was
heavy

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do

appear

like

,
Hexam
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
   
<EOS>
DON'T
like
him
,
"
said
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
Why
not
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
took

me

chin
in
a
precious

way
,
the
first

I

saw

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Again
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
nothing
.
<EOS>
Or
---

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Does
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
had
so

that

at
Mr.
Bradley
Headstone
as

on
side

,
without

;

,
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Going

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
It
ca
n't

!
"
said

boy
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
does
n't
know
her
well

.
<EOS>
I
should

catch
him
at

!
"
  
<EOS>
When
they
had

on
for
a
time
,
more

than
before
,
the
master
said
,
clasping
the
pupil
's
arm
between

elbow
and
the
shoulder
with

:
  
<EOS>
"
You
were

tell

something
about
that
person
.
<EOS>
What

say

name
was
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
He
is
what
they
call
a
barrister
,
with
nothing
to
do
.
<EOS>
The
first
time
he
came
to
our
old
place
was
when
my
father
was
alive
.
<EOS>
He
came
on
business
;
not
that
it
was
his
business
---
he
never
had
any
business
---
he
was
brought
by
a
friend
of
his
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
the
other
times
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
only
one
other
time
that
I
know
of
.
<EOS>
When
my
father
was
killed
by
accident
,
he
chanced
to
be
one
of
the
finders
.
<EOS>
He
was
mooning
about
,
I
suppose
,
taking
liberties
with
people
's
chins
;
but
there
he
was
,
somehow
.
<EOS>
He
brought
the
news
home
to
my
sister
early
in
the
morning
,
and
brought
Miss
Abbey
Potterson
,
a

,
to

it
to

.
<EOS>
He

mooning

the
house
when
I
was

home
in

---
they
did
n't

where
to
find
me
till
my
sister
could

brought

to

---
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
is

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
Headstone
gradually

boy
's

,
as

.
<EOS>
After

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
---
<EOS>
your
sister
---
"
with

,
"
has
received

,
Hexam
?
"
  
"
Hardly

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Sacrificed
,

,
to

's

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Yet
---
your
sister
---
scarcely

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lizzie
has
as

,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
Too

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

the
fire

,
her
books
,

---
sometimes

,
considering
---
when

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
It

:
  
"

,

;

---
I
wo

,

---
<EOS>
but
---
  
rather
put
to
the
blush

---
by
a
sister
who
has

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Bradley
Headstone
in

,
for
his

scarcely

,
so
smoothly

another
,
"
and
<EOS>
there

.
<EOS>
Some

---

---

---
 
<EOS>
and

,

,
overcoming
in

other

"
  
<EOS>
"
That

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Now

;

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

.
<EOS>
Sometimes

.
<EOS>
And

Miss
Peecher
---
"
  
"
For

,

Not

,
"
Bradley

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Their

was
almost

afterwards
,
until

-
house
.
<EOS>
There
,
one
of
neat
Miss
Peecher
's
little
windows
,
like
the
eyes
in
needles
,
was
illuminated
,
and
in

Mary
Anne
watching
,
while
Miss
Peecher
at
the
table
stitched
at
the
neat
little
body
she
was
making
up
by
brown
paper
pattern
for
her
own

.
<EOS>
N.B.
Miss
Peecher
and
Miss
Peecher
's
pupils
were
not
much

in
the
unscholastic
art
of
needlework
,
by
Government
.
  
<EOS>
Mary
Anne
with
her
face
to
the
window
,
held
her
arm
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mary
Anne
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Headstone
coming
home
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
In

a

,
Mary
Anne
again
hailed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mary
Anne
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Gone
in
and
locked

door
,
ma'am
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Peecher
repressed
a
sigh
as
she
gathered
her
work
together
for
bed
,
and
transfixed
that
part
of
her
dress
where
her
heart
would
have
been
if
she
had
had
the
dress
on
,
with
a
sharp
,
sharp
needle
.
   
<EOS>
STILL
EDUCATIONAL
.
 
<EOS>
The
person
of
the
house
,
doll
's
dressmaker
and
manufacturer
of
ornamental
pincushions
and
pen
-
wipers
,
sat
in
her
quaint
little
low
arm
-
chair
,
singing
in
the
dark
,
until
Lizzie
came
back
.
<EOS>
The
person
of
the
house
had
attained
that
dignity
while
yet
of
very
tender
years
indeed
,
through
being
the
only
trustworthy
person
in
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
Lizzie
-
Mizzie
-
Wizzie
,
"
said
she
,
breaking
off
in
her
song
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
news
out
of
doors
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
news
in
doors
?
<EOS>
"
returned
Lizzie
,
playfully
smoothing
the
bright
long
fair
hair
which
grew
very
luxuriant
and
beautiful
on
the
head
of
the
doll
's
dressmaker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
see
,
said
the
blind
man
.
<EOS>
Why
the
last
news
is
,
that
I
do

brother
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
-
o
,
"
shaking

.
<EOS>
"
Do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

I

's

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
finished

the

back

the
misshapen

,

.
<EOS>
It
showed

to

,

.
<EOS>
She

,
remote

the

open
,
and
the
house
door
open
,

.
<EOS>
It

,

this

a
fine
-

when
the
day
's

.
<EOS>
To

,

,

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
This

what
your

Jenny
Wren

,
"

.
<EOS>
Her

;

<EOS>
"

"

to
-

,
what

,

I
should

able

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"

?
<EOS>
The

"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
---

know
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
doubted
that
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
"
said

;
the
more

,
the
less

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very

.
<EOS>
Though

.
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
---
I

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Then

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

,

"
for

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Lizzie
Hexam
,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
For

---
you

,
Jenny
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Agreed
!
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

,

"

"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

---
<EOS>
so
---

.
<EOS>

May

,

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"
Pleasant

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
And

!
<EOS>
Oh
!
"

,

,
"
how
they
sing
!
"
  
<EOS>
There

,
quite

.
<EOS>
Then

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
dare
say
my
birds
sing
better
than

,

other

.
<EOS>
For

,
"

,
"

early
in

.
<EOS>
They

;

,

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
They

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
Such

<EOS>
All

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

`

!
<EOS>
Who

!
"
<EOS>
"

`

!
"
<EOS>
"

`

!
<EOS>
I
ca

!
"
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Then

`

<EOS>

,

!
<EOS>
who

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
"

,

,

.

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

;

?
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
But

,
with

,

,
"
Her

,
"
 
he

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
Who

what

is

,

!
  
<EOS>
A

,
who

.
<EOS>
Looking

this

,

.
  
<EOS>
On

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Do

from

.
<EOS>
Give

.
<EOS>
It
ai

---
ai

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
's

Jenny
Wren
,
best

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
To

,

in

,

:
"
Go

!
<EOS>
Go

!
<EOS>
Get

!
"
  
<EOS>
The
wretched
spectacle
made
as
if

would
have
offered
some

;
but
not

the
person
of
the
house
,
thought

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
-
h
-
h
!
"
cried

person

the
house
,

her

,
"
You
bad

!
<EOS>
Oh
-
h
-
h
you
naughty
,

!
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The

figure
,
unnerved
and

from

to

,
put

its
two
hands
a
little
way
,
as
making

of

and

.
<EOS>
Abject

stood
in

,
and
stained
the

of

.
<EOS>
The
swollen
lead
-
coloured
under
lip
trembled
with
a

.
<EOS>
The
whole
indecorous
thread
bare
ruin
,
from
the
broken
shoes
to
the
prematurely
-
grey
scanty

,
grovelled
.
<EOS>
Not
with
any
sense
worthy
to
be
called

sense
,
of
this
dire
reversal
of
the
places
of
parent
and
child
,
but
in
a
pitiful

to
be
let
off
from
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
your
tricks
and
your
manners
,
"
cried
Miss
Wren
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
where
you
've
been
to
!
"
<EOS>
(
which
indeed
it
did
not
require
discernment
to
discover
)
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
disgraceful
old
chap
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
very
breathing
of
the
figure
was
contemptible
,
as
it
laboured
and
rattled
in
that
operation
,
like
a
blundering
clock
.
  
<EOS>
"
Slave
,
slave
,
slave
,
from
morning
to
night
,
"
pursued
the
person
of
the
house
,
"
and
all
for
this
!
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
that
<EOS>
emphasized
"
<EOS>
What
,
"
which
absurdly
frightened
the
figure
.
<EOS>
As

the
person
of
the
house
worked
her

round
to

---
even
as

saw
that

was
coming
 
---
he
collapsed
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
had

up
,
and

,
"
said

person

the
house
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
had
been
poked
into

and

,
and

.
<EOS>
I

their

and
their
manners
,
and

'd

.
<EOS>
Ai
n't
you
ashamed
of
yourself
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
,
"
stammered
the
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
the
person
of
the
house
,
terrifying

by
a
grand

of
her

and
forces
before
recurring
to
the
emphatic
word
,
"
What
do
you
mean
by
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Circumstances
over
which
had
no
control
,
"
was
the
miserable
creature
's
plea
in
extenuation
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
circumstance
you
and
control
you
too
,
"
retorted
the
person
of
the
house
,
speaking
with
vehement

,
"
if
you
talk
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
I
'll
give
you
in

,
and
have

fined
five
shillings
when
you
ca
n't
pay
,
and
then
I
wo
n't
pay
the

,

you
'll

.
<EOS>
How

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Should
n't

.
<EOS>
Poor
shattered
invalid
.
<EOS>
Trouble
nobody
long
,
"
cried
the
wretched
figure
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
!
"
said
the
person

the
house
,

near
her
in
a

,
and
shaking

and
her

;
 
<EOS>
"
you
know
what
you
've

to
do
.
<EOS>
Put

this

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

figure
began
to
rummage
in
its

.
  
<EOS>
"
Spent
a
fortune
out
of
your

,
I
'll

bound
!
"
said
the
person
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Put
it
here
!
<EOS>
All
you
've
got
left
!
<EOS>
Every
farthing
!
"
  
<EOS>
Such
a
business
as
he
made
of
collecting
it
from
his
dogs'-eared
pockets
;
of
expecting
it
in
this
pocket
,
and
not

;
of
not

in
that

,
and
passing

over
;
of
finding
no
pocket
where
that
other
pocket
ought
to

!
  
<EOS>
"
Is
this
all
?
"
<EOS>
demanded
the
person
of
the
house
,
when
a
confused

of
pence
and

lay
on

.
  
<EOS>
"
Got
no
more
,
"
was
the
rueful
answer
,
with
an
accordant

the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
make
sure
.
<EOS>
You
know
what
you
've
got
to
do
.
<EOS>
Turn
all
your
pockets
inside
out
,
and
leave
'em
so
!
<EOS>
"
cried
the
person
of
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
He
obeyed
.
<EOS>
And
if
anything
could
have
made
him
look
more
abject
or
more
dismally

than
before
,
it
would
have

his
so

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
's
but
seven
and
eightpence
halfpenny
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Miss
Wren
,
after
reducing

heap
to
order
.
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
prodigal
old
son
!
<EOS>
Now

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
do

,
"
he

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you

,
"

,
"
you
'd

fed
upon

skewers
of
cats
'

;
---
only
the

,
after
the
cats
had

.
<EOS>
As

,
go
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When

out

,
he
again

,
and

:
"
Circumstances
over

no
control
---
"
  
"
Get
along

you
to
bed
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Miss
Wren
,

up
.
<EOS>
"
Do

.
<EOS>
I
'm
not

.
<EOS>
Go

!
"
  
<EOS>
Seeing
another
emphatic
<EOS>
"
What
"
upon

,
he
evaded
it
by

,
and
was
heard
to
shuffle
heavily
up
stairs
,
and
shut
his

,
and
throw

on

bed
.
<EOS>
Within
a
little
while
afterwards
,
Lizzie
came
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
we
have
our
supper
,
Jenny
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
bless
us
and

,
we
need
have
something
to
keep
us
going
,
"
returned
Miss
Jenny
,
shrugging

.
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
laid
a
cloth
upon
the
little
bench
(
more
handy
for
the
person
of
the
house
than
an
ordinary

)
,
and
put
upon
it
such
plain
fare
as
they
were
accustomed

,
and
drew

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
for
supper
!
<EOS>
What

you
thinking

,
Jenny
darling
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was

,
"
she

,

,
"
what
I

do
to
Him
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

he
wo

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
You
'll
take

of
that
,
beforehand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
try
to
take

it
beforehand
,
but
he
might
deceive

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
dear
,
all
those
fellows
with
their
tricks
and
their
manners
do
deceive
!
"
<EOS>
With
the
little
fist
in
full

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
if
so
,
I
tell
you
what
I
think
I
'd
do
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
asleep
,
I
'd
make
a
spoon
red

,
and
I
'd
have
some
boiling
liquor
bubbling
in
a
saucepan
,
and
I
'd
take
it
out
hissing
,
and
I
'd
open
his
mouth
with
the
other
hand
---
or
perhaps
he
'd
sleep
with
his

ready

---
<EOS>
and
I
'd
pour

down

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Should
n't
I
?
<EOS>
Well
;
perhaps
I
should

.
<EOS>
But
I
should
like

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
equally
sure
you
would
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
even
like
to
?
<EOS>
Well
,
you
generally
know
best
.
<EOS>
Only
you
have
n't
always
lived
among
it
as
I
have
lived
---
and
your
back
is
n't
bad
and
your
legs
are
not
queer
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
they
went
on
with
their
supper
,
Lizzie
tried
to
bring
her
round
to
that
prettier
and
better
state
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
charm
was
broken
.
<EOS>
The
person
of
the
house
was
the
person
of
a
house
full
of
sordid
shames
and
cares
,
with
an
upper
room
in
which
that
abased
figure
was
infecting
even
innocent
sleep
with
sensual
brutality
and
degradation
.
<EOS>
The
doll
's
dressmaker
had
become
a
little
quaint
shrew
;
of
the
world
,
worldly
;
of
the
earth
,
earthy
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
doll
's
dressmaker
!
<EOS>
How
often
so
dragged
down
by
hands
that
should
have
raised
her
up
;
how
often
so
misdirected
when
losing
her
way
on
the
eternal
road
,
and
asking
guidance
!
<EOS>
Poor
,
poor
little
doll
's
dressmaker
!
   
<EOS>
A
PIECE
OF
WORK
.
 
<EOS>
Britannia
,
sitting
meditating
one
fine
day
(
perhaps
in
the
attitude
in
which
she
is
presented
on
the
copper
coinage
)
,
discovers
all
of
a
sudden
that
she
wants
Veneering
in
Parliament
.
<EOS>
It
occurs
to
her
that
Veneering
is
"
a
representative
man
"
---
which
can
not
in
these
times
be
doubted
---
and
that
Her
Majesty
's
faithful
Commons
are
incomplete
without
him
.
<EOS>
So
,
Britannia
mentions
to
a
legal
gentleman
of
her
acquaintance
that
if
Veneering
will
"
put
down
"
five
thousand
pounds
,
he
may
write
a
couple
of
initial
letters
after
his
name
at
the
extremely
cheap
rate
of
two
thousand
five
hundred
per
letter
.
<EOS>
It
is
clearly
understood
between
Britannia
and
the
legal
gentleman
that
nobody
is
to
take
up
the
five
thousand
pounds
,
but
that
being
put
down
they
will
disappear
by
magical
conjuration
and
enchantment
.
  
<EOS>
The
legal
gentleman
in
Britannia
's
confidence
going
straight
from
that
lady
to
Veneering
,
thus
commissioned
,
Veneering
declares
himself
highly
flattered
,
but
requires
breathing
time
to
ascertain
"
whether
his
friends
will
rally
round
him
.
<EOS>
"
Above
all
things
,
he
says
,
it
behoves
him
to
be
clear
,
at
a
crisis
of
this
importance
,
"
whether
his
friends
will
rally
round
him
.
"
<EOS>
The
legal
gentleman
,
in
the
interests
of
his
client
can
not
allow
much
time
for
this
purpose
,
as
the
lady
rather
thinks
she
knows
somebody
prepared
to
put
down
six
thousand
pounds
;
but
he
says
he
will
give
Veneering
four
hours
.
  
<EOS>
Veneering
then
says
to
Mrs.
Veneering
,
"
We
must
work
,
"
and
throws
himself
into
a
Hansom
cab
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
in
the
same
moment
relinquishes
baby
to
Nurse
;
presses
her
aquiline
hands
upon
her
brow
,
to
arrange
the
throbbing
intellect
within
;
orders
out
the
carriage
;
and
repeats
in
a
distracted
and
devoted
manner
,
compounded
of
Ophelia
and
any
self
-
immolating
female
of
antiquity
you
may
prefer
,
"
We
must
work
.
"
  
<EOS>
Veneering
having
instructed
his
driver
to
charge
at
the
Public
in
the
streets
,
like
the
Life
-
Guards
at
Waterloo
,
is
driven
furiously
to
Duke
Streets
,
Saint
James
's
.
<EOS>
There
,
he
finds
Twemlow
in
his
lodgings
,
fresh
from
the
hands
of
a
secret
artist
who
has
been
doing
something
to
his
hair
with
yolks
of
eggs
.
<EOS>
The
process
requiring
that
Twemlow
<EOS>
shall
,
for
two
hours
after
the
application
,
allow
his
hair
to
stick
upright
and
dry
gradually
,
he
is
in
an
appropriate
state
for
the
receipt
of
startling
intelligence
;
looking
equally
like
the
Monument
on
Fish
Street
Hill
,
and
King
Priam
on
a
certain
incendiary
occasion
not
wholly
unknown
as
a
neat
point
from
the
classics
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Twemlow
,
"
says
Veneering
,
grasping
both
his
hands
,
"
as
the
dearest
and
oldest
of
my
friends
---
"
  
(
"
Then
there
can
be
no
more
doubt
about
it
in
future
,
"
thinks
Twemlow
,
"
and
I
am
!
"
<EOS>
)
  
<EOS>
"
---
Are
you
of
opinion
that
your
cousin
,
Lord
Snigsworth
,
would
give
his
name
as
a

of
my
Committee
?
<EOS>
I
do
n't
go
so
far
as
to
ask

lordship
;
I
only
ask
for

name
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
he
would
give
me
his
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
sudden
low
spirits
,
Twemlow
replies
,
"
I
do
n't
think
he
would
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
political

,
"
says
Veneering
,
not
previously

of
having
any
,
"
are
identical
with
those
of
Lord
Snigsworth
,
and
perhaps
as
a
matter
of
public

and
public

,
Lord
Snigsworth
would
give
me
his
name
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
might
be
so
,
"
says
Twemlow
;
"
<EOS>
but
---
"
And
perplexedly
scratching
his
head
,
forgetful
of
the
yolks
of
eggs
,
is
the
more
discomfited
by
being
reminded
how
stickey
he
is
.
  
<EOS>
"
Between
such
old
and
intimate
friends
as
ourselves
,
"
pursues
Veneering
,
"
there
should
in
such
a
case
be
no
reserve
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
that
if
I
ask
you
to
do
anything
for
me
which
you
do
n't
like
to
do
,
or
feel
the
slightest
difficulty
in
doing
,
you
will
freely
tell
me
so
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
,
Twemlow
is
so
kind
as
to
promise
,
with
every
appearance
of
most
heartily
intending
to
keep
his
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
have
any
objection
to
write
down
to
Snigsworthy
Park
,
and
ask
this
favor
of
Lord
Snigsworth
?
<EOS>
Of
course
if
it
were
granted
I
should
know
that
I
owed
it
solely
to
you
;
while
at
the
same
time
you
would
put
it
to
Lord
Snigsworth
entirely
upon
public
grounds
.
<EOS>
Would
you
have
any
objection
?
"
  
<EOS>
Says
Twemlow
,
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
,
"
You
have
exacted
a
promise
from
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
my
dear
Twemlow
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
you
expect
me
to
keep
it
honorably
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
my
dear
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
the
whole
,
then
;
---
observe
me
,
"
urges
Twemlow
with
great
nicety
,
as
if
,
in
the
case
of
its
having
been
off
the
whole
,
he
would
have
done
it
directly
---
"
on
the
whole
,
I
must
beg
you
to
excuse
me
from
addressing
any
communication
to
Lord
Snigsworth
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Bless
you
,
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
says
Veneering
;
horribly
disappointed
,
but
grasping
him
by
both
hands
again
,
in
a
particularly
fervent
manner
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
not
to
be
wondered
at
that
poor
Twemlow
should
decline
to
inflict
a
letter
on
his
noble
cousin
(
who
has
gout
in
the
temper
)
,
inasmuch
as
his
noble
cousin
,
who
allows
him
a
small
annuity
on
which
he
lives
,
takes
it
out
of
him
,
as
the
phrase
goes
,
in
extreme
severity
;
 
putting
him
,
when
he
visits
at
Snigsworthy
Park
,
under
a
kind
of
martial
law
;
ordaining
that
he
shall
hang
his
hat
on
a
particular
peg
,
sit
on
a
particular
chair
,
talk
on
particular
subjects
to
particular
people
,
and
perform
particular
exercises
:
such
as
sounding
the
praises
of
the
Family
Varnish
(
not
to
say
Pictures
)
,
and
abstaining
from
the
choicest
of
the
Family
Wines
unless
expressly

.
  
<EOS>

"

,

"

"
  
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

Mrs.

.
"

That

<EOS>
As

,

.
  
<EOS>
Lady

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

---
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
And

;

<EOS>
My

<EOS>

:

.
  
<EOS>
Now
,

,
that

working

is
to

,

,

.
<EOS>
More
is

,

---

---

,

"
going

,
"
than

fair
Tippins

.
<EOS>
Many
vast

have

,

by
taking

and

about
.
<EOS>
This
particularly
obtains
in
all
Parliamentary

.
<EOS>
Whether
the
business
in
hand
be
to

man

,

,
or

,

,
or

,
or
what
else
,
nothing
is
understood
to
be
so
effectual
as
scouring
nowhere
in
a
violent
hurry
---
in
short
,
as
taking
cabs
and
going
about
.
  
<EOS>
Probably
because
this
reason
is
in
the
air
,
Twemlow
,
far
from
being
singular
in
his
persuasion
that
he
works
like
a
Trojan
,
is
capped
by
Podsnap
,
who
in
his

is
capped
by
Boots
and

.
<EOS>
At
eight
o'clock
,
when
all
these
hard
workers
assemble
to

at
Veneering
's
,
it
is

that
the
cabs
of
Boots
and
Brewer
must

leave

door
,
but
that
pails
of
water
must
be
brought
from
the
nearest
baiting
-
place
,
and
cast
over

,
lest

away
.

Mrs.

.

<EOS>

,

.

,

Wind
"

"

.

.
<EOS>

!
"
   
<EOS>
CUPID
PROMPTED
.
 
<EOS>
To
use
the
cold
language
of
the
world
,
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
rapidly
improved
the
acquaintance
of
Miss
Podsnap
.
<EOS>
To
use
the
warm
language
of
Mrs.
Lammle
,
she
and
her
sweet
Georgiana
soon
became
one
:
in
heart
,
in
mind
,
in
sentiment
,
in
soul
.
  
<EOS>
Whenever
Georgiana
could
escape
from
the
thraldom
of
Podsnappery
;
 
could
throw
off
the

of
the
custard
-
coloured
phaton
,
and
get
up
;
could

out

the

of
her
mother
's

,
and
(
so
to
speak
)
rescue

poor
little
frosty
toes
from
being

over
;
 
she
repaired
to
her
friend
,
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Podsnap
by
no
means
objected
.
<EOS>
As
a
consciously
"
splendid

,
"
accustomed

so

by
elderly
osteologists
pursuing
their

in
dinner

,
Mrs.
Podsnap
could
dispense
with
her
daughter
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
,
for
his
part
,
on
being
informed
where

was
,
swelled
with
patronage
of
the
Lammles
.
<EOS>
That
they
,
when
unable
to
lay

of

,

at
the
hem
of
his

;
that
they
,
when

could
not
bask
in
the

of
him
the
sun
,
should
take

of
the
watery

his
daughter
;
appeared
quite
natural
,

,
and

.
<EOS>
It

as

.
<EOS>
So
,
Georgiana
repairing
to

,

,

,

See

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

Mr.

"
Oh
my
goodness
what
a
Fool
he
must
be
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
---
And
implores
to
be
asked
to
dinner
,
and
to
make
a
fourth
at
the
play
another
time
.
<EOS>
And
so
he
dines
to
-
morrow
and
goes
to
the
Opera
with
us
.
<EOS>
That
's
all
.
<EOS>
Except
,
my
dear
Georgiana
---
and
what
will
you
think
of
this
!
---
that
he
is
infinitely
shyer
than
you
,
and
far
more
afraid
of
you
than
you
ever
were
of
any
one
in
all
your
days
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
perturbation
of
mind
Miss
Podsnap
still
fumed
and
plucked
at
her
hands
a
little
,
but
could
not
help
laughing
at
the
notion
of
anybody
's
being
afraid
of
her
.
<EOS>
With
that
advantage
,
Sophronia
flattered
her
and
rallied
her
more
successfully
,
and
then
the
insinuating
Alfred
flattered
her
and
rallied
her
,
and
promised
that
at
any
moment
when
she
might
require
that
service
at
his
hands
,
he
would
take
young
Fledgeby
out
and
trample
on
him
.
<EOS>
Thus
it
remained
amicably
understood
that
young
Fledgeby
was
to
come
to
admire
,
and
that
Georgiana
was
to
come
to
be
admired
;
and
Georgiana
with
the
entirely
new
sensation
in
her
breast
of
having
that
prospect
before
her
,
and
with
many
kisses
from
her
dear
Sophronia
in
present
possession
,
preceded
six
feet
one
of
discontented
footman
(
an
amount
of
the
article
that
always
came
for
her
when
she
walked
home
)
to
her
father
's
dwelling
.
  
<EOS>
The
happy
pair
being
left
together
,
Mrs.
Lammle
said
to
her
husband
:
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
understand
this
girl
,
sir
,
your
dangerous
fascinations
have
produced
some
effect
upon
her
.
<EOS>
I
mention
the
conquest
in
good
time
because
I
apprehend
your
scheme
to
be
more
important
to
you
than
your
vanity
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
mirror
on
the
wall
before
them
,
and
her
eyes
just
caught
him
smirking
in
it
.
<EOS>
She
gave
the
reflected
image
a
look
of
the
deepest
disdain
,
and
the
image
received
it
in
the
glass
.
<EOS>
Next
moment
they
quietly
eyed
each
other
,
as
if
they
,
the
principals
,
had
had
no
part
in
that
expressive
transaction
.
  
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
that
Mrs.
Lammle
tried
in
some
manner
to
excuse
her
conduct
to
herself
by
depreciating
the
poor
little
victim
of
whom
she
spoke
with
acrimonious
contempt
.
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
too
that
in
this
she
did
not
quite
succeed
,
for
it
is
very
difficult
to
resist
confidence
,
and
she
knew
she
had
Georgiana
's
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
more
was
said
between
the
happy
pair
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
conspirators
who
have
once
established
an
understanding
,
may
not
be
overfond
of
repeating
the
terms
and
objects
of
their
conspiracy
.
<EOS>
Next
day
came
;
came
Georgiana
;
and
came
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
Georgiana
had
by
this
time
seen
a
good
deal
of
the
house
and
its
frequenters
.
<EOS>
As
there
was
a
certain
handsome
room
with
a
billiard
table
in
it
---
on
the
ground
floor
,
eating
out
a
backyard
---
which
might
have
been
Mr.
Lammle
's
office
,
or
library
,
but
was
called
by
neither
name
,
but
simply
Mr.
Lammle
's
room
,
so
it
would
have
been
hard
for
stronger
female
heads
than
Georgiana
's
to
determine
whether
its
frequenters
were
men
of
pleasure
or
men
of
business
.
<EOS>
Between
the
room
and
the
men
there
were
strong
points
of
general
resemblance
.
<EOS>
Both
were
too
gaudy
,
too
slangey
,
too
odorous
of
cigars
,
and
too
much
given
to
horseflesh
;
the
latter
characteristic
being
exemplified
in
the
room
by
its
decorations
,
and
in
the
men
by
their
conversation
.
<EOS>
High
-
stepping
horses
seemed
necessary
to
all
Mr.
Lammle
's
friends
---
as
necessary
as
their
transaction
of
business
together
in
a
gipsy
way
at
untimely
hours
of
the
morning
and
evening
,
and
in
rushes
and
snatches
.
<EOS>
There
were
friends
who
seemed
to
be
always
coming
and
going
across
the
Channel
,
on
errands
about
the
Bourse
,
and
Greek
and
Spanish
and
India
and
Mexican
and
par
and
premium
and
discount
and
three
quarters
and
seven
eighths
.
<EOS>
There
were
other
friends
who
seemed
to
be
always
lolling
and
lounging
in
and
out
of
the
City
,
on
questions
of
the
Bourse
,
and
Greek
and
Spanish
and
India
and
Mexican
and
par
and
premium
and
discount
and
three
quarters
and
seven
eighths
.
<EOS>
They
were
all
feverish
,
boastful
,
and
indefinably
loose
;
and
they
all
ate
and
drank
a
great
deal
;
and
made
bets
in
eating
and
drinking
.
<EOS>
They
all
spoke
of
sums
of
money
,
and
only
mentioned
the
sums
and
left
the
money
to
be
understood
;
as
"
five
and
forty
thousand
Tom
,
"
or
"
Two
hundred
and
twenty
-
two
on
every
individual
share
in
the
lot
Joe
.
<EOS>
"
They
seemed
to
divide
the
world
into
two
classes
of
people
;
people
who
were
making
enormous
fortunes
,
and
people
who
were
being
enormously
ruined
.
<EOS>
They
were
always
in
a
hurry
,
and
yet
seemed
to
have
nothing
tangible
to
do
;
except
a
few
of
them
(
these
,
mostly
asthmatic
and
thick
-
lipped
)
who
were
for
ever
demonstrating
to
the
rest
,
with
gold
pencil
-
cases
which
they
could
hardly
hold
because
of
the
big
rings
on
their
forefingers
,
how
money
was
to
be
made
.
<EOS>
Lastly
,
they
all
swore
at
their
grooms
,
and
the
grooms
were
not
quite
as
respectful
or
complete
as
other
men
's
grooms
;
seeming
somehow
to
fall
short
of
the
groom
point
as
their
masters
fell
short
of
the
gentleman
point
.
  
<EOS>
Young
Fledgeby
was
none
of
these
.
<EOS>
Young
Fledgeby
had
a
peachy
cheek
,
or
a
cheek
compounded
of
the
peach
and
the
red
red
red
wall
on
which
it
grows
,
and
was
an
awkward
,
sandy
-
haired
,
small
-
eyed
youth
,
exceeding
slim
(
his
enemies
would
have
said
lanky
)
,
and
prone
to
self
-
examination
in
the
articles
of
whisker
and
moustache
.
<EOS>
While
feeling
for
the
whisker
that
he
anxiously
expected
,
Fledgeby
underwent
remarkable
fluctuations
of
spirits
,
ranging
along
the
whole
scale
from
confidence
to
despair
.
<EOS>
There
were
times
when
he
started
,
as
exclaiming
"
By
Jupiter
here
<EOS>
it
is
at
last
!
<EOS>
"
There
were
other
times
when
,
being
equally
depressed
,
he
would
be
seen
to
shake
his
head
,
and
give
up
hope
.
<EOS>
To
see
him
at
those
periods
leaning
on
a
chimneypiece
,
like
as
on
an
urn
containing
the
ashes
of
his
ambition
,
with
the
cheek
that
would
not
sprout
,
upon
the
hand
on
which
that
cheek
had
forced
conviction
,
was
a
distressing
sight
.
  
<EOS>
Not
so
was
Fledgeby
seen
on
this
occasion
.
<EOS>
Arrayed
in
superb
raiment
,
with
his
opera
hat
under
his
arm
,
he
concluded
his
self
-
examination
hopefully
,
awaited
the
arrival
of
Miss
Podsnap
,
and
talked
small
-
talk
with
Mrs.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
In
facetious
homage
to
the
smallness
of
his
talk
,
and
the
jerky
nature
of
his
manners
,
Fledgeby
's
familiars
had
agreed
to
confer
upon
him
(
behind
his
back
)
<EOS>
the
honorary
title
of
Fascination
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Warm
weather
,
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
said
Fascination
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
thought
it
scarcely
as
warm
as
it
had
been
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
,
"
said
Fascination
Fledgeby
,
with
great
quickness
of
repartee
;
"
but
I
expect
it
will
be
devilish
warm
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
threw
off
another
little
scintillation
.
"
<EOS>
Been
out
to
-
day
,
Mrs.
Lammle
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
answered
,
for
a
short
drive
.
  
<EOS>
"
Some
people
,
"
said
Fascination
Fledgeby
,
"
are
accustomed
to
take
long
drives
;
but
it
generally
appears
to
me
that
if
they
make
'em
too
long
,
they
overdo
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Being
in
such
feather
,
he
might
have
surpassed
himself
in
his
next
sally
,
had
not
Miss
Podsnap
been
announced
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
flew
to
embrace
her
darling
little
Georgy
,
and
when
the
first
transports
were
over
,
presented
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
came
on
the
scene
last
,
for
he
was
always
late
,
and
so
were
the
frequenters
always
late
;
all
hands
being
bound
to
be
made
late
,
by
private
information
about
the
Bourse
,
and
Greek
and
Spanish
and
India
and
Mexican
and
par
and
premium
and
discount
and
three
quarters
and
seven
eighths
.
  
<EOS>
A
handsome
little
dinner
was
served
immediately
,
and
Mr.
Lammle
sat
sparkling
at
his
end
of
the
table
,
with
his
servant
behind
his
chair
,
and
his
ever
-
lingering
doubts
upon
the
subject
of
his
wages
behind
himself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
's
utmost
powers
of
sparkling
were
in
requisition
to
-
day
,
for
Fascination
Fledgeby
and
Georgiana
not
only
struck
each
other
speechless
,
but
struck
each
other
into
astonishing
attitudes
;
Georgiana
,
as
she
sat
facing
Fledgeby
,
making
such
efforts
to
conceal
her
elbows
as
were
totally
incompatible
with
the
use
of
a
knife
and
fork
;
and
Fledgeby
,
as
he
sat
facing
Georgiana
,
avoiding
her
countenance
by
every
possible
device
,
and
betraying
the
discomposure
of
his
mind
in
feeling
for
his
whiskers
with
his
spoon
,
his
wine
glass
,
and
his
bread
.
  
<EOS>
So
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
had
to
prompt
,
and
this
is
how
they
prompted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Georgiana
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
low
and
smiling
,
and
sparkling
all
over
,
like
a
harlequin
;
"
you
are
not
in
your
usual
spirits
.
<EOS>
Why
are
you
not
in
your
usual
spirits
,
Georgiana
?
"
  
<EOS>
Georgiana
faltered
that
she
was
much
the
same
as
she
was
in
general
;
she
was
not
aware
of
being
different
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
aware
of
being
different
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
.
<EOS>
"
You
,
my
dear
Georgiana
!
<EOS>
who
are
always
so
natural
and
unconstrained
with
us
!
<EOS>
who
are
such
a
relief
from
the
crowd
that
are
all
alike
!
<EOS>
who
are
the
embodiment
of
gentleness
,
simplicity
,
and
reality
!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Podsnap
looked
at
the
door
,
as
if
she
entertained
confused
thoughts
of
taking
refuge
from
these
compliments
in
flight
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
will
be
judged
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
raising
his
voice
a
little
,
"
by
my
friend
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
   
DON'T
!
"
<EOS>
Miss
Podsnap
faintly
ejaculated
:
when
Mrs.
Lammle
took
the
prompt
-
book
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Alfred
,
my
dear
,
but
I
can
not
part
with
Mr.
Fledgeby
quite
yet
;
you
must
wait
for
him
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
and
I
are
engaged
in
a
personal
discussion
.
"
  
<EOS>
Fledgeby
must
have
conducted
it
on
his
side
with
immense
art
,
for
no
appearance
of
uttering
one
syllable
had
escaped
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
personal
discussion
,
Sophronia
,
my
love
?
<EOS>
What
discussion
?
<EOS>
Fledgeby
,
I
am
jealous
.
<EOS>
What
discussion
,
Fledgeby
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
tell
him
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
Trying
too
look
as
if
he
knew
anything
about
it
,
Fascination
replied
,
"
Yes
,
tell
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
were
discussing
then
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
if
you
must
know
,
Alfred
,
whether
Mr.
Fledgeby
was
in
his
usual
flow
of
spirits
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
that
is
the
very
point
,
Sophronia
,
that
Georgiana
and
I
were
discussing
as
to
herself
!
<EOS>
What
did
Fledgeby
say
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
a
likely
thing
,
sir
,
that
I
am
going
to
tell
you
everything
,
and
be
told
nothing
!
<EOS>
What
did
Georgiana
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Georgiana
said
she
was
doing
her
usual
justice
to
herself
to
-
day
,
and
I
said
she
was
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Precisely
,
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
what
I
said
to
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
"
  
<EOS>
Still
,
it
would
n't
do
.
<EOS>
They
would
not
look
at
one
another
.
<EOS>
No
,
not
even
when
the
sparkling
host
proposed
that
the
quartette
should
take
an
appropriately
sparkling
glass
of
wine
.
<EOS>
Georgiana
looked
from
her
wine
glass
at
Mr.
Lammle
and
at
Mrs.
Lammle
;
but
might
n't
,
could
n't
,
should
n't
,
would
n't
,
look
at
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
Fascination
looked
from
his
wine
glass
at
Mrs.
Lammle
and
at
Mr.
Lammle
;
but
might
n't
,
could
n't
,
should
n't
,
would
n't
,
look
at
Georgiana
.
  
<EOS>
More
prompting
was
necessary
.
<EOS>
Cupid
must
be
brought
up
to
the
mark
.
<EOS>
The
manager
had
put
him
down
in
the
bill
for
the
part
,
and
he
must
play
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
"
I
do
n't
like
the
colour
of
your
dress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
appeal
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
to
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
I
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
"
to
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Georgy
,
my
love
,
"
remarked
Mrs.
Lammle
aside
to
her
dear
girl
,
"
I
rely
upon
you
not
to
go
over
to
the
opposition
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
"
  
<EOS>
Fascination
wished
to
know
if
the
colour
were
not
called
rose
-
colour
?
<EOS>
Yes
,
said
Mr.
Lammle
;
actually
he
knew
everything
;
it
was
really
rose
-
colour
.
<EOS>
Fascination
took
rose
-
colour
to
mean
the
colour
of
roses
.
<EOS>
(
In
this
he
was
very
warmly
supported
by
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
.
)
<EOS>
Fascination
had
heard
the
term
Queen
of
Flowers
applied
to
the
Rose
.
<EOS>
Similarly
,
it
might
be
said
that
the
dress
was
the
Queen
of
Dresses
.
<EOS>
(
"
Very
happy
,
Fledgeby
!
"
from
Mr.
Lammle
.
)
<EOS>
Notwithstanding
,
Fascination
's
opinion
was
that
we
all
had
our
eyes
---
or
at
least
a
large
majority
of
us
---
and
that
---
and
---
and
his
further
opinion
was
several
ands
,
with
nothing
beyond
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
to
desert
me
in
that
way
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
to
abandon
my
poor
dear
injured
rose
and
declare
for
blue
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Victory
,
victory
!
"
cried
Mr.
Lammle
;
"
your
dress
is
condemned
,
my
dear
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
stealing
her

towards
her
dear
girl
's
,
"
what
does
Georgy
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
She
says
,
"
replied
Mr.
Lammle
,
interpreting
for
her
,
"
that
in
her
eyes
you
look
well
in
any
colour
,
Sophronia
,
and
that
if
she
had
expected
to
be
embarrassed
by
so
pretty
a
compliment
as
she
has
received
,
she
would
have
worn
another
colour
herself
.
<EOS>
Though
I
tell
her
,
in
reply
,
that
it
would
not
have
saved
her
,
for
whatever
colour
she
had
worn
would
have
been
Fledgeby
's
colour
.
<EOS>
But
what
does
Fledgeby
say
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
says
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Lammle
,
interpreting
for
him
,
and
patting
the

of
her
dear
girl
's

,
as
if
it
were
Fledgeby
who
was
patting
it
,
"
that
it
was
no
compliment
,
but
a
little
natural
act
of
homage
that
he
could
n't
resist
.
<EOS>
And
,
"
expressing
more
feeling
as
if
it
were
more
feeling
on
the
part
of
Fledgeby
,
"
he
is
right
,
he
is
right
!
"
  
<EOS>
Still
,
no
not
even
now
,
would
they
look
at
one
another
.
<EOS>
Seeming
to
gnash
his
sparkling
teeth
,
studs
,
eyes
,
and
buttons
,
all
at
once
,
Mr.
Lammle
secretly
bent
a
dark
frown
on
the
two
,
expressive
of
an
intense
desire
to
bring
them
together
by

together
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
heard
this
opera
of
to
-
night
,
Fledgeby
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
stopping
very

,
to

into
"
confound

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
no
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
fact
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Neither

know

,
Georgy
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
N
-
no
,
"
replied
Georgiana
,
faintly
,
under
the
sympathetic

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
then
,
"
said
Mrs.

,

which
flowed
from

,
"
you
neither
of
you
know
it
!
<EOS>
How
charming
!
"
  
<EOS>
Even
the
craven
Fledgeby
felt
that
the
time
was
now
come
when
he
must
strike
a

.
<EOS>
He
struck
it
by

,
partly

and

,
"
I

by
---
"
  
As

,

,

that

of
his

to
look

,

"
Destiny
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

was

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I
was

say
Fate
.
<EOS>
I
consider

very
fortunate
that
Fate
has
written
in
the

of
---
in
the
book
which
is
its
own

---
that
I
should
go
to
that
opera
for
the
first

under
the

of
going
with
Miss
Podsnap
.
"
  
<EOS>
To

replied
,

in

,

,
"
Thank

,
but
I
generally

with
no
one
<EOS>
but
you
,
Sophronia
,
and
I
like

.
"
  
<EOS>
Content
perforce
with
this
success
for

time
,
Mr.
Lammle
let
Miss
Podsnap
out
of

room
,
as
if

were

her

,
and
Mrs.
Lammle
followed
.
<EOS>
Coffee
being
presently
served
up
stairs
,
he
kept
a
watch
on
Fledgeby
until
Miss
Podsnap
's
cup
was
empty
,
and
then
directed
him
with
his
finger
(
as
if
that
young
gentleman
were
a
slow
Retriever
)
to
go
and
fetch

.
<EOS>
This
feat
he
performed
,
not
only
without
failure
,
but
even
with
the
original
embellishment
of
informing
Miss
Podsnap
that
green
tea
was
considered
bad
for
the
nerves
.
<EOS>
Though
there
Miss
Podsnap
unintentionally
threw
him
out
by
faltering
,
"
Oh
,
is
it
indeed
?
<EOS>
How
does
it
act
?
<EOS>
"
Which
he
was
not
prepared
to

.
  
<EOS>
The
carriage
announced
,
Mrs.
Lammle
said
,
"
Do
n't
mind
me
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
my
skirts
and

occupy
both

hands
,
take
Miss
Podsnap
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
took

,
and
Mrs.
Lammle
went
next
,
and
Mr.
Lammle
went
last
,
savagely
following
his
little
flock
,
like
a
drover
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
all
sparkle
and
glitter
in
the
box
at
the
Opera
,
and
there
he
and
his
dear
wife
made
a
conversation
between
Fledgeby
and
Georgiana
in
the
following
ingenious
and

.
<EOS>
They
sat
in
this
order
:
Mrs.
Lammle
,
Fascination
Fledgeby
,
Georgiana
,
Mr.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
made
leading
remarks
to
Fledgeby
,
only
requiring
monosyllabic
replies
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
did
the
like
with
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
At
times
Mrs.
Lammle
would
lean
forward
to
address
Mr.
Lammle
to
this
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
"
Alfred
,
my
dear
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
very
justly
says
,
apropos
of
the
last
scene
,
that
true
constancy
would
not
require
any
such
stimulant
as
the
stage
deems
necessary
.
"
<EOS>
To

Lammle
would

,
"
Ay
,
Sophronia
,
my
love
,
but
as
Georgiana
has
observed
to

,
the
lady
had
no

to
know

state
of
the

's

.
<EOS>
"
To

Lammle
would

,
"
Very

,
Alfred
;
but
Mr.
Fledgeby
points
out
,
"
this
.
<EOS>
To
which
Alfred
would

:
"
Undoubtedly
,
Sophronia
,
but
Georgiana
acutely
remarks
,
"
 
that
.
<EOS>
Through
this
device
the
two
young
people
conversed
at
great
length
and
committed
themselves
to
a
variety
of
delicate
sentiments
,
without
having
once
opened
their
lips
,
save
to
say
yes
or

,
and
even
that
not
to
one
another
.
  
<EOS>
Fledgeby
took
his
leave
of
Miss
Podsnap
at
the
carriage
door
,
and
the
Lammles
dropped
her
at
her
own
home
,
and
on
the

Mrs.
Lammle
archly

her
,
in
her
fond
and
protecting

,
by
saying
at

,
"
Oh
little
Georgiana
,
little
Georgiana
!
"
 
<EOS>
Which
was
not
much
;
but
the
tone
added
,
`
`
You
have
enslaved
your
Fledgeby
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
thus
the
Lammles
got
home
at
last
,
and
the
lady
sat
down
moody
and
weary
,
looking
at
her
dark
lord
engaged
in
a
deed
of
violence
with
a
bottle
of
soda
-
water
as
though
he
were
wringing
the
neck
of
some
unlucky
creature
and
pouring
its
blood
down
his
throat
.
<EOS>
As
he
wiped
his
dripping
whiskers
in
an
ogreish
way
,
he
met
her
eyes
,
and
pausing
,
said
,
with
no
very
gentle
voice
:
  
"
Well
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
such
an
absolute
Booby
necessary
to
the
purpose
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
I
am
doing
.
<EOS>
He
is
no
such
dolt
as
you
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
genius
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
sneer
,
perhaps
;
and
you
take
a
lofty
air
upon
yourself
,
perhaps
!
<EOS>
But
I
tell
you
this
:
---
<EOS>
when
that
young
fellow
's
interest
is
concerned
,
he
holds
as
tight
as
a
horse
-
leech
.
<EOS>
When
money
is
in
question
with
that
young
fellow
,
he
is
a
match
for
the
Devil
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
a
match
for
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
.
<EOS>
Almost
as
good
a
one
as
you
thought
me
for
you
.
<EOS>
He
has
no
quality
of
youth
in
him
,
but
such
as
you
have
seen
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Touch
him
upon
money
,
and
you
touch
no
booby
then
.
<EOS>
He
really
is
a
dolt
,
I
suppose
,
in
other
things
;
but
it
answers
his
one
purpose
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Has
she
money
in
her
own
right
in
any
case
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
<EOS>
she
has
money
in
her
own
right
in
any
case
.
<EOS>
You
have
done
so
well
to
-
day
,
Sophronia
,
that
I
answer
the
question
,
<EOS>
though
you
know
I
object
to
any
such
questions
.
<EOS>
You
have
done
so
well
to
-
day
,
Sophronia
,
that
you
must
be
tired
.
<EOS>
Get
to
bed
.
"
   
<EOS>
MERCURY
PROMPTING
 
<EOS>
Fledgeby
deserved
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
's
eulogium
.
<EOS>
He
was
the
meanest
cur
existing
,
with
a
single
pair
of
legs
.
<EOS>
And
instinct
(
a
word
we
all
clearly
understand
)
going
largely
on
four
legs
,
and
reason
always
on
two
,
meanness
on
four
legs
never
attains
the
perfection
of
meanness
on
two
.
  
<EOS>
The
father
of
this
young
gentleman
had
been
a
money
-
lender
,
who
had
transacted
professional
business
with
the
mother
of
this
young
gentleman
,
when
he
,
the
latter
,
was
waiting
in
the
vast
dark
ante
-
chambers
of
the
present
world
to
be
born
.
<EOS>
The
lady
,
a
widow
,
being
unable
to
pay
the
money
-
lender
,
married
him
;
and
in
due
course
,
Fledgeby
was
summoned
out
of
the
vast
dark
ante
-
chambers
to
come
and
be
presented
to
the
Registrar
-
General
.
<EOS>
Rather
a
curious
speculation
how
Fledgeby
would
otherwise
have
disposed
of
his
leisure
until
Doomsday
.
  
<EOS>
Fledgeby
's
mother
offended
her
family
by
marrying
Fledgeby
's
father
.
<EOS>
It
is
one
of
the
easiest
achievements
in
life
to
offend
your
family
when
your
family
want
to
get
rid
of
you
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
's
mother
's
family
had
been
very
much
offended
with
her
for
being
poor
,
and
broke
with
her
for
becoming
comparatively
rich
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
's
mother
's
family
was
the
Snigsworth
family
.
<EOS>
She
had
even
the
high
honour
to
be
cousin
to
Lord
Snigsworth
<EOS>
---
so
many
times
removed
that
the
noble
Earl
would
have
had
no
compunction
in
removing
her
one
time
more
and
dropping
her
clean
outside
the
cousinly
pale
;
but
cousin
for
all
that
.
  
<EOS>
Among
her
pre
-
matrimonial
transactions
with
Fledgeby
's
father
,
Fledgeby
's
mother
had
raised
money
of
him
at
a
great
disadvantage
on
a
certain
reversionary
interest
.
<EOS>
The
reversion
falling
in
soon
after
they
were
married
,
Fledgeby
's
father
laid
hold
of
the
cash
for
his
separate
use
and
benefit
.
<EOS>
This
led
to
subjective
differences
of
opinion
,
not
to
say
objective
interchanges
of
boot
-
jacks
,
backgammon
boards
,
and
other
such
domestic
missiles
,
between
Fledgeby
's
father
and
Fledgeby
's
mother
,
and
those
led
to
Fledgeby
's
mother
spending
as
much
money
as
she
could
,
and
to
Fledgeby
's
father
doing
all
he
could
n't
to
restrain
her
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
's
childhood
had
been
,
in
consequence
,
a
stormy
one
;
but
the
winds
and
the
waves
had
gone
down
in
the
grave
,
and
Fledgeby
flourished
alone
.
  
<EOS>
He
lived
in
chambers
in
the
Albany
,
did
Fledgeby
,
and
maintained
a
spruce
appearance
.
<EOS>
But
his
youthful
fire
was
all
composed
of
sparks
from
the
grindstone
;
and
as
the
sparks
flew
off
,
went
out
,
and
never
warmed
anything
,
be
sure
that
Fledgeby
had
his
tools
at
the
grindstone
,
and
turned
it
with
a
wary
eye
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
came
round
to
the
Albany
to
breakfast
with
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
Present
on
the
table
,
one
scanty
pot
of
tea
,
one
scanty
loaf
,
two
scanty
pats
of
butter
,
two
scanty
rashers
of
bacon
,
two
pitiful
eggs
,
and
an
abundance
of
handsome
china
bought
a
second
-
hand
bargain
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
think
of
Georgiana
?
"
asked
Mr.
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
'll
tell
you
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
very
deliberately
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
,
my
boy
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
misunderstand
me
,
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
I
'll
tell
you
that
.
<EOS>
I
mean
I
'll
tell
you
something
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
me
anything
,
old
fellow
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
,
but
there
you
misunderstand
me
again
,
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
I
mean
I
'll
tell
you
nothing
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
sparkled
at
him
,
but
frowned
at
him
too
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
deep
and
you
're
ready
.
<EOS>
Whether
I
am
deep
or
not
,
never
mind
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
ready
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
do
one
thing
,
Lammle
,
I
can
hold
my
tongue
.
<EOS>
And
I
intend
always
doing
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
long
-
headed
fellow
,
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
be
,
or
may
not
be
.
<EOS>
If
I
am
a
short
-
tongued
fellow
,
it
may
amount
to
the
same
thing
.
<EOS>
Now
,
Lammle
,
I
am
never
going
to
answer
questions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
,
it
was
the
simplest
question
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
mind
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
so
,
but
things
are
not
always
what
they
seem
.
<EOS>
I
saw
a
man
examined
as
a
witness
in
Westminster
Hall
.
<EOS>
Questions
put
to
him
seemed
the
simplest
in
the
world
,
but
turned
out
to
be
anything
rather
than
that
,
after
he
had
answered
'em
.
<EOS>
Very
well
.
<EOS>
Then
he
should
have
held
his
tongue
.
<EOS>
If
he
had
held
his
tongue
he
would
have
kept
out
of
scrapes
that
he
got
into
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
held
my
tongue
,
you
would
never
have
seen
the
subject
of
my
question
,
"
remarked
Lammle
,
darkening
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Lammle
,
"
said
Fascination
Fledgeby
,
calmly
feeling
for
his
whisker
,
"
it
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
be
led
on
into
a
discussion
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
manage
a
discussion
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
manage
to
hold
my
tongue
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
fell
back
upon
propitiation
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
you
could
!
<EOS>
Why
,
when
these
fellows
of
our
acquaintance
drink
and
you
drink
with
them
,
the
more
talkative
they
get
,
the
more
silent
you
get
.
<EOS>
The
more
they
let
out
,
the
more
you
keep
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
object
,
Lammle
,
"
returned
Fledgeby
,
with
an
internal
chuckle
,
"
to
being
understood
,
though
I
object
to
being
questioned
.
<EOS>
That
certainly
is
the
way
I
do
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
when
all
the
rest
of
us
are
discussing
our
ventures
,
none
of
us
ever
know
what
a
single
venture
of
yours
is
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
none
of
you
ever
will
from
me
,
Lammle
,
"
replied
Fledgeby
,
with
another
internal
chuckle
;
"
that
certainly
is
the
way
I
do
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
of
course
it
is
,
I
know
!
"
rejoined
Lammle
,
with
a
flourish
of
frankness
,
and
a

,
and
stretching
out
his
hands
as
if
to
show
the
universe
a
remarkable
man
in
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
n't
known
it
of
my
Fledgeby
,
should
I
have
proposed
our
little
compact
of
advantage
,
to
my
Fledgeby
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
remarked
Fascination
,
shaking
his
head
slyly
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
not
to
be
got
at
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
vain
.
<EOS>
That
sort
of
vanity
do
n't
pay
,
Lammle
.
<EOS>
No
,
no
,
no
.
<EOS>
Compliments
only
make
me
hold
my
tongue
the
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alfred
Lammle
pushed
his
plate
away
(
no
great
sacrifice
under
the
circumstances
of
there
being
so
little
in
it
)
,
thrust
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
leaned
back
in
his
chair
,
and
contemplated
Fledgeby
in
silence
.
<EOS>
Then
he
slowly
released
his
left
hand
from
its
pocket
,
and
made
that
bush
of
his
whiskers
,
still
contemplating
him
in
silence
.
<EOS>
Then
he
slowly
broke
silence
,
and
slowly
said
:
"
What
---
<EOS>
the
---
  
Dev
-
il
is
this
fellow
about
this
morning
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,
look
here
,
Lammle
,
"
said
Fascination
Fledgeby
,
with
the
meanest
of
twinkles
in
his
meanest
of
eyes
:
which
were
too
near
together
,
by
the
way
:
<EOS>
"
look
here
,
Lammle
;
I
am
very
well
aware
that
I
did
n't
show
to
advantage
last
night
,
and
that
you
and
your
wife
---
  
<EOS>
who
,
I
consider
,
is
a
very
clever
woman
and
an
agreeable
woman
---
  
did
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
calculated
to
show
to
advantage
under
that
sort
of
circumstances
.
<EOS>
I
know
very
well
you
two
did
show
to
advantage
,
and
managed
capitally
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
you
on
that
account
come
talking
to
me
as
if
I
was
your
doll
and
puppet
,
because
I
am
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
all
this
,
"
cried
Alfred
,
after
studying
with
a
look
the
meanness
that
was
fain
to
have
the
meanest
help
,
and
yet
was
<EOS>
so
mean
as
to
turn
upon
it
:
"
all
this
because
of
one
simple
natural
question
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
should
have
waited
till
I
thought
proper
to
say
something
about
it
of
myself
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
like
your
coming
over
me
with
your
Georgianas
,
as
if
you
was
her
proprietor
and
mine
too
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
when
you
are
in
the
gracious
mind
to
say
anything
about
it
of
yourself
,
"
retorted
Lammle
,
"
pray
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
done
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
said
you
managed
capitally
.
<EOS>
You
and
your
wife
both
.
<EOS>
If
you
'll
go
on
managing
capitally
,
I
'll
go
on
doing
my
part
.
<EOS>
Only
do
n't
crow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
crow
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Lammle
,
shrugging
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Or
,
"
pursued
the
other
---
"
or
take
it
in
your

that
people
are
your
puppets
because
they
do
n't
come
out
to
advantage
at

when
you
do
,
with

.
<EOS>
All

on

,

Mrs.
Lammle
keep

doing
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
have
held
my
tongue
when
I
thought
proper
,
and
I
have
spoken
when
I
thought
proper
,
and
there
's
an
end

.
<EOS>
And
now
the

is
,
"
proceeded
Fledgeby
,
with

,
"
will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
wo
n't
,
"
said
Lammle
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
're
right
and
will
find
yourself
better
without
it
,
"
 
replied
Fascination
,
in
greatly
improved

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To
ask
you
if
you
'll
have
another
rasher
would
be
unmeaning
flattery
,
for
it
would
make
you
thirsty
all
day
.
<EOS>
Will
you
have
some
more
bread
and

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
wo
n't
,
"
repeated
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
,
"
said
Fascination
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
not
a
mere
retort
for
the
sound
's
sake
,
but
was
a
cheerful
cogent
consequence
of
the
refusal
;
for
if
Lammle
had
applied
himself
again
to
the
loaf
,
it
would
have
been
so
heavily
visited
,
in
Fledgeby
's
opinion
,
as
to
demand
abstinence
from
bread
,
on
his
part
,
for
the
remainder
of
that
meal
at
least
,
if
not
for
the
whole
of
the
next
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
this
young
gentleman
(
for
he
was
but
three
-
and
-
twenty
)
combined
with
the
miserly
vice
of
an
old
man
,
any
of
the
open
-
handed
vices
of
a
young
one
,
was
a
moot
point
;
so
very
honorably
did
he
keep
his
own
counsel
.
<EOS>
He
was
sensible
of
the
value
of
appearances
as
an
investment
,
and
liked
to
dress
well
;
but
he
drove
a
bargain
for
every
moveable
about
him
,
from
the
coat
on
his
back
to
the
china
on
his
breakfast
-
table
;
and
every
bargain
by
representing
somebody
's
ruin
or
somebody
's
loss
,
acquired
a
peculiar
charm
for
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
part
of
his
avarice
to
take
,
within
narrow
bounds
,
long
odds
at
races
;
if
he
won
,
he
drove
harder
bargains
;
 
if
he
lost
,
he
half
starved
himself
until
next
time
.
<EOS>
Why
money
should
be
so
precious
to
an
Ass
too
dull
and
mean
to
exchange
it
for
any
other
satisfaction
,
is
strange
;
but
there
is
no
animal
so
sure
to
get
laden
with
it
,
as
the
Ass
who
sees
nothing
written
on
the
face
of
the
earth
and
sky
but
the
three
letters
L.
S.
D.
---
not
Luxury
,
Sensuality
,
Dissoluteness
,
which
they
often
stand
for
,
but
the
three
dry
letters
.
<EOS>
Your
concentrated
Fox
is
seldom
comparable
to
your
concentrated
Ass
in
money
-
breeding
.
  
<EOS>
Fascination
Fledgeby
feigned
to
be
a
young
gentleman
living
on
his
means
,
but
was
known
secretly
to
be
a
kind
of
outlaw
in
the
billbroking
line
,
and
to
put
money
out
at
high
interest
in
various
ways
.
<EOS>
His
circle
of
familiar
acquaintance
,
from
Mr.
Lammle
round
,
all
had
a
touch
of
the
outlaw
,
as
to
their
rovings
in
the
merry
greenwood
of
Jobbery
Forest
,
lying
on
the
outskirts
of
the
Share
-
Market
and
the
Stock
Exchange
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
,
Lammle
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
eating
his
bread
and
butter
,
"
always
did
go
in
for
female
society
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Always
,
"
replied
Lammle
,
glooming
considerably
under
his
late
treatment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Came
natural
to
you
,
eh
?
"
said
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
sex
were
pleased
to
like
me
,
sir
,
"
said
Lammle
sulkily
,
but
with
the
air
of
a
man
who
had
not
been
able
to
help
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Made
a
pretty
good
thing
of
marrying
,
did
n't
you
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
The
other
smiled
(
an
ugly
smile
)
,
and
tapped
one
tap
upon
his
nose
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
late
governor
made
a
mess
of
it
,
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
Geor
---
is
the
right
name
Georgina
or
Georgiana
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
thinking
yesterday
,
<EOS>
I
did
n't
know
there
was
such
a
name
.
<EOS>
I
thought

must
end
in
ina
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
play
---
<EOS>
if
you
can
---
the
Concertina
,
you
know
,
"
replied
Fledgeby
,
meditating
very

.
"
<EOS>
And
you
have
---
when
you
catch

---
the
Scarlatina
.
<EOS>
And

---
<EOS>
no
<EOS>
you
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
Well
,

Georgeute
---
<EOS>
I

Georgiana
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
going
to
remark
of
Georgiana
---
?
"
<EOS>
Lammle
moodily
hinted
,
after
waiting
in
vain
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
to
remark
of
Georgiana
,
sir
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
not
at
all

to

of

,
"
that
she
do

seem
to
be
violent
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
seem
to
be
of
the
pitching
-
in
order
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
has
the
gentleness
of
the
dove
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
you
'll
say
so
,
"
replied
Fledgeby
,
sharpening
,
the
moment
his
interest
was
touched
by
another
.
"
<EOS>
But
you
know
,
the
real
lookout
is
this
:
---
what
I
say
,
not
what
you
say
.
<EOS>
I
say
---
having
my
late
governor
and
my
late
mother
in
my
eye
---
that
Georgiana
do
n't
seem
to
be
of
the
pitching
-
in
order
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
respected
Mr.
Lammle
was
a
bully
,
by
nature
and
by
usual
practice
.
<EOS>
Perceiving
,
as
Fledgeby
's
affronts
cumulated
,
that
conciliation
by
no
means
answered
the
purpose
here
,
he
now
directed
a
scowling
look
into
Fledgeby
's
small
eyes
for
the
effect
of
the
opposite
treatment
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
by
what
he
saw
there
,
he
burst
into
a
violent
passion
and
struck
his
hand
upon
the
table
,
making
the
china
ring
and
dance
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
very
offensive
fellow
,
sir
,
"
cried
Mr.
Lammle
,
rising
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
highly
offensive
scoundrel
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
mean
by
this
behaviour
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
"
remonstrated
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
break
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
very
offensive
fellow
sir
,
"
repeated
Mr.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
highly
offensive
scoundrel
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
you
know
!
"
urged
Fledgeby
,
quailing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
coarse
and
vulgar
vagabond
!
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
looking
fiercely
about
him
,
"
if
your
servant
was
here
to
give
me
sixpence
of
your
money
to
get
my
boots
cleaned
afterwards
---
for

<EOS>
Little

Podsnap

Young

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

we

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

'

<EOS>
Some

,

,
to

.
<EOS>
Riah

,

,

,

<EOS>
Lizzie
Hexam

.
<EOS>
For

,

.
<EOS>
Seated

,

;

;

<EOS>
Another

,

.
<EOS>
A

;
and

of

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Taking

,

,

.
<EOS>

"

ca

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

Poof

"

"
Ah

.
<EOS>
"
But

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
"

<EOS>
"
Oh

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,

<EOS>
And

,

,

down

!
<EOS>
And

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Her

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why

,
"

,

,
"

!
<EOS>
He

so

,

,

,

down
in

<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Till

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Why

?
"

"
He

<EOS>
"
But

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
Get

!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
seemed
to
think

rather

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

"
Do

.
<EOS>
Come

,

!
"
<EOS>
And

,
more

,
half

"
Come
back

dead
,
Come

be
dead
!
"
  
<EOS>
When

,
Fledgeby
,

the

,

,

:
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

one

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And

,
"
answered
Riah
.
  
<EOS>
"
At
all
events
,
"
observed
Fledgeby
,
with
a
dry
whistle
,
"
<EOS>
I
hope
she
ai
n't
bad
enough
to
put
any
chap
up
to
the
fastenings
,
and
get
the
premises
broken
open
.
<EOS>
You
look
out
.
<EOS>
Keep
your
weather
eye
awake
,
and
do
n't
make
any
more
acquaintances
,
however
handsome
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
always
keep
my
name
to
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
assuredly
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
they
ask
it
,
say
it
's
Pubsey
,
or
say
it
's
Co
,
or
say
it
's
anything
you
like
,
but
what
it
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
His
grateful
servant
---
in
whose
race
gratitude
is
deep
,
strong
,
and
enduring
---
bowed
his
head
,
and
actually
did
now
put
the
hem
of
his
coat
to
his
lips
:
though
so
lightly
that
the
wearer
knew
nothing
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
,
Fascination
Fledgeby
went
his
way
,
exulting
in
the
artful
cleverness
with
which
he
had
turned
his
thumb
down
on
a
Jew
,
and
the
old
man
went
his
different
way
up
-
stairs
.
<EOS>
As
he
mounted
,
the
call
or
song
began
to
sound
in
his
ears
again
,
and
,
looking
above
,
he
saw
the
face
of
the
little
creature
looking
down
out
of
a
Glory
of
her
long
bright
radiant
hair
,
and
musically
repeating
to
him
,
like
a
vision
:
  
<EOS>
"
Come
up
and
be
dead
!
<EOS>
Come
up
and
be
dead
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
RIDDLE
WITHOUT
AN
ANSWER
.
 
<EOS>
Again
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
and
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
sat
together
in
the
Temple
.
<EOS>
This
evening
,
however
,
they
were
not
together
in
the
place
of
business
of
the
eminent
solicitor
,
but
in
another
dismal
set
of
chambers
facing
it
on
the
same
second
-
floor
;
on
whose
dungeon
-
like
black
outer
-
door
appeared
the
legend
:
  
Private
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
.
  
<EOS>
(=
<EOS>
>
<EOS>
Mr.
Lightwood
's
Offices
opposite
.
)
  
<EOS>
Appearances
indicated
that
this
establishment
was
a
very
recent
institution
.
<EOS>
The
white
letters
of
the
inscription
were
extremely
white
and
extremely
strong
to
the
sense
of
smell
,
the
complexion
of
the
tables
and
chairs
was
(
like
Lady
Tippins
's
)
a
little
too
blooming
to
be
believed
in
,
and
the
carpets
and
floorcloth
seemed
to
rush
at
the
beholder
's
face
in
the
unusual
prominency
of
their
patterns
.
<EOS>
But
the
Temple
,
accustomed
to
tone
down
both
the
still
life
and
the
human
life
that
has
much
to
do
with
it
,
would
soon
get
the
better
of
all
that
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Eugene
,
on
one

the
fire
,
"
I
feel
tolerably
comfortable
.
<EOS>
I
hope
the
upholsterer
may
do

same
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should

?
"
asked

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
To

,
"

,

"

not

the

our

,

may

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall

,

?
"
returned

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Eugene
,

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

!

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But

---

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
It

.

His

The

.
<EOS>
Secrtaire

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
Mortimer

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mortimer

<EOS>

<EOS>
Despite

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

founded

Eugene
when

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
The

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Gratifying
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Eugene
,
"

,

,

.
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
All

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Now

,

<EOS>
The

form

,
`
`
Riddle

-
riddle

me
-
ree
,
p'raps

you
ca

?
"
<EOS>
"

,
"
No
.
<EOS>
Upon

,

.
<EOS>
"

So

,

.
  
<EOS>

!
"

.

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
They

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
No

"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,
"
nothing

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
"
  
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
,
"
