,
taking
another
little
piece
of
earth
,
and
shooting
it
with
great
precision
at
the
former
mark
,
"
how
injurious
to
any
one
else
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
,
"
said
Eugene
,
taking
,
as
he
said
the
word
,
another
shot
,
"
to
whom
else
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Checking
himself
with
another
piece
of
earth
in
his
hand
,
Eugene
looked
at
his
friend
inquiringly
and
a
little
suspiciously
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
concealed
or
half
-
expressed
meaning
in
his
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Two
belated
wanderers
in
the
mazes
of
the
law
,
"
said
Eugene
,
attracted
by
the
sound
of
footsteps
,
and
glancing
down
as
he
spoke
,
"
stray
into
the
court
.
<EOS>
They
examine
the
door
-
posts
of
number
one
,
seeking
the
name
they
want
.
<EOS>
Not
finding
it
at
number
one
,
they
come
to
number
two
.
<EOS>
On
the
hat
of
wanderer
number
two
,
the
shorter
one
,
I
drop
this
pellet
.
<EOS>
Hitting
him
on
the
hat
,
I
smoke
serenely
,
and
become
absorbed
in
contemplation
of
the
sky
.
"
  
<EOS>
Both
the
wanderers
looked
up
towards
the
window
;
but
,
after
interchanging
a
mutter
or
two
,
soon
applied
themselves
to
the
doorposts
below
.
<EOS>
There
they
seemed
to
discover
what
they
wanted
,
for
they
disappeared
from
view
by
entering
at
the
doorway
.
<EOS>
"
When
they
emerge
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
you
shall
see
me
bring
them
both
down
;
"
and
so
prepared
two
pellets
for
the
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
reckoned
on
their
seeking
his
name
,
or
Lightwood
's
.
<EOS>
But
either
the
one
or
the
other
would
seem
to
be
in
question
,
for
now
there
came
a
knock
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
on
duty
to
-
night
,
"
said
Mortimer
,
"
stay
you
where
you
are
,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
Requiring
no
persuasion
,
he
stayed
there
,
smoking
quietly
,
and
not
at
all
curious
to
know
who
knocked
,
until
Mortimer
spoke
to
him
from
within
the
room
,
and
touched
him
.
<EOS>
Then
,
drawing
in
his
head
,
he
found
the
visitors
to
be
young
Charley
Hexam
and
the
schoolmaster
;
both
standing
facing
him
,
and
both
recognized
at
a
glance
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
recollect
this
young
fellow
,
Eugene
?
"
said
Mortimer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
look
at
him
,
"
returned
Wrayburn
,
coolly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
,
yes
.
<EOS>
I
recollect
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
not
been
about
to
repeat
that
former
action
of
taking
him
by
the
chin
,
but
the
boy
had
suspected
him
of
it
,
and
had
thrown
up
his
arm
with
an
angry
start
.
<EOS>
Laughingly
,
Wrayburn
looked
to
Lightwood
for
an
explanation
of
this
odd
visit
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
says
he
has
something
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Surely
it
must
be
to
you
,
Mortimer
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
thought
,
but
he
says
no
.
<EOS>
He
says
it
is
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
say
so
,
interposed
the
boy
.
<EOS>
And
I
mean
to
say
what
I
want
to
say
,
too
,
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
!
"
  
<EOS>
Passing
him
with
his
eyes
as
if
there
were
nothing
where
he
stood
,
Eugene
looked
on
to
Bradley
Headstone
.
<EOS>
With
consummate
indolence
,
he
turned
to
Mortimer
,
inquiring
:
"
<EOS>
And
who
may
this
other
person
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
Charles
Hexam
's
friend
,
"
said
Bradley
;
"
I
am
Charles
Hexam
's
schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
good
sir
,
you
should
teach
your
pupils
better
manners
,
"
returned
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
Composedly
smoking
,
he
leaned
an
elbow
on
the
chimneypiece
,
at
the
side
of
the
fire
,
and
looked
at
the
schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
cruel
look
,
in
its
cold
disdain
of
him
,
as
a
creature
of
no
worth
.
<EOS>
The
schoolmaster
looked
at
him
,
and
that
,
too
,
was
a
cruel
look
,
though
of
the
different
kind
,
that
it
had
a
raging
jealousy
and
fiery
wrath
in
it
.
  
<EOS>
Very
remarkably
,
neither
Eugene
Wrayburn
nor
Bradley
Headstone
looked
at
all
at
the
boy
.
<EOS>
Through
the
ensuing
dialogue
,
those
two
,
no
matter
who
spoke
,
or
whom
was
addressed
,
looked
at
each
other
.
<EOS>
There
was
some
secret
,
sure
perception
between
them
,
which
set
them
against
one
another
in
all
ways
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
some
high
respects
,
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
"
said
Bradley
,
answering
him
with
pale
and
quivering
lips
,
"
the
natural
feelings
of
my
pupils
are
stronger
than
my
teaching
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
most
respects
,
I
dare
say
,
"
replied
Eugene
,
enjoying
his
cigar
,
"
though
whether
high
or
low
is
of
no
importance
.
<EOS>
You
have
my
name
very
correctly
.
<EOS>
Pray
what
is
yours
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
can
not
concern
you
much
to
know
,
but
---
"
  
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
interposed
Eugene
,
striking
sharply
and
cutting
him
short
at
his
mistake
,
"
it
does
not
concern
me
at
all
to
know
.
<EOS>
I
can
say
Schoolmaster
,
which
is
a
most
respectable
title
.
<EOS>
You
are
right
,
Schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
dullest
part
of
this
goad
in
its
galling
of
Bradley
Headstone
,
that
he
had
made
it
himself
in
a
moment
of
incautious
anger
.
<EOS>
He
tried
to
set
his
lips
so
as
to
prevent
their
quivering
,
but
they
quivered
fast
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
"
said
the
boy
,
"
I
want
a
word
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
wanted
it
so
much
,
that
we
have
looked
out
your
address
in
the
book
,
and
we
have
been
to
your
office
,
and
we
have
come
from
your
office
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
given
yourself
much
trouble
,
Schoolmaster
,
"
observed
Eugene
,
blowing
the
feathery
ash
from
his
cigar
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
may
prove
remunerative
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
am
glad
to
speak
,
"
pursued
the
boy
,
"
in
presence
of
Mr.
Lightwood
,
because
it
was
through
Mr.
Lightwood
that
you
ever
saw
my
sister
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
For
a
mere
moment
,
Wrayburn
turned
his
eyes
aside
from
the
schoolmaster
to
note
the
effect
of
the
last
word
on
Mortimer
,
who
,
standing
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
fire
,
as
soon
as
the
word
was
spoken
,
turned
his
face
towards
the
fire
and
looked
down
into
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Similarly
,
it
was
through
Mr.
Lightwood
that
you
ever
saw
her
again
,
for
you
were
with
him
on
the
night
when
my
father
was
found
,
and
so
I
found
you
with
her
on
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
Since
then
,
you
have
seen
my
sister
often
.
<EOS>
You
have
seen
my
sister
oftener
and
oftener
.
<EOS>
And
I
want
to
know
why
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
this
worth
while
,
Schoolmaster
?
"
<EOS>
murmured
Eugene
,
with
the
air
of
a
disinterested
adviser
.
<EOS>
"
So
much
trouble
for
nothing
?
<EOS>
You
should
know
best
,
but
I
think
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
"
answered
Bradley
,
with
his
passion
rising
,
<EOS>
"
why
you
address
me
---
"
  
"
Do
n't
you
?
"
said
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
Then
I
wo
n't
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
said
it
so
tauntingly
in
his
perfect
placidity
,
that
the
respectable
right
-
hand
,
clutching
the
respectable
hair
-
guard
of
the
respectable
watch
could
have
wound
it
round
his
throat
and
strangled
him
with
it
.
<EOS>
Not
another
word
did
Eugene
deem
it
worth
while
to
utter
,
but
stood
leaning
his
head
upon
his
hand
,
smoking
,
and
looking
imperturbably
at
the
chafing
Bradley
Headstone
with
his
clutching
right
-
hand
,
until
Bradley
was
wellnigh
mad
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
"
proceeded
the
boy
,
"
we
not
only
know
this
that
I
have
charged
upon
you
,
but
we
know
more
.
<EOS>
It
has
not
yet
come
to
my
sister
's
knowledge
that
we
have
found
it
out
,
but
we
have
.
<EOS>
We
had
a
plan
,
Mr.
Headstone
and
I
,
for
my
sister
's
education
,
and
for
its
being
advised
and
overlooked
by
Mr.
Headstone
,
who
is
a
much
more
competent
authority
,
whatever
you
may
pretend
to
think
,
as
you
smoke
,
than
you
could
produce
,
if
you
tried
.
<EOS>
Then
,
what
do
we
find
?
<EOS>
What
do
we
find
,
Mr.
Lightwood
?
<EOS>
Why
,
we
find
that
my
sister
is
already
being
taught
,
without
our
knowing
it
.
<EOS>
We
find
that
while
my
sister
gives
an
unwilling
and
cold
ear
to
our
schemes
for
her
advantage
---
I
,
her
brother
,
and
Mr.
Headstone
,
the
most
competent
authority
,
as
his
certificates
would
easily
prove
,
that
could
be
produced
---
she
is
wilfully
and
willingly
profiting
by
other
schemes
.
<EOS>
Ay
,
and
taking
pains
,
too
,
<EOS>
for
I
know
what
such
pains
are
.
<EOS>
And
so
does
Mr.
Headstone
!
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Somebody
pays
for
this
,
is
a
thought
that
naturally
occurs
to
us
;
who
pays
?
<EOS>
We
apply
ourselves
to
find
out
,
Mr.
Lightwood
,
and
we
find
that
your
friend
,
this
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
here
,
pays
.
<EOS>
Then
I
ask
him
what
right
<EOS>
has
he
to
do
it
,
and
what
does
he
mean
by
it
,
and
how
comes
he
to
be
taking
such
a
liberty
without
my
consent
,
when
I
am
raising
myself
in
the
scale
of
society
by
my
own
exertions
and
Mr.
Headstone
's
aid
,
and
have
no
right
to
have
any
darkness
cast
upon
my
prospects
,
or
any
imputation
upon
my
respectability
,
through
my
sister
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
boyish
weakness
of
this
speech
,
combined
with
its
great
selfishness
,
made
it
a
poor
one
indeed
.
<EOS>
And
yet
Bradley
Headstone
,
used
to
the
little
audience
of
a
school
,
and
unused
to
the
larger
ways
of
men
,
showed
a
kind
of
exultation
in
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
I
tell
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
"
pursued
the
boy
,
forced
into
the
use
of
the
third
person
by
the
hopelessness
of
addressing
him
in
the
first
,
"
that
I
object
to
his
having
any
acquaintance
at
all
with
my
sister
,
and
that
I
request
him
to
drop
it
altogether
.
<EOS>
He
is
not
to
take
it
into
his
head
that
I
am
afraid
of
my
sister
's
caring
for
him
---
"
  
(
As
the
boy
sneered
,
the
Master
sneered
,
and
Eugene
blew
off
the
feathery
ash
again
.
)
   
---
<EOS>
"
But
I
object
to
it
,
and
that
's
enough
.
<EOS>
I
am
more
important
to
my
sister
than
he
thinks
.
<EOS>
As
I
raise
myself
,
I
intend
to
raise
her
;
she
knows
that
,
and
she
has
to
look
to
me
for
her
prospects
.
<EOS>
Now
I
understand
all
this
very
well
,
and
so
does
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
My
sister
is
an
excellent
girl
,
but
she
has
some
romantic
notions
;
 
not
about
such
things
as
your
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburns
,
but
about
the
death
of
my
father
and
other
matters
of
that
sort
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wrayburn
encourages
those
notions
to
make
himself
of
importance
,
and
so
she
thinks
she
ought
be
grateful
to
him
,
and
perhaps
even
likes
to
be
.
<EOS>
Now
I
do
n't
choose
her
to
be
grateful
to
him
,
or
to
be
grateful
to
anybody
but
me
,
except
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
And
I
tell
Mr.
Wrayburn
that
if
he
do
n't
take
heed
of
what
I
say
,
it
will
be
worse
for
her
.
<EOS>
Let
him
turn
that
over
in
his
memory
,
and
make
sure
of
it
.
<EOS>
Worse
for
her
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
pause
ensued
,
in
which
the
schoolmaster
looked
very
awkward
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
suggest
,
Schoolmaster
,
"
said
Eugene
,
removing
his
fastwaning
cigar
from
his
lips
to
glance
at
it
,
"
that
you
can
now
take
your
pupil
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
Mr.
Lightwood
,
"
added
the
boy
,
with
a
burning
face
,
under
the
flaming
aggravation
of
getting
no
sort
of
answer
or
attention
,
"
I
hope
you
'll
take
notice
of
what
I
have
said
to
your
friend
,
and
of
what
your
friend
has
heard
me
say
,
word
by
word
,
whatever
he
pretends
to
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
You
are
bound
to
take
notice
of
it
,
Mr.
Lightwood
,
for
,
as
I
have
already
mentioned
,
you
first
brought
your
friend
into
my
sister
's
company
,
and
but
for
you
we
never
should
have
seen
him
.
<EOS>
Lord
knows
none
of
us
ever
wanted
him
,
any
more
than
any
of
us
will
ever
miss
him
.
<EOS>
Now
Mr.
Headstone
,
as
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
has
been
obliged
to
hear
what
I
had
to
say
,
and
could
n't
help
himself
,
and
as
I
have
said
it
out
to
the
last
word
,
we
have
done
all
we
wanted
to
do
,
and
may
go
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Go
down
-
stairs
,
and
leave
me
a
moment
,
Hexam
,
"
he
returned
.
<EOS>
The
boy
complying
with
an
indignant
look
and
as
much
noise
as
he
could
make
,
swung
out
of
the
room
;
and
Lightwood
went
to
the
window
,
and
leaned
there
,
looking
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
think
me
of
no
more
value
than
the
dirt
under
your
feet
,
"
 
said
Bradley
to
Eugene
,
speaking
in
a
carefully
weighed
and
measured
tone
,
or
he
could
not
have
spoken
at
all
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
assure
you
,
Schoolmaster
,
"
replied
Eugene
,
"
I
do
n't
think
about
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
true
,
"
returned
the
other
;
"
you
know
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
coarse
,
"
Eugene
retorted
;
"
but
you
do
n't
know
better
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
at
least
I
know
very
well
that
it
would
be
idle
to
set
myself
against
you
in
insolent
words
or
overbearing
manners
.
<EOS>
That
lad
who
has
just
gone
out
could
put
you
to
shame
in
half
-
a
-
dozen
branches
of
knowledge
in
half
an
hour
,
but
you
can
throw
him
aside
like
an
inferior
.
<EOS>
You
can
do
as
much
by
me
<EOS>
,
I
have
no
doubt
,
beforehand
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Possibly
,
"
remarked
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
more
than
a
lad
,
"
said
Bradley
,
with
his
clutching
hand
,
"
and
I
   
WILL
be
heard
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
a
schoolmaster
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
you
are
always
being
heard
.
<EOS>
That
ought
to
content
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
does
not
content
me
,
"
replied
the
other
,
white
with
passion
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
suppose
that
a
man
,
in
forming
himself
for
the
duties
I
discharge
,
and
in
watching
and
repressing
himself
daily
to
discharge
them
well
,
dismisses
a
man
's
nature
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
judging
from
what
I
see
as
I
look
at
you
,
to
be
rather
too
passionate
for
a
good
schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
"
As
he
spoke
,
he
tossed
away
the
end
of
his
cigar
.
  
<EOS>
"
Passionate
with
you
,
sir
<EOS>
,
I
admit
I
am
.
<EOS>
Passionate
with
you
,
sir
,
I
respect
myself
for
being
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
not
Devils
for
my
pupils
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
For
your
Teachers
,
I
should
rather
say
,
"
replied
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
my
name
is
Bradley
Headstone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
you
justly
said
,
my
good
sir
,
your
name
can
not
concern
me
.
<EOS>
Now
,
what
more
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
This
more
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
what
a
misfortune
is
mine
,
"
cried
Bradley
,
breaking
off
to
wipe
the
starting
perspiration
from
his
face
as
he
shook
from
head
to
foot
,
"
that
I
can
not
so
control
myself
as
to
appear
a
stronger
creature
than
this
,
when
a
man
who
has
not
felt
in
all
his
life
what
I
have
felt
in
a
day
can
so
command
himself
!
"
<EOS>
He
said
it
in
a
very
agony
,
and
even
followed
it
with
an
errant
motion
of
his
hands
as
if
he
could
have
torn
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Eugene
Wrayburn
looked
on
at
him
,
as
if
he
found
him
beginning
to
be
rather
an
entertaining
study
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
I
desire
to
say
something
to
you
on
my
own
part
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
come
,
Schoolmaster
,
"
returned
Eugene
,
with
a
languid
approach
to
impatience
as
the
other
again
struggled
with
himself
;
 
"
say
what
you
have
to
say
.
<EOS>
And
let
me
remind
you
that
the
door
is
standing
open
,
and
your
young
friend
waiting
for
you
on
the
stairs
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
accompanied
that
youth
here
,
sir
,
I
did
so
with
the
purpose
of
adding
,
as
a
man
whom
you
should
not
be
permitted
to
put
aside
,
in
case
you
put
him
aside
as
a
boy
,
that
his
instinct
is
correct
and
right
.
"
<EOS>
Thus
Bradley
Headstone
,
with
great
effort
and
difficulty
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
asked
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
"
said
the
other
,
flushed
and
fierce
.
<EOS>
"
I
strongly
support
him
in
his
disapproval
of
your
visits
to
his
sister
,
and
in
his
objection
to
your
officiousness
---
and
worse
---
in
what
you
taken
upon
yourself
to
do
for
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
asked
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
determined
to
tell
you
that
you
are
not
justified
in
these
proceedings
,
and
that
they
are
injurious
to
his
sister
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
her
schoolmaster
as
well
as
her
brother
's
?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Or
perhaps
you
would
like
to
be
?
"
said
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
stab
that
the
blood
followed
,
in
its
rush
to
Bradley
Headstone
's
face
,
as
swiftly
as
if
it
had
been
dealt
with
a
dagger
.
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
by
that
?
"
was
as
much
as
he
could
utter
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
natural
ambition
enough
,
"
said
Eugene
,
coolly
.
<EOS>
"
Far
be
it
from
me
to
say
otherwise
.
<EOS>
The
sister
---
who
is
something
too
much
upon
your
lips
,
perhaps
---
is
so
very
different
from
all
the
associations
to
which
she
has
been
used
,
and
from
all
the
low
obscure
people
about
her
,
that
it
is
a
very
natural
ambition
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
throw
my
obscurity
in
my
teeth
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
can
hardly
be
,
for
I
know
nothing
concerning
it
,
Schoolmaster
,
and
seek
to
know
nothing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
reproach
me
with
my
origin
,
"
said
Bradley
Headstone
;
<EOS>
"
you
cast
insinuations
at
my
bringing
-
up
.
<EOS>
But
I
tell
you
,
sir
,
I
have
worked
my
way
onward
,
out
of
both
and
in
spite
of
both
,
and
have
a
right
to
be
considered
a
better
man
than
you
,
with
better
reasons
for
being
proud
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
I
can
reproach
you
with
what
is
not
within
my
knowledge
,
or
how
I
can
cast
stones
that
were
never
in
my
hand
,
is
a
problem
for
the
ingenuity
of
a
schoolmaster
to
prove
,
"
returned
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
Is
that
all
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
<EOS>
If
you
suppose
that
boy
---
"
  
"
Who
really
will
be
tired
of
waiting
,
"
said
Eugene
,
politely
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
suppose
that
boy
to
be
friendless
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
you
deceive
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
am
his
friend
,
and
you
shall
find
me
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
will
find
him
on
the
stairs
,
"
remarked
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
have
promised
yourself
,
sir
,
that
you
could
do
what
you
chose
here
,
because
you
had
to
deal
with
a
mere
boy
,
inexperienced
,
friendless
,
and
unassisted
.
<EOS>
But
I
give
you
warning
that
this
mean
calculation
is
wrong
.
<EOS>
You
have
to
do
with
a
man
also
.
<EOS>
You
have
to
do
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
will
support
him
,
and
,
if
need
be
,
require
reparation
for
him
.
<EOS>
My
hand
and
heart
are
in
this
cause
,
and
are
open
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
---
quite
a
coincidence
---
the
door
is
open
,
"
remarked
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
scorn
your
shifty
evasions
,
and
I
scorn
you
,
"
said
the
Schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
"
In
the
meanness
of
your
nature
you
revile
me
with
the
meanness
of
my
birth
.
<EOS>
I
hold
you
in
contempt
for
it
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
do
n't
profit
by
this
visit
,
and
act
accordingly
,
you
will
find
me
as
bitterly
in
earnest
against
you
as
I
could
be
if
I
deemed
you
worth
a
second
thought
on
my
own
account
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
consciously
bad
grace
and
stiff
manner
,
as
Wrayburn
looked
so
easily
and
calmly
on
,
he
went
out
with
these
words
,
and
the
heavy
door
closed
like
a
furnace
-
door
upon
his
red
and
white
heats
of
rage
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
curious
monomaniac
,
"
said
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
The
man
seems
to
believe
that
everybody
was
acquainted
with
his
mother
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
Lightwood
being
still
at
the
window
,
to
which
he
had
in
delicacy
withdrawn
,
Eugene
called
to
him
,
and
he
fell
to
slowly
pacing
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
,
"
said
Eugene
,
as
he
lighted
another
cigar
,
"
I
fear
my
unexpected
visitors
have
been
troublesome
.
<EOS>
If
as
a
set
-
off
(
excuse
the
legal
phrase
from
a
barrister
-
at
-
law
)
<EOS>
you
would
like
to
ask
Tippins
to
tea
,
I
pledge
myself
to
make
love
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
Eugene
,
Eugene
,
"
replied
Mortimer
,
still
pacing
the
room
<EOS>
,
"
I
am
sorry
for
this
.
<EOS>
And
to
think
that
I
have
been
so
blind
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
blind
,
dear
boy
?
"
inquired
his
unmoved
friend
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
were
your
words
that
night
at
the
river
-
side
public
-
house
?
"
 
<EOS>
said
Lightwood
,
stopping
.
<EOS>
"
What
was
it
that
you
asked
me
?
<EOS>
Did
I
feel
like
a
dark
combination
of
traitor
and
pickpocket
when
I
thought
of
that
girl
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
seem
to
remember
the
expression
,
"
said
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
feel
when
you
think
of
her
just
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
His
friend
made
no
direct
reply
,
but
observed
,
after
a
few
whiffs
of
his
cigar
,
"
Do
n't
mistake
the
situation
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
better
girl
in
all
this
London
than
Lizzie
Hexam
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
better
among
my
people
at
home
;
no
better
among
your
people
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Granted
.
<EOS>
What
follows
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
"
said
Eugene
,
looking
after
him
dubiously
as
he
paced
away
to
the
other
end
of
the
room
,
"
you
put
me
again
upon
guessing
the
riddle
that
I
have
given
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
do
you
design
to
capture
and
desert
this
girl
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
,
no
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
design
to
marry
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
,
no
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
design
to
pursue
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
,
I
do
n't
design
anything
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
design
<EOS>
whatever
.
<EOS>
I
am
incapable
of
designs
.
<EOS>
If
I
conceived
a
design
,
I
should
speedily
abandon
it
,
exhausted
by
the
operation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Eugene
,
Eugene
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mortimer
,
not
that
tone
of
melancholy
reproach
,
I
entreat
.
<EOS>
What
can
I
do
more
than
tell
you
all
know
,
and
acknowledge
my
ignorance
of
all
I
do
n't
know
!
<EOS>
How
does
that
little
old
song
go
,
which
,
under
pretence
of
being
cheerful
,
is
by
far
the
most
lugubrious
I
ever
heard
in
my
life
?
   
<EOS>
`
`
Away
with
melancholy
,
  
Nor
doleful
changes
ring
  
On
life
and
human
folly
,
  
But
merrily
merrily
sing
  
Fal
la
!
"
<EOS>
"
  
Do
n't
let
us
sing
Fal
la
,
my
dear
Mortimer
(
which
is
comparatively
unmeaning
)
,
but
let
us
sing
that
we
give
up
guessing
the
riddle
altogether
.
"
  
"
Are
you
in
communication
with
this
girl
,
Eugene
,
and
is
what
these
people
say
true
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
concede
both
admissions
to
my
honorable
and
learned
friend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what
is
to
come
of
it
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
?
<EOS>
Where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mortimer
,
one
would
think
the
schoolmaster
had
left
behind
him
a
catechizing
infection
.
<EOS>
You
are
ruffled
by
the
want
of
another
cigar
.
<EOS>
Take
one
of
these
,
I
entreat
.
<EOS>
Light
it
at
mine
,
which
is
in
perfect
order
.
<EOS>
So
!
<EOS>
Now
do
me
the
justice
to
observe
that
I
am
doing
all
I
can
towards
self
-
improvement
,
and
that
you
have
a
light
thrown
on
those
household
implements
which
,
when
you
only
saw
them
as
in
a
glass
darkly
,
you
were
hastily
<EOS>
---
I
must
say
hastily
---
inclined
to
depreciate
.
<EOS>
Sensible
of
my
deficiencies
,
I
have
surrounded
myself
with
moral
influences
expressly
meant
to
promote
the
formation
of
the
domestic
virtues
.
<EOS>
To
those
influences
,
and
to
the
improving
society
of
my
friend
from
boyhood
,
commend
me
with
your
best
wishes
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
,
Eugene
!
"
said
Lightwood
,
affectionately
,
now
standing
near
him
,
so
that
they
both
stood
in
one
little
cloud
of
smoke
;
"
I
would
that
you
answered
my
three
questions
!
<EOS>
What
is
to
come
of
it
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
?
<EOS>
Where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
my
dear
Mortimer
,
"
returned
Eugene
,
lightly
fanning
away
the
smoke
with
his
hand
for
the
better
exposition
of
his
frankness
of
face
and
manner
,
"
believe
me
,
I
would
answer
them
instantly
if
I
could
.
<EOS>
But
to
enable
me
to
do
so
,
I
must
first
have
found
out
the
troublesome
conundrum
long
abandoned
.
<EOS>
Here
it
is
.
<EOS>
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
"
 
<EOS>
Tapping
his
forehead
and
breast
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Riddle
-
me
,
riddle
-
me
-
ree
<EOS>
,
perhaps
you
ca
n't
tell
me
what
this
may
be
?
---
<EOS>
No
,
upon
my
life
I
ca
n't
.
<EOS>
I
give
it
up
!
"
   
<EOS>
IN
WHICH
A
FRIENDLY
MOVE
IS
ORIGINATED
.
 
<EOS>
The
arrangement
between
Mr.
Boffin
and
his
literary
man
,
Mr.
Silas
Wegg
,
so
far
altered
with
the
altered
habits
of
Mr.
Boffin
's
life
,
as
that
the
Roman
Empire
usually
declined
in
the
morning
and
in
the
eminently
aristocratic
family
mansion
,
rather
than
in
the
evening
,
as
of
yore
,
and
in
Boffin
's
Bower
.
<EOS>
There
were
occasions
,
however
,
when
Mr.
Boffin
,
seeking
a
brief
refuge
from
the
blandishments
of
fashion
,
would
present
himself
at
the
Bower
after
dark
,
to
anticipate
the
next
sallying
forth
of
Wegg
,
and
would
there
,
on
the
old
settle
,
pursue
the
downward
fortunes
of
those
enervated
and
corrupted
masters
of
the
world
who
were
by
this
time
on
their
last
legs
.
<EOS>
If
Wegg
had
been
worse
paid
for
his
office
,
or
better
qualified
to
discharge
it
,
he
would
have
considered
these
visits
complimentary
and
agreeable
;
but
,
holding
the
position
of
a
handsomely
-
remunerated
humbug
,
he
resented
them
.
<EOS>
This
was
quite
according
to
rule
,
for
the
incompetent
servant
,
by
whomsoever
employed
,
is
always
against
his
employer
.
<EOS>
Even
those
born
governors
,
noble
and
right
honorable
creatures
,
who
have
been
the
most
imbecile
in
high
places
,
have
uniformly
shown
themselves
the
most
opposed
(
sometimes
in
belying
distrust
,
sometimes
in
vapid
insolence
)
to
their
employer
.
<EOS>
What
is
in
such
wise
true
of
the
public
master
and
servant
,
is
equally
true
of
the
private
master
and
servant
all
the
world
over
.
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Silas
Wegg
did
at
last
obtain
free
access
to
"
Our
House
,
"
as
he
had
been
wo
nt
to
call
the
mansion
outside
which
he
had
sat
shelterless
so
long
,
and
when
he
did
at
last
find
it
in
all
particulars
as
different
from
his
mental
plans
of
it
as
according
to
the
nature
of
things
it
well
could
be
,
that
far
-
seeing
and
far
-
reaching
character
,
by
way
of
asserting
himself
and
making
out
a
case
for
compensation
,
affected
to
fall
into
a
melancholy
strain
of
musing
over
the
mournful
past
;
as
if
the
house
<EOS>
and
he
had
had
a
fall
in
life
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
this
,
sir
,
"
Silas
would
say
to
his
patron
,
sadly
nodding
his
head
and
musing
,
"
was
once
Our
House
!
<EOS>
This
,
sir
,
is
the
building
from
which
I
have
so
often
seen
those
great
creatures
,
Miss
Elizabeth
,
Master
George
,
Aunt
Jane
,
and
Uncle
Parker
"
---
whose
very
names
were
of
his
own
inventing
---
"
pass
and
repass
!
<EOS>
And
has
it
come
to
this
,
indeed
!
<EOS>
Ah
dear
me
,
dear
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
So
tender
were
his
lamentations
,
that
the
kindly
Mr.
Boffin
was
quite
sorry
for
him
,
and
almost
felt
mistrustful
that
in
buying
the
house
he
had
done
him
an
irreparable
injury
.
  
<EOS>
Two
or
three
diplomatic
interviews
,
the
result
of
great
subtlety
on
Mr.
Wegg
's
part
,
but
assuming
the
mask
of
careless
yielding
to
a
fortuitous
combination
of
circumstances
impelling
him
towards
Clerkenwell
,
had
enabled
him
to
complete
his
bargain
with
Mr.
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bring
me
round
to
the
Bower
,
"
said
Silas
,
when
the
bargain
was
closed
,
"
<EOS>
next
Saturday
evening
,
and
if
a
sociable
glass
of
old
Jamaikey
warm
should
meet
your
views
,
I
am
not
the
man
to
begrudge
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
aware
of
my
being
poor
company
,
sir
,
"
replied
Mr.
Venus
,
"
but
be
it
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
being
so
<EOS>
,
here

Saturday
evening
come
,
and
here
is
Mr.
Venus
come
,
and
ringing
at

-
gate
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
opens

,

under

's

,

,

:
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

No
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Above

!
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But

"
a

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---
flowed
.
<EOS>
"

Thankee
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Now

,

mention

that
I
've

whether

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Do

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

ca

,

;
not

,

ca

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then

,
bone
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
As

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
As

point
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

I

,

"

,

;
"

I

;
and
as

point

fact
I
would
have
seen
you
---

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would

,

,
"
Mr.

suggests
,

.
   
---
"
Before

into

without

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

the
point
of
law
may

,
but
I
'm
thoroughly

upon

point

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Venus
is
irritable
(
no
doubt
owing
to
his

in
love
)
,
and
as

not

cue

,

,
"
I
only
put
it
as
a
little
case
;
I
only

ha'porthetically
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
'd
rather
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
you
put
it
another
time
,
penn'orthetically
,
"
 
is
Mr.
Venus
's

,
"
for
I
tell

candidly
I
do
n't
like
your
little
-
cases
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Arrived
by
this

's

,

chilly

,

;

that
he
(
Venus
)

.

"
Tolerable
,
"

.
"
<EOS>
But

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
Mix

and

a

-

.
<EOS>
Will

perform
upon

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

but

,

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
,

Venus

,

Wegg

;
and
Mr.
Venus
lights
and

,

lights

puffs
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
there
's
alloy
even
in
this
metal
of
yours
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
you
was
remarking
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mystery
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,
Mr.
Venus
.
<EOS>
I

of

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
know
who
profits
by

.
<EOS>
But
I
've
no
suspicions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
said
which
,
Mr.
Wegg
smokes
and

at

fire
with
a
most
determined
expression
of
Charity
;
as
if
he
had
caught
that

virtue

skirts
as

felt

her
painful
duty
to
depart
from
him
,
and
held
her
by

.
  
<EOS>
"
Similarly
,
"
resumes

,
<EOS>
"
I
have
observations
as
I
can
offer
upon
certain
points
and
parties
;
but
I
make
no
objections
,
Mr.
Venus
.
<EOS>
Here
is
an
immense
fortune
drops
from
the
clouds
upon
a
person
that
shall
be
nameless
.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
weekly
allowance
,
with
a
certain

of
coals
,
drops
from
the
clouds
upon
me
.
<EOS>
Which
of
us
is
the
better
man
?
<EOS>
Not
the
person
that
shall
be

.
<EOS>
That
's
an
observation
of
mine
,
but
I
do
n't
make

an

.
<EOS>
I
take
my
allowance
and
my
certain
weight
of
coals
.
<EOS>
He
takes
his

.
<EOS>
That
's
the

works
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

things
in

calm
light
you
do
,

Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Again

here
,
"

Silas
,
with

of

:
<EOS>
the
latter

;
"
here
's
another
observation
,
Mr.
Venus
,
unaccompanied

.
<EOS>
Him
that
shall
be
nameless
is
liable

be
talked
over
.
<EOS>
He
gets
talked
over
.
<EOS>
Him
that
shall
be
nameless
,

me

,
naturally
looking
to
be
promoted
higher
,
and
you
may
perhaps
say
meriting

higher
---
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(

that

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
---
Him
that
shall
be
nameless
,
under
such
circumstances
passes
me
by
,
and
puts
a
talking
-
over
stranger
above
my
head
.
<EOS>
Which
of
us
two
is
the
better
man
?
<EOS>
Which
of
us
two
can
repeat
most
poetry
?
<EOS>
Which
of
us
two
has
,
in

service
of
him
that
shall
be
nameless
,
tackled
the
Romans
,
both
civil

,
till

has
got
as

if

'd

weaned
and

?
<EOS>
Not

-
over

.
<EOS>
Yet

as

,
and

has

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Merit
,

,

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
I

,

ca

,

;

.
<EOS>

,

?

"

,

.

"
  
<EOS>
"

've

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"

"

but

-

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

quest

,

;

<EOS>
"

.
"
<EOS>
This

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

,

;

.

"

<EOS>

,

,

,

.

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

(

)
,

to

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
not

the

of
the

---

.
  
<EOS>
To

,

,

of

the

of

's
ears
,

.
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Wegg
,

,

,
as

Venus

his
breast
is
,
and
then
folds
them
pending
a
reply
,
Mr.
Venus
winks
at
him
with
both
eyes
some
little
time
before
speaking
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
you
have
tried
it
by
yourself
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
"
he
says
when
he
does
speak
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
found
out
the
difficulties
by
experience
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
it
can
hardly
be
said
that
I
have
tried
it
,
"
replies
Wegg
,
a
little
dashed
by
the
hint
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
skimmed
it
.
<EOS>
Skimmed
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
found
nothing
besides
the
difficulties
?
"
  
<EOS>
Wegg
shakes
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
scarcely
know
what
to
say
to
this
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
"
observes
Venus
,
after
ruminating
for
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
yes
,
"
Wegg
naturally
urges
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
was
n't
soured
,
my
answer
would
be
no
.
<EOS>
But
being
soured
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
and
driven
to
reckless
madness
and
desperation
,
I
suppose
it
's
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
Wegg
joyfully
reproduces
the
two
glasses
,
repeats
the
ceremony
of
clinking
their
rims
,
and
inwardly
drinks
with
great

to
the
health
and
success
in
life
of
the
young
lady
who
has
reduced
Mr.
Venus
to
his
present
convenient
state
of
mind
.
  
<EOS>
The
articles
of
the
friendly
move
are
then
severally
recited
and
agreed
upon
.
<EOS>
They
are
but
secrecy
,
fidelity
,
and
perseverance
.
<EOS>
The
Bower
to
be
always
free
of
access
to
Mr.
Venus
for
his
researches
,
and
every
precaution
to
be
taken
against
their
attracting
observation
in
the
neighbourhood
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
footstep
!
"
<EOS>
exclaims
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
cries
Wegg
,
starting
.
  
<EOS>
"
Outside
.
<EOS>
St
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
are
in
the
act
of
ratifying
the
treaty
of
friendly
move
,
by
shaking
hands
upon
it
.
<EOS>
They
softly
break
off
,
light
their
pipes
which
have
gone
out
,
and
lean

in
their

.
<EOS>
No
doubt
,
a
footstep
.
<EOS>
It
approaches
the
window
,
and
a
hand
taps
at
the
glass
.
<EOS>
"
Come
in
!
"
<EOS>
calls
Wegg
;
meaning
come
round
by
the
door
.
<EOS>
But
the
heavy
old
-
fashioned
sash
is
slowly
raised
,
and
a
head
slowly
looks
in
out
of
the
dark

of
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
is
Mr.
Silas
Wegg
here
?
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
see
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
friendly
movers
might
not
have

quite
at
their

,
even
though
the
visitor
had
entered
in

usual

.
<EOS>
But
,
leaning
on

breast
-

,
and
staring
in
out
of

,
they
find
the
visitor
extremely

.
<EOS>
Especially
Mr.
Venus
:
who
removes

,

,
and

starer
,
as
if

were
his
own
Hindoo
baby
come
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
Mr.
Wegg
.
<EOS>
The
yard
gate
-
lock
should
be
looked
to
,
if
you
please
;
it
do
n't
catch
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

Mr.
Rokesmith
?
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
Do

let
me
disturb

.
<EOS>
I
am
not
coming
in
.
<EOS>
I

only

,

undertook

.
<EOS>
I

about

gate
without
ringing
:
<EOS>
not

<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish

,
"

,
with

.
<EOS>
St
!
<EOS>
Hush
!
<EOS>
The
talking
-
over
stranger
,
Mr.
Venus
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
any
one
I

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
Friend

.
<EOS>
Passing

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
I

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin

,

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
That

.
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
They

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

,
"

,

,
"
I

!
<EOS>
Let

?
"
  
<EOS>
Apparently
,

,

,

that

has
"
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
double

,
you

,

,
"

,
playing

.
<EOS>
"
That
's

look
.
<EOS>
Any
amount
of
singular
look
for
me
,
but
not
a
double

!
<EOS>
That
's
an
under
-
handed

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

's
something
against
him
?
"
<EOS>
Venus

.
  
<EOS>
"
Something
against
him
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Something
?
<EOS>
What
would
the
relief
be
to
my
feelings
---
as
a
fellow
-
man
---
if
I
was
n't
the
slave
of
truth
,
and
did
n't
feel
myself
compelled
to
answer
,
Everything
!
"
  
<EOS>
See
into
what
wonderful
maudlin
refuges
,
featherless

plunge
their

!
<EOS>
It
is
such

compensation
to
Wegg
,
to
be
overcome
by
the

that
Mr.
Rokesmith
has
an
underhanded
mind
!
  
<EOS>
"
On
this
starlight
night
,
Mr.
Venus
,
"
he

,
when

is
showing
that
friendly
mover
out

,
and
both
are
something
the
worse
for
mixing
again

again
:
"
on

to

that
talking
-
over

,
and
underhanded
minds
,
can
go

home

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

,

,
"
brings
heavy

her
crushing
words
that
she
did
not

to
regard

nor
yet
to

---
"
  
"
<EOS>
I
know
!
<EOS>
I
know
!
<EOS>
You
need
n't
repeat
'
em
,
"
says
Wegg
,
pressing

.
<EOS>
"
But

how
those
stars
steady
me
in
the
cause
of
the
right
against
some
that
shall

nameless
.
<EOS>
It
is

.
<EOS>
But

glisten

!
<EOS>
Old

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,
"
Of

,
in
her
own

,
that

,

---
"
 
when
Silas
cuts

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Remembrances
of
Our
House
,
of
Master
George
,
of
Aunt
Jane
,
of
Uncle
Parker
,
all
laid
waste
!
<EOS>
All
offered
up
sacrifices
to
the
minion
of
fortune
and
the
worm
of
the
hour
!
"
   
<EOS>
IN
WHICH
AN
INNOCENT
ELOPEMENT
OCCURS
.
 
<EOS>
The
minion
of
fortune
and
the
worm
of
the
hour
,
or
in
less
cutting
language
,
Nicodemus
Boffin
,
Esquire
,
the
Golden
Dustman
,
had
become
as
much
at
home
in
his
eminently
aristocratic
family
mansion
as
he
was
likely
ever
to
be
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
but
feel
that
,
like
an
eminently
aristocratic
family
cheese
,
it
was
much
too
large
for
his
wants
,
and
bred
an
infinite
amount
of
parasites
;
but
he
was
content
to
regard
this
drawback
on
his
property
as
a
sort
of
perpetual
Legacy
Duty
.
<EOS>
He
felt
the
more
resigned
to
it
,
forasmuch
as
Mrs.
Boffin
enjoyed
herself
completely
,
and
Miss
Bella
was
delighted
.
  
<EOS>
That
young
lady
was
,
no
doubt
,
an
acquisition
to
the
Boffins
.
<EOS>
She
was
far
too
pretty
to
be
unattractive
anywhere
,
and
far
too
quick
of
perception
to
be
below
the
tone
of
her
new
career
.
<EOS>
Whether
it
improved
her
heart
might
be
a
matter
of
taste
that
was
open
to
question
;
 
but
as
touching
another
matter
of
taste
,
its
improvement
of
her
appearance
and
manner
,
there
could
be
no
question
whatever
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
it
soon
came
about
that
Miss
Bella
began
to
set
Mrs.
Boffin
right
;
and
even
further
,
that
Miss
Bella
began
to
feel
ill
at
ease
,
and
as
it
were
responsible
,
when
she
saw
Mrs.
Boffin
going
wrong
.
<EOS>
Not
that
so
sweet
a
disposition
and
so
sound
a
nature
<EOS>
could
ever
go
very
wrong
even
among
the
great
visiting
authorities
who
agreed
that
the
Boffins
were
"
charmingly
vulgar
"
(
which
for
certain
was
not
their
own
case
in
saying
so
)
,
but
that
when
she
made
a
slip
on
the
social
ice
on
which
all
the
children
of
Podsnappery
,
with
genteel
souls
to
be
saved
,
are
required
to
skate
in
circles
,
or
to
slide
in
long
rows
,
she
inevitably
tripped
Miss
Bella
up
(
so
that
young
lady
felt
)
,
and
caused
her
to
experience
great
confusion
under
the
glances
of
the
more
skilful
performers
engaged
in
those
ice
-
exercises
.
  
<EOS>
At
Miss
Bella
's
time
of
life
it
was
not
be
expected
that
she
should
examine
herself
very
closely
on
the
congruity
or
stability
of
her
position
in
Mr.
Boffin
's
house
.
<EOS>
And
as
she
had
never
been
sparing
of
complaints
of
her
old
home
when
she
had
no
other
to
compare

with
,
so
there
was
no
novelty
of
ingratitude
or
disdain
in
her
very
much

her
new
one
.
  
<EOS>
"
An
invaluable
man
is
Rokesmith
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
after
some
two
or
three
months
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
ca
n't
quite
make
him
out
.
"
  
<EOS>
Neither
could
Bella
,
so
she
found
the

rather

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
takes
more
care

my

,
morning
,

,

night
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
than

;
 
and

that
are
like
tying

the

,
and
bringing
me
up

when
I

almost
a
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
how
so
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my

,
"
said

Boffin
,
"
he
wo
n't
meet
any
company
here
,
but
you
.
<EOS>
When

,
I

the

like

;

,

wo
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
considers

above

,
"
said

Bella
,
with

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
ai
n't
that
,
my
dear
,
"
replied
Mr.
Boffin
,
thinking
it
over
.
"
<EOS>
He
do
n't
consider
himself
above
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
he
considers
himself
beneath
it
,
"
suggested
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
If
so
,
he
ought
to
know
best
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
;
nor
it
ai
n't
that
,
neither
.
<EOS>
No
,
"
repeated
Mr.
Boffin
,
with

shake

his
head
,
after
again
thinking

over
;
"
Rokesmith
's
a
modest

,
but
he
do
n't

beneath

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
what
does
he
consider
,
sir
?
"
asked
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dashed
if
I
know
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
It
seemed
at
first
as
if
it
was
only
Lightwood
that
he
objected
to
meet
.
<EOS>
And
now
it
seems
to
be
everybody
,

you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
"
thought
Miss
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
---
deed
!
<EOS>
That
's
it
,
is
it
!
"
<EOS>
For
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
had
dined
there
two
or
three
times
,
and
she
had
met
him
elsewhere
,
and
he
had
shown
her

attention
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Rather
cool
in
a
Secretary
---
and
Pa
's
lodger
---
to
make
me
the
subject
of
his

!
"
  
<EOS>
That
Pa
's
daughter
should
be
so
contemptuous
of
Pa
's
lodger
<EOS>
was
odd
;
but
there
were
odder
anomalies
than
that
in
the
mind
of
the
spoilt
girl
:
the
doubly
spoilt
girl
:
spoilt
first
by
poverty
,
and
then
by
wealth
.
<EOS>
Be
it
this
history
's
part
,
however
,
to
leave
them
to
unravel
themselves
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
little
too
much
,
I
think
,
"
Miss
Bella
reflected
scornfully
,
"
to
have
Pa
's
lodger
laying
claim
to
me
,
and
keeping
eligible
people
off
!
<EOS>
A
little
too
much
,
indeed
,
to
have
the
opportunities
opened
to
me
by
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
appropriated
by
a
mere
Secretary
and
Pa
's
lodger
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Yet
it
was
not
so
very
long
ago
that
Bella
had
been
fluttered
by
the
discovery
that
this
same
Secretary
and
lodger
seemed
to
like
her
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
but
the
eminently
aristocratic
mansion
and
Mrs.
Boffin
's
dressmaker
had
not
come
into
play
then
.
  
<EOS>
In
spite
of
his
seemingly
retiring
manners
a
very
intrusive
person
,
this
Secretary
and
lodger
,
in
Miss
Bella
's
opinion
.
<EOS>
Always
a
light
in
his
office
-
room
when
we
came
home
from
the
play
or
Opera
,
and
he
always
at
the
carriage
-
door
to
hand
us
out
.
<EOS>
Always
a
provoking
radiance
too
on
Mrs.
Boffin
's
face
,
and
an
abominably
cheerful
reception
of
him
,
as
if
it
were
possible
seriously
to
approve
what
the
man
had
in
his
mind
!
  
<EOS>
"
You
never
charge
me
,
Miss
Wilfer
,
"
said
the
Secretary
,
encountering
her
by
chance
alone
in
the
great
drawing
-
room
,
"
with
commissions
for
home
.
<EOS>
I
shall
always
be
happy
to
execute
any
commands
you
may
have
in
that
direction
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
what
may
you
mean
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
?
"
inquired
Miss
Bella
,
with
languidly
drooping
eyelids
.
  
<EOS>
"
By
home
?
<EOS>
I
mean
your
father
's
house
at
Holloway
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
coloured
under
the
retort
---
so
skilfully
thrust
,
that
the
words
seemed
to
be
merely
a
plain
answer
,
given
in
plain
good
faith
---
and
said
,
rather
more
emphatically
and
sharply
:
  
"
What
commissions
and
commands
are
you
speaking
of
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Only
such
little
words
of
remembrance
as
I
assume
you
send
somehow
or
other
,
"
replied
the
Secretary
with
his
former
air
.
<EOS>
"
It
would
be
a
pleasure
to
me
if
you
would
make
me
the
bearer
of
them
.
<EOS>
As
you
know
,
I
come
and
go
between
the
two
houses
every
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
remind
me
of
that
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
too
quick
in
this
petulant
sally
against
"
Pa
's
lodger
;
"
 
and
she
felt
that
she
had
been
so
when
she
met
his
quiet
look
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
do
n't
send
many
---
what
was
your
expression
?
<EOS>
---
words
of
remembrance
to
me
,
"
said
Bella
,
making
haste
to
take
refuge
in
illusage
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
frequently
ask
me
about
you
,
and
I
give
them
such
slight
intelligence
as
I
can
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
it
's
truly
given
,
"
exclaimed
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
can
not
doubt
it
,
for
it
would
be
very
much
against
you
,
if
you
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
not
doubt
it
.
<EOS>
I
deserve
the
reproach
,
which
is
very
just
indeed
.
<EOS>
I
beg
your
pardon
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
beg
you
not
to
do
so
,
but
that
it
shows
you
to
such
admirable
advantage
,
"
he
replied
with
earnestness
.
"
<EOS>
Forgive
me
;
I
could
not
help
saying
that
.
<EOS>
To
return
to
what
I
have
digressed
from
,
let
me
add
that
perhaps
they
think
I
report
them
to
you
,
deliver
little
messages
,
and
the
like
.
<EOS>
But
I
forbear
to
trouble
you
,
as
you
never
ask
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
,
sir
,
"
said
Bella
,
looking
at
him
as
if
he
had
reproved
her
"
to
see
them
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
,
"
he
asked
,
hesitating
,
said
to
me
,
or
to
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
which
you
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
both
?
<EOS>
Shall
I
make
it
a
message
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
if
you
like
,
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
Message
or
no
message
<EOS>
,
I
am
going
to
see
them
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
tell
them
so
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
lingered
a
moment
,
as
though
to
give
her
the
opportunity
of
prolonging
the
conversation
if
she
wished
.
<EOS>
As
she
remained
silent
,
he
left
her
.
<EOS>
Two
incidents
of
the
little
interview
were
felt
by
Miss
Bella
herself
,
when
alone
again
,
to
be
very
curious
.
<EOS>
The
first
was
,
that
he
unquestionably
left
her
with
a
penitent
air
upon
her
,
and
a
penitent
feeling
in
her
heart
.
<EOS>
The
second
was
,
that
she
had
not
had
an
intention
or
a
thought
of
going
home
,
until
she
had
announced
it
to
him
as
a
settled
design
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
mean
by
it
,
or
what
can
he
mean
by
it
?
"
was
her
mental
inquiry
:
"
<EOS>
He
has
no
right
to
any
power
over
me
,
and
how
do
I
come
to
mind
him
when
I
do
n't
care
for
him
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
,
insisting
that
Bella
should
make
to
-
morrow
's
expedition
in
the
chariot
<EOS>
,
she
went
home
in
great
grandeur
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
and
Miss
Lavinia
had
speculated
much
on
the
probabilities
and
improbabilities
of
her
coming
in
this
gorgeous
state
,
and
,
on
beholding
the
chariot
from
the
window
at
which
they
were
secreted
to
look
out
for
it
,
agreed
that
it
must
be
detained
at
the
door
as
long
as
possible
,
for
the
mortification
and
confusion
of
the
neighbours
.
<EOS>
Then
they
repaired
to
the
usual
family
room
,
to
receive
Miss
Bella
with
a
becoming
show
of
indifference
.
  
<EOS>
The
family
room
looked
very
small
and
very
mean
,
and
the
downward
staircase
by
which
it
was
attained
looked
very
narrow
and
very
crooked
.
<EOS>
The
little
house
and
all
its
arrangements
were
a
poor
contrast
to
the
eminently
aristocratic
dwelling
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
hardly
believe
,
"
 
thought
Bella
,
"
that
I
ever
did
endure
life
in
this
place
!
"
  
<EOS>
Gloomy
majesty
on
the
part
of
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
and
native
pertness
on
the
part
of
Lavvy
,
did
not
mend
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Bella
really
stood
in
natural
need
of
a
little
help
,
and
she
got
none
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
presenting
a
cheek
to
be
kissed
,
as
sympathetic
and
responsive
as
the
back
of
the
bowl
of
a
spoon
,
"
is
quite
an
honor
!
<EOS>
You
will
probably
find
your
sister
Lavvy
grown
,
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ma
,
"
Miss
Lavinia
interposed
,
"
there
can
be
no
objection
to
your
being
aggravating
,
because
Bella
richly
deserves
it
;
but
I
really
must
request
that
you
will
not
drag
in
such
ridiculous
nonsense
as
my
having
grown
when
I
am
past
the
growing
age
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
grew
,
myself
,
"
Mrs.
Wilfer
sternly
proclaimed
,
"
after
I
was
married
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
well
,
Ma
,
"
returned
Lavvy
,
"
<EOS>
then
I
think
you
had
much
better
have
left
it
alone
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
lofty
glare
with
which
the
majestic
woman
received
this
answer
,
might
have
embarrassed
a
less
pert
opponent
,
but
it
had
no
effect
upon
Lavinia
:
who
,
leaving
her
parent
to
the
enjoyment
of
any
amount
of
glaring
that
she
might
deem
desirable
under
the
circumstances
,
accosted
her
sister
,
undismayed
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
wo
n't
consider
yourself
quite
disgraced
,
<EOS>
Bella
,
if
I
give
you
a
kiss
?
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
And
how
do
you
do
,
Bella
?
<EOS>
And
how
are
your
Boffins
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Peace
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Wilfer
.
"
<EOS>
Hold
!
<EOS>
I
will
not
suffer
this
tone
of
levity
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
goodness
me
!
<EOS>
How
are
your
Spoffins
,
then
?
"
said
Lavvy
,
"
since
Ma
so
very
much
objects
to
your
Boffins
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Impertinent
girl
!
<EOS>
Minx
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
with
dread
severity
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
whether
I
am
a
Minx
,
or
a
Sphinx
,
"
returned
Lavinia
,
coolly
,
tossing
her
head
;
"
it
's
exactly
the
same
thing
to
me
,
and
I
'd
every
bit
as
soon
be
one
as
the
other
;
but
I
know
this
---
  
<EOS>
I
'll
not
grow
after
I
am
married
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
?
<EOS>
You
will
not
?
"
repeated
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
solemnly
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Ma
,
I
will
not
.
<EOS>
Nothing
shall
induce
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
having
waved
her
gloves
,
became
loftily
pathetic
.
"
<EOS>
But
it
was
to
be
expected
;
"
thus
she
spake
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
child
of
mine
deserts
me
for
the
proud
and
prosperous
,
and
another
child
of
mine
despises
me
.
<EOS>
It
is
quite
fitting
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ma
,
"
Bella
struck
in
,
"
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
are
prosperous
,
no
doubt
;
but
you
have
no
right
to
say
they
are
proud
.
<EOS>
You
must
know
very
well
that
they
are
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
short
,
Ma
,
"
said
Lavvy
,
bouncing
over
to
the
enemy
without
a
word
of
notice
,
"
you
must
know
very
well
---
or
if
you
do
n't
,
more
shame
for
you
!
---
that
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
are
just
absolute
perfection
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
courteously
receiving
the
deserter
,
"
it
would
seem
that
we
are
required
to
think
so
.
<EOS>
And
this
,
Lavinia
,
is
my
reason
for
objecting
to
a
tone
of
levity
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
(
of
whose
physiognomy
I
can
never
speak
with
the
composure
I
would
desire
to
preserve
)
,
and
your
mother
,
are
not
on
terms
of
intimacy
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
for
a
moment
to
be
supposed
that
she
and
her
husband
dare
to
presume
to
speak
of
this
family
as
the
Wilfers
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
therefore
condescend
to
speak
of
them
as
the
Boffins
.
<EOS>
No
;
 
for
such
a
tone
---
call
it
familiarity
,
levity
,
equality
,
or
what
<EOS>
you
will
 
---
would
imply
those
social
interchanges
which
do
not
exist
.
<EOS>
Do
I
render
myself
intelligible
?
"
  
<EOS>
Without
taking
the
least
notice
of
this
inquiry
,
albeit
delivered
in
an
imposing
and
forensic
manner
,
Lavinia
reminded
her
sister
,
"
After
all
,
you
know
,
Bella
,
you
have
n't
told
us
how
your
Whatshisnames
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
speak
of
them
here
,
"
replied
Bella
,
suppressing
indignation
,
and
tapping
her
foot
on
the
floor
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
much
too
kind
and
too
good
to
be
drawn
into
these
discussions
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
put
it
so
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
with
biting
sarcasm
.
<EOS>
"
Why
adopt
a
circuitous
form
of
speech
?
<EOS>
It
is
polite
and
it
is
obliging
;
but
why
do
it
?
<EOS>
Why
not
openly
say
that
they
are
much
too
kind
and
too
good
for
us
?
<EOS>
We
understand
the
allusion
.
<EOS>
Why
disguise
the
phrase
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ma
,
"
said
Bella
,
with
one
beat
of
her
foot
,
"
you
are
enough
to
drive
a
saint
mad
,
and
so
is
Lavvy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Unfortunate
Lavvy
!
"
cried
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
in
a
tone
of
commiseration
.
<EOS>
"
She
always
comes
in
for
it
.
<EOS>
My
poor
child
!
"
<EOS>
But
Lavvy
,
with
the
suddenness
of
her
former
desertion
,
now
bounced
over
to
the
other
enemy
:
very
sharply
remarking
,
"
Do
n't
patronise
me
,
Ma
,
because
I
can
take
care
of
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
only
wonder
,
"
resumed
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
directing
her
observations
to
her
elder
daughter
,
as
safer
on
the
whole
than
her
utterly
unmanageable
younger
,
"
that
you
found
time
and
inclination
to
tear
yourself
from
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
and
come
to
see
us
at
all
.
<EOS>
I
only
wonder
that
our
claims
,
contending
against
the
superior
claims
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
had
any
weight
.
<EOS>
I
feel
I
ought
to
be
thankful
for
gaining
so
much
,
in
competition
with
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
.
"
<EOS>
(
The
good
lady
bitterly
emphasized
the
first
letter
of
the
word
Boffin
,
as
if
it
represented
her
chief
objection
to
the
owners
of
that
name
,
and
as
if
she
could
have
borne
Doffin
,
Moffin
,
or
Poffin
much
better
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
Ma
,
"
said
Bella
,
angrily
,
<EOS>
"
you
force
me
to
say
that
I
am
truly
sorry
I
did
come
home
,
and
that
I
never
will
come
home
again
,
except
when
poor
dear
Pa
is
here
.
<EOS>
For
,
Pa
is
too
magnanimous
to
feel
envy
and
spite
towards
my
generous
friends
,
and
Pa
is
delicate
enough
and
gentle
enough
to
remember
the
sort
of
little
claim
they
thought
I
had
upon
them
and
the
unusually
trying
position
in
which
,
through
no
act
of
my
own
,
I
had
been
placed
.
<EOS>
And
I
always
did
love
poor
dear
Pa
better
than
all
the
rest
of
you
put
together
,
and
I
always
do
<EOS>
and
I
always
shall
!
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Bella
,
deriving
no
comfort
from
her
charming
bonnet
and
her
elegant
dress
,
burst
into
tears
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
R.
W.
,
"
cried
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
lifting
up
her
eyes
and
apostrophising
the
air
,
"
that
if
you
were
present
,
it
would
be
a
trial
to
your
feelings
to
hear
your
wife
and
the
mother
of
your
family
depreciated
in
your
name
.
<EOS>
But
Fate
has
spared
you
this
,
R.
W.
,
whatever
it
may
have
thought
proper
to
inflict
upon
her
!
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Mrs.
Wilfer
burst
into
tears
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hate
the
Boffins
!
"
protested
Miss
Lavinia
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
who
objects
to
their
being
called
the
Boffins
.
<EOS>
I
   
WILL
call
'em
the
Boffins
.
<EOS>
The
Boffins
,
the
Boffins
,
the
Boffins
!
<EOS>
And
I
say
they
are
mischief
-
making
Boffins
,
and
<EOS>
I
say
the
Boffins
have
set
Bella
against
me
,
and
I
tell
the
Boffins
to
their
faces
:
"
which
was
not
strictly
the
fact
,
but
the
young
lady
was
excited
:
"
that
they
are
detestable
Boffins
,
disreputable
Boffins
,
odious
Boffins
,
beastly
Boffins
.
<EOS>
There
!
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Miss
Lavinia
burst
into
tears
.
  
<EOS>
The
front
garden
-
gate
clanked
,
and
the
Secretary
was
seen
coming
at
a
brisk
pace
up
the
steps
.
"
<EOS>
Leave
Me
to
open
the
door
to
him
,
"
 
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
rising
with
stately
resignation
as
she
shook
her
head
and
dried
her
eyes
;
"
we
have
at
present
no
stipendiary
girl
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
We
have
nothing
to
conceal
.
<EOS>
If
he
sees
these
traces
of
emotion
on
our
cheeks
,
let
him
construe
them
as
he
may
.
<EOS>
"
  
With
those
words
she
stalked
out
.
<EOS>
In
a
few
moments
she
stalked
in
again
,
proclaiming
in
her
heraldic
manner
,
"
Mr.
Rokesmith
is
the
bearer
of
a
packet
for
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
followed
close
upon
his
name
,
and
of
course
saw
what
was
amiss
.
<EOS>
But
he
discreetly
affected
to
see
nothing
,
and
addressed
Miss
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Boffin
intended
to
have
placed
this
in
the
carriage
for
you
this
morning
.
<EOS>
He
wished
you
to
have
it
,
as
a
little
keepsake
he
had
prepared
---
it
is
only
a
purse
,
Miss
Wilfer
---
but
as
he
was
disappointed
in
his
fancy
,
I
volunteered
to
come
after
you
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
took
it
in
her
hand
,
and
thanked
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
been
quarrelling
here
a
little
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
but
not
more
than
we
used
;
you
know
our
agreeable
ways
among
ourselves
.
<EOS>
You
find
me
just
going
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
mamma
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
,
Lavvy
!
"
<EOS>
And
with
a
kiss
for
each
Miss
Bella
turned
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
The
Secretary
would
have
attended
her
,
but
Mrs.
Wilfer
advancing
and
saying
with
dignity
,
"
Pardon
me
!
<EOS>
Permit
me
to
assert
my
natural
right
to
escort
my
child
to
the
equipage
which
is
in
waiting
for
her
,
"
he
begged
pardon
and
gave
place
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
very
magnificent
spectacle
indeed
,
to
see
Mrs.
Wilfer
throw
open
the
house
---
door
,
and
loudly
demand
with
extended
gloves
,
"
The
male
domestic
of
Mrs.
Boffin
!
"
 
<EOS>
To
whom
presenting
himself
,
she
delivered
the
brief
but
majestic
charge
,
"
Miss
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
Coming
out
!
"
<EOS>
and
so
delivered
her
over
,
like
a
female
Lieutenant
of
the
Tower
relinquishing
a
State
Prisoner
.
<EOS>
The
effect
of
this
ceremonial
was
for
some
quarter
of
an
hour
afterwards
perfectly
paralysing
on
the
neighbours
,
and
was
much
enhanced
by
the
worthy
lady
airing
herself
for
that
term
in
a
kind
of
splendidly
serene
trance
on
the
top
step
.
  
<EOS>
When
Bella
was
seated
in
the
carriage
,
she
opened
the
little
packet
in
her
hand
.
<EOS>
It
contained
a
pretty
purse
,
and
the
purse
contained
a
bank
note
for
fifty
pounds
.
<EOS>
"
This
shall
be
a
joyful
surprise
for
poor
dear
Pa
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
and
I
'll
take
it
myself
into
the
City
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
was
uninformed
respecting
the
exact
locality
of
the
place
of
business
of
Chicksey
Veneering
and
Stobbles
,
but
knew
it
to
be
near
Mincing
Lane
,
she
directed
herself
to
be
driven
to
the
corner
of
that
darksome
spot
.
<EOS>
Thence
she
despatched
"
the
male
domestic
of
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
in
search
of
the
counting
-
house
of
Chicksey
Veneering
and
Stobbles
,
with
a
message
importing
that
if
R.
Wilfer
could
come
out
,
there
was
a
lady
waiting
who
would

to
speak
with

.
<EOS>
The
delivery
of
these
mysterious
words
from
the
mouth
of
a
footman
caused
so
great
an
excitement
in
the
counting
-
house
,
that
a
youthful
scout
was
instantly
appointed
to
follow
Rumty
,
observe
the
lady
,
and
come
in
with
his
report
.
<EOS>
Nor
was
the
agitation
by
any
means
diminished
,
when
the
scout
rushed
back
with
the
intelligence
that
the
lady
was
"
a
slap
-
up
gal
in
a
bang
-
up
chariot
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Rumty
himself
,
with
his
pen
behind
his
ear
under
his
rusty
hat
,
arrived
at
the
carriage
-
door
in
a

,
and
had
been
fairly

into
the
vehicle
by

and
embraced
almost
unto
choking
,
before
he
recognised
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
child
!
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
he
then
panted
,
incoherently
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Good
gracious
me
!
<EOS>
What
a
lovely
woman
you
are
!
<EOS>
I
thought
you
had
been
unkind
and
forgotten
your
mother
and
sister
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
just
been
to
see
them
,
<EOS>
Pa
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
and
how
---
how
did
you
find
your
mother
?
"
asked
R.
W.
,
dubiously
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
disagreeable
,
Pa
,
and
so
was
Lavvy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
sometimes
a
little
liable
to
it
,
"
observed
the
patient
cherub
;
"
but
I
hope
you
made
allowances
,
Bella
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
was
disagreeable
too
,
Pa
;
we
were
all
of
us
disagreeable
together
.
<EOS>
But
I
want
you
to
come
and
dine

,
<EOS>
Pa.
"
  
"
Why
,

dear
,
I
have

partaken

---

mention

---

---
Saveloy
,
"
replied

Wilfer
,
modestly

on

,
as

eyed
the
canary
-

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
That
's
nothing
,
Pa
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly
,
it
ai
n't
as
much
as
one
could
sometimes
wish

to
be
,
my
dear
,
"
he

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Still
when
,
circumstances

which

have

,
interpose

between

Small
Germans
,
you
ca
n't

to

on
"
---
again

in

---
"
Saveloys
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
poor
good
Pa
!
<EOS>
Pa
,
do
,
I
beg
and
pray
,
get
leave
for
the
rest

,

come

pass

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
dear
,
I
'll
cut
back
and
ask

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
before
you
cut
back
,
"
said
Bella
,
who
had
already
taken
him
by

chin
,
pulled
his

off
,
and
begun
to
stick
up

hair
in
her
old
way
,
"
do
say
that
you
are
sure
I
am
giddy
and
inconsiderate
,
but
have
never
really
slighted

,
<EOS>
Pa.
"
  
"
My
dear
,
I
say

with
all

heart
.
<EOS>
And
might
I
likewise
observe
,
"
her
father
delicately

,
with

out
at
window
,
"
that
perhaps

might

calculated

,
having
one
's
hair
publicly
done
by
a
lovely
woman
in
an
elegant
turn
-
out
in
Fenchurch
Street
?
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
laughed
and
put
on
his
hat
again
.
<EOS>
But
when
his
boyish
figure
bobbed
away
,
its
shabbiness
and
cheerful
patience
smote
the
tears
out
of
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
I
hate
that
Secretary
for
thinking
it
of
me
,
"
 
she
said
to
herself
,
"
and
yet
it
seems
half
true
!
"
  
<EOS>
Back
came
her
father
,
more
like
a
boy
than
ever
,
in
his
release
from
school
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
right
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
Leave
given
at
once
.
<EOS>
Really
very
handsomely
done
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
where
can
we
find
some
quiet
place
,
Pa
,
in
which
I
can
wait
for
you
while
you
go
on
an
errand
for
me
,
if
I
send
the
carriage
away
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
demanded
cogitation
.
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
my
dear
,
"
he
explained
,
"
you
really
have
become
such
a
very
lovely
woman
,
that
it
ought
to
be
a
very
quiet
place
.
<EOS>
"
At
length
he
suggested
,
"
Near
the
garden
up
by
the
Trinity
House
on
Tower
Hill
.
"
<EOS>
So
,
they
were
driven
there
,
and
Bella
dismissed
the
chariot
;
sending
a
pencilled
note
by
it
to
Mrs.
Boffin
,
that
she
was
with
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Pa
,
attend
to
what
I
am
going
to
say
,
and
promise
and
vow
to
be
obedient
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
promise
and
vow
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
ask
no
questions
.
<EOS>
You
take
this
purse
;
you
go
to
the
nearest
place
where
they
keep
everything
of
the
very
very
best
,
ready
made
;
you
buy
and
put
on
,
the
most
beautiful
suit
of
clothes
,
the
most
beautiful
hat
,
and
the
most
beautiful
pair
of
bright
boots
(
patent
leather
,
Pa
,
mind
!
)
<EOS>
that
are
to
be
got
for
money
;
and
you
come
back
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
my
dear
Bella
---
"
  
"
Take
care
,
Pa
!
"
pointing
her
forefinger
at
him
,
merrily
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
promised
and
vowed
.
<EOS>
It
's
perjury
,
you
know
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
water
in
the
foolish
little
fellow
's
eyes
,
but
she
kissed
them
dry
(
though
her
own
were
wet
)
,
and
he
bobbed
away
again
.
<EOS>
After
half
an
hour
,
he
came
back
,
so
brilliantly
transformed
,
that
Bella
was
obliged
to
walk
round
him
in
ecstatic
admiration
twenty
times
,
before
she
could
draw
her
arm
through
his
,
and
delightedly
squeeze
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Pa
,
"
said
Bella
,
hugging
him
close
,
"
take
this
lovely
woman
out
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
shall
we
go
,
my
dear
?
"
  
"
Greenwich
!
"
said
Bella
,
valiantly
.
"
<EOS>
And
be
sure
you
treat
this
lovely
woman
with
everything
of
the
best
.
"
  
<EOS>
While
they
were
going
along
to
take
boat
,
"
Do
n't
you
wish
,
my
dear
,
"
said
R.
W.
,
timidly
,
"
that
your
mother
was
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
,
Pa
,
for
I
like
to
have
you
all
to
myself
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
I
was
always
your
little
favourite
at
home
,
and
you
were
always
mine
.
<EOS>
We
have
run
away
together
often
,
before
now
;
have
n't
we
,
Pa
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
to
be
sure
we
have
!
<EOS>
Many
a
Sunday
when
your
mother
was
 
---
was
a
little
liable
to
it
,
"
repeating
his
former
delicate
expression
after
pausing
to
cough
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
I
am
afraid
I
was
seldom
or
never
as
good
as
I
ought
to
have
been
,
<EOS>
Pa.
I
made
you
carry
me
,
over
and
over
again
,
when
you
should
have
made
me
walk
;
and
I
often
drove
you
in
harness
,
when
you
would
much
rather
have
sat
down
and
read
your
newspaper
:
<EOS>
did

I
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sometimes
,
sometimes
.
<EOS>
But
Lor
,
what
a
child
you
were
!
<EOS>
What
a
companion
you
were
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Companion
?
<EOS>
That
's
just
what
I
want
to
be
to
-
day
,
Pa.
"
  
"
You
are
safe
to
succeed
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
Your
brothers
and
sisters
have
all
in
their
turns
been
companions
to
me
,
to
a
certain
extent
,
but
only
to
a
certain
extent
.
<EOS>
Your
mother
has
,
throughout
life
,
been
a
companion
that
any
man
might
---
might
look
up
to
---
and
---

becoming
Awful
---
"
her

when

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pa

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

<EOS>

,
after

!
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Now

<EOS>

<EOS>

that

.
"
  
<EOS>

.

!
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
before

<EOS>
IN

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
The

,

,

.
<EOS>

"

Mr.

<EOS>

<EOS>
And

"

,

"

,

"

"
No

,

"
  
<EOS>
Sloppy
knew
his
ground
well
.
<EOS>
To
conceal

in
sickness
,
like
a
lower

;
to

sight
and

away

;
had

this
woman
's

.
<EOS>
To
catch
up

her

the
sick
child
who
was
dear
to
her
,
and
hide

as

,
and
keep
off
all

but
such

her

and

,
had
become
this
woman
's
idea
of
maternal

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
The
shameful
accounts
we
read
,
every
week
in
the
Christian
year
,
my
lords
and
gentlemen
and

boards
,
the
infamous
records
of
small
official

,
do
not
pass
by
the
people
as
they
pass
by

.
<EOS>
And
hence

,

,

,
so

to
our

,
and

<EOS>
---
God

Queen

Con
-
found
their

---
<EOS>
no
,
than
smoke
has
in

!
  
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Tell

,

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
had

,
and

.
<EOS>
He
could

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
Pray

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
Therefore
a

was
ordered
,
of
capacity
to
take
them
all
,
and
in

Sloppy
was
regaled
,
feasting
alone
in
the
Secretary
's

,
with
a
complete
realization
of
that
fairy
vision
---
meat
,

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
In

which
his
buttons
became
more
importunate
of
public
notice
than
before
,
with

two
or
three
about

region
of
the

,
which
modestly

.
  
<EOS>
Punctual
to
the
time
,
appeared
the

and
the
Secretary
.
<EOS>
He
sat
on
the
box
,
and
Mr.
Sloppy
graced

rumble
.
<EOS>
So
,
to
the
Three
Magpies
as
before
:
where
Mrs.
Boffin
and
Miss
Bella
were
handed
out
,
and
whence
they
all
went
on
foot
to
Mrs.
Betty
Higden
's
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
on
the
way
down
,
they
had
stopped
at
a
toy
-
shop
,
and
had
bought
that
noble

,
a
description
of
whose
points
and

<EOS>
had
on

conciliated

then

orphan
,
and
also
a
Noah
's
ark
,
and
also
a
yellow
bird
with
an
artificial
voice
in
him
,
and
also
a
military
doll
so
well
dressed
that
if
he
had
only
been
of
life
-
size
<EOS>
his
brother
-
officers
in
the
Guards
might
never
have
found

out
.
<EOS>
Bearing
these
gifts
,
they
raised
the
latch
of
Betty
Higden
's
door
,
and
saw
her
sitting
in
the
dimmest
and

corner
with
poor
Johnny
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
how
's
my
boy
,
Betty
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Mrs.
Boffin
,
sitting
down

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
bad
!
<EOS>
He
's
bad
!
"
said
Betty
.
<EOS>
"
I
begin
to
be
afeerd
<EOS>
he
'll
not
be
yours
any

than
mine
.
<EOS>
All

him
have
gone
to
the

the

,
and
I
have
a

that
they
're
drawing

to

---
leading
him
away
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
said

Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

why
else
he
clenches

as

that
I
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
Look

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
always
so
.
<EOS>
It
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

asleep
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
think

.
<EOS>
You
're
not

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Johnny
,
with

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
's
the
lady
,
Johnny
.
<EOS>
And

horse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Johnny
could
bear
the
lady
,
with
complete

,
but
not
the
horse
.
<EOS>
Opening

heavy

,
he
slowly

on
beholding
that

,
and
wanted

in

.
<EOS>
As

was
much

,

.
<EOS>
Which

.
  
<EOS>
But
,
Johnny
murmuring
something
with
his

<EOS>
closed
,
and
Mrs.
Boffin
not

what
,
old
Betty
bent

to

and
took

to

.
<EOS>
Being

by

to

,

,

seen

,

,
"
Who

?
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,

lady

;
and

,
and
their
joke
about

woman
.
<EOS>
So
,

's

very

what

young

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
my
good

,
"

,

,

"

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Instantly
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Stand

every

!
"
<EOS>
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
see
what
ye
mean

.
<EOS>
Let

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
,
stay
!
"
<EOS>
said
Rokesmith
,

.
<EOS>
"
You
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
understand

.
<EOS>
I
know

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
Never
for

,

,
while

!
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
Yet

"
crops

"

,

<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

,
afore
<EOS>
I

!
"
  
<EOS>
But

"
Maybe

has

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

!
<EOS>
I
'm

,
I

,
and

summ'at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,

,

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
Come
,

!
<EOS>
Say

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Any

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

!
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
Betty
,
"

sweet

,

,
"
what
I
really
did

,
and
what
I

,

.
<EOS>
We

;

;

good

pass

with
children

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This

gained
,

,

.
<EOS>
He

;

;

;

,

;

.
<EOS>
Sloppy

,

.
  
<EOS>
At

's

,

,

's

,

,

<EOS>
But

"
This

.
<EOS>
Too

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
However
,

,

,

to

,

's

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
And

's

was

,

another
Johnny

surely
who

.
<EOS>
And
,

,
to

:

had

,
all

(

)
:
<EOS>
and

<EOS>
whereon

to

dolls
'

,
<EOS>
woolly

in

the

,
tin

,

,

,

earth
.
  
<EOS>
As
Johnny
murmured
something
in
his
placid

,
the
ministering
women
at
his
bed
's
head
asked
him
what
he
said
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
that
he
wanted
to
know
whether
all
these
were
brothers

of
his
?
<EOS>
So
they
told

yes
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
then
,
that
he
wanted
to
know
whether
God
had
brought

all
together
there
?
<EOS>
So

told

yes
again
.
<EOS>
They
made
out

,
that
he
wanted
to
know
whether
they
would
all
get
out

pain
?
<EOS>
So
they
answered
yes
to
that
question
likewise
,
and
made
him
understand
that
the
reply
included
himself
.
  
<EOS>
Johnny
's
powers
of
sustaining

were
as
yet
so
very

developed
,
even
in
a

health
,
that

were
little

.
<EOS>
But
,
he
had
to

washed

,
and

applied
,
and
though

were
far
,
far

than

,
so

,

would

which
laid

.
<EOS>
This
was
no
less
than

,
of
All
Creation
,

:
the

,
and

fly
,
with
a
diffident

of
his
size
,
politely

.
<EOS>
A

lying

,

by

that

;
and
so

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
see

,
Betty
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
Most

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
they

,

,
and
old
Betty
was
to
come
back
early

,
and
nobody
but

knew

certain

that

doctor

,
"
This

.
<EOS>
Too
late
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
Rokesmith
knowing

,
and

his

in

would

acceptable

that
good

in
the
childhood
of
desolate
John
Harmon
dead

,
resolved
that
late

he
would

back
to
the
bedside
of
John
Harmon
's

,

see
how
it
fared

him
.
  
<EOS>
The
family
whom
God
had
brought
together
were
not
all

,
but
were
all
quiet
.
<EOS>
From
bed
to
bed
,
a
light
womanly
tread
and
a
pleasant
fresh
face
passed
in
the

of

night
.
<EOS>
A
little
head
would
lift
itself
up
into
the
softened
light
here
and
there
,
to
be
kissed
as
the
face
went
by
---
for
these
little
patients
are
very
loving
---
and
would
then
submit
itself
to
be
composed

rest
again
.
<EOS>
The
mite
with
the
broken
leg
was
restless
,
and
moaned
;
but
after

turned
his
face
towards
Johnny
's
bed
,
to

with

,

.
<EOS>
Over
most

the
beds
,

were
yet

as

children
had
left

when

last
laid

down
,
and
,
in

and

,
they
might
have
stood
for
the
children
's

.
  
<EOS>
The
doctor
came
in
too
,
to
see
how
it
fared
with
Johnny
.
<EOS>
And
he
and
Rokesmith
stood
together
,
looking
down
with
compassion
on
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
it
,
Johnny
?
<EOS>
"
Rokesmith
was
the
questioner
,
and
put
an
arm
round
the
poor
baby
as
he
made
a
struggle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Him
!
"
said
the
little
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
Those
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
doctor
was
quick
to
understand
children
,
and
,
taking
the
horse
,
the
ark
,
the
yellow
bird
,
and
the
man
in
the
Guards
,
from
Johnny
's
bed
,
softly
placed
them
on
that
of
his
next
neighbour
,
the
mite
with
the
broken
leg
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
weary
and
yet
a
pleased
smile
,
and
with
an
action
as
if
he
stretched
his
little
figure
out
to
rest
,
the
child
heaved
his
body
on
the
sustaining
arm
,
and
seeking
Rokesmith
's
face
with
his
lips
,
said
:
  
"
<EOS>
A
kiss
for
the
boofer
lady
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Having
now
bequeathed
all
he
had
to
dispose
of
,
and
arranged
his
affairs
in
this
world
,
Johnny
,
thus
speaking
,
left
it
.
   
<EOS>
A
SUCCESSOR
.
 
<EOS>
Some
of
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
's
brethren
had
found
themselves
exceedingly
uncomfortable
in
their
minds
,
because
they
were
required
to
bury
the
dead
too
hopefully
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
Reverend
Frank
,
inclining
to
the
belief
that
they
were
required
to
do
one
or
two
other
things
(
say
out
of
nine
-
and
-
thirty
)
calculated
to
trouble
their
consciences
rather
more
if
they
would
think
as
much
about
them
,
<EOS>
held
his
peace
.
  
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
was
a
forbearing
man
,
who
noticed
many
sad
warps
and
blights
in
the
vineyard
wherein
he
worked
,
and
did
not
profess
that
they
made
him
savagely
wise
.
<EOS>
He
only
learned
that
the
more
he
himself
knew
,
<EOS>
in
his
little
limited
human
way
,
the
better
he
could
distantly
imagine
what
Omniscience
might
know
.
  
<EOS>
Wherefore
,
if
the
Reverend
Frank
had
had
to
read
the
words
that
troubled
some
of
his
brethren
,
and
profitably
touched
innumerable
hearts
,
in
a
worse
case
than
Johnny
's
,
he
would
have
done
so
out
of
the
pity
and
humility
of
his
soul
.
<EOS>
Reading
them
over
Johnny
,
he
thought
of
his
own
six
children
,
but
not
of
his
poverty
,
and
read
them
with
dimmed
eyes
.
<EOS>
And
very
seriously
did
he
and
his
bright
little
wife
,
who
had
been
listening
,
look
down
into
the
small
grave
and
walk
home
arm
-
in
-
arm
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
grief
in
the
aristocratic
house
,
and
there
was
joy
in
the
Bower
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
argued
,
if
an
orphan
were
wanted
,
was
he
not
an
orphan
himself
,
and
could
a
better
be
desired
?
<EOS>
And
why
go
beating
about
Brentford
bushes
,
seeking
orphans
forsooth
who
had
established
no
claims
upon
you
and
made
no
sacrifices
for
you
,
when
here
was
an
orphan
ready
to
your
hand
who
had
given
up
in
your
cause
,
Miss
Elizabeth
,
Master
George
,
Aunt
Jane
,
and
Uncle
Parker
?
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
chuckled
,
consequently
,
when
he
heard
the
tidings
.
<EOS>
Nay
,
it
was
afterwards
affirmed
by
a
witness
who
shall
at
present
be
nameless
,
that
in
the
seclusion
of
the
Bower
he
poked
out
his
wooden
leg
,
in
the
stage
-
ballet
manner
,
and
executed
a
taunting
or
triumphant
pirouette
on
the
genuine
leg
remaining
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
John
Rokesmith
's
manner
towards
Mrs.
Boffin
at
this
time
,
was
more
the
manner
of
a
young
man
towards
a
mother
,
than
that
of
a
Secretary
towards
his
employer
's
wife
.
<EOS>
It
had
always
been
marked
by
a
subdued
affectionate
deference
that
seemed
to
have
sprung
up
on
the
very
day
of
his
engagement
;
whatever
was
odd
in
her
dress
or
her
ways
had
seemed
to
have
no
oddity
for
him
;
he
had
sometimes
borne
a
quietly
-
amused
face
in
her
company
,
but
still
it
had
seemed
as
if
the
pleasure
her
genial
temper
and
radiant
nature
yielded
him
,
could
have
been
quite
as
naturally
expressed
in
a
tear
as
in
a
smile
.
<EOS>
The
completeness
of
his
sympathy
with
her
fancy
for
having
a
little
John
Harmon
to
protect
and
rear
,
he
had
shown
in
every
act
and
word
,
and
now
that
the
kind
fancy
was
disappointed
,
he
treated
it
with
a
manly
tenderness
and
respect
for
which
she
could
hardly
thank
him
enough
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
thank
you
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
and
I
thank
you
most
kindly
.
<EOS>
You
love
children
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
everybody
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
ought
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
;
"
but
we
do
n't
all
of
us
do
what
we
ought
;
do
us
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
John
Rokesmith
replied
,
"
Some
among
us
supply
the
shortcomings
of
the
rest
.
<EOS>
You
have
loved
children
well
,
Mr.
Boffin
has
told
me
.
"
  
"
Not
a
bit
better
than
he
has
,
but
that
's
his
way
;
he
puts
all
the
good
upon
me
.
<EOS>
You
speak
rather
sadly
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
sounds
to
me
so
.
<EOS>
Were
you
one
of
many
children
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
An
only
child
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
there
was
another
.
<EOS>
Dead
long

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Father
or
mother
alive
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dead
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
the
rest
of
your
relations
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dead
---
if
I
ever
had
any
living
.
<EOS>
I
never
heard
of
any
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
point
of
the
dialogue
Bella
came
in
with
a
light
step
.
<EOS>
She
paused
at
the
door
a
moment
,
hesitating
whether
to
remain
or
retire
;
 
perplexed
by
finding
that
she
was
not
observed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do
n't
mind
an
old
lady
's
talk
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
but
tell
me
.
<EOS>
Are
you
quite
sure
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
that
you
have
never
had
a
disappointment
in
love
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
sure
.
<EOS>
Why
do
you
ask
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
for
this
reason
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
you
have
a
kind
of
kept
-
down
manner
with
you
,
which
is
not
like

age
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
be
thirty
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
yet
thirty
.
"
  
<EOS>
Deeming
it
high
time
to
make
her
presence
known
,
Bella
coughed
here
to
attract
attention
,
begged
pardon
,
and
said
she
would
go
,
fearing
that
she
interrupted
some
matter
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
do
n't
go
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
because
we
are
coming
to
business
,
instead
of
having

it
,
and
you
belong
to
it
as
much
now
,
my
dear
Bella
,

I

.
<EOS>
But
I
want
my
Noddy
to
consult
with
us
.
<EOS>
Would
somebody
be
so
good
as
find
my
Noddy
for
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
Rokesmith
departed
on
that
errand
,
and
presently
returned
accompanied
by
Mr.
Boffin
at
his
jog
-
trot
.
<EOS>
Bella
felt
a
little
vague
trepidation
as
to
the
subject
-
matter
of
this
same
consultation
,
until
Mrs.
Boffin
announced
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
come
and
sit
by
me
,
my
dear
,
"
said
that
worthy
soul
,
taking
her
comfortable

on
a
large
ottoman
in
the

the
room
,
and
drawing
her

through
Bella
's
;
"
and
Noddy
,
you
sit

,
and
Mr.
Rokesmith
you

.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
see
,
what
I
want

talk
about
,
is
this
.
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Milvey
have
sent

the
kindest
note

(
which
Mr.
Rokesmith
just
now

,
for
I
ai
n't
good
at
handwritings
)
,
offering
to
find

another

child
to
name

and
bring

.
<EOS>
Well
.
<EOS>
This
has
set
me
thinking
.
<EOS>
"
  
(
"
And
she
is
a
steam
-
ingein
at

,
"
murmured

Boffin
,
in

,
"
when

.
<EOS>
It
may

so

;
but

,
she
's
a
ingein
.
"
<EOS>
)
  
<EOS>
"
---
This
has

me

,
I

,
"
repeated

Boffin
,
cordially

under

's

,
"
and
I
have
thought
two

.
<EOS>
First

all
,
that
I
have
grown
timid
of
reviving
John
Harmon
's
name
.
<EOS>
It
's
an
unfortunate
name
,
and
I
fancy
<EOS>
I
should
reproach
myself
if
I
gave
it
to
another
dear
child
,
and
it
proved
again
unlucky
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,
whether
,
"
said

Boffin
,

for
his
Secretary
's

;
"
whether

might

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a

of

Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
said
Rokesmith
,
gently
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
name
has
always

unfortunate
.
<EOS>
It
has
now
this
new
unfortunate

connected
with

.
<EOS>
The
name
has
died
out
.
<EOS>
Why
revive

?
<EOS>
Might

Miss
Wilfer
what
she

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
has
not
been
a
fortunate
name
for
me
,
"
said
Bella
,
colouring
---
  
"
or
at
least
it
was
not
,
until
it
led
to
my
being
here
---
<EOS>
but
that
is
not
the
point
in
my

.
<EOS>
As
we
had
given
the
name
to
the
poor
child
and
as
the

child
took
so

to

,
I
think

should

jealous

another
child

.
<EOS>
I

name

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

's

?
<EOS>
"

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
Miss
Wilfer
's
feeling
very
womanly

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

,
"
returned

,
"
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
we
agree
not
to
revive
John
Harmon
's

,

to

rest

.
<EOS>
It
is
,
as
Mr.
Rokesmith
says
,
a
matter
of

,
but
Lor
how
many
matters
are
matters
of
feeling
!
<EOS>
Well
;
and
so
I
come
to
the
second
thing
I
have

.
<EOS>
You
must
know
,
Bella
,
my

,
and
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
that

boy
in

of
John
Harmon
,
I

that
how
the
poor
boy
would
be
benefited
by
John
's
own
money
,
and

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
,

!
"
cried

Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
So
she
did
.
<EOS>
Ancoar
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
Ancoar
,
Noddy
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
because
I
am
going
to

something
else
.
<EOS>
I
meant
that
,
I
am
sure
,
as
much
as
I

mean

.
<EOS>
But
this
little
death
has
made
me
ask
myself
the
question
,
seriously
,
whether
I
was
n't
too
bent
upon
pleasing
myself
.
<EOS>
Else
why
did
I
seek
out
so
much
for
a
pretty
child
,
and
a
child
quite
to
my
liking
?
<EOS>
Wanting
to
do
good
,
why
not
do
it
for
its
own
sake
,
and
put
my
tastes
and
likings
by
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
said
Bella
;
and

hers

;
"

,

,

less

.
<EOS>
He

you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"
returned

,

,
"
<EOS>
it
's

you
to
find

,

may
have

,
and
indeed

a

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
However
,
that
do
n't
come
in

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Laid

as

,
"
suggested
Bella
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Much
better
said
,
my
dear
;
laid
it
up
as
a
remembrance
.
<EOS>
Well
then
;
I
have
been
thinking
<EOS>
if
I
take

orphan
to

for
,
let
it
not

pet
and

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned

Boffin
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor

then
?
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
necessarily
so
.
<EOS>
That
's
as
it
may
happen
.
<EOS>
A
well
-
disposed
boy
comes
in
my
way
who
may
be
even
a
little
wanting
in
such
advantages
for
getting
on
in
life
,
but
is
honest
and

and
requires

and
deserves

.
<EOS>
If
I
am
very
much
in
earnest
and
quite
determined
to
be
unselfish
,
let
me
take
care
of
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Here
the
footman
whose
feelings
had
been

on
the
former

,
appeared
,
and
crossing
to
Rokesmith
apologetically
announced
the
objectionable
Sloppy
.
  
<EOS>
The
four
members
of
Council
looked

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Shall

be

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
footman
disappeared
,
reappeared
presenting
Sloppy
,
and
retired
much
disgusted
.
  
<EOS>
The
consideration
of
Mrs.
Boffin
had
clothed
Mr.
Sloppy
in
a
suit
of
black
,
on
which
the
tailor
had
received
personal
directions
from
Rokesmith
to
expend
the
utmost
cunning
of
his
art
,
with
a
view
to
the
concealment
of
the
cohering
and
sustaining
buttons
.
<EOS>
But
,
so
much
more
powerful
were
the

of
Sloppy
's
form
than
the
strongest
resources
of
tailoring
science
,
that
he
now
stood
before
the
Council
,
a
perfect
Argus
in
the
way
of
buttons
:
shining
and

and

and

out
of
a
hundred
of
those
eyes
of

metal
,
at
the

.
<EOS>
The
artistic
taste
of
some
unknown
hatter
had
furnished
him
with
a
hatband
of
wholesale
capacity
which
was
fluted
behind
,
from
the

of
his
hat
to

,
and
terminated
in
a
black

,
from
which
the
imagination
shrunk

and
the
reason

.
<EOS>
Some
special
powers
with
which
his
legs
were
endowed
,
had
already
hitched
up
his
glossy
trousers
at
the

,
and
bagged
them
at
the

;
while
similar
gifts
in
his
arms
had
raised
his
coat
-

from

and
accumulated

.
<EOS>
Thus
set
forth
,
with
the
additional

of
a
very
little
tail
to
his
coat
,
and
a
yawning
gulf
at

,
Sloppy
stood

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

is
Betty
,

?
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin

.
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,

,
"

,
"
she
do
pretty

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

?
"
  
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
For

---
<EOS>
no

,

,

?
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Why

,

four
!
"
<EOS>

,

.

"
How

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

Sloppy

<EOS>
"
  
"
Off

<EOS>
O

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
---
<EOS>

Higden
,
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

.

.

,

"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"
the

might

night
,
do

?
<EOS>
I
could

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Or

"

.
<EOS>
I

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
On

,

's

,
and
then

from
that
good
creature
that
he
might

room
enough
for

,
threw

,
opened

,

.
<EOS>
It
was
creditable
to
his

of
heart
,
but
suggested

:
the
rather
,

,
on

"
that
he
