was
Cats
.
"
   
<EOS>
SOME
AFFAIRS
OF
THE
HEART
.
 
<EOS>
Little
Miss
Peecher
,
from
her
little
official
dwelling
-
house
,
with
its
little
windows
like
the
eyes
in
needles
,
and
its
little
doors
like
the
covers
of
school
-
books
,
was
very
observant
indeed
of
the
object
of
her
quiet
affections
.
<EOS>
Love
,
though
said
to
be
afflicted
with
blindness
,
is
a
vigilant
watchman
,
and
Miss
Peecher
kept
him
on
double
duty
over
Mr.
Bradley
Headstone
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
she
was
naturally
given
to
playing
the
spy
---
it
was
not
that
she
was
at
all
secret
,
plotting
,
or
mean
---
<EOS>
it
was
simply
that
she
loved
the
irresponsive
Bradley
with
all
the
primitive
and
homely
stock
of
love
that
had
never
been
examined
or
certificated
out
of
her
.
<EOS>
If
her
faithful
slate
had
had
the
latent
qualities
of
sympathetic
paper
,
and
its
pencil
those
of
invisible
ink
,
many
a
little
treatise
calculated
to
astonish
the
pupils
would
have
come
bursting
through
the
dry
sums
in
school
-
time
under
the
warming
influence
of
Miss
Peecher
's
bosom
.
<EOS>
For
,
oftentimes
when
school
was
not
,
and
her
calm
leisure
and
calm
little
house
were
her
own
,
Miss
Peecher
would
commit
to
the
confidential
slate
an
imaginary
description
of
how
,
upon
a
balmy
evening
at
dusk
,
two
figures
might
have
been
observed
in
the
market
-
garden
ground
round
the
corner
,
of
whom
one
,
being
a
manly
form
,
bent
over
the
other
,
being
a
womanly
form
of
short
stature
and
some
compactness
,
and
breathed
in
a
low
voice
<EOS>
the
words
,
"
Emma
Peecher
,
wilt
thou
be
my
own
?
"
<EOS>
after
which
the
womanly
form
's
head
reposed
upon
the
manly
form
's
shoulder
,
and
the
nightingales
tuned
up
.
<EOS>
Though
all
unseen
,
and
unsuspected
by
the
pupils
,
Bradley
Headstone
even
pervaded
the
school
exercises
.
<EOS>
Was
Geography
in
question
?
<EOS>
He
would
come
triumphantly
flying
out
of
Vesuvius
and
Aetna
ahead
of
the
lava
,
and
would
boil
unharmed
in
the
hot
springs
of
Iceland
,
and
would
float
majestically
down
the
Ganges
and
the
Nile
.
<EOS>
Did
History
chronicle
a
king
of
men
?
<EOS>
Behold
him
in
pepper
-
and
-
salt
pantaloons
,
with
his
watch
-
guard
round
his
neck
.
<EOS>
Were
copies
to
be
written
?
<EOS>
In
capital
B
's
and
H
's
most
of
the
girls
under
Miss
Peecher
's
tuition
were
half
a
year
ahead
of
every
other
letter
in
the
alphabet
.
<EOS>
And
Mental
Arithmetic
,
administered
by
Miss
Peecher
,
often
devoted
itself
to
providing
Bradley
Headstone
with
a
wardrobe
of
fabulous
extent
:
fourscore
and
four
neck
-
ties
at
two
and
ninepence
-

,
two
gross
of
silver
watches
at
four
pounds
fifteen
and
sixpence
,
seventy
-
four
black
hats
at
eighteen

;
and
many
similar
superfluities
.
  
<EOS>
The
vigilant
watchman
,
using
his
daily

of
turning
his
eyes
in
Bradley
's
direction
,
soon
apprized
Miss
Peecher
that
Bradley
was
more
preoccupied
than
had
been
his
wo
nt
,
and
more
given
to

,
turning
something

in

that
was
not

.
<EOS>
Putting

---

"
this
,
"
present
appearances
and
the

with
Charley
Hexam
,
and
ranging

"
that
"
the
visit

,
the

to
Miss

his
strong

the
sister
was
at

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

a
half

,
"
what

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mary
Anne
,
at

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

Anne
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
Lizzie
a
Christian

,
Mary
Anne
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mary
Anne
laid
down

,
rose
,
hooked

,
as

,

:
"
No
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who

?
"
<EOS>
Miss

was
going
on
,
from

mere
force

,
when

checked

,
on
Mary
Anne
's
evincing
theological

to
strike
in
with
her

and

,

:
"
I
mean

name

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Elizabeth
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Right
,

Anne
.
<EOS>
Whether

Lizzies
in
the
early
Christian
Church
must

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
Miss

sage

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

's

;

.
<EOS>

?

.

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

advice
,
and
persists
in
being
guided
by
somebody
else
's
;
and
that
---
"
  
"
Mr.
Headstone
coming
across
the
garden
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Peecher
,
with
a
flushed

at
the
looking
-
glass
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
answered
very
well
,
Mary
Anne
.
<EOS>
You
are
forming
an
excellent
habit
of
arranging
your
thoughts
clearly
.
<EOS>
That
will
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
discreet
Mary
Anne
resumed
her
seat
and
her
silence
,
and
stitched
,
and
stitched
,
and
was
stitching
when
the
schoolmaster
's
shadow
came
in
before

,
announcing
that
he
might
be
instantly
expected
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
Miss
Peecher
,
"
he
said
,
pursuing
the
shadow
,
and
taking

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
Mary
Anne
,
a
chair
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
Bradley
,
seating
himself
in
his
constrained

.
<EOS>
"
This
is
but
a
flying
visit
.
<EOS>
I
have
looked
in
,
on
my

,
to
ask
a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did

say

,
Mr.
Headstone
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
On

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Church
Street
,
Smith
Square
,
by
Mill

,
"

Peecher
,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
Hexam
has
gone
to
get
a
book

two
he

,
and
will
probably

back

.
<EOS>
As

,
I

.
<EOS>
Would

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
Going

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Partly

,

"
Business

,

<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
There

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
In

?
"
  
"
<EOS>
In

Westminster
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mill
Bank
,
"
Miss
Peecher
repeated
in
her
own

once

.
"
<EOS>
No
,
thank

,
Mr.
Headstone
;
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
could
n't
trouble
me
,
"
said
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
returned
Miss
Peecher
,
though
not

;
"
but
you
can
trouble
me
!
"
<EOS>
And
for
all
her
quiet
manner
,
and
her
quiet
smile
,
she
was
full
of
trouble
as
he
went
his
way
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
right
touching
his
destination
.
<EOS>
He
held
as
straight
a
course
for
the
house
of
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
as
the
wisdom
of
his
ancestors
,
exemplified
in
the
construction
of
the
intervening
streets
,
would
let
him
,
and
walked
with
a
bent
head
hammering
at
one
fixed
idea
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
an
immoveable
idea
since
he
first
set
eyes
upon
her
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
as
if
all
that
he
could
suppress
in
himself
he
her
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
to
him
as
if
all
that
he
could
suppress
in
himself
he
had
suppressed
,
as
if
all
that
he
could
restrain
in
himself
he
had
restrained
,
and
the
time
had
come
---
in
a
rush
,
in
a
moment
---
when
the
power
of
self
-
command
had
departed
from
him
.
<EOS>
Love
at
first
sight
is
a
trite
expression
quite
sufficiently
discussed
;
enough
that
in
certain
smouldering
natures
like
this
man
's
,
that
passion
leaps
into
a
blaze
,
and
makes
such
head
as
fire
does
in
a
rage
of
wind
,
when
other
passions
,
but
for
its
mastery
,
could
be
held
in
chains
.
<EOS>
As
a
multitude
of
weak
,
imitative
natures
are
always
lying
by
,
ready
to
go
mad
upon
the
next
wrong
idea
that
may
be
broached
---
in
these
times
,
generally
some
form
of
tribute
to
Somebody
for
something
that
never
was
done
,
or
,
if
ever
done
,
that
was
done
by
Somebody
Else
<EOS>
---
so
these
less
ordinary
natures
may
lie
by
for
years
,
ready
on
the
touch
of
an
instant
to
burst
into
flame
.
  
<EOS>
The
schoolmaster
went
his
way
,
brooding
and
brooding
,
and
a
sense
of
being
vanquished
in
a
struggle
might
have
been
pieced
out
of
his
worried
face
.
<EOS>
Truly
,
in
his
breast
there
lingered
a
resentful
shame
to
find
himself
defeated
by
this
passion
for
Charley
Hexam
's
sister
,
though
in
the
very
self
-
same
moments
he
was
concentrating
himself
upon
the
object
of
bringing
the
passion
to
a

issue
.
  
<EOS>
He
appeared
before
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
,
sitting
alone
at
her
work
.
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
"
thought
that
sharp
young
personage
,
"
it
's
you
,
is

?
<EOS>
I
know
your

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hexam
's
sister
,
"
said
Bradley
Headstone
,
"
is

come

yet
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite

,
"
returned
Miss
Wren
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"

Wren
.
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
.
<EOS>
I
hope
it
's

.
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
glanced

at
the
shrewd
face
again
bending
over
the
work
,
and
said
,
trying

:
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope

do

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
bear
you
to

that
,
"
 
returned

Wren
,

,
"
for
I
do
n't
like
Hexam
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Indeed
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
<EOS>
Miss
Wren
wrinkled

nose
,
to
express

.
"
<EOS>
Selfish
.
<EOS>
Thinks
only
of
himself
.
<EOS>
The
way

you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
way

all

?
<EOS>
Then

do

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
So

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Do

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

It

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Wo

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
Hah
!
<EOS>
Now

.
<EOS>
This

Truth
.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Full
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley

doll
she

---
which

,

she

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

Mrs.
T.

,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
To

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
But

?
"
  
"
Her

.
"
  
"
O

T.
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
To

,
"
pursued

,
half

what

,

;
"
for
her

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh

T.
!
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
For

,
"

,

"

's
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Really
,

T.
,
"

,
"
since

,
we

to

.
<EOS>
"
She
had

,
when
Lizzie
Hexam

,
and

some

on

Bradley
Headstone
there
,
and
Jenny
shaking
her
little
first
at
him
close
before
her

,
and
the
Honorable
Mrs.
T.
with
her

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here

,
Lizzie
dear
,
"
said
the
knowing
Miss
Wren
,
"
come
to

,

your

and

's
.
<EOS>
Think
of
that
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
there
ought
to
be
no
third
party
present
at
anything
<EOS>
so
very
kind
<EOS>
and
so

;
 
<EOS>
and

,

you
'll

third

,
my

,
the
third

will

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
took
the
hand
which
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
held

for
the
purpose
of
being
supported
away
,
but
only

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
third
party
hobbles
awfully
,
you

,
when
she
's

,
"
said
Miss
Wren
,
"
her
back
being
so

,
and
her

so

;
so
she
ca
n't
retire
gracefully
unless
you
help

,
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
can
do
no
better
than
stay
where
she
is
,
"
returned
Lizzie
,
releasing
the
hand
,
and
laying
her
own
lightly
on
Miss
Jenny
's
curls
.
<EOS>
And
then
to
Bradley
:
"
From
Charley
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
In
an
irresolute
way
,
and
stealing
a
clumsy
look
at
her
,
Bradley
rose
to
place
a
chair
for
her
,
and
then
returned
to
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
"
Strictly
speaking
,
"
said
he
,
"
I
come
from
Charley
,
because
I
left
him
only
a
little

ago
;
but
I
am
not
commissioned
by
Charley
.
<EOS>
I
come
of
my
own
spontaneous
act
.
<EOS>
"
  
With
her
elbows
on
her
bench
,
<EOS>
and
her
chin
upon
her
hands
<EOS>
,
Miss
Jenny
Wren
sat
looking
at
him
with
a
watchful
sidelong
look
.
<EOS>
Lizzie
,
in
her
different
way
,
sat
looking
at
him
too
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
fact
is
,
"
began
Bradley
,
with
a
mouth
so
dry
that
he
had
some
difficulty
in
articulating
his
words
:
the
consciousness
of
which
rendered
his
manner
still
more
ungainly
and
undecided
;
"
the
truth
is
,
that
Charley
,
having
no
secrets
from
me
(
to
the
best
of
my
belief
)
,
has
confided
the
whole
of
this
matter
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
came
to
a
stop
,
and
Lizzie
asked
:
"
What
matter
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
,
"
returned
the
schoolmaster
,
stealing
another
look
at
her
,
and
seeming
to
try
in
vain
to
sustain
it
;
for
the
look
dropped
as
it
lighted
on
her
eyes
,
"
that
it
might
be
so
superfluous
as
to
be
almost
impertinent
,
to
enter
upon
a
definition
of
it
.
<EOS>
My
allusion
was
to
this
matter
of
your
having
put
aside
your
brother
's
plans
for
you
,
and
given
the
preference
to
those
of
Mr.
---
I
believe
the
name
is
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
made
this
point
of
not
being
certain
of
the
name
,
with
another
uneasy
look
at
her
,
which
dropped
like
the
last
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
being
said
on
the
other
side
,
he
had
to
begin
again
,
and
began
with
new
embarrassment
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
brother
's
plans
were
communicated
to
me
when
he
first
had
them
in
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
In
point
of
fact
he
spoke
to
me
about
them
when
I
was
last
here
---
when
we
were
walking
back
together
,
and
when
I
---
when
the
impression
was
fresh
upon
me
of
having
seen
his
sister
.
"
  
<EOS>
There
might
have
been
no
meaning
in
it
,
but
the
little
dressmaker
here
removed
one
of
her
supporting
hands
from
her
chin
,
and
musingly
turned
the
Honorable
Mrs.
T.
with
her
face
to
the
company
.
<EOS>
That
done
,
she
fell
into
her
former
attitude
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
approved
of
his
idea
,
"
said
Bradley
,
with
his
uneasy
look
wandering
to
the
doll
,
and
unconsciously
resting
there
longer
than
it
had
rested
on
Lizzie
,
"
both
because
your
brother
ought
naturally
to
be
the
originator
of
any
such
scheme
,
and
because
I
hoped
to
be
able
to
promote
it
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
had
inexpressible
pleasure
,
I
should
have
taken
inexpressible
interest
,
in
promoting
it
.
<EOS>
Therefore
I
must
acknowledge
that
when
your
brother
was
disappointed
,
I
too
was
disappointed
.
<EOS>
I
wish
to
avoid
reservation
or
concealment
,
and
I
fully
acknowledge
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
appeared
to
have
encouraged
himself
by
having
got
so
far
.
<EOS>
At
all
events
he
went
on
with
much
greater
firmness
and
force
of
emphasis
:
though
with
a
curious
disposition
to
set
his
teeth
,
and
with
a
curious
tight
-
screwing
movement
of
his
right
hand
in
the
clenching

of
his
left
,
like
the
action
of
one
who
was
being
physically
hurt
,
and
was
unwilling
to
cry
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
a
man
of
strong
feelings
,
and
I
have
strongly
felt
this
disappointment
.
<EOS>
I
do
strongly
feel
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
show
what
I
feel
;
 
some
of
us
are
obliged
habitually
to
keep
it
down
.
<EOS>
To
keep
it
down
.
<EOS>
But
to
return
to
your
brother
.
<EOS>
He
has
taken
the
matter
so
much
to
heart
that
he
has
remonstrated
(
in
my
presence
he
remonstrated
)
with
Mr.
Engene
Wrayburn
,
if
that
be
the
name
.
<EOS>
He
did
so
,
quite
ineffectually
.
<EOS>
As
any
one
not
blinded
to
the
real
character
of
Mr.
 
---
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
---
would
readily
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
at
Lizzie
again
,
and
held
the
look
.
<EOS>
And
his
face
turned
from
burning
red
to
white
,
and
from
white
back
to
burning
red
,
and
so
for
the
time
to
lasting
deadly
white
.
  
<EOS>
"
Finally
,
I
resolved
to
come
here
alone
,
and
appeal
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
resolved
to
come
here
alone
,
and
entreat
you
to
retract
the
course
you
have
chosen
,
and
instead
of
confiding
in
a
mere
stranger
---
a
person
of
most
insolent
behaviour
to
your
brother
and
others
---
to
prefer
your
brother
and
your
brother
's
friend
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
Hexam
had
changed
colour
when
those
changes
came
over
him
,
and
her
face
now
expressed
some
anger
,
more
dislike
,
and
even
a
touch
of
fear
.
<EOS>
But
she
answered
him
very
steadily
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
doubt
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
that
your
visit
is
well
meant
.
<EOS>
You
have
been
so
good
a
friend
to
Charley
that
I
have
no
right
to
doubt
it
.
<EOS>
I
have
nothing
to
tell
Charley
,
but
that
I
accepted
the
help
to
which
he
so
much
objects
before
he
made
any
plans
for
me
;
or
certainly
before
I
knew
of
any
.
<EOS>
It
was
considerately
and
delicately
offered
,
and
there
were
reasons
that
had
weight
with
me
which
should
be
as
dear
to
Charley
as
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
more
to
say
to
Charley
on
this
subject
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
lips
trembled
and
stood
apart
,
as
he
followed
this
repudiation
of
himself
,
and
limitation
of
her
words
to
her
brother
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
have
told
Charley
,
if
he
had
come
to
me
,
"
she
resumed
,
as

an
after
-
thought
,
"
that
Jenny
and
I
find
our
teacher
very

and
very

,
and
that
she
takes
great

with

.
<EOS>
So
much
so
,
that
we
have
said
to
her
we
hope
in
a
very
little
while
to
be
able
to
go
on
by

.
<EOS>
Charley
knows
about
teachers
,
and
I
should
also
have
told
him
,
for
his

,
that
ours
comes
from
an
institution
where
teachers
are
regularly
brought
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
ask
you
,
"
said
Bradley
Headstone
,
grinding

words
slowly
out
,
as
though

came
from
a

;
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
ask
you
,
if
I
may
without

,
whether
you
would
have
objected
 
---
no
<EOS>
;
rather
,
I
should
like
to
say
,
if
I
may
without

,
that
I
wish
I

had

of
coming
here
with
your
brother
and
devoting
my
poor

and

to
your

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
fear
,
"
he
pursued
,
after
a

,
furtively

at
the
seat
of
his

with
one

,
as
if
he
would
have
wrenched
the
chair
to

,
and
gloomily
observing
her
while
her

were
cast
down
,
"
that
my
humble
services
would
not
have
found
much
favor
with
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
made
no
reply
,
and
the
poor
stricken
wretch
sat
contending
with
himself
in
a
heat
of
passion
and
torment
.
<EOS>
After
a
while
he
took
out
his
handkerchief
and
wiped

and
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
only
one
thing
more
I
had
to
say
,
but
it

most

.
<EOS>
There

against
this

,
there

a

relation

,

.
<EOS>
It

---
I
do

---
it
might
---
induce

to
think
differently
.
<EOS>
To
proceed
under
the
present

.
<EOS>
Will
you
please
come
to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
Charley
,

Headstone
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
With
---
well
,
"
he

,

,
"
yes
!
<EOS>
Say

.
<EOS>
Will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

,

,
"
understand

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Limit

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

,

?
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
---

.
"
<EOS>
Then

,
as

,
"
I
---
I
leave
it
all

!
<EOS>
There

a
spell
upon

,
I
think
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
added
,
almost

,
"
Good
-
night
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
held
out
his
hand
.
<EOS>
As
she
,
with
manifest
hesitation
,
not
to
say
reluctance
,
touched
it
,
a
strange

passed
over
him
,
and
his
face
,
so
deadly
white
,
was
moved
as
by
a
stroke
of
pain
.
<EOS>
Then
he
was
gone
.
  
<EOS>
The
dolls
'
dressmaker
sat
with
her
attitude
unchanged
,
eyeing
the
door
by
which
he
had
departed
,
until
Lizzie
pushed
her
bench
aside
and
sat
down
near
her
.
<EOS>
Then
,
eyeing
Lizzie
as
she
had
previously
eyed
Bradley
and
the
door
,
Miss
Wren
chopped
that
very
sudden
and
keen
chop
in
which
her
jaws
sometimes
indulged
,
leaned
back
in
her
chair
with

,
and
thus
expressed
herself
:
  
"
Humph
!
<EOS>
If
he
---
<EOS>
I
mean
,
of
course
,
my
dear
,
the
party
who
is
coming
to
court
me
when
the
time
comes
---
should
be
that
sort
of
man
,
he
may
spare
himself
the
trouble
.
<EOS>
He
would
n't
do

about
and
made

.
<EOS>
He
'd
take
fire
and
blow
up
while
he
was
about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
you
would
be

,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
He
would

.
<EOS>
He
'd
carry

up
with

.
<EOS>
I
know
his

and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Would
he
want

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Might

,

,
"

;
 
"

-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish

was
so
very
strange
<EOS>
a
man
as
to
be

total
stranger
<EOS>
,
"
 
answered

sharp

thing
.
  
<EOS>
It
being
Lizzie
's
regular
occupation
when

alone
of

to

of

dolls
'

,

that

while
the
little

was
at

,
and
it
fell
in
a
beautiful

over
the
poor
shoulders
that
were
much

such

.
"
<EOS>
Not
now
,
Lizzie
,
dear
,
"
said
Jenny
;
"
let
us
have
a
talk
by
the
fire
.
"
 
<EOS>
With
those
words
,
she
in
her

loosened
her
friend
's
dark
hair
,
and
it
dropped
of
its
own

over
her

,
in
two

.
<EOS>
Pretending
to
compare

and

,
Jenny
so
managed
a
mere

of

,

herself
laying

,

to
all

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Something

;

---

<EOS>

;

's

,

's
whose

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
about

Wrayburn
?
"
<EOS>
Lizzie

.
  
<EOS>
"
For
no

than
because
I
'm

the

.
<EOS>
I
wonder

's

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
To

!
<EOS>
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
Not

?
"
  
<EOS>
A

"
<EOS>
Oh

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
The

'

had
an

's

.
<EOS>
Adjusting

,

slyly

;

the
eye
down

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
When
He

,

sha

;

.
<EOS>
However

;

.
<EOS>
I

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

?
<EOS>
I

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

,

"
  
"
<EOS>
Perhaps
.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
What

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
I

!
"
<EOS>

,

"
<EOS>
Such

!
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I
,

"
  
<EOS>
(

He

!
"

.

<EOS>
"
I

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Lizzie

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

!
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

!
<EOS>
My

.
"
<EOS>
As

,

showed
her

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Look

,
as
I

.
<EOS>
Look

---

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

flare
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
That
's

!
<EOS>
You
can
find
a
lady
there
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
More
easily
than
I
can
make
one
of
such
material
as
myself
,
Jenny
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
sparkling
eye
looked
stedfastly
up
,
as
the
musing
face
looked
thoughtfully
down
.
"
<EOS>
Well
?
"
said
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
,
"
We
have
found
our
lady
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
nodded
,
and
asked
,
"
Shall
she
be
rich
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
had
better
be
,
as
he
's
poor
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
rich
.
<EOS>
Shall
she
be
handsome
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Even
you
can
be
that
,
Lizzie
,
so
she
ought
to
be
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
very
handsome
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
does
she
say
about
him
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Miss
Jenny
,
in
a
low
voice
:
<EOS>
watchful
,
through
an
intervening
silence
,
of
the
face
looking
down
at
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
glad
,
glad
,
to
be
rich
,
that
he
may
have
the
money
.
<EOS>
She
is
glad
,
glad
,
to
be
beautiful
,
that
he
may
be
proud
of
her
.
<EOS>
Her
poor
heart
---
"
  
"
Eh
?
<EOS>
Her
poor
heart
?
"
said
Miss
Wren
.
  
<EOS>
"
Her
heart
---
is
given
him
,
with
all
its
love
and
truth
.
<EOS>
She
would
joyfully
die
with
him
,
or
,
better
than
that
,
die
for
him
.
<EOS>
She
knows
he
has
failings
,
but
she
thinks
they
have
grown
up
through
his
being
like
one
cast
away
,
for
the
want
of
something
to
trust
in
,
and
care
for
,
and
think
well
of
.
<EOS>
And
she
says
,
that
lady
rich
and
beautiful
<EOS>
that
I
can
never
come
near
,
`
<EOS>
`
Only
put
me
in
that
empty
place
,
only
try
how
little
I
mind
myself
,
only
prove
what
a
world
of
things
I
will
do
and
bear
for
you
,
and
I
hope
that
you
might
even
come
to
be
much
better
than
you
are
,
through
me
who
am
so
much
worse
,
and
hardly
worth
the
thinking
of
beside
you
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
As
the
face
looking
at
the
fire
had
become
exalted
and
forgetful
in
the
rapture
of
these
words
,
the
little
creature
,
openly
clearing
away
her
fair
hair
with
her
disengaged
hand
,
had
gazed
at
it
with
earnest
attention
and
something
like
alarm
.
<EOS>
Now
that
the
speaker
ceased
,
the
little
creature
laid
down
her
head
again
,
and
moaned
,
"
O
me
,
O
me
,
O
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
pain
,
dear
Jenny
?
"
asked
Lizzie
,
as
if
awakened
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
but
not
the
old
pain
.
<EOS>
Lay
me
down
,
lay
me
down
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
go
out
of
my
sight
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
Lock
the
door
and
keep
close
to
me
.
"
 
<EOS>
Then
turning
away
her
face
,
she
said
in
a
whisper
to
herself
,
"
My
Lizzie
,
my
poor
Lizzie
!
<EOS>
O
my
blessed
children
,
come
back
in
the
long
bright
slanting
rows
,
and
come
for
her
,
not
me
.
<EOS>
She
wants
help
more
than
I
,
my
blessed
children
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
stretched
her
hands
up
with
that
higher
and
better
look
,
and
now
she
turned
again
,
and
folded
them
round
Lizzie
's
neck
,
and
rocked
herself
on
Lizzie
's
breast
.
   
<EOS>
MORE
BIRDS
OF
PREY
.
 
<EOS>
Rogue
Riderhood
dwelt
deep
and
dark
in
Limehouse
Hole
,
among
the
riggers
,
and
the
mast
,
oar
and
block
makers
,
and
the
boat
-
builders
,
and
the
sail
-
lofts
,
as
in
a
kind
of
ship
's
hold
stored
full
of
waterside
characters
,
some
no
better
than
himself
,
some
very
much
better
,
and
none
much
worse
.
<EOS>
The
Hole
,
albeit
in
a
general
way
not
over
nice
in
its
choice
of
company
,
was
rather
shy
in
reference
to
the
honor
of
cultivating
the
Rogue
's
acquaintance
;
more
frequently
giving
him
the
cold
shoulder
than
the
warm
hand
,
and
seldom
or
never
drinking
with
him
unless
at
his
own
expense
.
<EOS>
A
part
of
the
Hole
,
indeed
,
contained
so
much
public
spirit
and
private
virtue
that
not
even
this
strong
leverage
could
move
it
to
good
fellowship
with
a
tainted
accuser
.
<EOS>
But
,
there
may
have
been
the
drawback
on
this
magnanimous
morality
,
that
its
exponents
held
a
true
witness
before
Justice
to
be
the
next
unneighbourly
and
accursed
character
to
a
false
one
.
  
<EOS>
Had
it
not
been
for
the
daughter
whom
he
often
mentioned
,
Mr.
Riderhood
might
have
found
the
Hole
a
mere
grave
as
to
any
means
it
would
yield
him
of
getting
a
living
.
<EOS>
But
Miss
Pleasant
Riderhood
had
some
little
position
and
connection
in
Limehouse
Hole
.
<EOS>
Upon
the
smallest
of
small
scales
,
she
was
an
unlicensed
pawnbroker
,
keeping
what
was
popularly
called
a
Leaving
Shop
,
by
lending
insignificant
sums
on
insignificant
articles
of
property
deposited
with
her
as
security
.
<EOS>
In
her
four
-
and
-
twentieth
year
of
life
,
Pleasant
was
already
in
her
fifth
year
of
this
way
of
trade
.
<EOS>
Her
deceased
mother
had
established
the
business
,
and
on
that
parent
's
demise
she
had
appropriated
a
secret
capital
of
fifteen
shillings
to
establishing
herself
in
it
;
the
existence
of
such
capital
in
a
pillow
being
the
last
intelligible
confidential
communication
made
to
her
by
the
departed
,
before
succumbing
to
dropsical
conditions
of
snuff
and
gin
,
incompatible
equally
with
coherence
and
existence
.
  
<EOS>
Why
christened
Pleasant
,
the
late
Mrs.
Riderhood
might
possibly
have
been
at
some
time
able
to
explain
,
and
possibly
not
.
<EOS>
Her
daughter
had
no
information
on
that
point
.
<EOS>
Pleasant
she
found
herself
,
and
she
could
n't
help
it
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
been
consulted
on
the
question
,
any
more
than
on
the
question
of
her
coming
into
these
terrestrial
parts
,
to
want
a
name
.
<EOS>
Similarly
,
she
found
herself
possessed
of
what
is
colloquially
termed
a
swivel
eye
(
derived
from
her
father
)
,
which
she
might
perhaps
have
declined
if
her
sentiments
on
the
subject
had
been
taken
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
otherwise
positively
ill
-
looking
,
though
anxious
,
meagre
,
of
a
muddy
complexion
,
and
looking
as
old
again
as
she
really
was
.
  
<EOS>
As
some
dogs
have
it
in
the
blood
,
or
are
trained
,
to
worry
certain
creatures
to
a
certain
point
,
so
---
not
to
make
the
comparison
disrespectfully
---
  
<EOS>
Pleasant
Riderhood
had
it
in
the
blood
,
or
had
been
trained
,
to
regard
seamen
,
within
certain
limits
,
as
her
prey
.
<EOS>
Show
her
a
man
in
a
blue
jacket
,
and
,
figuratively
speaking
,
she
pinned
him
instantly
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
all
things
considered
,
she
was
not
of
an
evil
mind
or
an
unkindly
disposition
.
<EOS>
For
,
observe
how
many
things
were
to
be
considered
according
to
her
own
unfortunate
experience
.
<EOS>
Show
Pleasant
Riderhood
a
Wedding
in
the
street
,
and
she
only
saw
two
people
taking
out
a
regular
license
to
quarrel
and
fight
.
<EOS>
Show
her
a
Christening
,
and
she
saw
a
little
heathen
personage
having
a
quite
superfluous
name
bestowed
upon
it
,
inasmuch
as
it
would
be
commonly
addressed
by
some
abusive
epithet
:
which
little
personage
was
not
in
the
least
wanted
by
anybody
,
and
would
be
shoved
and
banged
out
of
everybody
's
way
,
until
it
should
grow
big
enough
to
shove
and
bang
.
<EOS>
Show
her
a
Funeral
,
and
she
saw
an
unremunerative
ceremony
in
the
nature
of
a
black
masquerade
,
conferring
a
temporary
gentility
on
the
performers
,
at
an
immense
expense
,
and
representing
the
only
formal
party
ever
given
by
the
deceased
.
<EOS>
Show
her
a
live
father
,
and
she
saw
but
a
duplicate
of
her
own
father
,
who
from
her
infancy
had
been
taken
with
fits
and
starts
of
discharging
his
duty
to
her
,
which
duty
was
always
incorporated
in
the
form
of
a
fist
or
a
leathern
strap
,
and
being
discharged
hurt
her
.
<EOS>
All
things
considered
,
therefore
,
Pleasant
Riderhood
was
not
so
very
,
very
bad
.
<EOS>
There
was
even
a
touch
of
romance
in
her
---
of
such
romance
as
could
creep
into
Limehouse
Hole
---
and
maybe
sometimes
of
a
summer
evening
,
when
she
stood
with
folded
arms
at
her
shopdoor
,
looking
from
the
reeking
street
to
the
sky
where
the
sun
was
setting
,
she
may
have
had
some
vaporous
visions
of
far
-
off
islands
in
the
southern
seas
or
elsewhere
(
not
being
geographically
particular
)
,
where
it
would
be
good
to
roam
with
a
congenial
partner
among
groves
of
bread
-
fruit
,
waiting
for
ships
to
be
wafted
from
the
hollow
ports
of
civilization
.
<EOS>
For
,
sailors
to
be
got
the
better
of
,
were
essential
to
Miss
Pleasant
's
Eden
.
  
<EOS>
Not
on
a
summer
evening
did
she
come
to
her
little
shop
-
door
,
when
a
certain
man
standing
over
against
the
house
on
the
opposite
side
of
the
street
took
notice
of
her
.
<EOS>
That
was
on
a
cold
shrewd
windy
evening
,
after
dark
.
<EOS>
Pleasant
Riderhood
shared
with
most
of
the
lady
inhabitants
of
the
Hole
,
the
peculiarity
that
her
hair
was
a
ragged
knot
,
constantly
coming
down
behind
,
and
that
she
never
could
enter
upon
any
undertaking
without
first
twisting
it
into
place
.
<EOS>
At
that
particular
moment
,
being
newly
come
to
the
threshold
to
take
a
look
out
of
doors
,
she
was
winding
herself
up
with
both
hands
after
this
fashion
.
<EOS>
And
so
prevalent
was
the
fashion
,
that
on
the
occasion
of
a
fight
or
other
disturbance
in
the
Hole
,
the
ladies
would
be
seen
flocking
from
all
quarters
universally
twisting
their
back
-
hair
as
they
came
along
,
and
many
of
them
,
in
the
hurry
of
the
moment
,
carrying
their
back
-
combs
in
their
mouths
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
wretched
little
shop
,
with
a
roof
that
any
man
standing
in
it
could
touch
with
his
hand
;
little
better
than
a
cellar
or
cave
,
down
three
steps
.
<EOS>
Yet
in
its
ill
-
lighted
window
,
among
a
flaring
handkerchief
or
two
,
an
old
peacoat
or
so
,
a
few
valueless
watches
and
compasses
,
a
jar
of
tobacco
and
two
crossed
pipes
,
a
bottle
of
walnut
ketchup
,
and
some
horrible
sweets
---
these
creature
discomforts
serving
as
a
blind
to
the
main
business
of
the
Leaving
Shop
---
was
displayed
the
inscription
Seaman
's
Boarding
-
House
.
  
<EOS>
Taking
notice
of
Pleasant
Riderhood
at
the
door
,
the
man
crossed
so
quickly
that
she
was
still
winding
herself
up
,
when
he
stood
close
before
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
your
father
at
home
?
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
,
"
returned
Pleasant
,
dropping
her
arms
;
"
come
in
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
tentative
reply
,
the
man
having
a
seafaring
appearance
.
<EOS>
Her
father
was
not
at
home
,
and
Pleasant
knew
it
.
<EOS>
"
Take
a
seat
by
the
fire
,
"
were
her
hospitable
words
when
she
had
got
him
in
;
 
"
men
of
your
calling
are
always
welcome
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
,
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
His
manner
was
the
manner
of
a
sailor
,
and
his
hands
were
the
hands
of
a
sailor
,
except
that
they
were
smooth
.
<EOS>
Pleasant
had
an
eye
for
sailors
,
and
she
noticed
the
unused
colour
and
texture
of
the
hands
,
sunburnt
though
they
were
,
as
sharply
as
she
noticed
their
unmistakable
looseness
and
suppleness
,
as
he
sat
himself
down
with
his
left
arm
carelessly
thrown
across
his
left
leg
a
little
above
the
knee
,
and
the
right
arm
as
carelessly
thrown
over
the
elbow
of
the
wooden
chair
,
with
the
hand
curved
,
half
open
and
half
shut
,
as
if
it
had
just
let
go
a
rope
.
  
<EOS>
"
Might
you
be
looking
for
a
Boarding
-
House
?
"
<EOS>
Pleasant
inquired
,
taking
her
observant
stand
on
one
side
of
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
rightly
know
my
plans
yet
,
"
returned
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
ai
n't
looking
for
a
Leaving
Shop
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
assented
Pleasant
,
"
you
've
got
too
much
of
an
outfit
on
you
for
that
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
should
want
either
,
this
is
both
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
"
said
the
man
,
glancing
round
the
place
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
.
<EOS>
I
've
been
here
before
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
Leave
anything
when
you
were
here
before
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Pleasant
,
with
a
view
to
principal
and
interest
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
The
man
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
pretty
sure
you
never
boarded
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
<EOS>
The
man
again
shook
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
did
you
do
here
when
you
were
here
before
?
"
asked
Pleasant
.
<EOS>
"
For
I
do
n't
remember
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
at
all
likely
you
should
.
<EOS>
I
only
stood
at
the
door
,
one
night
---
on
the
lower
step
there
---
while
a
shipmate
of
mine
looked
in
to
speak
to
your
father
.
<EOS>
I
remember
the
place
well
.
<EOS>
"
Looking
very
curiously
round
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Might
that
have
been
long
ago
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
a
goodish
bit
ago
.
<EOS>
When
I
came
off
my
last
voyage
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
have
not
been
to
sea
lately
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
Been
in
the
sick
bay
since
then
,
and
been
employed
ashore
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
to
be
sure
,
that
accounts
for
your
hands
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
with
a
keen
look
,
a
quick
smile
,
and
a
change
of
manner
,
caught
her
up
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
good
observer
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
That
accounts
for
my
hands
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Pleasant
was
somewhat
disquieted
by
his
look
,
and
returned
it
suspiciously
.
<EOS>
Not
only
was
his
change
of
manner
,
though
very
sudden
,
quite
collected
,
but
his
former
manner
,
which
he
resumed
,
had
a
certain
suppressed
confidence
and
sense
of
power
in
it
that
were
half
threatening
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
your
father
be
long
?
"
he
inquired
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
you
supposed
he
was
at
home
,
it
would
seem
that
he
has
just
gone
out
?
<EOS>
How
's
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
supposed
he
had
come
home
,
"
Pleasant
explained
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
You
supposed
he
had
come
home
?
<EOS>
Then
he
has
been
some
time
out
?
<EOS>
How
's
that
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
deceive
you
.
<EOS>
Father
's
on
the
river
in
his
boat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
the
old
work
?
"
asked
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
what
you
mean
,
"
said
Pleasant
,
shrinking
a
step
back
.
<EOS>
"
What
on
earth
d'ye
want
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
want
to
hurt
your
father
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
to
say
I
might
,
if
I
chose
.
<EOS>
I
want
to
speak
to
him
.
<EOS>
Not
much
in
that
,
is
there
?
<EOS>
There
shall
be
no
secrets
from
you
;
you
shall
be
by
.
<EOS>
And
plainly
,
Miss
Riderhood
,
there
's
nothing
to
be
got
out
of
me
,
or
made
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
not
good
for
the
Leaving
Shop
,
I
am
not
good
for
the
Boarding
-
House
,
I
am
not
good
for
anything
in
your
way
to
the
extent
of
sixpenn'orth
of
halfpence
.
<EOS>
Put
the
idea
aside
,
and
we
shall
get
on
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
're
a
seafaring
man
?
"
argued
Pleasant
,
as
if
that
were
a
sufficient
reason
for
his
being
good
for
something
in
her
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
and
no
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
,
and
I
may
be
again
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
for
you
.
<EOS>
Wo
n't
you
take
my
word
for
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
conversation
had
arrived
at
a
crisis
to
justify
Miss
Pleasant
's
hair
in
tumbling
down
.
<EOS>
It
tumbled
down
accordingly
,
and
she
twisted
it
up
,
looking
from
under
her
bent
forehead
at
the
man
.
<EOS>
In
taking
stock
of
his
familiarly
worn
rough
-
weather
nautical
clothes
,
piece
by
piece
,
she
took
stock
of
a
formidable
knife
in
a
sheath
at
his
waist
ready
to
his
hand
,
and
of
a
whistle
hanging
round
his
neck
,
and
of
a
short
jagged
knotted
club
with
a
loaded
head
that
peeped
out
of
a
pocket
of
his
loose
outer
jacket
or
frock
.
<EOS>
He
sat
quietly
looking
at
her
;
but
,
with
these
appendages
partially
revealing
themselves
,
and
with
a
quantity
of
bristling
oakum
-
colored
head
and
whisker
,
he
had
a
formidable
appearance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
take
my
word
for
it
?
<EOS>
he
asked
again
.
  
<EOS>
Pleasant
answered
with
a
short
dumb
nod
.
<EOS>
He
rejoined
with
another
short
dumb
nod
.
<EOS>
Then
he
got
up
and
stood
with
his
arms
folded
,
in
front
of
the
fire
,
looking
down
into
it
occasionally
,
as
she
stood
with
her
arms
folded
,
leaning
against
the
side
of
the
chimney
-
piece
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
wile
away
the
time
till
your
father
comes
,
"
he
said
,
---
<EOS>
"
pray
is
there
much
robbing
and
murdering
of
seamen
about
the
water
-
side
now
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Pleasant
.
  
<EOS>
"
Any
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Complaints
of
that
sort
are
sometimes
made
,
about
Rateliffe
and
Wapping
,
and
up
that
way
.
<EOS>
But
who
knows
how
many
are
true
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
.
<EOS>
And
it
do
n't
seem
necessary
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
say
,
"
observed
Pleasant
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
's
the
reason
for
it
?
<EOS>
Bless
the
sailors
,
it
ai
n't
as
if
they
ever
could
keep
what
they
have
,
without
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
right
.
<EOS>
Their
money
may
be
soon
got
out
of
them
,
without
violence
,
"
said
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
may
,
"
said
Pleasant
;
"
and
then
they
ship
again
,
and
get
more
.
<EOS>
And
the
best
thing
for
'em
,
too
,
to
ship
again
as
soon
as
ever
they
can
be
brought
to
it
.
<EOS>
They
're
never
so
well
off
as
when
they
're
afloat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
why
I
ask
,
"
pursued
the
visitor
,
looking
up
from
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
once
beset
that
way
myself
,
and
left
for
dead
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
?
"
said
Pleasant
.
<EOS>
"
Where
did
it
happen
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
happened
,
"
returned
the
man
,
with
a
ruminative
air
,
as
he
drew
his
right
hand
across
his
chin
,
and
dipped
the
other
in
the
pocket
of
his
rough
outer
coat
,
"
it
happened
somewhere
about
here
as
I
reckon
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
think
it
can
have
been
a
mile
from
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Were
you
drunk
?
"
asked
Pleasant
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
muddled
,
but
not
with
fair
drinking
.
<EOS>
I
had
not
been
drinking
,
you
understand
.
<EOS>
A
mouthful
did
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Pleasant
with
a
grave
look
shook
her
head
;
importing
that
she
understood
the
process
,
but
decidedly
disapproved
.
  
<EOS>
"
Fair
trade
is
one
thing
,
"
said
she
,
"
but
that
's
another
.
<EOS>
No
one
has
a
right
to
carry
on
with
Jack
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
sentiment
does
you
credit
,
"
returned
the
man
,
with
a
grim
smile
;
and
added
,
in
a
mutter
,
"
the
more
so
,
as
I
believe
it
's
not
your
father
's
.
<EOS>
---
Yes
,
I
had
a
bad
time
of
it
,
that
time
.
<EOS>
I
lost
everything
,
and
had
a
sharp
struggle
for
my
life
,
weak
as
I
was
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
get
the
parties
punished
?
"
asked
Pleasant
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
tremendous
punishment
followed
,
"
said
the
man
,
more
seriously
;
 
"
<EOS>
but
it
was
not
of
my
bringing
about
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Of
whose
,
then
?
"
asked
Pleasant
.
  
<EOS>
The
man
pointed
upward
with
his
forefinger
,
and
,
slowly
recovering
that
hand
,
settled
his
chin
in
it
again
as
he
looked
at
the
fire
.
<EOS>
Bringing
her
inherited
eye
to
bear
upon
him
,
Pleasant
Riderhood
felt
more
and
more
uncomfortable
,
his
manner
was
so
mysterious
,
so
stern
,
so
self
-
possessed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Anyways
,
"
said
the
damsel
,
"
I
am
glad
punishment
followed
,
and
I
say
so
.
<EOS>
Fair
trade
with
seafaring
men
gets
a
bad
name
through
deeds
of
violence
.
<EOS>
I
am
as
much
against
deeds
of
violence
being
done
to
seafaring
men
,
as
seafaring
men
can
be
themselves
.
<EOS>
I
am
of
the
same
opinion
as
my
mother
was
,
when
she
was
living
.
<EOS>
Fair
trade
,
my
mother
used
to
say
,
but
no
robbery
and
no
blows
.
"
 
<EOS>
In
the
way
of
trade
Miss
Pleasant
would
have
taken
---
and
indeed
did
take
when
she
could
---
as
much
as
thirty
shillings
a
week
for
board
that
would
be
dear
at
five
,
and
likewise
conducted
the
Leaving
business
upon
correspondingly
equitable
principles
;
yet
she
had
that
tenderness
of
conscience
and
those
feelings
of
humanity
,
that
the
moment
her
ideas
of
trade
were
overstepped
,
she
became
the
seaman
's
champion
,
even
against
her
father
whom
she
seldom
otherwise
resisted
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
she
was
here
interrupted
by
her
father
's
voice
exclaiming
angrily
,
"
Now
,
Poll
Parrot
!
"
<EOS>
and
by
her
father
's
hat
being
heavily
flung
from
his
hand
and
strking
her
face
.
<EOS>
Accustomed
to
such
occasional
manifestations
of
his
sense
of
parental
duty
,
Pleasant
merely
wiped
her
face
on
her
hair
(
which
of
course
had
tumbled
down
)
before
she
twisted
it
up
.
<EOS>
This
was
another
common
procedure
on
the
part
of
the
ladies
of
the
Hole
,
when
heated
by
verbal
or
fistic
altercation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Blest
if
I
believe
such
a
Poll
Parrot
as
you
was
ever
learned
to
speak
!
"
growled
Mr.
Riderhood
,
stooping
to
pick
up
his
hat
,
and
making
a
feint
at
her
with
his
head
and
right
elbow
;
for
he
took
the
delicate
subject
of
robbing
seamen
in
extraordinary
dudgeon
,
and
was
out
of
humour
too
.
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
Poll
Parroting
at
now
?
<EOS>
Ai
n't
you
got
nothing
to
do
but
fold
your
arms
and
stand
a
Poll
Parroting
all
night
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Let
her
alone
,
"
urged
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
She
was
only
speaking
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
her
alone
too
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Mr.
Riderhood
,
eyeing
him
all
over
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
know
she
's
my
daughter
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
do
n't
you
know
that
I
wo
n't
have
no
Poll
Parroting
on
the
part
of
my
daughter
?
<EOS>
No
,
<EOS>
nor
yet
that
I
wo
n't
take
no
Poll
Parroting
from
no
man
?
<EOS>
And
who
may
you
be
,
and
what
may
you
want
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
tell
you
until
you
are
silent
?
"
returned
the
other
fiercely
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"
said
Mr.
Riderhood
,
quailing
a
little
,
"
I
am
willing
to
be
silent
for
the
purpose
of
hearing
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
Poll
Parrot
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
thirsty
,
you
?
"
<EOS>
the
man
asked
,
in
the
same
fierce
short
way
,
after
returning
his
look
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
nat'rally
,
"
said
Mr.
Riderhood
,
"
ai
n't
I
always
thirsty
!
"
 
<EOS>
(
Indignant
at
the
absurdity
of
the
question
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
What
will
you
drink
?
"
demanded
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sherry
wine
,
"
returned
Mr.
Riderhood
,
in
the
same
sharp
tone
,
"
if
you
're
capable
of
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
put
his
hand
in
his
pocket
,
took
out
half
a
sovereign
,
and
begged
the
favour
of
Miss
Pleasant
that
she
would
fetch
a
bottle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
the
cork
undrawn
,
"
he
added
,
emphatically
,
looking
at
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
my
Alfred
David
,
"
muttered
Mr.
Riderhood
,
slowly
relaxing
into
a
dark
smile
,
"
that
you
know
a
move
.
<EOS>
Do
I
know
you
?
<EOS>
N
---
<EOS>
n
---
<EOS>
no
,
I
do
n't
know
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
replied
,
"
No
,
you
do
n't
know
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
so
they
stood
looking
at
one
another
surlily
enough
,
until
Pleasant
came
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
small
glasses
on
the
shelf
,
"
said
Riderhood
to
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Give
me
the
one
without
a
foot
.
<EOS>
I
gets
my
living
by
the
sweat
of
my
brow
,
and
it
's
good
enough
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
This
had
a
modest
self
-
denying
appearance
;
but
it
soon
turned
out
that
as
,
by
reason
of
the
impossibility
of
standing
the
glass
upright
while
there
was
anything
in
it
,
it
required
to
be
emptied
as
soon
as
filled
,
Mr.
Riderhood
managed
to
drink
in
the
proportion
of
three
to
one
.
  
<EOS>
With
his
Fortunatus
's
goblet
ready
in
his
hand
,
Mr.
Riderhood
sat
down
on
one
side
of
the
table
before
the
fire
,
and
the
strange
man
on
the
other
:
<EOS>
Pleasant
occupying
a
stool
between
the
latter
and
the
fireside
.
<EOS>
The
background
,
composed
of
handkerchiefs
,
coats
,
shirts
,
hats
,
and
other
old
articles
"
On
Leaving
,
"
had
a
general
dim
resemblance
to
human
listeners
;
especially
where
a
shiny
black
sou'wester
suit
and
hat
hung
,
looking
very
like
a
clumsy
mariner
with
his
back
to
the
company
,
who
was
so
curious
to
overhear
,
that
he
paused
for
the
purpose
with
his
coat
half
pulled
on
,
and
his
shoulders
up
to
his
ears
in
the
uncompleted
action
.
  
<EOS>
The
visitor
first
held
the
bottle
against
the
light
of
the
candle
,
and
next
examined
the
top
of
the
cork
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
that
it
had
not
been
tampered
with
,
he
slowly
took
from
his
breastpocket
a
rusty
clasp
-
knife
,
and
,
with
a
corkscrew
in
the
handle
,
opened
the
wine
.
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
looked
at
the
cork
,
unscrewed

from
the
corkscrew
,
laid
each
separately
on
the

,
and
,

the
end

the

's
knot
of
his

,
dusted
the
inside
of
the
neck
of
the
bottle
.
<EOS>
All
this
with
great
deliberation
.
  
<EOS>
At
first
Riderhood
had
sat
with
his
footless
glass
extended
at
arm
's
length
for
filling
,
while
the
very
deliberate
stranger
seemed
absorbed
in

.
<EOS>
But
,

his
arm
reverted
home

,
and

was
lowered
and
lowered
until

upside

upon

.
<EOS>
By
the
same

his
attention
became
concentrated
on
the
knife
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
as
the
man
held
out
the

to
fill
all

,
Riderhood
stood

,
leaned
over
the

to
look
closer

,

stared
from

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's

matter
?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
I
know
that
knife
!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
dare

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

to

to

,
and
filled

.
<EOS>
Riderhood
emptied

to
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
there
knife
---
"
  
"
Stop
,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
Your

,

.

"
  
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

.

.

<EOS>
"
Wish
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

!

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

,

,
poor
thing
,
using
her

for

.
   
<EOS>
A
SOLO
AND
<EOS>
A
DUETT
.
 
<EOS>
The
wind
was
blowing
so
hard
when
the
visitor
came
out
at
the
shop
-
door
into
the
darkness
and
dirt
of
Limehouse
Hole
,
that
it
almost
blew
him
in
again
.
<EOS>
Doors
were

,
lamps
were
flickering
or
blown
out
,
signs
were

in
their
frames
,
the
water
of
the
kennels
,
wind
-

,
flew
about
in

like

.
<EOS>
Indifferent
to
the
weather
,
and
even

to
better

for
its

of

,
the
man
looked
about

with

.
"
<EOS>
Thus
much
I
know
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
been
here
since
that
night
,
and
never
was
here
before
that
night
,
but
thus
much
I
recognize
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
which

did
we
take

.
<EOS>
We

I

,
but
I

recall
no

.
<EOS>
Did

by
this

?
<EOS>
Or

that
little
lane
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
tried

,
but
both

,
and
he
came

back

same

.
<EOS>
"
I
remember
there
were
poles

on

,
and
I
remember
a
low
public

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
And

but
a

,

,
a

,
and
a
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
tried
a
new

,
but
made
nothing
of
it
;
walls
,
dark
doorways
,
flights
of
stairs
and
rooms
,
were
too
abundant
.
<EOS>
And
,
like
most

so

,
he
again
and
again
described
a
circle
,
and
found
himself
at
the
point
from
which
he
had

.
<EOS>
"
This
is
like
what
I
have

,
"
said

,
"
where

,

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here

ceased

the
oakum

,
oakum

Riderhood
had

,

,

,

as
like

same
lost
wanted
<EOS>
Mr.
Julius
Handford
,

.
<EOS>

,

,

that

.
<EOS>
Yet

was
the
Secretary

,
Mr.

's
Secretary
.
<EOS>
For
John
Rokesmith
,

,
was
as
like
that
same
lost
wanted
Mr.
Julius
Handford
as
never

was
like
another

this

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
clue
to

scene

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
Not

.
<EOS>
But

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
With

he
abandoned

,

,
and

past
Limehouse
Church
.
<EOS>
At
the
great
iron
gate
of
the
churchyard
he
stopped
and
looked
in
.
<EOS>
He
looked
up

the
high

spectrally
resisting
the

,
and
he
looked
round
at
the
white

,
like
enough
to
the
dead
in
their
winding
-
sheets
,
and
he
counted
the
nine
tolls
of

clock
-
bell
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
sensation
not
experienced
by
many
mortals
,
"
said
he
,
"
to
be
looking
into
a
churchyard
on
a
wild

night
,
and
to
feel
that
I
no
more
hold
a
place
among
the
living
than
these
dead
do
,
and
even
to
know
that
I
lie
buried
somewhere
else
,
as
they
lie
buried
here
.
<EOS>
Nothing
uses
me
to
it
.
<EOS>
A
spirit
that
was
once
a
man
could
hardly
feel
stranger
or
lonelier
,
going
unrecognized
among
mankind
,
than
I
feel
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
this
is
the
fanciful
side
of
the
situation
.
<EOS>
It
has
a
real
side
,
so
difficult
that
,
though
I
think
of
it
every
day
,
I
never
thoroughly
think
it
out
.
<EOS>
Now
,
let
me
determine
to
think
it
out
as
I
walk
home
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
evade
it
,
as
many
men
---
perhaps
most
men
---
do
evade
thinking
their
way
through
their
greatest
perplexity
.
<EOS>
I
will
try
to
pin
myself
to
mine
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
evade
it
,
John
Harmon
;
do
n't
evade
it
;
 
think
it
out
!
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
came
back
to
England
,
attracted
to
the
country
with
which
I
had
none
but
<EOS>
most
miserable
associations
,
by
the
accounts
of
my
fine
inheritance
that
found
me
abroad
,
I
came
back
,
shrinking
from
my
father
's
money
,
shrinking
from
my
father
's
memory
,
mistrustful
of
being
forced
on
a
mercenary
wife
,
mistrustful
of
my
father
's
intention
in
thrusting
that
marriage
on
me
,
mistrustful
that
I
was
already
growing
avaricious
,
mistrustful
that
I
was
slackening
in

that

Coffee
House
,
or
taken
Mrs.
Wilfer
's
lodgings
.
  
<EOS>
"
Some
twelve
days
I
lived
at
that
hotel
,
before
the
night
when
I
saw
the
corpse
of
Radfoot
at
the
Police
Station
.
<EOS>
The
inexpressible
mental
horror
that
I
laboured
under
,
as
one
of
the
consequences
of
the
poison
,
makes
the
interval
seem
greatly
longer
,
but
I
know
it
can
not
have
been
longer
.
<EOS>
That
suffering
has
gradually
weakened
and
weakened
since
,
and
has
only
come
upon
me
by
starts
,
and
I
hope
I
am
free
from
it
now
;
but
even
now
,
I
have
sometimes
to
think
,
constrain
myself
,
and
stop
before
speaking
,
or
I
could
not
say
the
words
I
want
to
say
.
  
<EOS>
"
Again
I
ramble
away
from
thinking
it
out
to
the
end
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
so
far
to
the
end
that
I
need
be
tempted
to
break
off
.
<EOS>
Now
,
on
straight
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
examined
the
newspapers
every
day
for
tidings
that
I
was
missing
,
but
saw
none
.
<EOS>
Going
out
that
night
to
walk
(
for
I
kept
retired
while
it
was
light
)
,
I
found
a
crowd
assembled
round
a
placard
posted
at
Whitehall
.
<EOS>
It
described
myself
,
John
Harmon
,
as
found
dead
and
mutilated
in
the
river
under
circumstances
of
strong
suspicion
,
described
my
dress
,
described
the
papers
in
my
pockets
,
and
stated
where
I
was
lying
for
recognition
.
<EOS>
In
a
wild
incautious
way
I
hurried
there
,
and
there
---
with
the
horror
of
the
death
I
had
escaped
,
before
my
eyes
in
its
most
appalling
shape
,
added
to
the
inconceivable
horror
tormenting
me
at
that
time
when
the
poisonous
stuff
was
strongest
on
me
---
I
perceived
that
Radfoot
had
been
murdered
by
some
unknown
hands
for
the
money
for
which
he
would
have
murdered
me
,
and
that
probably
we
had
both
been
shot
into
the
river
from
the
same
dark
place
into
the
same
dark
tide
,
when
the
stream
ran
deep
and
strong
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
night
I
almost
gave
up
my
mystery
,
though
I
suspected
no
one
,
could
offer
no
information
,
knew
absolutely
nothing
save
that
the
murdered
man
was
not
I
,
but
Radfoot
.
<EOS>
Next
day
while
I
hesitated
,
and
next
day
while
I
hesitated
,
it
seemed
as
if
the
whole
country
were
determined
to
have
me
dead
.
<EOS>
The
Inquest
declared
me
dead
,
the
Government
proclaimed
me
dead
;
I
could
not
listen
at
my
fireside
for
five
minutes
to
the
outer
noises
,
but
it
was
borne
into
my
ears
that
I
was
dead
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
John
Harmon
died
,
and
Julius
Handford
disappeared
,
and
John
Rokesmith
was
born
.
<EOS>
John
Rokesmith
's
intent
to
-
night
has
been
to
repair
a
wrong
that
he
could
never
have
imagined
possible
,
coming
to
his
ears
through
the
Lightwood
talk
related
to
him
,
and
which
he
is
bound
by
every
consideration
to
remedy
.
<EOS>
In
that
intent
John
Rokesmith
will
persevere
,
as
his
duty
is
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
is
it
all
thought
out
?
<EOS>
All
to
this
time
?
<EOS>
Nothing
omitted
?
<EOS>
No
,
nothing
.
<EOS>
But
beyond
this
time
?
<EOS>
To
think
it
out
through
the
future
,
is
a
harder
though
a
much
shorter
task
than
to
think
it
out
through
the
past
.
<EOS>
John
Harmon
is
dead
.
<EOS>
Should
John
Harmon
come
to
life
?
  
<EOS>
"
If
yes
,
why
?
<EOS>
If
no
,
why
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
<EOS>
yes
,
first
.
<EOS>
To
enlighten
human
Justice
concerning
the
offence
of
one
far
beyond
it
who
may
have
a
living
mother
.
<EOS>
To
enlighten
it
with
the
lights
of
a
stone
passage
,
a
flight
of
stairs
,
a
brown
window
-
curtain
,
and
a
black
man
.
<EOS>
To
come
into
possession
of
my
father
's
money
,
and
with
it
sordidly
to
buy
a
beautiful
creature
whom
I
love
---
I
can
not
help
it
;
reason
has
nothing
to
do
with
it
;
I
love
her
against
reason
---
but
who
would
as
soon
love
me
for
my
own
sake
,
as
she
would
love
the
beggar
at
the
corner
.
<EOS>
What
a
use
for
the
money
,
and
how
worthy
of
its
old
misuses
!
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
take
no
.
<EOS>
The
reasons
why
John
Harmon
should
not
come
to
life
.
<EOS>
Because
he
has
passively
allowed
these
dear
old
faithful
friends
to
pass
into
possession
of
the
property
.
<EOS>
Because
he
sees
them
happy
with
it
,
making
a
good
use
of
it
,
effacing
the
old
rust
and
tarnish
on
the
money
.
<EOS>
Because
they
have
virtually
adopted
Bella
,
and
will
provide
for
her
.
<EOS>
Because
there
is
affection
enough
in
her
nature
,
and
warmth
enough
in
her
heart
,
to
develop
into
something
enduringly
good
,
under
favorable
conditions
.
<EOS>
Because
her
faults
have
been
intensified
by
her
place
in
my
father
's
will
,
and
she
is
already
growing
better
.
<EOS>
Because
her
marriage
with
John
Harmon
,
after
what
I
have
heard
from
her
own
lips
,
would
be
a
shocking
mockery
,
of
which
both
she
and
I
must
always
be
conscious
,
and
which
would
degrade
her
in
her
mind
,
and
me
in
mine
,
and
each
of
us
in
the
other
's
.
<EOS>
Because
if
John
Harmon
comes
to
life
and
does
not
marry
her
,
the
property
falls
into
the
very
hands
that
hold
it
now
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
I
have
?
<EOS>
Dead
,
I
have
found
the
true
friends
of
my
lifetime
still
as
true
as
tender
and
as
faithful
as
when
I
was
alive
,
and
making
my
memory
an
incentive
to
good
actions
done
in
my
name
.
<EOS>
Dead
,
I
have
found
them
when
they
might
have
slighted
my
name
,
and
passed
greedily
over
my
grave
to
ease
and
wealth
,
lingering
by
the
way
,
like
single
-
hearted
children
,
to
recall
their
love
for
me
when
I
was
a
poor
frightened
child
.
<EOS>
Dead
,
I
have
heard
from
the
woman
who
would
have
been
my
wife
if
I
had
lived
,
the
revolting
truth
that
I
should
have
purchased
her
,
caring
nothing
for
me
,
as
a
Sultan
buys
a
slave
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
would
I
have
?
<EOS>
If
the
dead
could
know
,
or
do
know
,
how
the
living
use
them
,
who
among
the
hosts
of
dead
has
found
a
more
disinterested
fidelity
on
earth
than
I
?
<EOS>
Is
not
that
enough
for
me
?
<EOS>
If
I
had
come
back
,
these
noble
creatures
would
have
welcomed
me
,
wept
over
me
,
<EOS>
given
up
everything
to
me
with
joy
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
come
back
,
and
they
have
passed
unspoiled
into
my
place
.
<EOS>
Let
them
rest
in
it
,
and
let
Bella
rest
in
hers
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
course
for
me
then
?
<EOS>
This
.
<EOS>
To
live
the
same
quiet
Secretary
life
,
carefully
avoiding
chances
of
recognition
,
until
they
shall
have
become
more
accustomed
to
their
altered
state
,
and
until
the
great
swarm
of
swindlers
under
many
names
shall
have
found
newer
prey
.
<EOS>
By
that
time
,
the
method
I
am
establishing
through
all
the
affairs
,
and
with
which
I
will
every
day
take
new
pains
to
make
them
both
familiar
,
will
be
,
I
may
hope
,
a
machine
in
such
working

as
that
they
can
keep

going
.
<EOS>
I
know
I
need
but
ask
of
their
generosity
,
to
have
.
<EOS>
When
the
right
time
comes
,
I
will
ask
no

than
will
replace
me
in
my
former
path
of
life
,
and
John
Rokesmith
shall
tread
it
as
contentedly
as
he
may
.
<EOS>
But
John
Harmon
shall
come
back
no
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
I
may
never
,
in
the
days
to
come
afar
off
,
have
any
weak

that
Bella
might
,
in
any

,
have
taken
me
for
my
own
sake
if
I
had
plainly

her
,
I
will
plainly
ask
her
:
proving
beyond
all
question
what
I
already
know
too
well
.
<EOS>
And
now
it
is
all
thought
out
,
from
the
beginning
to
the
end
,
and
my
mind
is
easier
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
deeply
engaged
had
the
living
-
dead
man
been
,
in
thus
communing
with
himself
,
that
he
had
regarded
neither
the
wind
nor
the
way
,
and
had

former
as

he

.
<EOS>
But

now
come
into
the
City
,
where
there
was
a
coach
-
stand
,
he
stood
irresolute
whether
to
go
to
his
lodgings
,
or
to
go
first
to
Mr.
Boffin
's
house
.
<EOS>
He
decided
to
go
round
by
the
house
,
arguing
,
as
he
carried
his
overcoat
upon

arm
,
that
it
was
less
likely
to
attract
notice
if
left
there
,
than
if

to
Holloway
:
both
Mrs.
Wilfer
and
Miss
Lavinia
being
ravenously
curious
touching
every
article
of
which
the
lodger
stood
possessed
.
  
<EOS>
Arriving
at
the
house
,
he
found
that
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
were
out
,
but
that
Miss
Wilfer
was
in
the

.
<EOS>
Miss
Wilfer
had
remained
at
home
,
in
consequence
of
not
feeling
very
well
,
and
had
inquired
in
the

if
Mr.
Rokesmith
were

.
  
<EOS>
"
Make
my
compliments
to
Miss
Wilfer
,
and
say
I
am
here
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Wilfer
's
compliments
came
down
in
return
,
and
,
if
it
were
not
too
much
trouble
,
would
Mr.
Rokesmith
be
so
kind

come
up
before

?
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
too
much
trouble
,
and
Mr.
Rokesmith
came
up
.
  
<EOS>
Oh
she
looked
very
pretty
,
she
looked
very
,
very
pretty
!
<EOS>
If
the
father
of
the
late
John
Harmon
had
but
left
his

unconditionally
to

son
,
and

but
lighted

this
loveable
girl
for

,
and
had

to
make

loving

!
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
Are

not

,
Mr.
Rokesmith
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
quite
well
.
<EOS>
I
was
sorry

,
when
I
came
in
,
that
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A

.
<EOS>
I
had

---

---
and

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

on

,

.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
what

the

's
,

<EOS>
What

you

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
But
,

Rokesmith
,

,

.
<EOS>
A

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
"

,

,
and

all

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
sharp
little
way

she

,
half

,
and

,

Harmon
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do

I

,

Wilfer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly

,

Rokesmith
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

---

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

Rokesmith
,
"

,
"

?
<EOS>
---
I

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because

,

,

,

Wilfer
.
<EOS>
Because

.
<EOS>
Because
I
---
  
shall

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Sir
,
"
returned

,

,
"
you

.
<EOS>
I

that
you

.
<EOS>
If

have
any

,
any

,
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
late
John
Harmon
,
looking

the

face
with

,
and
at
the

as

the

,
would
probably

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to

to

,

,
"
said

,
"
once
for
all
,
and
I
do

it
.
<EOS>
I
have
sat
here
all
this
evening
,
wishing
to
speak
to
you
,
and
determining
to
speak
to
you
,
and
feeling
that
I
must
.
<EOS>
I
beg
for
a
moment
's
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
remained
silent
,
and
she
remained
with
her
face
averted
,
sometimes
making
a
slight
movement
as
if
she
would
turn
and
speak
.
<EOS>
At
length
she
did
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
how
I
am
situated
here
,
sir
,
and
you
know
how
I
am
situated
at
home
.
<EOS>
I
must
speak
to
you
for
myself
,
since
there
is
no
one
about
me
whom
I
could
ask
to
do
so
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
generous
in
you
,
it
is
not
honorable
in
you
,
to
conduct
yourself
towards
me
as
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
ungenerous
or
dishonorable
to
be
devoted
to
you
;
fascinated
by
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Preposterous
!
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
The
late
John
Harmon
might
have
thought
it
rather
a
contemptuous
and
lofty
word
of
repudiation
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
now
feel
obliged
to
go
on
,
"
pursued
the
Secretary
,
"
though
it
were
only
in
self
-
explanation
and
self
-
defence
.
<EOS>
I
hope
,
Miss
Wilfer
,
that
it
is
not
unpardonable
---
even
in
me
---
to
make
an
honest
declaration
of
an
honest
devotion
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
An
honest
declaration
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
Bella
,
with
emphasis
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
otherwise
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
request
,
sir
,
"
said
Bella
,
taking
refuge
in
a
touch
of
timely
resentment
,
"
that
I
may
not
be
questioned
.
<EOS>
You
must
excuse
me
if
I
decline
to
be
cross
-
examined
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Miss
Wilfer
,
this
is
hardly
charitable
.
<EOS>
I
ask
you
nothing
but
<EOS>
what
your
own
emphasis
suggests
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
waive
even
that
question
.
<EOS>
But
what
I
have
declared
,
I
take
my
stand
by
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
recall
the
avowal
of
my
earnest
and
deep
attachment
to
you
,
and
I
do
not
recall
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
reject
it
,
sir
,
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
blind
and
deaf
if
I
were
not
prepared
for
the
reply
.
<EOS>
Forgive
my
offence
,
for
it
carries
its
punishment
with
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
punishment
?
"
asked
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
my
present
endurance
none
?
<EOS>
But
excuse
me
;
I
did
not
mean
to
cross
-
examine
you
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
take
advantage
of
a
hasty
word
of
mine
,
"
said
Bella
with
a
little
sting
of
self
-
reproach
,
"
to
make
me
seem
<EOS>
---
I
do
n't
know
what
.
<EOS>
I
spoke
without
consideration
when
I
used
it
.
<EOS>
If
that
was
bad
,
I
am
sorry
;
but
you
repeat
it
after
consideration
,
and
that
seems
to
me
to
be
at
least
no
better
.
<EOS>
For
the
rest
,
I
beg
it
may
be
understood
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
that
there
is
an
end
of
this
between
us
,
now
and
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
and
for
ever
,
"
he
repeated
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
appeal
to
you
,
sir
,
"
proceeded
Bella
with
increasing
spirit
,
"
not
to
pursue
me
.
<EOS>
I
appeal
to
you
not
to
take
advantage
of
your
position
in
this
house
to
make
my
position
in
it
distressing
and

.
<EOS>
I
appeal
to
you
to
discontinue
your
habit
of
making
your
misplaced
attentions
as
plain
to
Mrs.
Boffin
as
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
I
done
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
think
you
have
,
"
replied
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
In
any
case
it
is
not
your
fault
if
you
have
not
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
wrong
in
that
impression
.
<EOS>
I
should
be
very
sorry
to
have
justified
it
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
have
not
.
<EOS>
For
the
future
there
is
no
apprehension
.
<EOS>
It
is
all
over
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
relieved
to
hear
it
,
"
said
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
far
other
views
in
life
,
and
why
should
you
waste
your
own
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mine
!
"
said
the
Secretary
.
<EOS>
"
My
life
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
curious
tone
caused
Bella
to
glance
at
the
curious
smile
with
which
he
said
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
gone
as
he
glanced
back
.
"
<EOS>
Pardon
me
,
Miss
Wilfer
<EOS>
,
"
he
proceeded
,
when
their
eyes
met
;
"
you
have
used
some
hard
words
,
for
which
I
do
not
doubt
you
have
a
justification
in
your
mind
,
that
I
do
not
understand
.
<EOS>
Ungenerous
and
dishonorable
.
<EOS>
In
what
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
not
be
asked
,
"
said
Bella
,
haughtily
looking
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
not
ask
,
but
the
question
is
imposed
upon
me
.
<EOS>
Kindly
explain
;
or
if
not
kindly
,
justly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
sir
!
"
said
Bella
,
raising
her
eyes
to
his
,
after
a
little
struggle
to
forbear
,
"
is
it
generous
and
honorable
to
use
the
power
here
which
your
favor
with
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
and
your
ability
in
your
place
give
you
,
against
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Against
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
generous
and
honorable
to
form
a
plan
for
gradually
bringing
their
influence
to
bear
upon
a
suit
which
I
have
shown
you
that
I
do
not
like
,
and
which
I
tell
you
that
I
utterly
reject
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
late
John
Harmon
could
have
borne
a
good
deal
,
but
he
would
have
been
cut
to
the
heart
by
such
a
suspicion
as
this
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
it
be
generous
and
honorable
to
step
into
your
place
---
if
you
did
so
,
for
I
do
n't
know
that
you
did
,
and
I
hope
you
did
not
---
  
anticipating
,
or
knowing
beforehand
,
that
I
should
come
here
,
and
designing
to
take
me
at
this

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
This
mean
and
cruel
disadvantage
,
"
said
the
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
assented
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
kept
silence
for
a
little
while
;
then
merely
said
,
"
You
are
wholly
mistaken
,
Miss
Wilfer
;
wonderfully
mistaken
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
,
however
,
that
it
is
your
fault
.
<EOS>
If
I
deserve
better
things
of
you
,
you
do
not
know
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
At
least
,
sir
,
"
retorted
Bella
,
with
her
old
indignation
rising
,
"
you
know
the
history
of
my
being
here
at
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
heard
Mr.
Boffin
say
that
you
are
master
of
every
line
and
word
of
that
<EOS>
will
,
as
you
are
master
of
all
his

.
<EOS>
And
was

not
enough
that
I
should
have
been
willed
away
,
like
a
horse
,
or
a
dog
,
or
a

;
but
must
you
too
begin
to
dispose
of
me
in

,
and

me
,
as

as
I
had
ceased
to
be
the

the

of
the

?
<EOS>
Am

for

to
be

of

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Believe
me
,
"
returned
the
Secretary
,
"
you
are
wonderfully
mistaken
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
glad
to
know
it
,
"
answered
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
if
you
ever
will
.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
.
<EOS>
Of
course
I
shall
be
careful
to
conceal

of
this

from
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,

.
<EOS>
Trust
me
,
what
you
have
complained
of
is
at
an
end
for
ever
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
I
have
spoken
,
then
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
painful
and
difficult
,
but
it
is
done
.
<EOS>
If
I
have
hurt
you
,
I
hope
you
will
forgive
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
inexperienced
and
impetuous
,
and
I
have
been
a
little

;
but
I
really
am
not
so
bad
as
I
dare
say
I
appear
,
or
as
you
think
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
quitted
the
room
when
Bella
had
said
this
,
relenting
in
her
wilful
inconsistent
way
.
<EOS>
Left
alone
,
she
threw
herself
back
on
her
ottoman
,
and
said
,
"
I
did
n't
know
the
lovely
woman
was
such
a
Dragon
!
"
<EOS>
Then
,
she
got
up
and
looked
in
the
glass
,
and
said
to
her
image
,
"
You
have
been
positively
swelling
your
features
,
you
little
fool
!
"
<EOS>
Then
,
she
took
an
impatient
walk
to
the
other
end
of
the
room
and
back
,
and
said
,
"
I
wish
Pa
was
here
to
have
a
talk
about
an
avaricious
marriage
;
but
he
is
better
away
,
poor
dear
,
for
I
know
I
should
pull
his
hair
if
he
was
here
.
"
<EOS>
And
then
she
threw
her
work
away
,
and
threw
her
book
after
it
,
and
sat
down
and
hummed
a
tune
,
and
hummed
it
out
of
tune
,
and
quarrelled
with
it
.
  
<EOS>
And
John
Rokesmith
,
what
did
he
?
  
<EOS>
He
went
down
to
his
room
,
and
buried
John
Harmon
many
additional
fathoms
deep
.
<EOS>
He
took
his
hat
,
and
walked
out
,
and
,
as
he
went
to
Holloway
or
anywhere
else
---
not
at
all
minding
where
---
  
heaped
mounds
upon
mounds
of
earth
over
John
Harmon
's
grave
.
<EOS>
His
walking
did
not
bring
him
home
until
the
dawn
of
day
.
<EOS>
And
so
busy
had
he
been
all
night
,
piling
and
piling
weights
upon
weights
of
earth
above
John
Harmon
's
grave
,
that
by
that
time
John
Harmon
lay
buried
under
a
whole
Alpine
range
;
and
still
the
Sexton
Rokesmith
accumulated
mountains
over
him
,
lightening
his
labour
with
the
dirge
,
"
Cover
him
,
crush
him
,
keep
him
down
!
"
   
<EOS>
STRONG
OF
PURPOSE
.
 
<EOS>
The
sexton
-
task
of
piling
earth
above
John
Harmon
all
night
long
,
was
not
conducive
to
sound
sleep
;
but
Rokesmith
had
some
broken
morning
rest
,
and
rose
strengthened
in
his
purpose
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
over
now
.
<EOS>
No
ghost
should
trouble
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
's
peace
;
invisible
and
voiceless
,
the
ghost
should
look
on
for
a
little
while
longer
at
the
state
of
existence
out
of
which
it
had
departed
,
and
then
should
for
ever
cease
to
haunt
the
scenes
in
which
it
had
no
place
.
  
<EOS>
He
went
over
it
all
again
.
<EOS>
He
had
lapsed
into
the
condition
in
which
he
found
himself
,
as
many
a
man
lapses
into
many
a
condition
,
without
perceiving
the
accumulative
power
of
its
separate
circumstances
.
<EOS>
When
in
the
distrust
engendered
by
his
wretched
childhood
and
the
action
for
evil
---
never
yet
for
good
within
his
knowledge
then
---
  
of
his
father
and
his
father
's
wealth
on
all
within
their
influence
,
he
conceived
the
idea
of
his
first
deception
,
it
was
meant
to
be
harmless
,
it
was
to
last
but
<EOS>
a
few
hours
or
days
,
it
was
to
involve
in
it
only
the
girl
so
capriciously
forced
upon
him
,
and
upon
whom
he
was
so
capriciously
forced
,
and
it
was
honestly
meant
well
towards
her
.
<EOS>
For
,
if
he
had
found
her
unhappy
in
the
prospect
of
that
marriage
(
through
her
heart
inclining
to
another
man
or
for
any
other
cause
)
,
he
would
seriously
have
said
:
"
This
is
another
of
the
old
perverted
uses
of
the
misery
-
making
money
.
<EOS>
I
will
let
it
go
to
my
and
my
sister
's
only
protectors
and
friends
.
<EOS>
"
When
the
snare
into
which
he
fell
so
outstripped
his
first
intention
as
that
he
found
himself
placarded
by
the
police
authorities
upon
the
London
walls
for
dead
,
he
confusedly
accepted
the
aid
that
fell
upon
him
,
without
considering
how
firmly
it
must
seem
to
fix
the
Boffins
in
their
accession
to
the
fortune
.
<EOS>
When
he
saw
them
,
and
knew
them
,
and
even
from
his
vantage
-
ground
of
inspection
could
find
no
flaw
in
them
,
he
asked
himself
,
"
<EOS>
And
shall
I
come
to
life
to
dispossess
such
people
as
these
?
<EOS>
"
There
was
no
good
to
set
against
the
putting
of
them
to
that
hard
proof
.
<EOS>
He
had
heard
from
Bella
's
own
lips
when
he
stood
tapping
at
the
door
on
that
night
of
his
taking
the
lodgings
,
that
the
marriage
would
have
been
on
her
part
thoroughly
mercenary
.
<EOS>
He
had
since
tried
her
,
in
his
own
unknown
person
and
supposed
station
,
and
she
not
only
rejected
his
advances
but
resented
them
.
<EOS>
Was
it
for
him
to
have
the
shame
of
buying
her
,
or
the
meanness
of
punishing
her
?
<EOS>
Yet
,
by
coming
to
life
and
accepting
the
condition
of
the
inheritance
,
he
must
 
do
the
former
;
and
by
coming
to
life
and
rejecting
it
,
he
must
do
the
latter
.
  
<EOS>
Another
consequence
that
he
had
never
foreshadowed
,
was
the
implication
of
an
innocent
man
in
his
supposed
murder
.
<EOS>
He
would
obtain
complete
retractation
from
the
accuser
,
and
set
the
wrong
right
;
but
clearly
the
wrong
could
never
have
been
done
if
he
had
never
planned
a
deception
.
<EOS>
Then
,
whatever

or

the
deception

,
it
was
manful

to
accept
as
among
its

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
Thus
John
Rokesmith
in
the

,
and

buried
John
Harmon
<EOS>
still

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

for

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

---
  
<EOS>

to

something
quick
about
it
,
for
I
'm
a
getting
to
be
an
old
one
.
<EOS>
But
I
'm
a
strong
one
too
,
and
travel
and
weather
never
hurt
me
yet
!
<EOS>
Now
,
be
so
kind
as
speak
for
me
to
your
lady
and
gentleman
,
and
tell
'em
what
I
ask
of
their
good
friendliness
to
let
me
do
,
and
why
I
ask
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
felt
that
there
was
no
gainsaying
what
was
urged
by
this
brave
old
heroine
,
and
he
presently
repaired
to

Boffin

recommended

to
let
Betty
Higden
have

,
at

.
<EOS>
"
It
would

far

to
your
kind

,

"
he

,
"
to

for

,
but
it

.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
was
not

the

.
<EOS>
She
and
her
husband
had
worked
too
,
and
had

simple
faith

clean

.
<EOS>
If

owed
a

to
Betty
Higden
,
of

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Betty
,
"

,

John

,

,
"
granted

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
'
Twould

,
"

,

"
<EOS>
'

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
was

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
To

,
my
deary
,
to
-

.
<EOS>
Bless
ye
,
I
am
used
to

.
<EOS>
I
know
many

country

.
<EOS>
When

,
I
have

many

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
Betty

which

Rokesmith

---
"

<EOS>
"
---

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
We

"
  
<EOS>
"

---

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
Do

"

,

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
He

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

John

Resolved

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>
Pleasant

<EOS>
So

,

.
<EOS>
"
Does

sister

---
  
<EOS>
groundless

---

<EOS>
"
  
"
No

,
"

<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
sister
,
"

,

over

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

;
 
I

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
When

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
Bradley

knotted

,

,

"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Within

the
oakum

,

's

in

,

.
  
<EOS>
All

.
<EOS>
It

that

,

<EOS>

to

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
"

"

wo

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Patrons

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

ai

Old

It

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"
A

.

<EOS>
The

,

.
   
<EOS>
THE
WHOLE
CASE
SO
FAR
.
 
<EOS>
Bradley
Headstone
held
fast
by
that
other
interview
<EOS>
he
was
to
have
with
Lizzie
Hexam
.
<EOS>
In
stipulating
for
it
,
he
had
been
impelled
by
a
feeling
little
short
of
desperation
,
and
the
feeling
abided
by
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
very
soon
after
his
interview
with
the
Secretary
,
that
he

Charley
Hexam
set
out
one

,

Miss

,

this

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
dolls
'
dressmaker
,
"
said
Bradley
,
"
is
favourable
neither
to
me
nor

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
pert
crooked

chit
,
Mr.
Headstone
!
<EOS>
I
knew
she
would
put

in
the
way
,
if

,

.
<EOS>
It

I

to
the
City
to
-
night
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So

,
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
She

in

another
.
<EOS>
She

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

?
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
One

!
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
However
,

,

,

-

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly

,

.
<EOS>
Why
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Except

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Everything
on

,
"
repeated

.
<EOS>
"
Respectability
,

,

!
"

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Naturally
,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
we

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
Bradley
thought
again
,
"
Except
your
sister
,
perhaps
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
grey
dusty
withered
evening
in
London
city
has
not
a
hopeful
aspect
.
<EOS>
The
closed
warehouses
and
offices
have
an
air
of
death
about
them
,
and
the
national
dread
of
colour
has
an
air
of
mourning
.
<EOS>
The
towers
and
steeples
of
the
many
house
-
encompassed
churches
,
dark
and
dingy
as
the
sky
that
seems
descending
on
them
,
are
no
relief
to
the
general
gloom
;
a
sun
-
dial
on
a
church
-
wall
has
the
look
,
in
its
useless
black
shade
,
of
having
failed
in
its
business
enterprise
and
stopped
payment
for
ever
;
melancholy
waifs
and
strays
of
housekeepers
and
porters
sweep
melancholy
waifs
and
strays
of
papers
and
pins
into
the
kennels
,
and
other
more
melancholy
waifs
and
strays
explore
them
,
searching
and
stooping
and
poking
for
anything
to
sell
.
<EOS>
The
set
of
humanity
outward
from
the
City
is
as
a
set
of
prisoners
departing
from
gaol
,
and
dismal
Newgate
seems
quite
as
fit
a
stronghold
for
the
mighty
Lord
Mayor
as
his
own
state
-
dwelling
.
  
<EOS>
On
such
an
evening
,
when
the
city
grit
gets
into
the
hair
and
eyes
and
skin
,
and
when
the
fallen
leaves
of
the
few
unhappy
city
trees
grind
down
in
corners
under
wheels
of
wind
,
the
schoolmaster
and
the
pupil
emerged
upon
the
Leadenhall
Street
region
,
spying
eastward
for
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
Being
something
too
soon
in
their
arrival
,
they
lurked
at
a
corner
,
waiting
for
her
to
appear
.
<EOS>
The
best
-
looking
among
us
will
not
look
very
well
,
lurking
at
a
corner
,
and
Bradley
came
out
of
that
disadvantage
very
poorly
indeed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
she
comes
,
Mr.
Headstone
!
<EOS>
Let
us
go
forward
and
meet
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
they
advanced
,
she
saw
them
coming
,
and
seemed
rather
troubled
.
<EOS>
But
she
greeted
her
brother
with
the
usual
warmth
,
and
touched
the
extended
hand
of
Bradley
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
where
are
you
going
,
Charley
,
dear
?
<EOS>
"
she
asked
him
then
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nowhere
.
<EOS>
We
came
on
purpose
to
meet
you
.
"
  
"
To
meet
me
,
Charley
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
We
are
going
to
walk
with
you
.
<EOS>
But
do
n't
let
us
take
the
great
leading
streets
where
every
one
walks
,
and
we
ca
n't
hear
ourselves
speak
.
<EOS>
Let
us
go
by
the
quiet
backways
.
<EOS>
Here
's
a
large
paved
court
by
this
church
,
and
quiet
,
too
.
<EOS>
Let
us
go
up
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
it
's
not
in
the
way
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
it
is
,
"
said
the
boy
,
petulantly
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
in
my
way
,
and
my
way
is
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
not
released
his
hand
,
and
,
still
holding
it
,
looked
at
him
with
a
kind
of
appeal
.
<EOS>
He
avoided
her
eyes
,
under
pretence
of
saying
,
"
Come
along
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
"
<EOS>
Bradley
walked
at
his
side
 
---
not
at
hers
---
and
the
brother
and
sister
walked
hand
in
hand
.
<EOS>
The
court
brought
them
to
a
churchyard
;
a
paved
square
court
,
with
a
raised
bank
of
earth
about
breast
high
,
in
the
middle
,
enclosed
by
iron
rails
.
<EOS>
Here
,
conveniently
and
healthfully
elevated
above
the
level
of
the
living
,
were
the
dead
,
and
the
tombstones
,
some
of
the
latter
droopingly
inclined
from
the
perpendicular
,
as
if
they
were
ashamed
of
the
lies
they
told
.
  
<EOS>
They
paced
the
whole
of
this
place
once
,
in
a
constrained
and
uncomfortable
manner
,
when
the
boy
stopped
and
said
:
  
"
Lizzie
,
Mr.
Headstone
has
something
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish
to
be
an
interruption
either
to
him
or
to
you
,
and
so
I
'll
go
and
take
a
little
stroll
and
come
back
.
<EOS>
I
know
in
a
general
way
what
Mr.
Headstone
intends
to
say
,
and
I
very
highly
approve
of
it
,
as
I
hope
---
and
indeed
I
do
not
doubt
---
you
will
.
<EOS>
I
need
n't
tell
you
,
Lizzie
,
that
I
am
under
great
obligations
to
Mr.
Headstone
,
and
that
I
am
very
anxious
for
Mr.
Headstone
to
succeed
in
all
he
undertakes
.
<EOS>
As
I
hope
---
and
as
,
indeed
,
I
do
n't
doubt
---
you
must
be
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
"
returned
his
sister
,
detaining
his
hand
as
he
withdrew

,
"
I
think
you
had
better
stay
.
<EOS>
I
think
Mr.
Headstone
had
better
not
say
what
he
thinks
of
saying
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
how
do
you
know
what
it
is
?
"
returned
the
boy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
you
do
n't
,
but
---
"
  
"
Perhaps
you
do
n't
?
<EOS>
No
,
Liz
,
I
should
think
not
.
<EOS>
If
you
knew
what
it
was
,
you
would
give
me
a
very
different
answer
.
<EOS>
There
;
 
let
go
;
be
sensible
.
<EOS>
I
wonder
you
do
n't
remember
that
Mr.
Headstone
is
looking
on
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
allowed
him
to
separate
himself
from
her
,
and
he
,
after
saying
,
"
Now
,
Liz
,
be
a
rational
girl
and
a
good
sister
,
"
walked
away
.
<EOS>
She
remained
standing
alone
with
Bradley
Headstone
,
and
it
was
not
until
she
raised
her
eyes
,
that
he
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
"
he
began
,
"
when
I
saw
you
last
,
that
there
was
something
unexplained
,
which
might
perhaps
influence
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
come
this
evening
to
explain
it
.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
will
not
judge
of
me
by
my
hesitating
manner
when
I
speak
to
you
.
<EOS>
You
see
me
at
my
greatest
disadvantage
.
<EOS>
It
is
most
unfortunate
for
me
that
I
wish
you
to
see
me
at
my
best
,
and
that
I
know
you
see
me
at
my
worst
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
moved
slowly
on
when
he
paused
,
and
he
moved
slowly
on
beside
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
egotistical
to
begin
by
saying
so
much
about
myself
,
"
 
he
resumed
,
"
but
whatever
I
say
to
you
seems
,
even
in
my
own
ears
,
below
what
I
want
to
say
,
and
different
from
what
I
want
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
help
it
.
<EOS>
So
it
is
.
<EOS>
You
are
the
ruin
of
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
started
at
the
passionate
sound
of
the
last
words
,
and
at
the
passionate
action
of
his
hands
,
with
which
they
were
accompanied
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
you
are
the
ruin
---
the
ruin
---
the
ruin
---
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
resources
in
myself
,
I
have
no
confidence
in
myself
<EOS>
,
I
have
no
government
of
myself
when
you
are
near
me
or
in
my
thoughts
.
<EOS>
And
you
are
always
in
my
thoughts
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
never
been
quit
of
you
since
I
first
saw
you
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
was
a
wretched
day
for
me
!
<EOS>
That
was
a
wretched
,
miserable
day
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
touch
of
pity
for
him
mingled
with
her
dislike
of
him
,
and
she
said
:
"
Mr.
Headstone
,
I
am
grieved
to
have
done
you
any
harm
,
but
I
have
never
meant
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
he
cried
,
despairingly
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
I
seem
to
have
reproached
you
,
instead
of
revealing
to
you
the
state
of
my
own
mind
!
<EOS>
Bear
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
am
always
wrong
when
you
are
in
question
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
doom
.
"
  
<EOS>
Struggling
with
himself
,
and
by
times
looking
up
at
the
deserted
windows
of
the
houses
as
if
there
could
be
anything
written
in
their
grimy
panes
that
would
help
him
,
he
paced
the
whole
pavement
at
her
side
,
before
he
spoke
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
try
to
give
expression
to
what
is
in
my
mind
;
it
shall
and
must
be
spoken
.
<EOS>
Though
you
see
me
so
confounded
---
though
you
strike
me
so
helpless
---
I
ask
you
to
believe
that
there
are
many
people
who
think
well
of
me
;
that
there
are
some
people
who
highly
esteem
me
;
that
I
have
in
my
way
won
a
station
which
is
considered
worth
winning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Surely
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
I
do
believe
it
.
<EOS>
Surely
I
have
always
known
it
from
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
you
to
believe
that
if
I
were
to
offer
my
home
such
as
it
is
,
my
station
such
as
it
is
,
my
affections
such
as
they
are
,
to
any
one
of
the
best
considered
,
and
best
qualified
,
and
most
distinguished
,
among
the
young
women
engaged
in
my
calling
,
they
would
probably
be
accepted
.
<EOS>
Even
readily
accepted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
doubt
it
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
with
her
eyes
upon
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
sometimes
had
it
in
my
thoughts
to
make
that
offer
and
to
settle
down
<EOS>
as
many
men
of
my
class
do
:
I
on
the
one
side
of
a
school
,
my
wife
on
the
other
,
both
of
us
interested
in
the
same
work
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
have
you
not
done
so
?
"
asked
Lizzie
Hexam
.
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
not
do
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Far
better
that
I
never
did
!
<EOS>
The
only
one
grain
of
comfort
I
have
had
these
many
weeks
,
"
he
said
,
always
speaking
passionately
,
and
,
when
most

,
