that
former
action
of
his
hands
,
which
was
like
flinging
his
heart
's
blood
down
before
her
in
drops
upon
the
pavement
-
stones
;
"
the
only
one
grain
of
comfort
I
have
had
these
many
weeks
is
,
that
I
never
did
.
<EOS>
For
if
I
had
,
and
if
the
same
spell
had
come
upon
me
for
my
ruin
,
I
know
I
should
have
broken
that
tie
asunder
as
if
it
had
been
thread
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
glanced
at
him
with
a
glance
of
fear
,
and
a
shrinking
gesture
.
<EOS>
He
answered
,
as
if
she
had
spoken
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
It
would
not
have
been
voluntary
on
my
part
,
any
more
than
it
is
voluntary
in
me
to
be
here
now
.
<EOS>
You
draw
me
to
you
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
shut
up
in
a
strong
prison
,
you
would
draw
me
out
.
<EOS>
I
should
break
through
the
wall
to
come
to
you
.
<EOS>
If
I
were
lying
on
a
sick
bed
,
you
would
draw
me
up
---
to
stagger
to
your
feet
and
fall
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
wild
energy
of
the
man
,
now
quite
let
loose
,
was
absolutely
terrible
.
<EOS>
He
stopped
and
laid
his
hand
upon
a
piece
of
the
coping
of
the
burial
-
ground
enclosure
,
as
if
he
would
have
dislodged
the
stone
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
man
knows
till
the
time
comes
,
what
depths
are
within
him
.
<EOS>
To
some
men
it
never
comes
;
let
them
rest
and
be
thankful
!
<EOS>
To
me
,
you
brought
it
;
on
me
,
you
forced
it
;
and
the
bottom
of
this
raging
sea
,
"
striking
himself
upon
the
breast
,
"
has
been
heaved
up
ever
since
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Headstone
,
I
have
heard
enough
.
<EOS>
Let
me
stop
you
here
.
<EOS>
It
will
be
better
for
you
and
better
for
me
.
<EOS>
Let
us
find
my
brother
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Not
yet
.
<EOS>
It
shall
and
must
be
spoken
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
in
torments
ever
since
I
stopped
short
of
it
before
.
<EOS>
You
are
alarmed
.
<EOS>
It
is
another
of
my
miseries
that
I
can
not
speak
to
you
or
speak
of
you
without
stumbling
at
every
syllable
,
unless
I
let
the
check
go
altogether
and
run
mad
.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
man
lighting
the
lamps
.
<EOS>
He
will
be
gone
directly
.
<EOS>
I
entreat
of
you
<EOS>
let
us
walk
round
this
place
again
.
<EOS>
You
have
no
reason
to
look
alarmed
;
I
can
restrain
myself
,
and
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
yielded
to
the
entreaty
---
how
could
she
do
otherwise
!
<EOS>
---
and
they
paced
the
stones
in
silence
.
<EOS>
One
by
one
the
lights
leaped
up
making
the
cold
grey
church
tower
more
remote
,
and
they
were
alone
again
.
<EOS>
He
said
no
more
until
they
had
regained
the
spot
where
he
had
broken
off
;
there
,
he
again
stood
still
,
and
again
grasped
the
stone
.
<EOS>
In
saying
what
he
said
then
,
he
never
looked
at
her
;
but
looked
at
it
and
wrenched
at
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
what
I
am
going
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
love
you
.
<EOS>
What
other
men
may
mean
when
they
use
that
expression
,
I
can
not
tell
;
what
I
mean
is
,
that
I
am
under
the
influence
of
some
tremendous
attraction
which
I
have
resisted
in
vain
,
and
which
overmasters
me
.
<EOS>
You
could
draw
me
to
fire
,
you
could
draw
me
to
water
,
you
could
draw
me
to
the
gallows
,
you
could
draw
me
to
any
death
,
you
could
draw
me
to
anything
I
have
most
avoided
,
you
could
draw
me
to
any
exposure
and
disgrace
.
<EOS>
This
and
the
confusion
of
my
thoughts
,
so
that
I
am
fit
for
nothing
,
is
what
I
mean
by
your
being
the
ruin
of
me
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
would
return
a
favourable
answer
to
my
offer
of
myself
in
marriage
,
you
could
draw
me
to
any
good
---
  
<EOS>
every
good
---
with
equal
force
.
<EOS>
My
circumstances
are
quite
easy
,
and
you
would
want
for
nothing
.
<EOS>
My
reputation
stands
quite
high
,
and
would
be
a
shield
for
yours
.
<EOS>
If
you
saw
me
at
my
work
,
able
to
do
it
well
and
respected
in
it
,
you
might
even
come
to
take
a
sort
of
pride
in
me
;
---
I
would
try
hard
that
you
should
.
<EOS>
Whatever
considerations
I
may
have
thought
of
against
this
offer
,
I
have
conquered
,
and
I
make
it
with
all
my
heart
.
<EOS>
Your
brother
favors
me
to
the
utmost
,
and
it
is
likely
that
we
might
live
and
work
together
;
anyhow
,
it
is
certain
that
he
would
have
my
best
influence
and
support
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
that
I
could
say
more
if
I
tried
.
<EOS>
I
might
only
weaken
what
is
ill
enough
said
as
it
is
.
<EOS>
I
only
add
that
if
it
is
any
claim
on
you
to
be
in
earnest
,
I
am
in
thorough
earnest
,
dreadful
earnest
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
powdered
mortar
from
under
the
stone
at
which
he
wrenched
,
rattled
on
the
pavement
to
confirm
his
words
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Headstone
---
"
  
"
Stop
!
<EOS>
I
implore
you
,
before
you
answer
me
,
to
walk
round
this
place
once
more
.
<EOS>
It
will
give
you
a
minute
's
time
to
think
,
and
me
a
minute
's
time
to
get
some
fortitude
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again
she
yielded
,
to
the
entreaty
,
and
again
they
came
back
to
the
same
place
,
and
again
he
worked
at
the
stone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
,
"
he
said
,
with
his
attention
apparently
engrossed
by
it
,
"
yes
,
or
no
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Headstone
,
I
thank
you
sincerely
,
I
thank
you
gratefully
,
and
hope
you
may
find
a
worthy
wife
before
long
and
be
very
happy
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
no
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
no
short
time
necessary
for
reflection
;
no
weeks
or
days
?
"
he
asked
,
in
the
same
half
-
suffocated
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
None
whatever
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Are
you
quite
decided
,
and
is
there
no
chance
of
any
change
in
my
favor
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
quite
decided
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
and
I
am
bound
to
answer
<EOS>
I
am
certain
there
is
none
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
he
,
suddenly
changing
his
tone
and
turning
to
her
,
and
bringing
his
clenched
hand
down
upon
the
stone
with
a
force
that
laid
the
knuckles
raw
and
bleeding
;
"
then
I
hope
that
I
may
never
kill
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
dark
look
of
hatred
and
revenge
with
which
the
words
broke
from
his
livid
lips
,
and
with
which
he
stood
holding
out
his
smeared
hand
as
if
it
held
some
weapon
and
had
just
struck
a
mortal
blow
,
made
her
so
afraid
of
him
that
she
turned
to
run
away
.
<EOS>
But
he
caught
her
by
the
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Headstone
,
let
me
go
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Headstone
,
I
must
call
for
help
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
I
who
should
call
for
help
,
"
he
said
;
"
you
do
n't
know
yet
how
much
I
need
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
working
of
his
face
as
she
shrank
from
it
,
glancing
round
for
her
brother
and
uncertain
what
to
do
,
might
have
extorted
a
cry
from
her
in
another
instant
;
but
all
at
once
he
sternly
stopped
it
and
fixed
it
,
as
if
Death
itself
had
done
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
<EOS>
You
see
I
have
recovered
myself
.
<EOS>
Hear
me
out
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
much
of
the
dignity
of
courage
,
as
she
recalled
her
self
-
reliant
life
and
her
right
to
be
free
from
accountability
to
this
man
,
she
released
her
arm
from
his
grasp
and
stood
looking
full
at
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
never
been
so
handsome
,
in
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
A
shade
came
over
them
while
he
looked
back
at
her
,
as
if
she
drew
the
very
light
out
of
them
to
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
time
,
at
least
,
I
will
leave
nothing
unsaid
,
"
he
went
on
,
folding
his
hands
before
him
,
clearly
to
prevent
his
being
betrayed
into
any
impetuous
gesture
;
"
this
last
time
at
least
I
will
not
be
tortured
with
after
-
thoughts
of
a
lost
opportunity
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
it
of
him
you
spoke
in
your
ungovernable
rage
and
violence
?
"
 
<EOS>
Lizzie
Hexam
demanded
with
spirit
.
  
<EOS>
He
bit
his
lip
,
and
looked
at
her
,
and
said
never
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
Was
it
Mr.
Wrayburn
that
you
threatened
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
bit
his
lip
again
,
and
looked
at
her
,
and
said
never
a
word
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
asked
me
to
hear
you
out
,
and
you
will
not
speak
.
<EOS>
Let
me
find
my
brother
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
<EOS>
I
threatened
no
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
Her
look
dropped
for
an
instant
to
his
bleeding
hand
.
<EOS>
He
lifted
it
to
his
mouth
,
wiped
it
on
his
sleeve
,
and
again
folded
it
over
the
other
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
"
he
repeated
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
mention
that
name
again
and
again
,
Mr.
Headstone
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Because
it
is
the
text
of
the
little
I
have
left
to
say
.
<EOS>
Observe
!
<EOS>
There
are
no
threats
in
it
.
<EOS>
If
I
utter
a
threat
,
stop
me
,
and
fasten
it
upon
me
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
worse
threat
than
was
conveyed
in
his
manner
of
uttering
the
name
,
could
hardly
have
escaped
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
haunts
you
.
<EOS>
You
accept
favors
from
him
.
<EOS>
You
are
willing
enough
to
listen
to
him
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
,
as
well
as
he
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Wrayburn
has
been
considerate
and
good
to
me
,
sir
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
proudly
,
"
in
connexion
with
the
death
and
with
the
memory
of
my
poor
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
doubt
.
<EOS>
He
is
of
course
a
very
considerate
and
a
very
good
man
,
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
nothing
to
you
,
I
think
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
with
an
indignation
she
could
not
repress
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
yes
,
he
is
.
<EOS>
There
you
mistake
.
<EOS>
He
is
much
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
he
be
to
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
can
be
a
rival
to
me
among
other
things
,
"
said
Bradley
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Headstone
,
"
returned
Lizzie
,
with
a
burning
face
,
"
it
is
cowardly
in
you
to
speak
to
me
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
But
it
makes
me
able
to
tell
you
that
I
do
not
like
you
,
and
that
I
never
have
liked
you
from
the
first
,
and
that
no
other
living
creature
has
anything
to
do
with
the
effect
you
have
produced
upon
me
for
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
His
head
bent
for
a
moment
,
as
if
under
a
weight
,
and
he
then
looked
up
again
,
moistening
his
lips
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
going
on
with
the
little
I
had
left
to
say
.
<EOS>
I
knew
all
this
about
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
all
the
while
you
were
drawing
me
to
you
.
<EOS>
I
strove
against
the
knowledge
,
but
quite
in
vain
.
<EOS>
It
made
no
difference
in
me
.
<EOS>
With
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
in
my
mind
,
I
went
on
.
<EOS>
With
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
in
my
mind
,
I
spoke
to
you
just
now
.
<EOS>
With
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
in
my
mind
,
I
have
been
set
aside
and
I
have
been
cast
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
give
those
names
to
my
thanking
you
for
your
proposal
and
declining
it
,
is
it
my
fault
,
Mr.
Headstone
?
"
said
Lizzie
,
compassionating
the
bitter
struggle
he
could
not
conceal
,
almost
as
much
as
she
was
repelled
and
alarmed
by
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
complaining
,
"
he
returned
,
"
I
am
only
stating
the
case
.
<EOS>
I
had
to
wrestle
with
my
self
-
respect
when
I
submitted
to
be
drawn
to
you
in
spite
of
Mr.
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
You
may
imagine
how
low
my
self
-
respect
lies
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
hurt
and
angry
;
but
repressed
herself
in
consideration
of
his
suffering
,
and
of
his
being
her
brother
's
friend
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
it
lies
under
his
feet
,
"
said
Bradley
,
unfolding
his
hands
in
spite
of
himself
,
and
fiercely
motioning
with
them
both
towards
the
stones
of
the
pavement
.
<EOS>
"
Remember
that
!
<EOS>
It
lies
under
that
fellow
's
feet
,
and
he
treads
upon
it
and
exults
above
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
does
not
!
"
said
Lizzie
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
does
!
"
said
Bradley
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
stood
before
him
face
to
face
,
and
he
crushed
me
down
in
the
dirt
of
his
contempt
,
and
walked
over
me
.
<EOS>
Why
?
<EOS>
Because
he
knew
with
triumph
what
was
in
store
for
me
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
you
talk
quite
wildly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Quite
collectedly
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
say
too
well
.
<EOS>
Now
I
have
said
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
used
no
threat
,
remember
;
I
have
done
no
more
than
show
you
how
the
case
stands
;
---
how
the
case
stands
,
so
far
.
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
moment
her
brother
sauntered
into
view
close
by
.
<EOS>
She
darted
to
him
,
and
caught
him
by
the
hand
.
<EOS>
Bradley
followed
,
and
laid
his
heavy
hand
on
the
boy
's
opposite
shoulder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
Hexam
,
I
am
going
home
.
<EOS>
I
must
walk
home
by
myself
to
-
night
,
and
get
shut
up
in
my
room
without
being
spoken
to
.
<EOS>
Give
me
half
an
hour
's
start
,
and
let
me
be
,
till
you
find
me
at
my
work
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
at
my
work
in
the
morning
just
as
usual
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Clasping
his
hands
,
he
uttered
a
short
unearthly
broken
cry
,
and
went
his
way
.
<EOS>
The
brother
and
sister
were
left
looking
at
one
another
near
a
lamp
in
the
solitary
churchyard
,
and
the
boy
's
face
clouded
and
darkened
,
as
he
said
in
a
rough
tone
:
"
What
is
the
meaning
of
this
?
<EOS>
What
have
you
done
to
my
best
friend
?
<EOS>
Out
with
the
truth
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
Charley
!
"
said
his
sister
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Speak
a
little
more
considerately
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
in
the
humour
for
consideration
,
or
for
nonsense
of
any
sort
,
"
replied
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
been
doing
?
<EOS>
Why
has
Mr.
Headstone
gone
from
us
in
that
way
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
asked
me
---
<EOS>
you
know
he
asked
me
---
to
be
his
wife
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
said
the
boy
,
impatiently
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
was
obliged
to
tell
him
that
I
could
not
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
obliged
to
tell
him
,
"
repeated
the
boy
angrily
,
between
his
teeth
,
and
rudely
pushing
her
away
.
<EOS>
"
You
were
obliged
to
tell
him
!
<EOS>
Do
you
know
that
he
is
worth
fifty
of
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
may
easily
be
so
,
Charley
,
but
I
can
not
marry
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
that
you
are
conscious
that
you
ca
n't
appreciate
him
,
and
do
n't
deserve
him
,
I
suppose
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
I
do
not
like
him
,
Charley
,
and
that
I
will
never
marry
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
soul
,
"
exclaimed
the
boy
,
"
you
are
a
nice
picture
of
a
sister
!
<EOS>
Upon
my
soul
,
you
are
a
pretty
piece
of
disinterestedness
!
<EOS>
And
so
all
my
endeavours
to
cancel
the
past
and
to
raise
myself
in
the
world
,
and
to
raise
you
with
me
,
are
to
be
beaten
down
by
your
low
whims
;
are
they
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
reproach
you
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
her
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
the
boy
,
looking
round
at
the
darkness
.
<EOS>
"
She
wo
n't
reproach
me
!
<EOS>
She
does
her
best
to
destroy
my
fortunes
and
her
own
,
and
she
wo
n't
reproach
me
!
<EOS>
Why
,
you
'll
tell
me
,
next
,
that
you
wo
n't
reproach
Mr.
Headstone
for
coming
out
of
the
sphere
to
which
he
is
an
ornament
,
and
putting
himself
at
your
feet
,
to
be
rejected
by
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Charley
;
I
will
only
tell
you
,
as
I
told
himself
,
that
I
thank
him
for
doing
so
,
that
I
am
sorry
he
did
so
,
and
that
I
hope
he
will
do
much
better
,
and
be
happy
.
"
  
<EOS>
Some
touch
of
compunction
smote
the
boy
's
hardening
heart
as
he
looked
upon
her
,
his
patient
little
nurse
in
infancy
,
his
patient
friend
,
adviser
,
and
reclaimer
in
boyhood
,
the
self
-
forgetting
sister
who
had
done
everything
for
him
.
<EOS>
His
tone
relented
,
and
he
drew
her
arm
through
his
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
come
,
Liz
;
do
n't
let
us
quarrel
:
let
us
be
reasonable
and
talk
this
over
like
brother
and
sister
.
<EOS>
Will
you
listen
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Charley
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
she
replied
through
her
starting
tears
;
"
do
I
not
listen
to
you
,
and
hear
many
hard
things
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
am
sorry
.
<EOS>
There
,
Liz
!
<EOS>
I
am
unfeignedly
sorry
.
<EOS>
Only
you
do
put
me
out
so
.
<EOS>
Now
see
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Headstone
is
perfectly
devoted
to
you
.
<EOS>
He
has
told
me
in
the
strongest
manner
that
he
has
never
been
his
old
self
for
one
single
minute
since
I
first
brought
him
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
Miss
Peecher
,
our
schoolmistress
---
pretty
and
young
,
and
all
that
---
is
known
to
be
very
much
attached
to
him
,
and
he
wo
n't
so
much
as
look
at
her
or
hear
of
her
.
<EOS>
Now
,
his
devotion
to
you
must
be
a
disinterested
one
;
must
n't
it
?
<EOS>
If
he
married
Miss
Peecher
,
he
would
be
a
great
deal
better
off
in
all
worldly
respects
,
than
in
marrying
you
.
<EOS>
Well
then
;
he
has
nothing
to
get
by
it
,
has
he
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
Heaven
knows
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
then
,
"
said
the
boy
;
"
that
's
something
in
his
favour
,
and
a
great
thing
.
<EOS>
Then
I
come
in
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Headstone
has
always
got
me
on
,
and
he
has
a
good
deal
in
his
power
,
and
of
course
if
he
was
my
brother
-
in
-
law
he
would
n't
get
me
on
less
,
but
would
get
me
on
more
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Headstone
comes
and
confides
in
me
,
in
a
very
delicate
way
,
and
says
,
`
`
I
hope
my
marrying
your
sister
would
be
agreeable
to
you
,
Hexam
,
and
useful
to
you
?
"
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
`
`
There
's
nothing
in
the
world
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
that
I
could
be
better
pleased
with
.
"
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Headstone
says
,
`
`
Then
I
may
rely
upon
your
intimate
knowledge
of
me
for
your
good
word
with
your
sister
,
Hexam
?
"
<EOS>
"
And
I
say
,
`
`
Certainly
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
and
naturally
I
have
a
good
deal
of
influence
with
her
.
"
<EOS>
"
So
I
have
;
have
n't
I
,
Liz
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Charley
.
"
  
"
Well
said
!
<EOS>
Now
,
you
see
,
we
begin
to
get
on
,
the
moment
we
begin
to
be
really
talking
it
over
,
like
brother
and
sister
.
<EOS>
Very
well
.
<EOS>
Then
you
come
in
.
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Headstone
's
wife
you
would
be
occupying
a
most
respectable
station
,
and
you
would
be
holding
a
far
better
place
in
society
than
you
hold
now
,
and
you
would
at
length
get
quit
of
the
river
-
side
and
the
old
disagreeables
belonging
to
it
,
and
you
would
be
rid
for
good
of
dolls
'
dressmakers
and
their
drunken
fathers
,
and
the
like
of
that
.
<EOS>
Not
that
I
want
to
disparage
Miss
Jenny
Wren
:
I
dare
say
she
is
all
very
well
in
her
way
;
but
her
way
is
not
your
way
as
Mr.
Headstone
's
wife
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
see
,
Liz
,
on
all
three
accounts
---
on
Mr.
Headstone
's
,
on
mine
,
on
yours
---
nothing
could
be
better
or
more
desirable
.
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
walking
slowly
as
the
boy
spoke
,
and
here
he
stood
still
,
to
see
what
effect
he
had
made
.
<EOS>
His
sister
's
eyes
were
fixed
upon
him
;
but
as
they
showed
no
yielding
,
and
as
she
remained
silent
,
he
walked
her
on
again
.
<EOS>
There
was
some
discomfiture
in
his
tone
as
he
resumed
,
though
he
tried
to
conceal
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Having
so
much
influence
with
you
,
Liz
,
as
I
have
,
perhaps
I
should
have
done
better
to
have
had
a
little
chat
with
you
in
the
first
instance
,
before
Mr.
Headstone
spoke
for
himself
.
<EOS>
But
really
all
this
in
his
favour
seemed
so
plain
and
undeniable
,
and
I
knew
you
to
have
always
been
so
reasonable
and
sensible
,
that
I
did
n't
consider
it
worth
while
.
<EOS>
Very
likely
that
was
a
mistake
of
mine
.
<EOS>
However
,
it
's
soon
set
right
.
<EOS>
All
that
need
be
done
to
set
it
right
,
is
for
you
to
tell
me
at
once
that
I
may
go
home
and
tell
Mr.
Headstone
that
what
has
taken
place
is
not
final
,
and
that
it
will
all
come
round
by
-
and
-
by
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
stopped
again
.
<EOS>
The
pale
face
looked
anxiously
and
lovingly
at
him
,
but
she
shook
her
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ca
n't
you
speak
?
"
said
the
boy
sharply
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
unwilling
to
speak
,
Charley
.
<EOS>
If
I
must
,
I
must
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
authorize
you
to
say
any
such
thing
to
Mr.
Headstone
:
I
can
not
allow
you
to
say
any
such
thing
to
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
Nothing
remains
to
be
said
to
him
from
me
,
after
what
I
have
said
for
good
and
all
,
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
this
girl
,
"
cried
the
boy
,
contemptuously
throwing
her
off
again
,
"
calls
herself
a
sister
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
,
dear
,
that
is
the
second
time
that
you
have
almost
struck
me
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
hurt
by
my
words
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
---
Heaven
forbid
!
---
<EOS>
that
you
intended
it
;
but
you
hardly
know
with
what
a
sudden
swing
you
removed
yourself
from
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
However
!
"
said
the
boy
,
taking
no
heed
of
the
remonstrance
,
and
pursuing
his
own
mortified
disappointment
,
"
I
know
what
this
means
,
and
you
shall
not
disgrace
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
means
what
I
have
told
you
,
Charley
,
and
nothing
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
not
true
,
"
said
the
boy
in
a
violent
tone
,
"
and
<EOS>
you
know
it
's
not
.
<EOS>
It
means
your
precious
Mr.
Wrayburn
;
that
's
what
it
means
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
!
<EOS>
If
you
remember
any
old
days
of
ours
together
,
forbear
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
shall
not
disgrace
me
,
"
doggedly
pursued
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
determined
that
after
I
have
climbed
up
out
of
the
mire
,
you
shall
not
pull
me
down
.
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
disgrace
me
if
I
have
nothing
to
do
with
you
,
and
I
will
have
nothing
to
do
with
you
for
the
future
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
!
<EOS>
On
many
a
night
like
this
,
and
many
a
worse
night
,
I
have
sat
on
the
stones
of
the
street
,
hushing
you
in
my
arms
.
<EOS>
Unsay
those
words
without
even
saying
you
are
sorry
for
them
,
and
my
arms
are
open
to
you
still
,
and
so
is
my
heart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
not
unsay
them
.
<EOS>
I
'll
say
them
again
.
<EOS>
You
are
an
inveterately
bad
girl
,
and
a
false
sister
,
and
I
have
done
with
you
.
<EOS>
For
ever
,
I
have
done
with
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
threw
up
his
ungrateful
and
ungracious
hand
as
if
it
set
up
a
barrier
between
them
,
and
flung
himself
upon
his
heel
and
left
her
.
<EOS>
She
remained
impassive
on
the
same
spot
,
silent
and
motionless
,
until
the
striking
of
the
church
clock
roused
her
,
and
she
turned
away
.
<EOS>
But
then
,
with
the
breaking
up
of
her
immobility
came
the
breaking
up
of
the
waters
that
the
cold
heart
of
the
selfish
boy
had
frozen
.
<EOS>
And
"
O
that
I
were
lying
here
with
the
dead
!
"
<EOS>
and
"
O
Charley
,
Charley
,
that
this
should
be
the
end
of
our
pictures
in
the
fire
!
<EOS>
"
were
all
the
words
she
said
,
as
she
laid
her
face
in
her
hands
on
the
stone
coping
.
  
<EOS>
A
figure
passed
by
,
and
passed
on
,
but
stopped
and
looked
round
at
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
figure
of
an
old
man
with
a
bowed
head
,
wearing
a
large
brimmed
low
-
crowned
hat
,
and
a
long
-
skirted
coat
.
<EOS>
After
hesitating
a
little
,
the
figure
turned
back
,
and
,
advancing
with
an
air
of
gentleness
and
compassion
,
said
:
  
"
Pardon
me
,
young
woman
,
for
speaking
to
you
,
but
you
are
under
some
distress
of
mind
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
pass
upon
my
way
and
leave
you
weeping
here
alone
,
as
if
there
was
nothing
in
the
place
.
<EOS>
Can
I
help
you
?
<EOS>
Can
I
do
anything
to
give
you
comfort
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
raised
her
head
at
the
sound
of
these
kind
words
,
and
answered
gladly
,
"
O
,
Mr.
Riah
,
is
it
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
"
I
stand
amazed
!
<EOS>
I
spoke
as
to
a
stranger
.
<EOS>
Take
my
arm
,
take
my
arm
.
<EOS>
What
grieves
you
?
<EOS>
Who
has
done
this
?
<EOS>
Poor
girl
,
poor
girl
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
brother
has
quarrelled
with
me
,
"
sobbed
Lizzie
,
"
and
renounced
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
thankless
dog
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
angrily
.
<EOS>
"
Let
him
go
.
<EOS>
Shake
the
dust
from
thy
feet
and
let
him
go
.
<EOS>
Come
,
daughter
!
<EOS>
Come
home
with
me
---
<EOS>
it
is
but
across
the
road
---
and
take
a
little
time
to
recover
your
peace
and
to
make
your
eyes
seemly
,
and
then
I
will
bear
you
company
through
the
streets
.
<EOS>
For
it
is
past
your
usual
time
,
and
will
soon
be
late
,
and
the
way
is
long
,
and
there
is
much
company
out
of
doors
to
-
night
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
accepted
the
support
he
offered
her
,
and
they
slowly
passed
out
of
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
They
were
in
the
act
of
emerging
into
the
main
thoroughfare
,
when
another
figure
loitering
discontentedly
by
,
and
looking
up
the
street
and
down
it
,
and
all
about
,
started
and
exclaimed
,
"
Lizzie
!
<EOS>
why
,
where
have
you
been
?
<EOS>
Why
,
what
's
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
As
Eugene
Wrayburn
thus
addressed
her
,
she
drew
closer
to
the
Jew
,
and
bent
her
head
.
<EOS>
The
Jew
having
taken
in
the
whole
of
Eugene
at
one
sharp
glance
,
cast
his
eyes
upon
the
ground
,
and
stood
mute
,
  
"
<EOS>
Lizzie
,
what
is
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
I
can
not
tell
you
now
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
tell
you
tonight
,
if
I
ever
can
tell
you
.
<EOS>
Pray
leave
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,
Lizzie
,
I
came
expressly
to
join
you
.
<EOS>
I
came
to
walk
home
with
you
,
having
dined
at
a
coffee
-
house
in
this
neighbourhood
and
knowing
your
hour
.
<EOS>
And
I
have
been
lingering
about
,
"
added
Eugene
,
"
like
a
bailiff
;
or
,
"
with
a
look
at
Riah
,
"
an
old
clothesman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Jew
lifted
up
his
eyes
,
and
took
in
Eugene
once
more
,
at
another
glance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
pray
,
pray
,
leave
me
with
this
protector
.
<EOS>
And
one
thing
more
.
<EOS>
Pray
,
pray
be
careful
of
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mysteries
of
Udolpho
!
"
said
Eugene
,
with
a
look
of
wonder
.
<EOS>
"
May
I
be
excused
for
asking
,
in
the
elderly
gentleman
's
presence
,
who
is
this
kind
protector
?
"
  
"
A
trustworthy
friend
,
"
said
Lizzie
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
relieve
him
of
his
trust
,
"
returned
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
must
tell
me
,
Lizzie
,
what
is
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Her
brother
is
the
matter
,
"
said
the
old
man
,
lifting
up
his
eyes
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Our
brother
the
matter
?
"
returned
Eugene
,
with
airy
contempt
.
<EOS>
"
Our
brother
is
not
worth
a
thought
,
far
less
a
tear
.
<EOS>
What
has
our
brother
done
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
lifted
up
his
eyes
again
,
with
one
grave
look
at
Wrayburn
,
and
one
grave
glance
at
Lizzie
,
as
she
stood
looking
down
.
<EOS>
Both
were
so
full
of
meaning
that
even
Eugene
was
checked
in
his
light
career
,
and
subsided
into
a
thoughtful
"
Humph
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
an
air
of
perfect
patience
<EOS>
the
old
man
,
remaining
mute
and
keeping
his
eyes
cast
down
,
stood
,
retaining
Lizzie
's
arm
,
as
though
,
in
his
habit
of
passive
endurance
,
it
would
be
all
one
to
him
if
he
had
stood
there
motionless
all
night
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
Mr.
Aaron
,
"
said
Eugene
,
who
soon
found
this
fatiguing
,
"
will
be
good
enough
to
relinquish
his
charge
to
me
<EOS>
,
he
will
be
quite
free
for
any
engagement
he
may
have
at
the
Synagogue
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Aaron
,
will
you
have
the
kindness
?
"
  
<EOS>
But
the
old
man
stood
stock
still
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
Mr.
Aaron
,
"
said
Eugene
,
politely
;
"
we
need
not
detain
you
.
"
<EOS>
Then
turning
to
Lizzie
,
"
Is
our
friend
Mr.
Aaron
a
little
deaf
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
hearing
is
very
good
,
Christian
gentleman
,
"
replied
the
old
man
,
calmly
;
"
but
I
will
hear
only
one
voice
to
-
night
,
desiring
me
to
leave
this
damsel
before
I
have
conveyed
her
to
her
home
.
<EOS>
If
she
requests
it
,
I
will
do
it
.
<EOS>
I
will
do
it
for
no
one
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
ask
why
so
,
Mr.
Aaron
?
"
said
Eugene
,
quite
undisturbed
in
his
ease
.
  
<EOS>
"
Excuse
me
.
<EOS>
If
she
asks
me
,
I
will
tell
her
,
"
replied
the
old
man
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
tell
no
one
else
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
ask
you
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
"
and
I
beg
you
to
take
me
home
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
I
have
had
a
bitter
trial
to
-
night
,
and
I
hope
you
will
not
think
me
ungrateful
,
or
mysterious
,
or
changeable
.
<EOS>
I
am
neither
;
I
am
wretched
.
<EOS>
Pray
remember
what
I
said
to
you
.
<EOS>
Pray
,
pray
,
take
care
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Lizzie
,
"
he
returned
,
in
a
low
voice
,
bending
over
her
on
the
other
side
;
"
of
what
?
<EOS>
Of
whom
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Of
any
one
you
have
lately
seen
and
made
angry
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
snapped
his
fingers
and
laughed
.
<EOS>
"
Come
,
"
said
he
,
"
since
no
better
may
be
,
Mr.
Aaron
and
I
will
divide
this
trust
,
and
see
you
home
together
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Aaron
on
that
side
;
I
on
this
.
<EOS>
If
perfectly
agreeable
to
Mr.
Aaron
,
the
escort
will
now
proceed
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
knew
his
power
over
her
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
she
would
not
insist
upon
his
leaving
her
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
,
her
fears
for
him
being
aroused
,
she
would
be
uneasy
if
he
were
out
of
her
sight
.
<EOS>
For
all
his
seeming
levity
and
carelessness
,
he
knew
whatever
he
chose
to
know
of
the
thoughts
of
her
heart
.
  
<EOS>
And
going
on
at
her
side
,
so
gaily
,
regardless
of
all
that
had
been
urged
against
him
;
so
superior
in
his
sallies
and
self
-
possession
to
the
gloomy
constraint
of
her
suitor
and
the
selfish
petulance
of
her
brother
;
so
faithful
to
her
,
as
it
seemed
,
when
her
own
stock
was
faithless
;
what
an
immense
advantage
,
what
an
overpowering
influence
,
were
his
that
night
!
<EOS>
Add
to
the
rest
,
poor
girl
,
that
she
had
heard
him
vilified
for
her
sake
,
and
that
she
had
suffered
for
his
,
and
where
the
wonder
that
his
occasional
tones
of
serious
interest
(
setting
off
his
carelessness
,
as
if
it
were
assumed
to
calm
her
)
,
that
his
lightest
touch
,
his
lightest
look
,
his
very
presence
beside
her
in
the
dark
common
street
,
were
like
glimpses
of
an
enchanted
world
,
which
it
was
natural
for
jealousy
and
malice
and
all
meanness
to
be
unable
to
bear
the
brightness
of
,
and
to
gird
at
as
bad
spirits
might
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
more
being
said
of
repairing
to
Riah
's
,
they
went
direct
to
Lizzie
's
lodging
.
<EOS>
A
little
short
of
the
house
-
door
she
parted
from
them
,
and
went
in
alone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Aaron
,
"
said
Eugene
,
when
they
were
left
together
in
the
street
,
"
with
many
thanks
for
your
company
,
it
remains
for
me
unwillingly
to
say
Farewell
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
the
other
,
"
<EOS>
I
give
you
good
night
,
and
I
wish
that
you
were
not
so
thoughtless
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Aaron
,
"
returned
Eugene
,
"
I
give
you
good
night
,
and
I
wish
(
for
you
are
a
little
dull
)
that
you
were
not
so
thoughtful
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
now
,
that
his
part
was
played
out
for
the
evening
,
and
when
in
turning
his
back
upon
the
Jew
he
came
off
the
stage
,
he
was
thoughtful
himself
.
<EOS>
"
How
did
Lightwood
's
catechism
run
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he
murmured
,
as
he
stopped
to
light
his
cigar
.
<EOS>
"
What
is
to
come
of
it
?
<EOS>
What
are
you
doing
?
<EOS>
Where
are
you
going
?
<EOS>
We
shall
soon
know
now
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
"
<EOS>
with
a
heavy
sigh
.
  
<EOS>
The
heavy
sigh
was
repeated
as
if
by
an
echo
,
an
hour
afterwards
,
when
Riah
,
who
had
been
sitting
on
some
dark
steps
in
a
corner
over
against
the
house
,
arose
and
went
his
patient
way
;
stealing
through
the
streets
in
his
ancient
dress
,
like
the
ghost
of
a
departed
Time
.
   
<EOS>
AN
ANNIVERSARY
OCCASION
.
 
<EOS>
The
estimable
Twemlow
,
dressing
himself
in
his
lodgings
over
the
stable
-
yard
in
Duke
Street
,
Saint
James
's
,
and
hearing
the
horses
at
their
toilette
below
,
finds
himself
on
the
whole
in
a
disadvantageous
position
as
compared
with
the
noble
animals
at
livery
.
<EOS>
For
whereas
,
on
the
one
hand
,
he
has
no
attendant
to
slap
him
soundingly
and
require
him
in
gruff
accents
to
come
up
and
come
over
,
still
,
on
the
other
hand
,
he
has
no
attendant
at
all
;
and
the
mild
gentleman
's
finger
-
joints
and
other
joints
working
rustily
in
the
morning
,
he
could
deem
it
agreeable
even
to
be
tied
up
by
the
countenance
at
his
chamberdoor
,
so
he
were
there
skilfully
rubbed
down
and
slushed
and
sluiced
and
polished
and
clothed
,
while
himself
taking
merely
a
passive
part
in
these
trying
transactions
.
  
<EOS>
How
the
fascinating
Tippins
gets
on
when
arraying
herself
for
the
bewilderment
of
the
senses
of
men
,
is
known
only
to
the
Graces
and
her
maid
;
but
perhaps
even
that
engaging
creature
,
though
not
reduced
to
the
self
-
dependence
of
Twemlow
,
could
dispense
with
a
good
deal
of
the
trouble
attendant
on
the
daily
restoration
of
her
charms
,
seeing
that
as
to
her
face
and
neck
this
adorable
divinity
is
,
as
it
were
,
a
diurnal
species
of
lobster
---
throwing
off
a
shell
every
forenoon
,
and
needing
to
keep
in
a
retired
spot
until
the
new
crust
hardens
.
  
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
Twemlow
doth
at
length
invest
himself
with
collar
and
cravat
and
wristbands
to
his
knuckles
,
and
goeth
forth
to
breakfast
.
<EOS>
And
to
breakfast
with
whom
but
his
near
neighbours
,
the
Lammles
of
Sackville
Street
,
who
have
imparted
to
him
that
he
will
meet
his
distant
kinsman
,
Mr.
Fledgely
.
<EOS>
The
awful
Snigsworth
might
taboo
and
prohibit
Fledgely
,
but
the
peaceable
Twemlow
reasons
,
"
If
he
is
my
kinsman
I
did
n't
make
him
so
,
and
to
meet
a
man
is
not
to
know
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
is
the
first
anniversary
of
the
happy
marriage
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
,
and
the
celebration
is
a
breakfast
,
because
a
dinner
on
the
desired
scale
of
sumptuosity
can
not
be
achieved
within
less
limits
than
those
of
the
non
-
existent
palatial
residence
of
which
so
many
people
are
madly
envious
.
<EOS>
So
,
Twemlow
trips
with
not
a
little
stiffness
across
Piccadilly
,
sensible
of
having
once
been
more
upright
in
figure
and
less
in
danger
of
being
knocked
down
by
swift
vehicles
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
that
was
in
the
days
when
he
hoped
for
leave
from
the
dread
Snigs
-
worth
to
do
something
,
or
be
something
,
in
life
,
and
before
that
magnificent
Tartar
issued
the
ukase
,
"
As
he
will
never
distinguish
himself
,
he
must
be
a
poor
gentleman
-
pensioner
of
mine
,
and
let
him
hereby
consider
himself
pensioned
.
"
  
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
my
Twemlow
!
<EOS>
Say
,
little
feeble
grey
personage
,
what
thoughts
are
in
thy
breast
to
-
day
,
of
the
Fancy
---
<EOS>
so
still
to
call
her
who
bruised
thy
heart
when
it
was
green
and
<EOS>
thy
head
brown
---
and
whether
it
be
better
or
worse
,
more
painful
or
less
,
to
believe
in
the
Fancy
to
this
hour
,
than
to
know
her
for
a
greedy
armour
-
plated
crocodile
,
with
no
more
capacity
of
imagining
the
delicate
and
sensitive
and
tender
spot
behind
thy
waistcoat
,
than
of
going
straight
at
it
with
a
knitting
-
needle
.
<EOS>
Say
likewise
,
my
Twemlow
,
whether
it
be
the
happier
lot
to
be
a
poor
relation
of
the
great
,
or
to
stand
in
the
wintry
slush
giving
the
hack
horses
to
drink
out
of
the
shallow
tub
at
the
coach
-
stand
,
into
which
thou
hast
so
nearly
set
thy
uncertain
foot
.
<EOS>
Twemlow
says
nothing
,
and
goes
on
.
  
<EOS>
As
he
approaches
the
Lammles
'
door
,
drives
up
a
little
one
-
horse
carriage
,
containing
Tippins
the
divine
.
<EOS>
Tippins
,
letting
down
the
window
,
playfully
extols
the
vigilance
of
her
cavalier
in
being
in
waiting
there
to
hand
her
out
.
<EOS>
Twemlow
hands
her
out
with
as
much
polite
gravity
as
if
she
were
anything
real
,
and
they
proceed
upstairs
:
<EOS>
Tippins
all
abroad
about
the
legs
,
and
seeking
to
express
that
those
unsteady
articles
are
only
skipping
in
their
native
buoyancy
.
  
<EOS>
And
dear
Mrs.
Lammle
and
dear
Mr.
Lammle
<EOS>
,
how
do
you
do
,
and
when
are
you
going
down
to
what's
-
its
-
name
place
---
Guy
,
Earl
of
Warwick
,
you
know
---
<EOS>
what
is
it
?
<EOS>
---
Dun
Cow
---
to
claim
the
flitch
of
bacon
?
<EOS>
And
Mortimer
,
whose
name
is
for
ever
blotted
out
from
my
list
of
lovers
,
by
reason
first
of
fickleness
and
then
of
base
desertion
,
how
do
you
do
,
wretch
?
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
you
here
!
<EOS>
What
can
you
come
for
,
because
we
are
all
very
sure
beforehand
that
you
are
not
going
to
talk
!
<EOS>
And
Veneering
,
M.P.
,
how
are
things
going
on
down
at
the
house
,
and
when
will
you
turn

people
for

?
<EOS>
And
Mrs.
Veneering
,
my
dear
,
can

that
you
go
down

that

night

,

men

?
<EOS>
Talking
of
which
,
Veneering
,
why
do
n't
you
prose
,
for
you
have
n't
opened
your
lips
there
yet
,
and
we
are
dying
to

what
you
have
got

say

!
<EOS>
Miss
Podsnap
,
charmed
to
see
you
.
<EOS>
Pa
,
here
?
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
Ma
,
neither
?
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Boots
!
<EOS>
Delighted
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Brewer
!
<EOS>
This
is
a
gathering
of
the
clans
.
<EOS>
Thus
Tippins
,
and
surveys
Fledgeby
and
outsiders
through
golden
glass
,
<EOS>
murmuring
as
she
turns
about
and
about
,
in
her
innocent
giddy
way
<EOS>
,
Anybody
else
I
know
?
<EOS>
No
,
I
think
not
.
<EOS>
Nobody
there
.
<EOS>
Nobody
there
.
<EOS>
Nobody
anywhere
!
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
,
all
a
-
glitter
,
produces
his
friend
Fledgeby
,
as
dying
for
the
honour
of
presentation
to
Lady
Tippins
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
presented
,
has
the
air
of
going
to
say
something
,
has
the
air
of
going
to
say
nothing
,
has
an
air
successively
of
meditation
,
of
resignation
,
and
of
desolation
,
backs
on
Brewer
,
makes
the
tour
of
Boots
,
and
fades
into
the
extreme
background
,
feeling
for
his
whisker
,
as
if
it
might
have
turned
up
since
he
was
there
five
minutes
ago
.
  
<EOS>
But
Lammle
has
him
out
again
before
he
has
so
much
as
completely
ascertained
the
bareness
of
the
land
.
<EOS>
He
would
seem
to
be
in
a
bad
way
,
Fledgeby
;
for
Lammle
represents
him
as
dying
again
.
<EOS>
He
is
dying
now
,
of
want
of
presentation
to
Twemlow
.
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
offers
his
hand
.
<EOS>
Glad
to
see
him
.
"
<EOS>
Your
mother
,
sir
,
was
a
connexion
of
mine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
believe
so
,
"
says
Fledgeby
,
"
but
my
mother
and
her
family
were
two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
staying
in
town
?
"
asks
Twemlow
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
always
am
,
"
says
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
like
town
,
"
says
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
But
is
felled
flat
by
Fledgeby
's
taking
it
quite
ill
,
and
replying
,
<EOS>
No
,
he
do
n't
like
town
.
<EOS>
Lammle
tries
to
break
the
force
of
the
fall
,
by
remarking
that
some
people
do
not
like
town
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
retorting
that
he
never
heard
of
any
such
case
but
his
own
,
Twemlow
goes
down
again
heavily
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
nothing
new
this
morning
,
I
suppose
?
"
says
Twemlow
,
returning
to
the
mark
with
great
spirit
.
  
<EOS>
Fledgeby
has
not
heard
of
anything
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
there
's
not
a
word
of
news
,
"
says
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
particle
,
"
adds
Boots
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
an
atom
,
"
chimes
in
Brewer
.
  
<EOS>
Somehow
the
execution
of
this
little
concerted
piece
appears
to
raise
the
general
spirits
as
with
a
sense
of
duty
done
,
and
sets
the
company
a
going
.
<EOS>
Everybody
seems
more
equal
than
before
,
to
the
calamity
of
being
in
the
society
of
everybody
else
.
<EOS>
Even
Eugene
standing
in
a
window
,
moodily
swinging
the
tassel
of
a
blind
,
gives
it
a
smarter
jerk
now
,
as
if
he
found
himself
in
better
case
.
  
<EOS>
Breakfast
announced
.
<EOS>
Everything
on
table
showy
and
gaudy
,
but
with
a
self
-
assertingly
temporary
and
nomadic
air
on
the
decorations
,
as
boasting
that
they
will
be
much
more
showy
and

,
they
will
if
they
can
!
<EOS>
His
marriage
with
Sophronia
was
not
a
marriage
of
interest
on
either
side
:
she
had
her
little
fortune
,
he
had
his
little
fortune
:
they
joined
their
little
fortunes
:
it
was
a
marriage
of
pure
inclination
and
suitability
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
!
<EOS>
Sophronia
and
<EOS>
he
are
fond
of
the
society
of
young
people
;
but
he
is
not
sure
that
their
house
would
be
a
good
house
for
young
people
proposing
to
remain
single
,
since
the
contemplation
of
its
domestic
bliss
might
induce
them
to
change
their
minds
.
<EOS>
He
will
not
apply
this
to
any
one
present
;
certainly
not
to
their
darling
little
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
Again
thank
you
!
<EOS>
Neither
,
by
-
the
-
by
,
will
he
apply
it
to
his
friend
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
He
thanks
Veneering
for
the
feeling
manner
in
which
he
referred
to
their
common
friend
Fledgeby
,
for
he
holds
that
gentleman
in
the
highest
estimation
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
In
fact
(
returning
uexpectedly
to
Fledgeby
)
,
the
better
you
know
him
,
the
more
you
find
in
him
that
you
desire
to
know
.
<EOS>
Again
thank
you
!
<EOS>
In
his
dear
Sophronia
's
name
and
in
his
own
,
thank
you
!
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
has
sat
quite
still
,
with
her
eyes
cast
down
upon
the
table
-
cloth
.
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Lammle
's
address
ends
,
Twemlow
once
more
turns
to
her
involuntarily
,
not
cured
yet
of
that
often
recurring
impression
that
she
is
going
to
speak
to
him
.
<EOS>
This
time
she
really
is
going
to
speak
to
him
.
<EOS>
Veneering
is
talking
with
his
other
next
neighbour
,
and
she
speaks
in
a
low
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Twemlow
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
answers
,
"
I
beg
your
pardon
?
<EOS>
Yes
?
"
<EOS>
Still
a
little
doubtful
,
because
of
her
not
looking
at
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
the
soul
of
a
gentleman
,
and
I
know
I
may
trust
you
.
<EOS>
Will
you
give
me
the
opportunity
of
saying
a
few
words
to
you
when
you
come
up
stairs
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Assuredly
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
honored
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
seem
to
do
so
,
if
you
please
,
and
do
n't
think
it
inconsistent
if
my
manner
should
be
more
careless
than
my
words
.
<EOS>
I
may
be
watched
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Intensely
astonished
,
Twemlow
puts
his
hand
to
his
forehead
,
and
sinks
back
in
his
chair
meditating
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
rises
.
<EOS>
All
rise
.
<EOS>
The
ladies
go
up
stairs
.
<EOS>
The
gentlemen
soon
saunter
after
them
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
has
devoted
the
interval
to
taking
an
observation
of
Boots
's
whiskers
,
Brewer
's
whiskers
,
and
Lammle
's
whiskers
,
and
considering
which
pattern
of
whisker
he
would
prefer
to
produce
out
of
himself
by
friction
,
if
the
Genie
of
the
cheek
would
only
answer
to
his
rubbing
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
drawing
-
room
,
groups
form
as
usual
.
<EOS>
Lightwood
,
Boots
,
and
Brewer
,
flutter
like
moths
around
that
yellow
wax
candle
---
  
guttering
down
,
and
with
some
hint
of
a
winding
-
sheet
in
it
---
Lady
Tippins
.
<EOS>
Outsiders
cultivate
Veneering
,
M.P.
,
and
Mrs.
Veneering
,
W.M.P.
Lammle
stands
with
folded
arms
,
Mephistophelean
in
a
corner
,
with
Georgiana
and
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
,
on
a
sofa
by
a
table
,
invites
Mr.
Twemlow
's
attention
to
a
book
of
portraits
in
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
takes
his
station
on
a
settee
before
her
,
and
Mrs.
Lammle
shows
him
a
portrait
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
reason
to
be
surprised
,
"
she
says
softly
,
"
but
I
wish
you
would
n't
look
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Disturbed
Twemlow
,
making
an
effort
not
to
look
so
,
looks
much
more
so
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
Mr.
Twemlow
,
you
never
saw
that
distant
connexion
of
yours
before
to
-
day
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
,
never
.
"
  
"
Now
that
you
do
see
him
,
you
see
what
he
is
.
<EOS>
You
are
not
proud
of
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
say
the
truth
,
Mrs.
Lammle
,
no
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
knew
more
of
him
,
you
would
be
less
inclined
to
acknowledge
him
.
<EOS>
Here
is
another
portrait
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
has
just
presence
of
mind
enough
to
say
aloud
:
"
Very
like
!
<EOS>
Uncommonly
like
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
noticed
,
perhaps
,
whom
he
favours
with
his
attentions
?
<EOS>
You
notice
where
he
is
now
,
and
how
engaged
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Lammle
---
"
  
She
darts
a
look
at
him
which
he
can
not
comprehend
,
and
shows
him
another
portrait
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
good
;
is
it
not
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Charming
!
<EOS>
"
says
Twemlow
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
like
as
to
be
almost
a
caricature
?
---
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
,
it
is
impossible
to
tell
you
what
the
struggle
in
my
mind
has
been
,
before
I
could
bring
myself
to
speak
to
you
as
I
do
now
.
<EOS>
It
is
only
in
the
conviction
that
I
may
trust
you
never
to
betray
me
,
that
I
can
proceed
.
<EOS>
Sincerely
promise
me
that
you
never
will
betray
my
confidence
 
---
that
you
will
respect
it
,
even
though
you
may
no
longer
respect
me
,
---
and
I
shall
be
as
satisfied
as
if
you
had
sworn
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
on
the
honor
of
a
poor
gentleman
---
"
  
"
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
I
can
desire
no
more
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
,
I
implore
you
to
save
that
child
!
"
  
"
<EOS>
That
child
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
She
will
be
sacrificed
.
<EOS>
She
will
be
inveigled
and
married
to
that
connexion
of
yours
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
partnership
affair
,
a
money
-
speculation
.
<EOS>
She
has
no
strength
of
will
or
character
to
help
herself
,
and
she
is
on
the
brink
of
being
sold
into
wretchedness
for
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Amazing
!
<EOS>
But
what
can
I
do
to
prevent
it
?
"
<EOS>
demands
Twemlow
,
shocked
and
bewildered
to
the
last
degree
.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
is
another
portrait
.
<EOS>
And
not
good
,
is
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Aghast
at
the
light
manner
of
her
throwing
her
head
back
to
look
at
it
critically
<EOS>
,
Twemlow
still
dimly
perceives
the
expediency
of
throwing
his
own
head
back
,
and
does
so
.
<EOS>
Though
he
no
more
sees
the
portrait
than
if
it
were
in
China
.
  
<EOS>
"
Decidedly
not
good
,
"
says
Mrs.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Stiff
and
exaggerated
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
ex
---
<EOS>
"
But
Twemlow
,
in
his
demolished
state
,
can
not
command
the
word
,
and
trails
off
into
"
---
actly
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
Twemlow
,
your
word
will
have
weight
with
her
pompous
,
self
-
blinded
father
.
<EOS>
You
know
how
much
he
makes
of
your
family
.
<EOS>
Lose
no
time
.
<EOS>
Warn
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
warn
him
against
whom
?
"
  
"
Against
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
By
great
good
fortune
Twemlow
receives
a
stimulant
at
this
critical
instant
.
<EOS>
The
stimulant
is
Lammle
's
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
my
dear
,
what
portraits
are
you
showing
Twemlow
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Public
characters
,
Alfred
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Show
him
the
last
of
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Alfred
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
puts
the
book
down
,
takes
another
book
up
,
turns
the
leaves
,
and
presents
the
portrait
to
Twemlow
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
the
last
of
Mr.
Lammle
.
<EOS>
Do
you
think
it
good
?
<EOS>
---
Warn
her
father
against
me
.
<EOS>
I
deserve
it
,
for
I
have
been
in
the
scheme
from
the
first
.
<EOS>
It
is
my
husband
's
scheme
,
your
connexion
's
,
and
mine
.
<EOS>
I
tell
you
this
,
only
to
show
you
the
necessity
of
the
poor
little
foolish
affectionate
creature
's
being
befriended
and
rescued
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
repeat
this
to
her
father
.
<EOS>
You
will
spare
me
so
far
,
and
spare
my
husband
.
<EOS>
For
,
though
this
celebration
of
to
-
day
is
all
a
mockery
,
he
is
my
husband
,
and
we
must
live
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Do
you
think
it
like
?
"
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
,
in
a
stunned
condition
,
feigns
to
compare
the
portrait
in
his
hand
with
the
original
looking
towards
him
from
his
Mephistophelean
corner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
well
indeed
!
<EOS>
"
are
at
length
the
words
which
Twemlow
with
great
difficulty
extracts
from
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
you
think
so
.
<EOS>
On
the
whole
,
I
myself
consider
it
the
best
.
<EOS>
The
others
are
so
dark
.
<EOS>
Now
here
,
for
instance
,
is
another
of
Mr.
Lammle
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
understand
;
I
do
n't
see
my
way
,
<EOS>
"
Twemlow
stammers
,
as
he
falters
over
the
book
with
his
glass
at
his
eye
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
warn
her
father
,
and
not
tell
him
?
<EOS>
Tell
him
how
much
?
<EOS>
Tell
him
how
little
?
<EOS>
I
---
<EOS>
I
---
am
getting
lost
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell
him
I
am
a
match
-
maker
;
tell
him
I
am
an
artful
and
designing
woman
;
tell
him
you
are
sure
his
daughter
is
best
out
of
my
house
and
my
company
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
any
such
things
of
me
;
they
will
all
be
true
.
<EOS>
You
know
what
a
puffed
-
up
man
he
is
,
and
how
easily
you
can
cause
his
vanity
to
take
the
alarm
.
<EOS>
Tell
him
as
much
as
will
give
him
the
alarm
and
make
him
careful
of
her
,
and
spare
me
the
rest
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
,
I
feel
my
sudden
degradation
in
your
eyes
;
familiar
as
I
am
with
my
degradation
in
my
own
eyes
,
I
keenly
feel
the
change
that
must
have
come
upon
me
in
yours
,
in
these
last
few
moments
.
<EOS>
But
I
trust
to
your
good
faith
with
me
as
implicitly
as
when
I
began
.
<EOS>
If
you
knew
how
often
I
have
tried
to
speak
to
you
to
-
day
,
you
would
almost
pity
me
.
<EOS>
I
want
no
new
promise
from
you
on
my
own
account
,
for
I
am
satisfied
,
and
I
always
shall
be
satisfied
,
with
the
promise
you
have
given
me
.
<EOS>
I
can
venture
to
say
no
more
,
for
I
see
that
I
am
watched
.
<EOS>
If
you
would
set
my
mind
at
rest
with
the
assurance
that
you
will
interpose
with
the
father
and
save
this
harmless
girl
,
close
that
book
before
you
return
it
to
me
,
and
I
shall
know
what
you
mean
,
and
deeply
thank
you
in
my
heart
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Alfred
,
Mr.
Twemlow
thinks
the
last
one
the
best
,
and
quite
agrees
with
you
and
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Alfred
advances
.
<EOS>
The
groups
break
up
.
<EOS>
Lady
Tippins
rises
to
go
,
and
Mrs.
Veneering
follows
her
leader
.
<EOS>
For
the
moment
,
Mrs.
Lammle
does
not
turn
to
them
,
but
remains
looking
at
Twemlow
looking
at
Alfred
's
portrait
through
his
eyeglass
.
<EOS>
The
moment
past
,
Twemlow
drops
his
eyeglass
at
its
ribbon
's
length
,
rises
,
and
closes
the
book
with
an
emphasis
which
makes
that
fragile
nursling
of
the
fairies
,
Tippins
,
start
.
  
<EOS>
Then
good
-
bye
and
good
-
bye
,
and
charming
occasion
worthy
of
the
Golden
Age
,
and
more
about
the
flitch
of
bacon
,
and
the
like
of
that
;
 
and
Twemlow
goes
staggering
across
Piccadilly
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
,
and
is
nearly
run
down
by
a
flushed
letter
-
cart
,
and
at
last
drops
safe
in
his
easy
-
chair
,
innocent
good
gentleman
,
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
still
,
and
his
head
in
a
whirl
.
     
<EOS>
A
Long
Lane
.
 
<EOS>
LODGERS
IN
QUEER
STREET
.
 
<EOS>
It
was
a
foggy
day
in
London
,
and
the
fog
was
heavy
and
dark
.
<EOS>
Animate
London
,
with
smarting
eyes
and
irritated
lungs
,
was
blinking
,
wheezing
,
and
choking
;
inanimate
London
was
a
sooty
spectre
,
divided
in
purpose
between
being
visible
and
invisible
,
and
so
being
wholly
neither
.
<EOS>
Gaslights
flared
in
the
shops
with
a
haggard
and
unblest
air
,
as
knowing
themselves
to
be
night
-
creatures
that
had
no
business
abroad
under
the
sun
;
while
the
sun
itself
,
when
it
was
for
a
few
moments
dimly
indicated
through
circling
eddies
of
fog
,
showed
as
if
it
had
gone
out
and
were
collapsing
flat
and
cold
.
<EOS>
Even
in
the
surrounding
country
it
was
a
foggy
day
,
but
there
the
fog
was
grey
,
whereas
in
London
it
was
,
at
about
the
boundary
line
,
dark
yellow
,
and
a
little
within
it
brown
,
and
then
browner
,
and
then
browner
,
until
at
the
heart
of
the
City
 
---
which
call
Saint
Mary
Axe
---
it
was
rusty
-
black
.
<EOS>
From
any
point
of
the
high
ridge
of
land
northward
,
it
might
have
been
discerned
that
the
loftiest
buildings
made
an
occasional
struggle
to
get
their
heads
above
the
foggy
sea
,
and
especially
that
the
great
dome
of
Saint
Paul
's
seemed
to
die
hard
;
but
this
was
not
perceivable
in
the
streets
at
their
feet
,
where
the
whole
metropolis
was
a
heap
of
vapour
charged
with
muffled
sound
of
wheels
,
and
enfolding
a
gigantic
catarrh
.
  
<EOS>
At
nine
o'clock
on
such
a
morning
,
the
place
of
business
of
Pubsey
and
Co.
was
not
the
liveliest
object
even
in
Saint
Mary
Axe
---
which
is
not
a
very
lively
spot
---
with
a
sobbing
gaslight
in
the
countinghouse
window
,
and
a
burglarious
stream
of
fog
creeping
in
to
strangle
it
through
the
keyhole
of
the
main
door
.
<EOS>
But
the
light
went
out
,
and
the
main
door
opened
,
and
Riah
came
forth
with
a
bag
under
his
arm
.
  
<EOS>
Almost
in
the
act
of
coming
out
at
the
door
,
Riah
went
into
the
fog
,
and
lost
to
the
eyes
of
Saint
Mary
Axe
.
<EOS>
But
the
eyes
of
this
history
can
follow
him
westward
,
by
Cornhill
,
Cheapside
,
Fleet
Street
,
and
the
Strand
,
to
Piccadilly
and
the
Albany
.
<EOS>
Thither
he
went
at
his
grave
and
measured
pace
,
staff
in
hand
,
skirt
at
heel
;
 
and
more
than
one
head
,
turning
to
look
back
at
his
venerable
figure
already
lost
in
the
mist
,
supposed
it
to
be
some
ordinary
figure
indistinctly
seen
,
which
fancy
and
the
fog
<EOS>
had
worked
into
that
passing
likeness
.
  
<EOS>
Arrived
at
the
house
in
which
his
master
's
chambers
were
on
the
second
floor
,
Riah
proceeded
up
the
stairs
,
and
paused
at
Fascination
Fledgeby
's
door
.
<EOS>
Making
free
with
neither
bell
nor
knocker
,
he
struck
upon
the
door
with
the
top
of
his
staff
,
and
,
having
listened
,
sat
down
on
the
threshold
.
<EOS>
It
was
characteristic
of
his
habitual
submission
,
that
he
sat
down
on
the
raw
dark
staircase
,
as
many
of
his
ancestors
had
probably
sat
down
in
dungeons
,
taking
what
befell
him
as
it
might
befall
.
  
<EOS>
After
a
time
,
when
he
had
grown
so
cold
as
to
be
fain
to
blow
upon
his
fingers
,
he
arose
and
knocked
with
his
staff
again
,
and
listened
again
,
and
again
sat
down
to
wait
.
<EOS>
Thrice
he
repeated
these
actions
before
his
listening
ears
were
greeted
by
the
voice
of
Fledgeby
,
calling
from
his
bed
,
"
Hold
your
row
!
<EOS>
---
I
'll
come
and
open
the
door
directly
!
"
<EOS>
But
,
in
lieu
of
coming
directly
,
he
fell
into
a
sweet
sleep
for
some
quarter
of
an
hour
more
,
during
which
added
interval
Riah
sat
upon
the
stairs
and
waited
with
perfect
patience
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
the
door
stood
open
,
and
Mr.
Fledgeby
's
retreating
drapery
plunged
into
bed
again
.
<EOS>
Following
it
at
a
respectful
distance
,
Riah
passed
into
the
bed
-
chamber
,
where
a
fire
had
been
sometime
lighted
,
and
was
burning
briskly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
time
of
night
do
you
mean
to
call
it
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Fledgeby
,
turning
away
beneath
the
clothes
,
and
presenting
a
comfortable
rampart
of
shoulder
to
the
chilled
figure
of
the
old
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
it
is
full
half
-
past
ten
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
deuce
it
is
!
<EOS>
Then
it
must
be
precious
foggy
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
foggy
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
raw
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Chill
and
bitter
,
"
said
Riah
,
drawing
out
a
handkerchief
,
and
wiping
the
moisture
from
his
beard
and
long
grey
hair
as
he
stood
on
the
verge
of
the
rug
,
with
his
eyes
on
the
acceptable
fire
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
plunge
of
enjoyment
,
Fledgeby
settled
himself
afresh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Any
snow
,
or
sleet
,
or
slush
,
or
anything
of
that
sort
?
"
<EOS>
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
,
no
.
<EOS>
Not
quite
so
bad
as
that
.
<EOS>
The
streets
are
pretty
clean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
brag
about
it
,
"
returned
Fledgeby
,
disappointed
in
his
desire
to
heighten
the
contrast
between
his
bed
and
the
streets
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
're
always
bragging
about
something
.
<EOS>
Got
the
books
there
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
are
here
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
right
.
<EOS>
I
'll
turn
the
general
subject
over
in

mind
for
a
minute
or
two
,
and
while
I
'm
about
it
<EOS>
you
can
empty
your
bag
and
get
ready
for
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
another
comfortable
plunge
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
fell
asleep
again
.
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
having
obeyed
his
directions
,
sat
down
on
the
edge
of
a
chair
,
and
folding
his
hands
before
him
,
gradually
yielded
to
the
influence
of
the
warmth
,
and
dozed
.
<EOS>
He
was
roused
by
Mr.
Fledgeby
's
appearing
erect
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
,
in
Turkish
slippers
,
rose
-
<EOS>
coloured
Turkish
trousers
(
got
cheap
from
somebody
who
had
cheated
some
other
somebody
out
of
them
)
,
and
a
gown
and
cap
to
correspond
.
<EOS>
In
that
costume
he
would
have
left
nothing
to
be
desired
,
if
he
had
been
further
fitted
out
with
a
bottomless
chair
,
a

,
and
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
old
'
un
!
"
<EOS>
cried

,
in

light

,
"
what
dodgery
are
you
up

next
,
sitting
there
with
you

<EOS>
shut
?
<EOS>
You
ai
n't
asleep
.
<EOS>
Catch
a
weasel
at
it
,

catch
a
Jew
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Truly
,
sir
,
I
fear
I
nodded
,
"
said

old
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
you
!
"
returned
Fledgeby
,
with
a
cunning

.
"
<EOS>
A
telling
move
with
a
good
many
,
I
dare
say
,
but
it
wo
n't
put
me
off

guard
.
<EOS>
Not
a
bad
notion
though
,
if
you
want
to
look
indifferent
in
driving
a

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
are

!
"
  
<EOS>
The

man
shook
his
head
,
gently
repudiating
the
imputation
,
and
suppressed
a

,
and
moved
to
the
table
at
which
Mr.
Fledgeby
was
now
pouring

for

a
cup
of
steaming
and

coffee
from

that
had
stood

on

.
<EOS>
It
was
an
edifying
spectacle
,
the
young
man
in
his
easy
chair
taking
his

,
and
the
old
man
with
his
grey

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
!
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
Fork
out
your
balance
in
hand
,
and
prove
by
figures
how
you
make
it
out
that
it
ai
n't
more
.
<EOS>
First
of
all
,
light
that
candle
.
"
  
<EOS>
Riah
obeyed
,
and
then
taking
a
bag
from

breast
,
and
referring
to
the
sum
in
the
accounts
for
which
they
made
him
responsible
,
told
it
out
upon
the
table
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
told
it
again
with
great
care
,
and
rang
every

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
,
"
he

,
taking
one
up
to
eye
it
closely
,
"
you
have

been
lightening
any

;
but
it
's
a
trade
of
your
people
's
,

.
<EOS>
You

;

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Much

,

,
"

,

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
"
May
I

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"
Fledgeby

<EOS>
"
Do

,

---

---

without

---
sometimes

I

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Bother

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Jews

!
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
That
's

!
<EOS>
Bring

,

do

talk
Jerusalem

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

were

,

Mr.

.
<EOS>
They
and
the

were
all

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Next
,
"

,
"

-
broking

;
the

.
<EOS>
What
queer

,

?
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,

,
"

Riah
,

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Whew
!
"

,
as

.
"
<EOS>
Queer
Street
is
full

just

!
<EOS>
These

;

?

<EOS>
"
In

,
"

,

;
"
or

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Half

-
paper
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
That
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Riah

his

,
and
Fledgeby
cast
his
small

down

.
<EOS>
They
presently
began
to

,
and
he
no

,
than

-

.
<EOS>
Making

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
was
thus
amiably

when
a

outer

,

.
"
<EOS>
Hark
!
<EOS>
That

,
"

;
"

ca

.
<EOS>
"

,

Lammle

,

"

,

?

<EOS>

,

"
Here

!

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

"
  
"
<EOS>
Ha

?

"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Devilish

<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Always

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mr.
---
"
  
"
Riah
,

Saint
Mary

,
"
Fledgeby

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Riah
is
bound

such

made
and
provided
,
"
said
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
only
the
representative
of
another
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
Does
as
he
is
told
by
his
principal
!
<EOS>
Not
his
capital
that
's
invested
in
the
business
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
's
good
!
<EOS>
Ha
ha
ha
ha
!
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
joined
in
the
laugh
and
looked
knowing
;
and
the
more
he
did
both
,
the
more
exquisite
the
secret
joke
became
for
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
said
that
fascinating
gentleman
,
wiping
his
eyes
again
,
"
if
we
go
on
in
this
way
,
we
shall
seem
to
be
almost
making
game
of
Mr.
Riah
,
or
of
Pubsey
and
Co.
Saint
Mary
Axe
,
or
of
somebody
:
which
is
far
from
our
intention
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Riah
,
if
you
would
have
the
kindness
to
step
into
the
next
room
for
a
few
moments
while
I
speak
with
Mr.
Lammle
here
,
I
should
like
to
try
to
make
terms
with
you
once
again
before
you
go
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
who
had
never
raised
his
eyes
during
the
whole
transaction
of
Mr.
Fledgeby
's
joke
,
silently
bowed
and
passed
out
by
the
door
which
Fledgeby
opened
for
him
.
<EOS>
Having
closed
it
on
him
,
Fledgeby
returned
to
Lammle
,
standing
with
his
back
to
the
bedroom
fire
,
with
one
hand
under
his
coat
-
skirts
,
and
all
his
whiskers
in
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
There
's
something
wrong
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
know
it
?
"
demanded
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
you
show
it
,
"
replied
Fledgeby
in
unintentional
rhyme
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
then
;
there
is
,
"
said
Lammle
;
"
there
is
something
wrong
;
 
the
whole
thing
's
wrong
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
<EOS>
"
remonstrated
Fascination
very
slowly
,
and
sitting
down
with
his
hands
on
his
knees
to
stare
at
his
glowering
friend
with
his
back
to
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
tell
you
,
Fledgeby
,
"
repeated
Lammle
,
with
a
sweep
of
his
right
arm
,
"
the
whole
thing
's
wrong
.
<EOS>
The
game
's
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
game
's
up
?
<EOS>
"
demanded
Fledgeby
,
as
slowly
as
before
,
and
more
sternly
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
game
.
<EOS>
Our
game
.
<EOS>
Read
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
Fledgeby
took
a
note
from
his
extended
hand
and
read
it
aloud
.
"
<EOS>
Alfred
Lammle
,
Esquire
.
<EOS>
Sir
:
<EOS>
Allow
Mrs.
Podsnap
and
myself
to
express
our
united
sense
of
the
polite
attentions
of
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
and
yourself
towards
our
daughter
,
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
Allow
us
also
,
wholly
to
reject
them
for
the
future
,
and
to
communicate
our
final
desire
that
the
two
families
may
become
entire
strangers
.
<EOS>
I
have
the
honor
to
be
,
Sir
,
your
most
obedient
and
very
humble
servant
,
John
Podsnap
.
"
 
<EOS>
Fledgeby
looked
at
the
three
blank
sides
of
this
note
,
quite
as
long
and
earnestly
as
at
the
first
expressive
side
,
and
then
looked
at
Lammle
,
who
responded
with
another
extensive
sweep
of
his
right
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whose
doing
is
this
?
"
said
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Impossible
to
imagine
,
"
said
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
suggested
Fledgeby
,
after
reflecting
with
a
very
discontented
brow
,
"
somebody
has
been
giving
you
a
bad
character
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Or
you
,
"
said
Lammle
,
with
a
deeper
frown
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
appeared
to
be
on
the
verge
of
some
mutinous
expressions
,
when
his
hand
happened
to
touch
his
nose
.
<EOS>
A
certain
remembrance
connected
with
that
feature
operating
as
a
timely
warning
,
he
took
it
thoughtfully
between
his
thumb
and
forefinger
,
and
pondered
;
Lammle
meanwhile
eyeing
him
with
furtive
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
This
wo
n't
improve
with
talking
about
.
<EOS>
If
we
ever
find
out
who
did
it
,
we
'll
mark
that
person
.
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
more
to
be

,
except
that
you
undertook
to
do
what
circumstances
prevent
your
doing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
that
you
undertook
to
do
what
you
might
have
done
by
this
time
,
if
you
had
made
a
prompter
use
of
circumstances
,
"
snarled
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
<EOS>
That
,
"
remarked
Fledgeby
,
with
his
hands
in
the
Turkish

,
"
is
matter
of
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
"
said
Lammle
,
in
a
bullying

,
"
am
I
to
understand
that
you
in
any
way
reflect
upon
me
,
or
hint
dissatisfaction
with
me
,
in
this

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Fledgeby
;
"
provided
you
have
brought
my
promissory
note
in

,
and
now

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lammle
produced
it
,
not
without

.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
looked
at
it
,
identified
it
,
twisted
it
up
,
and
threw
it
into
the
fire
.
<EOS>
They
both
looked
at
it
as
it
blazed
,
went
out
,
and
flew
in

ash

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
"
said

,
as

;
"
am
I
to
understand
that
you
in
any

reflect

me
,
or

with

,
in
this

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
Finally
and
unreservedly
no
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fledgeby
,
my
hand
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
took
it
,
saying
,
"
<EOS>
And
if
we
ever
find
out
who
did
this
,
we
'll
mark
that
person
.
<EOS>
And
in
the
most
friendly

,
let
me
mention
one

more
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
what
your
circumstances
are
,
and
I
do
n't
ask
.
<EOS>
You
have
sustained
a
loss
here
.
<EOS>
Many
men
are
liable
to
be
involved
at

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
Lammle
,
do

---
do

---
do

,
I

---
ever
fall

the
hands
of
Pubsey

Co.
in
the
next
room
,
for
they
are

.
<EOS>
Regular
flayers
and

,
my

Lammle
,
"
repeated

with

,
"
and

'll

by

,
from
the

your

to

,
and
grind
every

of
your
skin
to

-

.
<EOS>
You
have
seen
what
Mr.
Riah
is
.
<EOS>
Never
fall
into
his
hands
,
Lammle
,
I
beg

you
as
a
friend
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
,
disclosing
some

at
the

of
this
affectionate
adjuration
,
demanded
why
the
devil
he
ever
should
fall
into
the
hands
of
Pubsey
and
Co.
?
  
<EOS>
"
To
confess

fact
,
I
was

,
"
said
the
candid
Fledgeby
,
"
by
the

which
that
Jew
looked

you
when
he
heard

.
<EOS>
I
did
n't
like
his
eye
.
<EOS>
But
it
may
have
been
the
heated
fancy
of
a
friend
.
<EOS>
Of

you
are

that
you

no

out
,
which
you
may
not

quite
equal
to

,
and
which
can
have
got
into
his
hands
,
it
must
have
been
fancy
.
<EOS>
Still
,
I
did
n't
like
his
eye
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
brooding
Lammle
,
with
certain
white
dints
coming
and
going
in
his

nose
,
looked
as

some

imp
were

.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
,
watching
him
with

in
his
mean
face
which
did
duty
there
for
a
smile
,
looked
very
like
the
tormentor
who
was
pinching
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
must
n't

too

,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
"
or
he
'll
revenge
it
on
my
unfortunate
friend
.
<EOS>
How
's
your
very
clever
and
agreeable
wife
?
<EOS>
She
knows
we
have
broken
down
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
showed
her
the
letter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
much

?
"
asked
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think

would

,
"

,
"
if

go

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
---
She
lays

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
I
will

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,
Lammle
,
"

,

,
"
because

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Then

do

?
<EOS>
To

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very

,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
plainly

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

to

.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
shook
hands
,
and
Lammle
strode
out
pondering
.
<EOS>
Fledgeby
saw
him
into
the
fog
,
and
,
returning
to
the
fire
and
musing
with
his
face
to
it
,
stretched
the
legs
of
the
rose
-
coloured
Turkish
trousers
wide
apart
,
and
meditatively
bent
his
knees
,
as
if
he
were
going
down
upon
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
a
pair
of
whiskers
,
Lammle
,
which
I
never
liked
,
"
murmured
Fledgeby
,
"
and
which
money
ca
n't
produce
;
you
are
boastful
of
your
manners
and
your
conversation
;
you
wanted
to
pull
my
nose
,
and
you
have
let
me
in
for
a
failure
,
and
your
wife
says
I
am
the
cause
of
it
<EOS>
.
<EOS>
I
'll
bowl
you
down
.
<EOS>
I
will
,
though
I
have
no
whiskers
,
"
 
here
he
rubbed
the
places
where
they
were
due
,
"
and
no
manners
,
and
no
conversation
!
"
  
<EOS>
Having
thus
relieved
his
noble
mind
,
he
collected
the

of
the
Turkish

,
straightened

on
his

,
and
called

to
Riah
in
the
next

,
"
Halloa
,
you
sir
!
"
<EOS>
At

of
the
old
man
re
-
entering
with
a
gentleness
monstrously
in
contrast
with
the
character
he
had
given

,
Mr.
Fledgeby
was
so

,
that

,

,
"
<EOS>
Good
!
<EOS>
Good
!
!
<EOS>
Upon
my

it
is

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
old
'
un
,
"
proceeded
Fledgeby
,
when
he
had

his

out
,
"
you
'll
buy
up
these

that
I
mark
with
my
pencil
<EOS>
---
there
's
a
tick

,
and
a

,
and
a
tick
there
---
<EOS>
and
I
wager
<EOS>
two
-
pence
you
'll
afterwards
go
on
squeezing
those
Christians
like
the
Jew
you

.
<EOS>
Now
,

'll

---

,

you
've
capital
enough
somewhere
,

,
but

---
and
that
cheque
<EOS>
I
'll

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When

had

and
taken
a
key
from

to
open
another

,
in
which
was
another
key
that
opened
another
drawer
,
in
which
was
another
key
that
opened
another
drawer
,
in
which
was
the
cheque
book
;
and
when
he
had
written
the
cheque
;
 
and
when
,

process
,

had

his
cheque

in

;
he

old
man
,
with

,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Old
'
un
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
when
the
Jew
had
put
it
in
his

,
and
was
putting
that
in
the
breast
of
his
outer
garment
;
"
so
much
at
present
for
my
affairs
.
<EOS>
Now
a
word
about
affairs
that
are
not

.
<EOS>
Where
is
she
?
"
  
<EOS>
With
his
hand
not
yet
withdrawn
from
the
breast
of
his
garment
,
Riah
started
and
paused
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oho
!
<EOS>
"
said
Fledgeby
,
"
Did
n't
expect
it
!
<EOS>
Where
have
you
hidden
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
Showing
that
he
was
taken
by
surprise
,
the
old
man
looked
at
his
master
with
some
passing

,
which
the
master
highly

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
in
the
house
I
pay
rent
and
taxes
for
in
Saint
Mary
Axe
?
<EOS>
"
 
demanded
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
she
in
your
garden
up
atop
of
that
house
---
gone
up
to
be
dead
,
or
whatever
the
game
is
?
"
asked
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
she
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
Riah
bent
his
eyes
upon
the
ground
,
as
if
considering
whether
he
could
answer
the
question
without
breach
of
faith
,
and
then
silently
raised
them
to
Fledgeby
's
face
,
as
if
he
could
not
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
!
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
press
that
just
now
.
<EOS>
But
I
want
to
know
this
,
and
I
will
know
this
,
mind
you
.
<EOS>
What
are
you
up
to
?
"
  
<EOS>
The

,
with

,
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
For
you
're
a
`
`
regular
pity
<EOS>
the

,
"
"
you

---
if

do

---
`
`

"
"
---

.
<EOS>

;

ca

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
O

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
O
,

,

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Honor

.
<EOS>
Well

<EOS>
Cut

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

?
"
<EOS>
the

<EOS>
"
Oh
,

.
<EOS>
Honor

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
The
old

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

could

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Perhaps

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
The

her
,

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
a

---

.
<EOS>
I

`
`

,

.
"
<EOS>
"
She

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"

"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
done

!
"
<EOS>
said

to

.
<EOS>
"
Slow
,

;

!
"
<EOS>
This

<EOS>
"
A

,

,
"

"
<EOS>
And

Jew

!
<EOS>
Now
,

.
<EOS>
Not

;

.
"
<EOS>
Herein

,

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,
"
by

.
<EOS>
If
your

,

had

something

's

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Having

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
It
do
n't

much
,

a
Jew
,
in

!
"
  
<EOS>
Another

,
made

.
  
<EOS>
"
As

,
"

,
"

,

,

!
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
To

and

not

,

,

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
With

Mr.
Fledgeby
appropriately

to
divest

,

.
<EOS>
Pending
which

,
and
his
morning

,
and
his

with
the
last
infallible

for

upon

human

(
quacks

the
only

he
believed
in
besides

)
,
the
murky

closed
about
him
and
shut

up
in
its

.
<EOS>
If
it
had
never
let
him
out
any
more
,
the
world
would
have
had
no
irreparable
loss
,
but
could
have
easily
replaced
him
from
its
stock
on
hand
.
   
<EOS>
A
RESPECTED
FRIEND
IN
A
NEW
ASPECT
.
 
<EOS>
In
the
evening
of
this
same
foggy
day
when
the
yellow
windowblind
of
Pubsey
and
Co.
was
drawn
down
upon
the
day
's
work
,
Riah
the
Jew
once
more
came
forth
into
Saint
Mary
Axe
.
<EOS>
But
this
time
he
carried
no
bag
,
and
was
not
bound
on
his
master
's
affairs
.
<EOS>
He
passed
over
London
Bridge
,
and
returned
to
the
Middlesex
shore
by
that
of
Westminster
,
and
so
,
ever
wading
through
the
fog
,
waded
to
the
doorstep
of
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Wren
expected
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
see
her
through
the
window
by
the
light
of
her
low
fire
---
carefully
banked
up
with
damp
cinders
that
it
might
last
the
longer
and
waste
the
loss
when
she
was
out
---
  
<EOS>
sitting
waiting
for
him
in
her

.
<EOS>
His
tap
at
the
glass
roused
her
from
the
musing

in
which
she
sat
,
and
she
came
to
the
door
to
open

;
aiding
her
steps
with
a
little
crutch
-
stick
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
evening
,
godmother
!
"
said
Miss
Jenny
Wren
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
laughed
,
and
gave
her
his
arm
to
lean
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
come
in
and
warm
yourself
,
godmother
?
"
asked
Miss
Jenny
Wren
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
if
you
are
ready
,
Cinderella
,
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
exclaimed
Miss
Wren
,

.
"
<EOS>
Now
you
ARE
a
clever

boy
!
<EOS>
If

gave

at
this
establishment
(
but
we
only
keep

)
,
you
should
have
the
first

,
for
taking
me
up
so
quick
.
"
<EOS>
As
she
spake

,
Miss
Wren
removed
the
key
of
the
house
-
door
from
the
keyhole
and
put
it
in
her
pocket
,
and
then
bustlingly
closed
the
door
,
and
tried
it
as
they
both
stood
on
the
step
.
<EOS>
Satisfied
that
her
dwelling
was
safe
<EOS>
,
she
drew
one
hand
through
the
old
man
's
arm
and
prepared
to
ply
her
crutch
-
stick
with
the
other
.
<EOS>
But
the
key
was
an
instrument
of
such
gigantic
proportions
,
that
before
they
started
Riah
proposed
to
carry
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
!
<EOS>
I
'll
carry
it
myself
,
"
returned
Miss
Wren
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
awfully

,
you

,
and
stowed
down
in
my
pocket
it
'll
trim

.
<EOS>
To
let
you
into

secret
,
godmother
,
I
wear
my
pocket
on
my
high
side
,
o
'
purpose
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
they
began
their
plodding
through
the
fog
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
was
truly
sharp
of
you
,
godmother
,
"
resumed

Wren
with
great

,
"
to
understand
me
.
<EOS>
But
,
you
see
,
you
are
so

bright

!
<EOS>
You
look

rest

,
and
so
much

if
you
had
changed

into
that

,
just

,
with

.
<EOS>
Boh
!
"
cried
Miss
Jenny
,
putting
her
face
close
to
the
old
man
's
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
see
your
features
,
godmother
,
behind

beard
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Does
the
fancy

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
That

!
<EOS>

---

<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
Let

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
With

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
O

!
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
Not

<EOS>
Has

He

"

well
of
those

deserve
well

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Right

"

"

---

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

,

's

.
<EOS>
Nothing

but
that
the

was

.
<EOS>
She

Murderer
,

;

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

.

<EOS>
Now

.

.

"

.
<EOS>
Heavy

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

hardly
as
high
as
the
half
door
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Abbey
started
back
at

it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
,
good
God
!
"
said

,

,
"

man
who
made
the
declaration
we
have
just
had
in

.
<EOS>
That
's
Riderhood
!
"
   
<EOS>
THE
SAME
RESPECTED
FRIEND
IN
MORE
ASPECTS
THAN
ONE
.
 
<EOS>
In
sooth
,
it
is
Riderhood
and
no
other
,
or
it
is
the
outer

and

of
Riderhood
and
no
other
,
that
is
borne
into
Miss
Abbey
's
first
-

.
<EOS>
Supple
to

and
turn
as
the
Rogue
has
ever
been
,
he
is
sufficiently
rigid
now
;
and
not
without

of
attendant
feet
,
and

this

that

,
and

of

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Fetch

,
"

.
<EOS>
And

,
"
Fetch
his
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
On

which

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
doctor
-
seeking
messenger
meets
the
doctor
halfway
,
coming
under

of
police
.
<EOS>
Doctor
examines
the
dank
carcase
,
and
pronounces
,
not

,
that
it
is
worth
while

to
reanimate

.
<EOS>
All

best
means
are
at

,
and
everybody

lends
a

,
and
a
heart
and

.
<EOS>
No

for
the
man
;
with

,

,

,

;
but

is

now
,
and

have
a
deep

in

,

because
it
is
life
,

and

.
  
<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
"

"

"

,

,

,

and

"
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
For
,

.
  
<EOS>
Captain
Joey
,
the

,

,

(

"
sim'lar
,
"

,
"
to

,
"
and

,

<EOS>
These

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Stay
!
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
So

,

.
  
<EOS>
No
.
  
<EOS>
Did

?
  
<EOS>
No
.
  
<EOS>
This

,

<EOS>
No
.
  
<EOS>
Over

again
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
See
!
<EOS>
A

!
<EOS>
An

!
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
The

rough

,

,

.
<EOS>
Neither

in
this

,

,

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Now
,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
And

Bob

Riderhood
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Poor

.

She

<EOS>
O

!
<EOS>
Is

?

Her

.

<EOS>
Sweet

Riderhood
.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
And

Tom

,

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

He

"

.

<EOS>
The

,

face

,

"

<EOS>
They

,

,

,

The

.

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
His

rum
;

?
"

Bob
,

.
  
<EOS>
Pleasant

.
  
<EOS>
"

'll

;

?
"

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Which

rumness
;

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
