<EOS>
"
No
,
"
retorts
Bob
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Nor
he
would
n't
have
been
let
in
,
if
he
had
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
short
delusion
is
quite
dispelled
now
.
<EOS>
As
plainly
as
she
sees
on
her
arm
the
old
father
,
unimproved
,
Pleasant
sees
that
everybody
there
will
cut
him
when
he
recovers
consciousness
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
him
away
ever
so
soon
as
I
can
,
"
thinks
Pleasant
with
a
sigh
;
"
he
's
best
at
home
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Presently
they
all
return
,
and
wait
for
him
to
become
conscious
that
they
will
all
be
glad
to
get
rid
of
him
.
<EOS>
Some
clothes
are
got
together
for
him
to
wear
,
his
own
being
saturated
with
water
,
and
his
present
dress
being
composed
of
blankets
.
  
<EOS>
Becoming
more
and
more
uncomfortable
,
as
though
the
prevalent
dislike
were
finding
him
out
somewhere
in
his
sleep
and
expressing
itself
to
him
,
the
patient
at
last
opens
his
eyes
wide
,
and
is
assisted
by
his
daughter
to
sit
up
in
bed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Riderhood
,
"
says
the
doctor
,
"
how
do
you
feel
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
replies
gruffly
,
"
Nothing
to
boast
on
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Having
,
in
fact
,
returned
to
life
in
an
uncommonly
sulky
state
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
to
preach
;
but
I
hope
,
"
says
the
doctor
,
gravely
shaking
his
head
,
"
that
this
escape
may
have
a
good
effect
upon
you
,
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
patient
's
discontented
growl
of
a
reply
is
not
intelligible
;
his
daughter
,
however
,
could
interpret
,
if
she
would
,
that
what
he
says
is
,
he
"
do
n't
want
no
Poll
-
Parroting
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Riderhood
next
demands
his
shirt
;
and
draws
it
on
over
his
head
(
with
his
daughter
's
help
)
exactly
as
if
he
had
just
had
a
Fight
.
  
<EOS>
"
Warn't
it
a
steamer
?
"
he
pauses
to
ask
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
father
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
have
the
law
on
her
,
bust
her
!
<EOS>
and
make
her
pay
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
then
buttons
his
linen
very
moodily
,
twice
or
thrice
stopping
to
examine
his
arms
and
hands
,
as
if
to
see
what
punishment
he
has
received
in
the
Fight
.
<EOS>
He
then
doggedly
demands
his
other
garments
,
and
slowly
gets
them
on
,
with
an
appearance
of
great
malevolence
towards
his
late
opponent
and
all
the
spectators
.
<EOS>
He
has
an
impression
that
his
nose
is
bleeding
,
and
several
times
draws
the
back
of
his
hand
across
it
,
and
looks
for
the
result
,
in
a
pugilistic
manner
,
greatly
strengthening
that
incongruous
resemblance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
's
my
fur
cap
?
"
he
asks
in
a
surly
voice
,
when
he
has
shuffled
his
clothes
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
river
,
"
somebody
rejoins
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
warn't
there
no
honest
man
to
pick
it
up
?
<EOS>
O
'
course
there
was
though
,
and
to
cut
off
with
it
arterwards
.
<EOS>
You
are
a
rare
lot
,
all
on
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Thus
,
Mr.
Riderhood
:
taking
from
the
hands
of
his
daughter
,
with
special
ill
-
will
,
a
lent
cap
,
and
grumbling
as
he
pulls
it
down
over
his
ears
.
<EOS>
Then
,
getting
on
his
unsteady
legs
,
leaning
heavily
upon
her
,
and
growling
"
Hold
still
,
ca
n't
you
?
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
You
must
be
a
staggering
next
,
must
you
?
"
<EOS>
he
takes
his
departure
out
of
the
ring
in
which
he
has
had
that
little
turn
-
up
with
Death
.
   
<EOS>
A
HAPPY
RETURN
OF
THE
DAY
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Wilfer
had
seen
a
full
quarter
of
a
hundred
more
anniversaries
of
their
wedding
day
than
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
had
seen
of
theirs
,
but
they
still
celebrated
the
occasion
in
the
bosom
of
their
family
.
<EOS>
Not
that
these
celebrations
ever
resulted
in
anything
particularly
agreeable
,
or
that
the
family
was
ever
disappointed
by
that
circumstance
on
account
of
having
looked
forward
to
the
return
of
the
auspicious
day
with
sanguine
anticipations
of
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
It
was
kept
morally
,
rather
as
a
Fast
than
a
Feast
,
enabling
Mrs.
Wilfer
to
hold
a
sombre
darkling
state
,
which
exhibited
that
impressive
woman
in
her
choicest
colours
.
  
<EOS>
The
noble
lady
's
condition
on
these
delightful
occasions
was
one
compounded
of
heroic
endurance
and
heroic
forgiveness
.
<EOS>
Lurid
indications
of
the
better
marriages
she
might
have
made
,
shone
athwart
the
awful
gloom
of
her
composure
,
and
fitfully
revealed
the
cherub
as
a
little
monster
unaccountably
favoured
by
Heaven
,
who
had
possessed
himself
of
a
blessing
for
which
many
of
his
superiors
had
sued
and
contended
in
vain
.
<EOS>
So
firmly
had
this
his
position
towards
his
treasure
become
established
,
that
when
the
anniversary
arrived
,
it
always
found
him
in
an
apologetic
state
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
impossible
that
his
modest
penitence
may
have
even
gone
the
length
of
sometimes
severely
reproving
him
for
that
he
ever
took
the
liberty
of
making
so
exalted
a
character
his
wife
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
the
children
of
the
union
,
their
experience
of
these
festivals
had
been
sufficiently
uncomfortable
to
lead
them
annually
to
wish
,
when
out
of
their
tenderest
years
,
either
that
Ma
had
married
somebody
else
instead
of
much
-
teased
Pa
,
or
that
Pa
had
married
somebody
else
instead
of
Ma
.
<EOS>
When
there
came
to
be
but
two
sisters
left
at
home
,
the
daring
mind
of
Bella
on
the
next
of
these
occasions
scaled
the
height
of
wondering
with
droll
vexation
<EOS>
"
what
on
earth
Pa
ever
could
have
seen
in
Ma
,
to
induce
him
to
make
such
a
little
fool
of
himself
as
to
ask
her
to
have
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
revolving
year
now
bringing
the
day
round
in
its
orderly
sequence
,
Bella
arrived
in
the
Boffin
chariot
to
assist
at
the
celebration
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
family
custom
when
the
day
recurred
,
to
sacrifice
a
pair
of
fowls
on
the
altar
of
Hymen
;
and
Bella
had
sent
a
note
beforehand
,
to
intimate
that
she
would
bring
the
votive
offering
with
her
.
<EOS>
So
,
Bella
and
the
fowls
,
by
the
united
energies
of
two
horses
,
two
men
,
four
wheels
,
and
a
plum
-
pudding
carriage
dog
with
as
uncomfortable
a
collar
on
as
if
he
had
been
George
the
Fourth
,
were
deposited
at
the
door
of
the
parental
dwelling
.
<EOS>
They
were
there
received
by
Mrs.
Wilfer
in
person
,
whose
dignity
on
this
,
as
on
most
special
occasions
,
was
heightened
by
a
mysterious
toothache
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
not
require
the
carriage
at
night
,
"
said
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
walk
back
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
male
domestic
of
Mrs.
Boffin
touched
his
hat
,
and
in
the
act
of
departure
had
an
awful
glare
bestowed
upon
him
by
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
intended
to
carry
deep
into
his
audacious
soul
the
assurance
that
,
whatever
his
private
suspicions
might
be
,
male
domestics
in
livery
were
no
rarity
there
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
dear
Ma
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
and
how
do
you
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
as
well
,
Bella
,
"
replied
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
"
as
can
be
expected
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
me
,
Ma
,
"
said
Bella
;
"
you
talk
as
if
one
was
just
born
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
exactly
what
Ma
has
been
doing
,
"
interposed
Lavvy
,
over
the
maternal
shoulder
,
"
ever
since
we
got
up
this
morning
.
<EOS>
It
's
all
very
well
to
laugh
,
Bella
,
but
anything
more
exasperating
<EOS>
it
is
impossible
to
conceive
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
with
a
look
too
full
of
majesty
to
be
accompanied
by
any
words
,
attended
both
her
daughters
to
the
kitchen
,
where
the
sacrifice
was
to
be
prepared
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
"
said
she
,
resignedly
,
"
has
been
so
polite
as
to
place
his
sitting
-
room
at
our
disposal
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
You
will
therefore
,
Bella
,
be
entertained
in
the
humble
abode
of
your
parents
,
so
far
in
accordance
with
your
present
style
of
living
,
that
there
will
be
a
drawing
-
room
for
your
reception
as
well
as
a
dining
-
room
.
<EOS>
Your
papa
invited
Mr.
Rokesmith
to
partake
of
our
lowly
fare
.
<EOS>
In
excusing
himself
on
account
of
a
particular
engagement
,
he
offered
the
use
of
his
apartment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
happened
to
know
that
he
had
no
engagement
out
of
his
own
room
at
Mr.
Boffin
's
,
but
she
approved
of
his
staying
away
.
<EOS>
"
We
should
only
have
put
one
another
out
of
countenance
,
"
she
thought
,
"
and
we
do
that
quite
often
enough
as
it
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
Yet
she
had
sufficient
curiosity
about
his
room
,
to
run
up
to
it
with
the
least
possible
delay
,
and
make
a
close
inspection
of
its
contents
.
<EOS>
It
was
tastefully
though
economically
furnished
,
and
very
neatly
arranged
.
<EOS>
There
were
shelves
and
stands
of
books
,
English
.
<EOS>
French
,
and
Italian
;
and
in
a
portfolio
on
the
writing
-
table
there
were
sheets
upon
sheets
of
memoranda
and
calculations
in
figures
,
evidently
referring
to
the
Boffin
property
.
<EOS>
On
that
table
also
,
carefully
backed
with
canvas
,
varnished
,
mounted
,
and
rolled
like
a
map
,
was
the
placard
descriptive
of
the
murdered
man
who
had
come
from
afar
to
be
her
husband
.
<EOS>
She
shrank
from
this
ghostly
surprise
,
and
felt
quite
frightened
as
she
rolled
and
tied
it
up
again
.
<EOS>
Peeping
about
here
<EOS>
and
there
,
she
came
upon
a
print
,
a
graceful
head
of
a
pretty
woman
,
elegantly
framed
,
hanging
in
the
corner
by
the
easy
chair
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
,
sir
!
"
said
Bella
,
after
stopping
to
ruminate
before
it
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
,
sir
!
<EOS>
I
fancy
<EOS>
I
can
guess
whom
you
think
that
's
like
.
<EOS>
But
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
's
much
more
like
---
your
impudence
!
"
 
<EOS>
Having
said
which
she
decamped
:
not
solely
because
she
was
offended
,
but
because
there
was
nothing
else
to
look
at
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Ma
,
"
said
Bella
,
reappearing
in
the
kitchen
with
some
remains
of
a
blush
,
"
you
and
Lavvy
think
magnificent
me
fit
for
nothing
,
but
I
intend
to
prove
the
contrary
.
<EOS>
I
mean
to
be
Cook
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
!
"
rejoined
her
majestic
mother
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
permit
it
.
<EOS>
Cook
,
in
that
dress
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
for
my
dress
,
Ma
,
"
returned
Bella
,
merrily
searching
in
a
dresser
-
drawer
,
"
I
mean
to
apron
it
and
towel
it
all
over
the
front
;
 
and
as
to
permission
,
I
mean
to
do
without
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
cook
?
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
"
You
,
who
never
cooked
when
you
were
at
home
?
"
  
"
Yes
,
Ma
,
"
returned
Bella
;
"
that
is
precisely
the
state
of
the
case
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
girded
herself
with
a
white
apron
,
and
busily
with
knots
and
pins
contrived
a
bib
to
it
,
coming
close
and
tight
under
her
chin
,
as
if
it
had
caught
her
round
the
neck
to
kiss
her
.
<EOS>
Over
this
bib
her
dimples
looked
delightful
,
and
under
it
her
pretty
figure
not
less
so
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Ma
,
"
said
Bella
,
pushing
back
her
hair
from
her
temples
with
both
hands
,
<EOS>
"
what
's
first
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
First
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Wilfer
solemnly
,
"
if
you
persist
in
what
I
can
not
but
regard
as
conduct
utterly
incompatible
with
the
equipage
in
which
you
arrived
---
"
  
(
"
Which
I
do
,
Ma
.
"
)
  
<EOS>
"
First
,
then
,
you
put
the
fowls
down
to
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
---
be
---
sure
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Bella
;
"
and
flour
them
,
and
twirl
them
round
,
and
there
they
go
!
"
<EOS>
sending
them
spinning
at
a
great
rate
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
next
,
Ma
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Next
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
with
a
wave
of
her

,
expressive
of
abdication
under

from
the
culinary

,
"
I
would
recommend
examination
of
the
bacon
in
the
saucepan
on

fire
,
and
also
of
the
potatoes
by
the
application
of

.
<EOS>
Preparation
of
the
greens
will
further
become
necessary
if
you
persist
in
this
unseemly
demeanour
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
of
course
I
do
,
Ma
.
"
  
<EOS>
Persisting
,
Bella
gave
her
attention
to
one
thing
and
forgot
the
other
,
and
gave
her
attention
to
the
other
and
forgot
the
third
,
and
remembering
the
third
was
distracted
by
the
fourth
,
and
made
amends
whenever
she
went
wrong
by
giving
the
unfortunate
fowls
an
extra
spin
,
which
made
their
chance
of
ever
getting
cooked
exceedingly
doubtful
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
pleasant
cookery
too
.
<EOS>
Meantime
Miss
Lavinia
,
oscillating
between
the
kitchen
and
the
opposite
room
,
prepared
the
dining
-
table
in
the
latter
chamber
.
<EOS>
This
office
she
(
always
doing
her
household
spiriting
with
unwillingness
)
performed
in
a
startling
series
of
whisks
and
bumps
;
laying
the
table
-
cloth
as
if
she
were
raising
the
wind
,
putting
down
the
glasses
and
salt
-
cellars
as
if
she
were
knocking
at
the
door
,
and
clashing
the
knives
and
forks
in
a
skirmishing
manner
suggestive
of
hand
-
to
-
hand
conflict
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
at
Ma
,
"
whispered
Lavinia
to
Bella
when
this
was
done
,
and
they
stood
over
the
roasting
fowls
.
<EOS>
"
If
one
was
the
most
dutiful
child
in
existence
(
of
course
on
the
whole
one
hopes
one
is
)
,
is
n't
she
enough
to
make
one
want
to
poke
her
with
something
wooden
,
sitting
there
bolt
upright
in
a
corner
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
suppose
,
"
returned
Bella
,
"
that
poor
Pa
was
to
sit
bolt
upright
in
another
corner
.
"
  
"
My
dear
,
he
could
n't
do
it
,
"
said
Lavvy
.
<EOS>
"
Pa
would
loll
directly
.
<EOS>
But
indeed
I
do
not
believe
there
ever
was
any
human
creature
who
could
keep
so
bolt
upright
as
Ma
,
or
put
such
an
amount
of
aggravation
into
one
back
!
<EOS>
What
's
the
matter
,
Ma
?
<EOS>
Ai
n't
you
well
,
Ma
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Doubtless
I
am
very
well
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
turning
her
eyes
upon
her
youngest
born
,
with
scornful
fortitude
.
<EOS>
"
What
should
be
the
matter
with
Me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
seem
very
brisk
,
Ma
,
"
retorted
Lavvy
the
bold
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brisk
?
"
repeated
her
parent
,
"
Brisk
?
<EOS>
Whence
the
low
expression
,
Lavinia
?
<EOS>
If
I
am
uncomplaining
,
if
I
am
silently
contented
with
my
lot
,
let
that
suffice
for
my
family
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Ma
,
"
returned
Lavvy
,
"
since
you
will
force
it
out
of
me
,
I
must
respectfully
take
leave
to
say
that
your
family
are
no
doubt
under
the
greatest
obligations
to
you
for
having
an
annual
toothache
on
your
wedding
day
,
and
that
it
's
very
disinterested
in
you
,
and
an
immense
blessing
to
them
.
<EOS>
Still
,
on
the
whole
,
it
is
possible
to
be
too
boastful
even
of
that
boon
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
incarnation
of
sauciness
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
"
do
you
speak
like
that
to
me
?
<EOS>
On
this
day
,
of
all
days
in
the
year
?
<EOS>
Pray
<EOS>
do
you
know
what
would
have
become
of
you
,
if
I
had
not
bestowed
my
hand
upon
R.
W.
,
your
father
,
on
this
day
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Ma
,
"
replied
Lavvy
,
"
I
really
do
not
;
and
,
with
the
greatest
respect
for
your
abilities
and
information
,
I
very
much
doubt
if
you
do
either
.
"
  
<EOS>
Whether
or
no
the
sharp
vigour
of
this
sally
on
a
weak
point
of
Mrs.
Wilfer
's
entrenchments
might
have
routed
that
heroine
for
the
time
,
is
rendered
uncertain
by
the
arrival
of
a
flag
of
truce
in
the
person
of
Mr.
George
Sampson
:
<EOS>
bidden
to
the
feast
as
a
friend
of
the
family
,
whose
affections
were
now
understood
to
be
in
course
of
transference
from
Bella
to
Lavinia
,
and
whom
Lavinia
kept
---
possibly
in
remembrance
of
his
bad
taste
in
having
overlooked
her
in
the
first
instance
---
under
a
course
of
stinging
discipline
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
congratulate
you
,
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
"
said
Mr.
George
Sampson
,
who
had
meditated
this
neat
address
while
coming
along
,
"
on
the
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
thanked
him
with
a
magnanimous
sigh
,
and
again
became
an
unresisting
prey
to
that
inscrutable
toothache
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
surprised
,
"
said
Mr.
Sampson
feebly
,
"
that
Miss
Bella
condescends
to
cook
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Miss
Lavinia
descended
on
the
ill
-
starred
young
gentleman
with
a
crushing
supposition
that
at
all
events
it
was
no
business
of
his
.
<EOS>
This
disposed
of
Mr.
Sampson
in
a
melancholy
retirement
of
spirit
,
until
the
cherub
arrived
,
whose
amazement
at
the
lovely
woman
's
occupation
was
great
.
  
<EOS>
However
,
she
persisted
in
dishing
the
dinner
as
well
as
cooking
it
,
and
then
sat
down
,
bibless
and
apronless
,
to
partake
of
it
as
an
illustrious
guest
:
Mrs.
Wilfer
first
responding
to
her
husband
's
cheerful
"
<EOS>
For
what
we
are
about
to
receive
---
"
with
a
sepulchral
Amen
,
calculated
to
cast
a
damp
upon
the
stoutest
appetite
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
,
"
said
Bella
,
as
she
watched
the
carving
of
the
fowls
,
"
makes
them
pink
inside
,
I
wonder
,
Pa
!
<EOS>
Is
it
the
breed
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
do
n't
think
it
's
the
breed
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
Pa.
<EOS>
"
I
rather
think
it
is
because
they
are
not
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
ought
to
be
,
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
aware
they
ought
to
be
,
my
dear
,
"
rejoined
her
father
,
"
but
they
---
ai
n't
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
the
gridiron
was
put
in
requisition
,
and
the
good
-
tempered
cherub
,
who
was
often
as
un
-
cherubically
employed
in
his
own
family
as
if
he
had
been
in
the
employment
of
some
of
the
Old
Masters
,
undertook
to
grill
the
fowls
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
except
in
respect
of
staring
about
him
(
a
branch
of
the
public
service
to
which
the
pictorial
cherub
is
much
addicted
)
,
this
domestic
cherub
discharged
as
many
odd
functions
as
his
prototype
;
with
the
difference
,
say
,
that
he
performed
with
a
blacking
-
brush
on
the
family
's
boots
,
instead
of
performing
on
enormous
wind
instruments
and
double
-
basses
,
and
that
he
conducted
himself
with
cheerful
alacrity
to
much
useful
purpose
,
instead
of
foreshortening
himself
in
the
air
with
the
vaguest
intentions
.
  
<EOS>
Bella
helped
him
with
his
supplemental
cookery
,
and
made
him
very
happy
,
but
put
him
in
mortal
terror
too
by
asking
him
when
they
sat
down
at
table
again
,
how
he
supposed
they
cooked
fowls
at
the
Greenwich
dinners
,
and
whether
he
believed
they
really
were
such
pleasant
dinners
as
people
said
?
<EOS>
His
secret
winks
and
nods
of
remonstrance
,
in
reply
,
made
the
mischievous
Bella
laugh
until
she
choked
,
and
then
Lavinia
was
obliged
to
slap
her
on
the
back
,
and
then
she
laughed
the
more
.
  
<EOS>
But
her
mother
was
a
fine
corrective
at
the
other
end
of
the
table
;
 
to
whom
her
father
,
in
the
innocence
of
his
good
-
fellowship
,
at
intervals
appealed
with
:
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
I
am
afraid
you
are
not
enjoying
yourself
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
so
,
R.
W.
?
<EOS>
"
she
would
sonorously
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
,
my
dear
,
you
seem
a
little
out
of
sorts
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
at
all
,
"
would
be
the
rejoinder
,
in
exactly
the
same
tone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
take
a
merry
-
thought
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
take
whatever
you
please
,
R.
W.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
,
but
my
dear
,
do
you
like
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
like
it
as
well
as
I
like
anything
,
R.
W.
"
<EOS>
The
stately
woman
would
then
,
with
a
meritorious
appearance
of
devoting
herself
to
the
general
good
,
pursue
her
dinner
as
if
she
were
feeding
somebody
else
on
high
public
grounds
.
  
<EOS>
Bella
had
brought
dessert
and
two
bottles
of
wine
,
thus
shedding
unprecedented
splendour
on
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
did
the
honors
of
the
first
glass
by
proclaiming
:
"
R.
W.
I
drink
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
And
I
to
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pa
and
Ma
!
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Permit
me
,
"
Mrs.
Wilfer
interposed
,
with
outstretched

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
I
think
not
.
<EOS>
I
drank
to
your
papa
.
<EOS>
If
,
however
,
you
insist
on
including
me
,
I
can
in
gratitude
offer
no
objection
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Lor
,
Ma
,
"
interposed
Lavvy
the
bold
,
"
is
n't
it
the
day
that
made
you
and
Pa
one
and
the
same
?
<EOS>
I
have
no
patience
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
whatever
other
circumstance
the
day
may
be
marked
,
it
is
not
the
day
,
Lavinia
,
on
which
I
will
allow
a
child
of
mine
to
pounce
upon
me
.
<EOS>
I
beg
---
nay
,
command
!
---
that
you
will
not
pounce
.
<EOS>
R.
W.
,
it
is
appropriate
to
recall
that
it
is
for
you
to
command
and
for
me
to
obey
.
<EOS>
It
is
your
house
,
and
you
are
master
at
your
own
table
.
<EOS>
Both
our
healths
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Drinking
the
toast
with
tremendous
stiffness
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
am
a
little
afraid
,
my
dear
,
"
hinted
the
cherub
meekly
,
"
that
you
are
not
enjoying
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
"
quite
so
.
<EOS>
Why
should
I
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
,
my
dear
,
that
perhaps
your
face
might
---
"
  
"
My
face
might
be
a
martyrdom
,
but
what
would
that
import
,
or
who
should
know
it
,
if
I
smiled
?
"
  
<EOS>
And
she
did
smile
;
manifestly
freezing
the
blood
of
Mr.
George
Sampson
by
so
doing
.
<EOS>
For
that
young
gentleman
,
catching
her
smiling
eye
,
was
so
very
much
appalled
by
its
expression
as
to
cast
about
in
his
thoughts
concerning
what
he
had
done
to
bring
it
down
upon
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
mind
naturally
falls
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
"
shall
I
say
into
a
reverie
,
or
shall
I
say
into
a
retrospect
?
<EOS>
on
a
day
like
this
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lavvy
,
sitting
with
defiantly
folded
arms
,
replied
(
but
not
audibly
)
,
"
For
goodness
'
sake
say
whichever
of
the
two
you
like
best
,
Ma
,
and
get
it
over
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
mind
,
"
pursued
Mrs.
Wilfer
in
an
oratorical
manner
,
"
naturally
reverts
to
Papa
and
Mamma
<EOS>
---
I
here
allude
to
my
parents
---
at
a
period
before
the
earliest
dawn
of
this
day
.
<EOS>
I
was
considered
tall
;
perhaps
I
was
.
<EOS>
Papa
and
Mamma
were
unquestionably
tall
.
<EOS>
I
have
rarely
seen
a
finer
woman
than
my
mother
;
never
than
my
father
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
irrepressible
Lavvy
remarked
aloud
,
"
Whatever
grandpapa
was
,
he
was
n't
a
female
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
grandpapa
,
"
retorted
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
with
an
awful
look
,
and
in
an
awful
tone
,
"
was
what
I
describe
him
to
have
been
,
and
would
have
struck
any
of
his
grandchildren
to
the
earth
who
presumed
to
question
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
mamma
's
cherished
hopes
that
I
should
become
united
to
a
tall
member
of
society
.
<EOS>
It
may
have
been
a
weakness
,
but
if
so
,
it
was
equally
the
weakness
,
I
believe
,
of
King
Frederick
of
Prussia
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
These
remarks
being
offered
to
Mr.
George
Sampson
,
who
had
not
the
courage
to
come
out
for
single
combat
,
but
lurked
with
his
chest
under
the
table
and
his
eyes
cast
down
,
Mrs.
Wilfer
proceeded
,
in
a
voice
of
increasing
sternness
and
impressiveness
,
until
she
should
force
that
skulker
to
give
himself
up
.
"
<EOS>
Mamma
would
appear
to
have
had
an
indefinable
foreboding
of
what
afterwards
happened
,
for
she
would
frequently
urge
upon
me
,
`
`
Not
a
little
man
.
<EOS>
Promise
me
,
my
child
,
not
a
little
man
.
<EOS>
Never
,
never
,
never
,
marry
a
little
man
!
"
<EOS>
"
Papa
also
would
remark
to
me
(
he
possessed
extraordinary
humour
)
,
`
`
that
a
family
of
whales
must
not
ally
themselves
with
sprats
.
"
<EOS>
"
His
company
was
eagerly
sought
,
as
may
be
supposed
,
by
the
wits
of
the
day
,
and
our
house
was
their
continual
resort
.
<EOS>
I
have
known
as
many
as
three
copper
-
plate
engravers
exchanging
the
most
exquisite
sallies
and
retorts
there
,
at
one
time
.
"
<EOS>
(
Here
Mr.
Sampson
delivered
himself
captive
,
and
said
,
with
an
uneasy
movement
on
his
chair
,
that
three
was
a
large
number
,
and
it
must
have
been
highly
entertaining
.
)
<EOS>
"
Among
the
most
prominent
members
of
that
distinguished
circle
,
was
a
gentleman
measuring
six
feet
four
in
height
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
an
engraver
.
"
<EOS>
(
Here
Mr.
Sampson
said
,
with
no
reason
whatever
,
Of
course
not
.
)
<EOS>
"
This
gentleman
was
so
obliging
as
to
honor
me
with
attentions
which
I
could
not
fail
to
understand
.
"
<EOS>
(
Here
Mr.
Sampson
murmured
that
when
it
came
to
that
,
you
could
always
tell
.
)
<EOS>
"
I
immediately
announced
to
both
my
parents
that
those

were

,
and
that
I
could
not

.
<EOS>
The
inquired
was
he
too
tall
?
<EOS>
I
replied
it
was
not
the
stature
,
but
the
intellect
was
too

.
<EOS>
At
our
house
,
I
said
,
the
tone
was
too

,
the

too
high
,
to
be

by
me
,
a

,
in
every
-

.
<EOS>
I
well

's

,
and

`
`
This
will
end
in
a
little
man
!
"
<EOS>
"
"
(
Here

.
)
<EOS>
"
She
afterwards
went

end

a

man

be
below

,
but

<EOS>
Within

,
"

my

<EOS>
Within

<EOS>
It

"
  
<EOS>

Wilfer

<EOS>
R.

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

fortune
,
it
is
my
benefactor
.
<EOS>
And
yet
,
Pa
,
think
how
terrible
the
fascination
of
money
is
!
<EOS>
I
see
this
,
and
hate
this
,
and
dread
this
,
and
do
n't
know
but
that
money
might
make
a
much
worse
change
in
me
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
have
money
always
in
my
thoughts
and
my
desires
;
and
the
whole
life
I
place
before
myself
is
money
,
money
,
money
,
and
what
money
can
make
of
life
!
"
   
<EOS>
THE
GOLDEN
DUSTMAN
FALLS
INTO
BAD
COMPANY
.
 
<EOS>
Were
Bella
Wilfer
's
bright
and
ready
little
wits
at
fault
,
or
was
the
Golden
Dustman
passing
through
the
furnace
of
proof
and
coming
out
dross
?
<EOS>
Ill
news
travels
fast
.
<EOS>
We
shall
know
full
soon
.
  
<EOS>
On
that
very
night
of
her
return
from
the
Happy
Return
,
something
chanced
which
Bella
closely
followed
with
her
eyes
and
ears
.
<EOS>
There
was
an
apartment
at
the
side
of
the
Boffin
mansion
,
known
as
Mr.
Boffin
's
room
.
<EOS>
Far
less
grand
than
the
rest
of
the
house
,
it
was
far
more
comfortable
,
being
pervaded
by
a
certain
air
of
homely
snugness
,
which
upholstering
despotism
had
banished
to
that
spot
when
it
inexorably
set
its
face
against
Mr.
Boffin
's
appeals
for
mercy
in
behalf
of
any
other
chamber
.
<EOS>
Thus
,
although
a
room
of
modest
situation
---
for
its
windows
gave
on
Silas
Wegg
's
old
corner
---
and
of
no
pretensions
to
velvet
,
satin
,
or
gilding
,
it
had
got
itself
established
in
a
domestic
position
analogous
to
that
of
an
easy
dressing
-
gown
or
pair
of
slippers
;
and
whenever
the
family
wanted
to
enjoy
a
particularly
pleasant
fireside
evening
,
they
enjoyed
it
,
as
an
institution
that
must
be
,
in
Mr.
Boffin
's
room
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
were
reported
sitting
in
this
room
,
when
Bella
got
back
.
<EOS>
Entering
it
,
she
found
the
Secretary
there
too
;
in
official
attendance
it
would
appear
,
for
he
was
standing
with
some
papers
in
his
hand
by
a
table
with
shaded
candles
on
it
,
at
which
Mr.
Boffin
was
seated
thrown
back
in
his
easy
chair
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
busy
,
sir
,
"
said
Bella
,
hesitating
at
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
,
my
dear
,
not
at
all
.
<EOS>
You
're
one
of
ourselves
.
<EOS>
We
never
make
company
of
you
.
<EOS>
Come
in
,
come
in
.
<EOS>
Here
's
the
old
lady
in
her
usual
place
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
adding
her
nod
and
smile
of
welcome
to
Mr.
Boffin
's
words
<EOS>
,
Bella
took
her
book
to
a
chair
in
the
fireside
corner
,
by
Mrs.
Boffin
's
work
-
table
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
's
station
was
on
the
opposite
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Rokesmith
,
"
said
the
Golden
Dustman
,
so
sharply
rapping
the
table
to
bespeak
his
attention
as
Bella
turned
the
leaves
of
her
book
,
that
she
started
;
"
where
were
we
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
were
saying
,
sir
,
"
returned
the
Secretary
,
with
an
air
of
some
reluctance
and
a
glance
towards
those
others
who
were
present
,
"
that
you
considered
the
time
had
come
for
fixing
my
salary
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
be
above
calling
it
wages
,
man
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
testily
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
the
deuce
!
<EOS>
I
never
talked
of
my
salary
when
I
was
in
service
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
wages
,
"
said
the
Secretary
,
correcting
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Rokesmith
,
you
are
not
proud
,
I
hope
?
"
observed
Mr.
Boffin
,
eyeing
him
askance
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
I
never
was
,
when
I
was
poor
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Poverty
and
pride
do
n't
go
at
all
well
together
.
<EOS>
Mind
that
.
<EOS>
How
can
they
go
well
together
?
<EOS>
Why
it
stands
to
reason
.
<EOS>
A
man
,
being
poor
,
has
nothing
to
be
proud
of
.
<EOS>
It
's
nonsense
.
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
slight
inclination
of
his
head
,
and
a
look
of
some
surprise
,
the
Secretary
seemed
to
assent
by
forming
the
syllables
of
the
word
"
nonsense
"
on
his
lips
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
concerning
these
same
wages
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Sit
down
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
sat
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
did
n't
you
sit
down
before
?
"
asked
Mr.
Boffin
,
distrustfully
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
that
was
n't
pride
?
<EOS>
But
about
these
wages
Now
,
I
've
gone
into
the
matter
,
and
<EOS>
I
say
tow
hundred
a
year
.
<EOS>
What
do
you
think
of
it
?
<EOS>
Do
you
think
it
's
enough
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
fair
proposal
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
say
,
you
know
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
stipulated
,
"
but
what
it
may
be
more
than
enough
.
<EOS>
And
I
'll
tell
you
why
,
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
A
man
of
property
,
like
me
,
is
bound
to
consider
the
market
-
price
.
<EOS>
At
first
I
did
n't
enter
into
that
as
much
as
I
might
have
done
;
but
I
've
got
acquainted
with
other
men
of
property
since
,
and
I
've
got
acquainted
with
the
duties
of
property
.
<EOS>
I
must
n't
go
putting
the
market
-
price
up
,
because
money
may
happen
not
to
be
an
object
with
me
.
<EOS>
A
sheep
is
worth
so
much
in
the
market
,
and
I
ought
to
give
it
<EOS>
and
no
more
.
<EOS>
A
secretary
is
worth
so
much
in
the
market
,
and
I
ought
to
give
it
<EOS>
and
no
more
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
do
n't
mind
stretching
a
point
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Boffin
,
you
are
very
good
,
"
replied
the
Secretary
,
with
an
effort
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
we
put
the
figure
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
at
two
hundred
a
year
.
<EOS>
Then
the
figure
's
disposed
of
.
<EOS>
Now
,
there
must
be
no
misunderstanding
regarding
what
I
buy
for
two
hundred
a
year
.
<EOS>
If
I
pay
for
a
sheep
,
I
buy
it
out
and
out
.
<EOS>
Similarly
,
if
I
pay
for
a
secretary
,
I
buy
him
out
and
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
other
words
,
you
purchase
my
whole
time
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
I
do
.
<EOS>
Look
here
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
it
ai
n't
that
I
want
to
occupy
your
whole
time
;
you
can
take
up
a
book
for
a
minute
or
two
when
you
've
nothing
better
to
do
,
though
I
think
you
'll
a'most
always
find
something
useful
to
do
.
<EOS>
But
I
want
to
keep
you
in
attendance
.
<EOS>
It
's
convenient
to
have
you
at
all
times
ready
on
the
premises
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
betwixt
your
breakfast
and
your
supper
,
---
on
the
premises
I
expect
to
find
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
bowed
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
bygone
days
,
when
I
was
in
service
myself
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
I
could
n't
go
cutting
about
at
my
will
and
pleasure
,
and
you
wo
n't
expect
to
go
cutting
about
at
your
will
and
pleasure
.
<EOS>
You
've
rather
got
into
a
habit
of
that
,
lately
;
but
perhaps
it
was
for
want
of
a
right
specification
betwixt
us
.
<EOS>
Now
,
let
there
be
a
right
specification
betwixt
us
,
and
let
it
be
this
.
<EOS>
If
you
want
leave
,
ask
for
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
the
Secretary
bowed
.
<EOS>
His
manner
was
uneasy
and
astonished
,
and
showed
a
sense
of
humiliation
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
have
a
bell
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
hung
from
this
room
to
yours
,
and
<EOS>
when
I
want
you
,
I
'll
touch
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
call
to
mind
that
I
have
anything
more
to
say
at
the
present
moment
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
rose
,
gathered
up
his
papers
,
and
withdrew
.
<EOS>
Bella
's
eyes
followed
him
to
the
door
,
lighted
on
Mr.
Boffin
complacently
thrown
back
in
his
easy
chair
,
and
drooped
over
her
book
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
let
that
chap
,
that
young
man
of
mine
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
taking
a
trot
up
and
down
the
room
,
"
get
above
his
work
.
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
I
must
have
him
down
a
peg
.
<EOS>
A
man
of
property
owes
a
duty
to
other
men
of
property
,
and
must
look
sharp
after
his
inferiors
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
felt
that
Mrs.
Boffin
was
not
comfortable
,
and
that
the
eyes
of
that
good
creature
sought
to
discover
from
her
face
what
attention
she
had
given
to
this
discourse
,
and
what
impression
it
had
made
upon

.
<EOS>
For
which
reason
Bella
's
eyes
drooped
more
engrossedly
over
her
book
,
and
she
turned
the
page
with
an
air

profound
absorption
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Noddy
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
after
thoughtfully
pausing
in
her
work
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
,
"
returned
the
Golden
Dustman
,
stopping
short
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Excuse
my
putting
it
to
you
,
Noddy
,
but
now
really
!
<EOS>
Have
n't
you
been
a

Rokesmith

?
<EOS>
Have

a
little
---
<EOS>
just

---
not

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
old
woman
,
I

,
"
returned

Boffin
,
cheerfully
,
if

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hope

,
deary
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Our
old
selves
would
n't
do
here
,
old

.
<EOS>
Have
n't
you
found
that
out
yet
?
<EOS>
Our
old
selves
would
be
fit
for
nothing
here
but
to

.
<EOS>
Our
old
selves
were
n't
people
of
fortune
;
 
our
new
selves
are
;
it
's
a
great
difference
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,

,
softly

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
great
difference
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
we
must
be
up
to
the
difference
,
"
pursued
her

;
 
"
we
must
be
equal
to
the
change
;
that
's
what
we
must
be
.
<EOS>
We
've
got
to
hold

own
now
,
against
everybody
<EOS>
(
for
everybody
's

is

)
,
and
we
have

to
recollect
that
money
makes
money
,
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mentioning
recollecting
,
"
said

Boffin
,
with
her

,
her

,
and

,
"
do
you

,
<EOS>
Noddy
,
how
you
said

Rokesmith

,
and

<EOS>
---

,

one

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

tried
what

.
<EOS>
Our

had

,
but

.
<EOS>
We
're

,
we
're

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
took

,
and
plied

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
As
to
Rokesmith
,
that
young
man
of
mine
,
"
said

Boffin
,

,
"

's

.
<EOS>
I
have

,

.
<EOS>
If
you
ai
n't
imperious
with
'em
,
they
wo
n't

your
being
any
better
than
themselves
,
if
as
good
,
after
the
stories
(
lies
mostly
)
that
they
have
heard
of
your

.
<EOS>
There
's
nothing
betwixt
stiffening

up
,

throwing
yourself
away
;
take
my
word
for

,
old

.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
ventured
for

to
look

towards
him
under
her

,
and
she
saw

of

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hows'ever
,
"
said

,
"
this
is
n't

to
Miss
Bella
.
<EOS>
Is

,
Bella
?
"
  
<EOS>
A
deceiving
Bella
<EOS>
she
was
,
to
look
at
him
with
that
pensively
abstracted
air
,
as
if
her
mind
were
full
of
her
book
,
and
she
had
not

!
  
<EOS>
"
Hah
!
<EOS>
Better
employed
than
to

,
"
said

Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
that
's
right
.
<EOS>
Especially
as
you
have
no
call
to
be
told
how
to
value
yourself
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Colouring
a
little
under
this
compliment
,
Bella
returned
,
"
I
hope
,
sir
,
you
do
n't
think
me
vain
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
a
bit
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
think
it
's
very
creditable
in
you
,
at
your
age
,
to
be
so
well
up
with
the
pace
of
the
world
,
and
to
know
what
to
go
in
for
.
<EOS>
You
are
right
.
<EOS>
Go
in
for
money
,
my
love
.
<EOS>
Money
's
the
article
.
<EOS>
You
'll
make
money
of
your
good
looks
,
and
of
the
money
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
and
me
will
have
the
pleasure
of
settling
upon
you
,
and
you
'll
live
and
die
rich
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
state
to
live
and
die
in
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
in
an
unctuous
manner
.
<EOS>
"
R
---
r
---
rich
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
an
expression
of
distress
in
Mrs.
Boffin
's
face
,
as
,
after
watching
her
husband
's
,
she
turned
to
their
adopted
girl
,
and
said
:
"
Do
n't
mind
him
,
Bella
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
cried
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
what
!
<EOS>
Not
mind
him
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
that
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
with
a
worried
look
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
mean
,
do
n't
believe
him
to
be
anything
but
good
and
generous
,
Bella
,
because
he
is
the
best
of
men
.
<EOS>
No
,
I
must
say
that
much
,
Noddy
.
<EOS>
You
are
always
the
best
of
men
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
made
the
declaration
as
if
he
were
objecting
to

:
which
assuredly
he
was
not
in
any
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
as
to
you
,
my
dear
Bella
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
still
with
that

,
"
he
is
so
much

to
you
,
whatever
he

,
that
your
own
father
has
not
a
truer
interest
in
you
and
can
hardly
like
you
better
than
he
does
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Says
too
!
"
cried
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Whatever
he
says
!
<EOS>
Why
,
I
say
so
,
openly
.
<EOS>
Give
me
a
kiss
,
by
dear
child
,
in
saying
Good
Night
,
and
let
me
confirm
what
my
old
lady
tells
you
.
<EOS>
I
am
very
fond
of
you
,
my
dear
,
and
I
am
entirely
of
your
mind
,
and
you
and
I
will
take

that
you

be
rich
.
<EOS>
These

of
yours
(
which
you
have
some

to
be
vain
of
,
my
dear
,
though
you
are
not
,
you
know
)
are
worth
money
,
and
you
shall
make
money
of
'em
.
<EOS>
The
money
you
will
have
,
will
be
worth
money
,
and
you
shall
make
money
of
that
too
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
golden
ball
at
your
feet
.
<EOS>
Good
night
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Somehow
,
Bella
was
not
so
well
pleased
with
this
assurance
and
this
prospect
as
she
might
have
been
.
<EOS>
Somehow
,
when
she
put
her
arms
round
Mrs.
Boffin
's

and
said
Good
Night
,
she
derived
a
sense
of
unworthiness
from
the
still
anxious
face
of
that
good
woman
and
her
obvious
wish
to
excuse
her
husband
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
need
to
excuse
him
?
"
thought
Bella
,
sitting
down
in
her
own
room
.
<EOS>
"
What
he
said
was
very
sensible
,
I
am
sure
,
and
very
true
,
I
am
sure
.
<EOS>
It
is
only
what
I
often
say
to
myself
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
like
it
then
?
<EOS>
No
,
I
do
n't
like
it
,
and
,
though
he
is
my
liberal
benefactor
,
I
disparage
him
for
it
.
<EOS>
Then
pray
,
"
said
Bella
,
sternly
putting
the
question
to
herself
in
the
looking
-
glass
as
usual
,
"
what
do
you
mean
by
this
,
you
inconsistent
little
Beast
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
looking
-
glass
preserving
a
discreet
ministerial
silence
<EOS>
when
thus
called
upon
for
explanation
,
Bella
went
to
bed
with
a
weariness
upon
her
spirit
which
was
more
than
the
weariness
of
want
of
sleep
.
<EOS>
And
again
in
the
morning
,
she
looked
for
the
cloud
,
and
for
the
deepening
of
the
cloud
,
upon
the
Golden
Dustman
's
face
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
begun
by
this
time
to
be
his
frequent
companion
in
his
morning
strolls
about
the
streets
,
and
it
was
at
this
time
that
he
made
her
a
party
to
his
engaging
in
a
curious
pursuit
.
<EOS>
Having
been
hard
at
work
in
one
dull
enclosure
all
his
life
,
he
had
a
child
's
delight
in
looking
at
shops
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
one
of
the
first
novelties
and
pleasures
of
his
freedom
,
and
was
equally
the
delight
of
his
wife
.
<EOS>
For
many
years
their
only
walks
in
London
had
been
taken
on
Sundays
when
the
shops
were
shut
;
and
when
every
day
in
the
week
became
their
holiday
,
they
derived
an
enjoyment
from
the
variety
and
fancy
and
beauty
of
the
display
in
the
windows
,
which
seemed
incapable
of
exhaustion
.
<EOS>
As
if
the
principal
streets
were
a
great
Theatre
and
the
play
were
childishly
new
to
them
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
from
the
beginning
of
Bella
's
intimacy
in
their
house
,
had
been
constantly
in
the
front
row
,
charmed
with
all
they
saw
and
applauding
vigorously
.
<EOS>
But
now
,
Mr.
Boffin
's
interest
began
to
centre
in
book
-
shops
;
and
more
than
that
---
for
that
of
itself
would
not
have
been
much
---
in
one
exceptional
kind
of
book
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
in
here
,
my
dear
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
would
say
,
checking
Bella
's
arm
at
a
bookseller
's
window
;
"
you
can
read
at
sight
,
and
your
eyes
are
as
sharp
as
they
're
bright
.
<EOS>
Now
,
look
well
about
you
,
my
dear
,
and
tell
me
if
you
see
any
book
about
a
Miser
.
"
  
<EOS>
If
Bella
saw
such
a
book
,
Mr.
Boffin
would
instantly
dart
in
and
buy
it
.
<EOS>
And
still
,
as
if
they
had
not
found
it
,
they
would
seek
out
another
book
-
shop
,
and
Mr.
Boffin
would
say
,
"
Now
,
look
well
all
round
,
my
dear
,
for
a
Life
of
a
Miser
,
or
any
book
of
that
sort
;
any
Lives
of
odd
characters
who
may
have
been
Misers
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
,
thus
directed
,
would
examine
the
window
with
the
greatest
attention
,
while
Mr.
Boffin
would
examine
her
face
.
<EOS>
The
moment
she
pointed
out
any
book
as
being
entitled
Lives
of
eccentric
personages
,
Anecdotes
of
strange

,
Records
of
remarkable
individuals
,
or
anything
to
that
purpose
,
Mr.
Boffin
's
countenance
would
light
up
,
and
he
would
instantly
dart
in
and
buy
it
.
<EOS>
Size
,
price
,
quality
,
were
of
no
account
.
<EOS>
Any
book
that
seemed
to
promise
a
chance
of
miserly
biography
,
Mr.
Boffin
purchased
without
a
moment
's
delay
and
carried
home
.
<EOS>
Happening
to
be
informed
by
a
bookseller
that
a
portion
of
the
Annual
Register
was
devoted
to
"
Characters
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
at
once
bought
a
whole
set
of
that
ingenious
compilation
,
and
began
to
carry
it
home
piecemeal
,
confiding
a
volume
to
Bella
,
and
bearing
three
himself
.
<EOS>
The
completion
of
his
labour
occupied
them
about
a
fortnight
.
<EOS>
When
the
task
was
done
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
his
appetite
for
Misers
whetted
instead
of
satiated
,
began
to
look
out
again
.
  
<EOS>
It
very
soon
became
unnecessary
to
tell
Bella
what
to
look
for
,
and
an
understanding
was
established
between
her
and
Mr.
Boffin
that
she
was
always
to
look
for
Lives
of
Misers
.
<EOS>
Morning
after
morning
they
roamed
about
the
town
together
,
pursuing
this
singular
research
.
<EOS>
Miserly
literature
not
being
abundant
,
the
proportion
of
failures
to
successes
may
have
been
as
a
hundred
to
one
;
still
Mr.
Boffin
,
never
wearied
,
remained
as
avaricious
for
misers
as
he
had
been
at
the
first
onset
.
<EOS>
It
was
curious
that
Bella
never
saw
the
books
about
the
house
,
nor
did
she
ever
hear
from
Mr.
Boffin
one
word

reference
to
their
contents
.
<EOS>
he
seemed
to
save
up
his
Misers
as
they
had
saved
up
their
money
.
<EOS>
As
they
had
been
greedy
for
it
,
and
secret
about
it
,
and
had
hidden
it
,
so
he
was
greedy
for
them
,
and
secret
about
them
,
and
hid
them
.
<EOS>
But
beyond
all
doubt
it
was
to
be
noticed
,
and
was
by
Bella
very
clearly
noticed
,
that
,
as
he
pursued
the
acquisition
of
those
dismal
records
with
the
ardour
of
Don
Quixote
for
his
books
of
chivalry
,
he
began
to
spend
his
money
with
a
more
sparing
hand
.
<EOS>
And
often
when
he
came
out
of
a
shop
with
some
new
account
of
one
of
those
wretched
lunatics
,
she
would
almost
shrink
from
the
sly
dry
chuckle
with
which
he
would
take
her
arm
again
and
trot
away
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
appear
that
Mrs.
Boffin
knew
of
this
taste
.
<EOS>
He
made
no
allusion
to
it
,
except
in
the
morning
walks
when
he
and
Bella
were
always
alone
;
and
Bella
,
partly
under
the
impression
that
he
took
her
into
his
confidence
by

,
and
partly
in
remembrance
of
Mrs.
Boffin
's
anxious
face
that
night
,
held
the
same
reserve
.
  
<EOS>
While
these
occurrences
were
in
progress
,
Mrs.
Lammle
made
the
discovery
that
Bella
had
a
fascinating
influence
over
her
.
<EOS>
The
Lammles
,
originally
presented
by
the
dear
Veneerings
,
visited
the
Boffins
on
all
grand
occasions
,
and
Mrs.
Lammle
had
not
previously
found
this
out
;
but
now
the
knowledge
came
upon
her
all
at
once
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
most
extraordinary
thing
(
shed
said
to
Mrs.
Boffin
)
;
she
was
foolishly
susceptible
of
the
power
of
beauty
,
but
it
was
n't
altogether
that
;
she
never
had
been
able
to
resist
a
natural
grace
of
manner
,
but
it
was
n't
altogether
that
;
it
was
more
than
that
,
and
there
was
no
name
for
the
indescribable
extent
and
degree
to
which
she
was
captivated
by
this
charming
girl
.
  
<EOS>
This
charming
girl
having
the
words
repeated
to
her
by
Mrs.
Boffin
(
who
was
proud
of
her
being
admired
,
and
would
have
done
anything
to
give
her
pleasure
)
,
naturally
recognized
in
Mrs.
Lammle
a
woman
of
penetration
and
taste
.
<EOS>
Responding
to
the
sentiments
,
by
being
very
gracious
to
Mrs.
Lammle
,
she
gave
that
lady
the
means
of
so
improving
her
opportunity
,
as
that
the
captivation
became
reciprocal
,
though
always
wearing
an
appearance
of
greater
sobriety
on
Bella
's
part
than
on
the
enthusiastic
Sophronia
's
.
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
they
were
so
much
together
that
,
for
a
time
,
the
Boffin
chariot
held
Mrs.
Lammle
oftener
than
Mrs.
Boffin
:
a
preference
of
which
the
latter
worthy
soul
was
not
in
the
least
jealous
,
placidly
remarking
,
"
Mrs.
Lammle
is
a
younger
companion
for
her
than
I
am
,
and
<EOS>
Lor
!
<EOS>
she
's
more
fashionable
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
between
Bella
Wilfer
and
Georgiana
Podsnap
there
was
this
one
difference
,
among
many
others
,
that
Bella
was
in
no
danger
of
being
captivated
by
Alfred
.
<EOS>
She
distrusted
and
disliked
him
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
her
perception
was
so
quick
,
and
her
observation
so
sharp
,
that
after
all
she
mistrusted
his
wife
too
,
though
with
her
giddy
vanity
and
wilfulness
she
squeezed
the
mistrust
away
into
a
corner
of
her
mind
,
and
blocked
it
up
there
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
took
the
friendliest
interest
in
Bella
's
making
a
good
match
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
said
,
in
a
sportive
way
,
she
really
must
show
her
beautiful
Bella
what
kind
of
wealthy
creatures
she
and
Alfred
had
on
hand
,
who
would
as
one
man
fall
at
her
feet
enslaved
.
<EOS>
Fitting
occasion
made
,
Mrs.
Lammle
accordingly
produced
the
most
passable
of
those
feverish
,
boastful
,
and
indefinably
loose
gentlemen
who
were
always
lounging
in
and
out
of
the
City
on
questions
of
the
Bourse
and
Greek
and
Spanish
and
India
and
Mexican
and
par
and
premium
and
discount
and
three
-
quarters
and
seven
-
eighths
.
<EOS>
Who
in
their
agreeable
manner
did
homage
to
Bella
as
if
she
were
a
compound
of
fine
girl
,
thorough
-
bred
horse
,
well
-
built
drag
,
and
remarkable
pipe
.
<EOS>
But
without
the
least
effect
,
though
even
Mr.
Fledgeby
's
attractions
were
cast
into
the
scale
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
fear
,
Bella
dear
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
one
day
in
the
chariot
,
"
that
you
will
be
very
hard
to
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
expect
to
be
pleased
,
dear
,
"
said
Bella
,
with
a
languid
turn
of
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Truly
,
my
love
,
"
returned
Sophronia
,
shaking
her
head
,
and
smiling
her
best
smile
,
"
it
would
not
be
very
easy
to
find
a
man
worthy
of
your
attractions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
question
is
not
a
man
,
my
dear
,
"
said
Bella
,
coolly
,
"
but
an
establishment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
your
prudence
amazes
me
---
  
where
did
you
study
life
so
well
!
---
<EOS>
you
are
right
.
<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
You

---
"
  
"
<EOS>

they

<EOS>
"
No
!
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
Mention

!

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Men

!
<EOS>

"

"
<EOS>
Oh

"

---
  
<EOS>
Sophronia

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

;

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

upon

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

Men

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.

,

,

,

<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
Their

now
,

before
Mr.

Boffin
;
and

were

,

.
<EOS>
She

face
when

,

,
and
could

.
<EOS>
He

subdued
;
but
he
had
acquired
a
strong

of
feature
,
and
,

Boffin

,

himself
Mr.

changed
no

.
<EOS>
A

,
that
expressed
nothing
but

,

,

---

from

,

,

,

,

,
set
,
as

.
  
<EOS>
The
worst
of
the
matter
was
,
that
it
thus
fell
out
insensibly
---
and
most

,
as

to

,

---

.
"
<EOS>
Wo

?
"
<EOS>
---
"
Can
it
be
possible
that
makes

?
"
 
<EOS>
Such

Bella

propose
to

,
often

in

.
<EOS>
Impossible
to
know
.
<EOS>
Always
the
same

face
.
  
<EOS>
"
Can

be
so
base
as

sell

for

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,
"
But

?
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
<EOS>
And
so

would
come
round

the
war

.
  
<EOS>
A

,

,

Boffin
's

.
<EOS>
Its

got

craftiness
that
assimilated

-

.
<EOS>
His
very
smile
was
cunning
,
as
if

had
been
studying

among

.
<EOS>
Saving

,

,

remained

,

;
and

all

,

,
as

had
an

to
hoard

up
,

must

.
  
<EOS>
What

,

,

<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
None

of

,

's
.
  
<EOS>
"
Rokesmith
,
"

.

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

.

,
"

,
"

wo

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
You

---
"

"

.

"

.
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Do

.
<EOS>
Only
,

.
<EOS>
Did

?
"
<EOS>

.

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

"

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

'

,

,
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

?
"

"
No

"

,

<EOS>
"

I
mean
.
<EOS>
Those
abject
wretches
---
"
  
"
Do
n't
call
names
,
Rokesmith
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
That
exemplary
brother
and
sister
---
lived
and
died
in
the
foulest
and
filthiest
degradation
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
pleased
themselves
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
and
I
suppose
they
could
have
done
no
more
if
they
had
spent
their
money
.
<EOS>
But
however
,
I
ai
n't
going
to
fling
mine
away
.
<EOS>
Keep
the
expenses
down
.
<EOS>
The
fact
is
,
you
ai
n't
enough
here
,
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
It
wants
constant
attention
in
the
littlest
things
.
<EOS>
Some
of
us
will
be
dying
in
a
workhouse
next
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
the
persons
you
have
cited
,
"
quietly
remarked
the
Secretary
,
"
thought
they
would
,
if
I
remember
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
very
creditable
in
'em
too
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Very
independent
in
'em
!
<EOS>
But
never
mind
them
just
now
.
<EOS>
Have
you
given
notice
to
quit
your
lodgings
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Under
your
direction
,
I
have
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
tell
you
what
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
;
"
pay
the
quarter
's
rent
---
pay
the
quarter
's
rent
<EOS>
,
it
'll
be
the
cheapest
thing
in
the
end
---
and
come
here
at
once
,
so
that
you
may
be
always
on
the
spot
,
day
and
night
,
and
keep
the
expenses
down
.
<EOS>
You
'll
charge
the
quarter
's
rent
to
me
,
and
we
must
try
and
save
it
somewhere
.
<EOS>
You
've
got
some
lovely
furniture
;
have
n't
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
furniture
in
my
rooms
is
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
we
sha
n't
have
to
buy
any
for
you
.
<EOS>
In
case
you
was
to
think
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
a
look
of
peculiar
shrewdness
,
"
so
honourably
independent
in
you
as
to
make
it
a
relief
to
your
mind
,
to
make
that
furniture
over
to
me
in
the
light
of
a
set
-
off
against
the
quarter
's
rent
,
why
ease
your
mind
,
ease
your
mind
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
it
,
but
I
wo
n't
stand
in
your
way
if
you
should
consider
it
due
to
yourself
.
<EOS>
As
to
your
room
,
choose
any
empty
room
at
the
top
of
the
house
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Any
empty
room
will
do
for
me
,
"
said
the
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
take
your
pick
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
and
it
'll
be
as
good
as
eight
or
ten
shillings
<EOS>
a
week
added
to
your
income
.
<EOS>
I
wo
n't
deduct
for
it
;
I
look
to
you
to
make
it
up
handsomely
by
keeping
the
expenses
down
.
<EOS>
Now
,
if
you
'll
show
a
light
,
I
'll
come
to
your
officeroom
and
dispose
of
a
letter
or
two
.
"
  
<EOS>
On
that
clear
,
generous
face
of
Mrs.
Boffin
's
,
Bella
had
seen
such
traces
of
a
pang
at
the
heart
while
this
dialogue
was
being
held
,
that
she
had
not
the
courage
to
turn
her
eyes
to
it
when
they
were
left
alone
.
<EOS>
Feigning
to
be
intent
on
her
embroidery
,
she
sat
plying
her
needle
-
until
her
busy
hand
was
stopped
by
Mrs.
Boffin
's
hand
being
lightly
laid
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Yielding
to
the
touch
,
she
felt
her
hand
carried
to
the
good
soul
's
lips
,
and
felt
a
tear
fall
on
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
loved
husband
!
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
This
is
hard
to
see
and
hear
.
<EOS>
But
my
dear
Bella
,
believe
me
that
in
spite
of
all
the
change
in
him
,
he
is
the
best
of
men
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
came
back
,
at
the
moment
when
Bella
had
taken
the
hand
comfortingly
between
her
own
.
  
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"
said
he
,
mistrustfully
looking
in
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
she
telling
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
only
praising
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
Praising
me
?
<EOS>
You
are
sure
?
<EOS>
Not
blaming
me
for
standing
on
my
own
defence
against
a
crew
of
plunderers
,
who
would
suck
me
dry
by
driblets
?
<EOS>
Not
blaming
me
for
getting
a
little
hoard
together
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
came
up
to
them
,
and
his
wife
folded
her
hands
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
shook
her
head
as
she
laid
it
on
her
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
there
,
there
!
"
urged
Mr.
Boffin
,
not
unkindly
.
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
take
on
,
old
lady
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
ca
n't
bear
to
see
you
<EOS>
so
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
Recollect
we
are
not
our
old
selves
.
<EOS>
Recollect
,
we
must
scrunch
or
be
scrunched
.
<EOS>
Recollect
,
we
must
hold
our
own
.
<EOS>
Recollect
,
money
makes
money
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
be
uneasy
,
Bella
,
my
child
;
do
n't
you
be
doubtful
.
<EOS>
The
more
I
save
,
the
more
you
shall
have
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
thought
it
was
well
for
his
wife
that
she
was
musing
with
her
affectionate
face
on
his
shoulder
;
for
there
was
a
cunning
light
in
his
eyes
as
he
said
all
this
,
which
seemed
to
cast
a
disagreeable
illumination
on
the
change
in
him
,
and
make
it
morally
uglier
.
   
<EOS>
THE
GOLDEN
DUSTMAN
FALLS
INTO
WORSE
COMPANY
.
 
<EOS>
It
had
come
to
pass
that
Mr.
Silas
Wegg
now
rarely
attended
the
minion
of
fortune
and
the
worm
of
the
hour
,
at
his
(
the
worm
's
and
minion
's
)
own
house
,
but
lay
under
general
instructions
to
await
him
within
a
certain
margin
of
hours
at
the
Bower
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
took
this
arrangement
in
great
dudgeon
,
because
the
appointed
hours
were
evening
hours
,
and
those
he
considered
precious
to
the
progress
of
the
friendly
move
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
quite
in
character
,
he
bitterly
remarked
to
Mr.
Venus
,
that
the
upstart
who
had
trampled
on
those
eminent
creatures
,
Miss
Elizabeth
,
Master
George
,
Aunt
Jane
,
and
Uncle
Parker
,
should
oppress
his
literary
man
.
  
<EOS>
The
Roman
Empire
having
worked
out
its
destruction
,
Mr.
Boffin
next
appeared
in
a
cab
with
Rollin
's
Ancient
History
,
which
valuable
work
being
found
to
possess
lethargic
properties
,
broke
down
,
at
about
the
period
when
the
whole
of
the
army
of
Alexander
the
Macedonian
(
at
that
time
about
forty
thousand
strong
)
burst
into
tears
simultaneously
,
on
his
being
taken
with
a
shivering
fit
after
bathing
.
<EOS>
The
Wars
of
the
Jews
,
likewise
languishing
under
Mr.
Wegg
's
generalship
,
Mr.
Boffin
arrived
in
another
cab
with
Plutarch
:
whose
Lives
he
found
in
the
sequel
extremely
entertaining
,
though
he
hoped
Plutarch
might
not
expect
him
to
believe
them
all
.
<EOS>
What
to
believe
,
in
the
course
of
his
reading
,
was
Mr.
Boffin
's
chief
literary
difficulty
indeed
;
for
some
time
he
was
divided
in
his
mind
between
half
,
all
,
or
none
;
at
length
,
when
he
decided
,
as
a
moderate
man
,
to
compound
with
half
,
the
question
still
remained
,
which
half
?
<EOS>
And
that
stumbling
-
block
he
never
got
over
.
  
<EOS>
One
evening
,
when
Silas
Wegg
had
grown
accustomed
to
the
arrival
of
his
patron
in
a
cab
,
accompanied
by
some
profane
historian
charged
with
unutterable
names
of
incomprehensible
peoples
,
of
impossible
descent
,
waging
wars
any
number
of
years
and
syllables
long
,
and
carrying
illimitable
hosts
and
riches
about
,
with
the
greatest
ease
,
beyond
the
confines
of
geography
---
one
evening
the
usual
time
passed
by
,
and
no
patron
appeared
.
<EOS>
After
half
an
hour
's
grace
,
Mr.
Wegg
proceeded
to
the
outer
gate
,
and
there
executed
a
whistle
,
conveying
to
Mr.
Venus
,
if
perchance
within
hearing
,
the
tidings
of
his
being
at
home
and
disengaged
.
<EOS>
Forth
from
the
shelter
of
a
neighbouring
wall
,
Mr.
Venus
then
emerged
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brother
in
arms
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
in
excellent
spirits
,
"
welcome
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
return
,
Mr.
Venus
gave
him
a
rather
dry
good
evening
.
  
<EOS>
"
Walk
in
,
brother
,
"
said
Silas
,
clapping
him
on
the
shoulder
,
"
and
take
your
seat
in
my
chimley
corner
;
for
what
says
the
ballad
?
   
<EOS>
`
`
No
malice
to
dread
,
sir
,
  
And
no
falsehood
to
fear
,
  
But
truth
to
delight
me
,
Mr.
Venus
,
  
<EOS>
And
I
forgot
what
to
cheer
.
  
<EOS>
Li
toddle
dee
om
dee
.
  
<EOS>
And
something
to
guide
,
  
<EOS>
My
ain
fireside
,
sir
,
  
My
ain
fireside
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
With
this
quotation
(
depending
for
its
neatness
rather
on
the
spirit
than
the
words
)
,
Mr.
Wegg
conducted
his
guest
to
his
hearth
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
you
come
,
brother
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
in
a
hospitable
glow
,
"
you
come
like
I
do
n't
know
<EOS>
what
---
exactly
like
it
---
I
should
n't
know
you
from
it
---
shedding
a
halo
all
around
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
kind
of
halo
?
"
asked
Mr.
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
'
Ope
sir
,
"
replied
Silas
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
your
halo
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
appeared
doubtful
on
the
point
,
and
looked
rather
discontentedly
at
the
fire
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
'll
devote
the
evening
,
brother
,
"
exclaimed
Wegg
,
"
to
prosecute
our
friendly
move
.
<EOS>
And
arterwards
,
crushing
a
flowing
wine
-
cup
---
which
I
allude
to
brewing
rum
and
water
---
we
'll
pledge
one
another
.
<EOS>
For
what
says
the
Poet
?
   
<EOS>
`
<EOS>
`
And
you
need
n't
Mr.
Venus
be
your
black
bottle
,
  
<EOS>
For
surely
I
'll
be
mine
,
  
<EOS>
And
we
'll
take
a
glass
with
a
slice
of
lemon
in
it
to
which
you
're
partial
,
  
<EOS>
For
auld
lang
syne
.
"
"
"
This
flow
of
quotation
and
hospitality
in
Wegg
indicated
his
observation
of
some
little
querulousness
on
the
part
of
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
as
to
the
friendly
move
,
"
observed
the
last
-
named

,
rubbing

peevishly
,
"
one
of
my
objections
to
it
is
,
that
it
do
n't
move
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rome
,
brother
,
"
returned
Wegg
:
"
a
city
which
(
it
may
not
be
generally
known
)
originated
in
twins
and
a
wolf
,
and
ended
in
Imperial
marble
:
was
n't
built
in
a
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
say
it
was
?
"
asked
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
you
did
not
,
brother
.
<EOS>
Well
-
inquired
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
say
,
"
proceeded
Venus
,
"
that
I
am
taken
from
among
my
trophies
of
anatomy
,
am
called
upon
to
exchange
my
human
warious
for
more
coal
-
ashes
warious
,
and
nothing
comes
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
must
give
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
remonstrated
Wegg
,
enthusiastically
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
sir
!
  
<EOS>
`
`
Charge
,
Chester
,
charge
,
  
<EOS>
On
,
Mr.
Venus
,
on
!
"
<EOS>
"
Never
say
die
,
sir
!
<EOS>
A
man
of
your
mark
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
so
much
saying
it
that
I
object
to
,
"
returned
Mr.
Venus
,
"
as
doing
it
.
<EOS>
And
having
got
to
do
it
whether
or
no
,
I
ca
n't
afford
to
waste
my
time
on
groping
for
nothing
in
cinders
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
think
how
little
time
you
have
given
to
the
move
,
sir
,
after
all
,
"
urged
Wegg
.
"
<EOS>
Add
the
evenings
so
occupied
together
,
and
what
do
they
come
to
?
<EOS>
And
you
,
sir
,
harmonizer
with
myself
in
opinions
,
views
,
and
feelings
,
you
with
the
patience
to
fit
together
on
wires
the
whole
framework
of
society
---
I
allude
to
the
human
skelinton
---
<EOS>
you
to
give
in
so
soon
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
it
,
"
returned
Mr.
Venus
moodily
,
as
he
put
his
head
between
his
knees
and
stuck
up
his
dusty
hair
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
there
's
no
encouragement
to
go
on
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
them
Mounds
without
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
extending
his
right
hand
with
an
air
of
solemn
reasoning
,
"
encouragement
?
<EOS>
Not
them
Mounds
now
looking
down
upon
us
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
're
too
big
,
"
grumbled
Venus
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
a
scratch
here
and
a
scrape
there
,
a
poke
in
this
place
and
a
dig
in
the
other
,
to
them
?
<EOS>
Besides
;
what
have
we
found
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
have
we
found
?
"
cried
Wegg
,
delighted
to
be
able
to
acquiesce
.
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
There
I
grant
you
,
comrade
.
<EOS>
Nothing
.
<EOS>
But
on
the
contrary
,
comrade
,
what
may
we
find
?
<EOS>
There
you
'll
grant
me
.
<EOS>
Anything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
it
,
"
pettishly
returned
Venus
as
before
.
<EOS>
"
I
came
into
it
without
enough
consideration
.
<EOS>
And
besides
again
.
<EOS>
Is
n't
your
own
Mr.
Boffin
well

with
the
Mounds
?
<EOS>
And
was
n't
he
well

with
the
deceased
and
his
ways
?
<EOS>
And
has
he
ever
showed
any
expectation
of
finding
anything
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
At
that
moment
wheels
were
heard
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
should
be
loth
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
with

patient

,
"
to
think
so
ill
of
him
as
to
suppose
him
capable

coming
at

night
.
<EOS>
And

like
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
A

at

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
him
,
"
said
Mr.
Wegg
,
"
and
he
is
capable
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
,
because
I
could
have

.
"
  
<EOS>
Here

Boffin
was
heard
lustily

at

,
"
Halloa
!
<EOS>
Wegg
!
<EOS>
Halloa
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Keep
your
seat
,
Mr.
Venus
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
He
may
not
stop
.
"
 
<EOS>
And
then
called

,
"
Halloa
,
sir
!
<EOS>
Halloa
!
<EOS>
I
'm
with

,
sir
!
<EOS>
Half
a
minute
,
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
Coming
,

,
as

my
leg
will
bring

!
"
<EOS>
And
so

much

stumped
out

with

,

,

,
blocked

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
!
lend

,

,
"

,
"
I
ca
n't

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
This

,
Wegg
,

<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For

,

Animal

,

,

.
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Catch

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Call

"

in

;
"
get

.
<EOS>
Do

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
Him

made

.
<EOS>
Where

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
But

Taylor

,

.
<EOS>
These

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Not

,

,

<EOS>
"
There
!
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

---

.
<EOS>
Get

,
Wegg
;

,

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg

.
  
<EOS>
"
Eh
?
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Of

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

"

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>

?

<EOS>
With

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

?

<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are

a

?
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Because

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
"
a

,
"
a
Teapot
,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.

:
and
Mr.
Wegg
,
in

,

,

,

:

.
  
<EOS>

A

,
"

,

"
a

,
a

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
Venus

,
Silas
pegged

,
to

.

"
Hem
!

!
<EOS>
"

,

---

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

no
,

.
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
This

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
"

?

<EOS>
"
Well
,

,
"

,
"
I

,

;

,

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
Give

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
With

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Page

,

.
<EOS>
Chapter

.
<EOS>
Contents

,
`
`

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Bob

.
<EOS>
Griffiths

.
<EOS>
How

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
The

---
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
Eh
?
<EOS>
What

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
`
`
The

,
"
"
sir
,
"
repeated
Silas
,

,
"
`
`

.
"
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Venus
,

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
This
,
to
secure
attention
to
his
adding
with
his

only
,
"
Mounds
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
drew
an
arm
-
chair
into
the
space
where
he
stood
,
and
said
,
seating
himself
and
slyly
rubbing
his
hands
:
  
<EOS>
"
Give
us
Dancer
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
pursued
the
biography
of
that
eminent
man
through
its
various
phases
of
avarice
and
dirt
,
through
Miss
Dancer
's
death
on
a
sick
regimen
of
cold
dumpling
,
and
through
Mr.
Dancer
's
keeping
his
rags
together
with
a
hayband
,
and
warming
his
dinner
by
sitting
upon
it
,
down
to
the
consolatory
incident
of
his
dying
naked
in
a
sack
.
<EOS>
After
which
he
read
on
as
follows
:
  
"
`
`
The
house
,
or
rather
the
heap
of
ruins
,
in
which
Mr.
Dancer
lived
,
and
which
at
his
death
devolved
to
the
right
of
Captain
Holmes
,
was
a
most
miserable
,
decayed
building
,
for
it
had
not
been
repaired
for
more
than
half
a
century
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
(
Here
Mr.
Wegg
eyed
his
comrade
and
the
room
in
which
they
sat
:
which
had
not
been
repaired
for
a
long
time
.
)
  
"
`
`
But
though
poor
in
external
structure
,
the
ruinous
fabric
was
very
rich
in
the
interior
.
<EOS>
It
took
many
weeks
to
explore
its
whole
contents
;
and
Captain
Holmes
found
it
a
very
agreeable
task
to
dive
into
the
miser
's
secret
hoards
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
(
Here
Mr.
Wegg
repeated
`
`
secret
hoards
,
"
"
and
pegged
his
comrade
again
.
)
  
"
`
`
One
of
Mr.
Dancer
's
richest
escretoires
was
found
to
be
a
dungheap
in
the
cowhouse
;
a
sum
but
little
short
of
two
thousand
five
hundred
pounds
was
contained
in
this
rich
piece
of
manure
;
and
in
an
old
jacket
,
carefully
tied
,
and
strongly
nailed
down
to
the
manger
,
in
bank
notes
and
gold
were
found
five
hundred
pounds
more
.
"
"
"
  
(
Here
Mr.
Wegg
's
wooden
leg
started
forward
under
the
table
,
and
slowly
elevated
itself
as
he
read
on
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
`
`
Several
bowls
were
discovered
filled
with
guineas
and
half
-
guineas
;
 
and
at
different
times
on
searching
the
corners
of
the
house
they
found
various
parcels
of
bank
notes
.
<EOS>
Some
were
crammed
into
the
crevices
of
the
wall
;
"
"
"
  
(
Here
Mr.
Venus
looked
at
the
wall
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
`
`
Bundles
were
hid
under
the
cushions
and
covers
of
the
chairs
;
"
"
"
  
(
Here
Mr.
Venus
looked
under
himself
on
the
settle
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
`
`
Some
were
reposing
snugly
at
the
back
of
the
drawers
;
and
notes
amounting
to
six
hundred
pounds
were
found
neatly
doubled
up
in
the
inside
of
an
old
teapot
.
<EOS>
In
the
stable
the
Captain
found
jugs
full
of
old
dollars
and
shillings
.
<EOS>
The
chimney
was
not
left
unsearched
,
and
paid
very
well
for
the
trouble
;
for
in
nineteen
different
holes
,
all
filled
with
soot
,
were
found
various
sums
of
money
,
amounting
together
to
more
than
two
hundred
pounds
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
On
the
way
to
this
crisis
Mr.
Wegg
's
wooden
leg
had
gradually
elevated
itself
more
and
more
,
and
he
had
nudged
Mr.
Venus
with
his
opposite
elbow
deeper
and
deeper
,
until
at
length
the
preservation
of
his
balance
became
incompatible
with
the
two
actions
,
and
he
now
dropped
over
sideways
upon
that
gentleman
,
squeezing
him
against
the
settle
's
edge
.
<EOS>
Nor
did
either
of
the
two
,
for
some
few
seconds
,
make
any
effort
to
recover
himself
;
both
remaining
in
a
kind
of
pecuniary
swoon
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
sight
of
Mr.
Boffin
sitting
in
the
arm
-
chair
hugging
himself
,
with
his
eyes
upon
the
fire
,
acted
as
a
restorative
.
<EOS>
Counterfeiting
a
sneeze
to
cover
their
movements
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
with
a
spasmodic
"
Tish
-
ho
!
"
pulled
himself
and
Mr.
Venus
up
in
a
masterly
manner
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
's
have
some
more
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
hungrily
.
  
<EOS>
"
John
Elwes
is
the
next
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Is
it
your
pleasure
to
take
John
Elwes
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Let
's
hear
what
John
did
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
appear
to
have
hidden
anything
,
so
went
off
rather
flatly
.
<EOS>
But
an
exemplary
lady
named
Wilcocks
,
who
had
stowed
away
gold
and
silver
in
a
pickle
-
pot
in
a
clock
-
case
,
a
canister
-
full
of
treasure
in
a
hole
under
her
stairs
,
and
a
quantity
of
money
in
an
old
rat
-
trap
,
revived
the
interest
.
<EOS>
To
her
succeeded
another
lady
,
claiming
to
be
a
pauper
,
whose
wealth
was
found
wrapped
up
in
little
scraps
of
paper
and
old
rag
.
<EOS>
To
her
,
another
lady
,
apple
-
woman
by
trade
,
who
had
saved
a
fortune
of
ten
thousand
pounds
and
hidden
it
"
here
and
there
,
in
cracks
and
corners
,
behind
bricks
and
under
the
flooring
.
"
<EOS>
To
her
,
a
French
gentleman
,
who
had
crammed
up
his
chimney
,
rather
to
the
detriment
of
its
drawing
powers
,
"
a
leather
valise
,
containing
twenty
thousand
francs
,
gold
coins
,
and
a
large
quantity
of
precious
stones
,
"
as
discovered
by
a
chimneysweep
after
his
death
.
<EOS>
By
these
steps
Mr.
Wegg
arrived
at
a
concluding
instance
of
the
human
Magpie
:
  
"
"
Many
years
ago
,
there
lived
at
Cambridge
a
miserly
old
couple
of
the
name
of
Jardine
<EOS>
:
they
had
two
sons
:
the
father
was
a
perfect
miser
,
and
at
his
death
one
thousand
guineas
were
discovered
secreted
in
his
bed
.
<EOS>
The
two
sons
grew
up
as
parsimonious
as
their
sire
.
<EOS>
When
about
twenty
years
of
age
,
they
commenced
business
at
Cambridge
as
drapers
,
and
they
continued
there
until
their
death
.
<EOS>
The
establishment
of
the
Messrs.
Jardine
was
the
most
dirty
of
all
the
shops
in
Cambridge
.
<EOS>
Customers
seldom
went
in
to
purchase
,
except
perhaps
out
of
curiosity
.
<EOS>
The
brothers
were
most
disreputable
-
looking
beings
;
for
,
although
surrounded
with
gay
apparel
as
their
staple
in
trade
,
they
wore
the
most
filthy
rags
themselves
.
<EOS>
It
is
said
that
they
had
no
bed
,
and
,
to
save
the
expense
of
one
,
always
slept
on
a
bundle
of
packing
-
cloths
under
the
counter
.
<EOS>
In
their
housekeeping
they
were
penurious
in
the
extreme
.
<EOS>
A
joint
of
meat
did
not
grace
their
board
for
twenty
years
.
<EOS>
Yet
when
the
first
of
the
brothers
died
,
the
other
,
much
to
his
surprise
,
found
large
sums
of
money
which
had
been
secreted
even
from
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
cried
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Even
from
him
,
you
see
!
<EOS>
There
was
only
two
of
'em
,
and
yet
one
of
'em
hid
from
the
other
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
,
who
since
his
introduction
to
the
French
gentleman
,
had
been
stooping
to
peer
up
the
chimney
,
had
his
attention
recalled
by
the
last
sentence
,
and
took
the
liberty
of
repeating
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
like
it
?
"
asked
Mr.
Boffin
,
turning
suddenly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
beg
your
pardon
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
like
what
Wegg
's
been
a
-
reading
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
answered
that
he
found
it
extremely
interesting
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
come
again
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
and
hear
some
more
.
<EOS>
Come
when
you
like
;
come
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
,
half
an
hour
sooner
.
<EOS>
There
's
plenty
more
;
there
's
no
end
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
expressed
his
acknowledgments
and
accepted
the
invitation
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
wonderful
<EOS>
what
's
been
hid
,
at
one
time
and
another
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
ruminating
;
"
truly
wonderful
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Meaning
sir
,
"
observed
Wegg
,
with
a

to

,
and
with

peg
at
his
friend
and
brother
,
"
in
the
way
of
money
?
"
  
"
Money
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
And
papers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
,
in
a

,
again

over
on
Mr.
Venus
,
and
again

,
masked

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Tish
-
ho
!
<EOS>
Did
you
say
papers
too
,
sir
?
<EOS>
Been
hidden
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hidden
and

,
"

Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Why
the
bookseller
that
sold

the
Wonderful
Museum
---
where
's
the
Wonderful
Museum
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
He
was
on
his
knees
on
the
floor
in

,

among

.
  
<EOS>
"
Can
I
assist

,

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
have
got
it
;

,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Wollume
four
.
<EOS>
I
know
it
was
the
fourth
wollume
,
that
the
bookseller
read

to
me
out

.
<EOS>
Look
for
it
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Silas
took
the
book
and
turned

.
  
<EOS>
"
Remarkable
petrefaction
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
that
's
not
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
It
ca
n't

petrefaction
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Memoirs
of
General
John
Reid
,

,

?
<EOS>
With

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Remarkable
case
of

who
swallowed

-
piece
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
To
hide

?
"

Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
no
,

,
"

Wegg
,
consulting

text
<EOS>
,
"
it
appears
to
have

done
by

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
This
next
must
be
it
.
`
`
Singular
discovery
of
a
will
,
lost
twenty
-
one
years
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
That
's
it
!
"
cried
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Read
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
`
`
A
most
extraordinary
case
,
"
"
"
read
Silas
Wegg
aloud
,
"
`
`
was
tried
at
the
last
Maryborough
assizes
in
Ireland
.
<EOS>
It
was
briefly
this
.
<EOS>
Robert
Baldwin
,
in
March
1782
,
made
his
will
,
in
which
he
devised
the
lands
now
in
question
,
to
the
children
of
his
youngest
son
;
soon
after
which
his
faculties
failed
him
,
and
he
became
altogether
childish
and
died
,
above
eighty
years
old
.
<EOS>
The
defendant
,
the
eldest
son
,
immediately
afterwards
gave
out
that
his
father
had
destroyed
the
will
;
and
no
will
being
found
,
he
entered
into
possession
of
the
lands
in
question
,
and
so
matters
remained
for
twenty
-
one
years
,
the
whole
family
during
all
that
time
believing
that
the
father
had
died
without
a
will
.
<EOS>
But
after
twenty
-
one
years
the
defendant
's
wife
died
,
and
he
very
soon
afterwards
,
at
the
age
of
seventy
-
eight
,
married
a
very
young
woman
:
which
caused
some
anxiety
to
his
two
sons
,
whose
poignant
expressions
of
this
feeling
so
exasperated
their
father
,
that
he
in
his
resentment
executed
a
will
to
disinherit
his
eldest
son
,
and
in
his
fit
of
anger
showed
it
to
his
second
son
,
who
instantly
determined
to
get
at
it
,
and
destroy
it
,
in
order
to
preserve
the
property
to
his
brother
.
<EOS>
With
this
view
,
he
broke
open
his
father
's
desk
,
where
he
found
---
not
his
father
's
will
which
he
sought
after
,
but
the
will
of
his
grandfather
,
which
was
then
altogether
forgotten
in
the
family
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
There
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
See
what
men
put
away
and
forget
,
or
mean
to
destroy
,
and
do
n't
!
"
<EOS>
He
then
added
in
a
slow
tone
,
"
As
---
ton
---
ish
---
ing
!
"
<EOS>
And
as
he
rolled
his
eyes
all
round
the
room
,
<EOS>
Wegg
and
Venus
likewise
rolled
their
eyes
all
round
the
room
.
<EOS>
And
then
Wegg
,
singly
,
fixed
his
eyes
on
Mr.
Boffin
looking
at
the
fire
again
;
as
if
he
had
a
mind
to
spring
upon
him
and
demand
his
thoughts
or
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
However
,
time
's
up
for
to
-
night
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
waving
his
hand
after
a

.
<EOS>
"
More
,
the
day
after
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Range
the
books
upon
the
shelves
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
I
dare
say
Mr.
Venus
will
be
so
kind
as
help
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
While
speaking
,
he
thrust
his
hand
into
the
breast
of
his
outer
coat
,
and
struggled
with
some
object
there
that
was
too
large
to
be
got
out
easily
.
<EOS>
What
was
the
stupefaction
of
the
friendly
movers
when
this
object
at
last
emerging
,
proved
to
be
a
much
-
dilapidated
dark
lantern
!
  
<EOS>
Without
at
all
noticing
the
effect
produced
by
this
little
instrument
,
Mr.
Boffin
stood
it
on
his
knee
,
and
,
producing
a
box
of
matches
,
deliberately
lighted
the
candle
in
the
lantern
,
blew
out
the
kindled
match
,
and
cast
the
end
into
the
fire
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
going
,
Wegg
,
"
 
he
then
announced
,
"
to
take
a
turn
about
the
place
and
round
the
yard
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
you
.
<EOS>
Me
and
this
same
lantern
have
taken
hundreds
---
thousands
---
of
such
turns
in
our
time
together
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
could
n't
think
,
sir
---
not
on
any
account
,
I
could
n't
,
"
---
  
<EOS>
Wegg
was
politely
beginning
,
when
Mr.
Boffin
,
who
had
risen
and
was
going
towards
the
door
,
stopped
:
  
"
I
have
told
you
that
I
do
n't
want
you
,
Wegg
.
"
  
<EOS>
Wegg
looked
intelligently
thoughtful
,
as
if
that
had
not
occurred
to
his
mind
until
he
now
brought
it
to
bear
on

.
<EOS>
He
had
nothing
for
it
but
to
let
Mr.
Boffin
go
out
and
shut
the
door
behind
him
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
instant
he
was
on
the
other
side
of
it
,
Wegg
clutched
Venus
with
both
hands
,
and
said
in

,
as
if

were
being

:
  
"
Mr.
Venus
,
he
must
be
followed
,
he
must

watched
,
he
must
n't
be
lost
sight

for

moment
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
must
n't
he
?
"
asked
Venus
,
also
strangling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Comrade
,
you
might
have
noticed
I
was
a
little
elewated
in
spirits
when
you
come
in
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
I
've
found
something
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
have
you
found
?
"
asked
Venus
,
clutching
him
with
both
hands
,
so
that
they
stood
interlocked
like
a
couple
of
preposterous
