.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
no
time
to
tell
you
now
.
<EOS>
I
think
he
must
have
gone
to
look
for
it
.
<EOS>
We
must
have
an
eye
upon
him
instantly
.
"
  
<EOS>
Releasing
each
other
,
they
crept
to
the
door
,
opened
it
softly
,
and
peeped
out
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
cloudy
night
,
and
the
black
shadow
of
the
Mounds
made
the
dark
yard
darker
.
<EOS>
"
If
not
a
double
swindler
,
"
 
whispered
Wegg
,
"
why
a
dark
lantern
?
<EOS>
We
could
have
seen
what
he
was
about
,
if
he
had
carried
a
light
one
.
<EOS>
Softly
,
this
way
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Cautiously
along
the
path
that
was
bordered
by
fragments
of
crockery
set
in
ashes
,
the
two
stole
after
him
.
<EOS>
They
could
hear
him
at
his
peculiar
trot
,
crushing
the
loose
cinders
as
he
went
.
"
<EOS>
He
knows
the
place
by
heart
,
"
muttered
Silas
,
"
and
do
n't
need
to
turn
his
lantern
on
,
confound
him
!
"
<EOS>
But
he
did
turn
it
on
,
almost
in
that
same
instant
,
and
flashed
its
light
upon
the
first
of
the
Mounds
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
the
spot
?
"
asked
Venus
in
a
whisper
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
warm
,
"
said
Silas
in
the
same
tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
's
precious
warm
.
<EOS>
He
's
close
.
<EOS>
I
think
he
must
be
going
to
look
for
it
.
<EOS>
What
's
that
he
's
got
in
his
hand
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
shovel
,
"
answered
Venus
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
knows
how
to
use
it
,
remember
,
fifty
times
as
well
as
either
of
us
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
he
looks
for
it
and
misses
it
,
partner
,
"
suggested
Wegg
,
"
what
shall
we
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
First
of
all
,
wait
till
he
does
,
"
said
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
Discreet
advice
too
,
for
he
darkened
his
lantern
again
,
and
the
mound
turned
black
.
<EOS>
After
a
few
seconds
,
he
turned
the
light
on
once
more
,
and
was
seen
standing
at
the
foot
of
the
second
mound
,
slowly
raising
the
lantern
little
by
little
until
he
held
it
up
at
arm
's
length
,
as
if
he
were
examining
the
condition
of
the
whole
surface
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
ca
n't
be
the
spot
too
?
"
said
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Wegg
,
"
he
's
getting
cold
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
strikes
me
,
"
whispered
Venus
,
"
that
he
wants
to
find
out
whether
any
one
has
been
groping
about
there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
returned
Wegg
,
"
he
's
getting
colder
and
colder
.
<EOS>
---
Now
he
's
freezing
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
exclamation
was
elicited
by
his
having
turned
the
lantern
off
again
,
and
on
again
,
and
being
visible
at
the
foot
of
the
third
mound
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
he
's
going
up
it
!
"
<EOS>
said
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shovel
and
all
!
"
said
Wegg
.
  
<EOS>
At
a
nimbler
trot
,
as
if
the
shovel
over
his
shoulder
stimulated
him
by
reviving
old
associations
,
Mr.
Boffin
ascended
the
"
serpentining
walk
,
"
up
the
Mound
which
he
had
described
to
Silas
Wegg
on
the
occasion
of
their
beginning
to
decline
and
fall
.
<EOS>
On
striking
into
it
he
turned
his
lantern
off
.
<EOS>
The
two
followed
him
,
stooping
low
,
so
that
their
figures
might
make
no
mark
in
relief
against
the
sky
when
he
should
turn
his
lantern
on
again
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
took
the
lead
,
towing
Mr.
Wegg
,
in
order
that
his
refractory
leg
might
be
promptly
extricated
from
any
pitfalls
it
should
dig
for
itself
.
<EOS>
They
could
just
make
out
that
the
Golden
Dustman
stopped
to
breathe
.
<EOS>
Of
course
they
stopped
too
,
instantly
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
his
own
Mound
,
"
whispered
Wegg
,
as
he
recovered
his
wind
,
"
this
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
all
three
are
his
own
,
"
returned
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
he
thinks
;
but
he
's
used
to
call
this
his
own
,
because
it
's
the
one
first
left
to
him
;
the
one
that
was
his
legacy
when
it
was
all
he
took
under
the
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When
he
shows
his
light
,
"
said
Venus
,
keeping
watch
upon
his
dusky
figure
all
the
time
,
"
drop
lower
and
keep
closer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
went
on
again
,
and
they
followed
again
.
<EOS>
Gaining
the
top
of
the
Mound
,
he
turned
on
his
light
---
but
only
partially
---
and
stood
it
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
A
bare
lopsided
weatherbeaten
pole
was
planted
in
the
ashes
there
,
and
had
been
there
many
a
year
.
<EOS>
Hard
by
this
pole
,
his
lantern
stood
:
lighting
a
few
feet
of
the
lower
part
of
it
and
a
little
of
the
ashy
surface
around
,
and
then
casting
off
a
purposeless
little
clear
trail
of
light
into
the
air
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
can
never
be
going
to
dig
up
the
pole
!
"
<EOS>
whispered
Venus
as
they
dropped
low
and
kept
close
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
's
holler
and
full
of
something
,
"
whispered
Wegg
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
going
to
dig
,
with
whatsoever
object
,
for
he
tucked
up
his
cuffs
and
spat
on
his
hands
,
and
then
went
at
it
like
an
old
digger
as
he
was
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
design
upon
the
pole
,
except
that
he
measured
a
shovel
's
length
from
it
before
beginning
,
nor
was
it
his
purpose
to
dig
deep
.
<EOS>
Some
dozen
or
so
of
expert
strokes
sufficed
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
stopped
,
looked
down
into
the
cavity
,
bent
over
it
,
and
took
out
what
appeared
to
be
an
ordinary
case
-
bottle
:
one
of
those
squat
,
high
-
shouldered
,
short
-
necked
glass
bottles
which
the
Dutchman
is
said
to
keep
his
Courage
in
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
had
done
this
,
he
turned
off
his
lantern
,
and
they
could
hear
that
he
was
filling
up
the
hole
in
the
dark
.
<EOS>
The
ashes
being
easily
moved
by
a
skilful
hand
,
the
spies
took
this
as
a
hint
to
make
off
in
good
time
.
<EOS>
Accordingly
,
Mr.
Venus
slipped
past
Mr.
Wegg
and
towed
him
down
.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Wegg
's
descent
was
not
accomplished
without
some
personal
inconvenience
,
for
his
self
-
willed
leg
sticking
into
the
ashes
about
half
way
down
,
and
time
pressing
,
Mr.
Venus
took
the
liberty
of
hauling
him
from
his
tether
by
the
collar
:
which
occasioned
him
to
make
the
rest
of
the
journey
on
his
back
,
with
his
head
enveloped
in
the
skirts
of
his
coat
,
and
his
wooden
leg
coming
last
,
like
a
drag
.
<EOS>
So
flustered
was
Mr.
Wegg
by
this
mode
of
travelling
,
that
when
he
was
set
on
the
level
ground
with
his
intellectual
developments
uppermost
,
he
was
quite
unconscious
of
his
bearings
,
and
had
not
the
least
idea
where
his
place
of
residence
was
to
be
found
,
until
Mr.
Venus
shoved
him
into
it
.
<EOS>
Even
then
he
staggered
round
and
round
,
weakly
staring
about
him
,
until
Mr.
Venus
with
a
hard
brush
brushed
his
senses
into
him
and
the
dust
out
of
him
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
came
down
leisurely
,
for
this
brushing
process
had
been
well
accomplished
,
and
Mr.
Venus
had
had
time
to
take
his
breath
,
before
he
reappeared
.
<EOS>
That
he
had
the
bottle
somewhere
about
him
could
not
be
doubted
;
where
,
was
not
so
clear
.
<EOS>
He
wore
a
large
rough
coat
,
buttoned
over
,
and
it
might
be
in
any
one
of
half
a
dozen
pockets
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
's
the
matter
,
Wegg
?
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
as
palo
as
a
candle
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
replied
,
with
literal
exactness
,
that
he
felt
as
if
he
had
had
a
turn
.
  
<EOS>
"
Bile
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
blowing
out
the
light
in
the
lantern
,
shutting
it
up
,
and
stowing
it
away
in
the
breast
of
his
coat
as
before
.
<EOS>
"
Are
you
subject
to
bile
,
Wegg
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
again
replied
,
with
strict
adherence
to
truth
,
that
he
did
n't
think
he
had
ever
had
a
similar
sensation
in
his
head
,
to
anything
like
the
same
extent
.
  
<EOS>
"
Physic
yourself
to
-
morrow
,
Wegg
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
to
be
in
order
for
next
night
.
<EOS>
By
-
the
-
by
,
this
neighbourhood
is
going
to
have
a
loss
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
loss
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Going
to
lose
the
Mounds
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
friendly
movers
made
such
an
obvious
effort
not
to
look
at
one
another
,
that
they
might
as
well
have
stared
at
one
another
with
all
their
might
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
parted
with
them
,
Mr.
Boffin
?
"
asked
Silas
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
they
're
going
.
<EOS>
Mine
's
as
good
as
gone
already
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
the
little
one
of
the
three
,
with
the
pole
atop
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
rubbing
his
ear
in
his
old
way
,
with
that
new
touch
of
craftiness
added
to
it
.
<EOS>
"
It
has
fetched
a
penny
.
<EOS>
It
'll
begin
to
be
carted
off
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
been
out
to
take
leave
of
your
old
friend
,
sir
?
"
asked
Silas
,
jocosely
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
What
the
devil
put
that
in
your
head
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
so
sudden
and
rough
,
that
Wegg
,
who
had
been
hovering
closer
and
closer
to
his
skirts
,
despatching
the
back
of
his
hand
on
exploring
expeditions
in
search
of
the
bottle
's
surface
,
retired
two
or
three
paces
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
offence
,
sir
,
"
said
Wegg
,
humbly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
offence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
eyed
him
as
a
dog
might
eye
another
dog
who
wanted
his
bone
;
and
actually
retorted
with
a
low
growl
,
as
the
dog
might
have
retorted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
night
,
"
he
said
,
after
having
sunk
into
a
moody
silence
,
with
his
hands
clasped
behind
him
,
and
his
eyes
suspiciously
wandering
about
Wegg
.
<EOS>
---
"
No
!
stop
there
.
<EOS>
I
know
the
way
out
,
and
I
want
no
light
.
"
  
<EOS>
Avarice
,
and
the
evening
's
legends
of
avarice
,
and
the
inflammatory
effect
of
what
he
had
seen
,
and
perhaps
the
rush
of
his
illconditioned
blood
to
his
brain
in
his
descent
,
wrought
Silas
Wegg
to
such
a
pitch
of
insatiable
appetite
,
that
when
the
door
closed
he
made
a
swoop
at
it
and
drew
Venus
along
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
must
n't
go
,
"
he
cried
.
<EOS>
"
We
must
n't
let
him
go
?
<EOS>
He
has
got
that
bottle
about
him
.
<EOS>
We
must
have
that
bottle
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
would
n't
take
it
by
force
?
<EOS>
"
said
Venus
,
restraining
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Would
n't
I
?
<EOS>
Yes
I
would
.
<EOS>
I
'd
take
it
by
any
force
,
I
'd
have
it
at
any
price
!
<EOS>
Are
you
so
afraid
of
one
old
man
as
to
let
him
go
,
you
coward
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
afraid
of
you
,
<EOS>
as
not
to
let
you
go
,
"
muttered
Venus
,
sturdily
,
clasping
him
in
his
arms
.
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
hear
him
?
"
<EOS>
retorted
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Did
you
hear
him
say
that
he
was
resolved
to
disappoint
us
?
<EOS>
Did
you
hear
him
say
,
you
cur
,
that
he
was
going
to
have
the
Mounds
cleared
off
,
when
no
doubt
the
whole
place
will
be
rummaged
?
<EOS>
If
you
have
n't
the
spirit
of
a
mouse
to
defend
your
rights
,
I
have
.
<EOS>
Let
me
go
after
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
in
his
wildness
he
was
making
a
strong
struggle
for
it
,
Mr.
Venus
deemed
it
expedient
to
lift
him
,
throw
him
,
and
fall
with
him
;
well
knowing
that
,
once
down
,
he
would
not
be
up
again
easily
with
his
wooden
leg
.
<EOS>
So
they
both
rolled
on
the
floor
,
and
,
as
they
did
so
,
Mr.
Boffin
shut
the
gate
.
   
<EOS>
THE
FRIENDLY
MOVE
TAKES
UP
A
STRONG
POSITION
.
 
<EOS>
The
friendly
movers
sat
upright
on
the
floor
,
panting
and
eyeing
one
another
,
after
Mr.
Boffin
had
slammed
the
gate
and
gone
away
.
<EOS>
In
the
weak
eyes
of
Venus
,
and
in
every
reddish
dustcoloured
hair
in
his
shock
of
hair
,
there
was
a
marked
distrust
of
Wegg
and
an
alertness
to
fly
at
him
on
perceiving
the
smallest
occasion
.
<EOS>
In
the
hard
-
grained
face
of
Wegg
,
and
in
his
stiff
knotty
figure
(
he
looked
like
a
German
wooden
toy
)
,
there
was
expressed
a
politic
conciliation
,
which
had
no
spontaneity
in
it
.
<EOS>
Both
were
flushed
,
flustered
,
and
rumpled
,
by
the
late
scuffle
;
and
Wegg
,
in
coming
to
the
ground
,
had
received
a
humming
knock
on
the
back
of
his
devoted
head
,
which
caused
him
still
to
rub
it
with
an
air
of
having
been
highly
---
but
disagreeably
---
astonished
.
<EOS>
Each
was
silent
for
some
time
,
leaving
it
to
the
other
to
begin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
said
Wegg
,
at
length
breaking
the
silence
,
"
you
were
right
,
and
I
was
wrong
.
<EOS>
I
forgot
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
knowingly
cocked
his
shock
of
hair
,
as
rather
thinking
Mr.
Wegg
had
remembered
himself
,
in
respect
of
appearing
without
any
disguise
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
comrade
,
"
pursued
Wegg
,
"
it
was
never
your
lot
to
know
Miss
Elizabeth
,
Master
George
,
Aunt
Jane
,
nor
Uncle
Parker
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
admitted
that
he
had
never
known
those
distinguished
persons
,
and
added
,
in
effect
,
that
he
had
never
so
much
as
desired
the
honor
of
their
acquaintance
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
say
that
,
comrade
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Wegg
<EOS>
;
"
No
,
do
n't
say
that

to

care
of
this
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
who
is
going
to
take
care
of
this
,
partner
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
,
"
said
Wegg
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
no
,
partner
,
"
retorted
Venus
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
mistake
.
<EOS>
I
am
.
<EOS>
Now
look
here
,
Mr.
Wegg
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
want
to
have
any
words
with
you
,
and
still
less
do
I
want
to
have
any
anatomical
pursuits
with
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
said
Wegg
,
quickly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
partner
,
"
replied
Venus
,
slowly
,
"
that
it
's
hardly
possible
for
a
man
to
feel
in
a
more
amiable
state
towards
another
man
than
I
do
towards
you
at
this
present
moment
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
on
my
own
ground
,
I
am
surrounded
by
the
trophies
of
my
art
,
and
my
tools
is
very
handy
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
,
Mr.
Venus
?
"
asked
Wegg
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
surrounded
,
as
I
have
observed
,
"
said
Mr.
Venus
,
placidly
,
"
by
the
trophies
of
my
art
.
<EOS>
They
are
numerous
,
my
stock
of
human
warious
is
large
,
the
shop
is
pretty
well
crammed
,
and
I
do
n't
just
now
want
any
more
trophies
of
my
art
.
<EOS>
But
I
like
my
art
,
and
I
know
how
to
exercise
my
art
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
man
better
,
"
assented
Mr.
Wegg
,
with
a
somewhat

air
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
the
Miscellanies
of
several
human
specimens
,
"
said
Venus
,
"
<EOS>
(
though
you
might
n't
think
it
)
in
the
box
on
which
you
're

.
<EOS>
There
's
the
Miscellanies
of
several
human
specimens
,
in
the
lovely
compo
-
one
behind
the
door
;
"
with
a

French

.
<EOS>
"
It
still
wants
a
pair
of
arms
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
say
that
I
'm
in
any
hurry
for
'
em
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
be
wandering
in

mind
,
partner
,
"
Silas
remonstrated
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
excuse
me
if
I
wander
,
"
returned
Venus
;
"
I
am
sometimes
rather
subject
to
it
.
<EOS>
I
like
my
art
,
and
I
know
how
to
exercise
my
art
,
and
I
mean
to
have

keeping

this

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
what
has
that
got
to
do
with
your
art
,
partner
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Wegg
,
in
an
insinuating
tone
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
winked
his
chronically
-
fatigued
eyes
both
at
once
,
and
adjusting
the
kettle
on
the
fire
,
remarked
to
himself
,
in
a
hollow

,
"
She
'll
bile
in
a
couple
of
minutes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Silas
Wegg
glanced
at
the
kettle
,
glanced
at
the
shelves
,
glanced
at
the
French
gentleman
behind
the
door
,
and
shrank
a
little
as
he
glanced
at
Mr.
Venus
winking
his
red
eyes
,
and
feeling
in
his
waistcoat
pocket
---
as
for
a
lancet
,
say
---
with
his
unoccupied
hand
.
<EOS>
He
and
Venus
were
necessarily
seated
close
together
,
as
each
held
a
corner
of
the
document
,
which
was
but
a
common
sheet
of
paper
.
  
<EOS>
"
Partner
,
"
said
Wegg
,
even
more

than
before
,
"
I
propose
that
we
cut
it
in
half
,
and
each
keep
a
half
.
"
  
<EOS>
Venus
shook
his
shock
of
hair
,
as
he
replied
,
"
It
would
n't
do
to
mutilate
it
,
partner
.
<EOS>
It
might
seem
to
be
cancelled
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Partner
,
"
said
Wegg
,
after
a

,
during
which
they
had
contemplated
one
another
,
"
do
n't
your
speaking
countenance
say
that
you
're
a
-
going
to
suggest

middle

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Venus
shook
his
shock
of
hair
as
he
replied
,
"
Partner
,
you
have
kept
this
paper
from
me
once
.
<EOS>
You
shall
never

.
<EOS>
I
offer

the
box
and
the
label
to
take

of
,
but
I
'll
take

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Silas
hesitated
a
little
longer
,
and
then
suddenly
releasing
his
corner
,
and
resuming
his
buoyant
and
benignant
tone
,
exclaimed
,
"
What
's
life
without
trustfulness
!
<EOS>
What
's
a
fellow
-
man
without
honor
!
<EOS>
You
're
welcome
to
it
,
partner
,
in
a
spirit
of
trust
and
confidence
.
"
  
<EOS>
Continuing
to
wink
his
red
eyes
both
together
---
but
in

self
-
communing
way
,
and
without
any
show

---
Mr.
Venus
folded
the
paper
now
left
in
his
hand
,
and
locked
it
in
a
drawer
behind

,
and
pocketed

key
.
<EOS>
He
then
proposed
"
A
cup
of
tea
,
partner
?
"
<EOS>
To
which
Mr.
Wegg
returned
,
"
Thank'ee
,
partner
,
"
and
the
tea
was
made
and
poured
out
.
  
<EOS>
"
Next
,
"
said
Venus
,
blowing
at
his
tea
in
his
saucer
,
and
looking
over
it
at
his
confidential
friend
,
"
comes
the
question
<EOS>
,
What
's
the
course
to
be
pursued
?
"
  
<EOS>
On
this
head
,
Silas
Wegg
had
much
to
say
.
<EOS>
Silas
had
to
say
That
,
he
would
beg
to
remind
his
comrade
,
brother
,
and
partner
,
of
the
impressive
passages
they
had
read
that
evening
;
of
the
evident
parallel
in
Mr.
Boffin
's
mind
between
them
and
the
late
owner
of
the
Bower
,
and
the
present
circumstances
of
the
Bower
;
of
the
bottle
;
 
and
of
the
box
.
<EOS>
That
,
the
fortunes
of
his
brother
and
comrade
,
and
of
himself
,
were
evidently
made
,
inasmuch
as
they
had
but
to
put
their
price
upon
this
document
,
and
get
that
price
from
the
minion
of
fortune
and
the
worm
of
the
hour
:
who
now
appeared
to
be
less
of
a
minion
and
more
of
a
worm
than
had
been
previously
supposed
.
<EOS>
That
,
he
considered
it
plain
that
such
price
was
stateable
in
a
single
expressive
word
,
and
that
the
word
was
,
"
Halves
!
"
<EOS>
That
,
the
question
then
arose
when
"
Halves
!
"
should
be
called
.
<EOS>
That
,
here
he
had
a
plan
of
action
to
recommend
,
with
a
conditional
clause
.
<EOS>
That
,
the
plan
of
action
was
that
they
should
lie
by
with
patience
;
 
that
,
they
should
allow
the
Mounds
to
be
gradually
levelled
and
cleared
away
,
while
retaining
to
themselves
their
present
opportunity
of
watching
the
process
---
which
would
be
,
he
conceived
,
to
put
the
trouble
and
cost
of
daily
digging
and
delving
upon
somebody
else
,
while
they
might
nightly
turn
such
complete
disturbance
of
the
dust
to
the
account
of
their
own
private
investigations
---
and
that
,
when
the
Mounds
were
gone
,
and
they
had
worked
those
chances
for
their
own
joint
benefit
solely
,
they
should
then
,
and
not
before
,
explode
on
the
minion
and
worm
.
<EOS>
But
here
came
the
conditional
clause
,
and
to
this
he
entreated
the
special
attention
of
his
comrade
,
brother
,
and
partner
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
to
be
borne
that
the
minion
and
worm
should
carry
off
any
of
that
property
which
was
now
to
be
regarded
as
their
own
property
.
<EOS>
When
he
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
had
seen
the
minion
surreptitiously
making
off
with
that
bottle
,
and
its
precious
contents
unknown
,
he
had
looked
upon
him
in
the
light
of
a
mere
robber
,
and
,
as
such
,
would
have
despoiled
him
of
his
ill
-
gotten
gain
,
but
for
the
judicious
interference
of
his
comrade
,
brother
,
and
partner
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
the
conditional
clause
he
proposed
was
,
that
,
if
the
minion
should
return
in
his
late
sneaking
manner
,
and
if
,
being
closely
watched
,
he
should
be
found
to
possess
himself
of
anything
,
no
matter
what
,
the
sharp
sword
impending
over
his
head
should
be
instantly
shown
him
,
he
should
be
strictly
examined
as
to
what
he
knew
or
suspected
,
should
be
severely
handled
by
them
his
masters
,
and
should
be
kept
in
a
state
of
abject
moral
bondage
and
slavery
until
the
time
when
they
should
see
fit
to
permit
him
to
purchase
his
freedom
at
the
price
of
half
his
possessions
.
<EOS>
If
said
Mr.
Wegg
by
way
of
peroration
,
he
had
erred
in
saying
only
"
Halves
!
"
<EOS>
he
trusted
to
his
comrade
,
brother
,
and
partner
not
to
hesitate
to
set
him
right
,
and
to
reprove
his
weakness
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
more
according
to
the
rights
of
things
,
to
say
Twothirds
;
 
it
might
be
more
according
to
the
rights
of
things
,
to
say
Three
-
fourths
.
<EOS>
On
those
points
he
was
ever
open
to
correction
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
,
having
wafted
his
attention
to
this
discourse
over
three
successive
saucers
of
tea
,
signified
his
concurrence
in
the
views
advanced
.
<EOS>
Inspirited
hereby
,
Mr.
Wegg
extended
his
right
hand
,
and
declared
it
to
be
a
hand
which
never
yet
.
<EOS>
Without
entering
into
more
minute
particulars
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
,
sticking
to
his
tea
,
briefly
professed
his
belief
,
as
polite
forms
required
of
him
,
that
it
was
a
hand
which
never
yet
.
<EOS>
But
contented
himself
with
looking
at
it
,
and
did
not
take
it
to
his
bosom
.
  
<EOS>
"
Brother
,
"
said
Wegg
,
when
this
happy
understanding
was
established
,
"
I
should
like
to
ask
you
something
.
<EOS>
You
remember
the
night
when
I
first
looked
in
here
,
and
found
you
floating
your
powerful
mind
in
tea
?
"
  
<EOS>
Still
swilling
tea
,
Mr.
Venus
nodded
assent
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
there
you
sit
,
sir
,
"
pursued
Wegg
with
an
sir

thoughtful

,
"
as
if
you
had
never
left
off
!
<EOS>
There
you
sit
,
sir
,
as
if
you
had
an
unlimited

of
assimilating
the
flagrant
article
!
<EOS>
There
you
sit
,
sir
,
in
the
midst
of
your
works
,
looking
as
if
you
'd
been
called
upon
for
Home
,
Sweet
Home
,
and
was
obleeging
the
company
!
   
<EOS>
"
`
`
A
exile
from
home
splendour
dazzles
in
vain
.
  
<EOS>
O
give
you
your
lowly
Preparations
again
,
  
The
birds
stuffed
so
sweetly
that
ca
n't
be
expected
to
come
at
your
call
,
  
Give
you
these
with
the
peace
of
mind
dearer
than
all
.
  
<EOS>
Home
,
Home
,
Home
,
sweet
Home
!
"
<EOS>
"
"
 
---
Be
it
ever
,
"
added
Mr.
Wegg
in
prose
as
he
glanced
about
the
shop
,
"
<EOS>
ever
so
ghastly
,
all
things
considered
there
's
no
place
like
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
said
you
'd
like
to
ask
something
;
but
you
have
n't
asked
it
,
"
 
remarked
Venus
,
very

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
peace
of
mind
,
"
said
Wegg
,
offering

,
"
your
peace
of
mind
was
in
a
poor
way
that
night
.
<EOS>
How
's
it
going
on
?
<EOS>
Is
it
looking
up
at
all
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
does
not
wish
,
"
replied
Mr.
Venus
with

,
"
to
regard
herself
,
nor
yet
to
be
regarded
,
in
that
particular
light
.
<EOS>
There
's
no
more
to
be
said
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ah
,
dear
me
,
dear
me
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Wegg
with
a
sigh
,
but
eyeing
him
while
pretending
to
keep
him
company
in
eyeing
the
fire
,
"
such
is
Woman
!
<EOS>
And
I
remember
you
said
that
night
,
sitting
there
as
I
sat
here
---
said
that
night
when
your
peace
of
mind
was
first

low
,
that
you
had
taken
an
interest
in
these
very

.
<EOS>
Such
is
coincidence
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Her
father
,
"
rejoined
Venus
,
and
then
stopped
to
swallow
more
tea
,
"
her
father
was
mixed
up
in
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
n't
mention
her
name
,
sir
,
I
think
?
"
<EOS>
observed
Wegg
,
pensively
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
you
did
n't
mention
her
name
that
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pleasant
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In
---
deed
!
"
cried
Wegg
.
"
<EOS>
Pleasant
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
There
's
some
thing
moving
in
the
name
.
<EOS>
Pleasant
.
<EOS>
Dear
me
!
<EOS>
Seems
to
express
what
she
might
have
been
,
if
she
had
n't
made
that
unpleasant
remark
---
and
what
she
ai
n't
,
in
consequence
of
having
made

.
<EOS>
Would
it
at
all
pour
balm
into
your
wounds
,
Mr.
Venus
,
to
inquire
how
you
came
acquainted
with
her
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
down
at
the
water
-
side
,
"
said
Venus
,
taking
another
gulp
of
tea
and

winking
at
the
fire
---
"
looking
for
parrots
"
---
  
taking
another
gulp
and
stopping
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
hinted
,
to
jog
his
attention
:
"
You
could
hardly
have
been
out
parrot
-
shooting
,
in

British

,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
no
,
"
said
Venus
fretfully
.
<EOS>
"
I
was
down
at
the
waterside
,
looking
for
parrots
brought
home
by
sailors
,
to
buy
for
stuffing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
,
ay
,
sir
!
"
  
"
---
And
looking
for
a
nice
pair
of
rattlesnakes
,
to
articulate
for
a
Museum
---
when
I
was
doomed
to
fail
in
with
her
and
deal
with
her
.
<EOS>
It
was
just
at
the
time
of
that
discovery
in
the
river
.
<EOS>
Her
father
had
seen
the
discovery
being
towed
in
the
river
.
<EOS>
I
made
the
popularity
of
the
subject
a
reason
for
going
back
to
improve
the
acquaintance
,
and
I
have
never
since
been
the
man
I
was
.
<EOS>
My
very
bones
is
rendered
flabby
by
brooding
over
it
.
<EOS>
If
they
could
be
brought
to
me
loose
,
to
sort
,
I
should
hardly
have
the
face
to
claim
'em
as
mine
.
<EOS>
to
such
an
extent
have
I
fallen
off
under
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
,
less
interested
than
he
had
been
,
glanced
at
one

in
the
dark
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
I
remember
,
Mr.
Venus
,
"
he
said
in

"
(
for
I
remember

,

)
,
<EOS>
I
remember
that
you
said
that
night
,
you
had

---
and

your
words
was
,
`
`
Never

.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
---
The
parrot
that
I
bought
of
her
,
"
said
Venus
,
with

and

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
;
there

lies
on

,
dried

;
 
except
for
its
plumage
,
very
like
myself
.
<EOS>
I
've
never
had
the
heart
to
prepare
it
,
and
I
never

have
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
disappointed
face
,
Silas
mentally
consigned
this
parrot
to
regions
more
than

,
and
seeming
for
the
time
to
have
lost

of

in
the

of
Mr.
Venus
,
fell
to
tightening
his
wooden
leg
as
a
preparation
for
departure
;
its
gymnastic
performances
of
that
evening
having
severely
tried
its
constitution
.
  
<EOS>
After
Silas
had
left
the
shop
,
hat
-
box
in
hand
,
and
had
left
Mr.
Venus
to
lower
himself
to
oblivion
-
point
with
the
requisite
weight
of
tea
,
it
greatly
preyed
on
his
ingenuous
mind
that
he
had
taken
this
artist
into
partnership
at
all
.
<EOS>
He
bitterly
felt
that
he
had
overreached
himself
in
the

,
by
grasping
at
Mr.
Venus
's
mere
straws
of
hints
,
now
shown
to
be
worthless
for
his

.
<EOS>
Casting
about
for
ways
and
means
of
dissolving
the
connexion
without
loss
of
money
,
reproaching
himself
for

an

of

,
and

beyond

on

,
he
beguiled
the
distance
between
Clerkenwell
and
the

of
the
Golden
Dustman
.
  
<EOS>
For
,
Silas
Wegg
felt
it
to
be
quite
out
of
the
question
that
he
could
lay

upon

in

,
without
first

over
Mr.
Boffin
's

in

.
<EOS>
Power
(

)

ever
the

for
the

;
and
the
mere

of
the
unconscious
house
-
front
,
with
his
power
to

like

of

cards
,
was
a
treat
which

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
Your
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Bella

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

!
"

.
<EOS>
"
You
wo

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
A

,

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Mr.

<EOS>
"
Yoop
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

,

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
You

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Having

.
<EOS>
Such

of

fellow
,
that
his

had

,
two

,

.
<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
We

.
"
  
<EOS>
We

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

;
 
but

,
for

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's

for

,
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
The

.
<EOS>
All

,
piano

,

,
"
He
's
GROWN

FOND

MONEY

THAT
,

's
GROWN

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Even
next

Silas
soothed

,
when

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

(

he

"
He
's
GROWN

,

's
GROWN

.
   
<EOS>
THE
END
OF
A
LONG
JOURNEY
.
 
<EOS>
The
train
of
carts
and
horses
came
and
went
all
day
from
dawn
to
nightfall
,
making
little
or
no
daily
,
impression
on
the
heap
of
ashes
,
though
,
as
the
days
passed
on
,
the
heap
was
seen
to
be
slowly
melting
.
<EOS>
My
lords
and
gentlemen
and
honorable
boards
,
when
you
in
the
course
of
your
dust
-
shovelling
and
cinder
-
raking
have
piled
up
a
mountain
of
pretentious
failure
,
you
must
off
with
your
honorable
coats
for
the
removal
of
it
,
and
fall
to
the
work
with
the
power
of
all
the
queen
's
horses
and
all
the
queen
's
men
,
or
it
will
come
rushing
down
and
bury
us
alive
.
  
<EOS>
Yes
,
verily
,
my
lords
and
gentlemen
and
honorable
boards
,
adapting
your
Catechism
to
the
occasion
,
and
by
God
's
help
so
you
must
.
<EOS>
For
when
we
have
got
things
to
the
pass
that
with
an
enormous
treasure
at
disposal
to
relieve
the
poor
,
the
best
of
the
poor
detest
our
mercies
,
hide
their
heads
from
us
,
and
shame

by
starving
to
death
in
the
midst
of
us
,
it
is
a
pass
impossible
of
prosperity
,
impossible
of
continuance
.
<EOS>
It
may
not
be
so
written
in
the
Gospel
according
to
Podsnappery
;
you
may
not
"
find
these
words
"
for

,
in
the
Returns
of
the
Board
of
Trade
;
but
they
have
been
the
truth
since
the

universe
were
laid
,
and
they
will

until
the

of
the

are
shaken
by
the
Builder
.
<EOS>
This
boastful
handiwork
of
ours
,
which
fails
in
its
terrors
for
the
professional
pauper
,
the
sturdy
breaker
of

and

of

,
strikes

and
a

at
the
stricken

,
and
is
a

and

.
<EOS>
We
must
mend
it
,
lords
and
gentlemen
and
honorable
boards
,
or
in
its
own
evil
hour
it
will
mar
every
one
of
us
.
  
<EOS>
Old
Betty
Higden
fared
upon
her
pilgrimage
as
many
ruggedly
honest
creatures
,
women
and
men
,
fare
on
their
toiling
way
along
the
roads
of
life
.
<EOS>
Patiently
to
earn
a
spare
bare
living
,
and
quietly
to
die
,
untouched
by
workhouse
hands
---
this
was
her
highest
sublunary
hope
.
  
<EOS>
Nothing
had
been
heard
of
her
at
Mr.
Boffin
's
house
since
she
trudged
off
.
<EOS>
The
weather
had
been
hard
and
the
roads
had
been
bad
,
and
her
spirit
was
up
.
<EOS>
A
less
stanch
spirit
might
have
been
subdued
by
such
adverse
influences
;
but
the
loan
for
her
little
outfit
was
in
no
part
repaid
,
and
it
had
gone
worse
with
her
than
she
had
foreseen
,
and
she
was
put
upon
proving
her
case
and
maintaining
her
independence
.
  
<EOS>
Faithful
soul
!
<EOS>
When
she
had
spoken
to
the
Secretary
of
that
"
deadness
that
steals
over
me
at
times
,
"
her
fortitude
had
made
too
little
of
it
.
<EOS>
Oftener
and
ever
oftener
<EOS>
,
it
came
stealing
over
her
;
 
darker
and
ever
darker
,
like
the
shadow
of
advancing
Death
.
<EOS>
That
the
shadow
should
be
deep
as
it
came
on
,
like
the
shadow
of
an
actual
presence
,
was
in
accordance
with
the
laws
o
the
physical
world
,
for
all
the
Light
that
shone
on
Betty
Higden
lay
beyond
Death
.
  
<EOS>
The
poor
old
creature
had
taken
the
upward
course
of
the
river
Thames
as
her
general
track
;
it
was
the
track
in
which
her
last
home
lay
,
and
of
which
she
had
last
had
local
love
and
knowledge
.
<EOS>
She
had
hovered
for
a
little
while
in
the
near
neighbourhood
of
her
abandoned
dwelling
,
and
had
sold
,
and
knitted
and
sold
,
and
gone
on
.
<EOS>
In
the
pleasant
towns
of
Chertsey
,
Walton
,
Kingston
,
and
Staines
,
her
figure
came
to
be
quite
well
known
for
some
short
weeks
,
and
then
again
passed
on
.
  
<EOS>
She
would
take
her
stand
in
market
-
places
,
where
there
were
such
things
,
on
market
days
;
at
other
times
,
in
the
busiest
(
that
was
seldom
very
busy
)
portion
of
the
little
quiet
High
Street
;
at
still
other
times
she
would
explore
the
outlying
roads
for
great
houses
,
and
would
ask
leave
at
the
Lodge
to
pass
in
with
her
basket
,
and
would
not
often
get
it
.
<EOS>
But
ladies
in
carriages
would
frequently
make
purchases
from
her
trifling
stock
,
and
were
usually
pleased
with
her
bright
eyes
and
her
hopeful
speech
.
<EOS>
In
these
and
her
clean
dress
originated
a
fable
that
she
was
well
to
do
in
the
world
:
one
might
say
,
for
her
station
,
rich
.
<EOS>
As
making
a
comfortable
provision
for
its
subject
which
costs
nobody
anything
,
this
class
of
fable
has
long
been
popular
.
  
<EOS>
In
those
pleasant
little
towns
on
Thames
,
you
may
hear
the
fall
of
the
water
over
the
weirs
,
or
even
,
in
still
weather
,
the
rustle
of
the
rushes
;
and
from
the
bridge
you
may
see
the
the
young
river
,
dimpled
like
a
young
child
,
playfully
gliding
away
among
the
trees
,
unpolluted
by
the
defilements
that
lie
in
wait
for
it
on
its
course
,
and
as
yet
out
of
hearing
of
the
deep
summons
of
the
sea
.
<EOS>
It
were
too
much
to
pretend
that
Betty
Higden
made
out
such
thoughts
;
no
;
 
but
she
heard
the
tender
river
whispering
to
many
like
herself
,
"
Come
to
me
,
come
to
me
!
<EOS>
When
the
cruel
shame
and
terror
you
have
so
long
fled
from
,
most
beset
you
,
come
to
me
!
<EOS>
I
am
the
Relieving
Officer
appointed
by
eternal
ordinance
to
do
my
work
;
I
am
not
held
in
estimation
according
as
I
shirk
it
.
<EOS>
My
breast
is
softer
than
the
pauper
-
nurse
's
;
death
in
my
arms
is
peacefuller
than
among
the
pauper
-
wards
.
<EOS>
Come
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
abundant
place
for
gentler
fancies
too
,
in
her
untutored
mind
.
<EOS>
Those
gentlefolks
and
their
children
inside
those
fine
houses
,
could
they
think
,
as
they
looked
out
at
her
,
what
it
was
to
be
really
hungry
,
really
cold
?
<EOS>
Did
they
feel
any
of
the
wonder
about
her
,
that
she
felt
about
them
?
<EOS>
Bless
the
dear
laughing
children
!
<EOS>
If
they
could
have
seen
sick
Johnny
in
her
arms
,
would
they
have
cried
for
pity
?
<EOS>
If
they
could
have
seen
dead
Johnny
on
that
little
bed
,
would
they
have
understood
it
?
<EOS>
Bless
the
dear
children
for
his
sake
,
<EOS>
any
how
!
<EOS>
So
with
the
humbler
houses
in
the
little
street
,
the
inner
firelight
shining
on
the
panes
as
the
outer
twilight
darkened
.

<EOS>
That
was
to
be
expected
of
a
man
of
his
merits
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As

,

woman
burst
into

,
and
clasped

,
as
if

.
  
<EOS>
"
As
I
've
told

,
Master
,
I
've
the
best

friends
.
<EOS>
This
letter
will
show

true
I
spoke
,
and
they

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

Lock
opened

,
which

.
<EOS>
But

done
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,
Missis

"

,

"

?
"
  
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
"
If

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

"
as

"

"
and
I

<EOS>
Go

"
  
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
But
,

,

<EOS>
That

the
Samaritan
in

,

---
worth

,

,
my

---
the

in

,
"
passed

other

,
"
she
would
have
most

for

from

.
  
<EOS>
The
morning
found
her
afoot

,
but
fast

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

in

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

was

,

,
when

this

.
<EOS>
She
could
not

,
though

.
<EOS>
The

was

,
but

.
<EOS>
She

on
,
poor

,
like

,
and

little

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
Sewn

her

,
the
money

.
<EOS>
If
she
could
wear
through
the

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

.
<EOS>
Gaining

,

"
She
prized

,
did
old
Betty
Higden
;
 
she

;
and

,
she

that
she

.
"
 
<EOS>
Most

,
this
;

in
the

the

;
 
and

,

more

.
  
<EOS>
So

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

!
"

be

.
<EOS>
Faring

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Water

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
There

,

,

.
<EOS>
Smoke

,

<EOS>
Between

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lizzie
Hexam
very
softly
raised
the
weather
-
stained
grey
head
,
and
lifted
her
as
high
as
Heaven
.
   
<EOS>
SOMEBODY
BECOMES
THE
SUBJECT
OF
A
PREDICTION
.
   
<EOS>
"
`
`
We
give
thee
hearty
thanks
for
that
it
hath
pleased
thee
to
deliver
this
our
sister
out
of
the
miseries
of
this
sinful
world
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
 
So
read
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
in
a
not
untroubled
voice
,
for
his
heart
misgave
him
that
all
was
not
quite
right
between
us
and
our
sister
---
or
say
our
sister
in
Law
---
Poor
Law
---
and
that
we
sometimes
read
these
words
in
an
awful
manner
,
over
our
Sister
and
our
Brother
too
.
  
<EOS>
And
Sloppy
---
on
whom
the
brave
deceased
had
never
turned
her
back
until
she
ran
away
from
him
,
knowing
that
otherwise
he
would
not
be
separated
from
her
---
Sloppy
could
not
in
his
conscience
as
yet
find
the
hearty
thanks
required
of
it
.
<EOS>
Selfish
in
Sloppy
,
and
yet
excusable
,
it
may
be
humbly
hoped
,
because
our
sister
had
been
more
than
his
mother
.
  
<EOS>
The
words
were
read
above
the
ashes
of
Betty
Higden
,
in
a
corner
of
a
churchyard
near
the
river
;
in
a
churchyard
so
obscure
that
there
was
nothing
in
it
<EOS>
but
grass
-
mounds
,
not
so
much
as
one
single
tombstone
.
<EOS>
It
might
not
be
to
do
an
unreasonably
great
deal
for
the
diggers
and
hewers
,
in
a
registering
age
,
if
we
ticketed
their
graves
at
the
common
charge
;
so
that
a
new
generation
might
know
which
was
which
:
so
that
the
soldier
,
sailor
,
emigrant
,
coming
home
,
should
be
able
to
identify
the
resting
-
place
of
father
,
mother
,
playmate
,
or
betrothed
.
<EOS>
For
,
we
turn
up
our
eyes
and
say
that
we
are
all
alike
in
death
,
and
we
might
turn
them
down
and
work
the
saying
out
in
this
world
,
so
far
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
sentimental
,
perhaps
?
<EOS>
But
how
say
ye
,
my
lords
and
gentlemen
and
honorable
boards
,
shall
we
not
find
good
standing
-
room
left
for
a
little
sentiment
,
if
we
look
into
our
crowds
?
  
<EOS>
Near
unto
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
as
he
read
,
stood
his
little
wife
,
John
Rokesmith
the
Secretary
,
and
Bella
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
These
,
over
and
above
Sloppy
,
were
the
mourners
at
the
lowly
grave
.
<EOS>
Not
a
penny
had
been
added
to
the
money
sewn
in
her
dress
:
what
her
honest
spirit
had
so
long
projected
,
was
fulfilled
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
took
it
in
my
head
,
"
said
Sloppy
,
laying
it
,
inconsolable
,
against
the
church
door
,
when
all
was
done
<EOS>
:
"
I
've
took
it
in
my
wretched
head
that
I
might
have
sometimes
turned
a
little
harder
for
her
,
and
it
cuts
me
deep
to
think
so
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
,
comforting
Sloppy
,
expounded
to
him
how
the
best
of
us
were
more
or
less
remiss
in
our
turnings
at
our
respective
Mangles
---
<EOS>
some
of
us
very
much
so
---
and
how
we
were
all
a
halting
,
failing
,
feeble
,
and
inconstant
crew
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
warn't
,
sir
,
"
said
Sloppy
,
taking
this
ghostly
counsel
rather
ill
,
in
behalf
of
his
late
benefactress
.
<EOS>
Let
us
speak
for
ourselves
,
sir
.
<EOS>
She
went
through
with
whatever
duty
she
had
to
do
.
<EOS>
She
went
through
with
me
<EOS>
,
she
went
through
with
the
Minders
,
she
went
through
with
herself
,
she
went
through
with
everythink
.
<EOS>
O
Mrs.
Higden
,
Mrs.
Higden
,
you
was
a
woman
and
a
mother
and
a
mangler
in
a
million
million
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
those
heartfelt
words
,
Sloppy
removed
his
dejected
head
from
the
church
door
,
and
took
it
back
to
the
grave
in
the
corner
,
and
laid
it
down
there
,
and
wept
alone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
a
very
poor
grave
,
"
said
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
,
brushing
his
hand
across
his
eyes
,
"
when
it
has
that
homely
figure
on
it
.
<EOS>
Richer
,
I
think
,
than
it
could
be
made
by
most
of
the
sculpture
in
Westminster
Abbey
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
left
him
undisturbed
,
and
passed
out
at
the
wicket
-
gate
.
<EOS>
The
water
-
wheel
of
the
paper
-
mill
was
audible
there
,
and
seemed
to
have
a
softening
influence
on
the
bright
wintry
scene
.
<EOS>
They
had
arrived
but
a
little
while
before
,
and
Lizzie
Hexam
now
told
them
the
little
she
could
add
to
the
letter
in
which
she
had
enclosed
Mr.
Rokesmith
's
letter
and
had
asked
for
their
instructions
.
<EOS>
This
was
merely
how
she
had
heard
the
groan
,
and
what
had
afterwards
passed
,
and
how
she
had
obtained
leave
for
the
remains
to
be
placed
in
that
sweet
,
fresh
,
empty
store
-
room
of
the
mill
from
which
they
had
just
accompanied
them
to
the
churchyard
,
and
how
the
last
requests
had
been
religiously
observed
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
could
not
have
done
it
all
,
or
nearly
all
,
of
myself
,
"
said
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
not
have
wanted
the
will
;
but
I
should
not
have
had
the
power
,
without
our
managing
partner
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Surely
not
the
Jew
who
received
us
?
"
said
Mrs.
Milvey
.
  
<EOS>
(
"
My
dear
,
"
observed
her
husband
in
parenthesis
,
"
why
not
?
"
<EOS>
)
  
<EOS>
"
The
gentleman

Jew
,
"
said

,
"
and

,

,

,

their
notice

.
<EOS>
But
I
think
there
can
not

kinder

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
suppose
they
try
to
convert
you
!
"
<EOS>
suggested
Mrs.
Milvey
,
bristling
in
her
good
little
way
,
as
a
clergyman
's
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
do
what
,
ma'am
?
"
asked
Lizzie
,
with
a
modest

.
  
<EOS>
"
To
make
you
change
your
religion
,
"
said
Mrs.
Milvey
.
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
shook
her
head
,
still
smiling
.
<EOS>
"
They
have
never
asked
me
what
my
religion
is
.
<EOS>
They
asked
me
what
my
story
was
,
and
I
told
them
.
<EOS>
They
asked
me
to
be
industrious
and
faithful
,
and
I
promised
to
be
so
.
<EOS>
They
most
willingly
and
cheerfully
do
their
duty
to
all
of
us
who
are
employed
here
,
<EOS>
and
we
try
to
do
ours
to
them
.
<EOS>
Indeed
they
do
much
more
than
their
duty
to
us
,
for
they
are
wonderfully
mindful
of
us
in
many

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
easy
to
see
you
're
a

,

,
"
said
little
Mrs.
Milvey
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
would

very

I

,
"
returned
Lizzie
,
"
for
I
have
been

raised

here
.
<EOS>
But
that
makes
no
difference
in
their
following

and

to

.
<EOS>
They
never

theirs
to

,

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
They

.

<EOS>
"
My

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

I

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
There

going
about
,
my
love
,
and
she
will

.
"
  
<EOS>
While
this
discourse
was
interchanging
,
both
Bella
and
the
Secretary
observed
Lizzie
Hexam
with
great
attention
.
<EOS>
Brought
face
to
face
for
the
first

with
the
daughter
of
his
supposed
murderer
,
it
was
natural
that
John
Harmon
should
have
his
own
secret
reasons
for
a
careful

of
her

and

.
<EOS>
Bella
knew
that
Lizzie
's
father
had
been
falsely
accused
of
the
crime
which
had
had
so
great

on
her
own

and

;
and
her

,
though

,

,

.
<EOS>
Both

expected
to
see
something
very

from
the
real
Lizzie
Hexam
,
and
thus
it
fell
out
that
she
became

unconscious

together
.
  
<EOS>
For
,

had

clean

,

.
<EOS>
This

away
for

,

;

whether

children

;

Frank
being
engaged
 
---

,

.
  
<EOS>
Bella

"
Had

"

"
By

<EOS>

As

Something

At

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"
No

"

,

.
"
<EOS>
Forgive

!
"
<EOS>
For

,

(

)

.
  
<EOS>
When

:
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Bella
nodded
<EOS>
Yes
.
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
I
have
it
in
charge
from
Mr.
Boffin
to
discover
,
and
I
am
very
desirous
for
myself
to
discover
,
whether
that
retracted
accusation
still
leaves
any
stain
upon
her
.
<EOS>
I
mean
whether
it
places
her
at
any
disadvantage
towards
any
one
,
even
towards
herself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
said
Bella
,
nodding
thoughtfully
;
"
I
understand
.
<EOS>
That
seems
wise
,
and
considerate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
not
have
noticed
,
Miss
Wilfer
,
that
she
has
the
same
kind
of
interest
in
you
,
that
you
have
in
her
.
<EOS>
Just
as
you
are
attracted
by
her
beaut
---
by
her
appearance
and
manner
,
she
is
attracted
by
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
certainly
have
not
noticed
it
,
"
returned
Bella
,
again
italicizing
with
the
dimple
,
"
and
I
should
have
given
her
credit
for
---
"
  
The
Secretary
with
a
smile
held
up
his
hand
<EOS>
,
so
plainly
interposing
"
not
for
better
taste
,
"
that
Bella
's
colour
deepened
over
the
little
piece
of
coquetry
<EOS>
she
was
checked
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
,
"
resumed
the
Secretary
,
"
if
you
would
speak
with
her
alone
before
we
go
away
from
here
,
I
feel
quite
sure
that
a
natural
and
easy
confidence
would
arise
between
you
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
would
not
be
asked
to
betray
it
;
and
of
course
you
would
not
,
if
you
were
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
do
not
object
to
put
this

to
her
---
to
ascertain
for
us
her
own

in
this
one

---
you
can
do
so
at
a
far
greater
advantage
than
I
or
any
else
could
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
is
anxious
on
the
subject
.
<EOS>
And
I
am
,
"
added
the
Secretary
after
a
moment
,
"
for
a
special
reason
,
very
anxious
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
happy
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
"
returned
Bella
,
"
to
be
of
the
least
use
;
for
I
feel
,
after
the
serious
scene
of
to
-
day
,
that
I
am
useless
enough
in
this
world
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
say
that
,
"
urged
the
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
but
I
mean
that
,
"
said
Bella
,
raising
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
one
is
useless
in
this
world
,
"
retorted
the
Secretary
,
"
who
lightens
the
burden
of
it
for
any
one
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
assure
you
I
do

,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
"
said
Bella
,
half

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
for
your
father
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
loving
,
self
-
forgetting
,
easily
-
satisfied
Pa
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
yes
!
<EOS>
He
thinks
so
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
enough
if
he
only
thinks
so
,
"
said

Secretary
.
<EOS>
"
Excuse
the
interruption
:
I
do
n't
like
to
hear

depreciate
yourself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
once
depreciated
me
,
sir
,
"
thought
Bella
,
pouting
,
"
and
I
hope
you
may
be
satisfied
with
the

you
brought
upon
your
head
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
However
,
she
said
nothing
to
that
purpose
;
she
even
said
something
to
a
different
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
it
seems
so
long
since
we
spoke
together

,
that
I
am
embarrassed
in
approaching
another

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
You
know
I
am
very

to
him
;
do

?
<EOS>
You

I

,

am

;

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Unquestionably
.
<EOS>
And

that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

,
"
so

of

.
<EOS>
But
---
.
Does
he
treat

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
how
he
treats

,
"
the
Secretary

,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
and
I
see

with
pain
,
"
said
Bella
,
very

.
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
gave
her
such
a

look
,
that
if
he
had
thanked
her
a

,
he
could
not

said
as
much
as
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
it
with
pain
,
"
repeated

,
"
and
it
often
makes
me
miserable
.
<EOS>
Miserable
,
because
I
can
not
bear
to
be
supposed
to
approve
of
it
,
or
have
any

in

.
<EOS>
Miserable
,
because
I
can
not
bear
to

that
Fortune
is

Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Miss
Wilfer
,
"
said
the
Secretary
,

,
"
if
you
could
know

what

I
make
the
discovery
that
Fortune
is
not

you
,
you
would
know
that
it
more

me
for
any

at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
do
n't
speak

,
"
said
Bella
,
giving

.
<EOS>
"
You
do

know

as

---
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
you
know

?
"
suggested
the
Secretary
,
finding
that

.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
yourself
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
quite
enough
of
myself
,
"
said
Bella
,
with
a
charming
air
of
being
inclined
to
give
herself
up
as
a
bad
job
,
"
and
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
But
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
Mr.
Boffin
's

to
me
,
or

for

,
is
not
what

to
be
,
"
observed

Secretary
,
"
must

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
disposed

,
Mr.
Rokesmith
?
"

,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ought
I

do

,

:

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

,
and
---

wo
n't

what

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

"
  
"
---
And

sometimes
,

,
"

,

,
"
a
little
lower

?
"
  
<EOS>
Assenting

,

,

"
I

,
Miss
Wilfer
,
for
bearing

of
my
position
in
the
house
<EOS>
we

.
<EOS>
Believe
that
they
are
not
all

,
although
I
have
,
through

series
of
strange

,
faded

my

in

.
<EOS>
If
what
you
see
with
such
a
gracious

is

my
pride
,
there
are
other

(
and

do
not

)
urging
me
to
quiet

.
<EOS>
The
latter
are
by
far

stronger
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
have

,

Rokesmith
,
"

,

,
as

,
"
that
you
repress

,
and
force

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
I
repress

and
force

to
act
a
part
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
in

that
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
a

one
<EOS>
,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

,
"
he

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Sometimes

,

,
"
said

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

again
;
it

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

!
<EOS>
May

,
Mr.
Rokesmith
?
"
  
"
Anything

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of

she

,

Mr.
Boffin

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,
and
am

her
pain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
give
her
pain
?
"
said
Bella
,
repeating

quickly
,
with
her

raised
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
generally
the
unfortunate
cause
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
she
says
to
you
,
as
she
often

to
me
,
that
he
is
the
best
of

,
in

all
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
often
overhear
her
,
in
her

beautiful
devotion
to
him
,
saying

you
,
"
returned

Secretary
,
with
the
same
steady

,
"
but
I
can
not
assert
that
she
ever
says
so
to
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
met
the
steady
look
for
a
moment
with
a
wistful
,
musing
little
look
of
her
own
,
and
then
,
nodding
her
pretty
head
several
times
,
like
a
dimpled
philosopher
(
of
the
very
best
school
)
who
was
moralizing
on
Life
,
heaved
a
little
sigh
,
and
gave
up
things
in
general
for
a
bad
job
,
as
she
had
previously
been
inclined
to
give
up
herself
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
for
all
that
,
they
had
a
very
pleasant
walk
.
<EOS>
The
trees
were
bare
of
leaves
,
and
the
river
was
bare
of
water
-
lilies
;
but
the
sky
was
not
bare
of
its
beautiful
blue
,
and
the
water
reflected
it
,
and
a
delicious
wind
ran
with
the
stream
,
touching
the
surface
crisply
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
old
mirror
was
never
yet
made
by
human
hands
,
which
,
if
all
the
images
it
has
in
its
time
reflected
could
pass
across
its
surface
again
,
would
fail
to
reveal
some
scene
of
horror
or
distress
.
<EOS>
But
the
great
serene
mirror
of
the
river
seemed
as
if
it
might
have
reproduced
all
it
had
ever
reflected
between
those
placid
banks
,
and
brought
nothing
to
the
light
save
what
was
peaceful
,
pastoral
,
and
blooming
.
  
<EOS>
So
,
they
walked
,
speaking
of
the
newly
filled
-
up
grave
,
and
of
Johnny
,
and
of
many
things
.
<EOS>
So
,
on
their
return
,
they
met
brisk
Mrs.
Milvey
coming
to
seek
them
,
with
the
agreeable
intelligence
that
there
was
no
fear
for
the
village
children
,
there
being
a
Christian
school
in
the
village
,
and
no
worse
Judaical
interference
with
it
than
to
plant
its
garden
.
<EOS>
So
,
they
got
back
to
the
village
as
Lizzie
Hexam
was
coming
from
the
paper
-
mill
,
and
Bella
detached
herself
to
speak
with
her
in
her
own
home
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
it
is
a
poor
room
for
you
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
with
a
smile
of
welcome
,
as
she
offered
the
post
of
honor
by
the
fireside
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
so
poor
as
you
think
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
Bella
,
"
if
you
knew
all
.
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
though
attained
by
some
wonderful
winding
narrow
stairs
,
which
seemed
to
have
been
erected
in
a
pure
white
chimney
,
and
though
very
low
in
the
ceiling
,
and
very
rugged
in
the
floor
,
and
rather
blinking
as
to
the
proportions
of
its
lattice
window
,
it
was
a
pleasanter
room
than
that
despised
chamber
once
at
home
,
in
which
Bella
had
first
bemoaned
the
miseries
of
taking
lodgers
.
  
<EOS>
The
day
was
closing
as
the
two
girls
looked
at
one
another
by
the
fireside
.
<EOS>
The
dusky
room
was
lighted
by
the
fire
.
<EOS>
The
grate
might
have
been
the
old
brazier
,
and
the
glow
might
have
been
the
old
hollow
down
by
the
flare
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
quite
new
to
me
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
"
to
be
visited
by
a
lady
so
nearly
of
my
own
age
,
and
so
pretty
,
as
you
.
<EOS>
It
's
a
pleasure
to
me
to
look
at
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
nothing
left
to
begin
with
,
"
returned
Bella
,
blushing
,
"
because
I
was
going
to
say
that
it
was
a
pleasure
to
me
to
look
at
you
,
Lizzie
.
<EOS>
But
we
can
begin
without
a
beginning
,
ca
n't
we
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
took
the
pretty
little
hand
that
was
held
out
in
as
pretty
a
little
frankness
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
dear
,
"
said
Bella
,
drawing
her
chair
a
little
nearer
,
and
taking
Lizzie
's
arm
as
if
they
were
going
out
for
a
walk
,
"
I
am
commissioned
with
something
to
say
,
and
I
dare
say
I
shall
say
it
wrong
,
but
I
wo
n't
if
I
can
help
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
in
reference
to
your
letter
to
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
and
this
is
what
it
is
.
<EOS>
Let
me
see
.
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
<EOS>
This
is
what
it
is
.
"
  
<EOS>

I

.

"
that

"

"

;
"

"

breast
already
.
<EOS>
I
have
no
more
dreamed
of
the
possibility
of
my
being
his
wife
,
than
he
ever
has
---
and
words
could
not
be
stronger
than
that
.
<EOS>
And
yet
I
love
him
.
<EOS>
I
love
him
so
much
,
and
so
dearly
,
that
when
I
sometimes
think
my
life
may
be
but
a
weary
one
,
I
am
proud
of
it
and
glad
of
it
.
<EOS>
I
am
proud
and
glad
to
suffer
something
for
him
,
even
though
it
is
of
no
service
to
him
,
and
he
will
never
know
of
it
or
care
for
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
sat
enchained
by
the
deep
,
unselfish
passion
of
this
girl
or
woman
of
her
own
age
,
courageously
revealing
itself
in
the
confidence
of
her
sympathetic
perception
of
its
truth
.
<EOS>
And
yet
she
had
never
experienced
anything
like
it
,
or
thought
of
the
existence
of
anything
like
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
late
upon
a
wretched
night
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
"
when
his
eyes
first
looked
at
me
in
my
old
river
-
side
home
,
very
different
from
this
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
may
never
look
at
me
again
.
<EOS>
I
would
rather
that
they
never
did
;
I
hope
that
they
never
may
.
<EOS>
But
I
would
not
have
the
light
of
them
taken
out
of
my
life
,
for
anything
my
life
can
give
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
told
you
everything
now
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
If
it
comes
a
little
strange
to
me
to
have
parted
with
it
,
I
am
not
sorry
.
<EOS>
I
had
no
thought
of
ever
parting
with
a
single
word
of
it
,
a
moment
before
you
came
in
;
but
you
came
in
,
and
my
mind
changed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
kissed
her
on
the
cheek
,
and
thanked
her
warmly
for
her
confidence
.
<EOS>
"
I
only
wish
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
I
was
more
deserving
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
More
deserving
of
it
?
"
repeated
Lizzie
,
with
an
incredulous
smile
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mean
in
respect
of
keeping
it
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
because
any
one
should
tear
me
to
bits
before
getting
at
a
syllable
of
it
---
though
there
's
no
merit
in
that
,
for
I
am
naturally
as
obstinate
as
a
Pig
.
<EOS>
What
I
mean
is
,
Lizzie
,
that
I
am
a
mere
impertinent
piece
of
conceit
,
and
you
shame
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
put
up
the
pretty
brown
hair
that
came
tumbling
down
,
owing
to
the
energy
with
which
Bella
shook
her
head
;
and
she
remonstrated
while
thus
engaged
,
"
My
dear
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
's
all
very
well
to
call
me
your
dear
,
"
said
Bella
,
with
a
pettish
whimper
,
"
and
I
am
glad
to
be
called
so
,
though
I
have
slight
enough
claim
to
be
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
such
a
nasty
little
thing
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
!
"
urged
Lizzie
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Such
a
shallow
,
cold
,
worldly
,
Limited
little
brute
!
"
said
Bella
,
bringing
out
her
last
adjective
with
culminating
force
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
,
"
inquired
Lizzie
with
her
quiet
smile
,
the
hair
being
now
secured
,
"
that
I
do
n't
know
better
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
know
better
though
?
"
said
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
really
believe
you
know
better
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
I
should
be
so
glad
if
you
did
know
better
,
but
I
am
so
very
much
afraid
that
I
must
know
best
!
"
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
asked
her
,
laughing
outright
,
whether
she
ever
saw
her
own
face
or
heard
her
own
voice
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
so
,
"
returned
Bella
;
"
I
look
in
the
glass
often
enough
,
and
I
chatter
like
a
Magpie
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
your
face
,
and
heard
your
voice
,
at
any
rate
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
"
and
they
have
tempted
me
to
say
to
you
---
with
a
certainty
of
not
going
wrong
---
what
I
thought
I
should
never
say
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
Does
that
look
ill
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
hope
it
does
n't
,
"
pouted
Bella
,
stopping
herself
in
something
between
a
humoured
laugh
and
a
humoured
sob
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
used
once
to
see
pictures
in
the
fire
,
"
said
Lizzie
playfully
,
"
to
please
my
brother
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
tell
you
what
I
see
down
there
where
the
fire
is
glowing
?
"
  
<EOS>
They
had
risen
,
and
were
standing
on
the
hearth
,
the
time
being
come
for
separating
;
each
had
drawn
an
arm
around
the
other
to
take
leave
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
tell
you
,
"
asked
Lizzie
,
"
what
I
see
down
there
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Limited
little
b
?
"
suggested
Bella
with
her
eyebrows
raised
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
heart
well
worth
winning
,
and
well
won
.
<EOS>
A
heart
that
,
once
won
,
goes
through
fire
and
water
for
the
winner
,
and
never
changes
,
and
is
never
daunted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Girl
's
heart
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Bella
,
with
accompanying
eyebrows
.
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
nodded
.
"
<EOS>
And
the
figure
to
which
it
belongs
---
"
  
"
Is
yours
,
"
suggested
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Most
clearly
and
distinctly
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
the
interview
terminated
with
pleasant
words
on
both
sides
,
and
with
many
reminders
on
the
part
of
Bella
that
they
were
friends
,
and
pledges
that
she
would
soon
come
down
into
that
part
of
the
country
again
.
<EOS>
Therewith
Lizzie
returned
to
her
occupation
,
and
Bella
ran
over
to
the
little
inn
to
rejoin
her
company
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
look
rather
serious
,
Miss
Wilfer
,
"
was
the
Secretary
's
first
remark
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
feel
rather
serious
,
"
returned
Miss
Wilfer
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
nothing
else
to
tell
him
but
that
Lizzie
Hexam
's
secret
had
no
reference
whatever
to
the
cruel
charge
,
or
its
withdrawal
.
<EOS>
Oh
yes
though
!
<EOS>
said
Bella
<EOS>
;
she
might
as
well
mention
one
other
thing
;
 
Lizzie
was
very
desirous
to
thank
her
unknown
friend
who
had
sent
her
the
written
retractation
.
<EOS>
Was
she
,
indeed
?
<EOS>
observed
the
Secretary
.
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
Bella
asked
him
,
had
he
any
notion
who
that
unknown
friend
might
be
?
<EOS>
He
had
no
notion
whatever
.
  
<EOS>
They
were
on
the
borders
of
Oxfordshire
,
so
far
had
poor
old
Betty
Higden
strayed
.
<EOS>
They
were
to
return
by
the
train
presently
,
and
,
the
station
being
near
at
hand
,
the
Reverend
Frank
and
Mrs.
Frank
,
and
Sloppy
and
Bella
and
the
Secretary
,
set
out
to
walk
to
it
.
<EOS>
Few
rustic
paths
are
wide
enough
for
five
,
and
Bella
and
the
Secretary
dropped
behind
.
  
<EOS>
"
Can
you
believe
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
that
I
feel
as
if
whole
years
had
passed
since
I
went
into
Lizzie
Hexam
's
cottage
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
have
crowded
a
good
deal
into
the
day
,
"
he
returned
,
"
and
you
were
much
affected
in
the
churchyard
.
<EOS>
You
are
over
-
tired
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
am
not
at
all
tired
.
<EOS>
I
have
not
quite
expressed
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
that
I
feel
as
if
a
great
space
of
time
had
gone
by
,
but
that
I
feel
as
if
much
had
happened
---
to
myself
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
good
,
I
hope
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
cold
;
I
felt
you
tremble
.
<EOS>
Pray
let
me
put
this
wrapper
of
mine
about
you
.
<EOS>
May
I
fold
it
over
this
shoulder
without
injuring
your
dress
?
<EOS>
Now
,
it
will
be
too
heavy
and
too
long
.
<EOS>
Let
me
carry
this
end
over
my
arm
,
as
you
have
no
arm
to
give
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
Yes
she
had
though
.
<EOS>
How
she
got
it
out
,
in
her
muffled
state
,
Heaven
knows
;
but
she
got
it
out
somehow
---
there
it
was
---
and
slipped
it
through
the
Secretary
's
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
had
a
long

with
Lizzie
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
and
she
gave
me
her
full
confidence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
could
not

it
,
"
said

Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
how
you
come
,
"
said
Bella
,
stopping
short
as
she
glanced
at
him
,
"
to
say

me
just
what

said

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
infer
that
it
must
be
because
I
feel
just
as
she

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
how
was
that
,
do
you
mean

,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Bella
,
moving
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
if
you
were
inclined
to
win
her
confidence
---
anybody
's
confidence
 
<EOS>
---
you
were
sure
to
do

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
railway
,
at
this
point
,
knowingly
shutting
a
green
eye
and
opening
a
red
one
,
they
had
to
run
for
it
.
<EOS>
As
Bella
could
not
run
easily
so
wrapped
up
,
the
Secretary
had
to
help
her
.
<EOS>
When
she
took
her

in

,

in
her

was
so

to

,
that
on

,
"
What

and
what

glorious

!
"
<EOS>
the
Secretary
said
"
Yes
,
"
but
seemed
to
prefer
to
see
the
night
and
the
stars
in
the
light
of
her
lovely
little
countenance
,
to
looking
out
of
window
.
  
<EOS>
O
boofer
lady
,
fascinating
boofer
lady
!
<EOS>
If
I
were
but
legally
executor
of
Johnny
's
will
!
<EOS>
If
I
had
but
the
right
to
pay
your
legacy
and
to
take
your
receipt
!
<EOS>
---
Something
to
this
purpose
surely
mingled
with
the
blast
of
the
train
as
it
cleared
the
stations
,
all
knowingly

up
their
green
eyes
and
opening
their
red
ones
when
they
prepared
to
let
the
boofer
lady
pass
.
   
<EOS>
SCOUTS
OUT
.
 
<EOS>
"
And
so
,
Miss
Wren
,
"
said
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
"
I
can
not
persuade
you
to
dress
me
a
doll
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
replied
Miss
Wren
snappishly
;
"
if
you
want
one
,
go
and
buy
one
at
the
shop
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
my
charming
young
goddaughter
,
"
said
Mr.
Wrayburn
plaintively
,
"
down
in
Hertfordshire
---
<EOS>
"
  
(
"
Humbugshire
you
mean
,
I
think
,
"
interposed
Miss
Wren
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
---
is
to
be
put
upon
the
cold
footing
of
the
general
public
,
and
is
to
derive
no

from
my
private

with
the
Court
Dressmaker
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
it
's
any
advantage
to
your
charming
godchild
---
and
oh
,
a
precious
godfather
she
has
got
!
<EOS>
"
---
replied
Miss
Wren
,
pricking
at
him
in
the
air
with
her
needle
,
"
to
be
informed
that
the
Court
Dressmaker
knows
your
tricks
and
your
manners
,
you
may
tell
her
so
by
post
,
with
my
compliments
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Wren
was
busy
at
her
work
by
candle
-
light
,
and
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
half
amused
and
half
vexed
,
and
all
idle
and

,
stood
by
her
bench
looking
on
.
<EOS>
Miss
Wren
's
troublesome
child
was
in
the
corner
in
deep
disgrace
,
and
exhibiting
great
wretchedness
in
the
shivering
stage
of
prostration
from
drink
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ugh
,
you
disgraceful
boy
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Miss
Wren
,
attracted
by
the
sound
of
his
chattering
teeth
,
"
I
wish
they
'd
all
drop
down
your
throat
and
play
at
dice
in
your
stomach
!
<EOS>
Boh
,
wicked
child
!
<EOS>
Bee
-
baa
,
black
sheep
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On
her
accompanying
each
of
these
reproaches
with
a
threatening
stamp
of
the
foot
,
the
wretched
creature
protested
with
a
whine
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pay
five
shillings
for
you
indeed
!
"
<EOS>
Miss
Wren
proceeded
;
"
how
many
hours
do
you
suppose
it
costs
me
to
earn
five
shillings
,
you
infamous
boy
?
---
<EOS>
Do
n't
cry
like
that
,
or
I
'll
throw
a
doll
at
you
.
<EOS>
Pay
five
shillings
fine
for
you
indeed
.
<EOS>
Fine
in
more
ways
than
one
,
I
think
!
<EOS>
I
'd
give
the
dustman
five
shillings
,
to
carry
you
off
in
the
dust
cart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
pleaded
the
absurd
creature
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Please
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
enough
to
break
his
mother
's
heart
,
is
this
boy
,
"
said
Miss
Wren
,
half

to
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
I
wish
I
had
never
brought
him
up
.
<EOS>
He
'd
be
sharper
than
a
serpent
's
tooth
,
if
he
was

as
dull
as
ditch
water
.
<EOS>
Look
at
him
.
<EOS>
There
's
a
pretty
object
for
a
parent
's
eyes
!
"
  
<EOS>
Assuredly
,
in
his
worse
than
swinish
state
(
for
swine
at
least
fatten
on
their
guzzling
,
and
make
themselves
good
to
eat
)
<EOS>
,
he
was

pretty

for
any

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

,
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Deration
,
<EOS>
oh

!
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?

"
Wo

<EOS>
Wo

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

"

the

'

,
through

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

the

,

.
<EOS>
No

than
Jenny
Wren
's
bad
boy
trying

.
  
<EOS>
A
more

this

making

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lightwood

!

See

!

.
<EOS>

!

.
<EOS>

,

But
it
would
be
premature
in
this
stage
,
and
it
's
not
the
character
of
my
mind
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
was
shaking
his
head
over
the
air
with
which
his
friend
held
forth
thus
---
an
air
so
whimsically
open
and
argumentative
as
almost
to
deprive
what
he
said
of
the
appearance
of
evasion
---
when
a
shuffling
was
heard
at
the
outer
door
,
and
then
an
undecided
knock
,
as
though
some
hand
were
groping
for
the
knocker
.
<EOS>
"
The
frolicsome
youth
of
the
neighbourhood
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
whom
I
should
be
delighted
to
pitch
from
this
elevation
into
the
church
-
yard
below
,
without
any
intermediate
ceremonies
,
have
probably
turned
the
lamp
out
.
<EOS>
I
am
on
duty
to
-
night
,
and
will
see
to
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
His
friend
had
barely
had
time
to
recall
the
unprecedented
gleam
of
determination
with
which
he
had
spoken
of
finding
this
girl
,
and
which
had
faded
out
of
him
with
the
breath
of
the
spoken
words
,
when
Eugene
came
back
,
ushering
in
a
most
disgraceful
shadow
of
a
man
,
shaking
from
head
to
foot
,
and
clothed
in
shabby

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
This
interesting
gentleman
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
is
the
son
---
the
occasionally
rather
trying
son
,
for
he
has
his
failings
---
of
a
lady
of
my
acquaintance
.
<EOS>
My
dear
Mortimer
---
Mr.
Dolls
.
<EOS>
"
Eugene
had
no
idea
what
his
name
was
,
knowing
the
little
dressmaker
's
to
be
assumed
,
but
presented
him
with
easy
confidence
under
the
first
appellation
that
his
associations
suggested
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
gather
,
my
dear
Mortimer
,
"
pursued
Eugene
,
as
Lightwood
stared
at
the
obscene

,
"
from
the
manner
of
Mr.
Dolls
---
which
is
occasionally
complicated
---
that
he
desires
to
make
some
communication
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
have
mentioned
to
Mr.
Dolls
that
you
and
I
are
on
terms
of
confidence
,
and
have
requested
Mr.
Dolls
to
develope
his
views
here
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
wretched
object
being
much
embarrassed
by
holding
what
remained
of
his
hat
<EOS>
,
Eugene
airily
tossed
it
to
the
door
,
and
put
him
down
in
a
chair
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
be
necessary
<EOS>
,
I
think
,
"
he

,
"
to
wind
up
Mr.
Dolls
,
before
anything
to

can
be
got

of
him
.
<EOS>
Brandy
,
Mr.
Dolls
,
or
---
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Threepenn'orth
Rum
,
"
said
Mr.
Dolls
.
  
<EOS>
A
judiciously
small
quantity
of
the
spirit
was
given
him
in
a
wineglass
,
and
he
began
to
convey
it
to
his
mouth
,
with
all
kinds
of

and
gyrations
on
the
road
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
nerves
of
Mr.
Dolls
,
"
remarked
Eugene
to
Lightwood
,
"
are
considerably
unstrung
.
<EOS>
And
I
deem
it
on
the
whole

to
fumigate
Mr.
Dolls
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
took
the

from

,

a

live

on

,
and
from
a
box
on

piece

,
which
he
set
upon

;
then
,

in

Mr.
Dolls
,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lord

,
Eugene
!
"
<EOS>

,
laughing

,
"
what

mad

!
<EOS>
Why
does
this
creature
come
to
see
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
hear
,
"
said
Wrayburn
,
very
observant
of
his
face
withal
.
<EOS>
"
Now
then
.
Speak
out
.
<EOS>
Do
n't

.
<EOS>
State

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mist
Wrayburn
!
"

,
thickly

.
"
<EOS>
---
'
Tis
Mist
Wrayburn
,
ai
n't
?
"
<EOS>
With

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
it
is
.
<EOS>
Look

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

collapsed

,

"
Threepenn'orth
Rum
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will

,
my

Mortimer
,
to
wind

Dolls
again
?
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
occupied
with
the
fumigation
.
"
  
<EOS>
A
similar
quantity
was
poured
into
his
glass
,
and
he
got

to
his

.
<EOS>
Having

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mist
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
Tried

,

.
<EOS>
You
want
that
drection
.
<EOS>
You

t'know

.
<EOS>
Do

Mist

?
"
  
<EOS>
With

,
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
er
man
,
"

,

,

,
"
er
do

.
<EOS>
I
am
er

er

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

man

do
?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Er

that
drection
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you

it
?
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

,

"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

:
"
<EOS>
Threepenn'orth
Rum
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wind

,
my

Mortimer
,
"
said

;
"
wind

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
Eugene
,
"

in

,

,
"
can

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
said
,
"
was

"
that

find

,
fair

.
<EOS>
These

,

I

---

Mr.
Dolls

.
<EOS>
Can

?
<EOS>
Do

?
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Stop

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,
"
er

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

,

"
  
<EOS>
"
I

ill
-

vidual
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Blown
up
morning
t'night
.
<EOS>
Called
names
.
<EOS>
She
makes
Mint
money
,

,
and
never
stands
Threepenn'orth
Rum
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Get

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
What
comes
next
?
"
  
<EOS>
Making

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
She

,

.
<EOS>
I
am
   
NOT
mere
child
,

.
<EOS>
Man
.
<EOS>
Man
talent
.
<EOS>
Lerrers
pass
betwixt
'em
.
<EOS>
Postman
lerrers
.
<EOS>
Easy
for
man
talent
<EOS>
er
get
drection
,

drection
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Get

,
"

;

,
"
---
You
Brute
!
<EOS>
Get

,

here

,

for
sixty

of

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

the

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Dolls
now
struck
out

that

had
been
insulted
by
Lightwood
,
and

"
have

with

"
on

,

come

,
upon
the
liberal

of
a

to

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Dolls
then
fell
a
crying
,
and
then
exhibited
a
tendency
to
fall

.
<EOS>
This

as
by
far

most
alarming
,
by

its
threatening

on

,
necessitated

.
<EOS>
Eugene
picked
up
his
worn
-
out
hat
with
the

,
clapped
it
on
his

,
and
,
taking
him
by

collar
---
all
this
at
arm
's

---
conducted
him
down
stairs
and
out
of
the
precincts
into
Fleet
Street
.
<EOS>
There
,
he
turned
his
face
westward
,
and
left
him
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
got
back
,
Lightwood
was
standing
over

fire
,
brooding
in
a
sufficiently
low

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
wash
my

of

Dolls
---
physically
---
"
said

,
"
and
be

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

much

,
"
retorted

,
"
your
washing
your
hands
of
Mr.
Dolls
,
morally
,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So

I
,
"
said
Eugene
;
"
but
you
see
,
dear
boy
,
I
ca
n't
do
without
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
In

he
resumed

,
as

usual
,
and
rallied
his
friend
on
having
so

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
be

,
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
can

,
Eugene
,
but

.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"

,
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
It

,
this

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
have

!
"
<EOS>

,
airily
.
<EOS>
"
We
have

one
in
that

,
scout
.
<EOS>
Do

like
Patience
on

frowning

Dolls
,
but

,
and
I
'll

that

really

.
<EOS>
Take
a

.
<EOS>
Look

of
mine
.
<EOS>
I
light
it
---
draw
one
puff
---
breathe
the
smoke
out
<EOS>
---
there
it
goes
---
it
's
Dolls
!
<EOS>
---
it
's
gone
---
and
being
gone
<EOS>
you
are
a
man
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
subject
,
"
said
Mortimer
,
after

,
and
comforting

with

,
"
was
scouts
,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Exactly
.
<EOS>
Is
n't
it
droll
that
I
never
go
out
after
dark
,
but
I
find
myself
attended
,
always
by
one
scout
,
and
often
by
two
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
took
his
cigar
from
his
lips
in
surprise
,
and
looked
at
his
friend
,
as
if
with
a
latent
suspicion
that
there
must
be
a
jest

in

.
  
<EOS>
"
On
my

,
no
,
"
said
Wrayburn
,
answering

and

;
"
I
do

wonder
at
your
supposing
so
,
but
on
my
honour
,
no
.
<EOS>
I
say
what
I
mean
.
<EOS>
I
never
go
out
after
dark
,
but
I
find
myself
in
the
ludicrous
situation
of
being
followed
and
observed
at

distance
,
always
by
one
scout
,
and
often

two
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
sure
,
Eugene
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sure
?
<EOS>
My
dear
boy
,
they
are
always
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
there
's
no
process
out
against
you
.
<EOS>
The
Jews
only
threaten
.
<EOS>
They
have
done
nothing
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
they
know
where
to
find
you
,
and
I
represent

.
<EOS>
Why
take
the
trouble
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Observe
the
legal
mind
!
"
<EOS>
remarked
Eugene
,
turning
round
to
the
furniture
again
,
with
an
air
of
indolent
rapture
.
<EOS>
"
Observe
the
dyer
's
hand
,
assimilating
itself
to
what
it
works
in
,
---
or
would
work
in
,
if
anybody
would
give
it
anything
to
do
.
<EOS>
Respected
solicitor
,
it
's
not
that
.
<EOS>
The
schoolmaster
's
abroad
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
schoolmaster
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
<EOS>
Sometimes
the
schoolmaster
and
the
pupil
are
both
abroad
.
<EOS>
Why
,
how
soon
you
rust
in
my
absence
!
<EOS>
You
do
n't
understand
yet
?
<EOS>
Those
fellows
who
were
here
one
night
.
<EOS>
They
are
the
scouts
I
speak
of
,
as
doing
me
the
honor
to
attend
me
after
dark
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
long
has
this
been
going
on
?
"
<EOS>
asked
Lightwood
,
opposing
a
serious
face
to
the
laugh
of
his
friend
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
apprehend
it
has
been
going
on
,
ever
since
a
certain
person
went
off
.
<EOS>
Probably
,
it
had
been
going
on
some
little
time
before
I
noticed
it
:
which
would
bring
it
to
about
that
time
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
they
suppose
you
to
have
inveigled
her
away
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mortimer
,
you
know
the
absorbing
nature
of
my
professional
occupations
;
I
really
have
not
had
leisure
to
think

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
asked

what

?
<EOS>
Have
you
objected
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
should
I
ask
them
what
they
want
,
<EOS>
dear
fellow
,
when
I
am
indifferent
what
they
want
?
<EOS>
Why
should
I
express
objection
,
when
I
do
n't
object
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
your
most
reckless
mood
.
<EOS>
But
you
called
the
situation
just
now
,
a
ludicrous
one
;
and
most
men
object
to
that
,
even
those
who
are
utterly

to
everything
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
charm
me
,
Mortimer
,
with
your
reading
of
my
weaknesses
.
<EOS>
(
By
-
the
-
by
,
that
very
word
,
Reading
,
in
its
critical
use
,
always
charms
me
.
<EOS>
An
actress
's
Reading
of
a
chambermaid
,
a
dancer
's
Reading
of
a
hornpipe
,
a

's

,
a

-

's
Reading
of

,
the
kettle
-

's
Reading
of
an

passage
,
are
phrases
ever
youthful
and

.
)
<EOS>
I
was
mentioning
your
perception
of
my
weaknesses
.
<EOS>
I
own
to
the
weakness
of
objecting
to
occupy
a
ludicrous
position
,
and
therefore
I
transfer
the
position
to
the
scouts
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
wish
,
Eugene
,
you
would
speak
a

and
plainly
,
if
it
were
only
out
of
consideration
for
my
feeling
less
at

than
you
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Then
soberly
and
plainly
,
Mortimer
,
I
goad
the
schoolmaster
to
madness
.
<EOS>
I
make
the
schoolmaster
,
so
ridiculous
,
and
so
aware
of
being
made
ridiculous
,
that
I
see
him
chafe
and
fret
at
every
pore
when
we
cross
one
another
.
<EOS>
The
amiable
occupation
has
been
the
solace
of
my
life
,
since
I
was
baulked
in
the
manner
unnecessary
to
recall
.
<EOS>
I
have
derived
inexpressible
comfort
from
it
.
<EOS>
I
do
it
thus
:
I
stroll
out
after
dark
,
stroll
a
little
way
,
look
in
at
a
window
and
furtively
look
out
for
the
schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
Sooner
or
later
,
I
perceive
the
schoolmaster
on
the
watch
;
sometimes
accompanied
by
his
hopeful
pupil
;
oftener
,
pupil
-
less
.
<EOS>
Having
made
sure
of
his
watching
me
,
I
tempt
him
on
,
all
over
London
.
<EOS>
One
night
I
go
east
,
another
night
north
,
in
a
few
nights
I
go
all
round
the
compass
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
I
walk
;
sometimes
,
I
proceed
in
cabs
,
draining
the
pocket
of
the
schoolmaster
who
then
follows
in
cabs
.
<EOS>
I
study
and
get
up
abstruse
No
Thoroughfares
in
the
course
of
the
day
.
<EOS>
With
Venetian
mystery
I
seek
those
No
Thoroughfares
at
night
,
glide
into
them
by
means
of
dark
courts
,
tempt
the
schoolmaster
to
follow
,
turn
suddenly
,
and
catch
him
before
he
can
retreat
.
<EOS>
Then
we
face
one
another
,
and
I
pass
him
as
unaware
of
his
existence
,
and
he
undergoes
grinding
torments
.
<EOS>
Similarly
,
I
walk
at
a
great
pace
down
a
short
street
,
rapidly
turn
the
corner
,
and
,
getting
out
of
his
view
,
as
rapidly
turn
back
.
<EOS>
I
catch
him
coming
on
post
,
again
pass
him
as
unaware
of
his
existence
,
and
again
he
undergoes
grinding
torments
.
<EOS>
Night
after
night
his
disappointment
is
acute
,
but
hope
springs
eternal
in
the
scholastic
breast
,
and
he
follows
me
again
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Thus
I
enjoy
the
pleasures
of
the
chase
,
and
derive
great
benefit
from
the
healthful
exercise
.
<EOS>
When

do
not
enjoy
the
pleasures
of
the
chase
,
for
anything
I
know
he
watches
at
the
Temple
Gate
all
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
an
extraordinary
story
,
"
observed
Lightwood
,
who
had

with

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
little

,

,
"
said

;
"
you
have

too
sedentary
.
<EOS>
Come

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
  
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>

and

.
<EOS>
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood

;
but
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Bravo
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
Or
,

Yoicks

,

said
Yoicks
.
<EOS>
Look

,
Mortimer
,

.
<EOS>
When

,
I

---

,

Forward
,
Hark

,
Tantivy
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

by

.
<EOS>
Ready
?
<EOS>
So
.
<EOS>
We

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
As

?
"
<EOS>

,
"

"

.
<EOS>

Green
?
"
<EOS>
Mortimer

,

.
"
<EOS>
Now
,

"

,
"
we

.
"
 
<EOS>
But
,
they
both
saw
him
,
before
they
got
there
;
alone
,
and
stealing
after

in
the

of

,
on

.
  
<EOS>
"
Get
your
wind
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
for
I
am
off
directly
.
<EOS>
Does

occur

that
the
boys
of
Merry
England
will

in
an

,

?
<EOS>
The
schoolmaster
ca
n't
attend
to
me
and
the
boys
too
.
<EOS>
Got
your
wind
?
<EOS>
I
am
off
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
what
a
rate
he
went
,
to
breathe
the
schoolmaster
;
and
how
he
then
lounged
and
loitered
,
to
put
his
patience
to
another
kind
of
wear
;
what
preposterous
ways
he
took
,
with
no
other
object
on
earth
than
to
disappoint
and
punish
him
;
and
how
he
wore
him
out
by
every
piece
of
ingenuity
that
his
eccentric
humour
could
devise
;
all
this
Lightwood
noted
,
with
a
feeling
of
astonishment
that
so
careless
a
man
could
be
so
wary
,
and
that
so
idle
a
man
could
take
so
much

.
<EOS>
At
last
,
far
on
in
the
third

of
the
pleasures
of
the
chase
,
when
he
had

the
poor

wretch
round

into
the
City
,
he
twisted
Mortimer
up
a

,
twisted
him
into
a
little
square
court
,
twisted
him
sharp
round

,
and
they
almost
ran
against
Bradley
Headstone
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
you
see
,
as
I
was
saying
,
Mortimer
,
"
remarked
Eugene
aloud

the

,
as

were

within

:
"
<EOS>
and
you
see
,
as
I
was
saying
---
undergoing
grinding
torments
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
not
too
strong
a
phrase
for
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
Looking
like
the
hunted
and
not
the
hunter
,
baffled
,
worn
,
with
the

of
deferred

and
consuming

and

in
his

,
white

,
wild
-

,
draggle
-
haired
,
seamed
with
jealousy
and
anger
,
and
torturing
himself
with
the
conviction
that
he
showed
it
all
<EOS>
and
they
exulted
in
it
<EOS>
,
he
went
by
them
in
the
dark
,
like
a
haggard
head
suspended
in
the
air
:
<EOS>
so
completely
did
the
force
of
his
expression
cancel
his
figure
.
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
Lightwood
was
not
an
extraordinarily
impressible
man
,
but
this
face
impressed
him
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
of
if
more
than
once
on
the
remainder
of
the
way
home
,
and
more
than
once
when
they
got
home
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
been
abed
in
their
respective
rooms
two
or
three
hours
,
when
Eugene
was
partly

by
hearing
a
footstep
going
about
,
and
was
fully

by

Lightwood
standing
at

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
wrong
,
Mortimer
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
fancy

you
,

,
for
walking
about

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
comes
that
about
,
I

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
I

's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Odd
!
"

,
"
I
can
.
"
<EOS>
And
turned
over
,
and

.
   
<EOS>
IN
THE
DARK
.
 
<EOS>
There
was
no
sleep
for
Bradley
Headstone
on
that
night
when
Eugene
Wrayburn
turned
so
easily
in
his
bed
;
there
was
no
sleep
for
little
Miss
Peecher
.
<EOS>
Bradley
consumed
the
lonely
hours
,
and
consumed
himself
,
in
haunting
the
spot
where
his
careless
rival
lay
a
dreaming
;
little
Miss
Peecher
wore
them
away
in
listening
for
the
return
home
of
the
master
of
her
heart
,
and
in
sorrowfully
presaging
that
much
was
amiss
with
him
.
<EOS>
Yet
more
was
amiss
with
him
than
<EOS>
Miss
Peecher
's
simply
arranged
little
work
-
box
of
thoughts
,
fitted
with
no
gloomy
and
dark
recesses
,
could
hold
.
<EOS>
For
,
the
state
of
the
man
was
murderous
.
  
<EOS>
The
state
of
the
man
was
murderous
,
and
he
knew
it
.
<EOS>
More
;
he
irritated
it
,
with
a
kind
of
perverse
pleasure
akin
to
that
which
a
sick
man
sometimes
has
in
irritating
a
wound
upon
his
body
.
<EOS>
Tied
up
all
day
with
his
disciplined
show
upon
him
,
subdued
to
the
performance
of
his
routine
of
educational
tricks
,
encircled
by
a
gabbling
crowd
,
he
broke
loose
at
night
like
at
ill
-
tames
wild
animal
.
<EOS>
Under
his
daily
restraint
,
it
was
his
compensation
,
not
his
trouble
,
to
give
a
glance
towards
his
state
at
night
,
and
to
the
freedom
of
its
being
indulged
.
<EOS>
If
great
criminals
told
the
truth
---
which
,
being
great
criminals
,
they
do
not
---
they
would
very
rarely
tell
of
their
struggles
against
the
crime
.
<EOS>
Their
struggles
are
towards
it
.
<EOS>
They
buffet
with
opposing
waves
,
to
gain
the
bloody
shore
,
not
to
recede
from
it
.
<EOS>
This
man
perfectly
comprehended
that
he
hated
his
rival
with
his
strongest
and
worst
forces
,
and
that
if
he
tracked
him
to
Lizzie
Hexam
,
his
so
doing
would
never
serve
himself
with
her
,
or
serve
her
.
<EOS>
All
his
pains
were
taken
,
to
the
end
that
he
might
incense
himself
with
the
sight
of
the
detested
figure
in
her
company
and
favour
,
in
her
place
of
concealment
.
<EOS>
And
he
knew
as
well
what
act
of
his
would
follow
if
he
did
,
as
he
know
that
his
mother
had
borne
him
.
<EOS>
Granted
,
that
he
may
not
have
held
it
necessary
to
make
express
mention
to
himself
of
the
one
familiar
truth
any
more
than
of
the
other
.
  
<EOS>
He
knew
equally
well
that
he
fed
his
wrath
and
hatred
,
and
that
he
accumulated
provocation
and
self
-
justification
,
by
being
made
the
nightly
sport
of
the
reckless
and

Eugene
.
<EOS>
Knowing
all
this
,
and
still
always
going
on
with
infinite
endurance
,
pains
,
and
perseverance
,
<EOS>
would
his
dark
soul
doubt
whither
he
went
?
  
<EOS>
Baffled
,

,
and
weary
<EOS>
,
he
lingered
opposite
the
Temple
gate
when

closed
on
Wrayburn
and
Lightwood
,
debating

he
go

for
that

or
should
he
watch
longer
.
<EOS>
Possessed
in
his

by
the
fixed

that
Wrayburn
was
in
the
secret
,
if
it

of
his
contriving
,
Bradley

as

the

at

to
him
,
as
he
would

---
and
often

---
of

any

study
in
the
way
of
his
vocation
,
by
the
like
slow
persistent
process
.
<EOS>
A
man
of
rapid
passions
and
sluggish
intelligence
,
it
had
served
him
often
and
should
serve

again
.
  
<EOS>
The
suspicion
crossed

as

in

upon
the
temple
gate
,
that
perhaps
she
was
even
concealed
in
that

Chambers
.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,
if

,
and
listen
.
<EOS>
So
,

,

neighbouring
Temple

.
  
<EOS>

"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
seemed

handle
his
name
as
if

was
a
Street

.
<EOS>
"
The
purport

"
Here

.
<EOS>
Can

?
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

.

?

Clearly

.

<EOS>

.

.
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
,

,

into

early

-

,

,
where

,

'

,

,

after

;
and
where

hovering

at
a

in
the

nightbird
with

,
the
worst

of
all
.
  
<EOS>
An
inspiration
of
affection
for
a
half
-

carter
going
his
way
led
to
Mr.
Riderhood
's
being

on

,
and

.
<EOS>
Bradley
then
turned
to
retrace
his
steps
,
and
by
-
and
-
by
struck
off
through
little
-

ways
,
and
by
-
and
-
by
reached
school
and

.
<EOS>
Up
came
the
sun
to
find
him
washed
and
brushed
,
methodically

in
decent
black
coat
and

,
decent

black

,
and

-

-

,
with
his
decent

watch
in
its

,
and
its
decent

-
guard
round

neck
;
a
scholastic
huntsman
clad
for
the
field
,
with
his
fresh
pack
yelping
and
barking
around
him
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
more
really
bewitched
than
the
miserable

of
the
much
-
lamented
times
,
who
accused
themselves
of
impossibilities
under

of
horror
and
the
strongly
suggestive
influences
of
Torture
,
he
had
been
ridden
hard
by
Evil
Spirits
in
the
night
that
was
newly
gone
.
<EOS>
He
had
been
spurred
and
whipped
any
heavily

.
<EOS>
If
a
record
of
the
sport
had

of
the

on

,
the
most

the

might

run
