master
.
   
<EOS>
MEANING
MISCHIEF
.
 
<EOS>
Up
came
the
sun
,
streaming
all
over
London
,
and
in
its
glorious
impartiality
even
condescending
to
make
prismatic
sparkles
in
the
whiskers
of
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
as
he
sat
at
breakfast
.
<EOS>
In
need
of
some
brightening
from
without
,
was
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
,
for
he
had
the
air
of
being
dull
enough
within
,
and
looked
grievously
discontented
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
faced
her
lord
.
<EOS>
The
happy
pair
of
swindlers
,
with
the
comfortable
tie
between
them
that
each
had
swindled
the
other
,
sat
moodily
observant
of
the
tablecloth
.
<EOS>
Things
looked
so
gloomy
in
the
breakfast
-
room
,
albeit
on
the
sunny
side
of
Sackville
Street
,
that
any
of
the
family
tradespeople
glancing
through
the
blinds
might
have
taken
the
hint
to
send
in
his
account
and
press
for
it
.
<EOS>
but
this
,
indeed
,
most
of
the
family
tradespeople
had
already
done
,
without
the
hint
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
seems
to
me
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
that
you
have
had
no
money
at
all
,
ever
since
we
have
been
married
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
seems
to
you
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
"
to
have
been
the
case
,
may
possibly
have
been
the
case
.
<EOS>
It
does
n't
matter
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Was
it
the
speciality
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
,
or
does
it
ever
obtain
with
other
loving
couples
?
<EOS>
In
these
matrimonial
dialogues
they
never
addressed
each
other
,
but
always
some
invisible
presence
that
appeared
to
take
a
station
about
midway
between
them
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
skeleton
in
the
cupboard
comes
out
to
be
talked
to
,
on
such
domestic
occasions
?
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
seen
any
money
in
the
house
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
to
the
skeleton
,
"
except
my
own
annuity
.
<EOS>
That
I
swear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
take
the
trouble
of
swearing
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
to
the
skeleton
;
"
once
more
,
it
does
n't
matter
.
<EOS>
You
never
turned
your
annuity
to
so
good
an
account
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
an
account
!
<EOS>
In
what
way
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
the
way
of
getting
credit
,
and
living
well
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
skeleton
laughed
scornfully
on
being
intrusted
with
this
question
and
this
answer
;
certainly
Mrs.
Lammle
did
,
and
Mr.
Lammle
did
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
to
happen
next
?
"
asked
Mrs.
Lammle
of
the
skeleton
.
  
<EOS>
"
Smash
is
to
happen
next
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
to
the
same
authority
.
  
<EOS>
After
this
,
Mrs.
Lammle
looked
disdainfully
at
the
skeleton
---
but
without
carrying
the
look
on
to
Mr.
Lammle
---
and
drooped
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
After
that
,
Mr.
Lammle
did
exactly
the
same
thing
,
and
drooped
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
A
servant
then
entering
with
toast
,
the
skeleton
retired
into
the
closet
,
and
shut
itself
up
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
when
the
servant
had
withdrawn
.
<EOS>
And
then
,
very
much
louder
:
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Attend
to
me
,
if
you
please
.
"
<EOS>
He
eyed
her
sternly
until
she
did
attend
,
and
then
went
on
.
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
take
counsel
with
you
.
<EOS>
Come
,
come
;
no
more
trifling
.
<EOS>
You
know
our
league
and
covenant
.
<EOS>
We
are
to
work
together
for
our
joint
interest
,
and
you
are
as
knowing
a
hand
as
I
am
.
<EOS>
We
should
n't
be
together
,
if
you
were
not
.
<EOS>
What
's
to
be
done
?
<EOS>
We
are
hemmed
into
a
corner
.
<EOS>
What
shall
we
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
no
scheme
on
foot
that
will
bring
in
anything
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
plunged
into
his
whiskers
for
reflection
,
and
came
out
hopeless
:
"
<EOS>
No
;
as
adventurers
we
are
obliged
to
play
rash
games
for
chances
of
high
winnings
,
and
there
has
been
a
run
of
luck
against
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
resuming
,
"
<EOS>
Have
you
nothing
---
"
when
he
stopped
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
We
,
we
,
we
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
we
nothing
to
sell
?
"
  
"
Deuce
a
bit
.
<EOS>
I
have
given
a
Jew
a
bill
of
sale
on
this
furniture
,
and
he
could
take
it
to
-
morrow
,
to
-
day
,
now
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
taken
it
before
now
,
I
believe
,
but
for
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
has
Fledgeby
to
do

him
?
"
  
"
Knew
him
.
<EOS>
Cautioned
me
against
him
before
I
got
into
his
claws
.
<EOS>
Could
n't
persuade
him
then
,
in
behalf

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

Fledgeby

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Us
,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
Us
,
us
,
us
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Towards
us
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
the
Jew
has
not
yet
done
what
he
might

done
,
and
that
Fledgeby
takes
the

of
having
got

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

Fledgeby
?
"
  
"
Sophronia
,
I
never
believe
anybody
.
<EOS>
I
never
have
,
<EOS>
my
dear
,
since
I

you
.
<EOS>
But
it
looks
like
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
Having
given
her
this
back
-
handed

of
her
mutinous

to
the
skeleton
,
Mr.
Lammle
rose
from
table
---
perhaps
,
the
better
to
conceal
a
smile
,
and
a
white
dint
or
two
about
his
nose
---
and
took
a
turn
on
the
carpet
and
came
to
the
hearthrug
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
we
could
have
packed
the
brute
off
with
Georgiana
;
---
but
however
;
that
's
spilled
milk
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
Lammle
,
standing
gathering
up
the
skirts
of
his
dressing
-
gown
with
his
back
to
the
fire
,
said
this
,
looking
down
at
his
wife
,
she
turned
pale
and
looked
down
at
the
ground
.
<EOS>
With
a
sense
of
disloyalty
upon
her
,
and
perhaps
with
a
sense
of
personal
danger
---
for
she
was

---
even
afraid

hand
and

foot
,
though
he
had
never
done
her
violence
---
she
hastened
to
put
herself
right
in
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
we
could
borrow
money
,
Alfred
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
Beg
money
,
borrow
money
,
or
steal
money
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
all
one
to
us
,
Sophronia
,
"
her

struck
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
---
Then
,
we
could
weather
this
?
"
  
"
No

.
<EOS>
To
offer
another
original
and
undeniable
remark
,
Sophronia
,
two
and
two
make
four
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
seeing
that
she
was
turning
something
in

,
he
gathered
up
the
skirts

his
dressing
-

again
,
and
,
tucking

under
one

,
and
collecting
his
ample
whiskers
in
his
other
hand
,
kept
his
eye
upon
her
,
silently
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
natural
,
Alfred
,
"
she
said
,
looking
up
with
some

into

,
"
to

in
such
an
emergency
of
the
richest
people
we
know
,
and
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
Boffins
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Just
so
,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
there
nothing
to
be
done
with

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
there
to
be
done
with
them
,
Sophronia
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
cast
about
in
her
thoughts
again
,
and
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
I
have
repeatedly
thought
of
the
Boffins
,
Sophronia
,
"
 
he
resumed
,

;
"
but
I
have
seen

to
nothing
.
<EOS>
They
are
well

.
<EOS>
That
infernal
Secretary

---

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If

?
"

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Take
time
,
Sophronia
,
"
observed

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
working
him
out
of
the
way

presented

a

Mr.
Boffin
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Take

,
Sophronia
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
have

,
Alfred
,

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Miserly

,

;

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
,

,
Sophronia
,
take

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
took
time
and
then
said
:
  
"
<EOS>
Suppose
we
should
address
ourselves
to
that
tendency
in
him
of
which
we
have
made
ourselves

.
<EOS>
Suppose
my
conscience
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
we
know
what
a
conscience
<EOS>
it
is
,
my
soul
.
<EOS>
Yes
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Suppose
my
conscience
should
not

me
to

what
that
upstart
girl

of

's

to

.
<EOS>
Suppose

should

to

Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
rather
like

,
"
said
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Suppose
I
so
repeated

to
Mr.
Boffin
,
as
to
insinuate
that
my
sensitive
delicacy
and

---
"
  
"
Very
good
words
,
Sophronia
.
"
  
"
---
As

that
our
sensitive
delicacy
and

,
"
she

,
with
a

upon

,
"
would
not
allow
us
to
be
silent

to
so

on
the
Secretary
's

,
and
so
gross
a

faith

his

.
<EOS>
Suppose
I
had
imparted
my
virtuous

to

,

,

,
`
`
Sophronia
,

Boffin
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
Once
more
,
Sophronia
,
"
observed
Lammle
,
changing
the
leg
on

he

,
"
I
rather
like
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
remark
that
he
is
well

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
think
so

.
<EOS>
But

this
should
lead
to
his
discharging
his
Secretary
,
there

a

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Go
on
expounding
,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
I
begin
to
like
this
very

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Having
,

our

,
done

the

of
opening

to
the

of
the

,
we
shall

.
<EOS>
Whether

,

,

---
because

ca
n't

---

.
<EOS>
Probably

make

most

it
that

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Probably
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"
she

,

,
"

?
"
  
"
Not

,

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
At

might
be

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
nodded
her
understanding
of
the
hint
,
as
she
looked
at
the
fire
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
,
"
she
said
,
musingly
:
not
without
a
slight

touch
:
"
Mr.
Lammle
would
be
so
delighted
to
do
anything
in
his
power
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
,
himself
a
man
of
business
as
well
as
a
capitalist
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
,
accustomed
to
be
intrusted
with
the
most
delicate
affairs
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
,
who
has
managed
my
own
little
fortune
so
admirably
,
but
who
,
to
be
sure
,
began
to
make
his
reputation
with
the
advantage
of
being
a
man
of
property
,
above

,
and
beyond
suspicion
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
smiled
,
and
even
patted
her
on
the
head
.
<EOS>
In
his
sinister
relish
of
the
scheme
,
as
he
stood
above
her
,
making
it
the
subject
of
his

,
he
seemed
to
have
twice
as
much
nose
on
his
face
as
he
had
ever
had
in
his
life
.
  
<EOS>
He
stood
pondering
,
and
she
sat
looking
at
the
dusty
fire
without
moving
,
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
moment
he
began
to
speak
again
she
looked
up
with
a

and
attended
to
him
,
as
if
that
double
-
dealing
of
hers
had
been
in
her
mind
,
and
the
fear
were
revived
in
her
of
his
hand
or
his
foot
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
appears
to
me
,
Sophronia
,
that
you
have
omitted
one
branch
of
the
subject
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
not
,
for
women
understand
women
.
<EOS>
We
might
oust
the
girl
herself
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
shook
her
head
.
<EOS>
"
She
has
an
immensely
strong
hold
upon
them
both
,
Alfred
.
<EOS>
Not
to
be
compared
with
that
of
a
paid
secretary
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
the
dear
child
,
"
said
Lammle
,
with
a
crooked
smile
,
"
ought
to
have
been
open
with
her
benefactor
and
benefactress
.
<EOS>
The
darling
love
ought
to
have
reposed
unbounded
confidence
in
her
benefactor
and
benefactress
.
"
  
<EOS>
Sophronia
shook
her
head
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Women
understand
women
,
"
said
her
husband
,
rather
disappointed
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
press
it
.
<EOS>
It
might
be
the
making
of
our
fortune
to
make
a
clean
sweep
of
them
both
.
<EOS>
With
me
to
manage
the
property
,
and
my
wife
to
manage
the
people
---
Whew
!
"
  
<EOS>
Again

her
head
,
she
returned
:
"
They
will
never
quarrel
with
the
girl
.
<EOS>
They
will
never
punish
the
girl
.
<EOS>
We
must
accept
the
girl
,
rely
upon
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
"
cried
Lammle
,
shrugging
his
shoulders
<EOS>
,
"
so
be
it
:
only
always
remember
that
we
do
n't
want
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
the
sole

is
,
"
said

,
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
can

,
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
As

,
the

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

Mr.
Boffin
alone
,
Alfred
.
<EOS>
If
his
wife
was

,
she

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Call
,

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
Leave

.
<EOS>
Spare

,
and

-

(
if

-

)
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Co.

,

<EOS>
"
Mr.

,
"

,

"
<EOS>
so

!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
They

,

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Holloa
!
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
You

,
Jerusalem
!
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Nothing

?
<EOS>
You
wo
n't

?

<EOS>
Ordered

<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---

,

---

"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
Toddle
,

!
"
   
GIVE
A
DOG
<EOS>
A
BAD
NAME
,
AND
HANG
HIM
.
 
<EOS>
Fascination
Fledgeby
,
left
alone
in
the
counting
-
house
,
strolled
about
with
his
hat
on
one
side
,
whistling
,
and
investigating
the
drawers
,
and
prying
here
and
there
for
any
small
evidences
of
his
being
cheated
,
but
could
find
none
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
his
merit
that
he
do
n't
cheat
me
,
"
was
Mr.
Fledgeby
's
commentary
delivered
with
a
wink
,
"
but
my
precaution
.
"
<EOS>
He
then
with
a
lazy
grandeur
asserted
his
rights
as
lord
of
Pubsey
and
Co.
by
poking
his
cane
at
the
stools
and
boxes
,
and
spitting
in
the
fireplace
,
and
so
loitered
royally
to
the
window
and
looked
out
into
the
narrow
street
,
with
his
small
eyes
just
peering
over
the
top
of
Pubsey
and
Co.
's
blind
.
<EOS>
As
a
blind
in
more
senses
than
one
,
it
reminded
him
that
he
was
alone
in
the
counting
-
house
with
the
front
door
open
.
<EOS>
He
was
moving
away
to
shut
it
,
lest
he
should
be
injudiciously
identified
with
the
establishment
,
when
he
was
stopped
by
some
one
coming
to
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
This
some
one
was
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
,
with
a
little
basket
on
her
arm
,
and
her
crutch
stick
in
her
hand
.
<EOS>
Her
keen
eyes
had
espied
Mr.
Fledgeby
before
Mr.
Fledgeby
had
espied
her
,
and
he
was
paralyzed
in
his
purpose
of
shutting
her
out
,
not
so
much
by
her
approaching
the
door
,
as
by
her
favouring
him
with
a
shower
of
nods
,
the
instant
he
saw
her
.

Hope

The

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
Condemned

such

little

,

<EOS>
"
Perhaps
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
"
you
may
be
a
little
proud
of
entering
on
the
topic
,
---
having
been
brought
up
as
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
that
,
sir
,
"
returned
Twemlow
,
"
it
's
not
that
.
<EOS>
I
hope
I
distinguish
between
true
pride
and
false
pride
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
pride
at
all
,
myself
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
"
and
perhaps
I
do
n't
cut
things
so
fine
as
to
know
one
from
t'other
.
<EOS>
But
I
know
this
is
a
place
where
even
a
man
of
business
needs
his
wits
about
him
;
and
if
mine
can
be
of
any
use
to
you
here
,
you
're
welcome
to
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
good
,
"
said
Twemlow
,
faltering
.
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
most
unwilling
---
"
  
"
I
do
n't
,
you
know
,
"
proceeded
Fledgeby
with
an
ill
-
favoured
glance
,
"
entertain
the
vanity
of
supposing
that
my
wits
could
be
of
any
use
to
you
in
society
,
but
they
might
be
here
.
<EOS>
You
cultivate
society
and
society
cultivates
you
,
but
Mr.
Riah
's
not
society
.
<EOS>
In
society
,
Mr.
Riah
is
kept
dark
;
eh
,
Mr.
Twemlow
?
"
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
,
much
disturbed
,
and
with
his
hand
fluttering
about
his
forehead
,
replied
:
"
Quite
true
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
confiding
young
man
besought
him
to
state
his
case
.
<EOS>
The
innocent
Twemlow
,
expecting
Fledgeby
to
be
astounded
by
what
he
should
unfold
,
and
not
for
an
instant
conceiving
the
possibility
of
its
happening
every
day
,
but
treating
of
it
as
a
terrible
phenomenon
occurring
in
the
course
of
ages
,
related
how
that
he
had
had
a
deceased
friend
,
a
married
civil
officer
with
a
family
,
who
had
wanted
money
for
change
of
place
on
change
of
post
,
and
how
he
,
Twemlow
,
had
"
given
him
his
name
,
"
with
the
usual
,
but
in
the
eyes
of
Twemlow
almost
incredible
result
that
he
had
been
left
to
repay
what
he
had
never
had
.
<EOS>
How
,
in
the
course
of
years
,
he
had
reduced
the
principal
by
trifling
sums
,
"
having
,
"
said
Twemlow
,
"
always
to
observe
great
economy
,
being
in
the
enjoyment
of
a
fixed
income
limited
in
extent
,
and
that
depending
on
the
munificence
of
a
certain
nobleman
,
"
and
had
always
pinched
the
full
interest
out
of
himself
with
punctual
pinches
.
<EOS>
How
he
had
come
,
in
course
of
time
,
to
look
upon
this
one
only
debt
of
his
life
as
a
regular
quarterly
drawback
,
and
no
worse
,
when
"
his
name
"
had
some
way
fallen
into
the
possession
of
Mr.
Riah
,
who
had
sent
him
notice
to
redeem
it
by
paying
up
in
full
,
in
one
plump
sum
,
or
take
tremendous
consequences
.
<EOS>
This
,
with
hazy
remembrances
of
how
he
had
been
carried
to
some
office
to
"
confess
judgment
"
(
as
he
recollected
the
phrase
)
,
and
how
he
had
been
carried
to
another
office
where
his
life
was
assured
for
somebody
not
wholly
unconnected
with
the
sherry
trade
whom
he
remembered
by
the
remarkable
circumstance
that
he
had
a
Straduarius
violin
to
dispose
of
,
and
also
a
Madonna
,
formed
the
sum
and
substance
of
Mr.
Twemlow
's
narrative
.
<EOS>
Through
which
stalked
the
shadow
of
the
awful
Snigsworth
,
eyed
afar
off
by
money
-
lenders
as
Security
in
the
Mist
,
and
menacing
Twemlow
with
his
baronial
truncheon
.
  
<EOS>
To
all
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
listened
with
the
modest
gravity
becoming
a
confiding
young
man
who
knew
it
all
beforehand
,
and
,
when
it
was
finished
,
seriously
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
,
Mr.
Twemlow
,
"
 
said
Fledgeby
,
"
I
do
n't
like
Riah
's
calling
in
the
principal
.
<EOS>
If
he
's
determined
to
call
it
in
,
it
must
come
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
supposing
,
sir
,
"
said
Twemlow
,
downcast
,
"
that
it
ca
n't
come
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
retorted
Fledgeby
,
"
you
must
go
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
asked
Twemlow
,
faintly
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
prison
,
"
returned
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
Whereat
Mr.
Twemlow
leaned
his
innocent
head
upon
his
hand
,
and
moaned
a
little
moan
of
distress
and
disgrace
.
  
<EOS>
"
However
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
appearing
to
pluck
up
his
spirits
,
"
we
'll
hope
it
's
not
so
bad
as
that
comes
to
.
<EOS>
If
you
'll
allow
me
,
I
'll
mention
to
Mr.
Riah
when
he
comes
in
,
who
you
are
,
and
I
'll
tell
him
you
're
my
friend
,
and
<EOS>
I
'll
say
my
say
for
you
,
instead
of
your
saying

for
yourself
;
I
may
be
able
to
do
it
in
a
more
business
-
like

.
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
consider
it
a

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
again
and
again
,
sir
,
"
said
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
strong
,
strongly
,
disinclined
to
avail
myself
of
your
generosity
,
though
my
helplessness
yields
.
<EOS>
For
I
can
not
but
feel
that
I
---
to
put
it
in
the
mildest
form
of
speech
---
that
I
have
done
nothing
to
deserve
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
can
he
be
?
"
<EOS>
muttered
Fledgeby
,
referring
to
his
watch
again
.
<EOS>
"
What
can
he
have
gone
out
for
?
<EOS>
Did
you
ever
see
him
,
Mr.
Twemlow
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Never
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
a
thorough
Jew
to
look
at
,
but
he
is
a
more
thorough
Jew
to
deal
with
.
<EOS>
He
's
worst
when
he
's
quiet
.
<EOS>
If
he
's
quiet
,
I
shall
take
it
as
a
very
bad
sign
.
<EOS>
Keep
your
eye
upon
him
when
he
comes
in
,
and
,
if
he
's
quiet
,
do
n't
be
hopeful
.
<EOS>
Here
he
is
!
---
<EOS>
He
looks
quiet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
these
words
,
which
had
the
effect
of
causing
the
harmless
Twemlow
painful
agitation
,
Mr.
Fledgeby
withdrew
to
his
former
post
,
and
the
old
man
entered
the
counting
-
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
Mr.
Riah
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,
"
I
thought
you
were
lost
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
,
glancing
at
the
stranger
,
stood
stock
-
still
.
<EOS>
He
perceived
that
his
master
was
leading
up
to
the
orders
he
was
to
take
,
and
he
waited
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
thought
,
"
repeated
Fledgeby
slowly
,
"
that
you
were
lost
,
Mr.
Riah
.
<EOS>
Why
,
now
I
look
at

---
but
no
,
you
ca
n't
have
done
it
;
 
no
<EOS>
,
you
ca
n't
have
done
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hat
in

,
the
old

lifted

,
and
looked

at
Fledgeby
as
seeking
to

what
new

was

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
ca
n't
have

,

in

's
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
Say

have

,
Mr.
Riah
.
"
  
"
Sir
,
I
have
,
"
replied
the
old
man
in
a
low

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
my
eye
!
"
cried
Fledgeby
.
"
<EOS>
Tut
,
tut
,
tut
!
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
,
<EOS>
dear
!
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I

,
Mr.
Riah
,

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said

,

,
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
but

,

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do

,
"
retorted
Fledgeby
,
secretly

old

,
with

of

of

two

.
<EOS>
"
Do

the

,
Mr.
Riah
.
<EOS>
You

,

do

,
but
do

.
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
Why

,
Mr.
Riah
?
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

clasped
the

of

long

with

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,
"

,
"

,

,

Riah
,

,

.
<EOS>
Look

,
Mr.
Riah
.
<EOS>
This

Twemlow
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Jew
turned
to
him
and
bowed
.
<EOS>
That
poor
lamb
bowed
in
return
;
polite
,
and
terrified
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
made

,
"
proceeded
Fledgeby
,
"
in

for

,
that
I
've

of

for
my
friend
(
and

)
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
But
I
do

,

would
for

,

I
wo
n't

,

Twemlow

.
<EOS>
Now
,

Riah
,
here

Mr.
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
Always
good
for
his

,
always

,
always

.
<EOS>
Now
,
why
should
you
press
Mr.
Twemlow
?
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
have
any
spite
against
Mr.
Twemlow
!
<EOS>
Why
not

easy

Mr.
Twemlow
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
into
Fledgeby
's
little

for
any

of
leave
to
be
easy
with
Mr.
Twemlow
;
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Twemlow
is
no
connexion
of

,
Mr.
Riah
,
"
said
Fledgeby
;
 
<EOS>
"
you
ca
n't
want

be
even

him
for
having
through
life
<EOS>
gone
in
for

and

Family
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Twemlow
has

,
what

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
"
interposed

,
"
I
have
not
.
<EOS>
I
should

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
Mr.
Riah
!
<EOS>
"
said
Fledgeby
,
"
is
n't
that
handsomely
said
?
<EOS>
Come
!
<EOS>
Make

Mr.
Twemlow
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
looked
again
for
any

to
spare
the
poor
little
gentleman
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
meant
him
to
be
racked
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
sorry
,
Mr.
Twemlow
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I
am

for

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
In

down
,

,
Mr.
Riah
?
<EOS>
"
asked
Fledgeby
,
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
In
full
,
sir
,
and
at
once
,
"
was
Riah
's

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
shook
his

at
Twemlow
,
and
mutely
expressed
in
reference

the

figure
standing

with

upon

:
"
What
a
Monster
of
an
Israelite
this
is
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Riah
,
"
said
Fledgeby
.
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
lifted
up
his
eyes
once
more
to
the
little
eyes
in
Mr.
Fledgeby
's
head
,
with
some
reviving
hope
that
the
sign
might
be
coming
yet
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Riah
,
it
's
of
no
use
my

back
the

.
<EOS>
There
's
a
certain
great
party
in

's

,

know

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know

,
"
the
old
man
admitted
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
'll
put
it
as
a

,
Mr.
Riah
.
<EOS>
Are

(

)

<EOS>
that
said

's

,

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Fully
determined
,
"
answered
Riah
,
as
he
read
his
master
's
face
,
and
learnt
the
book
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
at
all
caring
,
for
,
and
indeed
as
it
seems
to

<EOS>
,
"
 
said

,
with

unction
,
"
the
precious
kick
-
up
and
row
that
will
come
off
between
Mr.
Twemlow
and
the
said
great
party
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
required
no
answer
,
and
received
none
.
<EOS>
Poor
Mr.
Twemlow
,
who
had
betrayed
the
keenest
mental
terrors
since
his
noble
kinsman
loomed
in
the
perspective
,
rose
with
a
sigh
to
take
his

.
<EOS>
"
I
thank
you
very
much
,
sir
,
"
he
said
,
offering
Fledgeby
his
feverish
hand
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
done
me
an
unmerited
service
.
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
thank
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
mention
it
,
"
answered
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
a
failure
so
far
,
but
I
'll
stay
behind
,
and
take
another
touch
at
Mr.
Riah
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
not
deceive
yourself
,
Mr.
Twemlow
,
"
said
the
Jew
,
then
addressing
him
directly
for
the
first
time
.
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
hope
for
you
.
<EOS>
You
must
expect
no
leniency
here
.
<EOS>
You
must
pay
in
full
,
and
you
can
not
pay
too
promptly
,
or
you
will
be
put
to
heavy
charges
.
<EOS>
Trust
nothing
to
me
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Money
,
money
,
money
.
<EOS>
"
When
he
had
said
these
words
in
an
emphatic
manner
,
he
acknowledged
Mr.
Twemlow
's
still
polite
motion
of
his
head
,
and
that
amiable
little
worthy
took
his
departure
in
the
lowest
spirits
.
  
<EOS>
Fascination
Fledgeby
was
in
such
a
merry
vein
when
the
counting
-
house
was
cleared
of
him
,
that
he
had
nothing
for
it
but
to
go
to
the
window
,
and
lean
his
arms
on
the
frame
of
the
blind
,
and
have
his
silent
laugh
out
,
with
his
back
to
his
subordinate
.
<EOS>
When
he
turned
round
again
with
a
composed
countenance
,
his
subordinate
still
stood
in
the
same
place
,
and
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
sat
behind
the
door
with
a
look
of
horror
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
!
"
cried
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
"
you
're
forgetting
this
young
lady
,
Mr.
Riah
,
and
she
has
been
waiting
long
enough
too
.
<EOS>
Sell
her
her
waste
,
please
,
and
give
her
good
measure
if
you
can
make
up
your
mind
to
do
the
liberal
thing
for
once
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
on
for
a
time
,
as
the
Jew
filled
her
little
basket
with
such
scraps
as
she
was
used
to
buy
;
but
,
his
merry
vein
coming
on
again
,
he
was
obliged
to
turn
round
to
the
window
once
more
,
and
lean
his
arms
on
the
blind
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
my
Cinderella
dear
,
"
said
the
old
man
in
a
whisper
,
and
with
a
worn
-
out
look
,
"
the
basket
's
full
now
.
<EOS>
Bless
you
!
<EOS>
And
get
you
gone
!
"
  
"
Do
n't
call
me
your
Cinderella
dear
,
"
returned
Miss
Wren
.
<EOS>
"
O
you
cruel
godmother
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
shook
that
emphatic
little
forefinger
of
hers
in
his
face
at
parting
,
as
earnestly
and
reproachfully
as
she
had
ever
shaken
it
at
her
grim
old
child
at
home
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
not
the
godmother
at
all
!
"
<EOS>
said
she
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
Wolf
in
the
Forest
,
the
wicked
Wolf
!
<EOS>
And
if
ever
my
dear
Lizzie
is
sold
and
betrayed
,
I
shall
know
who
sold
and
betrayed
her
!
"
   
<EOS>
MR
.
<EOS>
WEGG
PREPARES
A
GRINDSTONE
FOR
MR
.
BOFFIN
'S
NOSE
.
 
<EOS>
Having
assisted
at
a
few
more
expositions
of
the
lives
of
Misers
,
Mr.
Venus
became
almost
indispensable
to
the
evenings
at
the
Bower
.
<EOS>
The
circumstance
of
having
another
listener
to
the
wonders
unfolded
by
Wegg
,
or
,
as
it
were
,
another
calculator
to
cast
up
the
guineas
found
in
teapots
,
chimneys
,
racks
and
mangers
,
and
other
such
banks
of
deposit
,
seemed
greatly
to
heighten
Mr.
Boffin
's
enjoyment
;
while
Silas
Wegg
,
for
his
part
,
though
of
a
jealous
temperament
which
might
under
ordinary
circumstances
have
resented
the
anatomist
's
getting
into
favour
,
was
so
very
anxious
to
keep
his
eye
on
that
gentleman
---
lest
,
being
too
much
left
to
himself
,
he
should
be
tempted
to
play
any
tricks
with
the
precious
document
in
his
keeping
---
that
he
never
lost
an
opportunity
of
commending
him
to
Mr.
Boffin
's
notice
as
a
third
party
whose
company
was
much
to
be
desired
.
<EOS>
Another
friendly
demonstration
towards
him
Mr.
Wegg
now
regularly
gratified
.
<EOS>
After
each
sitting
was
over
,
and
the
patron
had
departed
,
Mr.
Wegg
invariably
saw
Mr.
Venus
home
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
he
as
invariably
requested
to
be
refreshed
with
a
sight
of
the
paper
in
which
he
was
a
joint
proprietor
;
but
he
never
failed
to
remark
that
it
was
the
great
pleasure
he
derived
from
Mr.
Venus
's
improving
society
which
had
insensibly
lured
him
round
to
Clerkenwell
again
,
and
that
,
finding
himself
once
more
attracted
to
the
spot
by
the
social
powers
of
Mr.
V.
,
he
would
beg
leave
to
go
through
that
little
incidental
procedure
,
as
a
matter
of
form
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
For
well
I
know
,
sir
,
"
Mr.
Wegg
would
add
,
"
that
a
man
of
your
delicate
mind
would
wish
to
be
checked
off
whenever
the
opportunity
arises
,
and
it
is
not
for
me
to
baulk
your
feelings
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
certain
rustiness
in
Mr.
Venus
,
which
never
became
so
lubricated
by
the
oil
of
Mr.
Wegg
but
that
he
turned
under
the
screw
in
a
creaking
and
stiff
manner
,
was
very
noticeable
at
about
this
period
.
<EOS>
While
assisting
at
the
literary
evenings
,
he
even
went
so
far
,
on
two
or
three
occasions
,
as
to
correct
Mr.
Wegg
when
he
grossly
mispronounced
a
word
,
or
made
nonsense
of
a
passage
;
insomuch
that
Mr.
Wegg
took
to
surveying
his
course
in
the
day
,
and
to
making
arrangements
for
getting
round
rocks
at
night
instead
of
running
straight
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Of
the
slightest
anatomical
reference
he
became
particularly
shy
,
and
,
if
he
saw
a
bone
ahead
,
would
go
any
distance
out
of
his
way
rather
than
mention
it
by
name
.
  
<EOS>
The
adverse
destinies
ordained
that
one
evening
Mr.
Wegg
's
labouring
bark
became
beset
by
polysyllables
,
and
embarrassed
among
a
perfect
archipelago
of
hard
words
.
<EOS>
It
being
necessary
to
take
soundings
every
minute
,
and
to
feel
the
way
with
the
greatest
caution
,
Mr.
Wegg
's
attention
was
fully
employed
.
<EOS>
Advantage
was
taken
of
this
dilemma
by
Mr.
Venus
,
to
pass
a
scrap
of
paper
into
Mr.
Boffin
's
hand
,
and
lay
his
finger
on
his
own
lip
.
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Boffin
got
home
at
night
he
found
that
the
paper
contained
Mr.
Venus
's
card
and
these
words
:
"
<EOS>
Should
be
glad
to
be
honored
with
a
call
respecting
business
of
your
own
,
about
dusk
on
an
early
evening
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
very
next
evening
saw
Mr.
Boffin
peeping
in
at
the
preserved
frogs
in
Mr.
Venus
's
shop
-
window
,
and
saw
Mr.
Venus
espying
Mr.
Boffin
with
the
readiness
of
one
on
the
alert
,
and
beckoning
that
gentleman
into
his
interior
.
<EOS>
Responding
,
Mr.
Boffin
was
invited
to
seat
himself
on
the
box
of
human
miscellanies
before
the
fire
,
and
did
so
,
looking
round
the
place
with
admiring
eyes
.
<EOS>
The
fire
being
low
and
fitful
,
and
the
dusk
gloomy
,
the
whole
stock
seemed
to
be
winking
and
blinking
with
both
eyes
,
as
Mr.
Venus
did
.
<EOS>
The
French
gentleman
,
though
he
had
no
eyes
,
was
not
at
all
behindhand
,
but
appeared
,
as
the
flame
rose
and
fell
,
to
open
and
shut
his
no
eyes
,
with
the
regularity
of
the
glass
-
eyed
dogs
and
ducks
and
birds
.
<EOS>
The
big
-
headed
babies
were
equally
obliging
in
lending
their
grotesque
aid
to
the
general
effect
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
see
,
Mr.
Venus
,
I
've
lost
no
time
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Here
I
am
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Here
you
are
,
sir
,
"
assented
Mr.
Venus
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like

,
"
pursued
Mr.
Boffin
---
"
at
least
,
not
in

general
way
I
do
n't
---
<EOS>
but
I
dare
say
you
'll
show
me
good
reason
for
being
secret
so
far
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
shall
,

,
"
returned

.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
expect
Wegg
,
I
take

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

glanced
about

,
as

the
French

and
the
circle

did

,
and

,
"
The
present
company
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
said
Mr.
Venus
,
"
before

upon
business
,
I
shall
have
to
ask
you
for
your
word
and

that
we

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
's
wait

bit

understand

the

means
,
"
 
answered

Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
In
confidence
for
how
long
?
<EOS>
In
confidence
for
ever

a
day
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
take
your
hint
,
sir
,
"
said
Venus
;
"
you
think

might

the
business
,
when

came

,
to
be

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
might
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
with
a
cautious

.
  
<EOS>
"
True
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Well
,
sir
,
"
observed
Venus
,
after

at

,
to

,
"
let
us
put
it
another

.
<EOS>
I
open

,

not
to
do

in

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
sounds
fair
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
I
agree
to
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
your
word
and
honor
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
good
fellow
,
"
retorted
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
you
have
my
word
;
and
how
you
can
have
that
,
without
my
honor
too
<EOS>
,
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
I
've
sorted
a
lot
of
dust
in
my
time
,
but
I
never
knew
the
two
things
go
into
separate
heaps
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
remark
seemed
rather
to
abash
Mr.
Venus
.
<EOS>
He
hesitated
,
and
said
,
"
Very
true
,
sir
;
"
and
again
,
"
Very
true
,
sir
,
"
before
resuming
the
thread
of
his
discourse
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Boffin
,
if
I
confess
to
you
that
I
fell
into
a
proposal
of
which
you
were
the
subject
,
and
of
which
you
ought
n't
to
have
been
the
subject
,
you
will
allow
me
to
mention
,
and
will
please
take
into
favourable
consideration
,
that
I
was
in
a
crushed
state
of
mind
at
the
time
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Golden
Dustman
,
with
his
hands
folded
on
the
top
of
his
stout
stick
,
with
his
chin
resting
upon
them
,
and
with
something
leering
and
whimsical
in
his
eyes
,
gave
a
nod
,
and
said
,
"
<EOS>
Quite
so
,
Venus
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
That
proposal
,
sir
,
was
a
conspiring
breach
of
your
confidence
,
to
such
an
extent
,
that
I
ought
at
once
to
have
made
it
known
to
you
.
<EOS>
But
I
did
n't
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
and
I
fell
into
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Without
moving
eye
or
finger
,
Mr.
Boffin
gave
another
nod
,
and
placidly
repeated
,
"
Quite
so
,
Venus
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
that
I
was
ever
hearty
in
it
,
sir
,
"
the
penitent
anatomist
went
on
,
"
or
that
I
ever
viewed
myself
with
anything
but
reproach
for
having
turned
out
of
the
paths
of
science
into
the
paths
of
---
"
 
he
was
going
to
say
"
villany
,
"
but
,
unwilling
to
press
too
hard
upon
himself
,
substituted
with
great
emphasis
---
"
Weggery
.
"
  
<EOS>
Placid
and
whimsical
of
look
as
ever
,
Mr.
Boffin
answered
:
"
Quite
so
,
Venus
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
now
,
sir
,
"
said
Venus
,
"
having
prepared
your
mind
in
the
rough
,
I
will
articulate
the
details
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
which
brief
professional
exordium
,
he
entered
on
the
history
of
the
friendly
move
,
and
truly
recounted
it
.
<EOS>
One
might
have
thought
that
it
would
have
extracted
some
show
of
surprise
or
anger
,
or
other
emotion
,
from
Mr.
Boffin
,
but
it
extracted
nothing
beyond
his
former
comment
:
"
Quite
so
,
Venus
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
astonished
you
,
sir
,
I
believe
?
"
said
Mr.
Venus
,
pausing
dubiously
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
simply
answered
as
aforesaid
:
"
Quite
so
,
Venus
.
"
  
<EOS>
By
this
time
the
astonishment
was
all
on
the
other
side
.
<EOS>
It
did
not
,
however
,
so
continue
.
<EOS>
For
,
when
Venus
passed
to
Wegg
's
discovery
,
and
from
that
to
their
having
both
seen
Mr.
Boffin
dig
up
the
Dutch
bottle
,
that
gentleman
changed
colour
,
changed
his
attitude
,
became
extremely
restless
,
and
ended
(
when
Venus
ended
)
by
being
in
a
state
of
manifest
anxiety
,
trepidation
,
and
confusion
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
said
Venus
,
finishing
off
;
"
you
best
know
what
was
in
that
Dutch
bottle
,
and
why
you
dug
it
up
,
and
took
it
away
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
pretend
to
know
anything
more
about
it
than
I
saw
.
<EOS>
All
I
know
is
this
:
I
am
proud
of
my
calling
after
all
(
though
it
has
been
attended
by
one
dreadful
drawback
which
has
told
upon
my
heart
,
and
almost
equally
upon
my
skeleton
)
,
and
I
mean
to
live
by
my
calling
.
<EOS>
Putting
the
same
meaning
into
other
words
,
I
do
not
mean
to
turn
a
single
dishonest
penny
by
this
affair
.
<EOS>
As
the
best
amends
I
can
make
you
for
having
ever
gone
into
it
,
I
make
known
to
you
,
<EOS>
as
a
warning
,
what
Wegg
has
found
out
.
<EOS>
My
opinion
is
,
that
Wegg
is
not
to
be
silenced
at
a
modest
price
,
and
I
build
that
opinion
on
his
beginning
to
dispose
of
your
property
the
moment
he
knew
his
power
.
<EOS>
Whether
it
's
worth
your
while
to
silence
him
at
any
price
,
you
will
decide
for
yourself
,
and
take
your
measures
accordingly
.
<EOS>
As
far
as
I
am
concerned
,
I
have
no
price
.
<EOS>
If
I
am
ever
called
upon
for
the
truth
,
I
tell
it
,
but
I
want
to
do
no
more
than
I
have
now
done
and
ended
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Venus
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
a
hearty

;
"
thank'ee
,
Venus
,
thank'ee
,
Venus
!
"
<EOS>
And
then

.
<EOS>
"
But

,

,
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Possibly

of
Mr.

Wegg
was

,
for

hit

.
  
<EOS>
He
was

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,
for
again

behind

and

,
and
again

.
<EOS>
Then

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

's

,

.

"

,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

;

---

---

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

.
<EOS>

and
delicacy
of
the
matter
so
much
that
I
would
rather
avoid
speaking
to
you
at
your
own
home
.
<EOS>
You
must
think
this
very
strange
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
said
no
,
but
meant
yes
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
because
I
am
so
grateful
for
the
good
opinion
of
all
my
friends
,
and
am
so
touched
by
it
,
that
I
can
not
bear
to
run
the
risk
of
forfeiting
it
in
any
case
,
even
in
the
cause
of
duty
.
<EOS>
I
have
asked
my
husband
(
my
dear
Alfred
,
Mr.
Boffin
)
whether
it
is
the
cause
of
duty
,
and
he
has
most
emphatically
said
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
had
asked
him
sooner
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
spared
me
much
distress
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
"
Can
this
be
more
dropping
down
upon
me
!
"
thought
Mr.
Boffin
,
quite
bewildered
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
Alfred
who
sent
me
to
you
,
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
Alfred
said
,
`
`
Do
n't
come
back
,
Sophronia
,
until
you
have
seen
Mr.
Boffin
,
and
told
him
all
.
<EOS>
Whatever
he
may
think
of
it
,
he
ought
certainly
to
know
it
.
"
<EOS>
"
Would
you
mind
coming
into
the
carriage
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
answered
,
"
Not
at
all
,
"
and
took
his
seat
at
Mrs.
Lammle
's
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
Drive
slowly
anywhere
,
"
Mrs.
Lammle
called
to
her
coachman
,
"
and
do
n't
let
the
carriage
rattle
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
must
be
more
dropping
down
,
I
think
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
to
himself
.
<EOS>
"
What
next
?
"
   
<EOS>
THE
GOLDEN
DUSTMAN
<EOS>
AT
<EOS>
HIS
WORST
.
 
<EOS>
The
breakfast
table
at
Mr.
Boffin
's
was
usually
a
very
pleasant
one
,
and
was
always
presided
over
by
Bella
.
<EOS>
As
though
he
began
each
new
day
in
his
healthy
natural
character
,
and
some
waking
hours
were
necessary
to
his
relapse
into
the
corrupting
influences
of
his
wealth
,
the
face
and
the
demeanour
of
the
Golden
Dustman
were
generally
unclouded
at
that
meal
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
easy
to
believe
then
,
that
there
was
no
change
in
him
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
the
day
went
on
that
the
clouds
gathered
,
and
the
brightness
of
the
morning
became
obscured
.
<EOS>
One
might
have
said
that
the
shadows
of
avarice
and
distrust
lengthened
as
his
own
shadow
lengthened
,
and
that
the
night
closed
around
him
gradually
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
one
morning
long
afterwards
to
be
remembered
,
it
was
black
midnight
with
the
Golden
Dustman
when
he
first
appeared
.
<EOS>
His
altered
character
had
never
been
so
grossly
marked
.
<EOS>
His
bearing
towards
his
Secretary
was
so
charged
with
insolent
distrust
and
arrogance
,
that
the
latter
rose
and
left
the
table
before
breakfast
was
half
done
.
<EOS>
The
look
he
directed
at
the
Secretary
's
retiring
figure
was
so
cunningly
malignant
,
that
Bella
would
have
sat
astounded
and
indignant
,
even
though
he
had
not
gone
the
length
of
secretly
threatening
Rokesmith
with
his
clenched
fist
as
he
closed
the
door
.
<EOS>
This
unlucky
morning
,
of
all
mornings
in
the
year
,
was
the
morning
next
after
Mr.
Boffin
's
interview
with
Mrs.
Lammle
in
her
little
carriage
.
  
<EOS>
Bella
looked
to
Mrs.
Boffin
's
face
for
comment
on
,
or
explanation
of
,
this
stormy
humour
in
her
husband
,
but
none
was
there
.
<EOS>
An
anxious
and
a
distressed
observation
of
her
own
face
was
all
she
could
read
in
it
.
<EOS>
When
they
were
left
alone
together
---
which
was
not
until
noon
,
for
Mr.
Boffin
sat
long
in
his
easy
-
chair
,
by
turns
jogging
up
and
down
the
breakfast
-
room
,
clenching
his
fist
and
muttering
---
Bella
,
in
consternation
,
asked
her
what
had
happened
,
what
was
wrong
?
<EOS>
"
I
am
forbidden
to
speak
to
you
about
it
,
Bella
dear
;
 
I
must
n't
tell
you
,
"
was
all
the
answer
she
could
get
.
<EOS>
And
still
,
whenever
,
in
her
wonder
and
dismay
,
she
raised
her
eyes
to
Mrs.
Boffin
's
face
,
she
saw
in
it
the
same
anxious
and
distressed
observation
of
her
own
.
  
<EOS>
Oppressed
by
her
sense
that
trouble
was
impending
,
and
lost
in
speculations
why
Mrs.
Boffin
should
look
at
her
as
if
she
had
any
part
in
it
,
Bella
found
the
day
long
and
dreary
.
<EOS>
It
was
far
on
in
the
afternoon
when
,
she
being
in
her
own
room
,
a
servant
brought
her
a
message
from
Mr.
Boffin
begging
her
to
come
to
his
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
was
there
,
seated
on
a
sofa
,
and
Mr.
Boffin
was
jogging
up
and
down
.
<EOS>
On
seeing
Bella
he
stopped
,
beckoned
her
to
him
,
and
drew
her
arm
through
his
.
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
my
dear
,
"
he
said
,
gently
;
"
I
am
not
angry
with
you
.
<EOS>
Why
you
actually
tremble
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
Bella
my
dear
.
<EOS>
I
'll
see
you
righted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
See
me
righted
?
"
thought
Bella
.
<EOS>
And
then
repeated
aloud
in
a
tone
of
astonishment
:
<EOS>
"
see
me
righted
,
sir
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
See
you
righted
.
<EOS>
Send
Mr.
Rokesmith
here
,
you
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
would
have
been
lost
in
perplexity
if
there
had
been
pause
enough
;
but
the
servant
found
Mr.
Rokesmith
near
at
hand
,
and
he
almost
immediately
presented
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Shut
the
door
,
sir
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
got
something
to
say
to
you
which
I
fancy
<EOS>
you
'll
not
be
pleased
to
hear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
reply
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
returned
the
Secretary
,
as
,
having
closed
the
door
,
he
turned
and
faced
him
,
"
that
I
think
that
very
likely
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
mean
?
"
blustered
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
that
it
has
become
no
novelty
to
me
to
hear
from
your
lips
what
I
would
rather
not
hear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Perhaps
we
shall
change
that
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
with
a
threatening
roll
of
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
so
,
"
returned
the
Secretary
.
<EOS>
He
was
quiet
and
respectful
;
 
but
stood
,
as
Bella
thought
(
and
was
glad
to
think
)
,
on
his
manhood
too
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
<EOS>
look
at
this
young
lady
on
my
arm
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
involuntarily
raising
her
eyes
,
when
this
sudden
reference
was
made
to
herself
,
met
those
of
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
He
was
pale
and
seemed
agitated
.
<EOS>
Then
her
eyes
passed
on
to
Mrs.
Boffin
's
,
and
she
met
the
look
again
.
<EOS>
In
a
flash
it
enlightened
her
,
and
she
began
to
understand
what
she
had
done
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
to
you
,
sir
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
repeated
,
"
<EOS>
look
at
this
young
lady
on
my
arm
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
so
,
"
returned
the
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
As
his
glance
rested
again
on
Bella
for
a
moment
,
she
thought
there
was
reproach
in
it
.
<EOS>
But
it
is
possible
that
the
reproach
was
within
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
dare
you
,
sir
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
tamper
,
unknown
to
me
,
with
this
young
lady
?
<EOS>
How
dare
you
come
out
of
your
station
,
and
your
place
in
my
house
,
to
pester
this
young
lady
with
your
impudent
addresses
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
decline
to
answer
questions
,
"
said
the
Secretary
,
"
that
are
so
offensively
asked
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
decline
to
answer
?
"
retorted
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
You
decline
to
answer
,
do
you
?
<EOS>
Then
I
'll
tell
you
what
it
is
,
Rokesmith
;
I
'll
answer
for
you
.
<EOS>
There
are
two
sides
to
this
matter
,
and
I
'll
take
'em
separately
.
<EOS>
The
first
side
is
,
sheer
Insolence
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
first
side
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
Secretary
smiled
with
some
bitterness
,
as
though
he
would
have
said
,
"
So
I
see
and
hear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
sheer
Insolence
in
you
,
I
tell
you
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
even
to
think
of
this
young
lady
.
<EOS>
This
young
lady
was
far
above
you
.
<EOS>
This
young
lady
was
no
match
for
you
.
<EOS>
This
young
lady
was
lying
in
wait
(
as
she
was
qualified
to
do
)
for
money
,
and
you
had
no
money
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
hung
her
head
and
seemed
to
shrink
a
little
from
Mr.
Boffin
's
protecting
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
,
I
should
like
to
know
,
"
pursued
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
that
you
were
to
have
the
audacity
to
follow
up
this
young
lady
?
<EOS>
This
young
lady
was
looking
about
the
market
for
a
good
bid
;
she
was
n't
in
it
to
be
snapped
up
by
fellows
that
had
no
money
to
lay
out
;
nothing
to
buy
with
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Mr.
Boffin
!
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
,
pray
say
something
for
me
!
"
<EOS>
murmured
Bella
,
disengaging
her
arm
,
and
covering
her
face
with
her
hands
.
  
<EOS>
"
Old
lady
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
anticipating
his
wife
,
"
you
hold
your
tongue
.
<EOS>
Bella
,
my
dear
,
do
n't
you
let
yourself
be
put
out
.
<EOS>
I
'll
right
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
do
n't
,
you
do
n't
right
me
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Bella
,
with
great
emphasis
.
<EOS>
"
You
wrong
me
,
wrong
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
be
put
out
,
my
dear
,
"
complacently
retorted
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
bring
this
young
man
to
book
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
Rokesmith
!
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
decline
to
hear
,
you
know
,
as
well
as
to
answer
.
<EOS>
You
hear
me
tell
you
that
the
first
side
of
your
conduct
was
Insolence
---
Insolence
and
Presumption
.
<EOS>
Answer
me
one
thing
,
if
you
can
.
<EOS>
Did
n't
this
young
lady
tell
you
so
herself
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
?
"
asked
Bella
with
her
face
still
covered
.
<EOS>
"
O
say
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
!
<EOS>
Did
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
distressed
,
Miss
Wilfer
;
it
matters
very
little
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
You
ca
n't
deny
it
,
though
!
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
a
knowing
shake
of
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
asked
him
to
forgive
me
since
,
"
cried
Bella
;
"
and
I
would
ask
him
to
forgive
me
now
again
,
upon
my
knees
,
if
it
would
spare
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Mrs.
Boffin
broke
out
a
-
crying
.
  
<EOS>
"
Old
lady
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
stop
that
noise
!
<EOS>
Tender
-
hearted
in
you
,
Miss
Bella
;
but
I
mean
to
have
it
out
right
through
with
this
young
man
,
having
got
him
into
a
corner
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
I
tell
you
that
's
one
side
of
your
conduct
---
Insolence
and
Presumption
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
'm
a
-
coming
to
the
other
,
which
is
much
worse
.
<EOS>
This
was
a
speculation
of
yours
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
indignantly
deny
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
no
use
your
denying
it
;
it
does
n't
signify
a
bit
whether
you
deny
it
or
not
;
I
've
got
a
head
upon
my
shoulders
,
and
it
ai
n't
a
baby
's
.
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
gathering
himself
together
in
his
most
suspicious
attitude
,
and
wrinkling
his
face
into
a
very
map
of
curves
and
corners
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
n't
I
know
what
grabs
are
made
at
a
man
with
money
?
<EOS>
If
I
did
n't
keep
my
eyes
open
,
and
my
pockets
buttoned
,
should
n't
I
be
brought
to
the
workhouse
before
I
knew
where
I
was
?
<EOS>
Was
n't
the
experience
of
Dancer
,
and
Elwes
,
and
Hopkins
,
and
Blewbury
Jones
,
and
ever
so
many
more
of
'em
,
similar
to
mine
?
<EOS>
Did
n't
everybody
want
to
make
grabs
at
what
they
'd
got
,
and
bring
'em
to
poverty
and
ruin
?
<EOS>
Were
n't
they
forced
to
hide
everything
belonging
to
'em
,
for
fear
it
should
be
snatched
from
'em
?
<EOS>
Of
course
they
was
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
told
next
that
they
did
n't
know
human
natur
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
!
<EOS>
Poor
creatures
,
"
murmured
the
Secretary
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
say
?
"
asked
Mr.
Boffin
,
snapping
at
him
,
"
However
,
you
need
n't
be
at
the
trouble
of
repeating
it
,

"

"

,

.

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ask
me
anything
you
wish
to
ask
,
"
returned
Rokesmith
,
"
but
use
the
expedition
that
you
recommend
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
pretend
to
have
a
mighty
admiration
for
this
young
lady
?
"
 
<EOS>
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
laying
his
hand
protectingly
on
Bella
's
head
without
looking
down
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
pretend
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Well
.
<EOS>
You
have
a
mighty
admiration
for
this
young
lady
 
---
since
you
are
so
particular
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
reconcile
that
,
with
this
young
lady
's
being
a
weak
-
spirited
,
improvident
idiot
,
not
knowing
what
was
due
to
herself
,
flinging
up
her
money
to
the
church
-
weathercocks
,
and
racing
off
at
a
splitting
pace
for
the
workhouse
?
"
  
"
I
do
n't
understand
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
?
<EOS>
Or
wo
n't
you
?
<EOS>
What
else
could
you
have
made
this
young
lady
out
to
be
,
if
she
had
listened
to
such
addresses
as
yours
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
else
,
if
I
had
been
so
happy
as
to
win
her
affections
and
possess
her
heart
?
"
  
"
Win
her
affections
.
<EOS>
"
retorted
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
ineffable
contempt
,
"
and
possess
her
heart
!
<EOS>
Mew
says
the
cat
,
<EOS>
Quack
-
quack
says
the
duck
,
<EOS>
Bow
-
wow
-
wow
says
the
dog
!
<EOS>
Win
her
affections
and
possess
her
heart
!
<EOS>
Mew
,
Quack
-
quack
,
Bow
-
wow
!
"
  
<EOS>
John
Rokesmith
started
at
him
in
his

,
as
if
with
some

idea
that
he
had
gone

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
due
to
this
young

,
"
said

Boffin
,
"
is
Money
,
and
this
young
lady
<EOS>
right

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
slander

young

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
slander
the
young
lady
;
you
with
your
affections
and
hearts

,
"
returned
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
of

.
<EOS>
I
heard
of

of

only

,
or

heard

from

,
sooner
,

.
<EOS>
I

,

young

,

,

Money
<EOS>
she

---
money
,

,
money
---

that

Lie
,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"

,

,
"
for
your
delicate

kindness
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
Miss
Wilfer
,

!
"
  
"
<EOS>
And

,
my

,
"
said

,

's

,
"
you
may
begin

make

,
and
I

've

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
Bella
was
so
far

,
that
she
shrank
from

hand

from

,
and
,

,
and

,
cried
,
"
O
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
before
you
go
,
if
you
could
but
make
me
poor
again
!
<EOS>
O
!
<EOS>
Make
me
poor
again
,
Somebody
,
I
beg
and
pray
,
or
my
heart
will
break
if
this
goes
on
!
<EOS>
Pa
,
dear
,
make
me
poor
again
and
take
me
home
!
<EOS>
I
was
bad
enough
there
,
but
I
have
been
so
much

here
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
give
me
money
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
I
wo
n't
have
money
.
<EOS>
Keep
it
away
from
me
,
and
only
let
me
speak
to
good
little
Pa
,
and
lay
my

upon

,
and
tell
him
all
my
griefs
.
<EOS>
NObody
else
can
understand
me
,
nobody
else

comfort
me
,
nobody
else
knows
how
unworthy
I
am
,
and
yet
can
love
me
like
a
little
child
.
<EOS>
I
am
better
with
Pa
than
any
one
---
more
innocent
,
more
sorry
,
more
glad
!
"
<EOS>
So
,

out
in
a
wild

that
she
could
not

,
Bella
drooped
her

on
Mrs.
Boffin
's
ready

.
  
<EOS>
John
Rokesmith
from
his
place
in
the
room
,
and
Mr.
Boffin
from

,
looked
on

her
in

until
she
was

herself
.
<EOS>
Then
Mr.
Boffin
observed
in
a

,
"
There
,
my
dear
,
there
;
you
are
righted

,
and
it
's

.
<EOS>
I
do

wonder
<EOS>
,
I

,
at

by

,
but
it
's
all

,
my

,

're

,

's
---
<EOS>
and
it
's
all
right
!
"
<EOS>
Which

Boffin
repeated
with
a

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hate
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Bella
,
turning

upon
him
,
with
a
stamp

her
little
foot
---
<EOS>
"
at
least
,
I
ca
n't
hate
you
,
but
I
do
n't
like
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hul
---
lo
!
"
exclaimed
Mr.
Boffin
in

under
-
tone
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
a
scolding
,
unjust
,
abusive
,
aggravating
,
bad
old
creature
!
"
 
cried
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
angry
with
my
ungrateful
self
for
calling
you
names
;
but
you
are
,
you
are
;
you
know
you
are
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
stared
here
,
and
stared
there
,
as
misdoubting
that
he
must
be
in
some
sort
of
fit
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
you
with
shame
,
"
said
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
With
shame
for
myself
,
and
with
shame
for
you
.
<EOS>
You
ought
to
be
above
the
base
talebearing
of
a
time
-
serving
woman
;
but
you
are
above
nothing
now
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,
seeming
to
become
convinced
that
this
was
a
fit
,
rolled
his
eyes
and
loosened
his
neckcloth
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
came
here
,
I
respected
you
and

you
,
and
I
soon
loved
you
,
"
cried

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
now
I
ca
n't
bear
the
sight

you
.
<EOS>
At
least
,
I
do
n't
know
that
I
ought
to
go
so
far
as
that
<EOS>
---
only
you
're
a
---
you
're
a
Monster
!
"
<EOS>
Having
shot
this
bolt
out
with
a
great
expenditure
of
force
,
Bella
hysterically
laughed
and
cried
together
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
best
wish
I
can
wish
you
is
,
"
said
Bella
,
returning
to
the
charge
,
"
that
you
had
not
one
single
farthing
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
If
any
true
friend
and
well
-
wisher
could
make
you
a
bankrupt
,
you
would
be
a
Duck
;
but
as
a
man
of
property
you
are
a
Demon
!
"
  
<EOS>
After
despatching
this
second
bolt
with
a
still
greater
expenditure
of
force
,
Bella
laughed
and
cried
still
more
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
pray
stay
one
moment
.
<EOS>
Pray
hear
one
word
from
me
before
you
go
!
<EOS>
I
am
deeply
sorry
for
the

you
have
borne

.
<EOS>
Out
of
the
depths
of
my
heart
I
earnestly
and
truly
beg
your
pardon
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
she
stepped
towards
him
,
he
met
her
.
<EOS>
As
she
gave
him
her
hand
,
he
put
it
to
his
lips
,
and
said
,
"
God
bless
you
!
"
<EOS>
No
laughing
was
mixed
with
Bella
's
crying
then
;
her
tears
were
pure
and
fervent
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
not
an
ungenerous
word
that
I
have
heard

you
---
heard
with
scorn
and
indignation
,
Mr.
Rokesmith
---
but
it
has
wounded
me
far
more
than
you
,
for
I
have
deserved
it
,
and
you
never
have
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
it
is
to
me
you
owe
this
perverted

of
what
passed
between

that
night
.
<EOS>
I
parted
with
the
secret
,
even
while
I
was

for

.
<EOS>
It

,
but

.
<EOS>
I
did

in

and
folly
 
---
one
of
my
many
such

---
one

my
many
such

---
years
.
<EOS>
As
I
am

for
it
severely
,
try
to
forgive

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
.
<EOS>
O

!
<EOS>
Do

part
from
me
till
I
have
said
one
other

,
to
do

justice
.
<EOS>
The
only
fault
you
can
be
truly
charged

,
in
having
spoken

me

you

---
with
how

and
<EOS>
how
much
forbearance
<EOS>
no
one
<EOS>
but
I

know

for
---
<EOS>
is
,
that
you
laid

a

girl
whose
head
was
turned
,
and
who
was
quite

rise

worth
of

you
offered
her
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
that
girl
has
often

in
a

since
,
but
never
in

,

in

---
sordid

girl
that

---
has
been
echoed
in

by
Mr.
Boffin
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
kissed
her
hand
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Boffin
's
speeches
were
detestable
to
me
,
shocking
to

,
"
said

,
startling
that
gentleman
with

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
quite
true
that
there

,

,

I

so
`
`
righted
,
"
"
Mr.
Rokesmith
;
but
I
hope
that
I
shall
never

!
"
  
<EOS>
He
once

put
her

to

,
and

,

left

room
.
<EOS>
Bella
was
hurrying
back
to
the
chair
in
which
she
had
hidden
her
face
<EOS>
so
long
,
when
,
catching
sight

Mrs.
Boffin
by

,
she
stopped
at

.
"
<EOS>
He
is
gone
,
"
sobbed
Bella
indignantly
,
despairingly
,
in
fifty
ways
at
once
,
with
her
arms
round
Mrs.
Boffin
's
neck
.
<EOS>
"
He
has
been
most
shamefully
abused
,
and
most
unjustly
and
most
basely
driven
away
,
and
I
am
the
cause
of
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
Mr.
Boffin
had
been
rolling
his
eyes
over
his
loosened
neckerchief
,
as
if
his
fit
were
still
upon
him
.
<EOS>
Appearing
now
to
thing
that
he
was
coming
to
,
he
stared
straight
before
him
for
a
while
,
tied
his
neckerchief
again
,
took
several
long

,
swallowed
several
times
,
and
ultimately
exclaimed
with
a
deep

,
as
if
he
felt
himself
on

better
:
"
Well
!
"
  
<EOS>
No
word
,
good
or
bad
,
did
Mrs.
Boffin
say
;
but
she
tenderly
took
care
of
Bella
,
and
glanced
at
her
husband
as
if
for
orders
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,
without
imparting
any
,
took
his
seat
on
a
chair
over
against
them
,
and
there
sat
leaning
forward
,
with
a
fixed
countenance
,
his
legs
apart
,
a
hand
on
each
knee
,
and
his
elbows
squared
,
until
Bella
should
dry
her
eyes
and
raise
her
head
,
which
in
the
fulness
of
time
she
did
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
go
home
,
"
said
Bella
,
rising
hurriedly
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
very
grateful
to
you
for
all
you
have
done
for
me
,
but
I
ca
n't
stay
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
My
darling
girl
!
"
remonstrated
Mrs.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
ca
n't
stay
here
,
"
said
Bella
;
"
I
ca
n't
indeed
.
<EOS>
---
Ugh
!
<EOS>
you
vicious
old
thing
!
"
<EOS>
(
This
to
Mr.
Boffin
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
rash
,
my
love
,
"
urged
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
Think
well
of
what
you
do
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
had
better
think
well
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
more
think
well
of
you
,
"
cried
Bella
,
cutting
him
short
,
with
intense
defiance
in
her
expressive
little
eyebrows
,
and
championship
of
the
late
Secretary
in
every
dimple
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
Never
again
!
<EOS>
Your
money
has
changed
you
to
marble
.
<EOS>
You
are
a
hard
-
hearted
Miser
.
<EOS>
You
are
worse
than
Dancer
,
worse
than
Hopkins
,
worse
than
Blackberry
Jones
,
worse
than
any
of
the
wretches
.
<EOS>
And
more
!
"
 
<EOS>
proceeded
Bella
,
breaking
into
tears
again
<EOS>
,
"
you
were
wholly
undeserving
of
the
Gentleman
you
have
lost
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
you
do
n't
mean
to
say
,
Miss
Bella
,
"
the
Golden
Dustman
slowly
remonstrated
,
"
that
you
set
up
Rokesmith
against
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
!
"
said
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
He
is
worth
a
Million
of
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Very
pretty
she
looked
,
though
very
angry
,
as
she
made
herself
as
tall
as
she
possibly
could
<EOS>
(
which
was
not
extremely
tall
)
,
and
utterly
renounced
her
patron
with
a

of
her
rich
brown

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
he
thought
well
of
me
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
though
he
swept
the
street
for
bread
,
than
that
you
did
,
though
you
splashed
the
mud
upon
him
from
the

of
a

of
pure
gold
.
<EOS>
---
There
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
I
'm
sure
!
<EOS>
"
cried
Mr.
Boffin
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

past
,

you
have
thought
you
set

,
I

,
"
said

---
"
<EOS>
There
!
<EOS>
And
throughout
I

,
and
I
saw

you
the
man
 
<EOS>
---
There
!
<EOS>
And
when
you
used

shamefully
,
I

and
loved
him
---
There
!
<EOS>
I
boast
of

!
"
  
<EOS>
After
which
strong
avowal
Bella
underwent
reaction
,
and
cried
to
any

,
with
her

on

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"

Boffin
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Give

,
Bella
.
<EOS>
I

not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
!
"
said
Bella
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
resumed
the
Golden

,
"
I
am
not

,
and
I
mean

to

,

.
<EOS>
So

'll

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
ca
n't

,
"

,

;
"
I
ca
n't
think
of

here
.
<EOS>
I
must

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
do

,
"
Mr.
Boffin

.
<EOS>
"
Do
n't

what
you
ca
n't

;
do

what
you
're
sure
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

never

,
"

;
"
<EOS>

,

every

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Look

.
<EOS>

,

's

,

as

.
<EOS>
Go

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

that
I
can
never

,

,
"
 
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

"
that
I
'm
a
-

,

,

.
<EOS>
No
,

!
<EOS>
Be

!
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Expect
!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
Do

think
that
any

,

did
,

?
"
  
<EOS>
But
there
was
Mrs.
Boffin
to

and
,

,

.
<EOS>
Down

,

,
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

a
dear
,

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
You
're
the
best
of
human

.
<EOS>
I
can
never

thankful
enough
to
you
,
and
can
never

.
<EOS>
If

see

,
in

,

the
last

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Boffin
wept
most

,
and

her
with
all

;
 
but
said
not

except

was
her

.
<EOS>
She

often

,
to

,
for

;
but

.
  
<EOS>
Bella
broke
from

,

,
when
in

affectionate

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Say

"
  
<EOS>

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-

,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
as

.
  
<EOS>
Bella
caught
him
round

and
kissed

,
and
ran
out
for

.
  
<EOS>
She
ran
up

stairs
,
and
sat

the
floor
in
her
own

,
and
cried
abundantly
.
<EOS>
But
the
day
was
declining
and
she
had
no
time
to

.
<EOS>
She
opened
all
the
places
where
she
kept

;
 
selected

she

with

,

rest
;
 
and
made

bundle

,
to

afterwards
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo
n't
take

,
"
said
Bella
,
tying

of
the
bundle
very

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll

,

.
"
 
That

,

she

,
for
that

.
<EOS>
Even

bonnet

put
on
,
was
the
bonnet
that
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It
's

,

I
have
steeped

in

,
and
I
wo
n't
ery

.
<EOS>
You
have

pleasant

to

,
dear

.
<EOS>
Adieu
!
<EOS>
We

never

.
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

,
and
went

,

,
that

.
<EOS>
No

to

about
,
and

.
<EOS>
The

of

late

's

.
<EOS>
She

in

,
and
divined

,

things
,
that

.
<EOS>
Softly

,

,

turned

on
the

---
insensible
old

wood
and
iron
that
it
was
!
<EOS>
---
before
she
ran

from

house
at

swift

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
was
well
done
!
"
<EOS>
panted
Bella
,
slackening
in

next

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
left
myself
any

,
I

have

.
<EOS>
Now
poor
dear
darling
little
Pa
,
you
are
going
to
see
your
lovely
woman
unexpectedly
.
"
   
<EOS>
THE
FEAST
OF
THE
THREE
HOBGOBLINS
.
 
<EOS>
The
city
looked
unpromising
enough
,
as
Bella
made
her
way
along
its
gritty
streets
.
<EOS>
Most
of
its
money
-
mills
were
slackening
sail
,
or
had
left
off
grinding
for
the
day
.
<EOS>
The
master
-
millers
had
already
departed
,
and
the
journeymen
were
departing
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
jaded
aspect
on
the
business
lanes
and
courts
,
and
the
very
pavements
had
a
weary
appearance
,
confused
by
the
tread
of
a
million
of
feet
.
<EOS>
There
must
be
hours
of
night
to
temper
down
the
day
's
distraction
of
so
feverish
a
place
.
<EOS>
As
yet
the
worry
of
the
newly
-
stopped
whirling
and
grinding
on
the
part
of
the
money
-
mills
seemed
to
linger
in
the
air
,
and
the
quiet
was
more
like
the
prostration
of
a
spent
giant
than
the
repose
of
one
who
was
renewing
his
strength
.
  
<EOS>
If
Bella
thought
,
as
she
glanced
at
the
mighty
Bank
,
how
agreeable
it
would
be
to
have
an
hour
's
gardening
there
,
with
a
bright
copper

,
<EOS>
among
the
money
,
still
she
was
not
in
an
avaricious
vein
.
<EOS>
Much
improved
in
that
respect
,
and
with
certain
half
-
formed
images
which
had
little
gold
in
their
composition
,
dancing
before
her
bright

,

in
the
drug
-
flavoured
region
of
Mincing
Lane
,
with
;
the
sensation
of
having
just
opened
a
drawer
in
a

's
shop
.
  
<EOS>
The
counting
-
house
of
Chicksey
,
Veneering
,
and
Stobbles
was
pointed
out
by
an
elderly
female
accustomed
to
the
care
of
offices
,
who
dropped
upon
Bella
out
of
a
public
-
house
,
wiping
her
mouth
,
and
accounted
for
its
humidity
on
natural
principles
well
known
to
the
physical
sciences
,
by
explaining
that
she
had
looked
in
at
the
door
to
see
what
o'clock

was
.
<EOS>
The
counting
-
house
was
a
walleyed
ground
floor
by
a
dark
gateway
,
and
Bella
was
considering
,
as
she
approached

,
could
there
be
any
precedent
in
the
City
for
her

in
and

R.
Wilfer
,
when

should

see
,

one

the
plate
-
glass

,
but
R.
Wilfer
himself
,
preparing
to
take
a
slight

!
  
<EOS>
On
approaching
nearer
,
Bella
discerned
that
the
refection
had
the
appearance
of
a
small
cottage
-
loaf
and
a
pennyworth
of
milk
.
<EOS>
Simultaneously
with
this
discovery
on
her
part
,
her
father
discovered
her
,
and
invoked
the
echoes
of
Mincing
Lane
to
exclaim
"
My
gracious
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
then
came
cherubically
flying
out
without
a
hat
,
and
embraced
her
,
and
handed
her
in
.
<EOS>
"
For
it
's
after
hours
<EOS>
and
I
am
all
alone
,
my
dear
,
"
he
explained
,
"
and
am
having
---
as
I
sometimes
do
when
they
are
all
gone
---
a
quiet
tea
.
"
  
<EOS>
Looking
round
the
office
,
as

her

were
a
captive
and
this
his
cell
,
Bella
hugged
him
and
choked

to
her
heart
's
content
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
was
so
surprised
,
my
dear
!
"
said
her
father
.
<EOS>
"
I
could
n't
believe

.
<EOS>
Upon
my
life
,
I
thought
they
had
taken
to
lying
!
<EOS>
The
idea

your
coming

Lane
yourself
!
<EOS>
Why
did
n't
you
send
the
footman
down
the
Lane
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
brought
no
footman
with

,
<EOS>
Pa.
"
  
"
Oh

!
<EOS>
But
you
have

the
elegant
turn
-
out
,
my
love
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
,
Pa.
<EOS>
"
  
"
You
never
can
have
walked
,
my
dear
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
have
,
<EOS>
Pa.
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
so
very
much
astonished
,
that
Bella
could
not
make

to
break
it

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
consequence

.
<EOS>
Pa
,
that
your
lovely
woman
feels
a
little
faint
,
and
would
very
much
like
to
share
your
tea
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
cottage
loaf
and
the
pennyworth
of
milk
had
been
set
forth
on
a
sheet
of
paper
on
the
window
-

.
<EOS>
The
cherubic
pocket
-

,
with

of

loaf

,

where

.
<EOS>
Bella
took
the
bit
off
,
and
put
it
in
her
mouth
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
dear
child
,
"
said
her
father
,
"
the
idea
of
your

such
lowly
fare
!
<EOS>
But

must

.
<EOS>
One

,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
The
Dairy
is
just
over

and
round

corner
.
"
  
<EOS>
Regardless

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My

,
"

the

---
!
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"
---

!

---

<EOS>

,

for

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
Lor

?

<EOS>
To

,

<EOS>
"

My

This

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

.
<EOS>
"
My

<EOS>
You

?

!

<EOS>

Pa.

.
<EOS>
Is

---

?

There

"

John

.

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,
"
a

,

?
<EOS>
Am
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Upon

,
"
pursued

,
"
the
certain

young
person
distantly
related

myself
,
having
previously
observed

mentioned

that

Boffin
,

,

,

<EOS>
"

.

"
And

---

,
"

"

distantly
related

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Have

?
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
's

round

neck

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

distantly

,
"
said

,
"
did
well
!
<EOS>
The

young
person
distantly
related
to
myself
,
did
not
trust

me

!
<EOS>
I
admire
this
mercenary
young
person
distantly
related
to
myself
,
more
in
this
dress
than
if

had
come
to

in

silks
,
Cashmere
shawls
,
and
Golconda
diamonds
.
<EOS>
I
love
this
young
person
dearly
.
<EOS>
I
say
to
the
man
of
this
young
person
's
heart
,
out
of
my
heart
and
with
all
of
it
,
`
`
My
blessing
on
this
engagement
betwixt
you
,
and
she

when
she
brings

the
poverty
she
has
accepted
for
your

and
the

's
!
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
The

's

gave
John
Rokesmith
his

,

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

.
<EOS>
He

,

:
  
"
<EOS>

,

,
that

all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
,
as
Bella

,
like
the

,

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

"

,
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

Hem

---

"
  
"

<EOS>
Pa.

?

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Well
!
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If

<EOS>

,
<EOS>

<EOS>
laying

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
---

!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Mr.

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

George

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

Ma

.

<EOS>
Bella

,

's

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
And

(
as

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
Ma

,
"
said

in

,
"
the
salad
's
ready
,
and
it
's
past
supper
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer

,
but

.
"
<EOS>
George
!
<EOS>
"
said
Miss
Lavinia
in
her

,
"
Ma
's
chair
!
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Sampson
flew
to

lady
's
back
,
and

up

,
chair

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

with

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

not

<EOS>
an

,

,
as
"
Mutton

,

;
"

Ma

.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.

's

;
in

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
A
magnetic
result
of
such

was
,
that

person

at
could
not
by
any

successfully

to

:
so

.
  
<EOS>
Miss

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

"

Pa.

!

Pa
,
the
lovely
woman
means
to
look
forward
to
this
fortune
that
has
been
told
for
her
,
so
delightfully
,
and
to
cause
it
to
make
her
a
much
better
lovely
woman
than
she
ever
has
been
yet
.
<EOS>
What
the
little
fair
man
is
expected
to
do
,
sir
,
is
to
look
forward
to
it
also
,
by
saying
to
himself
when
he
is
in
danger
of
being
over
-
worried
,
`
`
I
see
land
at
last
!
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
"
I
see
land
at
last
!
"
<EOS>
repeated
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
a
dear
Knave
of
Wilfers
!
"
<EOS>
exclaimed
Bella
;
then
putting
out
her
small
white
bare
foot
.
<EOS>
"
That
's
the
mark
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Come
to
the
mark
.
<EOS>
Put
your
boot
against
it
.
<EOS>
We
keep
to
it
together
,
mind
!
<EOS>
Now
,
sir
,
you
may
kiss
the
lovely
woman
before
she
runs
away
,
so
thankful
and
so
happy
.
<EOS>
O
yes
,
fair
little
man
,
so
thankful
and
so
happy
!
"
   
<EOS>
A
SOCIAL
CHORUS
.
 
<EOS>
Amazement
sits
enthroned
upon
the
countenances
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Alfred
Lammle
's
circle
of
acquaintance
,
when
the
disposal
of
their
first
-
class
furniture
and
effects
(
including
a
Billiard
Table
in
capital
letters
)
,
"
by
auction
,
under
a
bill
of
sale
,
"
is
publicly
announced
on
a
waving
hearthrug
in
Sackville
Street
.
<EOS>
But
,
nobody
is
half
so
much
amazed
as
Hamilton
Veneering
,
Esquire
,
M.P.
for
Pocket
Breaches
,
who
instantly
begins
to
find
out
that
the
Lammles
are
the
only
people
ever
entered
on
his
soul
's
register
,
who
are
not
the
oldest
and
dearest
friends
he
has
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
,
W.
M.
P.
for
Pocket
.
<EOS>
Breaches
,
like
a
faithful
wife
shares
her
husband
's
discovery
and
inexpressible
astonishment
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
Veneerings
twain
may
deem
the
last
unutterable
feeling
particularly
due
to
their
reputation
,
by
reason
that
once
upon
a
time
some
of
the
longer
heads
in
the
City
are
whispered
to
have
shaken
themselves
,
when
Veneering
's
extensive
dealings
and
great
wealth
were
mentioned
.
<EOS>
But
,
it
is
certain
that
neither
Mr.
nor
Mrs.
Veneering
can
find
words
to
wonder
in
,
and
it
becomes
necessary
that
they
give
to
the
oldest
and
dearest
friends
they
have
in
the
world
,
a
wondering
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
For
,
it
is
by
this
time
<EOS>
noticeable
that
,
whatever
befals
,
the
Veneerings
must
give
a
dinner
upon
it
.
<EOS>
Lady
Tippins
lives
in
a
chronic
state
of
invitation
to
dine
with
the
Veneerings
,
and
in
a
chronic
state
of
inflammation
arising
from
the
dinners
.
<EOS>
Boots
and
Brewer
go
about
in
cabs
,
with
no
other
intelligible
business
on
earth
than
to
beat
up
people
to
come
and
dine
with
the
Veneerings
.
<EOS>
Veneering
pervades
the
legislative
lobbies
,
intent
upon
entrapping
his
fellow
-
legislators
to
dinner
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
dined
with
five
-
and
-
twenty
bran
-
new
faces
over
night
;
calls
upon
them
all
to
day
;
sends
them
every
one
a
dinner
-
card
to
-
morrow
,
for
the
week
after
next
;
before
that
dinner
is
digested
,
calls
upon
their
brothers
and
sisters
,
their
sons
and
daughters
,
their
nephews
and
nieces
,
their
aunts
and
uncles
and
cousins
,
and
invites
them
all
to
dinner
.
<EOS>
And
still
,
as
at
first
,
howsoever
,
the
dining
circle
widens
,
it
is
to
be
observed
that
all
the
diners
are
consistent
in
appearing
to
go
to
the
Veneerings
,
not
to
dine
with
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
(
which
would
seem
to
be
the
last
thing
in
their
minds
)
,
but
to
dine
with
one
another
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
,
after
all
,
---
who
knows
?
<EOS>
---
Veneering
may
find
this
dining
,
though
expensive
,
remunerative
,
in
the
sense
that
it
makes
champions
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
,
as
a
representative
man
,
is
not
alone
in
caring
very
particularly
for
his
own
dignity
,
if
not
for
that
of
his
acquaintances
,
and
therefore
in
angrily
supporting
the
acquaintances
who
have
taken
out
his
Permit
,
lest
,
in
their
being
lessened
,
he
should
be
.
<EOS>
The
gold
and
silver
camels
,
and
the
ice
-
pails
,
and
the
rest
of
the
Veneering
table
decorations
,
make
a
brilliant
show
,
and
when
I
,
Podsnap
,
casually
remark
elsewhere
<EOS>
that
I
dined
last
Monday
with
a
gorgeous
caravan
of
camels
<EOS>
,
I
find
it
personally
offensive
to
have
it
hinted
to
me
that
they
are
broken
-
kneed
camels
,
or
camels
labouring
under
suspicion
of
any
sort
.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
display
camels
myself
,
I
am
above
them
;
 
I
am
a
more
solid
man
;
but
these
camels
have
basked
in
the
light
of
my
countenance
,
and
how
dare
you
,
sir
,
insinuate
to
me
that
I
have
irradiated
any
but
unimpeachable
camels
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
camels
are
polishing
up
in
the
Analytical
's
pantry
for
the
dinner
of
wonderment
on
the
occasion
of
the
Lammles
going
to
pieces
,
and
Mr.
Twemlow
feels
a

queer
on
the
sofa
at
his

over
the
stable

in
Duke
Street
,
Saint
James
's
,
in

having
taken
two
advertised

at
about

-

,
on
the
faith

the

the
box
(
price
one

a

halfpenny
,

)
,
that
the
same
"
will
be
found
highly
salutary
as

in

of
the
table
.
<EOS>
"
To
whom
,
while
sickly
with
the
fancy
of
an
insoluble
pill
sticking
in

,
and
also

the

of
a

of
warm

languidly
wandering
within
him
a
little
lower
down
,
a
servant
enters
with
the
announcement
that
a
lady
wishes
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
lady
!
<EOS>
"
says
Twemlow
,
pluming

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ask
the
favour
of
the
lady
's
name
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
lady
's
name
is
Lammle
.
<EOS>
The
lady
will
not
detain
Mr.
Twemlow
longer
than
a
very
few
minutes
.
<EOS>
The
lady
is
sure
that
Mr.
Twemlow
will
do
her
the
kindness
to
see
her
,
on
being
told
that
she
particularly
desires

short

.
<EOS>
The
lady
has
no
doubt
whatever
of
Mr.
Twemlow
's
compliance
when
he
hears
her
name
.
<EOS>
Has
begged
the
servant
to
be
particular
not
to
mistake
her
name
.
<EOS>
Would
have
sent
in
a
card
,
but
has
none
.
  
<EOS>
"
Show
the
lady
in
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
shown
in
,
comes
in
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
's
little
rooms
are
modestly
furnished
,
in
an
oldfashioned
manner
(
rather
like
the
housekeeper
's
room
at
Snigsworthy
Park
)
,
and
would
be
bare
of
mere
ornament
,
were
it
not
for
a
full
-
length
engraving
of
the
sublime
Snigsworth
over
the
chimneypiece
,
snorting
at
a
Corinthian
column
,
with
an
enormous
roll
of
paper
at
his
feet
,
and
a
heavy
curtain
going
to
tumble
down
on
his
head
;
those
accessories
being
understood
to
represent
the
noble
lord
as
somehow
in
the
act
of
saving
his
country
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
take
a
seat
,
Mrs.
Lammle
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
takes
a
seat
and
opens
the
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
no
doubt
,
Mr.
Twemlow
,
that
you
have
heard
of
a
reverse
of
fortune
having
befallen
us
.
<EOS>
Of
course
you
have
heard
of
it
,
for
no
kind

news
travels
so
fast
---
among
one
's
friends
especially
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mindful
of
the
wondering
dinner
,
Twemlow
,
with

twinge
,
admits
the
imputation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Probably
it
will
not
,
"
says
Mrs.
Lammle
,

upon

,

,
"
have
surprised

so
much
as
some
others
,
after
what
passed
between

at
the
house
which
is
now
turned

at
windows
.
<EOS>
I
have
taken

liberty
of
calling
upon

,
Mr.
Twemlow
,
to
add
a
sort

postscript
to

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
's
dry
and
hollow
cheeks
become
more
dry
and
hollow
at
the
prospect
of
some
new
complication
.
  
<EOS>
"
Really
,
"
says
the
uneasy

gentleman
,
"
really
,
Mrs.
Lammle
,
I
should
take
it
as
a
favour
if
you
could
excuse
me
from
any

confidence
.
<EOS>
It
has
ever

one

my

---
which
,

,
has
not

many

---
to
be

,
and
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
,
by
far

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
postscript
---
to

the
term
I
have
used
"
---
says
Mrs.
Lammle
,

,

what

---
  
"
coincides
exactly
with
what
you
say
,
Mr.
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
So
far

you
with
any

,
I

to

the

.
<EOS>
So
far

asking

for

,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
going
on
to
reply
,
she

her

again
,
knowing
her
ears
to
be
quite
enough
for
the
contents
of
so
weak
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
,
I
suppose
,
"
says
Twemlow
,
nervously
,
"
offer

to

anything
that

do

the

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,
<EOS>
I
<EOS>
---
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"

Lammle
,

again
,
and
quite

with

,
"
I

a

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Which
I

,
"
says
Twemlow
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
for

which
,
I
thank

;
though
,

,
I
scarcely

why
I
turned
traitress

in

,
for
the
girl
is

.
<EOS>
I
was
a
poor
little
fool
once
myself
;
I
can

no
better
reason
.
<EOS>
"
Seeing

effect
she

by

,

keeps

upon

as

.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Twemlow
,
if
you
should
chance
to
see
my
husband
,
or
to
see

,
or
to
see
both

us
,
in
the
favour

confidence
of
any
one
else
---
whether
of

or

,
is

no

---

right
to
use
against
us
the
knowledge
I
intrusted
you
with
,
for
one
special
purpose
which
has
been
accomplished
.
<EOS>
This
is
what
I
came
to
say
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
a
stipulation
;
to
a
gentleman
it
is
simply
a
reminder
.
"
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
sits
murmuring
to
himself
with
his
hand
to

forehead
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
so
plain
a
case
,
"
Mrs.
Lammle
goes
on
,
"
as
between
me
(
from
the
first
relying
on

)
and
you
,
that
I
will
not
waste
another
word
upon

.
"
<EOS>
She
looks
steadily
at
Mr.
Twemlow
,
until
,
with

shrug
,
he
makes
her
a
little
one
-
sided
bow
,
as
though

"
Yes
,
I
think
you
have
a
right
to
rely
upon
me
,
"
and
then
she
moistens
her

,
and
shows
a
sense
of
relief
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
trust
I
have
kept
the
promise
I
made
through
your
servant
,
that
I
would
detain

a

.
<EOS>
I
need
trouble
<EOS>
you
no
longer
,
Mr.
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
!
"
says
Twemlow
,
rising
as
she
rises
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pardon
me
a
moment
.
<EOS>
I
should
never
have
sought
you
out
,
madam
,
to
say
what
I
am

say
,
but
since
you
have

out
and
are

,
I
will
throw
it
off

.
<EOS>
Was

quite

,
in

,
with
our

that
resolution
against
Mr.
Fledgeby
,
that
you
should
afterwards

Mr.
Fledgeby
as
your

,
and

a
favour
of
Mr.
Fledgeby
?
<EOS>
Always
supposing
that
you
did
;
I
assert
no
knowledge
of
my
own
on
the
subject
;
it
has

that

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
he
told

?
"
<EOS>
retorts
Mrs.
Lammle
,
who
again
has
saved
her
eyes
while
listening
,
and
uses

with
strong
effect
while

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
strange
that
he
should
have
told
you
the
truth
,
"
says
Mrs.
Lammle
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Pray
where
did
a
circumstance
so
very
extraordinary
happen
?
"
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
hesitates
.
<EOS>
He
is
shorter
than
the
lady
as
well
as
weaker
,
and
,
as
she
stands
above
him
with

.
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
In

?
<EOS>
"

Tippins

imagine
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Eugene
suggests
that
Mrs.
Lammle
,
not
being
a
mother
,
had
no
baby
to
look
at
.
  
<EOS>
"
True
,
"
says
Mrs.
Veneering
,
"
but
the
principle
is
the
same
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Boots
is
clear
that
the
principle
is
the
same
.
<EOS>
So
is
Buffer
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
unfortunate
destiny
of
Buffer
to
damage
a
cause
by
espousing
it
.
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
company
have
meekly
yielded
to
the
proposition
that
the
principle
is
the
same
,
until
Buffer
says
it
is
;
when
instantly
a
general
murmur
arises
that
the
principle
is
not
the
same
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
n't
understand
,
"
says
the
Father
of
the
three
hundred
and
seventy
-
five
thousand
pounds
,
"
---
if
these
people
spoken
of
,
occupied
the
position
of
being
in
society
---
they
were
in
society
?
"
  
<EOS>
Veneering
is
bound
to
confess
that
they
dined
here
,
and
were
even
married
from
here
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
do
n't
understand
,
"
pursues
the
Father
,
"
how
even
their
living
beyond
their
means
could
bring
them
to
what
has
been
termed
a
total
smash
.
<EOS>
Because
,
there
is
always
such
a
thing
as
an
adjustment
of
affairs
,
in
the
case
of
people
of
any
standing
at
all
.
"
  
<EOS>
Eugene
(
who
would
seem
to
be
in
a
gloomy
state
of
suggestiveness
)
,
suggests
,
"
Suppose
you
have
no
means
and
live
beyond
them
?
"
  
<EOS>
This
is
too
insolvent
a
state
of
things
for
the
Father
to
entertain
.
<EOS>
It
is
too
insolvent
a
state
of
things
for
any
one
with
any
self
-
respect
to
entertain
,
and
is
universally
scouted
.
<EOS>
But
,
it
is
so
amazing
how
any
people
can
have
come
to
a
total
smash
,
that
everybody
feels
bound
to
account
for
it
specially
.
<EOS>
One
of
the
Fathers
says
,
"
Gaming
table
.
"
 
<EOS>
Another
of
the
Fathers
says
,
"
Speculated
without
knowing
that
speculation
is
a
science
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Boots
says
"
Horses
.
"
<EOS>
Lady
Tippins
says
to
her
fan
,
"
Two
establishments
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Podsnap
,
saying
nothing
,
is
referred
to
for
his
opinion
;
which
he
delivers
as
follows
;
much
flushed
and
extremely
angry
:
  
"
Do
n't
ask
me
.
<EOS>
I
desire
to
take
no
part
in
the
discussion
of
these
people
's
affairs
.
<EOS>
I
abhor
the
subject
.
<EOS>
It
is
an
odious
subject
,
an
offensive
subject
,
a
subject
that
makes
me
sick
,
and
I
---
"
And
with
his
favourite
right
-
arm
flourish
which
sweeps
away
everything
and
settles
it
for
ever
,
Mr.
Podsnap
sweeps
these
inconveniently
unexplainable
wretches
who
have
lived
beyond
their
means
and
gone
to
total
smash
,
off
the
face
of
the
universe
.
  
<EOS>
Eugene
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
,
is
observing
Mr.
Podsnap
with
an
irreverent
face
,
and
may
be
about
to
offer
a
new
suggestion
,
when
the
Analytical
is
beheld
in
collision
with
the
Coachman
;
the
Coachman
manifesting
a
purpose
of
coming
at
the
company
with
a
silver
salver
,
as
though
intent
upon
making
a
collection
for
his
wife
and
family
;
the
Analytical
cutting
him
off
at
the
sideboard
.
<EOS>
The
superior
stateliness
,
if
not
the
superior
generalship
,
of
the
Analytical
prevails
over
a
man
who
is
as
nothing
off
the
box
;
and
the
Coachman
,
yielding
up
his
salver
,
retires
defeated
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
the
Analytical
,
perusing
a
scrap
of
paper
lying
on
the
salver
,
with
the
air
of
a
literary
Censor
,
adjusts
it
,
takes
his
time
about
going
to
the
table
with
it
,
and
presents
it
to
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
Whereupon
the
pleasant
Tippins
says
aloud
,
"
The
Lord
Chancellor
has
resigned
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
distracting
coolness
and
slowness
---
for
he
knows
the
curiosity
of
the
Charmer
to
be
always
devouring
---
Eugene
makes
a
pretence
of
getting
out
an
eyeglass
,
polishing
it
,
and
reading
the
paper
with
difficulty
,
long
after
he
has
seen
what
is
written
on
it
.
<EOS>
What
is
written
on
it
in
wet
ink
,
is
:
  
"
Young
Blight
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Waiting
?
<EOS>
"
says
Eugene
over
his
shoulder
,
in
confidence
,
with
the
Analytical
.
  
<EOS>
"
Waiting
,
"
returns
the
Analytical
in
responsive
confidence
.
  
<EOS>
Eugene
looks
"
<EOS>
Excuse
me
,
"
towards
Mrs.
Veneering
,
goes
out
,
and
finds
Young
Blight
,
Mortimer
's
clerk
,
at
the
hall
-
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
told
me
to
bring
him
,
sir
,
to
wherever
you
was
,
if
he
come
while
you
was
out
<EOS>
and
I
was
in
,
"
says
that
discreet
young
gentleman
,
standing
on
tiptoe
to
