;
"
and
I
've
brought
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sharp
boy
.
<EOS>
Where
is
he
?
"
asks
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
's
in
a
cab
,
sir
,
at
the
door
.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
not
to
show
him
,
you
see
,
if
it
could
be
helped
;
for
he
's
a
-
shaking
all
over
,
like
---
"
 
<EOS>
Blight
's
simile
is
perhaps
inspired
by
the
surrounding
dishes
of
sweets
---
"
like
Glue
Monge
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Sharp
boy
again
,
"
returns
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
go
to
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Goes
out
straightway
,
and
,
leisurely
leaning
his
arms
on
the
open
window
of
a
cab
in
waiting
,
looks
in
at
Mr.
Dolls
:
who
has
brought
his
own
atmosphere
with
him
,
and
would
seem
from
its
odour
to
have
brought
it
,
for
convenience
of
carriage
,
in
a
rum
-
cask
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
Dolls
,
wake
up
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mist
Wrayburn
?
<EOS>
Drection
!
<EOS>
Fifteen
shillings
!
"
  
<EOS>
After
carefully
reading
the
dingy
scrap
of
paper
handed
to
him
,
and
as
carefully
tucking
it
into
his
waistcoat
pocket
,
Eugene
tells
out
the
money
;
beginning
incautiously
by
telling
the
first
shilling
into
Mr.
Dolls
's
hand
,
which
instantly
jerks
it
out
of
window
;
and
ending
by
telling
the
fifteen
shillings
on
the
seat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Give
him
a
ride
back
to
Charing
Cross
,
sharp
boy
,
and
there
get
rid
of
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Returning
to
the
dining
-
room
,
and
pausing
for
an
instant
behind
the
screen
at
the
door
,
Eugene
overhears
,
above
the
hum
and
clatter
,
<EOS>
the
fair
Tippins
saying
:
"
I
am
dying
to
ask
him
what
he
was
called
out
for
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
?
"
<EOS>
mutters
Eugene
,
"
then
perhaps
if
you
ca
n't
ask
him
,
you
'll
die
.
<EOS>
So
I
'll
be
a
benefactor
to
society
,
and
go
.
<EOS>
A
stroll
and
a
cigar
,
and
I
can
think
this
over
.
<EOS>
Think
this
over
.
"
<EOS>
Thus
,
with
a
thoughtful
face
,
he
finds
his
hat
and
cloak
,
unseen
of
the
Analytical
,
and
goes
his
way
.
     
<EOS>
A
Turning
.
 
<EOS>
SETTING
TRAPS
.
 
<EOS>
Plashwater
weir
-
Mill
Lock
looked
tranquil
and
pretty
on
an
evening
in
the
summer
time
.
<EOS>
A
soft
air
stirred
the
leaves
of
the
fresh
green
trees
,
and
passed
like
a
smooth
shadow
over
the
river
,
and
like
a
smoother
shadow
over
the
yielding
grass
.
<EOS>
The
voice
of
the
falling
water
,
like
the
voices
of
the
sea
and
the
wind
,
were
as
an
outer
memory
to
a
contemplative
listener
;
but
not
particularly
so
to
Mr.
Riderhood
,
who
sat
on
one
of
the
blunt
wooden
levers
of
his
lock
-
gates
,
dozing
.
<EOS>
Wine
must
be
got
into
a
butt
by
some
agency
before
it
can
be
drawn
out
;
and
the
wine
of
sentiment
never
having
been
got
into
Mr.
Riderhood
by
any
agency
,
nothing
in
nature
tapped
him
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
Rogue
sat
,
ever
and
again
nodding
himself
off
his
balance
,
his
recovery
was
always
attended
by
an
angry
stare
and
growl
,
as
if
,
in
the
absence
of
any
one
else
,
he
had
aggressive
inclinations
towards
himself
.
<EOS>
In
one
of
these
starts
the
cry
of
"
Lock
,
ho
!
<EOS>
Lock
!
"
<EOS>
prevented
his
relapse
into
a
doze
.
<EOS>
Shaking
himself
as
he
got
up
,
like
the
surly
brute
<EOS>
he
was
,
he
gave
his
growl
a
responsive
twist
at
the
end
,
and
turned
his
face
down
-
stream
to
see
who
hailed
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
an
amateur
-
sculler
,
well
up
to
his
work
though
taking
it
easily
,
in
so
light
a
boat
that
the
Rogue
remarked
:
"
A
little
less
on
you
,
and
you
'd
a'most
ha
'
been
a
Wagerbut
;
"
then
went
to
work
at
his
windlass
handles
and
sluices
,
to
let
the
sculler
in
.
<EOS>
As
the
latter
stood
in
his
boat
,
holding
on
by
the
boat
-
hook
to
the
woodwork
at
the
lock
side
,
waiting
for
the
gates
to
open
,
Rogue
Riderhood
recognized
his
"
T'other
governor
,
"
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
;
who
was
,
however
,
too
indifferent
or
too
much
engaged
to
recognize
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
creaking
lock
-
gates
opened
slowly
,
and
the
light
boat
passed
in
as
soon
as
there
was
room
enough
,
and
the
creaking
lock
-
gates
closed
upon
it
,
and
it
floated
low
down
in
the
dock
between
the
two
sets
of
gates
,
until
the
water
should
rise
and
the
second
gates
should
open
and
let
it
out
.
<EOS>
When
Riderhood
had
run
to
his
second
windlass
and
turned
it
,
and
while
he
leaned
against
the
lever
of
that
gate
to
help
it
to
swing
open
presently
,
he
noticed
,
lying
to
rest
under
the
green
hedge
by
the
towing
-
path
astern
of
the
Lock
,
a
Bargeman
.
  
<EOS>
The
water
rose
and
rose
as
the
sluice
poured
in
,
dispersing
the
scum
which
had
formed
behind
the
lumbering
gates
,
and
sending
the
boat
up
,
so
that
the
sculler
gradually
rose
like
an
apparition
against
the
light
from
the
bargeman
's
point
of
view
.
<EOS>
Riderhood
observed
that
the
bargeman
rose
too
,
leaning
on
his
arm
,
and
seemed
to
have
his
eyes
fastened
on
the
rising
figure
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
there
was
the
toll
to
be
taken
,
as
the
gates
were
now
complaining
and
opening
.
<EOS>
The
T'other
governor
tossed
it
ashore
,
twisted
in
a
piece
of
paper
,
and
as
he
did
so
,
knew
his
man
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
,
ay
?
<EOS>
It
's
you
,
is
it
,
honest
friend
?
"
said
Eugene
,
seating
himself
preparatory
to
resuming
his
sculls
.
<EOS>
"
You
got
the
place
,
then
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
got
the
place
,
and
no
thanks
to
you
for
it
,
nor
yet
none
to
Lawyer
Lightwood
,
"
gruffly
answered
Riderhood
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
saved
our
recommendation
,
honest
fellow
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
for
the
next
candidate
---
the
one
who
will
offer
himself
when
you
are
trans
ported
or
hanged
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
long
about
it
;
will
you
be
so
good
?
"
  
<EOS>
So
imperturbable
was
the
air
with
which
he
gravely
bent
to
his
work
that
Riderhood
remained
staring
at
him
,
without
having
found
a
retort
,
until
he
had
rowed
past
a
line
of
wooden
objects
by
the
weir
,
which
showed
like
huge
teetotums
standing
at
rest
in
the
water
,
and
was
almost
hidden
by
the
drooping
boughs
on
the
left
bank
,
as
he
rowed
away
,
keeping
out
of
the
opposing
current
.
<EOS>
It
being
then
too
late
to
retort
with
any
effect
---
if
that
could
ever
have
been
done
 
---
the
honest
man
confined
himself
to
cursing
and
growling
in
a
grim
under
-
tone
.
<EOS>
Having
then
got
his
gates
shut
,
he
crossed
back
by
his
plank
lock
-
bridge
to
the
towing
-
path
side
of
the
river
.
  
<EOS>
If
,
in
so
doing
,
he
took
another
glance
at
the
bargeman
,
he
did
it
by
stealth
.
<EOS>
He
cast
himself
on
the
grass
by
the
Lock
side
,
in
an
indolent
way
,
with
his
back
in
that
direction
,
and
,
having
gathered
a
few
blades
,
fell
to
chewing
them
.
<EOS>
The
dip
of
Eugene
Wrayburn
's
sculls
had
become
hardly
audible
in
his
ears
when
the
bargeman
passed
him
,
putting
the
utmost
width
that
he
could
between
them
,
and
keeping
under
the
hedge
.
<EOS>
Then
,
Riderhood
sat
up
and
took
a
long
look
at
his
figure
,
and
then
cried
:
"
<EOS>
Hi
---
i
---
i
!
<EOS>
Lock
,
ho
!
<EOS>
Lock
!
<EOS>
Plashwater
Weir
-
Mill
Lock
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
bargeman
stopped
,
and
looked
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Plashwater
Weir
-
Mill
Lock
,
T'otherest
gov
---
er
---
nor
---
or
---
or
---
  
or
!
"
cried
Mr.
Riderhood
,
with
his
hands
to
his
mouth
.
  
<EOS>
The
bargeman
turned
back
.
<EOS>
Approaching
nearer
and
nearer
,
the
bargeman
became
Bradley
Headstone
,
in
rough
water
-
side
secondhand
clothing
.
  
<EOS>
"
Wish
I
may
die
,
"
said
Riderhood
,
smiting
his
right
leg
,
and
laughing
,
as
he
sat
on
the
grass
,
"
if
you
ai
n't
ha
'
been
a
imitating
me
,
T'otherest
governor
!
<EOS>
Never
thought
myself
so
good
-
looking
afore
!
"
  
<EOS>
Truly
,
Bradley

Lock
<EOS>
(

)

<EOS>
"

?

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
Rogue

,

neckhankecher

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Lock
ho
!
<EOS>
Lock
!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
I

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Bradley

.

,

<EOS>

Lock

<EOS>
Lock

thrice

"

"

<EOS>

"
Your

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

,
"
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

"

,
before

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Then

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
I

wot

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
<EOS>
"

,

"
<EOS>
How

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Anyways

.
<EOS>
Sleep

;
 
the

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
His

,

Bradley
's

.
<EOS>
He

,
and
east

,
all

,

.
  
<EOS>
Riderhood
sat
down
in
his
wooden
arm
-
chair
,
and
looked
through
the
window
at
the
lightning
,
and
listened

.
<EOS>
But
,
his
thoughts
were
far
from
being
absorbed
by
the
thunder
and
the
lightning
,
for
again
and
again
and
again
he
looked
very

at
the
exhausted
man
upon
the
bed
.
<EOS>
The
man
had
turned
up
the
collar
of
the
rough
coat
he
wore
,
to
shelter

from
the
storm
,
and
had
buttoned

about

.
<EOS>
Unconscious
of
that
,
and
of
most
things
,
he
had
left
the
coat
so
,
both
when
he
had
laved
his
face
in
the
river
,
and
when
he
had
cast
himself
upon
the
bed
;
though
it
would
have
been
much
easier
to
him
if
he
had
unloosened
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
thunder
rolled
heavily
,
and
the
forked
lightning
seemed
to
make
jagged
rents
in
every
part
of
the
vast
curtain
without
,
as
Riderhood
sat
by
the
window
,
glancing
at
the
bed
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
,
he
saw
the
man
upon
the
bed
,
by
a
red
light
;
sometimes
,
by
a
blue
;
 
sometimes
,
he
scarcely
saw
him
in
the
darkness
of
the
storm
;
sometimes
he
saw
nothing
of
him
in
the
blinding

of
palpitating
white
fire
.
<EOS>
Anon
,
the
rain
would
come
again
with
a
tremendous

,
and
the
river
would
seem
to
rise
to
meet
it
,
and
a
blast
of
wind
,
bursting
upon
the
door
,
would
flutter
the
hair
and
dress
of
the
man
,
as
if
invisible
messengers
were
come
around
the
bed
to
carry

.
<EOS>
From
all
these
phases
of
the
storm
,
Riderhood
would
turn
,
as
if
they
were
interruptions
---
rather
striking
interruptions
possibly
,
but
interruptions
still
---
of
his
scrutiny
of
the
sleeper
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
sleeps
sound
,
"
he
said
within
himself
;
"
yet
he
's
that
up
to
me
and
that
noticing
of
me
that
my
getting
out
of
my
chair
may
wake
him
,
when
a
rattling
peal
wo
n't
;
let
alone
my
touching
of
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
very
cautiously
rose
to
his
feet
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
T'otherest
,
"
he
said
,
in
a
low
,
calm
voice
,
"
are
you
a
lying
easy
?
<EOS>
There
's
a
chill
in
the
air
,
governor
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
put
a
coat
over
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
No
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
about
what
it
is
a'ready
<EOS>
,
you
see
,
"
muttered
Riderhood
in
a
lower
and
a
different
voice
;
"
a
coat
over
you
,
a
coat
over
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
sleeper
moving
an
arm
,
he
sat
down
again
in
his
chair
,
and
feigned
to
watch
the
storm
from
the
window
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
grand
spectacle
,
but
not
so
grand
as
to
keep
his
eyes
,
for
half
a
minute
together
,
from
stealing
a
look
at
the
man
upon
the
bed
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
at
the
concealed
throat
of
the
sleeper
that
Riderhood
so
often
looked
so
curiously
,
until
the
sleep
seemed
to
deepen
into
the
stupor
of
the
dead
-
tired
in
mind
and
body
.
<EOS>
Then
,
Riderhood
came
from
the
window
cautiously
,
and
stood
by
the
bed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
man
!
"
<EOS>
he
murmured
in
a
low
tone
,
with
a
crafty
face
,
and
a
very
watchful
eye
and
ready
foot
,
lest
he
should
start
up
;
"
this
here
coat
of
his
must
make
him
uneasy
in
his
sleep
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
loosen
if
for
him
,
and
make
him
more
comfortable
?
<EOS>
Ah
!
<EOS>
I
think
I
ought
to
it
,
poor
man
.
<EOS>
I
think
I
will
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
touched
the
first
button
with
a
very
cautions
hand
,
and
a
step
backward
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
sleeper
remaining
in
profound
unconsciousness
,
he
touched
the
other
buttons
with
a
more
assured
hand
,
and
perhaps
the
more
lightly
on
that
account
.
<EOS>
Softly
and
slowly
,
he
opened
the
coat
and
drew
it
back
.
  
<EOS>
The
draggling
ends
of
a
bright
-
red
neckerchief
were
then
disclosed
,
and
he
had
even
been
at
the
pains
of
dipping
parts
of
it
in
some
liquid
,
to
give
it
the
appearance
of
having
become
stained
by
wear
.
<EOS>
With
a
much
-
perplexed
face
,
Riderhood
looked
from
it
to
the
sleeper
,
and
from
the
sleeper
to
it
,
and
finally
crept
back
to
his
chair
,
and
there
,
with
his
hand
to
his
chin
,
sat
long
in
a
brown
study
,
looking
at
both
.
   
<EOS>
THE
GOLDEN
DUSTMAN
RISES
A
LITTLE
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
had
come
to
breakfast
with
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
They
were
not
absolutely
uninvited
,
but
had
pressed
themselves
with
so
much
urgency
on
the
golden
couple
,
that
evasion
of
the
honor
and
pleasure
of
their
company
would
have
been
difficult
,
if
desired
.
<EOS>
They
were
in
a
charming
state
of
mind
,
were
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
,
and
almost
as
fond
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
as
of
one
another
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
"
it
imparts
new
life
to
me
,
to
see
my
Alfred
in
confidential
communication
with
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
The
two
were
formed
to
become
intimate
.
<EOS>
So
much
simplicity
combined
with
so
much
force
of
character
,
such
natural
sagacity
united
to
such
amiability
and
gentleness
<EOS>
---
these
are
the
distinguishing
characteristics
of
both
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
being
said
aloud
,
gave
Mr.
Lammle
an
opportunity
,
as
he
came
with
Mr.
Boffin
from
the
window
to
the
breakfast
table
,
of
taking
up
his
dear
and
honored
wife
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
Sophronia
,
"
said
that
gentleman
,
"
your
too
partial
estimate
of
your
poor
husband
's
character
---
"
  
"
<EOS>
No
!
<EOS>
Not
too
partial
,
Alfred
<EOS>
,
"
urged
the
lady
,
tenderly
moved
;
 
"
never
say
that
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
child
,
your
favourable
opinion
,
then
,
of
your
husband
---
you
do
n't
object
to
that
phrase
,
darling
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
,
Alfred
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
favourable
opinion
then
,
my
Precious
,
does
less
than
justice
to
Mr.
Boffin
,
and
more
than
justice
to
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
the
first
charge
,
Alfred
,
I
plead
guilty
.
<EOS>
But
to
the
second
,
oh
no
,
no
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Less
than
justice
to
Mr.
Boffin
,
Sophronia
,
"
said
Mr.
Lammle
,
soaring
into
a
tone
of
moral
grandeur
,
"
because
it
represents
Mr.
Boffin
as
on
my
lower
level
;
more
than
justice
to
me
,
Sophronia
,
because
it
represents
me
as
on
Mr.
Boffin
's
higher
level
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
bears
and
forbears
far
more
than
I
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Far
more
than
you
could
for
yourself
,
Alfred
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
love
,
that
is
not
the
question
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
the
question
,
Lawyer
?
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
archly
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
dear
Sophronia
.
<EOS>
From
my
lower
level
,
I
regard
Mr.
Boffin
as
too
generous
,
as
possessed
of
too
much
clemency
,
as
being
too
good
to
persons
who
are
unworthy
of
him
and
ungrateful
to
him
.
<EOS>
To
those
noble
qualities
I
can
lay
no
claim
.
<EOS>
On
the
contrary
,
they
rouse
my
indignation
when
I
see
them
in
action
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Alfred
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
rouse
my
indignation
,
my
dear
,
against
,
the
unworthy
persons
,
and
give
me
a
combative
desire
to
stand
between
Mr.
Boffin
and
all
such
persons
.
<EOS>
Why
?
<EOS>
Because
,
in
my
lower
nature
I
am
more
worldly
and
less
delicate
.
<EOS>
Not
being
so
magnanimous
as
Mr.
Boffin
,
I
feel
his
injuries
more
than
he
does
himself
,
and
feel
more
capable
of
opposing
his
injurers
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
struck
Mrs.
Lammle
that
it
appeared
rather
difficult
this
morning
to
bring
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
into
agreeable
conversation
.
<EOS>
Here
had
been
several
lures
thrown
out
,
and
neither
of
them
had
uttered
a
word
.
<EOS>
Here
were
she
,
Mrs.
Lammle
,
and
her
husband
discoursing
at
once
affectingly
and
effectively
,
but
discoursing
alone
.
<EOS>
Assuming
that
the
dear
old
creatures
were
impressed
by
what
they
heard
,
still
one
would
like
to
be
sure
of
it
,
the
more
so
,
as
at
least
one
of
the
dear
old
creatures
was
somewhat
pointedly
referred
to
.
<EOS>
If
the
dear
old
creatures
were
too
bashful
or
too
dull
to
assume
their
required
places
in
the
discussion
,
why
then
it
would
seem
desirable
that
the
dear
old
creatures
should
be
taken
by
their
heads
and
shoulders
and
brought
into
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
is
not
my
husband
saying
in
effect
,
"
asked
Mrs.
Lammle
,
therefore
,
with
an
innocent
air
,
of
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
that
he
becomes
unmindful
of
his
own
temporary
misfortunes
in
his
admiration
of
another
whom
he
is
burning
to
serve
?
<EOS>
And
is
not
that
making
an
admission
that
his
nature
is
a
generous
one
?
<EOS>
I
am
wretched
in
argument
,
but
surely
this
is
so
,
dear
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
?
"
  
<EOS>
Still
,
neither
Mr.
nor
Mrs.
Boffin
said
a
word
.
<EOS>
He
sat
with
his
eyes
on
his
plate
,
eating
his
muffins
and
ham
,
and
she
sat
shyly
looking
at
the
teapot
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
's
innocent
appeal
was
merely
thrown
into
the
air
,
to
mingle
with
the
steam
of
the
urn
.
<EOS>
Glancing
towards
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
she
very
slightly
raised
her
eyebrows
,
as
though
inquiring
of
her
husband
:
"
Do
I
notice
anything
wrong
here
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
,
who
had
found
his
chest
effective
on
a
variety
of
occasions
,
manoeuvred
his
capacious
shirt
front
into
the
largest
demonstration
possible
,
and
then
smiling
retorted
on
his
wife
,
thus
:
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
darling
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
will
remind
you
of
the
old
adage
,
that
self
-
praise
is
no
recommendation
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Self
-
praise
,
Alfred
?
<EOS>
Do
you
mean
because
we
are
one
and
the
same
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
my
dear
child
.
<EOS>
I
mean
that
you
can
not
fail
to
remember
,
<EOS>
if
you
reflect
for
a
single
moment
,
that
what
you
are
pleased
to
compliment
me
upon
feeling
in
the
case
of
Mr.
Boffin
,
you
have
yourself
confided
to
me
as
your
own
feeling
in
the
case
of
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
  
(
"
I
shall
be
beaten
by
this
Lawyer
,
"
Mrs.
Lammle
gaily
whispered
to
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
I
must
admit
it
,
<EOS>
if
he
presses
me
,
for
it
's
damagingly
true
.
"
)
  
<EOS>
Several
white
dints
began
to
come
and
go
about
Mr.
Lammle
's
nose
,
as
he
observed
that
Mrs.
Boffin
merely
looked
up
from
the
teapot
for
a
moment
with
an
embarrassed
smile
,
which
was
no
smile
,
and
then
looked
down
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
admit
the
charge
,
Sophronia
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
Alfred
,
in
a
rallying
tone
.
  
<EOS>
"
Really
,
I
think
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
still
gaily
,
"
I
must
throw
myself
on
the
protection
of
the
Court
.
<EOS>
Am
I
bound
to
answer
that
question
,
my
Lord
?
"
<EOS>
To
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
need
n't
,
if
you
do
n't
like
ma'am
,
"
was
his
answer
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
of
the
least
consequence
.
"
  
<EOS>
Both
husband
and
wife
glanced
at
him
,
very
doubtfully
.
<EOS>
His
manner
was
grave
,
but
not
coarse
,
and
derived
some
dignity
from
a
certain
repressed
dislike
of
the
tone
of
the
conversation
.
  
<EOS>
Again
Mrs.
Lammle
raised
her
eyebrows
for
instruction
from
her
husband
.
<EOS>
He
replied
in
a
slight
nod
,
"
Try
'em
again
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
protect
myself
against
the
suspicion
of
covert
self
-
laudation
,
my
dear
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
said
the
airy
Mrs.
Lammle
therefore
,
"
I
must
tell
you
how
it
was
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
Pray
do
n't
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
interposed
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
turned
to
him
laughingly
.
"
<EOS>
The
Court
objects
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ma'am
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
the
Court
(
if
I
am
the
Court
)
does
object
.
<EOS>
The
Court
objects
for
two
reasons
.
<EOS>
First
,
because
the
Court
do
n't
think
it
fair
.
<EOS>
Secondly
,
because
the
dear
old
lady
,
Mrs.
Court
(
if
I
am
Mr.
)
gets
distressed
by
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
very
remarkable
wavering
between
two
bearings
---
between
her
propitiatory
bearing
there
,
and
her
defiant
bearing
at
Mr.
Twemlow
's
 
---
was
observable
on
the
part
of
Mrs.
Lammle
as
she
said
:
"
What
does
the
Court
not
consider
fair
?
"
  
<EOS>
Letting
you
go
on
,
"
replied
Mr.
Boffin
,
nodding
his
head
soothingly
,
as
who
should
say
,
We
wo
n't
be
harder
on
you
than
we
can
help
;
we
'll
make
the
best
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
not
above
-
board
<EOS>
and
it
's
not
fair
.
<EOS>
When
the
old
lady
is
uncomfortable
,
there
's
sure
to
be
good
reason
for
it
.
<EOS>
I
see
she
is
uncomfortable
,
and
I
plainly
see
this
is
the
good
reason
wherefore
.
<EOS>
Have
you
breakfasted
,
ma'am
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
,
settling
into
her
defiant
manner
,
pushed
her
plate
away
,
looked
at
her
husband
,
and
laughed
;
but
by
no
means
gaily
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
breakfasted
,
sir
?
"
inquired
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
replied
Alfred
,
showing
all
his
teeth
.
<EOS>
"
If
Mrs.
Boffin
will
oblige
me
,
I
'll
take
another
cup
of
tea
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
spilled
a
little
of
it
over
the
chest
which
ought
to
have
been
so
effective
,
and
which
had
done
so
little
;
but
on
the
whole
drank
it
with
something
of
an
air
,
though
the
coming
and
going
dints
got
almost
as
large
,
the
while
,
as
if
they
had
been
made
by
pressure
of
the
teaspoon
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
thousand
thanks
,
"
he
then
observed
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
breakfasted
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Now
,
which
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
softly
,
taking
out
a
pocket
-
book
,
"
which
of
you
two
is
Cashier
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
my
dear
,
"
remarked
her
husband
,
as
he
leaned
back
in
his
chair
,
waving
his
right
hand
towards
her
,
while
he
hung
his
left
hand
by
the
thumb
in
the
arm
-
hole
of
his
waistcoat
:
"
it
shall
be
your
department
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
rather
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
that
it
was
your
husband
's
,
ma'am
,
because
---
<EOS>
but
never
mind
,
because
.
<EOS>
I
would
rather
have
to
do
with
him
.
<EOS>
However
,
what
I
have
to
say
,
I
will
say
with
as
little
offence
as
possible
;
if
I
can
say
it
without
any
,
I
shall
be
heartily
glad
.
<EOS>
You
two
have
done
me
a
service
,
a
very
great
service
,
in
doing
what
you
did
(
my
old
lady
knows
what
it
was
)
,
and
I
have
put
into
this
envelope
a
bank
note
for
a
hundred
pound
.
<EOS>
I
consider
the
service
well
worth
a
hundred
pound
,
and
I
am
well
pleased
to
pay
the
money
.
<EOS>
Would
you
do
me
the
favour
to
take
it
,
and
likewise
to
accept
my
thanks
?
<EOS>
"
  
With
a
haughty
action
,
and
without
looking
towards
him
,
Mrs.
Lammle
held
out
her
left
hand
,
and
into
it
Mr.
Boffin
put
the
little
packet
.
<EOS>
When
she
had
conveyed
it
to
her
bosom
,
Mr.
Lammle
had
the
appearance
of
feeling
relieved
,
and
breathing
more
freely
,
as
not
having
been
quite
certain
that
the
hundred
pounds
were
his
,
until
the
note
had
been
safely
transferred
out
of
Mr.
Boffin
's
keeping
into
his
own
Sophronia
's
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
impossible
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
addressing
Alfred
,
"
that
you
have
had
some
general
idea
,
sir
,
of
replacing
Rokesmith
,
in
course
of
time
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
,
"
assented
Alfred
,
with
a
glittering
smile
and
a
great
deal
of
nose
,
"
not
impossible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
perhaps
,
ma'am
,
"
pursued
Mr.
Boffin
,
addressing
Sophronia
,
"
you
have
been
so
kind
as
to
take
up
my
old
lady
in
your
own
mind
,
and
to
do
her
the

of
turning
the
question
over
whether
you
might
n't
one
of
these
days
have
her
in
charge
,
like
?
<EOS>
Whether
you
might
n't
be
a
sort
of
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
to
her
,
and
something
more
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
hope
,
"
returned
Mrs.
Lammle
,
with
a

and
in
a

,
"
that
if
I
were
anything
to
your
wife
,
sir
,
I
could
hardly
fail
to
be
something
more
than
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
,
as
you
call

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
call
her
,
ma'am
?
"
asked
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
disdained
to
reply
,
and
sat
defiantly
beating
one
foot
on
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
"
Again
I
think
I
may
say
,
that
's
not

.
<EOS>
Is
it
,
sir
?
"
 
<EOS>
asked
Mr.
Boffin
,

Alfred
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
,
"
said
Alfred
,
smiling
assent
as
before
,
"
not
impossible
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
gently
,
"
it
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
wish
to
say
a
single
word
that
might
be
afterwards
remembered
as
unpleasant
;
 
but
it
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
my
love
,
"
her
husband

in
a

,
"
you
hear
?
<EOS>
It
wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
with

,
"
it
really
wo
n't
.
<EOS>
You
positively
must

.
<EOS>
If
you
'll
go
your
way
,
we
'll
go
ours
,
and
<EOS>
so
I
hope
this
affair
ends
to
the

all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
gave

from
the
category
;
but
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

of

,
"

,
"

,

's

.
<EOS>
You
have
done
me
a
great

,
a
very

,
and
I
have

for
it
.
<EOS>
Is

any

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
looked
at

another
across
the
table
,
but
neither
could
say
that
there
was
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
shrugged

,
and
Mrs.
Lammle

.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
We
hope
(
my
old

and

)

you

for

the
plainest

that
could

.
<EOS>
We
have
talked

over
with
a
deal

(
my

)
,
and

have
felt
that
at

,

all

on
of

,

.
<EOS>
So
,
I
have

to
understand
that
<EOS>
---
"
Mr.
Boffin
sought

,
but

,

,
"
---
that

wo
n't
do
.
<EOS>
If
I
could
have
put
the
case
more
pleasantly
<EOS>
I

;
<EOS>
but
I

I
have

;
 
at
all
events
I
have
n't
meant
to
.
<EOS>
So
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,

,
"

,
we
now

with
the

that
perhaps
you
'll
go
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Lammle
rose
with
an

on
his
side
of

table
,
and
Mrs.
Lammle
rose
with
a
disdainful
frown
on
hers
.
<EOS>
At
this
moment
a
hasty
foot
was
heard
on
the
staircase
,
and
Georgiana
Podsnap
broke
into
the
room
,
unannounced
and
in
tears
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
my
dear
Sophronia
,
"
cried
Georgiana
,
wringing
her
hands
as
she
ran
up
to

her
,
"
to
think
that
you
and
Alfred
should
be
ruined
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
poor
dear
Sophronia
,
to
think
that
you
should
have
had
a
Sale
at
your
house
after
all
your
kindness
to
me
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
pray
forgive
me
for
this
intrusion
,
but
you
do
n't
know
how
fond
I
was
of
Sophronia
when
Pa
would
n't
let
me
go
there
any
more
,
or
what
I
have
felt
for
Sophronia
since
I
heard
from
Ma
of
her
having
been
brought
low
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
,
you
ca
n't
<EOS>
,
you
never
can
,
think
,
how
I
have
lain
awake
at
night
and
cried
for
my
good
Sophronia
,
my
first
and
only
friend
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
's
manner
changed
under
the
poor
silly
girl
's
embraces
,
and
she
turned
extremely
pale
:
directing
one
appealing
look
,
first
to
Mrs.
Boffin
,
and
then
to
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
Both
understood
her
instantly
,
with
a
more
delicate
subtlety
than
much
better
educated
people
,
whose
perception
came
less
directly
from
the
heart
,
could
have
brought
to
bear
upon
the
case
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
n't
a
minute
,
"
said
poor
little
Georgiana
,
"
to
stay
.
<EOS>
I
am
out
shopping
early
with
Ma
,
and
I
said
I
had
a
headache
and
got
Ma
to
leave
me
outside
in
the
phaeton
,
in
Piccadilly
,
and
ran
round
to
Sackville
Street
,
and
heard
that
Sophronia
was
here
,
and
then
Ma
came
to
see
,
oh
such
a
dreadful
old
stony
woman
from
the
country
in
a
turban
in
Portland
Place
,
and
I
said
I
would
n't
go
up
with
Ma
but
would
drive
round
and
leave
cards
for
the
Boffins
,
which
is
taking
a
liberty
with
the
name
;
but
oh
my
goodness
I
am
distracted
,
and
the
phaeton
's
at
the
door
,
and
what
would
Pa
say
if
he
knew
it
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

ye
be
timid
,

,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
You
came
in
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
no
,
I
did

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It
's

impolite
,
I

,
but
I
came
to

my
poor
Sophronia
,

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
how
I
felt
the
separation
,
my

Sophronia
,
before

low
in
the

,
and

I

it
now
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
were
actually
tears
in

bold
woman
's

,
as

softheaded
and
soft

hearted
girl
twined

.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
've
come
on
business
,
"
said

,

and

,
and
then

in

,
"
and
if
I
do
n't
despatch
it
<EOS>
I
shall
have
come
for
nothing
,
and
oh
good
gracious
!
<EOS>
what
would
Pa
say
if
he
knew
of
Sackville
Street
,
and
what
would
Ma
say
if
she
was
kept
waiting
on

of
that
dreadful

,
and
there
never
were
such

as
ours
unsettling
my

every

more
and
more
when
I
want
more
mind
than
I
have
got
,
by
pawing
up
Mr.
Boffin
's
street
where
they
have
no
business
to
be
.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
where
is
,
where
is
it
?
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
find
it
!
<EOS>
"
All
this
time
sobbing
,
and
searching
in
the
little
reticule
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
miss
,
my
dear
?
"
asked
Mr.
Boffin
,
stepping
forward
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
it
's
little
enough
,
"
replied
Georgiana
,
"
because
Ma
always
treats
me
as
if
I
was
in
the
nursery
<EOS>
(
I
am
sure
I
wish
I
was
!
)
,
but
I
hardly
ever
spend
it
<EOS>
and
it
has
mounted
up
to
fifteen
pounds
,
Sophronia
,
and
I
hope
three
five
-
pound
notes
are
better
than
nothing
,
though
so
little
,
so
little
!
<EOS>
And
now
I
have
found
that
---
oh
,
my
goodness
!
<EOS>
there
's
the
other
gone
next
!
<EOS>
Oh
no
,
it
is
n't
,
here
it
is
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
that
,
always
sobbing
and
searching
in
the
reticule
,
Georgiana
produced
a
necklace
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ma
says
chits
and
jewels
have
no
business
together
,
"
pursued
Georgiana
,
"
and
that
's
reason
why
I
have
no
trinkets
except
this
,
but
I
suppose
my
aunt
Hawkinson
was
of

,
because
she
left

this
,
though
I
used
to
think

might
just

buried
it
,
for
it
's
always
kept
in

'

.
<EOS>
However
,
here
it
is
,
I
am
thankful
to
say
,
and
of
use
at
last
,
and
you
'll
sell
it
,
dear
Sophronia
,
and
buy
things
with

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Give
it
to
me
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
gently

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
see
that
it
's

of
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
are
you
such
a

of
Sophronia
's
,
Mr.
Boffin
?
"
cried

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
how
good
of

!
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
gracious
!
<EOS>
there
was
something
else
,
and
it
's
gone
out
of
my
head
!
<EOS>
Oh
no
,
it
is
n't
,
I
remember
what
it
was
.
<EOS>
My
grandmamma
's
property
,
that
'll
come
to
me
when
I
am
of
age
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
will
be
all
my
own
,
and
neither
Pa
nor
Ma
nor

else
will
have
any

it
,
and
what
I
wish

is
to
make

over

to
Sophronia
and
Alfred
,
by

something
somewhere
that
'll

to

something
.
<EOS>
I
want
them
to
have
something
handsome
to
bring
them
up
in
the
world
again
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
goodness
me
!
<EOS>
Being
such
a

of
my
dear
Sophronia
's
,
you
wo
n't
refuse
me
,
will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
it
shall
be
seen
to
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
thank
you
,
thank
you
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Georgiana
.
<EOS>
"
If
my
maid
had
a
little
note
and
half
a
crown
,
I
could
run
round
to
the
pastrycook
's
to
sign
something
,
or
I
could
sign
something
in
the
Square
if
some
body
would
come
and
cough
for
me
to
let
'em
in
with
the
key
,
and
would
bring
a
pen
and

with

and
a
bit
of

-

.
<EOS>
Oh
,
my
gracious
!
<EOS>
I
must
tear
myself
away
,
or
Pa
and
Ma
will
both
find
out
!
<EOS>
Dear
,
dear
Sophronia
,
good
,
good
-
bye
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
credulous
little
creature
again
embraced
Mrs.
Lammle
most
affectionately
,
and
then
held
out
her
hand
to
Mr.
Lammle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-
bye
,
<EOS>
dear
Mr.
Lammle
---
I
mean
<EOS>
Alfred
.
<EOS>
You
wo
n't
think
after
to
-
day
that
I
have
deserted
you
and
Sophronia
because
you
have
been
brought
low
in
the
world
,
will

?
<EOS>
Oh
me
!
<EOS>
oh
me
!
<EOS>
I
have
been
crying
my
eyes
out
of
my
head
,
and
Ma
will
be
sure
to
ask
me
what
's
the
matter
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
take
me
down
,
somebody
,
please
,
please
,
please
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
took
her
down
,
and
saw
her
driven
away
,
with
her
poor
little
red
eyes
and
weak
chin
peering
over
the
great
apron
of
the
custard
-
coloured
phaeton
,
as
if
she
had
been
ordered
to
expiate
some
childish
misdemeanor
by
going
to
bed
in
the
daylight
,
and
were
peeping
over
the
counterpane
in
a
miserable
flutter
of
repentance
and
low
spirits
.
<EOS>
Returning
to
the
breakfast
-
room
,
he
found
Mrs.
Lammle
still
standing
on
her
side
of
the
table
,
and
Mr.
Lammle
on
his
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
take
care
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
,
showing
the
money
and
the
necklace
,
"
that
these
are
soon
given
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
had
taken
up
her
parasol
from
a
side
table
,
and
stood
sketching
with
it
on
the
pattern
of
the
damask
cloth
,
as
she
had
sketched
on
the
pattern
of
Mr.
Twemlow
's
papered
wall
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
undeceive
her
<EOS>
I
hope
,
Mr.
Boffin
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
,
turning
her
head
towards
him
,
but
not
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
as
to
the
worth
and
value
of
her
friend
,
"
Mrs.
Lammle
explained
,
in
a
measured

,
and
with
an
emphasis

her

word
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
he
returned
.
<EOS>
"
I
may
try
to
give
a
hint
at
her

that
she
is
in
want

kind

,
but
I

say
no

than
that

her
parents
,
and
I
shall
say
nothing
to
the
young

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
,
"
said
Mrs.
Lammle
,
still

,
and
seeming
to
bestow
great
pains
upon
it
,
"
there
are
not
many
people
,
I
think
,
who
,
under
the

,
would
have
been
so
considerate
and
sparing
as
you
have
been
to
me
just
now
.
<EOS>
Do
you
care
to
be
thanked
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thanks
are
always
worth
having
,
"
said
Mrs.
Boffin
,
in
her
ready
good
nature
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
thank
you
both
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sophronia
,
"
asked
her
husband
,
mockingly
,
"
are
you
sentimental
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
well
,
my
good
sir
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
interposed
,
"
it
's
a
very
good
thing
to
think
well
of
another
person
,
and
it
's
a
very
good
thing
to
be
thought
well
of
by
another
person
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Lammle
will
be
none
the
worse
for
it
,
if
she
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Much
obliged
.
<EOS>
But
I
asked
Mrs.
Lammle
if
she
was
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
stood
sketching
on
the
table
-
cloth
,
with
her
face
clouded
and
set
,
and
was
silent
.
  
<EOS>
"
Because
,
"
said
Alfred
,
"
I
am
disposed
to
be
sentimental
myself
,
on
your
appropriation
of
the
jewels
and
the
money
,
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
As
our
little
Georgiana
,
said
,
three
five
-
pound
notes
are
better
than
nothing
,
and
if
you
sell
a
necklace
you
can

things

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
sell
it
,
"
was
Mr.
Boffin
's
comment
,
as
he
put
it
in
his
pocket
.
  
<EOS>
Alfred
followed
it
with
his
looks
,
and
also
greedily
pursued
the
notes
until
they
vanished
into
Mr.
Boffin
's
waistcoat
pocket
.
<EOS>
Then
he
directed
a
look
,
half
exasperated
and
half
jeering
,
at
his
wife
.
<EOS>
She
still
stood
sketching
;
but
,
as
she

,
there
was
a
struggle
within
her
,
which
found
expression
in
the
depth
of
the
few
last
lines
the
parasol
point
indented
into
the
table
-
cloth
,
and
then
some
tears
fell
from
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
confound
the
woman
,
"
exclaimed
Lammle
,
"
she
is
sentimental
!
  
<EOS>
She
walked
to
the
window
,
flinching
under
his
angry
stare
,
looked
out
for
a
moment
,
and
turned
round
quite

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
had
no
former
cause
of
complaint
on
the
sentimental
score
,
Alfred
,
and
you
will
have
none
in
future
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
worth
your
noticing
.
<EOS>
We
go
abroad
soon
,
with
the
money
we
have
earned
here
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
we
do
;
you
know
we
must
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
fear
of
my
taking
any
sentiment
with
me
.
<EOS>
I
should
soon
be
eased
of
it
,
if
I
did
.
<EOS>
But
it
will
be
all
left
behind
.
<EOS>
It
is
all
left
behind
.
<EOS>
Are
you
ready
,
Alfred
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
the
deuce
have
I
been
waiting
for
<EOS>
but
you
,
Sophronia
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
go
then
.
<EOS>
I
am
sorry
I
have
delayed
our
dignified
departure
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
passed
out
and
he
followed
her
.
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
had
the
curiosity
softly
to
raise
a
window
and
look
after
them
as
they
went
down
the
long
street
.
<EOS>
They
walked
arm
-
in
-
arm
,
showily
enough
,
but
without
appearing
to
interchange
a
syllable
.
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
fanciful
to
suppose
that
under
their
outer
bearing
there
was
something
of
the
shamed
air
of
two
cheats
who
were
linked
together
by
concealed
handcuffs
;
but
,
not
so
,
to
suppose
that
they
were
haggardly
weary
of
one
another
,
of
themselves
,
and
of
all
this
world
.
<EOS>
In
turning
the
street
corner
they
might
have
turned
out
of
this
world
,
for
anything
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
ever
saw
of
them
to
the
contrary
;
 
for
,
they
set
eyes
on
the
Lammles
never
more
.
   
<EOS>
THE
GOLDEN
DUSTMAN
SINKS
AGAIN
.
 
<EOS>
The
evening
of
that
day
being
one
of
the
reading
evenings
at
the
Bower
<EOS>
,
Mr.
Boffin
kissed
Mrs.
Boffin
after
a
five
o'clock
dinner
,
and
trotted
out
,
nursing
his
big
stick
in
both
arms
,
so
that
,
as
of
old
,
it
seemed
to
be
whispering
in
his
ear
.
<EOS>
He
carried
so
very
attentive
an
expression
on
his
countenance
that
it
appeared
as
if
the
confidential
discourse
of
the
big
stick
required
to
be
followed
closely
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
's
face
was
like
the
face
of
a
thoughtful
listener
to
an
intricate
communication
,
and
,
in
trotting
along
,
he
occasionally
glanced
at
that
companion
with
the
look
of
a
man
who
was
interposing
the
remark
:
"
<EOS>
You
do
n't
mean
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
and
his
stick
went
on
alone
together
,
until
they
arrived
at
certain
cross
-
ways
where
they
would
be
likely
to
fall
in
with
any
one
coming
,
at
about
the
same
time
,
from
Clerkenwell
to
the
Bower
.
<EOS>
Here
they
stopped
,
and
Mr.
Boffin
consulted
his
watch
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
wants
five
minutes
,
good
,
to
Venus
's
appointment
,
"
said
he
.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
rather
early
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Venus
was
a
punctual
man
,
and
,
even
as
Mr.
Boffin
replaced
his
watch
in
its
pocket
,
was
to
be
descried
coming
towards
him
.
<EOS>
He
quickened
his
pace
on
seeing
Mr.
Boffin
already
at
the
place
of
meeting
,
and
was
soon
at
his
side
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank'ee
,
Venus
,
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thank'ee
,
thank'ee
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
would
not
have
been
very
evident
why
he
thanked
the
anatomist
,
but
for
his
furnishing
the
explanation
in
what
he
went
on
to
say
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
right
,
Venus
,
all
right
.
<EOS>
Now
,
that
you
've
been
to
see
me
,
and
have
consented
to
keep
up
the
appearance
before
Wegg
of
remaining
in
it
for
a
time
<EOS>
,
I
have
got
a
sort

.
<EOS>
All
right
,
Venus
,
Thank'ee
,
Venus
.
<EOS>
Thank'ee
,
thank'ee
,
thank'ee
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
shook
the
proffered
hand
with
a
modest
air
,
and
they
pursued
the
direction
of
the
Bower
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
think
Wegg
is
likely
to
drop
down
upon
me
to
-
night
,
Venus
?
<EOS>
"
inquired

Boffin
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
he
is
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
you
any
particular

for
thinking

,
Venus
?
"
  
"
Well
,

,
"
returned
that

,
"
the

he
has
given

another
look
-
in
,
to
make

what
he

our
stock
-
in
-
trade
being

,
and

off

you
the

.
<EOS>
And
this
,
"
hinted

Venus
,

,
"
being
the
very
next

,
you

,

---
"
   
---
"
Why
,
therefore
you
suppose
he
'll
turn
to
at
the
grindstone
,
eh
,
Wegg
?
"
said
Mr.
Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
"
Just
so
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
took
his
nose
in
his
hand
,
as
if
it
were
already
excoriated
,
and
the
sparks
were
beginning
to
fly
out
of
that
feature
.
<EOS>
"
He
's
a
terrible
fellow
,
Venus
;
he
's
an
awful

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
ever
I
shall
go
through
with
it
.
<EOS>
You
must
stand
by
me
,
Venus
,
like
a

and
true
.
<EOS>
You
'll
do
all
you
can
to
stand
by
me
,
Venus
;
wo
n't
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
replied
with
the
assurance
that
he
would
;
and
Mr.
Boffin
,
looking

and

,
pursued
the
way
in
silence
until
they
rang
at
the
Bower
gate
.
<EOS>
The
stumping
approach
of
Wegg
was
soon
heard
behind
it
,
and
as
it
turned
upon
its
hinges
he
became
visible
with
his
hand
on
the
lock
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Boffin
,
sir
?
"
<EOS>
he
remarked
.
<EOS>
"
You
're
quite
a
stranger
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
've
been
otherwise
occupied
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
indeed
,
sir
?
"
returned
the
literary

with
a
threatening

.
"
<EOS>
Hah
!
<EOS>
I
've
been
looking
for
you
,
sir
,
<EOS>
rather
what
I
may
call
specially
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
say
so
,
Wegg
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
do
say
so
,
sir
.
<EOS>
And
if
you
had
n't
come
round
to
me
tonight
,
dash
my
wig
if
I
would
n't
have
come
round
to
you
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Now
!
<EOS>
I
tell

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
wrong
,
I

,
Wegg
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
no
,
Mr.
Boffin
,
"
was

ironical

.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
wrong
!
<EOS>
What
should
be
wrong
in
Boffinses
Bower
!
<EOS>
Step
in
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
    
<EOS>
`
`
If
you
'll
come
to
the
Bower
I
've
shaded
for

,
  
Your
bed
sha
n't
be
roses
all

with
doo
;
  
Will

,

,

,

?
  
<EOS>
Oh
,
wo
n't
you
,
wo
n't
you
,
wo
n't
you
,
<EOS>
wo
n't

,

the
Bower
?
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
An
unholy

of
contradiction
and

shone
in

Mr.

,

turned

key
on
his

,
after

into
the
yard
with
this
vocal

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
's
air
was
crestfallen
and
submissive
.
<EOS>
Whispered
Wegg
to
Venus
,
as
they
crossed
the
yard
behind
him
:
<EOS>
"
Look
at
the
worm
and
minion
;
he
's
down
in
the
mouth
already
.
"
<EOS>
Whispered
Venus
to
Wegg
:
<EOS>
"
That
's
because
I
've
told
him
.
<EOS>
I
've
prepared
the
way
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,
entering
the
usual
chamber
,
laid
his
stick
upon
the
settle
usually
reserved
for
him
,
thrust
his
hands
into
his
pockets
,
and
,
with
his
shoulders
raised
and
his
hat

back

,
looked

at
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
My
friend
and
partner
,
Mr.
Venus
,
gives
me

understand
,
"
remarked
that
man
of
might
,

,
"
that
you
are
aware
of
our
power
over
you
.
<EOS>
Now
,
when
you
have
took
your
hat
off
,
we
'll
go
into
that
pint
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
shook
it
off
with
one
shake
,
so
that
it
dropped
on
the
floor
behind
him
,
and
remained
in
his
former
attitude
with
his
former

look
upon

.
  
<EOS>
"
First
of
all
,
I
'm
a
-
going
to
call
you
Boffin
,
for
short
,
"
said
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
n't
like
it
,
it
's
open
to
you
to
lump

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
mind
it
,
Wegg
,
"
Mr.
Boffin
replied
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
lucky
for
you
,
Boffin
.
<EOS>
Now
,
do
you
want

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
particularly
care
about
it
to
-
night
,
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
if
you
did
want
to
,
"
pursued
Mr.
Wegg
,
the
brilliancy
of
whose
point
was
dimmed
by
his
having
been
unexpectedly
answered
:
"
you
would
n't
be
.
<EOS>
I
've
been
your
slave
long
enough
.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
to
be
trampled
under
-
foot
by
a
dustman
any
more
.
<EOS>
With
the
single
exception
of
the
salary
,
I
renounce

whole
and
total
sitiwation
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Since
you
say
it
is
to
be
so
<EOS>
,
Wegg
,
"
returned
Mr.
Boffin
,
with
folded

,
"
<EOS>
I
suppose
it
must
be
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
it
must
be
,
"
Wegg
retorted
.
<EOS>
"
Next
(
to
clear
the
ground
before
coming
to
business
)
,
you
've
placed
in
this
yard
a
skulking
,

,

a

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
had
n't
a

I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Boffin
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Wegg
<EOS>
,
"
I
warn

not
to

!
"
  
<EOS>
Here
Mr.
Venus
interposed
,
and
remarked
that
he
conceived
Mr.
Boffin
to
have
taken

description
literally
;
the
rather
,
forasmuch
as

,
Mr.
Venus
,

himself

nose
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Any
how
,

how
,
"

,
"
he
has

,
and

is
here
.
<EOS>
Now
,
I
wo
n't

.
<EOS>
So

call

Boffin
,
before

another

,
to
fetch

in
and
send

packing
to
the
right
-
about
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
unsuspecting
Sloppy
was
at
that

airing
his
many
buttons
within
view

the
window
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
call
upon
Boffin
,
"

,
with

-

,

,
"
to

that
I

Master

!
"
  
<EOS>
In

,
when
the
button

Sloppy
entered

:
"

,

,

is

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
For

!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
For
good
,
"
said

Boffin
.
  
<EOS>
Sloppy

,

,

<EOS>
"
The

<EOS>
Boffin

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

,
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

)

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Wegg
!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dreadful
,

,

!
<EOS>
I

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,

;

.
<EOS>
You
've

.
<EOS>
You
've

seen

of

this

.
<EOS>
Two

at
the
present

brought

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

,
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,

,

,

,
nothing

,
Wegg
;
upon

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Prepared
,
Mr.

,
"

,

,
"
for

,

.
<EOS>
We

against

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Boffin
drew

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
Boffin
;

's

.
<EOS>
In

is

,

.
<EOS>
It
wo
n't

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Rokesmith

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Already

,
is

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
Then
,
Boffin
,
I

's

present
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
unlucky
gentleman
continuing
to
rock

to
and
fro
,
and
to
utter
an

,
Mr.
Venus
besought
him
to
bear
up
against

,
and
to
take
time
to
accustom

to
the
thought
of
his
new

.
<EOS>
But
,
his
taking

was
exactly
the
thing
of
all
others
that
Silas
Wegg
could
not
be
induced
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
or
no
,
and
no
half
measures
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
motto
which
that
obdurate
person
many
times
repeated
;
shaking
his
fist
at
Mr.
Boffin
,
and
rate
person
many
times
repeated
;
shaking
his
fist
at
Mr.
Boffin
,
and
pegging
his
motto
into
the
floor
with
his
wooden
leg
,
in
a
threatening
and
alarming
manner
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
,
Mr.
Boffin
entreated
to
be
allowed
a
quarter
of
an
hour
's
grace
,
and
a
cooling
walk
of
that
duration
in
the
yard
.
<EOS>
With
some
difficulty
Mr.
Wegg
granted
this
great
favour
,
but
only
on
condition
that
he
accompanied
Mr.
Boffin
in
his
walk
,
as
not
knowing
what
he
might
fraudulently
unearth
if
he
were
left
to
himself
.
<EOS>
A
more
absurd
sight
,
than
Mr.
Boffin
in
his
mental
irritation
trotting
very
nimbly
,
and
Mr.
Wegg
hopping
after
him
with
great
exertion
,
eager
to
watch
the
slightest
turn
of
an
eyelash
,
lest
it
should
indicate
a
spot
rich
with
some
secret
,
assuredly
had
never
been
seen
in
the
shadow
of
the
Mounds
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
was
much
distressed
when
the
quarter
of
an
hour
expired
,
and
came
hopping
in
,
a
very
bad
second
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
help
myself
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Mr.
Boffin
,
flouncing
on
the
settle
in
a
forlorn
manner
,
with
his
hands
deep
in
his
pockets
,
as
if
his
pockets
had
sunk
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
's
the
good
of
my
pretending
to
stand
out
,
when
I
ca
n't
help
myself
?
<EOS>
I
must
give
in
to
the
terms
.
<EOS>
But
I
should
like
to
see
the
document
.
"
  
<EOS>
Wegg
,
who
was
all
for
clinching
the
nail
he
had
so
strongly
driven
home
,
announced
that
Boffin
should
see
it
without
an
hour
's
delay
.
<EOS>
Taking
him
into
custody
for
that
purpose
,
or
overshadowing
him
as
if
he
really
were
his
Evil
Genius
in
visible
form
,
Mr.
Wegg
clapped
Mr.
Boffin
's
hat
upon
the
back
of
his
head
,
and
walked
him
out
by
the
arm
,
asserting
a
proprietorship
over
his
soul
and
body
that
was
at
once
more
grim
and
more
ridiculous
than
anything
in
Mr.
Venus
's
rare
collection
.
<EOS>
That
light
-
haired
gentleman
followed
close
upon
their
heels
,
at
least
backing
up
Mr.
Boffin
in
a
literal
sense
if
he
had
not
had
recent
opportunities
of
doing
so
spiritually
;
while
Mr.
Boffin
,
trotting
on
as
hard
as
he
could
trot
,
involved
Silas
Wegg
in
frequent
collisions
with
the
public
,
much
as
a
pre
-
occupied
blind
man
's
dog
may
be
seen
to
involve
his
master
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
they
reached
Mr.
Venus
's
establishment
,
somewhat
heated
by
the
nature
of
their
progress
thither
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wegg
,
especially
,
was
in
a
flaming
glow
,
and
stood
in
the
little
shop
,
panting
and
mopping
his
head
with
his
pocket
-
handkerchief
,
speechless
for
several
minutes
.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
Mr.
Venus
,
who
had
left
the
duelling
frogs
to
fight
it
out
in
his
absence
by
candlelight
for
the
public
delectation
,
put
the
shutters
up
.
<EOS>
When
all
was
snug
,
and
the
shop
-
door
fastened
,
he
said
to
the
perspiring
Silas
:
"
I
suppose
,
Mr.
Wegg
,
we
may
now
produce
the
paper
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
on
a
minute
,
sir
,
"
replied
that
discreet
character
;
"
hold
on
a
minute
.
<EOS>
Will
you
obligingly

that
box
---
which
you
mentioned
on
a
former

as
containing

---
towards
me

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Venus
did

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

:
"
ve
---
<EOS>
ry

.
<EOS>
Will

,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
Venus

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now

,
"

,
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

"

"

here

"

<EOS>
Venus

"
<EOS>

,
"

"

.

<EOS>

,

,

Bof

fin

,

.

.
  
<EOS>
"
Bof
---
fin
!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

---

<EOS>

:

Bof
---
fin
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This

,
but

at

outside

,
while
Mr.
Boffin
stooped
at
it
within
;
he
then
laughed

,
and
stumped
home
.
   
<EOS>
A
RUNWAY
MATCH
.
 
<EOS>
Cherubic
Pa
arose
with
as
little
noise
as
possible
from
beside
majestic
Ma
,
one
morning
early
,
having
a
holiday
before
him
.
<EOS>
Pa
and
the
lovely
woman
had
a
rather
particular
appointment
to
keep
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
Pa
and
the
lovely
woman
were
not
going
out
together
.
<EOS>
Bella
was
up
before
four
,
but
had
no
bonnet
on
.
<EOS>
she
was
waiting
at
the
foot
of
the
stairs
---
was
sitting
on
the
bottom
stair
,
in
fact
---
to
receive
Pa
when
he
came
down
,
but
her
only
object
seemed
to
be
to
get
Pa
well
out
of
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
"
Your
breakfast
is
ready
,
sir
,
"
whispered
Bella
,
after
greeting
him
with
a
hug
,
"
and
all
you
have
to
do
,
is
,
to
eat
it
up
and
drink
it
up
,
and
escape
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
feel
,
Pa
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
the
best
of
my
judgment
,
like
a
housebreaker
new
to
the
business
,
my
dear
,
who
ca
n't
make
himself
quite
comfortable
till
he
is
off
the
premises
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
tucked
her
arm
in
his
with
a
merry
noiseless
laugh
,
and
they
went
down
to
the
kitchen
on
tiptoe
;
she
stopping
on
every
separate
stair
to
put
the
tip
of
her
forefinger
on
her
rosy
lips
,
and
then
lay
it
on
his
lips
,
according
to
her
favourite
petting
way
of
kissing
Pa.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
feel
,
my
love
?
"
asked
R.
W.
,
as
she
gave
him
his
breakfast
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
feel
as
if
the
Fortune
-
teller
was
coming
true
,
dear
Pa
,
and
the
fair
little
man
was
turning
out
as
was
predicted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ho
!
<EOS>
Only
the
fair
little
man
?
"
said
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
Bella
put
another
of
those
finger
-
seals
upon
his
lips
,
and
then
said
,
kneeling
down
by
him
as
he
sat
at
table
:
"
<EOS>
Now
,
look
here
,

.
<EOS>
If
you
keep

mark
this

,

?
<EOS>
What

I

have
,
if

,
upon
a
certain

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon
my
word
I
do
n't
remember
,
Precious
.
<EOS>
Yes
,
I
do
,
though
.
<EOS>
Was
n't

one
of
these
beau
---
tiful
tresses
?
"
with
his

upon

.
  
<EOS>
"
Was

it
,
too
!
"
returned
Bella
,

.
"
<EOS>
Upon

!
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Near

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Ah

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
"

"

---
"

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
Would

I
---
<EOS>
"
  
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
So

,
and
Pa
,

.
<EOS>
When

a

,

.
<EOS>
Upon

,
Bella
set
another
of
those
finger

upon

,
and

her
little

expressive
of

mark
.
<EOS>
Pa
,
in
appropriate
action
,
expressed
fidelity
to
the
mark
,
and
made
off
as
fast
as
he

.
  
<EOS>
Bella
walked
thoughtfully
in
the

for
an

,
and

,

where

the

.
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
Behold

girl

!
<EOS>
Behold

.
<EOS>
Behold

.
  
<EOS>
Were

?
<EOS>
Probably
.
<EOS>
At

,

John

<EOS>
but

)

.
<EOS>
Probably
.
<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
Probably
.
<EOS>
At

's

,
without

.
<EOS>
Two

had
this

,

through

's
,

.
<EOS>
Stranded
was

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Say
,
cherubic

,

?
<EOS>
With

R.
W.
<EOS>
There

"

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
For

,

,

.
<EOS>
Some

,

.
<EOS>
Be

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

went

,
all

;
Bella

Rokesmith

;
Gruff

.
<EOS>
For

,

;

Bella

per

,

.
  
<EOS>
He
was
a

,

for

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
And

?
"
<EOS>
on

,

.
  
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
I

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

Forasmuch
,

<EOS>
To

,

And

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
After

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Dearest

,
  
"
I

wo

,

I

John
Rokesmith
,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
Please

,
  
"

,

,

<EOS>
(

---

)
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Then
,

---
when
had
Her

!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
and

Bella

into

,

,
"
Now
,

Pa
,
you
are

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
Pa

,

,

,
so

,

,

-

from

,

of
the
Astronomer
Royal
nightly
outwatch

.
<EOS>
But
,
the

on
and
no
Mrs.
Wilfer
in
the

,
he
became
more

,
and
so

with

and

to
Mr.
and
Mrs.
John
Rokesmith
's
cottage
on
Blackheath
,
where

was
ready
.
  
<EOS>
A
modest
little
cottage
but
a
bright
and
a
fresh
,
and
on
the
snowy
tablecloth
the
prettiest
of
little

.
<EOS>
In

,
too
,
like
an
attendant

,
a

damsel
,
all

and

,
blushing
as
if

had
been

Bella
,
and
yet
asserting
the

of
her
sex
over
both

Pa
,
in
an

:
as
who

,
"
This

you
must

,

,

book
.
"
 
<EOS>
This
same
young
damsel
was
Bella
's
serving
-
maid
,
and
unto

did
deliver
a

,

in
the
way
of

,

,

,
the
investigation
of
which
made
pastime
after

,
when
Bella
declared
that
"
Pa
must
taste
everything
,
John
dear
,
or
it
will
never
be
lucky
,
"
and
when
Pa
had
all
sorts
of
things
poked
into
his
mouth
,
and
did
n't

know
what
to
do
with
them
when
they
were
put
there
.
  
<EOS>
Then
they
,
all
three
,
out
for
a
charming
ride
,
and
for
a
charming
stroll
among
heath
in
bloom
,
and
there
behold
the
identical
Gruff
and
Glum
with
his
wooden
legs
horizontally
disposed
before
him
,
apparently
sitting
meditating
on
the
vicissitudes
of
life
!
<EOS>
To
whom
said
Bella
,
in
her
light
-
hearted
surprise
:
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
How
do
you
do
again
?
<EOS>
What
a
dear
old
pensioner
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
To
which
Gruff
and
Glum
responded
that
he
see
her
married
this
morning
,
my
Beauty
,
and
that
if
it
warn't
a
liberty
he
wished
her
ji
and
the
fairest
of
fair
wind
and
weather
;
<EOS>
further
,
in
a
general
way
requesting
to
know
what
cheer
?
and
scrambling
up
on
his
two
wooden
legs
to
salute
,
hat
in
hand
,
ship
-
shape
,
with
the
gallantry
of
a
man
-
of
-
warsman
and
a
heart
of
oak
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
pleasant
sight
,
in
the
midst
of
the
golden
bloom
,
to
see
this
salt
old
Gruff
and
Glum
,
waving
his
shovel
hat
at
Bella
,
while
his
thin
white
hair
flowed
free
,
as
if
she
had
once
more
launched
him
into
blue
water
again
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
a
charming
old
pensioner
,
"
said
Bella
,
"
and
I
am
so
happy
that
I
wish
I
could
make
you
happy
,
too
.
"
<EOS>
Answered
Gruff
and
Glum
,
"
<EOS>
Give
me
leave
to
kiss
your
hand
,
my
Lovely
,
and
it
's
done
!
"
<EOS>
So
it
was
done
to
the
general
contentment
;
and
if
Gruff
and
Glum
did
n't
in
the
course
of
the
afternoon
splice
<EOS>
the
main
brace
,
it
was
not
for
want
of
the
means
of
inflicting
that
outrage
on
the
feelings
of
the
Infant
Bands
of
Hope
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
the
marriage
dinner
was
the
crowning
success
,
for
what
had
bride
and
bridegroom
plotted
to
do
,
but
to
have
and
to
hold
that
dinner
in
the
very
room
of
the
very
hotel
where
Pa
and
the
lovely
woman
had
once
dined
together
!
<EOS>
Bella
sat
between
Pa
and
John
,
and
divided
her
attentions
pretty
equally
,
but
felt
it
necessary
(
in
the
waiter
's
absence
before

)
to
remind
Pa
that
she
was
his
lovely
woman
no
longer
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
well
aware
of
it
,
my
dear
,
"
returned
the
cherub
,
"
and
I
resign
you
willingly
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Willingly
,
sir
?
<EOS>
You
ought
to
be
brokenhearted
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
So
I
should
be
,
my
dear
,
<EOS>
if
I
thought
that
I
was
going
to
lose
you
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
know
you
are
not
;
do

,
poor

Pa
?
<EOS>
You
know
that
you
have
only

new

who
will
be
as

you
and
as

---
for
my

own

---
  
as
I
am
;
do

you
,
dear
little
Pa
?
<EOS>
Look
here
,
Pa
!
"
<EOS>
Bella
put
her
finger
on
her
own

,
and
then
on
Pa
's
,
and
then
on
her
own
lip
again
,
and
then
on
her
husband
's
.
"
<EOS>
Now
,
we
are
a
partnership
of
three
,
dear
<EOS>
Pa.
"
  
The
appearance
of
dinner
here
cut
Bella
short
in
one
of
her
disappearances
:
the
more
effectually
,
because
it
was
put
on
under
the
auspices
of
a
solemn
gentleman
in
black
clothes
and
a
white
cravat
,
who
looked
much
more
like
a
clergyman
than
the
clergyman
,
and
seemed
to
have
mounted
a
great
deal
higher
in
the
church
:
not
to
say
,
scaled
the
steeple
.
<EOS>
This
dignitary
,
conferring
in
secrecy
with
John
Rokesmith
on
the
subject
of
punch
and
wines
,
bent
his
head
as
though
stooping
to
the
Papistical
practice
of
receiving
auricular

.
<EOS>
Likewise
,
on
John
's
offering
a
suggestion
which
did
n't
meet
his
views
,
his
face
became
overcast
and
reproachful
,
as
enjoining
penance
.
  
<EOS>
What
a
dinner
!
<EOS>
Specimens
of
all
the
fishes
that
swim
in
the
sea
,
surely
had
swum
their
way
to
it
,
and
if
samples
of
the
fishes
of
divers
colours
that
made
a
speech
in
the
Arabian
Nights
(
quite
a
ministerial
explanation
in
respect
of
cloudiness
)
,
and
then
jumped
out
of
the
frying
-
pan
,
were
not
to
be
recognized
,
it
was
only
because
they
had
all
become
of
one
hue
by
being
cooked
in
batter
among
the
whitebait
.
<EOS>
And
the
dishes
being
seasoned
with
Bliss
---
an
article
which
they
are
sometimes
out
of
,
at
Greenwich
---
were
of
perfect
flavour
,
and
the
golden
drinks
had
been
bottled
in
the
golden
age
and
hoarding
up
their
sparkles
ever
since
.
  
<EOS>
The
best
of
it
was
,
that
Bella
and
John
and
the
cherub
had
made
a
covenant
that
they
would
not
reveal
to
mortal
eyes
any
appearance
<EOS>
whatever
of
being
a
wedding
party
.
<EOS>
Now
,
the
supervising
dignitary
,
the
Archbishop
of
Greenwich
,
knew
this
as
well
as
if
he
had
performed
the

.
<EOS>
And
the
loftiness
with
which
his
Grace
entered
into
their
confidence
without
being

,
and
insisted
on
a
show
of
keeping
the
waiters
out
of
it
,
was
the
crowning
glory
of
the
entertainment
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
an
innocent
young
waiter
of
a
slender
form
and
with
weakish
legs
,
as
yet
unversed
in
the
wiles
of
of
waiterhood
,
and
<EOS>
but
too
evidently
of
a
romantic

,
and
deeply
(
it
were
not
too
much
to
add

)
in
love
with
some
young
female
not
aware
of
his
merit
.
<EOS>
This
guileless
youth
,
descrying
the
position
of
affairs
,
which
even
his
innocence
could
not
mistake
,
limited
his
waiting
to
languishing
admiringly
against
the
sideboard
when
Bella
did
n't
want
anything
,
and
swooping
at
her
when
she
did
.
<EOS>
Him
,
his
Grace
the
Archbishop
perpetually
obstructed
,
cutting
him
out
with
his
elbow
in
the
moment
of
success
,
despatching
him
in
degrading
quest
of
melted
butter
,
and
,
when
by
any
chance
he
got
hold
of
any
dish
worth
having
,
bereaving
him
of
it
,
and
ordering
him
to
stand
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
excuse
him
,
madam
,
"
said
the
Archbishop
in
a
low

;
"
he
is
a
very
young
man
on
liking
,
and
we
do
n't
like
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
induced
John
Rokesmith
to
observe
---
by
way

making
the
thing
more
natural
<EOS>
---
"
Bella
,
my
love
,
this

any

past

,
that
I
think

must
keep

future

here
.
"
  
<EOS>
Whereunto

,
with

looking

that
ever

:
"
<EOS>
Indeed
,
I

,
John
,
dear
.
"
  
<EOS>
Here
the
Archbishop
of
Greenwich
coughed
a
stately

to
attract
the
attention
of
three
of
his
ministers
present
,
and
staring
at

,
seemed

:
"
I
call

your

to
believe

!
"
  
<EOS>
With

he
afterwards

,
as

,
<EOS>
"
The

in
our

,
"
and
would

from

misguided

of
the
young
man
on

.
<EOS>
He
finding
,
by
ill
-

,
a

somewhere

now
approached
undetected
with
the
same
in
a

,
and
placed

's
right

.
<EOS>
The

instantly
ejected

;
but
the

done
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
trust
,

,
"

,

"

,

a
very

man
who
is

here
on
liking
,
and
who
will
never

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

solemnly

,
and

,
long

.
<EOS>
"
Disguise
is

,
"
said

;
 
"
they
all
find
me
out
;
I
think

must
be
,
Pa

John
dear
,
because
I
look
so

!
"
  
<EOS>
Her

on

,

;

<EOS>
"
You

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
"
  
"
Is

,

,

Pa
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Pa
!
<EOS>
Not

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

dear
.
<EOS>
How

coming
people
are
aboard

!
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
remaining
invisible

,
her

at

and

,
until

remembered

.
<EOS>
"
Though
I

can
not

,
"
 
he

"
---

a
sin
---
without

to
many
,
many
happy

of
this
most
happy

.
"
  
"
Hear
!
<EOS>
ten

times
!
<EOS>
"
cried

.
<EOS>
"
I
fill
my
glass
and
my
precious
wife
's
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Gentlemen
,
"
said

,

,
in

Anglo

Saxon

,
the
boys
down
below
,
who
were

:
"
Gentlemen
---
and
Bella

John
---
  
<EOS>
you

it

.
<EOS>
You

I

.
<EOS>
Gentlemen
---

Bella

John
---
  
<EOS>
the

is
an

.
<EOS>
But
gentlemen
---
and
Bella
and
John
 
---
for
the

I

,

,

,

<EOS>
Gentlemen
---

John
---
my

,

,
as
on

,
on

<EOS>
;
that

,
gentlemen
---
and
Bella

John
---
on
many

the
present

.
"
  
<EOS>
Having

,
the
amiable

embraced
his
daughter
,
and
took

flight
to

which
was
to

to
London
,
and
was

lying

,

bits
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
happy
couple
were
not
going

part

him
in

way
,
and

on

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Pa
,
dear
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Bella
,
beckoning
him
with
her
parasol
to
approach

side
,
and
bending

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
darling
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
beat
you
much
with
that
horrid
little
bonnet
,
Pa
?
"
  
"
Nothing
to
speak

,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
pinch
your

,
Pa
?
"
  
"
Only
nicely
,
my
pet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
sure
you
quite
forgive

,
Pa
?
<EOS>
Please
,
Pa
,
please
,

!
"
<EOS>
Half

half

,
Bella

in
the

;
in
a

,
that
her

parent
made

as
if

never

,

,
"
What

Mouse

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

;

,
Pa
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

do

,

;

,
Pa
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lord

!
<EOS>
No
,

Life
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
-

,

pa
.
<EOS>
Good
-

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good

,

!
<EOS>
Take

,

.
<EOS>
Take

!
"
  
<EOS>
So
,
she

her

,
they

homeward
by
a

which
the

out

in
its

.
<EOS>
And
O
there
are
days
in
this
life
,
worth
life
and
worth
death
.
<EOS>
And
O
what
a
bright
old
song
it
is
,
that
O
'
tis
love
,
'
tis
love
,
'
tis
love
that
makes
the
world
go
round
!
   
<EOS>
CONCERNING
THE
MENDICANT
'S
BRIDE
.
 
<EOS>
The
impressive
gloom
with
which
Mrs.
Wilfer
received
her
husband
on
his
return
from
the
wedding
,
knocked
so
hard
at
the
door
of
the
cherubic
conscience
,
and
likewise
so
impaired
the
firmness
of
the
cherubic
legs
,
that
the
culprit
's
tottering
condition
of
mind
and
body
might
have
roused
suspicion
in
less
occupied
persons
than
the
grimly
heroic
lady
,
Miss
Lavinia
,
and
that
esteemed
friend
of
the
family
,
Mr.
George
Sampson
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
attention
of
all
three
being
fully
possessed
by
the
main
fact
of
the
marriage
,
they
had
happily
none
to
bestow
on
the
guilty
conspirator
;
to
which
fortunate
circumstance
he
owed
the
escape
for
which
he
was
in
nowise
indebted
to
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
not
,
R.
W.
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
from
her
stately
corner
,
"
inquire
for
your
daughter
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
,
my
dear
,
"
he
returned
,
with
a
most
flagrant
assumption
of
unconsciousness
,
"
I
did
omit
it
.
<EOS>
How
---
or
perhaps
I
should
rather
say
where
---
is
Bella
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
here
,
"
Mrs.
Wilfer
proclaimed
,
with
folded
arms
.
  
<EOS>
The
cherub
faintly
muttered
something
to
the
abortive
effect
of
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
indeed
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
here
,
"
repeated
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
in
a
stern
sonorous
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
a
word
,
R.
W.
,
you
have
no
daughter
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
No
daughter
Bella
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
Your
daughter
Bella
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
with
a
lofty
air
of
never
having
had
the
least
copartnership
in
that
young
lady
:
of
whom
she
now
made
reproachful
mention
as
an
article
of
luxury
which
her
husband
had
set
up
entirely
on
his
own
account
,
and
in
direct
opposition
to
her
advice
:
"
---
your
daughter
Bella
has
bestowed
herself
upon
a
Mendicant
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
,
my
dear
!
"
  
"
Show
your
father
his
daughter
Bella
's
letter
,
Lavinia
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
in
her
monotonous
Act
of
Parliament
tone
,
and
waving
her
hand
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
your
father
will
admit
it
to
be
documentary
proof
of
what
I
tell
him
.
<EOS>
I
believe
your
father
is
acquainted
with
his
daughter
Bella
's
writing
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
not
know
.
<EOS>
He
may
tell
you
he
is
not
.
<EOS>
Nothing
will
surprise
me
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Posted
at
Greenwich
,
and
dated
this
'
morning
,
"
said
the
Irrepressible
,
flouncing
at
her
father
in
handing
him
the
evidence
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hopes
Ma
wo
n't
be
angry
,
but
is
happily
married
to
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
,
and
did
n't
mention
it
beforehand
to
avoid
words
,
and
please
tell
darling
you
,
and
love
to
me
,
and
I
should
like
to
know
what
you
'd
have
said
if
any
other
unmarried
member
of
the
family
had
done
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
read
the
letter
,
and
faintly
exclaimed
"
Dear
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
well
say
Dear
me
!
"
<EOS>
rejoined
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
in
a
deep
tone
.
<EOS>
Upon
which
encouragement
he
said
it
again
,
though
scarcely
with
the
success
he
had
expected
;
for
the
scornful
lady
then
remarked
,
with
extreme
bitterness
:
"
<EOS>
You
said
that
before
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
very
surprising
.
<EOS>
But
I
suppose
,
my
dear
,
"
hinted
the
cherub
,
as
he
folded
the
letter
after
a

,
"
that
we
must
make
the
best
of
it
?
<EOS>
Would
you
object
to
my
pointing
out
,
my
dear
,
that
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
is
not
(
so
far
as
I
am
acquainted
with
him
)
,
strictly
speaking
,
a
Mendicant
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Indeed
?
"
returned
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
with
an
awful
air
of
politeness
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Truly
so
?
<EOS>
I
was
not
aware
that
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
was
a
gentleman
of
landed
property
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
much
relieved
to
hear
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
doubt
if
you
have
heard
it
,
my
dear
,
"
the
cherub
submitted
with
hesitation
.
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
"
I
make
false
statements
,
it
appears
?
<EOS>
So
be
it
.
<EOS>
If
my
daughter
flies
in
my
face
,
surely
my
husband
may
.
<EOS>
The
one
thing
is
not
more
unnatural
than
the
other
.
<EOS>
There
seems
a
fitness
in
the
arrangement
.
<EOS>
By
all
means
!
"
 
<EOS>
Assuming
,
with
a
shiver
of
resignation
,
a
deadly
cheerfulness
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
here
the
Irrepressible
skirmished
into
the
conflict
,
dragging
the
reluctant
form
of
Mr.
Sampson
after
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ma
,
"
interposed
the
young
lady
,
"
I
must
say
I
think
it
would
be
much
better
if
you
would
keep
to
the
point
,
and
not
hold
forth
about
people
's
flying
into
people
's
faces
,
which
is
nothing
more
nor
less
than
impossible
nonsense
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
How
!
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
knitting
her
dark
brows
.
  
<EOS>
"
Just
im
-
possible
nonsense
,
Ma
,
"
returned
Lavvy
,
"
and
George
Sampson
knows
it
is
,
as
well
as
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
suddenly
becoming
petrified
,
fixed
her
indignant
eyes
upon
the
wretched
George
:
who
,
divided
between
the
support
due
from
him
to
his
love
,
and
the
support
due
from
him
to
his
love
's
mamma
,
supported
nobody
,
not
even
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
true
point
is
,
"
pursued
Lavinia
,
"
that
Bella
has
behaved
in
a
most
unsisterly
way
to
me
,
and
might
have
severely
compromised
me
with
George
and
with
George
's
family
,
by
making
off
and
getting
married
in
this
very
low

disreputable

---
with
some
pew

opener
or
other
,
I
suppose
,
for
a

---
when
she
ought
to
have
confided

me
,
and
ought
to
have
said
,
`
`
If
,
Lavvy
,
you
consider

due
to
your
engagement
with
George
,
that
you
should

by
being
present
,
then
Lavvy
,
I
beg
you
to
be
present
,
keeping
my
secret
from
Ma
and
Pa.
"
<EOS>
"
As
of
course
I
should
have
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
of
course
you
would
have
done
?
<EOS>
Ingrate
!
<EOS>
"
exclaimed
Mrs.
Wilfer
.
<EOS>
"
Viper
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
!
<EOS>
You
know
ma'am
.
<EOS>
Upon
my
honor
you
must
n't
,
"
 
Mr.
Sampson
remonstrated
,
shaking
his

seriously
,
"
With
the
highest
respect
for
you
,
ma'am
,
upon
my
life
you
must
n't
.
<EOS>
No

,
you
know
.
<EOS>
When
a
man
with

of
a
gentleman
finds

,
and
it
comes
(
even

)
to

,
you
know
!
<EOS>
---
I
would

it
to
your
own
good
feeling
,
you
know
,
"
said
Mr.
Sampson
,
in
rather
lame

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
's
baleful
stare
at
the
young
gentleman
in
acknowledgment
of
his
obliging
interference
was
of
such
a
nature
that
Miss
Lavinia
burst
into
tears
,
and
caught
him
round
the
neck
for
his
protection
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
own
unnatural
mother
,
"
screamed
the
young
lady
,
"
wants
to
annihilate
George
!
<EOS>
But
you
sha
n't
be
annihilated
,
George
.
<EOS>
I
'll
die
first
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Sampson
,
in
the
arms
of
his
mistress
,
still
struggled
to
shake
his
head
at
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
and
to

:
"
With
every
sentiment
of
respect
for
you
,
you
know
,
ma'am
---
vipers
really
does
n't
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not

annihilated
,
George
!
"
<EOS>

Lavinia
.
<EOS>
"
Ma
shall
destroy
me
first
,
and
then
she
'll
be
contented
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
oh
,
<EOS>
oh
!
<EOS>
Have

George
from

happy

to

!
<EOS>
George
,
dear
,

!
<EOS>
Leave
me
,
ever

George
,
to
Ma
and
to
my

.
<EOS>
Give
my
love
to
your
aunt
,
George
dear
,
and

to
curse
the
viper
that
has
crossed

and
blighted

existence
.
<EOS>
Oh
,
oh
,
oh
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
young
lady
who
,
hysterically
speaking
,
was
only
just
come
of
age
,
and
had
never
gone
off
yet
,
here
fell
into
a
highly
creditable
crisis
,
which
,
regarded
as
a
first
performance
,
was
very
successful
;
Mr.
Sampson
,
bending
over
the
body
meanwhile
,
in
a
state
of
distraction
,
which
induced
him
to
address
Mrs.
Wilfer
in
the
inconsistent
expressions
:
  
"
Demon
---
with
the
highest
respect
for
you
---
behold
your
work
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
cherub
stood
helplessly
rubbing
his
chin
and
looking
on
,
but
on
the
whole
was
inclined
to
welcome
this
diversion
as
one
in
which
,
by
reason
of
the
absorbent
properties
of
hysterics
,
the
previous
question
would
become
absorbed
.
<EOS>
And
so
,
indeed
,
it
proved
,
for
the
Irrepressible
gradually
coming
to
herself
,
and
asking
with
wild
emotion
,
"
George
dear
,
are
you
safe
?
"
and
further
,
"
<EOS>
George
love
,
what
has
happened
?
<EOS>
Where
is
Ma
?
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Sampson
,
with
words
of
comfort
,
raised
her
prostrate
form
,
and
handed
her
to
Mrs.
Wilfer
as
if
the
young
lady
were
something
in
the
nature
of
refreshments
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
with
dignity
partaking
of
the
refreshments
,
by
kissing
her
once
on
the
brow
(
as
if
accepting
an
oyster
)
,
Miss
Lavvy
,
tottering
,
returned
to
the
protection
of
Mr.
Sampson
;
to
whom
she
said
,
"
George
dear
,
I
am
afraid
I
have
been
foolish
;
but
I
am
still
a
little
weak
and
giddy
;
do
n't
let
go
my
hand
,
George
!
"
<EOS>
And
whom
she
afterwards
greatly
agitated
at
intervals
,
by
giving
utterance
,
when
least
expected
,
to
a
sound
between
a
sob
and
a
bottle
of
soda
water
,
that
seemed
to
rend
the
bosom
of
her
frock
.
  
<EOS>
Among
the
most
remarkable
effects
of
this
crisis
may
be
mentioned
its
having
,
when
peace
was
restored
,
an
inexplicable
moral
influence
,
of
an
elevating
kind
,
on
Miss
Lavinia
,
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
and
Mr.
George
Sampson
,
from
which
R.
W.
was
altogether
excluded
,
as
an
outsider
and
non
-
sympathizer
.
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
assumed
a
modest
air
of
having
distinguished
herself
;
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
a
serene
air
of
forgiveness
and
resignation
;
Mr.
Sampson
,
an
air
of
having
been
improved
and
chastened
.
<EOS>
The
influence
pervaded
the
spirit
in
which
they
returned
to
the
previous
question
.
  
<EOS>
"
George
dear
,
"
said
Lavvy
,
with
a
melancholy
smile
,
"
after
what
has
passed
,
I
am
sure
Ma
will
tell
Pa
that
he
may
tell
Bella
we
shall
all
be
glad
to
see
her
and
her
husband
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Sampson
said
he
was
sure
of
it
too
;
murmuring
how
eminently
he
respected
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
and
ever
must
,
and
ever
would
.
<EOS>
Never
more
eminently
,
he
added
,
than
after
what
had
passed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Far
be
it
from
me
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
making
deep
proclamation
from
her
corner
,
"
to
run
counter
to
the
feelings
of
a
child
of
mine
,
and
of
a
Youth
<EOS>
,
"
Mr.
Sampson
hardly
seemed
to
like
that
word
,
"
who
is
the
object
of
her
maiden
preference
.
<EOS>
I
may
feel
---
nay
,
know
---
that
I
have

.
<EOS>
I
may
feel
---
nay
,
know
---
that
I
have
been

and
passed

.
<EOS>
I
may
feel
---
  
<EOS>
nay
,

---
that
after

so

my

towards
Mr.

Boffin
as

,

's
,
"

"

,

your
daughter
Bella
,
"
again

,
"

in
a
worldly

view

a

,

.
<EOS>
I

---
nay
,

that

Rokesmith
she

,

,
a
Mendicant
.
<EOS>
And
I
may

well

that
your
daughter
Bella
,
"
again

,
"
does

by

a
Mendicant
's

.
<EOS>
But
I
suppress
what
I
feel
,
and
say
nothing
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Sampson
murmured
that
this
was
the
sort
of
thing
you
might
expect
from
one
who
had
ever
in
her
own
family
been
an
example
and
never
an
outrage
.
<EOS>
And
ever
more
so
(
Mr.
Sampson
added
,
with
some
degree
of
obscurity
,
)
and
never
more
so
,
than
in
and
through
what
had
passed
.
<EOS>
He
must
take
the
liberty
of
adding
,
that
what
was
true
of
the
mother
was
true
of
the
youngest
daughter
,
and
that
he
could
never
forget
the
touching
feelings
that
the
conduct
of
both
had
awakened
within
him
.
<EOS>
In
conclusion
,
he
did
hope
that
there
was
n't
a
man
with
a
beating
heart
who
was
capable
of
something
that
remained
undescribed
,
in
consequence
of
Miss
Lavinia
's
stopping
him
as
he
reeled
in
his
speech
.
  
<EOS>
"
Therefore
,
R.
W.
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
resuming
her
discourse
and
turning
to
her
lord
again
,
"
let
your
daughter
Bella
come
when
she
will
,
and
she
will
be
received
.
<EOS>
So
,
"
after
a
short
pause
,
and
an
air
of
having
taken
medicine
in
it
,
"
so
will
her
husband
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
beg
,
Pa
,
"
said
Lavinia
,
"
that
you
will
not
tell
Bella
what
I
have
undergone
.
<EOS>
It
can
do
no
good
,
and
it
might
cause
her
to
reproach
herself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dearest
girl
,
"
urged
Mr.
Sampson
,
"
she
ought
to
know
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
George
,
"
said
Lavinia
,
in
a
tone
of
resolute
self
-
denial
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
dearest
George
,
let
it
be
buried
in
oblivion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Sampson
considered
that
,
"
too
noble
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
is
too
noble
,
dearest
George
,
"
returned
Lavinia
.
"
<EOS>
And
Pa
,
I
hope
you
will
be
careful
not
to
refer
before
Bella
,
if
you
can
help
it
,
to
my
engagement
to
George
.
<EOS>
It
might
seem
like
reminding
her
of
her
having
cast
herself
away
.
<EOS>
And
I
hope
,
Pa
,
that
you
will
think
it
equally
right
to
avoid
mentioning
George
's
rising
prospects
,
when
Bella
is
present
.
<EOS>
It
might
seem
like
taunting
her
with
her
own
poor
fortunes
.
<EOS>
Let
me
ever
remember
that
I
am
her
younger
sister
,
and
ever
spare
her
painful
contrasts
,
which
could
not
but
wound
her
sharply
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Sampson
expressed
his
belief
that
such
was
the
demeanour
of
Angels
.
<EOS>
Miss
Lavvy
replied
with
solemnity
,
"
No
,
dearest
George
,
I
am
but
too
well
aware
that
I
am
merely
human
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
for
her
part
,
still
further
improved
the
occasion
by
sitting
with
her
eyes
fastened
on
her
husband
,
like
two
great
black
notes
of
interrogation
,
severely
inquiring
,
Are
you
looking
into
your
breast
?
<EOS>
Do
you
deserve
your
blessings
?
<EOS>
Can
you
lay
your
hand
upon
your
heart
and
say
that
you
are
worthy
of
so
hysterical
a
daughter
?
<EOS>
I
do
not
ask
you
if
you
are
worthy
of
such
a
wife
---
put
Me
out
of
the
question
---
but
are
you
sufficiently
conscious
of
,
and
thankful
for
,
the
pervading
moral
grandeur
of
the
family
spectacle
on
which
you
are

?
<EOS>
These
inquiries
proved
very
harassing
to
R.
W.
who
,
besides
being
a
little
disturbed
by
wine
,
was
in
perpetual
terror
of
committing
himself
by
the
utterance
of
stray
words
that
would
betray
his
guilty
foreknowledge
.
<EOS>
However
,
the
scene
being
over
,
and
---
all
things
considered
---
well
over
,
he
sought
refuge
in
a
doze
;
which
gave
his
lady
immense
offence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Can
you
think
of
your
daughter
Bella
,
and
sleep
?
<EOS>
"
she
disdainfully
inquired
.
  
<EOS>
To
which
he
mildly
answered
,
"
Yes
,
I
think
I
can
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
"
said
Mrs.
Wilfer
,
with
solemn
indignation
,
"
I
would
recommend
you
,
if
you
have
a
human
feeling
,
to
retire
to
bed
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
my
dear
,
"
he
replied
;
"
I
think
it
is
the
best
place
for
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
with
these
unsympathetic
words
very
gladly
withdrew
.
  
<EOS>
Within
a
few
weeks
afterwards
,
the
Mendicant
's
bride
(
arm
-
in
-
arm
with
the
Mendicant
)
came
to
tea
,
in
fulfilment
of
an
engagement
made
through
her
father
.
<EOS>
And
the
way
in
which
the
Mendicant
's
bride
dashed
at
the
unassailable
position
so
considerately
to
be
held
by
Miss
Lavvy
,
and
scattered
the
whole
of
the
works
in
all
directions
in
a
moment
,
was
triumphant
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dearest
Ma
,
"
cried
Bella
,
running
into
the
room
with
a
radiant
face
,
<EOS>
"
how
do
you
do
,
dearest
Ma
?
"
<EOS>
And
then
embraced
her
,
joyously
.
"
<EOS>
And
Lavvy
darling
,
how
do
you
do
,
and
how
's
George
Sampson
,
and
how
is
he
getting
on
,
and
when
are
you
going
to
be
married
,
and
how
rich

you
going
to
grow
?
<EOS>
You
must
tell
me
all
about
it
,
<EOS>
Lavvy
dear
,
immediately
.
<EOS>
John
,
love
,
kiss
Ma
and
Lavvy
,
and
then
we
shall
all
be
at
home
and
comfortable
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Wilfer
stared
,
but
was
helpless
.
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
stared
,
but
was
helpless
.
<EOS>
Apparently
with
no
compunction
,
and
assuredly
with
no
ceremony
,
Bella
tossed
her
bonnet
away
,
and
sat
down
to
make
the
tea
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dearest
Ma
and
Lavvy
,
you
both
take
sugar
,
I
know
.
<EOS>
And
Pa
(
you
good
little
Pa
)
,
you
do
n't
take
milk
.
<EOS>
John
does
.
<EOS>
I
did
n't
before
I
was
married
;
but
I
do
now
,
because
John
does
.
<EOS>
John
dear
,
did
you
kiss
Ma
and
Lavvy
?
<EOS>
Oh
,
you
did
!
<EOS>
Quite
correct
,
John
dear
;
but
I
did
n't
see
you
do
it
,
so
I
asked
.
<EOS>
Cut
some
bread
and
butter
,
John
;
 
<EOS>
that
's
a
love
.
<EOS>
Ma
likes
it
doubled
.
<EOS>
And
now
you
must
tell
me
,
dearest
Ma
and
Lavvy
,
upon
your
words
and
honours
!
<EOS>
Did
n't
you
for
a
moment
---
just
a
moment
---
think
I
was
a
dreadful
little
wretch
when
I
wrote
to
say
I
had
run
away
?
"
  
<EOS>
Before
Mrs.
Wilfer
could
wave
her
gloves
,
the
Mendicant
's
bride
in
her
merriest
affectionate
manner
went
on
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
must
have
made
you
rather
cross
,
dear
Ma
and
Lavvy
,
and
I
know
I
deserved
that
you
should
be
very
cross
.
<EOS>
But
you
see
I
had
been
such
a
heedless
,

,
and
had
led
you
so
to
expect
that
I
should
marry
for
money
,
and
so
to
make

that
I
was
incapable
of
marrying
for
love
,
that
I
thought
you
could
n't
believe
me
.
<EOS>
Because
,
you
see
,
you
did
n't
know
how
much
of
Good
,
Good
,
<EOS>
Good
,
I
had
learnt
from
John
.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
So
I
was
sly
about
it
,
and
ashamed
of
what
you
supposed
me
to
be
,
and
fearful
that
we
could
n't
understand
one
another
and
might
come
to
words
,
which
we
should
all
be

for
afterwards
,
and
<EOS>
so
I
said
to
John
that
if
he
liked
to
take
me
without
any

,
he
might
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
did
like
,
I
let
him
.
<EOS>
And
we
were
married
at
Greenwich
church
in
the
presence
of
nobody
---
except
an
unknown
individual
who
dropped
in
,
"
here
her
eyes
sparkled
more
brightly
,
"
and
half
a
pensioner
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
is

it
nice
,
dearest
Ma
and
Lavvy
,
to

that
no

which

be

for
,
and
that
we
are
all
the
best
of

at
the

!
"
  
<EOS>
Having

again
she

(
after
a
loop
on
the
road
to

her

)

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now

will

,

,

,

what

.
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
And
so

live

Blackheath
,

---
ingest
of
dolls
'

,
de
---
lightfully

,
and
we

a

who
is
de
---
cidedly

,

,

,
and
we
have
a

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

,
what

husband
,
my

---
that
I
almost
love

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
if

would
like

know
in

,

,
"
said
her

,

,

,
"
my

wife
,
my

is
---
.
<EOS>
"
But
Bella
started
up
,
and
put
her
hand
upon
his
lips
.
  
<EOS>
"
Stop
,
sir
!
<EOS>
No
,
John
,
dear
!
<EOS>
Seriously
!
<EOS>
Please
not
yet
a

!
<EOS>
I
want
to

something
so
much

than
the
doll
in

doll
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,
not
a

,
so
much

as
I

!
<EOS>
Try

,
John
---

---

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
,
my
Life
,
"
said
John
.
<EOS>
"
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
my
dear
John
.
<EOS>
And
you
wo
n't
speak
a
word
now
;

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
wo
n't
,
"
said
John
,
with
a
very

of

around

,
"
speak
a
word
now
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
laid
her
laughing

upon
his
breast
to

,
and
said
,
looking

the
rest

them
<EOS>
sideways
out

her

<EOS>
:
"
I
'll

further
,
Pa

Ma

Lavvy
.
<EOS>
John
do
n't
suspect
it
---
he
has
no

---
but
I
quite
love
him
!
"
  
<EOS>
Even
Mrs.
Wilfer
relaxed
under
the
influence
of
her
married
daughter
,
and
seemed
in
a
majestic
manner
to
imply
remotely
that
if
R.
W.
had
been
a
more
deserving
object
,
she
too
might
have
condescended
to
come
down

her

for

.
<EOS>
Miss
Lavinia
,
on
the
other
hand
,
had
strong
doubts
of
the
policy
of
the
course
of
treatment
,
and
whether
it
might
not
spoil
Mr.
Sampson
,
if
experimented
on
in
the
case
of
that
young
gentleman
.
<EOS>
R.
W.
himself
was
for
his
part
convinced
that
he
was
father
of
one
of
the
most
charming
of
girls
,
and
that
Rokesmith
was
the
most
favoured
of
men
;
which
opinion
,
if
propounded
to
him
,
Rokesmith
would
probably
not
have
contested
.
  
<EOS>
The
newly
-
married
pair
left
early
,
so
that
they
might
walk
at
leisure
to
their
starting
-
place
from
London
,
for
Greenwich
.
<EOS>
At
first
they
were
very
cheerful
and
talked
much
;
but
after
a
while
,
Bella
fancied
that
her
husband
was
turning
somewhat
thoughtful
.
<EOS>
So
she
asked
him
:
  
"
<EOS>
John
dear
<EOS>
,
what
's
the
matter
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Matter
,
my
love
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Wo
n't
you
tell
me
,
"
said
Bella
,
looking
up
into
his
face
,
"
what
you
are
thinking
of
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
not
much
in
the
thought
,
my
soul
.
<EOS>
I
was
thinking
whether
you
would
n't
like
me
to
be
rich
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
rich
,
John
?
"
repeated
Bella
,
shrinking
a
little
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
,
really
rich
.
<EOS>
Say
,
as
rich
as
Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
You
would
like
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
almost
afraid
to
try
,
John
dear
.
<EOS>
Was
he
much
the
better
for
his
wealth
?
<EOS>
Was
I
much
the
better
for
the
little
part
I
once
had
in
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
all
people
are
not
the
worse
for
riches
,
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Most
people
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Bella
musingly
suggested
with
raised
eyebrows
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nor
even
most
people
,
it
may
be
hoped
.
<EOS>
If
you
were
rich
,
for
instance
,
you
would
have
a
great
power
of
doing
good
to
others
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
for

,
"
Bella
playfully

;
"
but
should
I
exercise
the
power
,
for
instance
?
<EOS>
And
again
,
sir
,
for
instance
;
should
I
,
at
the
same
