,
have
a
great
power
of
doing
harm
to
myself
?
"
  
<EOS>
Laughing
and
pressing
her
arm
,
he
retorted
:
"
But
still
,
again
for
instance
;
would
you
exercise
that
power
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
"
said
Bella
,
thoughtfully
shaking

.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
not
.
<EOS>
I
think
not
.
<EOS>
But
it
's
so
easy
to
hope
not
and
think
not
,
without
the
riches
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
you
say
,
my
darling
---
instead
of
that
phrase
---
being
poor
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
looking
earnestly
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
n't
I
say
,
being
poor
!
<EOS>
Because
I
am
not
poor
.
<EOS>
Dear
John
,
it
's
not
possible
that
you
suppose
I
think
we
are
poor
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
my
love
.
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
John
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Understand
me
,
sweetheart
.
<EOS>
I
know
that
I
am
rich
beyond
all
wealth
in
having
you
;
but
I
think
of
you
,
and
think
for
you
.
<EOS>
In
such
a
dress
as
you
are
wearing
now
,
you
first
charmed
me
,
and
in
no
dress
could
you
ever
look
,
to
my

,
more
graceful
or
more

.
<EOS>
But
you
have
admired
many

this
very
day
;
 
and
is
it
not
natural
that
I
wish
I
could
give
them
to

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
John
.
<EOS>
It

these

,

with
such

.
<EOS>
But
I
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Again
,
"

,
"

now

.
<EOS>
I
love
those
pretty

,

your

.
<EOS>
Is

not
natural
that
I
wish

could
ride

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"
said

,

,
"

,
John

a

.
<EOS>
But
I
do

a

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
like

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should

like

for

,
half
so
well

.
<EOS>
Dear

,
your

in

,

<EOS>

,

I
have
as
good
as
got

,
John
.
<EOS>
I
have
better
than
got
it
,
John
!
"
  
<EOS>
They
were
not
the
less
happy
for
such
talk
,
and
home
was
not
the
less
home
for
coming
after
it
.
<EOS>
Bella
was
fast
developing
a
perfect
genius
for
home
.
<EOS>
All
the
loves
and
graces
seemed
(
her
husband
thought
)
to
have
taken
domestic
service
with
her
,
and
to
help
her
to
make
home
engaging
.
  
<EOS>
Her
married
life
glided
happily
on
.
<EOS>
She
was
alone
all
day
,
for
,
after
an
early
breakfast
her
husband
repaired
every
morning
to
the
City
,
and
did
not
return
until
their
late
dinner
hour
.
<EOS>
He
was
"
in
a
China
house
,
"
he
explained
to
Bella
:
which
she
found
quite
satisfactory
,
without
pursuing
the
China
house
into
minuter
details
than
a
wholesale
vision
of
tea
,
rice
,
odd
-

,
carved

,
and
tight

more

,

of

,

.
<EOS>
She
always
walked
with
her
husband
to
the

,
and
was
always
there
again
to

;
her
old
coquettish
ways
a
little

down
(
but
not

)
,
and
her
dress
as

.
<EOS>
But
,
John
gone

Bella
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

,
would

.
<EOS>
Such

and

and

,

,

,

and

,
such
diverse

,

above

!
<EOS>
For
Mrs.
J.
R.
,
who
had

wo
nt

as
Miss
B.
W.
,

The
Complete

,

,

her

,

.
<EOS>
This
,
principally
because
the
Complete

,
however
sound

,

Briton

British

,

sometimes

.
<EOS>
In

,

,
"
Oh

,

?
<EOS>
You

!
"
<EOS>
And

,
would
try
the
Housewife
again
,
with
all
her

screwed
into
an

.
  
<EOS>
There

likewise

coolness
on
the

of
the
British
Housewife
,
which
Mrs.
John
Rokesmith
found
highly

.
<EOS>
She
would

,
"
Take

,
"
as

<EOS>
Or

"

---
"
of

.
<EOS>
In

,
the
Housewife
's
most
glaring

,
Bella
would
shut

and

on

,

,
"
O
you
   
ARE

!
<EOS>
Where

I
to

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
Another

claimed

of

John
Rokesmith
for
a

.
<EOS>
This
was
the
mastering
of
the
newspaper
,
so
that

might
be
close
up

John

when
John
came

.
<EOS>
In
her

to
be
in

his

,

would

to

,
or

,
if

.
<EOS>
Wonderful

would

City

,
and
beamingly

it
upon
John
in
the

;

that
were
looking
up

,

had
been
taken
to
the
Bank
,
and

wise

over

until

would

would

,

:
"
It
all
comes
of
my

,
John

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
For

,

certainly

,

got

.
<EOS>
But

,
beyond

,

,
as

that
was
always

,
and
that
never

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

's

,

that

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

?

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
Rich

!
<EOS>

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
No
!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
Oh

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
With

's

,

Pa

.
  
<EOS>
Pa

---

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

,

.

.
<EOS>
Which

,

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

,

;

"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"

"

!

<EOS>

,

,

and
rubbed
his
face
,
and
soaped
his
hands
and
rubbed
his
hands
,
and
splashed
him
and
rinsed
him
and
towelled
him
,
until
he
was
as
red
as
beetroot
,
even
to
his
very
ears
:
"
Now
you
must
be
brushed
and
combed
,
sir
,
"
said
Bella
,
busily
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hold
the
light
,
John
.
<EOS>
Shut
your
eyes
,
sir
,
and
let
me
take
hold
of
your
chin
.
<EOS>
Be
good
directly
,
and
do
as
you
are
told
!
"
  
<EOS>
Her
father
being
more
than
willing
to
obey
,
she
dressed
his
hair
in
her
most
elaborate
manner
,
brushing
it
out
straight
,
parting
it
,
winding
it
over
her
fingers
,
sticking
it
up
on
end
,
and
constantly
falling
back
on
John
to
get
a
good
look
at
the
effect
of
it
.
<EOS>
Who
always
received
her
on
his
disengaged
arm
,
and
detained
her
,
while
the
patient
cherub
stood
waiting
to
be
finished
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
!
"
said
Bella
,
when
she
had
at
last
completed
the
final
touches
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
you
are
something
like
a
genteel
boy
!
<EOS>
Put
your
jacket
on
,
and
come
and
have
your
supper
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
cherub
investing
himself
with
his
coat
was
led
back
to
his
corner
---
<EOS>
where
,
but
for
having
no
egotism
in
his
pleasant
nature
,
he
would
have
answered
well
enough
for
that
radiant
though
self

boy
,
Jack
Horner
---
Bella
with
her
own
hands
laid
a
cloth
for
him
,
and
brought
him
his
supper
on

.
"
<EOS>
Stop
a
moment
,
"
 
said
she
,
"
we
must
keep
his
little
clothes
clean
;
"
and
tied
a
napkin
under
his
chain
,
in
a
very
methodical
manner
.
  
<EOS>
While
he
took
his
supper
,
Bella
sat
by
him
,
sometimes
admonishing

to
hold
his
fork
by

handle
,
like
a
polite
child
,
and
at
other

carving
for

,
or
pouring

.
<EOS>
Fantastic
as
it
all
was
,
and
accustomed
as
she
ever
had
been
to
make
a
plaything
of
her
good
father
,
ever
delighted
that
she
should
put
him
to
that
account
,
still
there
was
an
occasional
something
on
Bella
's
part
that
was
new
.
<EOS>
It
could
not
be
said
that
she
was
less
playful
,
whimsical
,
or
natural
,
than
she
always
had
been
;
but
it

,
her
husband
thought
,
as
if

were
some
rather
graver

than
he

supposed
for
what
she
had
so
lately
said
,
and
as

,
throughout

,

of
an

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
circumstance
in
support
of
this
view
of
the
case
,
that
when
she

her

,

his

between

father

,

,
and

very

.
<EOS>
So

,
that
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
go

Pa
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
.
<EOS>
Do

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

Hexam

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

John

<EOS>
Good

Pa.

"
  
<EOS>
Left

<EOS>

<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
"

,

!
<EOS>
To

.
<EOS>

?
"
  
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

?
"

<EOS>
My

"
  
<EOS>
"
Pretty

!
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Again
,
his
secret
!
<EOS>
He

,

.

.

.

---

.

<EOS>

.....

<EOS>

,

.
"
   
<EOS>
A
CRY
FOR
HELP
.
 
<EOS>
The
Paper
Mill
had
stopped
work
for
the
night
,
and
the
paths
and
roads
in
its
neighbourhood
were
sprinkled
with
clusters
of
people
going
home
from
their
day
's
labour
in
it
.
<EOS>
There
were
men
,
women
,
and
children
in
the
groups
,
and
there
was
no
want
of
lively
colour
to
flutter
in
the
gentle
evening
wind
.
<EOS>
The
mingling
of
various
voices
and
the
sound
of
laughter
made
a
cheerful
impression
upon
the
ear
,
analogous
to
that
of
the
fluttering
colours
upon
the
eye
.
<EOS>
Into
the
sheet
of
water
reflecting
the
flushed
sky
in
the
foreground
of
the
living
picture
,
a
knot
of
urchins
were
casting
stones
,
and
watching
the
expansion
of
the
rippling
circles
.
<EOS>
So
,
in
the
rosy
evening
,
one
might
watch
the
ever
-
widening
beauty
of
the
landscape
---
beyond
the
newly
-
released
workers
wending
home
---
beyond
the
silver
river
---
beyond
the
deep
green
fields
of
corn
,
so
prospering
,
that
the
loiterers
in
their
narrow
threads
of
pathway
seemed
to
float
immersed
breast
-
high
---
beyond
the
hedgerows
and
the
clumps
of
trees
---
beyond
the
windmills
on
the
ridge
---
  
away
to
where
the
sky
appeared
to
meet
the
earth
,
as
if
there
were
no
immensity
of
space
between
mankind
and
Heaven
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
Saturday
evening
,
and
at
such
a
time
the
village
dogs
,
always
much
more
interested
in
the
doings
of
humanity
than
in
the
affairs
of
their
own
species
,
were
particularly
active
.
<EOS>
At
the
general
shop
,
at
the
butcher
's
and
at
the
public
-
house
,
they
evinced
an
inquiring
spirit
never
to
be
satiated
.
<EOS>
Their
especial
interest
in
the
public
-
house
would
seem
to
imply
some
latent
rakishness
in
the
canine
character
;
for
little
was
eaten
there
,
and
<EOS>
they
,
having
no
taste
for
beer
or
tobacco
<EOS>
(
Mrs.
Hubbard
's
dog
is
said
to
have
smoked
,
but
proof
is
wanting
)
<EOS>
,
could
only
have
been
attracted
fiddle
played
within
;
a
fiddle
so
unutterably
vile
,
<EOS>
that
one
lean
long
-
bodied
cur
,
with
a
better
ear
than
the
rest
,
found
himself
under
compulsion
at
intervals
to
go
round
the
corner
and
howl
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
even
he
returned
to
the
public
-
house
on
each
occasion
with
the
tenacity
of
a
confirmed
drunkard
.
  
<EOS>
Fearful
to
relate
,
there
was
even
a
sort
of
little
Fair
in
the
village
.
<EOS>
Some
despairing
gingerbread
that
had
been
vainly
trying
to
dispose
of
itself
all
over
the
country
,
and
had
cast
a
quantity
of
dust
upon
its
head
in
its
mortification
,
again
appealed
to
the
public
from
an
infirm
booth
.
<EOS>
So
did
a
heap
of
nuts
,
long
,
long
exiled
from
Barcelona
,
and
yet
speaking
English
so
indifferently
as
to
call
fourteen
of
themselves
a
pint
.
<EOS>
A
Peep
-
show
which
had
originally
started
with
the
Battle
of
Waterloo
,
and
had
since
made
it
every
other
battle
of
later
date
by
altering
the
Duke
of
Wellington
's
nose
,
tempted
the
student
of
illustrated
history
.
<EOS>
A
Fat
Lady
,
perhaps
in
part
sustained
upon
postponed
pork
,
her
professional
associate
being
a
Learned
Pig
,
displayed
her
life
-
size
picture
in
a
low
dress
as
she
appeared
when
presented
at
Court
,
several
yards
round
.
<EOS>
All
this
was
a
vicious
spectacle
as
any
poor
idea
of
amusement
on
the
part
of
the
rougher
hewers
of
wood
and
drawers
of
water
in
this
land
of
England
<EOS>
ever
is
and
shall
be
.
<EOS>
They
must
not
vary
the
rheumatism
with
amusement
.
<EOS>
They
may
vary
it
with
fever
and
ague
,
or
with
as
many
rheumatic
variations
as
they
have
joints
;
but
positively
not
with
entertainment
after
their
own
manner
.
  
<EOS>
The
various
sounds
arising
from
this
scene
of
depravity
,
and
floating
away
into
the
still
evening
air
,
made
the
evening
,
at
any
point
which
they
just
reached
fitfully
,
mellowed
by
the
distance
,
more
still
by
contrast
.
<EOS>
Such
was
the
stillness
of
the
evening
to
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
as
he
walked
by
the
river
with
his
hands
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
He
walked
slowly
,
and
with
the
measured
step
and
preoccupied
air
of
one
who
was
waiting
.
<EOS>
He
walked
between
the
two
points
,
an
osier
-
bed
at
this
end
and
some
floating
lilies
at
that
,
and
at
each
point
stopped
and
looked
expectantly
in
one
direction
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
very
quiet
,
"
said
he
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
very
quiet
.
<EOS>
Some
sheep
were
grazing
on
the
grass
by
the
river
-
side
,
and
it
seemed
to
him
that
he
had
never
before
heard
the
crisp
tearing
sound
with
which
they
cropped
it
.
<EOS>
He
stopped
idly
,
and
looked
at
them
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
stupid
enough
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
are
clever
enough
to
get
through
life
tolerably
to
your
satisfaction
,
you
have
got
the
better
of
me
,
Man
as
I
am
,
and
Mutton
as
you
are
!
"
  
<EOS>
A
rustle
in
a
field
beyond
the
hedge
attracted
his
attention
.
<EOS>
"
What
's
here
to
do
?
"
he
asked
himself
,
leisurely
going
towards
the
gate
and
looking
over
.
"
<EOS>
No
jealous
paper
-
miller
?
<EOS>
No
pleasures
of
the
chase
in
this
part
of
the
country
?
<EOS>
Mostly
fishing
hereabouts
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
field
had
been
newly
mown
,
and
there
were
yet
the
marks
of
the
scythe
on
the
yellow
-
green
ground
,
and
the
track
of
wheels
where
the
hay
had
been
carried
.
<EOS>
Following
the
tracks
with
his
eyes
,
the
view
closed
with
the
new
hayrick
in
a
corner
.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
if
he
had
gone
on
to
the
hayrick
,
and
gone
round
it
?
<EOS>
But
,
say
that
the
event
was
to
be
,
as
the
event
fell
out
,
and
how
idle
are
such
suppositions
!
<EOS>
Besides
,
if
he
had
gone
;
what
is
there
of
warning
in
a
Bargeman
lying
on
his
face
?
  
<EOS>
"
A
bird
flying
to
the
hedge
,
"
was
all
he
thought
about
it
;
and
came
back
,
and
resumed

walk
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
not
a
reliance
on
her
being

,
"
said
Eugene
,
after
taking
some

,
"
I
should

she
had
given

the

.
<EOS>
But
she
promised
,
and
she
is
a
girl
of

.
"
  
<EOS>
Turning
again
at
the
water

,
he
saw

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was

,

,
that

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had
to

,
and
I
had
speak

several

,

Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
the
lads

village
---
and
the

---
such
scandal
-
mongers
?
"
 
he
asked
,
as
he
took
her
hand
and
drew
it
through
his
arm
  
She
submitted
to
walk
slowly
on
,
with
downcast

.
<EOS>
He
put
her
hand
to
his
lips
,
and
she
quietly
drew

away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
walk
beside
me
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
and
not
touch
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
For
,
his
arm
was
already
stealing
round
her
waist
.
  
<EOS>
She
stopped
again
,
and
gave

an

.
"
<EOS>
Well
,
Lizzie
,
well
!
"
said

,
in

though
ill

,
"
don;'t
be
unhappy
,
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

I

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wrayburn
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lizzie
,

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As

.
<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Faith
!
"

<EOS>
"
Because

wo

.
<EOS>
Mind
!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,
"

"
<EOS>
See

!
<EOS>
Napoleon
Buonaparte

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
When

I

Mill

,
"

,

<EOS>
Was

?
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Can

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
O

Wrayburn
,
"

"

!
<EOS>
O
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

"
  
<EOS>
"
In

"
do

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>

,

,

!
"
<EOS>
said
Lizzie
,

.
  
<EOS>
He

with
a
real

of

and

.
<EOS>
It
was
not
strong
enough
to

and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lizzie
!
<EOS>
I
never

,
that
there

a

.
<EOS>
But
do

.
<EOS>
You
don;t

my

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
You

,
   
WON'T

.
<EOS>
You
have

dead
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
To
consider
,
wrong

,

,

!
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

Wrayburn
;
it

.
<EOS>
I
do

you
.
<EOS>
Indeed
I
do

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
But

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

<EOS>
"
Think

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell

,

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Think

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Respect

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
How
true

to

Queen
!
"
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
His

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
Again

"
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
did
consider
within
himself
for
a
moment
or
two
,
and
then
retorted
,
"
Drive
you
?
<EOS>
To
what
shall
I
drive
you
,
Lizzie
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
drive
me
away
.
<EOS>
I
live
here
peacefully
and
respected
,
and
I
am
well
employed
here
.
<EOS>
You
will
force
me
to
quit
this
place
as
I
quitted
London
,
and
---
by
following
me
again
---
will
force
me
to
quit
the
next
place
in
which
I
may
find
refuge
,
as
I
quitted
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
so
determined
,
Lizzie
---
forgive
the
word
I
am
going
to
use
,
for
its
literal
truth
---
to
fly
from
a
lover
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
so
determined
,
"
she
answered
resolutely
,
though
trembling
,
"
to
fly
from
such
a
lover
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
poor
woman
died
here
but
a
little
while
ago
,
scores
of
years
older
than
I
am
,
whom
I
found
by
chance
,
lying
on
the
wet
earth
.
<EOS>
You
may
have
heard
some
account
of
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
have
,
"
he
answered
,
"
if
her
name
was
Higden
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Her
name
was
Higden
.
<EOS>
Though
she
was
so
weak
and
old
,
she
kept
true
to
one
purpose
to
the
very
last
.
<EOS>
Even
at
the
very
last
,
she
made
me
promise
that
her
purpose
should
be
kept
to
,
after
she
was
dead
,
so
settled
was
her
determination
.
<EOS>
What
she
did
,
I
can
do
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
if
I
believed
---
but
I
do
not
believe
---
that
you
could
be
so
cruel
to
me
as
to
drive
me
from
place
to
place
to
wear
me
out
,
you
should
drive
me
to
death
and
not
do
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
full
at
her
handsome
face
,
and
in
his
own
handsome
face
there
was
a
light
of
blended
admiration
,
anger
,
and
reproach
,
<EOS>
which
she
---
who
loved
him
so
in
secret
---
whose
heart
had
long
been
so
full
,
and
he
the
cause
of
its
overflowing
---
drooped
before
.
<EOS>
She
tried
hard
to
retain
her
firmness
,
but
he
saw
it
melting
away
under
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
In
the
moment
of
its
dissolution
,
and
of
his
first
full
knowledge
of
his
influence
upon
her
,
she
dropped
,
and
he
caught
her
on
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lizzie
!
<EOS>
Rest
so
a
moment
.
<EOS>
Answer
what
I
ask
you
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
not
been
what
you
call
removed
from
you
and
cut
off
from
you
,
would
you
have
made
this

to
me
to
leave
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
,
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
ask
me
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
Let
me
go
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
swear

you
,
Lizzie
,
you
shall

.
<EOS>
I

,
you
shall

.
<EOS>
I
'll
not
accompany
you
<EOS>
,
I
'll
not
follow
you
,
if
you
will

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
I
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
?
<EOS>
How

tell

what
I
should
have
done
,
if

not

what

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
not

what
you
make
me
out
to
be
,
"
he
struck
in
,

,
"
would
you
still
have

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
"
she

appealingly
,

,
"
you
know

better
than
to

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
not
been
what
you
make

out
to
be
,
Lizzie
,
would
you
still
have
been
indifferent
to
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
"
she
answered
as
before
,
"
you
know
me
better
than
that
too
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
something
in
the
attitude
of
her
whole
figure
as
he
supported
it
,
and
she
hung
her
head
,
which
besought
him
to
be

and
not
force
her
to
disclose

.
<EOS>
He
was
not
merciful
with
her
,
and
he
made
her
do
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
know
you
better
than
quite
to
believe
(
unfortunate
dog
though
I
am
!
)
<EOS>
that
you
hate
me
,
or
even
that
you

to
me
,
<EOS>
Lizzie
,
let
me

so
much
more
from

before

.
<EOS>
Let
me
know
how
you
would
have
dealt
with
me
if

me
as
being
what
you
would
have
considered
on
equal

with

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
impossible
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
How
can
I
think
of
you
as
being
on
equal

with

?
<EOS>
If
my
mind
could
put
you
on
equal

with
me
,
you
could
not
be
yourself
.
<EOS>
How
could
I
remember
,
then
,
the
night
when
I

,

when

of
the

because

?
<EOS>
Or
,
the
night
that
passed
into
the
morning
when
you
broke

that
my
father
was
dead
?
<EOS>
Or
,
the
nights
when
you
used

?
<EOS>
Or
,
your

known

,
and
having
caused
me
to
be

?
<EOS>
Or
,
my

so

you
and
wondered

you
,
and

first
thought
you
so
good
to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Only
`
`
at
first
"
"
thought
me
so
good
,
Lizzie
?
<EOS>
What
did
you
think
me
after
`
`
at
first
"
"
?
<EOS>
So
bad
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
say
that
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
mean
that
.
<EOS>
But
after
the
first
wonder
and
pleasure
of
being
noticed
by
one
so

from
any

who
had

spoken
to
me
,
I
began
to
feel
that
it
might
have

better
if
I

never

you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Because
you

so
different
,
"
she
answered
in
a
lower

.
"
<EOS>
Because
it
was
so
endless
,
so
hopeless
.
<EOS>
Spare
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
you
think
for
me
at
all
,
Lizzie
?
"
<EOS>
he
asked
,
as
if
he
were
a

stung
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
much
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
Not
much
until
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
tell
me
why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
never
supposed
until
to
-
night
that
you
needed
to
be
thought
for
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
do
need
to
be
;
if
you
do
truly
feel
at
heart
that
you
have
indeed

towards
me
what

to
-

,

nothing

but

;

Heaven

,

Heaven

!
"
  
<EOS>
The
purity
with
which
in
these
she
expressed
something
of
her
own
love
and
her
own

,
made
a
deep

on
him
for

passing

.
<EOS>
He
held
her
,
almost
as

were

to
him
by

,
and

her
,
once
,
almost
as
he
might

the
dead
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
promised
that
I
would
not
accompany
you
,
nor

you
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
keep
you
in
view
?
<EOS>
You
have
been
agitated
,
and
it
's
growing
dark
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
used
to
be

alone
at
this

,

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
promise
.
<EOS>
I
can
bring
myself
to
promise
nothing
more
to
night
,
Lizzie
,
except
that
I
will
try
what
I
can
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
but
one

,
Mr.
Wrayburn
,
of

,
every

.
<EOS>
Leave
this

to
-
morrow

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
try
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
spoke
the
words
in
a
grave

,
she
put
her
hand

,
removed

,
and
went
away
by

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
could
Mortimer
believe
this
?
"
<EOS>
murmured
Eugene
,
still
remaining
,
after
a
while
,
where
she
had
left
him
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Can
I
even
believe
it
myself
?
"
  
<EOS>
He
referred
to
the
circumstance
that
there
were
tears
upon
his
hand
,
as
he
stood
covering
his

.
<EOS>
"
A
most
ridiculous
position
this
,
to
be
found
out
in
!
<EOS>
"
was
his
next
thought
.
<EOS>
And
his
next
struck
its
root
in
a
little
rising
resentment
against
the
cause
of
the
tears
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yet
I
have
gained
a
wonderful
power
over
her
,
too
,
let
her
be
as
much
in
earnest
as
she
will
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
reflection
brought
back
the
yielding
of
her
face
and
form
as
she
had
drooped
under
his
gaze
.
<EOS>
Contemplating
the
reproduction
,
he
seemed
to
see
,
for
the
second
time
,
in
the
appeal
and
in
the

,
a
little

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
she
loves
me
.
<EOS>
And
so
earnest
a
character
must
be
very
earnest
in
that
passion
.
<EOS>
She
can
not
choose
for
herself
to
be
strong
in
this
fancy
,
wavering
in
that
,
and
weak
in

.
<EOS>
She
must
go
through
with
her

,
as
I
must
go
through

.
<EOS>
If
mine
exacts
its
pains
and

all
round
,
so
must
hers
,
I
suppose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Pursuing
the
inquiry
into
his
own
nature
,
he
thought
,
"
Now
,
if
I
married
her
.
<EOS>
If
,
outfacing
the
absurdity
of
the

in

M.
R.
F.
,
I
astonished
M.
R.
F.
to

,
by

,
how

M.
R.
F.
reason
with

legal

?
`
`
You
would
n't
marry
for
some
money
and
some
station
,
because
you
were

to

.
<EOS>
Are
you
less

likely
to
become
bored
,
marrying
for
no

and
no

?
<EOS>
Are
you
sure

yourself
?
"
<EOS>
"
Legal
mind
,
in

forensic

,
must

,
`
`
Good
reasoning
on
the
part
of
M.
R.
F.
Not
sure
of
myself
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
In

of
calling
this
tone
of
levity
to
his

,
he
felt
it
to
be
profligate
and
worthless
,
and
asserted
her
against
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
I
should
like
to
see
the
fellow
(
Mortimer
excepted
)
who

,

,

,
and
that

would
not

true

.
<EOS>
I
should
particularly
like
to
see
the
fellow
to
-
night
who
would
tell
me
so
,
or
who
would
tell
me
anything
that
could
be
construed
to
her
disadvantage
;
 
for
I
am
wearily
out
of
sorts
with
one
Wrayburn
who
cuts
a
sorry
figure
,
and
I
would
far
rather
be
out
of
sorts
with
somebody
else
.
<EOS>
`
`
Eugene
,
Eugene
,
Eugene
,
this
is
a
bad
business
.
"
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
So
go
the
Mortimer
Lightwood
bells
,
and
they
sound
melancholy
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Strolling
on
,
he
thought
of
something
else
to
take
himself
to
task
for
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
the
analogy
,
Brute
Beast
,
"
he
said
impatiently
,
"
between

woman
whom
your
father
coolly
finds
out
for
you
and
a
woman
whom
you
have
found
out
for
yourself
,
and
have
ever
drifted
after
with
more
and
more
of
constancy
since
you
first
set
eyes
upon
her
?
<EOS>
Ass
!
<EOS>
Can
you
reason
no
better
than
that
?
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
again
he
subsided
into
a
reminiscence
of
his
first
full
knowledge
of
his
power
just
now
,
and
of
her
disclosure
of
her
heart
.
<EOS>
To
try
no
more
to
go
away
,
and
to
try
her
again
,
was
the
reckless
conclusion
it
turned
uppermost
.
<EOS>
And
yet
again
,
"
Eugene
,
Eugene
,
Eugene
,
this
is
a
bad
business
!
"
<EOS>
And
,
"
I
wish
I
could
stop
the
Lightwood
peal
,
<EOS>
for
it
sounds
like
a
knell
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Looking
above
,
he
found
that
the
young
moon
was
up
,
and
that
the
stars
were
beginning
to
shine
in
the
sky
from
which
the
tones
of
red
and
yellow
were
flickering
out
,
in
favour
of
the
calm
blue
of
a
summer
night
.
<EOS>
He
was
still
by
the
river
-
side
.
<EOS>
Turning
suddenly
,
he
met
a
man
,
so
close
upon
him
that
Eugene
,
surprised
,
stepped
back
,
to
avoid
a
collision
.
<EOS>
The
man
carried
something
over
his
shoulder
which
might
have
been
a
broken
oar
,
or
spar
,
or
bar
,
and
took
no
notice
of
him
,
but
passed
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
Halloa
,
friend
!
<EOS>
"
said
Eugene
,
calling
after
him
,
"
are
you
blind
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
man
made
no
reply
,
but
went
his
way
.
  
<EOS>
Eugene
Wrayburn
went
the
opposite
way
,
with
his
hands
behind
him
and
his
purpose
in
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
He
passed
the
sheep
,
and
passed
the
gate
,
and
came
within
hearing
of
the
village
sounds
,
and
came
to
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
The
inn
where
he
stayed
,
like
the
village
and
the
mill
,
was
not
across
the
river
,
but
on
that
side
of
the
stream
on
which
he
walked
.
<EOS>
However
,
knowing
the
rushy
bank
and
the
backwater
on
the
other
side
to
be
a
retired
place
,
and
feeling
out
of
humour
for
noise
or
company
,
he
crossed
the
bridge
,
and
sauntered
on
:
looking
up
at
the
stars
as
they
seemed
one
by
one
to
be
kindled
in
the
sky
,
and
looking
down
at
the
river
as
the
same
stars
seemed
to
be
kindled
deep
in
the
water
.
<EOS>
A
landing
-
place
overshadowed
by
a
willow
,
and
a
pleasure
-
boat
lying
moored
there
among
some
stakes
,
caught
his
eye
as
he
passed
along
.
<EOS>
The
spot
was
in
such
dark
shadow
,
that
he
paused
to
make
out
what
was
there
,
and
then
passed
on
again
.
  
<EOS>
The
rippling
of
the
river
seemed
to
cause
a
correspondent
stir
in
his
uneasy
reflections
.
<EOS>
He
would
have
laid
them
asleep
if
he
could
,
but
they
were
in
movement
,
like
the
stream
,
and
all
tending
one
way
with
a
strong
current
.
<EOS>
As
the
ripple
under
the
moon
broke
unexpectedly
now
and
then
,
and
palely
flashed
in
a
new
shape
and
with
a
new
sound
,
so
parts
of
his
thoughts
started
,
<EOS>
unbidden
,
from
the
rest
,
and
revealed
their
wickedness
.
<EOS>
"
Out
of
the
question
to
marry
her
,
"
said
Eugene
,
"
and
out
of
the
question
to
leave
her
.
<EOS>
The
crisis
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
sauntered
far
enough
.
<EOS>
Before
turning
to
retrace
his
steps
,
he
stopped
upon
the
margin
,
to
look
down
at
the
reflected
night
.
<EOS>
In
an
instant
,
with
a
dreadful
crash
,
the
reflected
night
turned
crooked
,
flames
shot
jaggedly
across
the
air
,
and
the
moon
and
stars
came
bursting
from
the
sky
.
  
<EOS>
Was
he
struck
by
lightning
?
<EOS>
With
some
incoherent
half
-
formed
thought
to
that
effect
,
he
turned
under
the
blows
that
were
blinding
him
and
mashing
his
life
,
and
closed
with
a
murderer
,
whom
he
caught
by
a
red
neckerchief
---
unless
the
raining
down
of
his
own
blood
gave
it
that
hue
.
  
<EOS>
Eugene
was
light
,
active
,
and
expert
;
but
his
arms
were
broken
,
or
he
was
paralyzed
,
and
could
do
no
more
than
hang
on
to
the
man
,
with
his
head
swung
back
,
so
that
he
could
see
nothing
but
the
heaving
sky
.
<EOS>
After
dragging
at
the
assailant
,
he
fell
on
the
bank
with
him
,
and
then
there
was
another
great
crash
,
and
then
a
splash
,
and
all
was
done
.
  
<EOS>
Lizzie
Hexam
,
too
,
had
avoided
the
noise
,
and
the
Saturday
movement
of
people
in
the
straggling
street
,
and
chose
to
walk
alone
by
the
water
until
her
tears
should
be
dry
,
and
she
could
so
compose
herself
as
to
escape
remark
upon
her
looking
ill
or
unhappy
on
going
home
.
<EOS>
The
peaceful
serenity
of
the
hour
and
place
,
having
no
reproaches
or
evil
intentions
within
her
breast
to
contend
against
,
sank
healingly
into
its
depths
.
<EOS>
She
had
meditated
and
taken
comfort
.
<EOS>
She
,
too
,
was
turning
homeward
,
when
she
heard
a
strange
sound
.
  
<EOS>
It
startled
her
,
for
it
was
like
a
sound
of
blows
.
<EOS>
She
stood
still
,
and
listened
.
<EOS>
It
sickened
her
,
for
blows
fell
heavily
and
cruelly
on
the
quiet
of
the
night
.
<EOS>
As
she
listened
,
undecided
,
all
was
silent
.
<EOS>
As
she
yet
listened
,
she
heard
a
faint
groan
,
and
a
fall
into
the
river
.
  
<EOS>
Her
old
bold
life
and
habit
instantly
inspired
her
.
<EOS>
Without
vain
waste
of
breath
in
crying
for
help
where
there
were
none
to
hear
,
she
ran
towards
the
spot
from
which
the
sounds
had
come
.
<EOS>
It
lay
between
her
and
the
bridge
,
but
it
was
more
removed
from
her
than
she
had
thought
;
the
night
being
so
very
quiet
,
and
sound
travelling
far
with
the
help
of
water
.
  
<EOS>
At
length
,
she
reached
a
part
of
the
green
bank
,
much
and
newly
trodden
,
where
there
lay
some
broken
splintered
pieces
of
wood
and
some
torn
fragments
of
clothes
.
<EOS>
Stooping
,
she
saw
that
the
grass
was
bloody
.
<EOS>
Following
the
drops
and
smears
,
she
saw
that
the
watery
margin
of
the
bank
was
bloody
.
<EOS>
Following
the
current
with
her
eyes
,
she
saw
a
bloody
face
turned
up
towards
the
moon
,
and
drifting
away
.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
merciful
Heaven
be
thanked
for
that
old
time
,
and
grant
,
O
Blessed
Lord
,
that
through
thy
wonderful
workings
it
may
turn
to
good
at
last
!
<EOS>
To
whomsoever
the
drifting
face
belongs
,
be
it
man
's
or
woman
's
,
help
my
humble
hands
,
Lord
God
,
to
raise
it
from
death
and
restore
it
to
some
one
to
whom
it
must
be
dear
!
  
<EOS>
It
was
thought
,
fervently
thought
,
but
not
for
a
moment
did
the
prayer
check
her
.
<EOS>
She
was
away
before
it
welled
up
in
her
mind
,
away
,
swift
and
true
,
yet
steady
above
all
---
<EOS>
for
without
steadiness
it
could
never
be
done
---
to
the
landing
-
place
under
the
willow
-
tree
,
where
she
also
had
seen
the
boat
lying
moored
among
the
stakes
.
  
<EOS>
A
sure
touch
of
her
old
practised
hand
,
a
sure
step
of
her
old
practised
foot
,
a
sure
light
balance
of
her
body
,
and
she
was
in
the
boat
.
<EOS>
A
quick
glance
of
her
practised
eye
showed
her
,
even
through
the
deep
dark
shadow
,
the
sculls
in
a
rack
against
the
red
-
brick
garden
-
wall
.
<EOS>
Another
moment
,
and
she
had
cast
off
(
taking
the
line
with
her
)
,
and
the
boat
had
shot
out
into
the
moonlight
,
and
she
was
rowing
down
the
stream
as
never
other
woman
rowed
on
English
water
.
  
<EOS>
Intently
over
her
shoulder
,
without
slackening
speed
,
she
looked
ahead
for
the
driving
face
.
<EOS>
She
passed
the
scene
of
the
struggle
---
  
yonder
<EOS>
it
was
,
on
her
left
,
well
over
the
boat
's
stern
---
she
passed
on
her
right
,
the
end
of
the
village
street
,
a
hilly
street
that
almost
dipped
into
the
river
;
its
sounds
were
growing
faint
again
,
and
she
slackened
;
looking
as
the
boat
drove
,
everywhere
,
everywhere
,
for
the
floating
face
.
  
<EOS>
She
merely
kept
the
boat
before
the
stream
now
,
and
rested
on
her
oars
,
knowing
well
that
if
the
face
were
not
soon
visible
,
it
had
gone
down
,
and
she
would
overshoot
it
.
<EOS>
An
untrained
sight
would
never
have
seen
by
the
moonlight
what
she
saw
at
the
length
of
a
few
strokes
astern
.
<EOS>
She
saw
the
drowning
figure
rise
to
the
surface
,
slightly
struggle
,
and
as
if
by
instinct
turn
over
on
its
back
to
float
.
<EOS>
Just
so
had
she
first
dimly
seen
the
face
which
she
now
dimly
saw
again
.
  
<EOS>
Firm
of
look
and
firm
of
purpose
,
she
intently
watched
its
coming
on
,
until
it
was
very
near
;
then
,
with
a
touch
unshipped
her
sculls
,
and
crept
aft
in
the
boat
,
between
kneeling
and
crouching
.
<EOS>
Once
,
she
let
the
body
evade
her
,
not
being
sure
of
her
grasp
.
<EOS>
Twice
,
and
she
had
seized
it
by
its
bloody
hair
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
insensible
,
if
not
virtually
dead
;
it
was
mutilated
,
and
streaked
the
water
all
about
it
with
dark
red
streaks
.
<EOS>
As
it
could
not
help
itself
,
it
was
impossible
for
her
to
get
it
on
board
.
<EOS>
She
bent
over
the
stern
to
secure
it
with
the
line
,
and
then
the
river
and
its
shores
rang
to
the
terrible
cry
she
uttered
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
as
if
possessed
by
supernatural
spirit
and
strength
,
she
lashed
it
safe
,
resumed
her
seat
,
and
rowed
in
,
desperately
,
for
the
nearest
shallow
water
where
she
might
run
the
boat
aground
.
<EOS>
Desperately
,
but
not
wildly
,
for
she
knew
that
if
she
lost
distinctness
of
intention
,
all
was
lost
and
gone
.
  
<EOS>
She
ran
the
boat
ashore
,
went
into
the
water
,
released
him
from
the
line
,
and
by
main
strength
lifted
him
in
her
arms
and
laid
him
in
the
bottom
of
the
boat
.
<EOS>
He
had
fearful
wounds
upon
him
,
and
she
bound
them
up
with
her
dress
torn
into
strips
.
<EOS>
Else
,
supposing
him
to
be
still
alive
,
she
foresaw
that
he
must
bleed
to
death
before
he
could
be
landed
at
his
inn
,
which
was
the
nearest
place
for
succour
.
  
<EOS>
This
done
very
rapidly
,
she
kissed
his
disfigured
forehead
,
looked
up
in
anguish
to
the
stars
,
and
blessed
him
and
forgave
him
,
"
if
she
had
anything
to
forgive
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
only
in
that
instant
that
she
thought
of
herself
,
and
then
she
thought
of
herself
only
for
him
.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
merciful
Heaven
be
thanked
for
that
old
time
,
enabling
me
,
without
a
wasted
moment
,
to
have
got
the
boat
afloat
again
,
and
to
row
back
against
the
stream
!
<EOS>
And
grant
,
O
Blessed
Lord
God
,
that
through
poor
me
he
may
be
raised
from
death
,
and
preserved
to
some
one
else
to
whom
he
may
be
dear
one
day
,
though
never
dearer
than
to
me
!
  
<EOS>
She
rowed
hard
---
rowed
desperately
,
but
never
wildly
---
and
seldom
removed
her
eyes
from
him
in
the
bottom
of
the
boat
.
<EOS>
She
had
so
laid
him
there
,
as
that
she
might
see
his
disfigured
face
;
it
was
so
much
disfigured
that
his
mother
might
have
covered
it
,
but
it
was
above
and
beyond
disfigurement
in
her
eyes
.
  
<EOS>
The
boat
touched
the
edge
of
the
patch
of
inn
lawn
,
sloping
gently
to
the
water
.
<EOS>
There
were
lights
in
the
windows
,
but
there
chanced
to
be
no
one
out
of
doors
.
<EOS>
She
made
the
boat
fast
,
and
again
by
main
strength
took
him
up
,
and
never
laid
him
down
until
she
laid
him
down
in
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
Surgeons
were
sent
for
,
and
she
sat
supporting
his
head
.
<EOS>
She
had
oftentimes
heard
in
days
that
were
gone
,
how
doctors
would
lift
the
hand
of
an
insensible
wounded
person
,
and
would
drop
it
if
the
person
were
dead
.
<EOS>
She
waited
for
the
awful
moment
when
the
doctors
might
lift
this
hand
,
all
broken
and
bruised
,
and
let
it
fall
.
  
<EOS>
The
first
of
the
surgeons
came
,
and
asked
,
before
proceeding
to
his
examination
,
"
Who
brought
him
in
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
brought
him
in
,
sir
,
"
answered
Lizzie
,
at
whom
all
present
looked
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
,
my
dear
?
<EOS>
You
could
not
lift
,
far
less
carry
,
this
weight
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
could
not
,
at
another
time
,
sir
;
but
I
am
sure
I
did
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
surgeon
looked
at
her
with
great
attention
,
and
with
some
compassion
.
<EOS>
Having
with
a
grave
face
touched
the
wounds
upon
the
head
,
and
the
broken
arms
,
he
took
the
hand
.
  
<EOS>
O
!
<EOS>
would
he
let
it
drop
?
  
<EOS>
He
appeared
irresolute
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
retain
it
,
but
laid
it
gently
down
,
took
a
candle
,
looked
more
closely
at
the
injuries
on
the
head
,
and
at
the
pupils
of
the
eyes
.
<EOS>
That
done
,
he
replaced
the
candle
and
took
the
hand
again
.
<EOS>
Another
surgeon
then
coming
in
,
the
two
exchanged
a
whisper
,
and
the
second
took
the
hand
.
<EOS>
Neither
did
he
let
it
fall
at
once
,
but
kept
it
for
a
while
and
laid
it
gently
down
.
  
<EOS>
"
Attend
to
the
poor
girl
,
"
said
the
first
surgeon
then
.
<EOS>
"
She
is
quite
unconscious
.
<EOS>
She
sees
nothing
and
hears
nothing
.
<EOS>
All
the
better
for
her
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
rouse
her
,
if
you
can
help
it
;
only
move
her
.
<EOS>
Poor
girl
,
poor
girl
!
<EOS>
She
must
be
amazingly
strong
of
heart
,
but
it
is
much
to
be
feared
that
she
has
set
her
heart
upon
the
dead
.
<EOS>
Be
gentle
with
her
.
"
   
<EOS>
BETTER
TO
BE
ABEL
THAN
CAIN
.
 
<EOS>
Day
was
breaking
at
Plashwater
Weir
Mill
Lock
.
<EOS>
Stars
were
yet
visible
,
but
there
was
dull
light
in
the
east
that
was
not
the
light
of
night
.
<EOS>
The
moon
had
gone
down
,
and
a
mist
crept
along
the
banks
of
the
river
,
seen
through
which
the
trees
were
the
ghosts
of
trees
,
and
the
water
was
the
ghost
of
water
.
<EOS>
This
earth
looked
spectral
,
and
so
did
the
pale
stars
:
<EOS>
while
the
cold
eastern
glare
,
expressionless
as
to
heat
or
colour
,
with
the
eye
of
the
firmament
quenched
,
might
have
been
likened
to
the
stare
of
the
dead
.
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
so
likened
by
the
lonely
Bargeman
,
standing
on
the
brink
of
the
lock
.
<EOS>
For
certain
,
Bradley
Headstone
looked
that
way
,
when
a
chill
air
came
up
,
and
when
it
passed
on
murmuring
,
as
if
it
whispered
something
that
made
the
phantom
trees
and
water
tremble
---
or
threaten
---
for
fancy
might
have
made
it
either
.
  
<EOS>
He
turned
away
,
and
tried
the
Lock
-
house
door
.
<EOS>
It
was
fastened
on
the
inside
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
afraid
of
me
?
"
<EOS>
he
muttered
,
knocking
.
  
<EOS>
Rogue
Riderhood
was
soon
roused
,
and
soon
undrew
the
bolt
and
let
him
in
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
T'otherest
,
I
thought
you
had
been
and
got
lost
!
<EOS>
Two
nights
away
!
<EOS>
I
a'most
believed
as
you
'd
giv
'
<EOS>
me
<EOS>
the
slip
,
and
<EOS>
I
had
as
good
as
half
a
mind
for
to
advertise
you
in
the
newspapers
to
come
for'ard
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
's
face
turned
so
dark
on
this
hint
,
that
Riderhood
deemed
it
expedient
to
soften
it
into
a
compliment
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
not
you
,
governor
,
not
you
,
"
he
went
on
,
stolidly
shaking
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
For
what
did
I
say
to
myself
after
having
amused
myself
with
that
<EOS>
there
stretch
of
a
comic
idea
,
as
a
sort
of
a
playful
game
?
<EOS>
Why
,
I
says
to
myself
,
`
`
He
's
a
man
o
'
honor
.
"
<EOS>
"
That
's
what
I
says
to
myself
.
`
<EOS>
`
He
's
<EOS>
a
man
o
'
double
honor
.
"
<EOS>
"
"
  
Very
remarkably
,
Riderhood
put
no
question
to
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
looked
at
him
on
opening
the
door
,
and
he
now
looked
at
him
again
(
stealthily
this
time
)
,
and
the
result
of
his
looking
was
,
that
he
asked
him
no
question
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
'll
be
for
another
forty
on
'em
,
governor
,
as
I
judges
,
afore
you
turns
your
mind
to
breakfast
,
"
said
Riderhood
,
when
his
visitor
sat
down
,
resting
his
chin
on
his
hand
,
with
his
eyes
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
And
very
remarkably
again
:
Riderhood
feigned
to
set
the
scanty
furniture
in
order
,
while
he
spoke
,
to
have
a
show
of
reason
for
not
looking
at
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
had
better
sleep
,
I
think
,
"
said
Bradley
,
without
changing
his
position
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
myself
should
recommend
it
,
governor
,
<EOS>
"
assented
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
"
Might
you
be
anyways
dry
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
should
like
a
drink
,
"
said
Bradley
;
but
without
appearing
to
attend
much
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Riderhood
got
out
his
bottle
,
and
fetched
his
jug
-
full
of
water
,
and
administered
a
potation
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
shook
the
coverlet
of
his
bed
and
spread
it
smooth
,
and
Bradley
stretched
himself
upon
it
in
the
clothes
he
wore
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Riderhood
poetically
remarking
that
he
would
pick
the
bones
of
his
night
's
rest
,
in
his
wooden
chair
,
sat
in
the
window
as
before
;
but
,
as
before
,
watched
the
sleeper
narrowly
until
he
was
very
sound
asleep
.
<EOS>
Then
,
he
rose
and
looked
at
him
close
,
in
the
bright
daylight
,
on
every
side
,
with
great
minuteness
.
<EOS>
He
went
out
to
his
Lock
to
sum
up
what
he
had
seen
.
  
<EOS>
"
One
of
his
sleeves
is
tore
right
away
below
the
elber
,
and
the
t'other
's
had
a
good
rip
at
the
shoulder
.
<EOS>
He
's
been
hung
on
to
,
pretty
tight
,
for
his
shirt
's
all
tore
out
of
the
neck
-
gathers
.
<EOS>
He
's
been
in
the
grass
and
he
's
been
in
the
water
.
<EOS>
And
he
's
spotted
,
and
I
know
with
what
,
and
with
whose
.
<EOS>
Hooroar
!
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
slept
long
.
<EOS>
Early
in
the
afternoon
a
barge
came
down
.
<EOS>
Other
barges
had
passed
through
,
both
ways
,
before
it
;
but
the
Lock
-
keeper
hailed
only
this
particular
barge
,
for
news
,
as
if
he
had
made
a
time
calculation
with
some
nicety
.
<EOS>
The
men
on
board
told
him
a
piece
of
news
,
and
there
was
a
lingering
on
their
part
to
enlarge
upon
it
.
  
<EOS>
Twelve
hours
had
intervened
since
Bradley
's
lying
down
,
when
he
got
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Not
that
I
swaller
it
,
"
said
Riderhood
,
squinting
at
his
Lock
,
when
he
saw
Bradley
coming
out
of
the
house
,
"
as
you
've
been
a
sleeping
all
the
time
,
old
boy
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
came
to
him
,
sitting
on
his
wooden
lever
,
and
asked
what
o'clock
it
was
?
<EOS>
Riderhood
told
him
it
was
between
two
and
three
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
are
you
relieved
?
"
asked
Bradley
.
  
<EOS>
"
Day
after
to
-
morrow
,
governor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
sooner
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
a
inch
sooner
,
governor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
On
both
sides
,
importance
seemed
attached
to
this
question
of
relief
.
<EOS>
Riderhood
quite
petted
his
reply
;
saying
a
second
time
,
and
prolonging
a
negative
roll
of
his
head
,
"
n
---
<EOS>
n
---
not
a
inch
sooner
,
governor
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Did
I
tell
you
I
was
going
on
to
-
night
?
"
asked
Bradley
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
governor
,
"
returned
Riderhood
,
in
a
cheerful
,
affable
,
and
conversational

,
"
you
did
not
tell
me
so
.
<EOS>
But
most
like
you
meant
to
it
and
forgot
to
it
.
<EOS>
How
,
otherways
,
could
a
doubt
have
come
into
your
head
about
it
,
governor
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As
the
sun
goes
down
,
I
intend
to
go
on
,
"
said
Bradley
.
  
<EOS>
"
So
much
the
more
necessairy
is
a
Peck
,
"
returned
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
"
Come
in
and
have
it
,
T'otherest
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
formality
of
spreading
a
tablecloth
not
being
observed
in
Mr.
Riderhood
's
establishment
,
the
serving
of
the
"
peck
"
was
the
affair
of
a
moment
;
it
merely
consisting
in
the
handing
down
of
a
capacious
baking
dish
with
three
-
fourths
of
an
immense
meat
pie
in
it
,
and
the
production
of
two
pocket
-
knives
,
an
earthenware
mug
,
and
a
large
brown
bottle
of
beer
.
  
<EOS>
Both
ate
and
drank
,
but
Riderhood
much
the
more
abundantly
.
<EOS>
In
lieu
of
plates
,
that
honest
man
cut
two
triangular
pieces
from
the
thick
crust
of
the
pie
,
and
laid
them
,
inside
uppermost
,
upon
the
table
:
the
one
before
himself
,
and
the
other
before
his
guest
.
<EOS>
Upon
these
platters
he
placed
two
goodly
portions
of
the
contents
of
the
pie
,
thus
imparting
the
unusual
interest
to
the
entertainment
that
each
partaker
scooped
out
the
inside
of
his
plate
,
and
consumed
it
with
his
other
fare
,
besides
having
the
sport
of
pursuing
the
clots
of
congealed
gravy
over
the
plain
of
the
table
,
and
successfully
taking
them
into
his
mouth
at
last
from
the
blade
of
his
knife
,
in
case
of
their
not
first
sliding
off
it
.
  
<EOS>
Bradley
Headstone
was
so
remarkably
awkward
at
these
exercises
,
that
the
Rogue
observed
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
out
,
T'otherest
!
"
<EOS>
he
cried
,
"
you
'll
cut
your
hand
!
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
the
caution
came
too
late
,
for
Bradley
gashed
it
at
the
instant
.
<EOS>
And
,
what
was
more
unlucky
,
in
asking
Riderhood
to
tie
it
up
,
and
in
standing
close
to
him
for
the
purpose
,
he
shook
his
hand
under
the
smart
of
the
wound
,
and
shook
blood
over
Riderhood
's
dress
.
  
<EOS>
When
dinner
was
done
,
and
when
what
remained
of
the

and
what

the
congealed

had
been

back
into
what

of
the
pie
,
which
served
as
an
economical

for
all
miscellaneous
savings
,
Riderhood
filled
the
mug
with
beer
and
took

long

.
<EOS>
And
now
he
did
look
at
Bradley
,
and
with
an
evil

.
  
<EOS>
"
T'otherest
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
hoarsely
,
as
he
bent
across
the
table
to
touch

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
news
has
gone
down
the
river
afore
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
news
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Who
do
you
think
,
"
said
Riderhood
,
with
a

his

,
<EOS>
as
if
he
disdainfully
jerked
the
feint
away
,
"
picked
up

body
?
<EOS>
Guess
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
good
at
guessing
anything
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
did
.
<EOS>
Hooroar
!
<EOS>
You
had
him
there
again
.
<EOS>
She
did
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
convulsive
twitching
of
Bradley
Headstone
's
face
,
and
the
sudden
hot
humour
that
broke
out
upon
it
,
showed
how
grimly
the
intelligence
touched
him
.
<EOS>
But
he
said
not
a
single
word
,
good
or
bad
.
<EOS>
He
only
smiled
in
a
lowering
manner
,
and
got
up
and
stood
leaning
at
the
window
,
looking
through
it
.
<EOS>
Riderhood
followed
him
with
his
eyes
.
<EOS>
Riderhood
cast
down
his
eyes
on
his
own
besprinkled
clothes
.
<EOS>
Riderhood
began
to
have
an
air
of
being
better
at
a
guess
than
Bradley
owned
to
being
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
been
so
long
in
want
of
rest
,
"
said
the
school
-
master
,
"
that
with
your
leave
I
'll
lie
down
again
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
welcome
,
T'otherest
!
<EOS>
"
was
the
hospitable
answer
of
his
host
.
<EOS>
He
had
laid
himself
down
without
waiting
for
it
,
and
he
remained
upon
the
bed
until
the
sun
was
low
.
<EOS>
When
he
arose
and
came
out
to
resume

journey
,
he
found
his
host
waiting
for
him
on
the
grass
by
the
towing
-
path
outside

door
.
  
<EOS>
"
Whenever
it
may
be
necessary
that
you

should

together
,
"
said
Bradley
,
"
I
will
come
back
.
<EOS>
Good
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
since
no
better
can
be
,
"
said
Riderhood
,
turning
on
his
heel
,
"
Good
-
night
!
<EOS>
"
But
he
turned
again
as
the
other
set
forth
,
and
added
under
his
breath
,
looking
after
him
with
a
leer
:
"
You
would
n't
be
let
to
go
like
that
,
if
my
Relief
warn't
<EOS>
as
good
as
come
.
<EOS>
I
'll
catch
you
up
in
a
mile
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
In
a
word
,
his
real
time
of
relief
being
that
evening
at
sunset
,
his
mate
came
lounging
in
,
within
a
quarter
of
an
hour
.
<EOS>
Not
staying
to
fill
up
the
utmost
margin
of
his
time
,
but
borrowing
an
hour
or
so
,
to
be
repaid
again
when
he
should
relieve
his
reliever
,
Riderhood
straightway
followed
on
the
track
of
Bradley
Headstone
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
a
better
follower
than
Bradley
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
the
calling
of
his
life
to
slink
and
skulk
and
dog
and
waylay
,
and
he
knew
his
calling
well
.
<EOS>
He
effected
such
a
forced
march
on
leaving
the
Lock
House
that
he
was
close
up
with
him
---
that
is
to
say
,
as
close
up
with
him
as
he
deemed
it
convenient
to
be
---
before
another
Lock
was
passed
.
<EOS>
His
man
looked
back
pretty
often
as
he
went
,
but
got
no
hint
of
him
.
<EOS>
He
knew
how
to
take
advantage
of
the
ground
,
and
where
to
put
the
hedge
between
them
,
and
where
the
wall
,
and
when
to
duck
,
and
when
to
drop
,
and
had
a
thousand
arts
beyond
the
doomed
Bradley
's
slow
conception
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
all
his
arts
were
brought
to
a
standstill
,
like
himself
,
when
Bradley
,
turning
into
a
green
lane
or
riding
by
the
river
-
side
---
a
solitary
spot
run
wild
in
nettles
,
briars
,
and
brambles
,
and
encumbered
with
the
scathed
trunks
of
a
whole
hedgerow
of
felled
trees
,
on
the
outskirts
of
a
little
wood
---
began
stepping
on
these
trunks
and
dropping
down
among
them
and
stepping
on
them
again
,
apparently
as
a
schoolboy
might
have
done
,
but
assuredly
with
no
schoolboy
purpose
,
or
want
of
purpose
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
are
you
up
to
?
"
<EOS>
muttered
Riderhood
,
down
in
the
ditch
,
and
holding
the
hedge
a
little
open
with
both
hands
.
<EOS>
And
soon
his
actions
made
a
most
extraordinary
reply
.
"
<EOS>
By
George
and
the
Draggin
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Riderhood
,
"
if
he
ai
n't
a
going
to
bathe
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
had
passed
back
,
on
and
among
the
trunks
of
trees
again
,
and
had
passed
on
to
the
water
-
side
and
had
begun
undressing
on
the
grass
.
<EOS>
For
a
moment
it
had
a
suspicious
look
of
suicide
,
arranged
to
counterfeit
accident
.
<EOS>
"
But
you
would
n't
have
fetched
a
bundle
under
your
arm
,
from
among
that
timber
,
if
such
was
your
game
!
"
said
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
Nevertheless
it
was
a
relief
to
him
when
the
bather
after
a
plunge
and
a
few
strokes
came
out
.
<EOS>
"
For
I
should
n't
,
"
he
said
in
a
feeling
manner
,
"
have
liked
to
lose
you
till
I
had
made
more
money
out
of
you
neither
.
"
  
<EOS>
Prone
in
another
ditch
(
he
had
changed
his
ditch
as
his
man
had
changed
his
position
)
,
and
holding
apart
so
small
a
patch
of
the
hedge
that
the
sharpest
eyes
could
not
have
detected
him
,
Rogue
Riderhood
watched
the
bather
dressing
.
<EOS>
And
now
gradually
came
the
wonder
that
he
stood
up
,
completely
clothed
,
another
man
,
and
not
the
Bargeman
.
  
<EOS>
"
Aha
!
"
said
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
"
Much
as
you
was
dressed
that
night
.
<EOS>
I
see
.
<EOS>
You
're
a
taking
me
with
you
,
now
.
<EOS>
You
're
deep
.
<EOS>
But
I
knows
a
deeper
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
the
bather
had
finished
dressing
,
he
kneeled
on
the
grass
,
doing
something
with
his
hands
,
and
again
stood
up
with
his
bundle
under
his
arm
.
<EOS>
Looking
all
around
him
with
great
attention
,
he
then
went
to
the
river
's
edge
,
and
flung
it
in
as
far
,
and
yet
as
lightly
as
he
could
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
until
he
was
so
decidedly
upon
his
way
again
as
to
be
beyond
a
bend
of
the
river
and
for
the
time
out
of
view
,
that
Riderhood
scrambled
from
the
ditch
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
"
was
his
debate
with
himself
,
"
shall
I
foller
you
on
,
or
shall
I
let
you
loose
for
this
once
,
and
go
a
fishing
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
debate
continuing
,
he
followed
,
as
a
precautionary
measure
in
any
case
,
and
got
him
again
in
sight
.
<EOS>
"
If
I
was
to
let
you
loose
this
once
,
"
said
Riderhood
then
,
still
following
,
"
I
could
make
you
come
to
me
again
,
or
I
could
find
you
out
in
one
way
or
another
.
<EOS>
If
I
was
n't
to
go
a
fishing
,
others
might
.
<EOS>
---
I
'll
let
you
loose
this
once
,
and
go
a
fishing
!
"
<EOS>
With
that
,
he
suddenly
dropped
the
pursuit
and
turned
.
  
<EOS>
The
miserable
man
whom
he
had
released
for
the
time
,
but
not
for
long
,
went
on
towards
London
.
<EOS>
Bradley
was
suspicious
of
every
sound
he
heard
,
and
of
every
face
he
saw
,
but
was
under
a
spell
which
very
commonly
falls
upon
the
shedder
of
blood
,
and
had
no
suspicion
of
the
real
danger
that
lurked
in
his
life
,
and
would
have
it
yet
.
<EOS>
Riderhood
was
much
in
his
thoughts
---
had
never
been
out
of
his
thoughts
since
the
night
-
adventure
of
their
first
meeting
;
but
Riderhood
occupied
a
very
different
place
there
,
from
the
place
of
pursuer
;
 
and
Bradley
had
been
at
the
pains
of
devising
so
many
means
of
fitting
that
place
to
him
,
and
of
wedging
him
into
it
,
that
his
mind
could
not
compass
the
possibility
of
his
occupying
any
other
.
<EOS>
And
this
is
another
spell
against
which
the
shedder
of
blood
for
ever
strives
in
vain
.
<EOS>
There
are
fifty
doors
by
which
discovery
may
enter
.
<EOS>
With
infinite
pains
and
cunning
,
he
double
locks
and
bars
forty
-
nine
of
them
,
and
can
not
see
the
fiftieth
standing
wide
open
.
  
<EOS>
Now
,
too
,
was
he
cursed
with
a
state
of
mind
more
wearing
and
more
wearisome
than
remorse
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
remorse
;
but
the
evildoer
who
can
hold
that
avenger
at
bay
,
can
not
escape
the
slower
torture
of
incessantly
doing
the
evil
deed
again
and
doing
it
more
efficiently
.
<EOS>
In
the
defensive
declarations
and
pretended
confessions
of
murderers
,
the
pursuing
shadow
of
this
torture
may
be
traced
through
every
lie
they
tell
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
done
it
as
alleged
,
is
it
conceivable
that
I
would
have
made
this
and
this
mistake
?
<EOS>
If
I
had
done
it
as
alleged
,
should
I
have
left
that
unguarded
place
which
that
false
and
wicked
witness
against
me
so
infamously
deposed
to
?
<EOS>
The
state
of
that
wretch
who
continually
finds
the
weak
spots
in
his
own
crime
,
and
strives
to
strengthen
them
when
it
is
unchangeable
,
is
a
state
that
aggravates
the
offence
by
doing
the
deed
a
thousand
times
instead
of
once
;
but
it
is
a
state
,
too
,
that
tauntingly
visits
the
offence
upon
a
sullen
unrepentant
nature
with
its
heaviest
punishment
every
time
.
  
<EOS>
Bradley
toiled
on
,
chained
heavily
to
the
idea
of
his
hatred
and
his
vengeance
,
and
thinking
how
he
might
have
satiated
both
in
many
better
ways
than
the
way
he
had
taken
.
<EOS>
The
instrument
might
have
been
better
,
the
spot
and
the
hour
might
have
been
better
chosen
.
<EOS>
To
batter
a
man
down
from
behind
in
the
dark
,
on
the
brink
of
a
river
,
was
well
enough
,
but
he
ought
to
have
been
instantly
disabled
,
whereas
he
had
turned
and
seized
his
assailant
;
 
and
so
,
to
end
it
before
chance
-
help
came
,
and
to
be
rid
of
him
,
he
had
been
hurriedly
thrown
backward
into
the
river
before
the
life
was
fully
beaten
out
of
him
.
<EOS>
Now
if
it
could
be
done
again
,
it
must
not
be
so
done
.
<EOS>
Supposing
his
head
had
been
held
down
under
water
for
a
while
.
<EOS>
Supposing
the
first
blow
had
been
truer
.
<EOS>
Supposing
he
had
been
shot
.
<EOS>
Supposing
he
had
been
strangled
.
<EOS>
Suppose
this
way
,
that
way
,
the
other
way
.
<EOS>
Suppose
anything
but
getting
unchained
from
the
one
idea
,
for
that
was
inexorably
impossible
.
  
<EOS>
The
school
reopened
next
day
.
<EOS>
The
scholars
saw
little
or
no
change
in
their
master
's
face
,
for
it
always
wore
its
slowly
labouring
expression
.
<EOS>
But
,
as
he
heard
his
classes
,
he
was
always
doing
the
deed
and
doing
it
better
.
<EOS>
As
he
paused
with
his
piece
of
chalk
at
the
black
board
before
writing
on
it
,
he
was
thinking
of
the
spot
,
and
whether
the
water
was
not
deeper
and
the
fall
straighter
,
a
little
higher
up
,
or
a
little
lower
down
.
<EOS>
He
had
half
a
mind
to
draw
a
line
or
two
upon
the
board
,
and
show
himself
what
he
meant
.
<EOS>
He
was
doing
it
again
and
improving
on
the
manner
,
at
prayers
,
in
his
mental
arithmetic
,
all
through
his
questioning
,
all
through
the
day
.
  
<EOS>
Charley
Hexam
was
a
master
now
,
in
another
school
,
under
another
head
.
<EOS>
It
was
evening
,
and
Bradley
was
walking
in
his
garden
observed
from
behind
a
blind
by
gentle
little
Miss
Peecher
,
who
contemplated
offering
him
a
loan
of
her
smelling
salts
for
headache
,
when
Mary
Anne
,
in
faithful
attendance
,
held
up
her
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
Mary
Anne
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Young
Mr.
Hexam
,
if
you
please
,
ma'am
,
coming
to
see
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
good
,
Mary
Anne
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
Mary
Anne
held
up
her
arm
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
may
speak
,
Mary
Anne
?
"
  
"
Mr.
Headstone
has
beckoned
young
Mr.
Hexam
into
his
house
,
ma'am
,
and
he
has
gone
in
himself
without
waiting
for
young
Mr.
Hexam
to
come
up
,
and
now
he
has
gone
in
too
,
ma'am
,
and
has
shut
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
With
all
my
heart
,
Mary
Anne
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again
Mary
Anne
's
telegraphic
arm
worked
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
more
,
Mary
Anne
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
They
must
find
it
rather
dull
and
dark
,
Miss
Peecher
,
for
the
parlour
blind
's
down
,
and
neither
of
them
pulls
it
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
accounting
,
"
said
good
Miss
Peecher
with
a
little
sad
sigh
which
she
repressed
by
laying
her
hand
on
her
neat
methodical
boddice
,
"
there
is
no
accounting
for
tastes
,
Mary
Anne
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Charley
,
entering
the
dark
room
,
stopped
short
when
he
saw
his
old
friend
in
its
yellow
shade
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
in
,
Hexam
,
come
in
.
"
  
<EOS>
Charley
advanced
to
take
the
hand
that
was
held
out
to
him
;
but
stopped
again
,
short
of
it
.
<EOS>
The
heavy
,
bloodshot
eyes
of
the
schoolmaster
,
rising
to
his
face
with
an
effort
,
met
his
look
of
scrutiny
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Headstone
,
what
's
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Matter
?
<EOS>
Where
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Headstone
,
have
you
heard
the
news
?
<EOS>
This
news
about
the
fellow
,
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
?
<EOS>
That
he
is
killed
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
dead
,
then
!
"
exclaimed
Bradley
.
  
<EOS>
Young
Hexam
standing
looking
at
him
,
he
moistened
his
lips
with
his
tongue
,
looked
about
the
room
,
glanced
at
his
former
pupil
,
and
looked
down
.
<EOS>
"
I
heard
of
the
outrage
,
"
said
Bradley
,
trying
to
constrain
his
working
mouth
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
had
not
heard
the
end
of
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
were
you
,
"
said
the
boy
,
advancing
a
step
as
he
lowered
his
voice
,
"
when
it
was
done
?
<EOS>
Stop
!
<EOS>
I
do
n't
ask
that
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
tell
me
.
<EOS>
If
you
force
your
confidence
upon
me
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
I
'll
give
up
every
word
of
it
.
<EOS>
Mind
!
<EOS>
Take
notice
.
<EOS>
I
'll
give
up
it
,
and
I
'll
give
up
you
.
<EOS>
I
will
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
wretched
creature
seemed
to
suffer
acutely
under
this
renunciation
.
<EOS>
A
desolate
air
of
utter
and
complete
loneliness
fell
upon
him
,
like
a
visible
shade
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
for
me
to
speak
,
not
you
,
"
said
the
boy
.
<EOS>
"
If
you
do
,
you
'll
do
it
at
your
peril
.
<EOS>
I
am
going
to
put
your
selfishness
before
you
,
Mr.
Headstone
---
your
passionate
,
violent
,
and
ungovernable
selfishness
 
---
to
show
you
why
I
can
,
and
why
I
will
,
have
nothing
more
to
do
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
looked
at
young
Hexam
as
if
he
were
waiting
for
a
scholar
to
go
on
with
a
lesson
that
he
knew
by
heart
and
was
deadly
tired
of
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
said
his
last
word
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
had
any
part
---
I
do
n't
say
what
---
in
this
attack
,
"
pursued
the
boy
;
"
or
if
you
know
anything
about
it
---
I
do
n't
say
how
much
---
  
or
if
you
know
who
did
it
<EOS>
---
I
go
no
closer
---
you
did
an
injury
to
me
that
's
never
to
be
forgiven
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
took
you
with
me
to
his
chambers
in
the
Temple
when
I
told
him
my
opinion
of
him
,
and
made
myself
responsible
for
my
opinion
of
you
.
<EOS>
You
know
that
I
took
you
with
me
when
I
was
watching
him
with
a
view
to
recovering
my
sister
and
bringing
her
to
her
senses
;
you
know
that
I
have
allowed
myself
to
be
mixed
up
with
you
,
all
through
this
business
,
in
favouring
your
desire
to
marry
my
sister
.
<EOS>
And
how
do
you
know
that
,
pursuing
the
ends
of
your
own
violent
temper
,
you
have
not
laid
me
open
to
suspicion
?
<EOS>
Is
that
your
gratitude
to
me
,
Mr.
Headstone
?
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
sat
looking
steadily
before
him
at
the
vacant
air
.
<EOS>
As
often
as
young
Hexam
stopped
,
he
turned
his
eyes
towards
him
,
as
if
he
were
waiting
for
him
to
go
on
with
the
lesson
,
and
get
it
done
.
<EOS>
As
often
as
the
boy
resumed
,
Bradley
resumed
his
fixed
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
be
plain
with
you
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
"
said
young
Hexam
,
shaking
his
head
in
a
half
-
threatening
manner
,
"
because
this
is
no
time
for
affecting
not
to
know
things
that
I
do
know
---
except
certain
things
at
which
it
might
not
be
very
safe
for
you
,
to
hint
again
.
<EOS>
What
I
mean
is
this
:
if
you
were
a
good
master
,
I
was
a
good
pupil
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
you
plenty
of
credit
,
and
in
improving
my
own
reputation
I
have
improved
yours
quite
as
much
.
<EOS>
Very
well
then
.
<EOS>
Starting
on
equal
terms
,
I
want
to
put
before
you
how
you
have
shown
your
gratitude
to
me
,
for
doing
all
I
could
to
further
your
wishes
with
reference
to
my
sister
.
<EOS>
You
have
compromised
me
by
being
seen
about
with
me
,
endeavouring
to
counteract
this
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
That
's
the
first
thing
you
have
done
.
<EOS>
If
my
character
,
and
my
now
dropping
you
,
help
me
out
of
that
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
the
deliverance
is
to
be
attributed
to
me
,
and
not
to
you
.
<EOS>
No
thanks
to
you
for
it
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
boy
stopping
again
,
he
moved
his
eyes
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
on
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
do
n't
you
be
afraid
.
<EOS>
I
am
going
on
to
the
end
,
and
I
have
told
you
beforehand
what
the
end
is
.
<EOS>
Now
,
you
know
my
story
.
<EOS>
You
are
as
well
aware
as
I
am
,
that
I
have
had
many
disadvantages
to
leave
behind
me
in
life
.
<EOS>
You
have
heard
me
mention
my
father
,
and
you
are
sufficiently
acquainted
with
the
fact
that
the
home
from
which
I
,
as
I
may
say
,
escaped
,
might
have
been
a
more
creditable
one
than
it
was
.
<EOS>
My
father
died
,
and
then
it
might
have
been
supposed
that
my
way
to
respectability
was
pretty
clear
.
<EOS>
No
.
<EOS>
For
then
my
sister
begins
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
spoke
as
confidently
,
and
with
as
entire
an
absence
of
any
tell
-
tale
colour
in
his
cheek
,
as
if
there
were
no
softening
old
time
behind
him
.
<EOS>
Not
wonderful
,
for
there
was
none
in
his
hollow
empty
heart
.
<EOS>
What
is
there
but
self
,
for
selfishness
to
see
behind
it
?
  
<EOS>
"
When
I
speak
of
my
sister
,
I
devoutly
wish
that
you
had
never
seen
her
,
Mr.
Headstone
.
<EOS>
However
,
you
did
see
her
,
and
that
's
useless
now
.
<EOS>
I
confided
in
you
about
her
.
<EOS>
I
explained
her
character
to
you
,
and
how
she
interposed
some
ridiculous
fanciful
notions
in
the
way
of
our
being
as
respectable
as
I
tried
for
.
<EOS>
You
fell
in
love
with
her
,
and
I
favoured
you
with
all
my
might
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
be
induced
to
favour
you
,
and
so
we
came
into
collision
with
this
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
.
<EOS>
Now
,
what
have
you
done
?
<EOS>
Why
,
you
have
justified
my
sister
in
being
firmly
set
against
you
from
first
to
last
,
and
you
have
put
me
in
the
wrong
again
!
<EOS>
And
why
have
you
done
it
?
<EOS>
Because
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
you
are
in
all
your
passions
so
selfish
,
and
so
concentrated
upon
yourself
,
that
you
have
not
bestowed
one
proper
thought
on
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
cool
conviction
with
which
the
boy
took
up
and
held
his
position
,
could
have
been
derived
from
no
other
vice
in
human
nature
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
,
"
he
went
on
,
actually
with
tears
,
"
an
extraordinary
circumstance
attendant
on
my
life
,
that
every
effort
I
make
towards
perfect
respectability
,
is
impeded
by
somebody
else
through
no
fault
of
mine
!
<EOS>
Not
content
with
doing
what
I
have
put
before
you
,
you
will
drag
my
name
into
notoriety
through
dragging
my
sister
's
---
  
which
you
are
pretty
sure
to
do
,
if
my
suspicions
have
any
foundation
at
all
---
and
the
worse
you
prove
to
be
,
the
harder
it
will
be
for
me
to
detach
myself
from
being
associated
with
you
in
people
's
minds
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
he
had
dried
his
eyes
and
heaved
a
sob
over
his
injuries
,
he
began
moving
towards
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
However
,
I
have
made
up
my
mind
that
I
will
become
respectable
in
the
scale
of
society
,
and
that
I
will
not
be
dragged
down
by
others
.
<EOS>
I
have
done
with
my
sister
as
well
as
with
you
.
<EOS>
Since
she
cares
so
little
for
me
as
to
care
nothing
for
undermining
my
respectability
,
she
shall
go
her
way
<EOS>
and
I
will
go
mine
.
<EOS>
My
prospects
are
very
good
,
and
I
mean
to
follow
them
alone
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Headstone
,
I
do
n't
say
what
you
have
got
upon
your
conscience
,
for
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
Whatever
lies
upon
it
,
I
hope
you
will
see
the
justice
of
keeping
wide
and
clear
of
me
,
and
will
find
a
consolation
in
completely
exonerating
all
but
yourself
.
<EOS>
I
hope
,
before
many
years
are
out
,
to
succeed
the
master
in
my
present
school
,
and
the
mistress
being
a
single
woman
,
though
some
years
older
than
I
am
,
I
might
even
marry
her
.
<EOS>
If
it
is
any
comfort
to
you
to
know
what
plans
I
may
work
out
by
keeping
myself
strictly
respectable
in
the
scale
of
society
,
these
are
the
plans
at
present
occurring
to
me
.
<EOS>
In
conclusion
,
if
you
feel
a
sense
of
having
injured
me
,
and
a
desire
to
make
some
small
reparation
,
I
hope
you
will
think
how
respectable
you
might
have
been
yourself
,
and
will
contemplate
your
blighted
existence
.
"
  
<EOS>
Was
it
strange
that
the
wretched
man
should
take
this
heavily
to
heart
?
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
had
taken
the
boy
to
heart
,
first
,
through
some
long
laborious
years
;
perhaps
through
the
same
years
he
had
found
his
drudgery
lightened
by
communication
with
a
brighter
and
more
apprehensive
spirit
than
his
own
;
perhaps
a
family
resemblance
of
face
and
voice
between
the
boy
and
his
sister
,
smote
him
hard
in
the
gloom
of
his
fallen
state
.
<EOS>
For
whichsoever
reason
,
or
for
all
,
he
drooped
his
devoted
head
when
the
boy
was
gone
,
and
shrank
together
on
the
floor
,
and
grovelled
there
,
with
the
palms
of
his
hands
tight
-
clasping
his
hot
temples
,
in
unutterable
misery
,
and
unrelieved
by
a
single
tear
.
  
<EOS>
Rogue
Riderhood
had
been
busy
with
the
river
that
day
.
<EOS>
He
had
fished
with
assiduity
on
the
previous
evening
,
but
the
light
was
short
,
and
he
had
fished
unsuccessfully
.
<EOS>
He
had
fished
again
that
day
with
better
luck
,
and
had
carried
his
fish
home
to
Plashwater
Weir
Mill
Lock
-
house
,
in
a
bundle
.
   
<EOS>
A
FEW
GRAINS
OF
PEPPER
.
 
<EOS>
The
dolls
'
dressmaker
went
no
more
to
the
business
-
premises
of
Pubsey
and
Co.
in
St.
Mary
Axe
,
after
chance
had
disclosed
to
her
(
as
she
supposed
)
<EOS>
the
flinty
and
hypocritical
character
of
Mr.
Riah
.
<EOS>
She
often
moralized
over
her
work
on
the
tricks
and
the
manners
of
that
venerable
cheat
,
but
made
her
little
purchases
elsewhere
,
and
lived
a
secluded
life
.
<EOS>
After
much
consultation
with
herself
,
she
decided
not
to
put
Lizzie
Hexam
on
her
guard
against
the
old
man
,
arguing
that
the
disappointment
of
finding
him
out
would
come
upon
her
quite
soon
enough
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
in
her
communication
with
her
friend
by
letter
,
she
was
silent
on
this
theme
,
and
principally
dilated
on
the
backslidings
of
her
bad
child
,
who
every
day
grew
worse
and
worse
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
wicked
old
boy
,
"
Miss
Wren
would
say
to
him
,
with
a

,
"
you
'll
force
me
to
run
away
from
you
,
after
all
,
you
will
;
and
then
you
'll
shake
to
bits
,
and
there
'll
be
nobody
to
pick
up
the
pieces
!
"
  
<EOS>
At
this
foreshadowing
of
a
desolate
decease
,
the
wicked
old
boy
would
whine
and
whimper
,
and
would
sit
shaking
himself
into
the
lowest
of
low
spirits
,
until
such
time
as
he
could
shake
himself
out
of
the
house
and
shake
another
threepennyworth
into
himself
.
<EOS>
But
dead
drunk
or
dead
sober
(
he
had
come
to
such
a
pass
that
he
was
least
alive
in
the
latter
state
)
,
it
was
always
on
the
conscience
of
the
paralytic
scarecrow
that
he
had
betrayed
his
sharp
parent
for
sixty

of
rum
,
which
were
all
gone
,
and
that
her
sharpness
would
infallibly
detect

having
done

,
sooner
or
later
.
<EOS>
All
things
considered
therefore
,
and
addition
made
of
the
state
of
his
body
to
the
state
of
his

,
the
bed
on
which
Mr.
Dolls
reposed
was
a
bed

roses
from
which
the
flowers
and

had
entirely

,
leaving
him
to
lie
upon
the

.
  
<EOS>
On
a
certain
day
,
Miss
Wren
was
alone
at
her

,
with
the
house
-
door
set
open
for

,

was

a

which
might

she

,

the

of

,
when
whom

standing

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Did

?
"
<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
Quite

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>

!

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
A

<EOS>

<EOS>
---

<EOS>

We

"

No
,

Navy

<EOS>

Mr.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

out
her
doll
at
arm
's
length
,
and
critically
contemplating
the
effect
of
her
art
with
her
scissors
on
her
lips
and
her
head
thrown
back
,
as
if
her
interest
lay
there
,
and
not
in
the
conversation
;
"
perhaps
you
'll
explain
your
meaning
,
young
man
,
which
is
Greek
to
me
.
<EOS>
---
You
must
have
another
touch
of
blue
in
your
trimming
,
my
dear
.
"
<EOS>
Having
addressed
the
last
remark
to
her
fair
client
,
Miss
Wren
proceeded
to
snip
at
some
blue
fragments
that
lay
before
her
,
among
fragments
of
all

,
and
to
thread
a
needle
from
a
skein
of
blue
silk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
here
,
"
said
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
---
"
Are
you
attending
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
attending
,

,
"

Miss
Wren
,
without

.
"
<EOS>
Another
touch
of
blue
in
your

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

here
,
"
said
Fledgeby
,

.
<EOS>
"
If

're

---
"
  
(
"
Light

,

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Little

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
Now

<EOS>
So

,
<EOS>
Miss

,

that

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
---

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
This

"

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mr.

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
Thereupon
,

,

into

,
seemed
to
bowstring

into
the

.
  
<EOS>
For
the
terrors
undergone
by
Mr.
Dolls
that
evening
when
his
little
parent
sat
profoundly
meditating
over
her
work
,
and
when
he
imagined
himself
found
out
,
as
often
as
she
changed
her
attitude
;
or

him
,
there

.
<EOS>
Moreover

her

to
shake

at
that
wretched
old
boy
when

caught
his
eye
as

and
shook
.
<EOS>
What
are
popularly
called
"
the
trembles
"
being
in

that

,
and

"
the
horrors
,
"
he

a

;
which
was
not

by
his
being
so

as
frequently

"
Sixty

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This

not

at

as

,

Gargantuan

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
What

Dolls
,
could

for

dolls
'

.
<EOS>
However
,
she
was
on
the
alert

,
and
drove

,
and
set

two

,

her

to

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
Until

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
While

,

,

,
as

,

.
<EOS>
The
lady
being
of
a
stature
to
stop

,
and

,

dressmaker

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
?
<EOS>
Why

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

a

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Fledgeby
in

,

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

's

,
I

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
's
carpet
<EOS>
,
I
dare
say
,
"
replied
the
smiling
lady
.
  
<EOS>
Miss
Wren
had
a
reasonably
good
eye
for
smiles
,
being
well
accustomed
to
them
on
the
part
of
her
young
friends
,
though
their
smiles
mostly
ran
smaller
than
in
nature
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
never
seen
so
singular
a
smile
as
that
upon
this
lady
's
face
.
<EOS>
It
twitched
her
nostrils
open
in
a
remarkable
manner
,
and
contracted
her
lips
and
eyebrows
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
smile
of
enjoyment
too
,
though
of
such
a
fierce
kind
that
Miss
Wren
thought
she
would
rather
not
enjoy
herself
than
do
it
in
that
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
!
"
said
the
lady
,
watching
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
now
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
there
's
nothing
the
matter
!
"
said
the
dressmaker
.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
?
"
inquired
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
where
,
"
said
Miss
Wren
,
staring

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
never
heard
such
odd
noises
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
you
think
I
had

call

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
you
had
better
not
,
"
returned
the
lady
with
a
significant
frown
,
and
drawing
closer
.
  
<EOS>
On
this
hint
,
the
dressmaker
relinquished
the
idea
,
and
stood
looking
at
the
lady
as
hard
as
the
lady
looked
at
her
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
the
dressmaker
listened
with
amazement
to
the
odd
noises
which
still
continued
,
and
the
lady
listened
too
,
but
with
a
coolness
in
which
there
was
no
trace
of

.
  
<EOS>
Soon
afterwards
,
came
a
slamming
and
banging
of
doors
;
and
then
came
running
down
stairs
,
a
gentleman
with

,
and
out

,
who
seemed
to
be
red
-
hot
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
your
business
done
,
Alfred
?
"
inquired

lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
thoroughly
done
,
"
replied
the
gentleman
,
as
he
took
his

from
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
go
up
to
Mr.
Fledgeby
as
soon
as
you
like
,
"
said
the
lady
,
moving
haughtily

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
And
you
can
take
these

,
"
added

,
"

,

Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
,

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
.
<EOS>
Be
so
good
as

name
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
three
pieces
of
stick
were
three
broken
and

of
a
stout
lithe
cane
.
<EOS>
Miss
Jenny
taking

wonderingly
,
and
the

with
a

,
"
Mr.
Alfred
Lammle
,
if
you
'll
be
so
good
.
<EOS>
Compliments
,
on
leaving
England
,
"
the

walked
away
quite

,
and
Miss

and

up

.
<EOS>
"
Lammle
,
Lammle
,
Lammle
?
"
Miss
Jenny
repeated
as
she
panted
from
stair
to

,
"
where
have
I
heard
that
name
?
<EOS>
Lammle
,
Lammle
?
<EOS>
I

!
<EOS>
Saint
Mary
Axe
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
gleam
of
new
intelligence
in
her
sharp
face
,
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
pulled
at
Fledgeby
's
bell
.
<EOS>
No
one
answered
;
but
,
from
within
the
chambers
,
there
proceeded
a
continuous
spluttering
sound
of
a
highly
singular
and
unintelligible
nature
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
gracious
!
<EOS>
Is
Little
Eyes
choking
?
"
cried
Miss
Jenny
.
  
<EOS>
Pulling
at
the
bell
again
and
getting
no

,
she
pushed
the
outer
door
,
and
found
it
standing
ajar
.
<EOS>
No

being
visible
on
her
opening

wider
,
and
the

continuing
,
she
took
the
liberty
of
opening
an
inner

,
and
then
beheld
the
extraordinary

of
Mr.
Fledgeby
in

,

,
and

,
rolling
over
and

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Lord
!
"
gasped
Mr.
Fledgeby
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
my
eye
!
<EOS>
Stop
thief
!
<EOS>
I
am
strangling
.
<EOS>
Fire
!
<EOS>
Oh
my
eye
!
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
Give

a
glass

water
.
<EOS>
Shut

.
<EOS>
Murder
!
<EOS>
Oh
Lord
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
rolled
and
spluttered
more
than

.
  
<EOS>
Hurrying
into
another
room
,
Miss
Jenny
got
a
glass
of
water
,
and
brought
it
for
Fledgeby
's
relief
;
who
,
gasping
,
spluttering
,
and
rattling
in
his

betweenwhiles
,
drank
some
water
,
and
laid
his

faintly
on
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
my
eye
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Fledgeby
,

.
<EOS>
"
It
's
salt
and
snuff
.
<EOS>
It
's
up
my

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
Ugh
!
<EOS>
Ow
!
<EOS>
Ow
!
<EOS>
Ow
!
<EOS>
Ah
---
h
---
h
---
h
!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
Oh
my
Eye
,

"
<EOS>

,
starting
,
over

<EOS>
"
Oh
I
smart
so
!
<EOS>
Do

,

.
<EOS>
Ugh
!
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
Ow

<EOS>
Ow
!
<EOS>
Ow
!
<EOS>
Ah

h
---
h
---

!
<EOS>
Oh

smart
so
!
"
 
<EOS>
Here

Fledgeby

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
The
dolls
'
dressmaker

on

<EOS>
But
,

"
Oh

!
<EOS>
do

!
<EOS>
I

covered

weales
and
<EOS>
I
smart

!
"
  
<EOS>

,

saving

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Lammle
.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Ugh

---

.

.
<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>

<EOS>
Will

<EOS>

!

In

"

.
<EOS>
They

,

,

.
<EOS>
Cut

;

.
<EOS>
Oh

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
There
?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
Lord
,

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
"
<EOS>
And

!
<EOS>
Everywhere
!
"
  
<EOS>
The

dressmaker

,
and
laid
bare
the
results
of
as

even

Fledgeby
merited
.
<EOS>
"
You
may
well
smart
,

!
<EOS>
"

Miss
Jenny
.
<EOS>
And
stealthily
rubbed
her

,
and
poked

with
her
two

over

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
think
of

?
"
<EOS>
inquired

Fledgeby
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Does

brown

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Fledgeby
collapsed

"
Pickled
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
My

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
It
ca

.
<EOS>

,

---

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,

,
"

.

<EOS>
Miss

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

,
"

<EOS>
Just

?
<EOS>

's

make

?
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

's

on

chimneypiece
<EOS>
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

:
<EOS>
Mr.

uttering

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,

!
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Now

?
"
  
<EOS>

"
<EOS>
Oh
---
h
<EOS>
how
I
do
smart
!
"
  
<EOS>
Miss

,

"

"
Oh

"

.

<EOS>
No
,
I
ai

.
<EOS>
Oh

h
---
h
!
<EOS>
how

!

<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
She

,
and
all

other

,
and

and
emerging
from

into

,
took

for
Saint
Mary
Axe
:
pressing
on

all
the

-
dressed
ladies
whom
she
could
see
from

,
and
making
them
unconscious
lay
-
figures
for
dolls
,
while
she
mentally
cut
them
out
and
basted
them
.
   
<EOS>
TWO
PLACES
VACATED
.
 
<EOS>
Set
down
by
the
omnibus
at
the
corner
of
Saint
Mary
Axe
,
and
trusting
to
her
feet
and
her
crutch
-
stick
within
its
precincts
,
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
proceeded
to
the
place
of
business
of
Pubsey
and
<EOS>
Co.
All
there
was
sunny
and
quiet
externally
,
and
shady
and
quiet
internally
.
<EOS>
Hiding
herself
in
the
entry
outside
the
glass
door
,
she
could
see
from
that
post
of
observation
the
old
man
in
his
spectacles
sitting
writing
at
his
desk
.
  
<EOS>
"
Boh
!
"
cried
the
dressmaker
,
popping
in
her
head
at
the
glass
-
door
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Wolf
at
home
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
old
man
took
his
glasses
off
,
and
mildly

down

.
"
<EOS>
Ah
Jenny
,
is
it
you
?
<EOS>
I
thought
you
had
given
me
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
I
had

,

the
trodden
vegetable
refuse
which
is
so
like
their
own
dress
that
perhaps
they
take
the
Market
for
a
great
wardrobe
;
but
be
it
<EOS>
what
it
may
,
you
shall
see
no
such
individual
drunkards
on

anywhere
,
as
there
.
<EOS>
Of
dozing
women
-
drunkards
especially
,
you
shall
come
upon
such
specimens
there
,
in
the
morning

,
as
you
might
seek
out
of
doors
in
vain
through
London
.
<EOS>
Such
stale
vapid
rejected
cabbage
-
leaf
and
cabbage
-
stalk
dress
,
such
damaged
-
orange
countenance
,
such
squashed
pulp
of
humanity
,
are
open
to
the
day
nowhere
else
.
<EOS>
So
,
the
attraction
of
the
Market
drew
Mr.
Dolls
to
it
,
and
he
had
out
his
two
fits
of
trembles
and
horrors
in
a
doorway
on
which
a
woman
had
had
out
her
sodden
nap
a
few
hours
before
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
a
swarm
of
young
savages
always
flitting
about
this
same
place
,
creeping
off
with
fragments
of
orange
-
chests
,
and
mouldy
litter
---
Heaven
knows
into
what
holes
they
can
convey
them
,
having
no
home
!
---
whose
bare
feet
fall
with
a
blunt

softness
on
the
pavement
as
the
policeman
hunts
them
,
and
who
are
(
perhaps
for
that
reason
)
<EOS>
little
heard
by
the
Powers
that
be
,
whereas
in
topboots
they
would
make
a
deafening
clatter
.
<EOS>
These
,
delighting
in
the
trembles
and
the
horrors
of
Mr.
Dolls
,
as
in
a
gratuitous
drama
,
flocked
about
him
in
his
doorway
,
butted
at
him
,
leaped
at
him
,
and
pelted
him
.
<EOS>
Hence
,
when
he
came
out
of
his
invalid
retirement
and
shook
off
that
ragged
train
,
he
was
much
bespattered
,
and
in
worse
case
than
ever
.
<EOS>
But
,
not
yet
at
his
worst
;
for
,
going
into
a
public
-
house
,
and
being
supplied
in
stress
of
business
with
his
rum
,
and
seeking
to
vanish
without
payment
,
he
was
collared
,
searched
,
found
penniless
,
and
admonished
not
to
try
that
again
,
by
having
a
pail
of
dirty
water
cast
over
him
.
<EOS>
This
application
superinduced
another
fit
of
the
trembles
;
after
which
Mr.
Dolls
,
as
finding
himself
in
good
cue
for
making
a
call
on
a
professional
friend
,
addressed
himself
to
the
Temple
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
nobody
at
the
chambers
but
Young
Blight
.
<EOS>
That
discreet
youth
,
sensible
of
a
certain
incongruity
in
the
association
of
such
a
client
with
the
business
that
might
be
coming
some
day
,
with
the
best
intentions
temporized
with
Dolls
,
and
offered
a

for
coach
-
hire
home
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Dolls
,
accepting
the
shilling
,
promptly
laid
it
out
in
two
threepennyworths
of
conspiracy
against
his
life
,
and
two
threepennyworths
of
raging
repentance
.
<EOS>
Returning
to
the
Chambers
with
which
burden
,
he
was
descried
coming
round
into
the
court
,
by
the
wary
young
Blight
watching
from
the
window
:
who
instantly
closed
the
outer

,
and
left
the
miserable
object
to
expend

fury
on

.
  
<EOS>
The
more
the
door
resisted
him
,
the
more
dangerous
and
imminent
became
that
bloody
conspiracy
against
his
life
.
<EOS>
Force
of
police
arriving
,
he
recognized
in
them
the
conspirators
,
and
laid
about
him
hoarsely
,
fiercely
,
staringly
,
convulsively
,

.
<EOS>
A
humble
machine
,
familiar
to
the

and
called
by

of
Stretcher
,
being

sent
for
,

was
rendered
a
harmless

being

down

,
with
voice
and

gone

,
and
life

going
.
<EOS>
As
this
machine
was

out

gate
by
four

,
the
poor
little
dolls
'
dressmaker
and
her
Jewish

street
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Let

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

was
but

.
"
<EOS>
O

,

,

<EOS>
"
Belongs

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
O

<EOS>
My

<EOS>
and

<EOS>
O

"

The

(

"

.

<EOS>
As

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,

?
"

<EOS>
But

less

,
on

"

<EOS>
Thither

,

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
,

"
Mine
.

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
All

.
"
  
<EOS>
Therefore
,

,

covered

,

.
<EOS>
After

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

---
<EOS>
the

<EOS>
Many

,

.
<EOS>
As

,
Riah
,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
Not

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
None

,
Jenny
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank

,
godmother
.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
well
,

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
How

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Too

,

!
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

"
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
As

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Where

!
"
  
<EOS>
With

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
If

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
After

,

.
<EOS>
He

)

<EOS>
Yet
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
At
last

was

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Those
Furies
,
the

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
must
have
a
very

,
godmother
,
before
I
cheer
up
for
good
,
"
said
the
little
creature
,
coming
in
.
<EOS>
"
Because
after
all
a
child
is
a
child
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
longer
cry
than
might
have
been
expected
.
<EOS>
Howbeit
,
it
wore
itself
out
in
a
shadowy
corner
,
and
then
the
dressmaker
came
forth
,
and
washed
her
face
,
and
made
the
tea
.
<EOS>
"
You
would

my
cutting
out
something
while
we
are
at
tea
,
would
you
?
"
<EOS>
she

her
Jewish
friend
,
with
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Cinderella
,
dear
child
,
"
the
old
man
expostulated
,
"
will
you
never
rest
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
It
's
not
work
,
cutting
out
a
pattern
is
n't
,
"
said
Miss
Jenny
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
The
truth
is
,
godmother
,
I
want
to
fix

while
I
have

correct
in

.
"
  
"
Have
you
seen
it
to
-
day
then
?
"
asked
Riah
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
godmother
.
<EOS>
Saw
it
just

.
<EOS>
It
's
a
surplice
,

's

.
<EOS>
Thing

wear
,
you

"

Jenny
,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
godmother
,
"

,
"

we
Professors
who
live

,

.
<EOS>
And

I

many

.
<EOS>
So
,

my

's

,
that
something

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

,

!
"
returned

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
public
do
n't
like

,
I

.
<EOS>
I
am
seldom

to

into

;
not

,

;
Court

they

.
<EOS>
But
a
doll

,
my

,
 
---
glossy

---
uniting

,
"
said

Jenny
,

,
"
is

.
<EOS>
If

at
the

,
in
a

,
my
name
's
Jack
Robinson
!
"
  
<EOS>
With
her
expert
little
ways
in
sharp
