,
she
had
got
a
doll
into
whitey
-
brown
paper
orders
,
before
the
meal

over
,
and
was

for
the
edification

the
Jewish
mind
,
when

.
<EOS>
Riah
went
to
open

,
and

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

;

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

'

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Lizzie

?
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

,

"
<EOS>
And
Lizzie
Hexam
's

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Riah

.
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"
said

,

,
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
no

to

longer
.
<EOS>
Time
was
so

.
<EOS>
My
dear
friend
Mr.
Eugene
Wrayburn
is
dying
.
  
<EOS>
The
dressmaker
clasped
her
hands
,
and
uttered

little

.
  
<EOS>
"
Is

,
"

Lightwood
,

,
"
at
some

.
<EOS>
He
is

under

received

a

who

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
In

,
or

,
I

that

asked

.
<EOS>
Hardly

Lizzie
to

.
<EOS>
We
were
both

that

asked

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,
with

,

from

.
  
<EOS>
"
If

delay
,
he

with

,
with
his
last

---
intrusted
to

---
we
have
long

much

than

---
unfulfilled
.
<EOS>
I
shall
break

,
if
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
In

the
black

and

were
on
duty
,

good
Jew

left

,

dolls
'

,
side

in

,

.
   
<EOS>
THE
DOLLS
'
<EOS>
DRESSMAKER
<EOS>
DISCOVERS
<EOS>
A
WORD
.
 
<EOS>
A
darkened
and
hushed
room
;
the
river
outside
the
windows
flowing
on
to
the
vast
ocean
;
a
figure
on
the
bed
,
swathed
and
bandaged
and
bound
,
lying
helpless
on
its
back
,
with
its
two
useless
arms
in
splints
at
its
sides
.
<EOS>
Only
two
days
of
usage
so
familiarized
the
little
dressmaker
with
this
scene
,
that
it
held
the
place
occupied
two
days
ago
by
the
recollections
of
years
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
scarcely
moved
since
her
arrival
.
<EOS>
Sometimes
his
eyes
were
open
,
sometimes
closed
.
<EOS>
When
they
were
open
,
there
was
no
meaning
in
their
unwinking
stare
at
one
spot
straight
before
them
,
unless
for
a
moment
the
brow
knitted
into
a
faint
expression
of
anger
,
or
surprise
.
<EOS>
Then
,
Mortimer
Lightwood
would
speak
to
him
,
and
on
occasions
he
would
be
so
far
roused
as
to
make
an
attempt
to
pronounce
his
friend
's
name
.
<EOS>
But
,
in
an
instant
consciousness
was
gone
again
,
and
no
spirit
of
Eugene
was
in
Eugene
's
crushed
outer
form
.
  
<EOS>
They
provided
Jenny
with
materials
for
plying
her
work
,
and
she
had
a
little
table
placed
at
the
foot
of
his
bed
.
<EOS>
Sitting
there
,
with
her
rich
shower
of
hair
falling
over
the
chair
-
back
,
they
hoped
she
might
attract
his
notice
.
<EOS>
With
the
same
object
,
she
would
sing
,
just
above
her
breath
,
when
he
opened
his
eyes
,
or
she
saw
his
brow
knit
into
that
faint
expression
,
so
evanescent
that
it
was
like
a
shape
made
in
water
.
<EOS>
But
as
yet
he
had
not
heeded
.
<EOS>
The
"
they
"
here
mentioned
,
were
the
medical
attendant
;
Lizzie
,
who
was
there
in
all
her
intervals
of
rest
;
and
Lightwood
,
who
never
left
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
days
became
three
,
and
the
three
days
became
four
.
<EOS>
At
length
,
quite
unexpectedly
,
he
said
something
in
a
whisper
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
was
it
,
my
dear
Eugene
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
,
Mortimer
---
"
  
"
Will
I
---
?
"
   
---
"
Send
for
her
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
fellow
,
she
is
here
.
"
  
<EOS>
Quite
unconscious
of
the
long
blank
,
he
supposed
that
they
were
still
speaking
together
.
  
<EOS>
The
little
dressmaker
stood
up
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
,
humming
her
song
,
and
nodded
to
him
brightly
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
shake
hands
,
Jenny
,
"
 
said
Eugene
,
with
something
of
his
old
look
;
"
<EOS>
but
I
am
very
glad
to
see
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
repeated
this
to
her
,
for
it
could
only
be
made
out
by
bending
over
him
and
closely
watching
his
attempts
to
say

.
<EOS>
In
a
little
while
,
he
added
:
  
"
<EOS>
Ask
her
if
she
has
seen
the
children
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
could
not
understand
this
,
neither
could
Jenny
herself
,
until

:
  
<EOS>
"
Ask
her
if
she
has
smelt
the
flowers
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
!
I
know
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
understand
him
now
!
"
<EOS>
Then
,
Lightwood
yielded
his
place
to
her
quick
approach
,
and
she
said
,
bending
over
the
bed
,
with
that
better
look
:
"
<EOS>
You
mean
my
long
bright
slanting
rows
of
children
,
who
used
to
bring

ease
and
rest
?
<EOS>
You
mean
the
children
who
used
to
take
me
up
,
and
make

light
?
<EOS>
"
  
Eugene
smiled
,
"
Yes
.
"
  
"
I
have
not
seen
them
since
I
saw
you
.
<EOS>
I
never
see
them
now
,
but
I
am
hardly
ever
in
pain
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
a
pretty
fancy
,
"
said
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
have
heard
my
birds
sing
,
"
cried

little

,
"
and
I
have
smelt

.
<EOS>
Yes
,
indeed
I
have
!
<EOS>
And
both
were
most
beautiful
and
most
Divine
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Stay
and
help
to
nurse
me
,
"
said
Eugene
,
quietly
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
you
to
have
the
fancy
here
,
before
I
die
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
touched
his
lips
with
her
hand
,
and
shaded
her
eyes
with
that
same
hand
as
she
went
back
to
her
work
and
her
little
low
song
.
<EOS>
He
heard
the
song
with
evident
pleasure
,
until
she
allowed
it
gradually
to
sink
away
into
silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mortimer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
can
give
me
anything
to
keep
me
here
for
only
a

minutes
---
"
  
"
To
keep
you
here
,
Eugene
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
To
prevent
my
wandering
away
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
where
---
for
I
begin
to
be
sensible
that
I
have
just
come
back
,
and
that
I
shall
lose
myself
again
---
do

,
dear
boy
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
gave
him
such

as
could
be
given
him
with
safety
(
they
were
always
at
hand
,
ready
)
,
and
bending
over

once
more
,
was
about
to
caution

,
when
he
said
:
  
"
Do
n't
tell
me
not
to

,
for
I
must
speak
.
<EOS>
If
you
knew
the
harassing
anxiety
that
gnaws

when
I
am

in
those

---
<EOS>
where
are
those
endless
places
,
Mortimer
?
<EOS>
They
must
be
at
an
immense
distance
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
saw
in
his
friend
's
face
that
he
was
losing

;
for
he
added
after

:
"
Do
n't

---
I
am

.
<EOS>
What
was
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
wanted

,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
My
poor
dear
fellow
,
you
wanted
to

to
your
old
friend
---
to
the
friend
who
has
always
loved
you
,
admired
you
,
imitated

,
founded
himself
upon
you
,
been
nothing
without
you
,
and
who
,
God
knows
,
would
be
here
in
your
place
if
he
could
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tut
,
tut
!
"
said
Eugene
with
a
tender
glance
as
the
other
put
his
hand
before
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
worth
it
.
<EOS>
I
acknowledge
that
I
like
it
,
dear
boy
,
but
I
am
not
worth
it
.
<EOS>
This
attack
,
my
dear
Mortimer
;
this
murder
---
"
  
<EOS>
His
friend
leaned
over
him
with
renewed
attention
,
saying
:
"
You
and
I
suspect
some
one
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
More
than
suspect
.
<EOS>
But
,
Mortimer
,
while
I
lie
here
,
and
when
I
lie
here
no
longer
,
I
trust
to
you
that
the
perpetrator
is
never
brought
to
justice
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Her
innocent
reputation
would
be
ruined
,
my
friend
.
<EOS>
She
would
be
punished
,
not
he
.
<EOS>
I
have
wronged
her
enough
in

;
I
have

in

.
<EOS>
You
recollect
what
pavement
is
said
to
be
made

good

.
<EOS>
It
is

bad

.
<EOS>
Mortimer
,
I
am
lying
on
it
,
and
I
know
!
<EOS>
"
  
"
Be
comforted
,
my

Eugene
.
"
  
"
I
will
,
when
you
have
promised
me
.
<EOS>
Dear
Mortimer
,
the
man
must
never
be

.
<EOS>
If
he
should
be
accused
,
you
must
keep
him
silent
and
save
him
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
think
of
avenging
me
;
think
only
of
hushing
the
story
and
protecting
her
.
<EOS>
You
can
confuse
the
case
,
and
turn
aside
the
circumstances
.
<EOS>
Listen
to
what
I
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
the
schoolmaster
,
Bradley
Headstone
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
me
?
<EOS>
Twice
;
it
was
not
the
schoolmaster
,
Bradley
Headstone
.
<EOS>
Do
you
hear
me
?
<EOS>
Three
times
;
it
was
not
the
schoolmaster
,
Bradley
Headstone
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
stopped
,
exhausted
.
<EOS>
His
speech
had
been
whispered
,
broken
,
and
indistinct
;
but
by
a
great
effort
he
had
made
it
plain
enough
to
be
unmistakeable
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
fellow
,
I
am
wandering
away
.
<EOS>
Stay
me
for
another
moment
,
if
you
can
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
lifted
his
head
at
the
neck
,
and
put
a
wine
-
glass
to
his
lips
.
<EOS>
He
rallied
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
long
ago
it
was
done
,
whether
weeks
,
days
,
or
hours
.
<EOS>
No
matter
.
<EOS>
There
is
inquiry
on
foot
,
and
pursuit
.
<EOS>
Say
!
<EOS>
Is
there
not
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Check
it
;
divert
it
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
her
be
brought
in
question
.
<EOS>
Shield
her
.
<EOS>
The
guilty
man
,
brought
to
justice
,
would
poison
her
name
.
<EOS>
Let
the
guilty
man
go
unpunished
.
<EOS>
Lizzie
and
my
reparation
before
all
!
<EOS>
Promise
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Eugene
,
I
do
.
<EOS>
I
promise
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
act
of
turning
his
eyes
gratefully
towards
his
friend
,
he
wandered
away
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
stood
still
,
and
settled
into
that
former
intent
unmeaning
stare
.
  
<EOS>
Hours
and
hours
,
days
and
nights
<EOS>
,
he
remained
in
this
same
condition
.
<EOS>
There
were
times
when
he
would
calmly
speak
to
his
friend
after
a
long
period
of
unconsciousness
,
and
would
say
he
was
better
,
and
would
ask
for
something
.
<EOS>
Before
it
could
be
given
him
,
he
would
be
gone
again
.
  
<EOS>
The
dolls
'
dressmaker
,
all
softened
compassion
now
,
watched
him
with
an
earnestness
that
never
relaxed
.
<EOS>
She
would
regularly
change
the
ice
,
or
the
cooling
spirit
,
on
his
head
,
and
would
keep
her
ear
at
the
pillow
between
whiles
,
listening
for
any
faint
words
that
fell
from
him
in
his
wanderings
.
<EOS>
It
was
amazing
through
how
many
hours
at
a

she
would
remain
beside
him
,
in
a
crouching
attitude
,
attentive
to
his
slightest
moan
.
<EOS>
As
he
could
not
move
a
hand
,
he
could
make
no
sign
of
distress
;
but
,
through
this
close
watching
(
if
through
no
secret
sympathy
or
power
)
the
little
creature
attained
an
understanding
of
him
that
Lightwood
did
not
possess
.
<EOS>
Mortimer
would
often
turn
to
her
,
as
if
she
were
an
interpreter
between
this
sentient
world
and
the
insensible
man
;
and
she
would
change
the
dressing
of
a
wound
,
or
ease
a
ligature
,
or
turn
his
face
,
or
alter
the
pressure
of
the
bedclothes
on
him
,
with
an
absolute
certainty
of
doing
right
.
<EOS>
The
natural
lightness
and
delicacy
of
touch
which
had
become
very
refined
by
practice
in
her
miniature
work
,
no
doubt
was
involved
in
this
;
but
her
perception
was
at
least
as
fine
.
  
<EOS>
The
one
word
,
Lizzie
,
he
muttered
millions
of
times
.
<EOS>
In
a
certain
phase
of
his
distressful
state
,
which
was
the
worst
to
those
who
tended
him
,
he
would
roll
his
head
upon
the
pillow
,
incessantly
repeating
the
name
in
a
hurried
and
impatient
manner
,
with
the
misery
of
a
disturbed
mind
,
and
the
monotony
of
a
machine
.
<EOS>
Equally
,
when
he
lay
still
and
staring
,
he
would
repeat
it
for
hours
without
cessation
,
but
then
,
always
in
a
tone
of
subdued
warning
and
horror
.
<EOS>
Her
presence
and
her
touch
upon
his
breast
or
face
would
often
stop
this
,
and
then
they
learned
to
expect
that
he
would
for
some
time
remain
still
,
with
his
eyes
closed
,
and
that
he
would
be
conscious
on
opening
them
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
heavy
disappointment
of
their
hope
---
revived
by
the
welcome
silence
of
the
room
---
was
,
that
his
spirit
would
glide
away
again
and
be
lost
,
in
the
moment
of
their
joy
that
it
was
there
.
  
<EOS>
This
frequent
rising
of
a
drowning
man
from
the
deep
,
to
sink
again
,
was
dreadful
to
the
beholders
.
<EOS>
But
,
gradually
the
change
stole
upon
him
that
it
became
dreadful
to
himself
.
<EOS>
His
desire
to
impart
something
that
was
on
his
mind
,
his

to
have
speech
with

a
communication
to
him
,
so
troubled
him
when
he
recovered

,
that
its
term
was
thereby
shortened
.
<EOS>
As
the
man
rising
from
the

would
disappear
the
sooner
for
fighting
with
the
water
,
so
he
in
his
desperate
struggle
went
down
again
.
  
<EOS>
One

when
he
had
been
lying

,
and
Lizzie
,
unrecognized
,
had
just
stolen

the
room
to

,
he
uttered
Lightwood
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
Eugene
,
I
am
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
long
is
this
to
last
,
Mortimer
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
shook
his
head
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Still
,
Eugene
,
you
are
no
worse
than
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
know
there
's
no

.
<EOS>
Yet
I
pray
it
may
last
long
enough
for
you
to
do

last

,
and
for
me
to
do
one
last

.
<EOS>
Keep
me
here
a
few
moments
,
Mortimer
.
<EOS>
Try
,
try
!
"
  
<EOS>
His
friend
gave
him
what

he
could
,
and
encouraged
him
to
believe
that
he
was
more
composed
,
though

were

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hold
me
here
,
dear

,
if
you

.
<EOS>
Stop
my
wandering
away
.
<EOS>
I
am
going
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
yet
,
not

.
<EOS>
Tell
me
,
dear
Eugene
,
what
is

I
shall

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Keep
me
here
for
only
a

.
<EOS>
I
am
going
away
again
.
<EOS>
Do

me

.
<EOS>
Hear
me
speak
first
.
<EOS>
Stop
me
---
stop
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
poor
Eugene
,
try
to

calm
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
I
try
so

.
<EOS>
If
you
only

!
<EOS>
Do

let
me
wander
till
I
have
spoken
.
<EOS>
Give

wine
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
complied
.
<EOS>
Eugene
,
with

most

against
the
unconsciousness
that
was
coming

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
You
wo

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
Eugene
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

!
<EOS>
You
ca

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tell

,
Eugene
!
"
  
<EOS>
His

were
fixed
again
,
and
the

that

from
his
lips
was
the
word
millions
of

.
<EOS>
Lizzie
,
Lizzie
,
Lizzie
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
the
watchful
little
dressmaker
had
been
vigilant
as
ever
in

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
with

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His
eyes
are
closing
.
<EOS>
He
'll
be
conscious
when
he
next
opens

.
<EOS>
Shall

a
leading
word

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
Jenny
,
if

could

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
.
<EOS>
Stoop
down
.
"
  
<EOS>
He

,
and
she
whispered
in

.
<EOS>
She
whispered
in
his
ear
one
short
word
of
a
single

.
<EOS>
Lightwood
started
,
and
looked
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Try
it
,
"
said
the
little
creature
,
with
an

.
<EOS>
She

bent
over
the
unconscious
man
,
and
,

,
kissed
him
on

check
,
and

poor

hand
that
was
nearest

.
<EOS>
Then
,
she
withdrew
to
the
foot

bed
.
  
<EOS>
Some
two
hours
afterwards
,
Mortimer
Lightwood
saw
his
consciousness
come
back
,
and
instantly
,
but
very
tranquilly
,
bent
over
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
speak
,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
Do
no
more
than
look
at
me
,
and
listen

me
.
<EOS>
You
follow
what
I
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
moved
his
head
in
assent
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
on
from
the
point
where
we
broke
off
.
<EOS>
Is
the
word
we
should
soon
have
come
to
<EOS>
---
is
it
---
Wife
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
O
God
bless
you
,
Mortimer
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Hush
!
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
agitated
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
speak
.
<EOS>
Hear
me
,
dear
Eugene
.
<EOS>
Your
mind
will
be
more
at
peace
,
lying
here
,
if
you
make
Lizzie
your
wife
.
<EOS>
You
wish
me
to
speak
to
her
,
and
tell
her
so
,
and
entreat

be
your
wife
.
<EOS>
You

kneel

this

and
be
married

,
that
your
reparation
may
be
complete
.
<EOS>
Is

so
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
God
bless
you
!
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
shall
be
done
,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
Trust
it
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
shall
have
to
go
away
for
some

hours
,
to
give

.
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear

,
I
said

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
True
.
<EOS>
But
I
had

the
clue
then
.
<EOS>
How
do
you
think
I
got
it
?
"
  
<EOS>
Glancing

around
,
Eugene
saw
Miss
Jenny
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
,
looking
at
him
with
her
elbows
on
the
bed
,
and
her

upon

.
<EOS>
There
was
a
trace
of
his
whimsical
air
upon
him
,
as
he
tried
to
smile
at
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
indeed
,
"
said
Lightwood
,
"
the
discovery
was
hers
.
<EOS>
Observe
,
my
dear
Eugene
;
while
I
am
away
you
will
know
that
I
have
discharged
my

with
Lizzie
,
by
finding
her
here
,
in
my
present

at
your
bedside
,
to
leave
you
no
more
.
<EOS>
A
final
word
before
I
go
.
<EOS>
This
is
the
right
course
of
a
true
man
,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
And
I
solemnly
believe
,
with

,
that
if
Providence
should
mercifully
restore
you
to
us
,
you
will
be
blessed
with
a
noble
wife
in
the
preserver
of
your
life
,
whom
you
will
dearly
love
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Amen
.
<EOS>
I
am
sure
of
that
.
<EOS>
But
I
shall
not
come
through
it
,
Mortimer
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
be
the
less
hopeful
or
less
strong
,
for
this
,
Eugene
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
Touch
my
face
with
yours
,
in
case
I
should
not
hold
out
till
you
come
back
.
<EOS>
I
love
you
,
Mortimer
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
be
uneasy
for
me
while
you
are
gone
.
<EOS>
If
my
dear
brave
girl
will
take
me
,
I
feel
persuaded
that
I
shall
live
long
enough
to
be
married
,
dear
fellow
.
"
  
<EOS>
Miss
Jenny
gave
up
altogether
on
this
parting
taking
place
between
the
friends
,
and
,
sitting
with

towards
the
bed
in
the
bower
made
by
her
bright
hair
,
wept

,
though

.
<EOS>
Mortimer
Lightwood
was
soon
gone
.
<EOS>
As
the
evening
light
lengthened
the
heavy
reflections
of
the
trees
in
the
river
,
another
figure
came
with
a
soft
step
into
the
sick
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
he
conscious
?
"
asked
the
little
dressmaker
,
as
the
figure
took
its
station
by
the

.
<EOS>
For
,
Jenny
had
given
place
to
it
immediately
,
and
could
not
see
the
sufferer
's
face
,
in

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
conscious
,
Jenny
,
"
murmured
Eugene
for
himself
.
"
<EOS>
He
knows
his
wife
.
"
   
<EOS>
EFFECT
IS
GIVEN
TO
THE
DOLLS
'
DRESSMAKER
'S
DISCOVERY
.
   
<EOS>
Mrs.
John
Rokesmith
sat
at
needlework
in
her
neat
little
room
,
beside
a
basket
of
neat
little
articles
of
clothing
,
which
presented
so
much
of
the
appearance
of
being
in
the
dolls
'
dressmaker
's
way
of
business
,
that
one
might
have
supposed
she
was
going
to
set
up
in
opposition
to
Miss
Wren
.
<EOS>
Whether
the
Complete
British
Family
Housewife
had
imparted
sage
counsel
anent
them
,
did
not
appear
,
but
probably
not
,
as
that
cloudy
oracle
was
nowhere
visible
.
<EOS>
For
certain
,
however
,
Mrs.
John
Rokesmith
stitched
at
them
with
so
dexterous
a
hand
,
that
she
must
have
taken
lessons
of
somebody
.
<EOS>
Love
is
in
all
things
a
most
wonderful
teacher
,
and
perhaps
love
(
from
a
pictorial
point
of
view
,
with
nothing
on
but
a
thimble
)
,
had
been
teaching
this
branch
of
needle
work
to
Mrs.
John
Rokesmith
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
near
John
's
time
for
coming
home
,
but
as
Mrs.
John
was
desirous
to
finish
a
special
triumph
of
her
skill
before
dinner
,
she
did
not
go
out
to
meet

.
<EOS>
Placidly
,
though
rather
consequentially
smiling
,
she
sat

away
with
a
regular

,
like
a
sort
of
dimpled
little
charming
Dresden
-
china
clock
by
the
very
best
maker
.
  
<EOS>
A
knock
at
the
door
,
and
a
ring
at
the
bell
.
<EOS>
Not
John
;
or
Bella
would
have
flown
out
to
meet
him
.
<EOS>
Then
who
,
if
not
John
?
<EOS>
Bella
was
asking
herself
the
question
,
when
that
fluttering
little
fool
of
a
servant
fluttered
in
,
saying
,
"
Mr.
Lightwood
!
"
  
<EOS>
Oh
good
gracious
!
  
<EOS>
Bella
had
but
time
to
throw
a
handkerchief
over
the
basket
,
when
Mr.
Lightwood
made
his
bow
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
amiss
with
Mr.
Lightwood
,
for
he
was

grave
and

ill
.
  
<EOS>
With

brief

to
the
happy

Rokesmith
as
Miss

,

explained
what

why

.
<EOS>
He

bearing
Lizzie
Hexam
's

.
  
<EOS>
Bella

by

,

he

,
that

John
's

.
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

;
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,

<EOS>
"

,

.

<EOS>
"
What

?
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
All

;
"

<EOS>

"

---

<EOS>

None

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

---

Bella
,

,
"

<EOS>

Blue

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
"

?

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
They

,

-

;

;

Milvey
,

,

Lightwood

,

.
  
<EOS>
That

,
who
was
one

of

,
and

whom

most

-

,

infection
of

about

,
that
communicated

to
everything
with

,

,
she

.
<EOS>
She
was
a
member

the
Reverend
Frank
's

,
and
made
a

of
distinguishing
herself
in
that

,
by

at

,
however

,
<EOS>
said
by
the
Reverend
Frank
in
his
public

;
 
also
by
applying
to
herself
the
various

of
David
,
and
complaining
in
a
personally
injured
manner
(
much
in
arrear
of
the
clerk
and
the
rest
of
the
respondents
)
that
her
enemies
were
digging

-
falls
about
her
,
and
breaking
her
with
rods
of
iron
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
this
old
widow
discharged
herself
of
that
portion
of
the
Morning
and
Evening
Service
as
if
she
were
lodging
a
complaint
on
oath
and

for
a

before
a

.
<EOS>
But
this
was
not
her
most
inconvenient
characteristic
,
for
that
took
the
form
of
an
impression
,
usually

in
inclement
weather
and
at
about

,
that
she
had
something
on
her
mind
and
stood
in
immediate
need
of

Reverend
Frank
to
come

.
<EOS>
Many

had
that
kind
creature
got
up
,
and
gone
out
to
Mrs.
Sprodgkin
(
such

the
disciple
's
name
)
,
suppressing
a
strong
sense
of
her
comicality
by
his
strong
sense
of
duty
,
and
perfectly
knowing
that
nothing
but

cold
would
come
of

.
<EOS>
However
,
beyond
themselves
,
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
and
Mrs.

seldom

that
Mrs.
Sprodgkin
was
hardly
worth
the

she

;
but
both
made

best
of
her
,
as
they
did
of
all

.
  
<EOS>
This
very
exacting
member
of
the
fold
appeared
to
be
endowed
with
a
sixth
sense
,
in
regard
of
knowing
when
the
Reverend
Frank
Milvey
least
desired
her
company
,
and
with
promptitude
appearing
in
his
little
hall
.
<EOS>
Consequently
,

the
Reverend
Frank
had
willingly

that

wife
would
accompany
Lightwood
back
,

,
as

:
"
We
must
make
haste
to
get
out
.
<EOS>
Margaretta
,
my
dear
,
or
we
shall
be
descended
on
by
Mrs.
Sprodgkin
.
"
 
<EOS>
To
which
Mrs.
Milvey
replied
,
in
her
pleasantly
emphatic
way
,
"
Oh
yes
,
for
she
is
such
a
marplot
,
Frank
,
and
does
worry
so
!
"
<EOS>
Words
that
were
scarcely
uttered
when
their
theme
was
announced
as
in
faithful
attendance
below
,
desiring
counsel
on
a
spiritual
matter
.
<EOS>
The
points
on
which
Mrs.
Sprodgkin
sought
elucidation
being
seldom
of
a
pressing
nature
(
<EOS>
as
Who
begat
Whom
,
or
some
information
concerning
the
Amorites
)
,
Mrs.
Milvey
on
this
special
occasion
resorted
to
the
device
of
buying
her
off
with
a
present
of
tea
and
sugar
,
and
a
loaf
and
butter
.
<EOS>
These
gifts
Mrs.
Sprodgkin
accepted
,
but
still
insisted
on
dutifully
remaining
in
the
hall
,
to
curtsey
to
the
Reverend
Frank
as
he
came
forth
.
<EOS>
Who
,
incautiously
saying
in
his
genial
manner
,
"
Well
,
Sally
,
there
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
involved
himself
in
a
discursive
address
from
Mrs.
Sprodgkin
,
revolving
around
the
result
that
she
regarded
tea
and
sugar
in
the
light
of
myrrh
and
frankincense
,
and
considered
bread
and
butter
identical
with
locusts
and
wild
honey
.
<EOS>
Having
communicated
this
edifying
piece
of
information
,
Mrs.
Sprodgkin
was
left
still
unadjourned
in
the
hall
,
and
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Milvey
hurried
in
a
heated
condition
to
the
railway
station
.
<EOS>
All
of
which
is
here
recorded
to
the
honor
of
that
good
Christian
pair
,
representatives
of
hundreds
of
other
good
Christian
pairs
as
conscientious
and
as
useful
,
who
merge
the
smallness
of
their
work
in
its
greatness
,
and
feel
in
no
danger
of
losing
dignity
when
they
adapt
themselves
to
incomprehensible
humbugs
.
  
<EOS>
"
Detained
at
the
last
moment
by
one
who
had
a
claim
upon
me
,
"
 
was
the
Reverend
Frank
's
apology
to
Lightwood
,
taking
no
thought
of
himself
.
<EOS>
To
which
Mrs.
Milvey
added
,
taking
thought
for
him
,
like
the
championing
little
wife
she
was
;
"
Oh
yes
,
detained
at
the
last
moment
.
<EOS>
But
as
to
the
claim
,
Frank
,
I
must
say
that
I
do
think
you
are
over
-
considerate
sometimes
,
and
allow
that
to
be
a
little
abused
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
felt
conscious
,
in
spite
of
her
late
pledge
for
herself
,
that
her
husband
's
absence
would
give
disagreeable
occasion
for
surprise
to
the
Milveys
.
<EOS>
Nor
could
she
appear
quite
at
her
ease
when
Mrs.
Milvey
asked
:
  
"
How
is
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
and
is
he
gone
before
us
,
or
does
he
follow
us
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
becoming
necessary
,
upon
this
,
to
send
him
to
bed
again
and
hold
him
in
waiting
to
be
lanced
again
,
Bella
did
it
.
<EOS>
But
not
half
as
well
on
the
second
occasion
as
on
the
first
;
for
,
a
twice
-
told
white
one
seems
almost
to
become
a
black
one
,
when
you
are
not
used
to
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
dear
!
"
said
Mrs.
Milvey
,
"
I
am
so
sorry
!
<EOS>
Mr.
Rokesmith
took
such
an
interest
in
Lizzie
Hexam
,
when
we
were
there
before
.
<EOS>
And
if
we
had
only
known
of
his
face
,
we
could
have
given
him
something
that
would
have
kept
it
down
long
enough
for
so
short
a
purpose
.
"
  
<EOS>
By
way
of
making
the
white
one
whiter
,
Bella
hastened
to
stipulate
that
he
was
not
in
pain
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Milvey
was
so
glad
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
how
it
is
,
"
said
Mrs.
Milvey
,
"
and
I
am
sure
you
do
n't
,
Frank
,
but
the
clergy
and
their
wives
seem
to
cause
swelled
faces
.
<EOS>
Whenever
I
take
notice
of
a
child
in
the
school
,
it
seems
to
me
as
if
its
face
swelled
instantly
.
<EOS>
Frank
never
makes
acquaintance
with
a
new
old
woman
,
but
she
gets
the
face
-
ache
.
<EOS>
And
another
thing
is
,
we
do
make
the
poor
children
sniff
so
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
how
we
do
it
,
and
I
should
be
so
glad
not
to
;
but
the
more
we
take
notice
of
them
,
the
more
they
sniff
.
<EOS>
Just
as
they
do
when
the
text
is
given
out
.
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
Frank
,
that
's
a
schoolmaster
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
him
somewhere
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
reference
was
to
a
young
man
of
reserved
appearance
,
in
a
coat
and
waistcoat
of
black
,
and
pantaloons
of
pepper
and
salt
.
<EOS>
He
had
come
into
the
office
of
the
station
,
from
its
interior
,
in
an
unsettled
way
,
immediately
after
Lightwood
had
gone
out
to
the
train
:
and
he
had
been
hurriedly
reading
the
printed
bills
and
notices
on
the
wall
.
<EOS>
He
had
had
a
wandering
interest
in
what
was
said
among
the
people
waiting
there
and
passing
to
and
fro
.
<EOS>
He
had
drawn
nearer
,
at
about
the
time
when
Mrs.
Milvey
mentioned
Lizzie
Hexam
,
and
had
remained
near
,
since
:
though
always
glancing
towards
the
door
by
which
Lightwood
had
gone
out
.
<EOS>
He
stood
with
his
back
towards
them
,
and
his
gloved
hands
clasped
behind
him
.
<EOS>
There
was
now
so
evident
a
faltering
upon
him
,
<EOS>
expressive
of
indecision
<EOS>
whether
or
no
he
should
express
his
having
heard
himself
referred
to
,
that
Mr.
Milvey
spoke
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
recall
your
name
,
"
he
said
,
"
<EOS>
but
I
remember
to
have
seen
you
in
your
school
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Bradley
Headstone
,
sir
,
"
he
replied
,
backing
into
a
more
retired
place
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ought
to
have
remembered
it
,
"
said
Mr.
Milvey
,
giving
him
his
hand
.
<EOS>
"
I
hope
you
are
well
?
<EOS>
A
little
overworked
,
I
am
afraid
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
overworked
just
at
present
,
sir
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Had
no
play
in
your
last
holiday
time
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
sir
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
All
work
and
no
play
<EOS>
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
will
not
make
dulness
,
in
your
case
,
I
dare
say
;
but
it
will
make
dyspepsia
,
if
you
do
n't
take
care
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
will
endeavour
to
take
care
,
sir
.
<EOS>
Might
I
beg
leave
to
speak
to
you
,
outside
,
a
moment
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
By
all
means
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
evening
,
and
the
office
was
well
lighted
.
<EOS>
The
schoolmaster
,
who
had
never
remitted
his
watch
on
Lightwood
's
door
,
now
moved
by
another
door
to
a
corner
without
,
where
there
was
more
shadow
than
light
;
and
said
,
plucking
at
his
gloves
:
  
"
One
of
your
ladies
,
sir
,
mentioned
within
my
hearing
a
name
that
I
am
acquainted
with
;
I
may
say
,
well
acquainted
with
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
the
sister
of
an
old
pupil
of
mine
.
<EOS>
He
was
my
pupil
for
a
long
time
,
and
has
got
on
and
gone
upward
rapidly
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
Hexam
.
<EOS>
The
name
of
Lizzie
Hexam
.
"
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
be
a
shy
man
,
struggling
against
nervousness
,
and
spoke
in
a
very
constrained
way
.
<EOS>
The
break
he
set
between
his
two
last
sentences
was
quite
embarrassing
to
his
hearer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"
replied
Mr.
Milvey
.
<EOS>
"
We
are
going
down
to
see
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
gathered
as
much
,
sir
.
<EOS>
I
hope
there
is
nothing
amiss
with
the
sister
of
my
old
pupil
?
<EOS>
I
hope
no
bereavement
has
befallen
her
.
<EOS>
I
hope
she
is
in
no
affliction
?
<EOS>
Has
lost
no
---
relation
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Milvey
thought
this
a
man
with
a
very
odd
manner
,
and
a
dark
downward
look
;
but
he
answered
in
his
usual
open
way
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
glad
to
tell
you
,
Mr.
Headstone
,
that
the
sister
of
your
old
pupil
has
not
sustained
any
such
loss
.
<EOS>
You
thought
I
might
be
going
down
to
bury
some
one
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
may
have
been
the
connexion
of
ideas
,
sir
,
with
your
clerical
character
,
but
I
was
not
conscious
of
it
.
<EOS>
---
Then
you
are
not
,
sir
?
"
  
<EOS>
A
man
with
a
very
odd
manner
indeed
,
and
with
a
lurking
look
that
was
quite
oppressive
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
<EOS>
In
fact
,
"
said
Mr.
Milvey
,
"
since
you
are
so
interested
in
the
sister
of
your
old
pupil
,
I
may
as
well
tell
you
that
I
am
going
down
to
marry
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
schoolmaster
started
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
to
marry
her
,
myself
,
"
said
Mr.
Milvey
,
with
a
smile
,
"
because
I
have
a
wife
already
.
<EOS>
To
perform
the
marriage
service
at
her
wedding
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bradley
Headstone
caught
hold
of
a
pillar
behind
him
.
<EOS>
If
Mr.
Milvey
knew
an
ashy
face
when
he
saw
it
,
he
saw
it
then
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
ill
,
Mr.
Headstone
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
not
much
,
sir
.
<EOS>
It
will
pass
over
very
soon
.
<EOS>
I
am
accustomed
to
be
seized
with
giddiness
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
let
me
detain
you
,
sir
;
I
stand
in
need
of
no
assistance
,
I
thank
you
.
<EOS>
Much
obliged
by
your
sparing
me
these
minutes
of
your
time
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
Mr.
Milvey
,
who
had
no
more
minutes
to
spare
,
made
a
suitable
reply
and
turned
back
into
the
office
,
he
observed
the
schoolmaster
to
lean
against
the
pillar
with
his
hat
in
his
hand
,
and
to
pull
at
his
neckcloth
as
if
he
were
trying
to
tear
it
off
.
<EOS>
The
Reverend
Frank
accordingly
directed
the
notice
of
one
of
the
attendants
to
him
,
by
saying
:
"
There
is
a
person
outside
who
seems
to
be
really
ill
,
and
to
require
some
help
,
though
he
says
he
does
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
had
by
this
time
secured
their
places
,
and
the
departure
-
bell
was
about
to
be
rung
.
<EOS>
They
took
their
seats
,
and
were
beginning
to
move
out
of
the
station
,
when
the
same
attendant
came
running
along
the
platform
,
looking
into
all
the
carriages
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
You
are
here
,
sir
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
springing
on
the
step
,
and
holding
the
window
-
frame
by
his
elbow
,
as
the
carriage
moved
.
<EOS>
"
That
person
you
pointed
out
to
me
is
in
a
fit
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
infer
from
what
he
told
me
that
he
is
subject
to
such
attacks
.
<EOS>
He
will
come
to
,
in
the
air
,
in
a
little
while
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
took
very
bad
to
be
sure
,
and
was
biting
and
knocking
about
him
(
the
man
said
)
furiously
.
<EOS>
Would
the
gentleman
give
him
his
card
,
as
he
had
seen
him
first
?
<EOS>
The
gentleman
did
so
,
with
the
explanation
that
he
knew
no
more
of
the
man
attacked
than
that
he
was
a
man
of
a
very
respectable
occupation
,
who
had
said
he
was
out
of
health
,
as
his
appearance
would
of
itself
have
indicated
.
<EOS>
The
attendant
received
the
card
,
watched
his
opportunity
for
sliding
down
,
slid
down
,
and
so
it
ended
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
the
train
rattled
among
the
house
-
tops
,
and
among
the
ragged
sides
of
houses
torn
down
to
make
way
for
it
,
and
over
the
swarming
streets
,
and
under
the
fruitful
earth
,
until
it
shot
across
the
river
:
bursting
over
the
quiet
surface
like
a
bomb
-
shell
,
and
gone
again
as
if
it
had
exploded
in
the
rush
of
smoke
and
steam
and
glare
.
<EOS>
A
little
more
,
and
again
it
roared
across
the
river
,
a
great
rocket
:
spurning
the
watery
turnings
and
doublings
with
ineffable
contempt
,
and
going
straight
to
its
end
,
as
Father
Time
goes
to
his
.
<EOS>
To
whom
it
is
no
matter
what
living
waters
run
high
or
low
,
reflect
the
heavenly
lights
and
darknesses
,
produce
their
little
growth
of
weeds
and
flowers
,
turn
here
,
turn
there
,
are
noisy
or
still
,
are
troubled
or
at
rest
,
for
their
course
has
one
sure
termination
,
though
their
sources
and
devices
are
many
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
a
carriage
ride
succeeded
,
near
the
solemn
river
,
stealing
away
by
night
,
as
all
things
steal
away
,
by
night
and
by
day
,
so
quietly
yielding
to
the
attraction
of
the
loadstone
rock
of
Eternity
;
and
the
nearer
they
drew
to
the
chamber
where
Eugene
lay
,
the
more
they
feared
that
they
might
find
his
wanderings
done
.
<EOS>
At
last
they
saw
its
dim
light
shining
out
,
and
it
gave
them
hope
:
though
Lightwood
faltered
as
he
thought
:
"
If
he
were
gone
,
she
would
still
be
sitting
by
him
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
he
lay
quiet
,
half
in
stupor
,
half
in
sleep
.
<EOS>
Bella
,
entering
with
a
raised
admonitory
finger
,
kissed
Lizzie
softly
,
but
said
not
a
word
.
<EOS>
Neither
did
any
of
them
speak
,
but
all
sat
down
at
the
foot
of
the
bed
,
silently
waiting
.
<EOS>
And
now
,
in
this
night
-
watch
,
mingling
with
the
flow
of
the
river
and
with
the
rush
of
the
train
,
came
the
questions
into
Bella
's
mind
again
:
<EOS>
What
could
be
in
the
depths
of
that
mystery
of
John
's
?
<EOS>
Why
was
it
that
he
had
never
been
seen
by
Mr.
Lightwood
,
whom

still

?
<EOS>
When
would
that
trial
come
,
through
which
her
faith
in
,
and
her
duty
to
,
her
dear
husband
,
was
to
carry
her
,
rendering
him
triumphant
?
<EOS>
For
,
that
had
been
his
term
.
<EOS>
Her
passing
through
the
trial
was
to
make
the
man
she
loved
with
all
her
heart
,
triumphant
.
<EOS>
Term
not
to
sink
out
of
sight
in
Bella
's
breast
.
  
<EOS>
Far
on
in
the
night
,
Eugene
opened

.
<EOS>
He
was
sensible
,
and
said
at
once
:
"
How
does
the
time
go
?
<EOS>
Has
our
Mortimer
come
back
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lightwood
was
there
immediately
,
to
answer
for
himself
.
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
Eugene
,
and
all
is
ready
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
boy
!
"
returned
Eugene
with

,
"
we
both
thank

heartily
.
<EOS>
Lizzie
,
tell
them
how
welcome
they
are
,
and
that
I
would
be

if
I
could
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
no
need
,
"
said
Mr.
Milvey
.
<EOS>
"
We
know
it
.
<EOS>
Are
you
better
,
Mr.
Wrayburn
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
much
happier
,
"
said
Eugene
.
  
<EOS>
"
Much
better
too
,
I
hope
?
"
  
<EOS>
Eugene
turned
his

towards
Lizzie
,
as
if

her
,
and

nothing
.
  
<EOS>
Then
,
they
all
stood
around

bed
,

Milvey
,
opening

,

the
service
;
so

with

shadow

;
so

.
<EOS>
Bella
thought
how
different

her
own
sunny
little
wedding
,
and
wept
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Milvey
overflowed
with
pity
,
and
wept

.
<EOS>
The
dolls
'

,
with
her

,

in

.
<EOS>
Reading

,

,

,

did

.
<EOS>
As

could
not

,
they
touched

with

ring
,
and
so

on

.
<EOS>
When
the
two
plighted

troth
,
she

,
and

there
.
<EOS>
When

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Undraw

,

,
"

,

,
"
and
let

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
sun
was

,
and
his

struck

room
,
as
she
came

,
and
put
her

.
<EOS>
"
I

!
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
I
bless
the
day
!
"
said
Lizzie
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
made
a
poor

,
my

,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have

the

that
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
But
you
have
followed
the

of
your

.
<EOS>
My

,
that
you
had
thrown
that

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
I
had
given

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
same

,
my

Lizzie
!
"
  
"
Hush
,
hush
!
<EOS>
A
very
different

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
,
"

,

"

,
Lizzie
,
while
I

.
<EOS>
You

!
<EOS>
You

!
"
  
<EOS>
Her

filled

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Lizzie
,
"

"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
There
!
"
he

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
A

,

,

:
"
Eugene
,

!
"
<EOS>
He

"
There

!
<EOS>
You

recall

!
"
<EOS>
And

,

he

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

was
high

,
when
she

to

.
<EOS>
The

of
the

that

,
now

,
but

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
<EOS>
"
How

I

all

owe

,

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,
"
she

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
would
require

,
Lizzie
,

;
more

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Live

,

;

,

;

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

girl
,
"
he

,
rallying

.
<EOS>
"
On
the
contrary
,
I
have
been
thinking

I
can
do
,

die
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

you

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

,
my
dear
girl
.
<EOS>
I
was
not

of
that
.
<EOS>
What
I
was

was
this
.
<EOS>
Out

,

,

much
of

---
you

so

me
<EOS>
---
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Heaven

!
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
Heaven

I
prize

!
<EOS>
Well
.
<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

that

has
a

,
and
will
turn

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"
said

,
wistfully
,

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
But

ca

.
<EOS>
How

,

as

!
<EOS>
I

;
but
I
dare

.
<EOS>
There

sharp

that
if
I

live
,
I
should
disappoint
your
good
opinion
and
my
own
---
and
that
I
ought
to
die
,
my
dear
!
"
   
<EOS>
THE
PASSING
SHADOW
.
 
<EOS>
The
winds
and
tides
rose
and
fell
a
certain
number
of
times
<EOS>
,
the
earth
moved
round
the
sun
a
certain
number
of
times
,
the
ship
upon
the
ocean
made
her
voyage
safely
,
and
brought
a
baby
-
Bella
home
.
<EOS>
Then
who
so
blest
and
happy
as
Mrs.
John
Rokesmith
,
saving
and
excepting
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
!
  
<EOS>
"
Would
you
not
like
to
be
rich
now
,
my
darling
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
can
you
ask
me
such
a
question
,
John
dear
?
<EOS>
Am
I
not
rich
?
"
  
<EOS>
These
were
among
the
first
words
spoken
near
the
baby
Bella
as
she
lay
asleep
.
<EOS>
She
soon
proved
to
be
a
baby
of
wonderful
intelligence
,
evincing
the
strongest
objection
to
her
grandmother
's
society
,
and
being
invariably
seized
with
a
painful
acidity
of
the
stomach
when
that
dignified
lady
honoured
her
with
any
attention
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
charming
to
see
Bella
contemplating
this
baby
,
and
finding
out
her
own
dimples
in
that
tiny
reflection
,
as
if
she
were
looking
in
the
glass
without
personal
vanity
.
<EOS>
Her
cherubic
father
justly
remarked
to
her
husband
that
the
baby
seemed
to
make
her
younger
than
before
,
reminding
him
of
the
days
when
she
had
a
pet
doll
and
used
to
talk
to
it
as
she
carried
it
about
.
<EOS>
The
world
might
have
been
challenged
to
produce
another
baby
who
had
such
a
store
of
pleasant
nonsense
said
and
sung
to
it
,
as
Bella
said
and
sung
to
this
baby
;
or
who
was
dressed
and
undressed
as
in
four
-
and
-
twenty
hours
as
Bella
dressed
and
undressed
this
baby
:
or
who
was
held
behind
doors
and
poked
out
to
stop
its
father
's
way
when
he
came
home
,
as
this
baby
was
;
or
,
in
a
word
,
who
did
half
the
number
of
baby
things
,
through
the
lively
invention
of
a
gay
and
proud
young
mother
,
that
this
inexhaustible
baby
did
.
  
<EOS>
The
inexhaustible
baby
was
two
or
three
months
old
,
when
Bella
began
to
notice
a
cloud
upon
her
husband
's
brow
.
<EOS>
Watching
it
,
she
saw
a
gathering
and
deepening
anxiety
there
,
which
caused
her
great
disquiet
.
<EOS>
More
than
once
,
she
awoke
him
muttering
in
his
sleep
;
and
,
though
he
muttered
nothing
worse
than
her
own
name
,
it
was
plain
to
her
that
his
restlessness
originated
in
some
load
of
care
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
Bella
at
length
put
in
her
claim
to
divide
this
load
,
and
bear
her
half
of
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
know
,
John
dear
,
"
she
said
,
cheerily

to
their
former
conversation
,
"
that
I
hope
I
may
safely
be
trusted
in
great

.
<EOS>
And
it
surely
can
not
be
a
little

.
<EOS>
It

very

about
something
,
but
it
's

,
John
love
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
admit
that
I
am
rather

,
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
please
to

what
about
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
But
no
,
he
evaded

.
"
<EOS>
Never
mind
!
"
<EOS>
thought
Bella
,

.
"
<EOS>
John
requires
me
to
put

him
,
and
he
shall
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
went
up

London
one

,
to

,

order
that
they
might

.
<EOS>
She
found

for

's

,

they

away

.
<EOS>
He
was
in
gay

,
though

that

of
their

rich
;
and

,
now

yonder

theirs
,
and

fine

had
;
what

,

,
best
like

find

?
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
Bella
did
n't
know
:
already
having
everything
she
wanted
,
she
could
n't

.
<EOS>
But
,

she
would
like
to
have
for
the

baby
such

as
never

.
<EOS>
It
was
to

"
a
very
rainbow
for
colours
,
"
 
as
she
was
quite
sure
baby
noticed
colours
;
and
the

was
to

,
as
she
was
absolutely
certain
baby
noticed

;
and

was
to

an

,
of
the
loveliest

,
as
there

not
the
smallest
doubt
in
the
world
that
baby
noticed
birds
.
<EOS>
Was
there
nothing
else
?
<EOS>
No
,
John
dear
.
<EOS>
The
predilections
of
the
inexhaustible
baby
being
provided
for
,
Bella
could
think
of
nothing
else
.
  
<EOS>
They
were

on
in
this

,
and
John
had
suggested
,
"
No
jewels
for
your
own

,

?
"
<EOS>
and
Bella

.
<EOS>
O
!
<EOS>
if
he
came
to

,
yes
,
there

a
beautiful
ivory
case
of
jewels
on
her
dressing
-
table
;
when
these
pictures
were
in
a
moment
darkened
and
blotted
out
.
  
<EOS>
They
turned
a
corner
,
and
met
Mr.
Lightwood
.
  
<EOS>
He
stopped
as
if
he
were
petrified
by
the
sight
of
Bella
's
husband
,
who
in
the
same
moment
had
changed
colour
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Lightwood
and
I
have
met
before
,
"
he
said
.
  
<EOS>
"
Met
before
,
John
?
"
<EOS>
Bella
repeated
in
a
tone
of
wonder
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Lightwood
told
me
he
had
never
seen
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
then
know
that
I
had
,
"
said
Lightwood
,
discomposed
on
her
account
.
<EOS>
"
I
believed
that
I
had
only
heard
of
---
Mr.
Rokesmith
.
"
 
With
an
emphasis
on
the
name
.
  
<EOS>
"
When
Mr.
Lightwood
saw
me
,
my
love
,
"
observed
her
husband
,
not
avoiding
his
eye
,
but
looking
at
him
,
"
my
name
was
Julius
Handford
.
"
  
<EOS>
Julius
Handford
!
<EOS>
The
name
that
Bella
had
so
often
seen
in
old
newspapers
,
when
she
was
an
inmate
of
Mr.
Boffin
's
house
!
<EOS>
Julius
Handford
,
who
had
been
publicly
entreated
to
appear
,
and
for
intelligence
of
whom
a
reward
had
been
publicly
offered
!
  
<EOS>
"
I
would
have
avoided
mentioning
it
in
your
presence
,
"
said
Lightwood
to
Bella
,
delicately
;
"
but
since
your
husband
mentions
it
himself
,
I
must
confirm
his
strange
admission
.
<EOS>
I
saw
him
as
Mr.
Julius
Handford
,
and
I
afterwards
(
unquestionably
to
his
knowledge
)
took
great
pains
to
trace
him
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Quite
true
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
my
object
or
my
interest
,
"
said
Rokesmith
,
quietly
,
"
to
be
traced
out
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
looked
from
the
one
to
the
other
,
in
amazement
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Lightwood
,
"
pursued
her
husband
,
"
as
chance
has
brought
us
face
to
face
at
last
---
which
is
not
to
be
wondered
at
,
for
the
wonder
is
,
that
,
in
spite
of
all
my
pains
to
the
contrary
,
chance
has
not
confronted
us
together
sooner
<EOS>
---
I
have
only
to
remind
you
that
you
have
been
at
my
house
,
and
to
add
that
I
have
not
changed
my
residence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returned
Lightwood
,
with
a
meaning
glance
towards
Bella
,
"
my
position
is
a
truly
painful
one
.
<EOS>
I
hope
that
no
complicity
in
a
very
dark
transaction
may
attach
to
you
,
but
you
can
not
fail
to
know
that
your
own
extraordinary
conduct
has
laid
you
under
suspicion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
it
has
,
"
was
all
the
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
professional
duty
,
"
said
Lightwood
hesitating
,
with
another
glance
towards
Bella
,
"
is
greatly
at
variance
with
my
personal
inclination
;
but
I
doubt
,
Mr.
Handford
,
or
Mr.
Rokesmith
,
whether
I
am
justified
in
taking
leave
of
you
here
,
with
your
whole
course
unexplained
.
"
  
<EOS>
Bella
caught
her
husband
by
the
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
be
alarmed
,
my
darling
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Lightwood
will
find
that
he
is
quite
justified
in
taking
leave
of
me
here
.
<EOS>
At
all
events
,
"
 
added
Rokesmith
,
"
he
will
find
that
I
mean
to
take
leave
of
him
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
,
sir
,
"
said
Lightwood
,
"
you
can
scarcely
deny
that
when
I
came
to
your
house
on
the
occasion
to
which
you
have
referred
,
you
avoided
me
of
a
set
purpose
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Lightwood
,
I
assure
you
I
have
no
disposition
to
deny
it
,
or
intention
to
deny
it
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
continued
to
avoid
you
,
in
pursuance
of
the
same
set
purpose
,
for
a
short
time
longer
,
if
we
had
not
met
now
.
<EOS>
I
am
going
straight
home
,
and
shall
remain
at
home
to
-
morrow
until
noon
.
<EOS>
Hereafter
,
I
hope
we
may
be
better
acquainted
.
<EOS>
Good
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
Lightwood
stood
irresolute
,
but
Bella
's
husband
passed
him
in
the
steadiest
manner
,
with
Bella
on
his
arm
;
and
they
went
home
without
encountering
any
further
remonstrance
or
molestation
from
any
one
.
  
<EOS>
When
they
had
dined
and
were
alone
,
John
Rokesmith
said
to
his
wife
,
who
had
preserved
her
cheerfulness
:
"
<EOS>
And
you
do
n't
ask
me
,
my
dear
,
why
I
bore
that
name
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
John
love
.
<EOS>
I
should
dearly
like
to
know
,
of
course
;
"
(
which
her
anxious
face
confirmed
;
)
"
<EOS>
but
I
wait
until
you
can
tell
me
of
your
own
free
will
.
<EOS>
You
asked
me
if
I
could
have
perfect
faith
in
you
,
and
I
said
yes
,
<EOS>
and
I
meant
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
did
not
escape
Bella
's
notice
that
he
began
to
look
triumphant
.
<EOS>
She
wanted
no
strengthening
in
her
firmness
;
but
if
she
had
had
need
of
any
,
she
would
have
derived
it
from
his
kindling
face
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
have
been
prepared
,
my
dearest
,
for
such
a
discovery
as
that
this
mysterious
Mr.
Handford
was
identical
with
your
husband
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
John
dear
,
of
course
not
.
<EOS>
But
you
told
me
to
prepare
to
be
tried
,
and
I
prepared
myself
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
drew
her
to
nestle
closer
to
him
,
and
told
her
it
would
soon
be
over
,
and
the
truth
would
soon
appear
.
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
"
he
went
on
,
"
lay
stress
,
my
dear
,
on
these
words
that
I
am
going
to
add
.
<EOS>
I
stand
in
no
kind
of
peril
,
and
I
can
by
possibility
be
hurt
at
no
one
's
hand
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
quite
,
quite
sure
of
that
,
John
dear
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Not
a
hair
of
my
head
!
<EOS>
Moreover
,
I
have
done
no
wrong
,
and
have
injured
no
man
.
<EOS>
Shall
I
swear
it
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
John
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Bella
,
laying
her
hand
upon
his
lips
,
with
a
proud
look
.
"
<EOS>
Never
to
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
circumstances
,
"
he
went
on
"
---
I
can
,
and
I
will
,
disperse
them
in
a
moment
---
have
surrounded
me
with
one
of
the
strangest
suspicions
ever
known
.
<EOS>
You
heard
Mr.
Lightwood
speak
of
a
dark
transaction
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
John
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
prepared
to
hear
explicitly
what
he
meant
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
John
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
life
,
he
meant
the
murder
of
John
Harmon
,
your
allotted
husband
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
a
fast
palpitating
heart
Bella
grasped
him
by
the
arm
.
<EOS>
"
You
can
not
be
suspected
,
John
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
love
,
I
can
be
---
for
I
am
!
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
silence
between
them
,
as
she
sat
looking
in
his
face
,
with
the
colour
quite
gone
from
her
own
face
and
lips
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
How
dare
they
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
at
length
,
in
a
burst
of
generous
indignation
.
<EOS>
"
My
beloved
husband
,
how
dare
they
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
caught
her
in
his
arms
as
she
opened
hers
,
and
held
her
to
his
heart
.
"
<EOS>
Even
knowing
this
,
you
can
trust
me
,
Bella
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
trust
you
,
John
dear
,
with
all
my
soul
.
<EOS>
If
I
could
not
trust
you
,
I
should
fall
dead
at
your
feet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
kindling
triumph
in
his
face
was
bright
indeed
,
as
he
looked
up
and
rapturously
exclaimed
,
what
had
he
done
to
deserve
the
blessing
of
this
dear
confiding
creature
's
heart
!
<EOS>
Again
she
put
her
hand
upon
his
lips
,
saying
,
"
Hush
!
"
and
then
told
him
,
in
her
own
little
natural
pathetic
way
,
that
if
all
the
world
were
against
him
,
she
would
be
for
him
;
that
if
all
the
world
repudiated
him
,
she
would
believe
him
;
that
if
he
were
infamous
in
other
eyes
,
he
would
be
honored
in
hers
;
and
that
,
under
the
worst
unmerited
suspicion
,
she
could
devote
her
life
to
consoling
him
,
and
imparting
her
own
faith
in
him
to
their
little
child
.
  
<EOS>
A
twilight
calm
of
happiness
then
succeeding
to
their
radiant
noon
,
they
remained
at
peace
,
until
a
strange
voice
in
the
room
startled
them
both
.
<EOS>
The
room
being
by
that
time
dark
,
the
voice
said
,
"
Do
n't
let
the
lady
be
alarmed
by
my
striking
a
light
,
"
and
immediately
a
match
rattled
,
and
glimmered
in
a
hand
.
<EOS>
The
hand
and
the
match
and
the
voice
were
then
seen
by
John
Rokesmith
to
belong
to
Mr.
Inspector
,
once
meditatively
active
in
this
chronicle
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
take
the
liberty
,
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
,
in
a
business
-
like
manner
,
"
to
bring
myself
to
the
recollection
of
Mr.
Julius
Handford
,
who
gave
me
his
name
and
address
down
at
our
place
a
considerable
time
ago
.
<EOS>
Would
the
lady
object
to
my
lighting
the
pair
of
candles
on
the
chimneypiece
,
to
throw
a
further
light
upon
the
subject
?
<EOS>
No
?
<EOS>
Thank
you
,
ma'am
.
<EOS>
Now
,
we
look
cheerful
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
,
in
a
dark
-
blue
buttoned
-
up
frock
coat
and
pantaloons
,
presented
a
serviceable
,
half
-
pay
,
Royal
Arms
kind
of
appearance
,
as
he
applied
his
pocket
handkerchief
to
his
nose
and
bowed
to
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
favoured
me
,
Mr.
Handford
,
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
,
"
by
writing
down
your
name
and
address
,
and
I
produce
the
piece
of
paper
on
which
you
wrote
it
.
<EOS>
Comparing
the
same
with
the
writing
on
the
fly
-
leaf
of
this
book
on
the
table
---
and
a
sweet
pretty
volume
<EOS>
it
is
---
I
find
the
writing
of
the
entry
,
`
`
Mrs
.
John
Rokesmith
.
<EOS>
From
her
husband
on
her
birthday
"
"
---
and
very
gratifying
to
the
feelings
such
memorials
are
---
to
correspond
exactly
.
<EOS>
Can
I
have
a
word
with
you
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Certainly
.
<EOS>
Here
,
if
you
please
,
"
was
the
reply
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
"
retorted
Mr.
Inspector
,
again
using
his
pocket
handkerchief
,
"
though
there
's
nothing
for
the
lady
to
be
at
all
alarmed
at
still
,
ladies
are
apt
to
take
alarm
at
matters
of
business
---
<EOS>
being
of
that
fragile
sex
that
they
're
not
accustomed
to
them
when
not
of
a
strictly
domestic
character
---
<EOS>
and
I
do
generally
make
it
a
rule
to
propose
retirement
from
the
presence
of
ladies
,
before
entering
upon
business
topics
.
<EOS>
Or
perhaps
,
"
Mr.
Inspector
hinted
,
"
if
the
lady
was
to
step
up
-
stairs
,
and
take
a
look
at
baby
now
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Rokesmith
,
"
---
her
husband
was
beginning
;
when
Mr.
Inspector
,
regarding
the
words
as
an
introduction
,
said
,
"
Happy
,
I
am
sure
,
to
have
the
honor
.
"
<EOS>
And
bowed
,
with
gallantry
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mrs.
Rokesmith
,
"
resumed
her
husband
,
"
is
satisfied
that
she
can
have
no
reason
for
being
alarmed
,
whatever
the
business
is
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Really
?
<EOS>
Is
that
so
?
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
's
a
sex
to
live
and
learn
from
,
and
there
's
nothing
a
lady
ca
n't
accomplish
when
she
once
fully
gives
her
mind
to
it
.
<EOS>
It
's
the
case
with
my
own
wife
.
<EOS>
Well
,
ma'am
,
this
good
gentleman
of
yours
has
given
rise
to
a
rather
large
amount
of
trouble
which
might
have
been
avoided
if
he
had
come
forward
and
explained
himself
.
<EOS>
Well
you
see
!
<EOS>
He
did
n't
come
forward
and
explain
himself
.
<EOS>
Consequently
,
now
that
we
meet
,
him
and
me
,
you
'll
say
---
and
say
right
---
that
there
's
nothing
to
be
alarmed
at
,
in
my
proposing
to
him
to
come
forward
---
or
,
putting
the
same
meaning
in
another
form
,
to
come
along
with
me
---
and
explain
himself
.
"
  
<EOS>
When
Mr.
Inspector
put
it
in
that
other
form
,
"
to
come
along
with
me
,
"
there
was
a
relishing
roll
in
his
voice
,
and
his
eye
beamed
with
an
official
lustre
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
propose
to
take
me
into
custody
?
"
<EOS>
inquired
John
Rokesmith
,
very
coolly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
argue
?
"
returned
Mr.
Inspector
in
a
comfortable
sort
of
remonstrance
;
"
ai
n't
it
enough
that
I
propose
that
you
shall
come
along
with
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
For
what
reason
?
"
  
"
Lord
bless
my
soul
and
body
!
"
returned
Mr.
Inspector
,
"
I
wonder
at
it
in
a
man
of
your
education
.
<EOS>
Why
argue
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
charge
against
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
at
you
before
a
lady
,
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
,
shaking
his
head
reproachfully
:
"
I
wonder
,
brought
up
as
you
have
been
,
you
have
n't
a
more

!
<EOS>
I
charge
you
,
then
,
with
being
some

concerned
in
the
Harmon
Murder
.
<EOS>
I
do

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

with

has
n't

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't

me
.
<EOS>
I
foresaw

visit
this

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Do
n't
!
"
said
Mr.
Inspector
.
<EOS>
"
Why
,
why
argue
?
<EOS>
It

whatever

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
And
I
will
say

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

(

)

.
<EOS>
They

a
full

in

.
<EOS>
When

,
Mr.
Inspector

<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
declined
eating
,
but
assented
to

a

and

.
<EOS>
Mixing

cold
,
and

,

as
that

never

know
such
a

,

never

,

that
what
a
game
was
this
to

the
sort

stuff
a
man
's
opinion

was
made

!
<EOS>
Concurrently

,

more

,
with

half
-

,
who
had

up
a
good
conundrum
,
after
much

,
and
been

.
<EOS>
Bella
was
so
timid
of
him
,
that
she
noted
these
things
in
a
half
-

,
half
-
perceptive
way
,

similarly

that
there

.
<EOS>
That
coming
-
along
-
with
-
him
deportment
was
now
lost
in
long

looks
at
John
and

,
and
sometimes
in

heavy

,

his

made

.
<EOS>
He
had
had
some

satellites
secretly

him
about
the
premises
,
but
they
were
now

,
and
he
eyed
John
as
if

had
meant

,
but
had

.
<EOS>
Whether

noted

,

,

;
but

all

,
and
not
the

of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
's
increased
notice
of
herself
,
and
knowing
way
of
raising

when
their

by

,

the

"
Do

see
?
"
augmented

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
For

,

,

,

,

;

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
But
what
a

that
!
  
<EOS>
They

,

<EOS>

Police

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

;

<EOS>
We

,

<EOS>
The
whitewashed
room
was
pure
white
as

,

-
keeping
was
in
peaceful
progress
as
of
old
,

as

.
<EOS>
The

was
not
a

,
but
a
kind

criminal
Pickford
's
.
<EOS>
The

were
regularly

off

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Inspector
placed
two

,
before

,

(

,

)

,

.
<EOS>
Their

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

;
"

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

.

,

in

<EOS>
The

"

,

<EOS>

Abbey

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

,

"
(

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Potterson
started
up
,
started
back
,
and
exclaimed
:
"
Heaven
defend
us
,
what
's
that
!
"
 
<EOS>
Bella
's
husband
stepped
back
to
Bella
,
took
her
in
his
arms
(
for
she
was
terrified
by
the
unintelligible
terror
of
the
two
men
)
,
and
shut
the
door
of
the
little
room
.
<EOS>
A
hurry
of
voices
succeeded
,
in
which
Mr.
Inspector
's
voice
was
busiest
;
it
gradually
slackened
and
sank
;
 
and
Mr.
Inspector
reappeared
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Sharp
's
the
word
,
sir
!
"
he
said
,
looking
in
with
a
knowing
wink
.
<EOS>
"
We
'll
get
your
lady
out
at
once
.
"
 
<EOS>
Immediately
,
Bella
and
her
husband
were
under
the
stars
,
making
their
way
back
alone
,
to
the
vehicle
they
had
kept
in
waiting
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
was
most
extraordinary
,
and
Bella
could
make
nothing
of
it
but
that
John
was
in
the
right
.
<EOS>
How
in
the
right
,
and
how
suspected
of
being
in
the
wrong
,
she
could
not
divine
.
<EOS>
Some
vague
idea
that
he
had
never
really
assumed
the
name
of
Handford
,
and
that
there
was
a
remarkable
likeness
between
him
and
that
mysterious
person
,
was
her
nearest
approach
to
any
definite
explanation
.
<EOS>
But
John
was
triumphant
;
that
much
was
made
apparent
;
and
she
could
wait
for
the
rest
.
  
<EOS>
When
John
came
home
to
dinner
next
day
,
he
said
,
sitting
down
on
the
sofa
by
Bella
and
baby
-
Bella
:
"
My
dear
,
I
have
a
piece
of
news
to
tell

.
<EOS>
I
have
left
the
China
House
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
As
he
seemed
to
like
having
left
it
,
Bella
took
it
for
granted
that
there
was
no
misfortune
in
the
case
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
a
word
,
my
love
,
"
said
John
,
"
<EOS>
the
China
House
is
broken
up
and
abolished
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
such
thing
any
more
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
,
are
you
already
in
another
House
,
John
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
darling
.
<EOS>
I
am
in
another
way
of
business
.
<EOS>
And
I
am
rather
better
off
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
inexhaustible
baby
was
instantly
made
to
congratulate
him
,
and
to
say
,
with
appropriate
action
on
the
part

a
very
limp
arm

fist
:
"
Three
cheers
,
ladies
and
gemplemorums
.
<EOS>
Hoo
---
ray
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
afraid
,
my
life
,
"
said
John
,
"
that
you
have
become
very
much

to
this

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Afraid
I
have
,
John
?
<EOS>
Of

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
O
John
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
we

.
<EOS>
We

quarters

.
<EOS>
In

,
there

dwelling

rent

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's

,
John
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
my
dear
,

is

.
"
  
<EOS>
He

her
a
very

,
and
a

sly

.
<EOS>
Which

baby
to
square

with
the

fists
,

?
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

gain
,

a
gain
.
<EOS>
A

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wo

,
"

"
---
<EOS>
allow
---
you
---
to
make
 
---
game
---
of
---
my
---

---
Ma
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
At

.
  
<EOS>
John

,

?
<EOS>
Why

,

(

)
,

.
<EOS>
Taking

,

<EOS>
(

.
<EOS>

"
<EOS>
But

And

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

,

?
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

morrow

.
<EOS>
"
Appointment
made
,
accordingly
,
for
Bella
to
go
up

him
to
-
morrow
morning
;
John
kissed
;
and
Bella

.
  
<EOS>
When

reached
London
in

of

little

,

took

and
drove
westward
.
<EOS>
Not

,

,
which
Bella
had
seen

when

's

.
<EOS>
Not

,

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
John
dear
!
"
<EOS>
cried

,

.
<EOS>
"
De

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
The

's

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
house
-

was

without
any

or

,
and
John
promptly

.
<EOS>
The

who
stood
holding

,

no

of

,
neither

.
<EOS>
It

's

,
urging

,
that
prevented

from
stopping
at
the

.
<EOS>
As
they
ascended
,
it
was
seen
to
be
tastefully
ornamented
with
most

flowers
.
  
<EOS>
"
O
John
!
"
said
Bella
,

.
<EOS>
"
What
does
this
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nothing
,
my
darling
,
nothing
.
<EOS>
Let

go
on
.
"
  
<EOS>
Going
on
a

higher
,
they
came
to
a
charming

,
in
which
a
number
of
tropical
birds
,
more
gorgeous
in

than

flowers
,
were

;
and

those
birds
were

,

,

water
-

,
and
a

,
and
all

of

.
  
<EOS>
"
O
my
dear
John
!
"
said
Bella
.
<EOS>
"
What
does
this
mean
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nothing
,
my
darling
,
nothing
.
<EOS>
Let

.
"
  
<EOS>
They

,
until

to
a
door
.
<EOS>
As
John

,
Bella

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
but

's

.
<EOS>
Hold

,
John
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
John

up

,
and
lightly

into

.
  
<EOS>
Behold

Boffin
,

!
<EOS>
Behold

Boffin

,

,

"

,

Noddy

married

,

<EOS>
My

,
deary
,

<EOS>
My

,

,
bright
,
Pretty
Pretty
!
<EOS>
Welcome

,

!
"
   
<EOS>
SHOWING
HOW
THE
GOLDEN
DUSTMAN
HELPED
TO
SCATTER
DUST
.
 
<EOS>
In
all
the
first

of
her

,

the

Mr.
Boffin
.
<EOS>
That
his
wife
should
be

,

-

,
and

,
or
that
her

should

every

that
was
large

,
and
no

was
little
or

,
was
accordant
with
Bella
's
experience
.
<EOS>
But
,
that
he
,
with
a
perfectly

air
and

,
should
be

,

John
,

,
was

.
<EOS>
For
,
how
had
he
looked
when
she
last
saw
him
in
that
very
room
<EOS>
(
it

the
room
in

that

)
,

?
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

,

John
her

<EOS>
Mrs.

,

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,

,

"

<EOS>
Bella

<EOS>
"
Rokesmith

"
  
<EOS>
"
No

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

I

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Did

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
!
<EOS>
That

!
"

Boffin
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Harkee
to
me
,
deary
,
"

Boffin
,
taking

's

,
and

.
<EOS>
"
It
was
after
a

when
John
had
been
disappointed
 
---
as
he
thought
---
in
his

.
<EOS>
It
was
after
a
night
when
John
had
made
an

to
a
certain
young
lady
,
and
the
certain
young
lady
had

.
<EOS>
It
was
after
a
particular
night
,
when
he
felt
himself
cast
-
away
-
like
,
and
had

to
go

.
<EOS>
It
was
the
very

.
<EOS>
My
Noddy
wanted

out

Secretary
's
room
,
and
I

,
`
`
I

,

'll

.
"
<EOS>
"
I

,

her
child
in
her
fair
young
arms
,
and
her
soft

shading

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
looks
as
if
the
old
man
's
spirit
had
found

at
last
;
do
n't

?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
old

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

in

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

in
this
---
delivered

regular

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
pretty

?
<EOS>
Mew
,
Quack

,
Bow
-
wow
!
"
<EOS>
And
then
trotted

,
with
his

in
a
state
of
the

.
   
<EOS>
CHECKMATE
TO
THE
FRIENDLY
MOVE
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
John
Harmon
had
so
timed
their
taking
possession
of
their
rightful
name
and
their
London
house
,
that
the
event

on
the

when
the
last

-
load

last

Boffin
's

.
<EOS>
As

jolted
away
,
Mr.

that
the
last
load
was
correspondingly
removed
from
his
mind
,
and
hailed
the
auspicious
season
when
that
black
sheep
,
Boffin
,
was
to
be
closely

.
  
<EOS>
Over
the
whole
slow

of

Mounds
,
Silas
had
kept
watch
with
rapacious

.
<EOS>
But
,
eyes
no
less
rapacious
had
watched
the
growth
of
the
Mounds
in
years
bygone
,
and
had
vigilantly

the
dust
of
which
they
were
composed
.
<EOS>
No
valuables
turned
up
.
<EOS>
How
should

be
any
,
seeing
that
the
old
hard
jailer
of
Harmony
Jail
had
coined
every
waif
and
stray
into
money
,
long
before
?
  
<EOS>
Though
disappointed
by
this
bare
result
,
Mr.
Wegg
felt
too
sensibly
relieved
by
the
close
of
the
labour
,
to
grumble
to
any
great
extent
.
<EOS>
A
foreman
-
representative
of
the
dust

,
purchasers

,
had
worn
Mr.
Wegg
down
to

.
<EOS>
This
supervisor
of
the

,
asserting
his

'

by

,
nightlight

torchlight
,
when
they
would
,
must
have
been
the
death

Silas
if

work
had
lasted

.
<EOS>
Seeming
never
to
need

,

would

,

broken

,

fantail

and

,

,
at

most

.
<EOS>
Tired
out
by
keeping
close
ward
over
a
long
day
's
work
in
fog
and

,
Silas
would
have
just

to
bed
and
be

,
when
a

under

would
announce

,
escorted
by
this
Demon
of
Unrest
,
to

again
.
<EOS>
At
another

,
he
would
be
rumbled

,
in
the
dead

night
;
at
another
,
would
be
kept
at

eight
-

.
<EOS>
The

his

to
turn
out
<EOS>
,

suspicious
was
the
crafty
Wegg
that
indications

observed
of
something
hidden

,

that

.
<EOS>
So

of
having

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
However
.
<EOS>
Wegg

comfort

,

To

I
'll
knock
you
down
)
,
leaving
the
whole
of
his
property
to
the
Crown
,
"
said
John
Harmon
,
with
as
much
indifference
as
was
compatible
with
extreme
sternness
.
  
<EOS>
"
Right
you
are
!
"
<EOS>
cried
Wegg
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Then
,
"
screwing
the
weight
of
his
body
upon
his
wooden
leg
,
and
screwing
his
wooden
head
very
much
on
one
side
,
and
screwing
up
one
eye
:
"
then
,
I
put
the
question
to
you
,
what
's
this
paper
worth
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nothing
,
"
said
John
Harmon
.
  
<EOS>
Wegg
had
repeated

word
with
a

,
and
was
entering
on
some
sarcastic

,
when
,
to
his
boundless

,
he
found
himself

by

;
shaken

his

;
 
shoved
back
,

,
into

room
;
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
scoundrel
!
"
said
John
Harmon
,
whose
seafaring
hold
was
like
that
of
a
vice
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
knocking
my
head
against
the
wall
,
"
urged

faintly
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
knock
your
head
against
the
wall
,
"
returned
John
Harmon
,
suiting
his

to
his

,
with
the
heartiest
good
will
;
 
"
and
I
'd
give
a
thousand
pounds
for
leave
to
knock
your
brains
out
.
<EOS>
Listen
,
you
scoundrel
,
and
look
at
that
Dutch
bottle
.
"
  
<EOS>
Sloppy
held
it
up
,
for
his
edification
.
  
<EOS>
"
That
Dutch
bottle
,
scoundrel
,
contained
the
latest
will
of
the
many
wills
made
by
my
unhappy
self
-

father
.
<EOS>
That
will
gives
everything
absolutely
to
my
noble

and

,
Mr.
Boffin
,
excluding
and
reviling
me
,
and
my
sister
(
then

of

)
,
by

.
<EOS>
That
Dutch
bottle
was
found
by
my

and
yours
,
after
he
entered
on

.
<EOS>
That
Dutch
bottle
distressed

beyond

,
because
,

which
he

,

.
<EOS>
That
Dutch
bottle
,
therefore
,
he
buried
in
the

,
and
there

lay
while
you
,

,
were

---
often

,
I
dare

.
<EOS>
His

,
that

never

;
but

,
lest

,

,

.
<EOS>
After

who

,

Boffin
,

,

,
upon

impossible

,

.

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Consequently
,

---

---
is

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
That

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here
,
John

assisted

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,

,
"

"
I

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
---

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Through

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
(

)

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
So
.
<EOS>

,

"
  
<EOS>
Silas
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Simultaneously

on

in

,

,
and
on

surface

,
movement

by

Sloppy
:
who

along

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

,
"
that

I
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
Therefore

,

,

"

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.

,
"

"

"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

,
"
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,
"

,

,
"

's

,

.
<EOS>
So

,

,

;

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Upon

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

,
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Ah

<EOS>
When

;

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

.
<EOS>

!
<EOS>
There

hat

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
!
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
In

,

n't

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

were
but

mouth
when
John
Harmon
lifted

,
and
Sloppy
,
who

now

Wegg
,
backed
to

's

,

,
grasped

coat

behind
with

,
and
deftly
swung
him
up
like
the
sack
of
flour
or

before
mentioned
.
<EOS>
A
countenance
of
special
discontent
and
amazement
Mr.
Wegg
exhibited
in
this
position
,
with
his
buttons
almost
as
prominently
on
view
as
Sloppy
's
own
,
and
with
his
wooden
leg
in
a
highly
unaccommodating
state
.
<EOS>
But
,
not
for
many
seconds
was
his
countenance
visible
in
the
room
;
for
,
Sloppy
lightly
trotted
out
with
him
and
trotted
down
the
staircase
,
Mr.
Venus
attending
to
open
the
street
door
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Sloppy
's
instructions
had
been
to
deposit
his
burden
in
the
road
;
but
;
a
scavenger
's
cart
happening
to
stand
unattended
at
the
corner
,
with
its
little
ladder
planted
against
the
wheel
,
Mr.
S.
found
it
impossible
to
resist
the
temptation
of
shooting
Mr.
Silas
Wegg
into
the
cart
's
contents
.
<EOS>
A
somewhat
difficult
feat
,
achieved
with
great
dexterity
,
and
with
a
prodigious
splash
.
   
<EOS>
WHAT
WAS
CAUGHT
IN
THE
TRAPS
THAT
WERE
SET
.
 
<EOS>
How
Bradley
Headstone
had
been
racked
and
riven
in
his
mind
since
the
quiet
evening
when
by
the
river
-
side
he
had
risen
,
as
it
were
,
out
of
the
ashes
of
the
Bargeman
,
none
but
he
could
have
told
.
<EOS>
Not
even
he
could
have
told
,
for
such
misery
can
only
be
felt
.
  
<EOS>
First
,
he
had
to
bear
the
combined
weight
of
the
knowledge
of
what
he
had
done
,
of
that
haunting
reproach
that
he
might
have
done
it
so
much
better
,
and
of
the
dread
of
discovery
.
<EOS>
This
was
load
enough
to
crush
him
,
and
he
laboured
under
it
day
and
night
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
heavy
on
him
in
his
scanty
sleep
,
as
in
his
red
-
eyed
waking
hours
.
<EOS>
It
bore
him
down
with
a
dread
unchanging
monotony
,
in
which
there
was
not
a
moment
's
variety
.
<EOS>
The
overweighted
beast
of
burden
,
or
the
overweighted
slave
,
can
for
certain
instants
shift
the
physical
load
,
and
find
some
slight
respite
even
in
enforcing
additional
pain
upon
such
a
set
of
muscles
or
such
a
limb
.
<EOS>
Not
even
that
poor
mockery
of
relief
could
the
wretched
man
obtain
,
under
the
steady
pressure
of
the
infernal
atmosphere
into
which
he
had
entered
.
  
<EOS>
Time
went
by
,
and
no
visible
suspicion
dogged
him
;
time
went
by
,
and
in
such
public
accounts
of
the
attack
as
were
renewed
at
intervals
,
he
began
to
see
Mr.
Lightwood
(
who
acted
as
lawyer
for
the
injured
man
)
straying
further
from
the
fact
,
going
wider
of
the
issue
,
and
evidently
slackening
in
his
zeal
.
<EOS>
By
degrees
,
a
glimmering
of
the
cause
of
this
began
to
break
on
Bradley
's
sight
.
<EOS>
Then
came
the
chance
encounter
with
Mr.
Milvey
at
the
railway
station
(
where
he
often
lingered
in
his
leisure
hours
,
as
a
place
where
any
fresh
news
of
his
deed
would
be
circulated
,
or
any
placard
referring
to
it
would
be
posted
)
,
and
then
he
saw
in
the
light
what
he
had
brought
about
.
  
<EOS>
For
,
then
he
saw
that
through
his
desperate
attempt
to
separate
those
two
for
ever
,
he
had
been
made
the
means
of
uniting
them
.
<EOS>
That
he
had
dipped
his
hands
in
blood
,
to
mark
himself
a
miserable
fool
and
tool
.
<EOS>
That
Eugene
Wrayburn
,
for
his
wife
's
sake
,
set
him
aside
and
left
him
to
crawl
along
his
blasted
course
.
<EOS>
He
thought
of
Fate
,
or
Providence
,
or
be
the
directing
Power
what
it
might
,
as
having
put
a
fraud
upon
him
---
overreached
him
---
and
in
his
impotent
mad
rage
bit
,
and
tore
,
and
had
his
fit
.
  
<EOS>
New
assurance
of
the
truth
came
upon
him
in
the
next
few
following
days
,
when
it
was
put
forth
how
the
wounded
man
had
been
married
on
his
bed
,
and
to
whom
,
and
how
,
though
always
in
a
dangerous
condition
,
he
was
a
shade
better
.
<EOS>
Bradley
would
far
rather
have
been
seized
for
his
murder
,
than
he
would
have
read
that
passage
,
knowing
himself
spared
,
and
knowing
why
.
  
<EOS>
But
,
not
to
be
still
further
defrauded
and
overreached
---
which
he
would
be
,
if
implicated
by
Riderhood
,
and
punished
by
the
law
for
his
abject
failure
,
as
though
it
had
been
a
success
---
he
kept
close
in
his
school
during
the
day
,
ventured
out
warily
at
night
,
and
went
no
more
to
the
railway
station
.
<EOS>
He
examined
the
advertisements
in
the
newspapers
for
any
sign
that
Riderhood
acted
on
his
hinted
threat
of
so
summoning
him
to
renew
their
acquaintance
,
but
found
none
.
<EOS>
Having
paid
him
handsomely
for
the
support
and
accommodation
he
had
had
at
the
Lock
House
,
and
knowing
him
to
be
a
very
ignorant
man
who
could
not
write
,
he
began
to
doubt
whether
he
was
to
be
feared
at
all
,
or
whether
they
need
ever
meet
again
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
,
his
mind
was
never
off
the
rack
,
and
his
raging
sense
of
having
been
made
to
fling
himself
across
the
chasm
which
divided
those
two
,
and
bridge
it
over
for
their
coming
together
,
never
cooled
down
.
<EOS>
This
horrible
condition
brought
on
other
fits
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
have
said
how
many
,
or
when
;
but
he
saw
in
the
faces
of
his
pupils
that
they
had
seen
him
in
that
state
,
and
that
they
were
possessed
by
a
dread
of
his
relapsing
.
  
<EOS>
One
winter
day
when
a
slight
fall
of
snow
was
feathering
the
sills
and
frames
of
the
schoolroom
windows
,
he
stood
at
his
black
board
,
crayon
in
hand
,
about
to
commence
with
a
class
;
when
,
reading
in
the
countenances
of
those
boys
that
there
was
something
wrong
,
and
that
they
seemed
in
alarm
for
him
,
he
turned
his
eyes
to
the
door
towards
which
they
faced
.
<EOS>
He
then
saw
a
slouching
man
of
forbidding
appearance
standing
in
the
midst
of
the
school
,
with
a
bundle
under
his
arm
;
and
saw
that
it
was
Riderhood
.
  
<EOS>
He
sat
down
on
a
stool
which
one
of
his
boys
put
for
him
,
and
he
had
a
passing
knowledge
that
he
was
in
danger
of
falling
,
and
that
his
face
was
becoming
distorted
.
<EOS>
But
,
the
fit
went
off
for
that
time
,
and
he
wiped
his
mouth
,
and
stood
up
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
governor
!
<EOS>
By
your
leave
!
"
said
Riderhood
,
knuckling
his
forehead
,
with
a
chuckle
and
a
leer
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
place
may
this
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
school
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Where
young
folks
learns
wot
's
right
?
"
said
Riderhood
gravely
nodding
.
<EOS>
"
Beg
your
pardon
,
governor
!
<EOS>
By
your
leave
!
<EOS>
But
who
teaches
this
school
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
're
the
master
,
are

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
I
am
the
master
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
a
lovely
thing
it
must
be
.
"
said
Riderhood
,
"
fur
to
learn
young
folks
<EOS>
wot
's
right
,
and
fur
to
know
wot
<EOS>
they
know
<EOS>
wot
<EOS>
you
do

.
<EOS>
Beg

,

!
<EOS>
By
your
leave
!
<EOS>
---
<EOS>
That
there
black
board
;
wot
's
it
for
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
for
drawing
on
,
or
writing
on
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
though
!
"
said
Riderhood
.
<EOS>
"
Who
'd
have
thought
it
,
from
the
locks
on

!
<EOS>
Would
you
be
so

as
write
your
name
upon

,
learned

?
"
<EOS>
(
in
a

.
)
  
<EOS>
Bradley
hesitated
for
a
moment
;
but
placed
his
usual
signature
,
enlarged
,
upon
the
board
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ai
n't
a
learned
character

,
"
said
Riderhood
surveying

,
"
<EOS>
but
I
do
admire
learning
in

.
<EOS>
I
should
dearly
like
to
hear
these
here

read
that
there
name
off
,
from
the

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

of
the
class
went
up
.
<EOS>
At

's

,

shrill

:
"
Bradley
Headstone
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
?
"

.
<EOS>
"
You
do

mean

?
<EOS>
Headstone
!
<EOS>
Why
,
that
's
in
a

.
<EOS>
Hooroar
for
another
turn
!
"
  
<EOS>
Another

,
another

,
and
another

:
"
Bradley
Headstone
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
got
it
now
!
"
<EOS>
said
Riderhood
,
after

,
and

:
"
Bradley
.
<EOS>
I
see
.
<EOS>
Chris'en
name
,
Bradley
sim'lar
to
Roger
which
is
my
own
.
<EOS>
Eh
?
<EOS>
Fam'ly
name
,
Headstone
,
sim'lar
to
Riderhood
which
is
my
own
.
<EOS>
Eh
?
"
  
Shrill

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Might
you
be

,
learned

,
"
said
Riderhood
,
"
with
a
person
of
about
your
own
height

,
and
wot
'
ud
pull
down
in
a
scale
about

,

sounding
summat
like
Totherest
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With

in

that
made

perfectly

,
though
his
jaw
was

;
with

upon
Riderhood
:
and

quickened

in

;

,

,
after

:
"
<EOS>
I
think
I
know

man
you

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
you
knowed
the
man
I
mean
,
learned
governor
.
<EOS>
I
want
the
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With

half

around
him
at

,
Bradley

:
"
<EOS>
Do
you
suppose
he

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Begging
your

,

,

<EOS>
,
"

,

"
how
could

,
when
there
's
nobody
here
<EOS>
but

,

,

young

<EOS>
wot

?
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
D'ye

he

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
P'raps

you
'd
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thankee
.
<EOS>
As
I
says
a

ago
,
"

,

,
"
though
not

character
<EOS>
my

,

,

!
<EOS>
Being

,
Master
,

,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>
It

!
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Wot

,

?
<EOS>
Wot

?
"
  
<EOS>
Shrill

:
"
Seas
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Seas
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
They
've

,

!
<EOS>
Blowed

,

.
<EOS>

.

,

,

<EOS>

(

:
"
Fish
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good

!
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

?
"

.

:

Weed
!
"

Good

<EOS>

.

It

.

Bradley

.
  
<EOS>

,

wery

!
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
ask
your

,

,
"

,

,
"
tain't
<EOS>
fair

,

.
<EOS>
It
wos

.
<EOS>
But
upon

!
<EOS>
I

here

!
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
You

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
How

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
'Cause
I

,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
They

at

other
.
<EOS>
Bradley
,
slowly

his

,
turned
his

to

black

and
slowly

out
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
heap
of

,
Master
,
"
said

,
"
for

,

'

,

as
has
n't

you
than

.
<EOS>
Wishing

my
Lock

,
the

've

,
and

've

of

learned
governor
both
.
"
  
<EOS>
With

,
he

,
leaving
the
master
to
get
through
his
weary

as
he
might
,
and
leaving

to
observe
the
master
's
face
until
he
fell
into
the
fit
which
had
been
long
impending
.
  
<EOS>
The
next
day
but
one
was
Saturday
,
and
a
holiday
.
<EOS>
Bradley
rose
early
,
and
set
out
on
foot
for
Plashwater
Weir
Mill
Lock
.
<EOS>
He
rose
so
early
that
it
was
not
yet
light
when
he
began
his
journey
.
<EOS>
Before
extinguishing
the
candle
by
which
he
had
dressed
himself
,
he
made
a
little

of
his
decent

and
its

,

:
"
Kindly

.
"
<EOS>
He
then

to
Miss
Peecher
,
and

on
the
most
protected

little

.
  
<EOS>
It

a

easterly

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,
while
the

blew
black
.
<EOS>
The

did
not

until
he
had
been
on
foot
two
hours
,
and
had

a

.
<EOS>
Such

as

,

comfortless

-
house

Riderhood

.
<EOS>
He

Riderhood

.
  
<EOS>
He
outwalked

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

's

there
as
Eugene
's

.
<EOS>
To

<EOS>

"

.

?

<EOS>
Riderhood

<EOS>
PERSONS
AND
THINGS
IN
GENERAL
.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
and
Mrs.
John
Harmon
's
first

was
,
to
set
all

that

in

wrong
,
or

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
In

for

John
's

;

,

,

dolls
'

,

,

.
<EOS>

,
Riah
,

.
<EOS>
Nor

Inspector
,
as

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

"

,

)

.

,

;

;

as

,

,

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

You
and
I
may
well
stumble
at
the
word
,
"
returned
Eugene
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
we
mean
our
Tippins
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
we
   
DO
,
"
said
Mortimer
,
laughing
also
.
  
<EOS>
"
Faith
,
we
   
DO
!
"
<EOS>
returned
Eugene
,
with
great
animation
.
<EOS>
"
We
may
hide
behind
the
bush
and
beat
about
it
,
but
we
   
DO
!
<EOS>
Now
,
my
wife
is
something
nearer
to
my
heart
,
Mortimer
,
than
Tippins
is
,
and
I
owe
her
a
little
more
than
I
owe
to
Tippins
,
and
I
am
rather
prouder
of
her
than
I
ever
was
of
Tippins
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
will
fight
it
out
to
the
last
gasp
,
with
her
and
for
her
,
here
,
in
the
open
field
.
<EOS>
When
I
hide
her
,
or
strike
for
her
,
faint
-
heartedly
,
in
a
hole
or
a
corner
,
do
you
whom
I
love
next
best
upon
earth
,
tell
me
what
I
shall
most
righteously
deserve
to
be
told
:
---
that
she
would
have
done
well
to
turn
me
over
with
her
foot
that
night
when
I
lay
bleeding
to
death
,
and
spat
in
my
dastard
face
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
glow
that
shone
upon
him
as
he
spoke
the
words
,
so
irradiated
his
features
that
he
looked
,
for
the
time
,
as
though
he
had
never
been
mutilated
.
<EOS>
His
friend
responded
as
Eugene
would
have
had
him
respond
,
and
they
discoursed
of
the
future
until
Lizzie
came
back
.
<EOS>
After
resuming
her
place
at
his
side
,
and
tenderly
touching
his
hands
and
his
head
,
she
said
:
  
"
Eugene
,
dear
,
you
made
me
go
out
,
but
I
ought
to
have
stayed
with
you
.
<EOS>
You
are
more
flushed
than
you
have
been
for
many
days
.
<EOS>
What
have
you
been
doing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
,
"
replied
Eugene
,
"
but
looking
forward
to
your
coming
back
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
And
talking
to
Mr.
Lightwood
,
"
said
Lizzie
,
turning
to
him
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
But
it
can
not
have
been
Society
that
disturbed
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Faith
,
my
dear
love
!
"
<EOS>
retorted
Eugene
,
in
his
old
airy
manner
.
<EOS>
as
he
laughed
and
kissed
her
,
"
I
rather
think
it
was
Society
though
!
"
  
<EOS>
The
word
ran
so
much
in
Mortimer
Lightwood
's
thoughts
as
he
went
home
to
the
Temple
that
night
,
that
he
resolved
to
take
a
look
at
Society
,
which
he
had
not
seen
for
a
considerable
period
.
   
<EOS>
THE
VOICE
OF
SOCIETY
.
 
<EOS>
Behoves
Mortimer
Lightwood
,
therefore
,
to
answer
a
dinner
card
from
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
requesting
the
honor
,
and
to
signify
that
Mr.
Mortimer
Lightwood
will
be
happy
to
have
the
other
honor
.
<EOS>
The
Veneerings
have
been
,
as
usual
,
indefatigably
dealing
dinner
cards
to
Society
,
and
whoever
desires
to
take
a
hand
had
best
be
quick
about
it
,
for
it
is
written
in
the
Books
of
the
Insolvent
Fates
that
Veneering
shall
make
a
resounding
smash
next
week
.
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Having
found
out
the
clue
to
that
great
mystery
how
people
can
contrive
to
live
beyond
their
means
,
and
having
over
-
jobbed
his
jobberies
as
legislator
deputed
to
the
Universe
by
the
pure
electors
of
Pocket
Breeches
,
it
shall
come
to
pass
next
week
that
Veneering
will
accept
the
Chiltern
Hundreds
,
that
the
legal
gentleman
in
Britannia
's
confidence
will
again
accept
the
Pocket
,
Breeches
Thousands
,
and
that
the
Veneerings
will
retire
to
Calais
,
there
to
live
on
Mrs.
Veneering
's
diamonds
(
in
which
Mr.
Veneering
,
as
a
good
husband
,
has
from
time
to
time
invested
considerable
sums
)
,
and
to
relate
to
Neptune
and
others
,
how
that
,
before
Veneering
retired
from
Parliament
,
the
House
of
Commons
was
composed
of
himself
and
the
six
hundred
and
fifty
-
seven
dearest
and
oldest
friends
he
had
in
the
world
.
<EOS>
It
shall
likewise
come
to
pass
,
at
as
nearly
as
possible
the
same
period
,
that
Society
will
discover
that
it
always
did
despise
Veneering
,
and
distrust
Veneering
,
and
that
when
it
went
to
Veneering
's
to
dinner
it
always
had
misgivings
---
though
very
secretly
at
the
time
,
it
would
seem
,
and
in
a
perfectly
private
and
confidential
manner
.
  
<EOS>
The
next
week
's
books
of
the
Insolvent
Fates
,
however
,
being
not
yet
opened
,
there
is
the
usual
rush
to
the
Veneerings
,
of
the
people
who
go
to
their
house
to
dine
with
one
another
and
not
with
them
.
<EOS>
There
is
Lady
Tippins
.
<EOS>
There
are
Podsnap
the
Great
,
and
Mrs.
Podsnap
.
<EOS>
There
is
Twemlow
.
<EOS>
There
are
Buffer
,
Boots
,
and
Brewer
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
Contractor
,
who
is
Providence
to
five
hundred
thousand
men
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
Chairman
,
travelling
three
thousand
miles
per
week
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
brilliant
genius
who
turned
the
shares
into
that
remarkably
exact
sum
of
three
hundred
and
seventy
five
thousand
pounds
,
no
shillings
,
and
nopence
.
  
<EOS>
To
whom
,
add
Mortimer
Lightwood
,
coming
in
among
them
with
a
reassumption
of
his
old
languid
air
,
founded
on
Eugene
,
and
belonging
to
the
days
when
he
told
the
story
of
the
man
from
Somewhere
.
  
<EOS>
That
fresh
fairy
,
Tippins
,
all
but
screams
at
sight
of
her
false
swain
.
<EOS>
She
summons
the
deserter
to
her
with
her
fan
;
but
the
deserter
,
predetermined
not
to
come
,
talks
Britain
with
Podsnap
.
<EOS>
Podsnap
always
talks
Britain
,
and
talks
as
if
he
were
a
sort
of
Private
Watchman
employed
,
in
the
British
interests
,
against
the
rest
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
"
We
know
what
Russia
means
,
sir
,
"
says
Podsnap
;
"
we
know
what
France
wants
:
we
see
what
America
is
up
to
;
but
we
know
what
England
is
.
<EOS>
That
's
enough
for
us
.
"
  
<EOS>
However
,
when
dinner
is
served
,
and
Lightwood
drops
into
his
old
place
over
against
Lady
Tippins
,
she
can
be
fended
off
no
longer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Long
banished
Robinson
Crusoe
,
"
says
the
charmer
,
exchanging
salutations
,
"
how
did
you
leave
the
Island
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
"
says
Lightwood
.
<EOS>
"
It
made
no
complaint
of
being
in
pain
anywhere
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Say
,
how
did
you

the
savages
?
"
asks

Tippins
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
were
becoming
civilized
when
I
left
Juan
Fernandez
,
"
says
Lightwood
.
<EOS>
"
At
least
they
were
eating
one
another
,
which
looked
like
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Tormentor
!
<EOS>
"
returns
the
dear
young
creature
.
<EOS>
"
You
know
what
I
mean
,
and
you
trifle
with
my
impatience
.
<EOS>
Tell
me
something
,
immediately
,
about
the
married
pair
.
<EOS>
You
were
at
the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Was
I
,
by
-
the
-
by
?
"
<EOS>
Mortimer

,
at
great

,
to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
I
was
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
How
was
