bride
dressed
?
<EOS>
In
rowing
costume
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mortimer
looks
gloomy
,
and
declines
to
answer
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
she
steered
herself
,
skiffed
herself
,
paddled

,
larboarded
and
starboarded

,
or
whatever

,

?
"

Tippins
.
  
<EOS>
"
However
she
got
to
it
,
she
graced

,
"
says
Mortimer
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Tippins
with
a
skittish
little
scream
,
attracts
the
general
attention
.
<EOS>
"
Graced
it
!
<EOS>
Take
care
of
me
if
I
faint
,
Veneering
.
<EOS>
He
means
to
tell
us
,
that
a
horrid
female
waterman
is
graceful
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
.
<EOS>
I
mean
to
tell
you
nothing
,
Lady
Tippins
,
"
replies
Lightwood
.
<EOS>
And
keeps
his
word
by
eating
his
dinner
with
a
show
of
the
utmost

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
escape
me
in
this
way
,
you
morose
backwoods
-
man
,
"
 
retorts
Lady
Tippins
.
<EOS>
"
You
shall
not
evade
the
question
,
to
screen
your
friend
Eugene
,
who
has
made
this

of

.
<EOS>
The
knowledge
shall
be
brought
home

you
that
such

ridiculous

is

by
the
voice

Society
.
<EOS>
My
dear
Mrs.
Veneering
,
do

resolve

into
a
Committee
of
the
whole
House
on

.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Veneering
,
always
charmed
by
this
rattling

,

;
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
<EOS>
Do
let
us
resolve
ourselves
into
a
Committee
of
the
whole
House
!
<EOS>
So
delicious
!
"
<EOS>
Veneering
says
.
<EOS>
"
As

as
are

that

,
say
Aye
,
---
<EOS>
contrary
,
No
---
the
Ayes
have
it
.
"
<EOS>
But
nobody
takes
the
slightest

of
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
I
am
Chairwoman
of
Committees
!
"
<EOS>
cries
Lady
Tippins
.
  
<EOS>
(
"
What
spirits
she
has
!
"
exclaims
Mrs.
Veneering
;
to
whom
likewise
nobody
attends
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
And
this
,
"
pursues
the
sprightly
one
,
"
is
a
Committee
of
the
whole
House
to
what
-
you
-
may
-
call
-
it
---
elicit
,
I
suppose
---
the
voice
of
Society
.
<EOS>
The
question
before
the
Committee
is
,
whether
a
young
man
of
very
fair
family
,
good
appearance
,
and
some
talent
,
makes
a
fool
or
a
wise
man
of
himself
in

a
female
waterman
,
turned
factory
girl
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Hardly
so
,
I
think
,
"
the
stubborn
Mortimer
strikes
in
.
<EOS>
"
I
take
the
question
to
be
,
whether
such
a
man
as
you
describe
,
Lady
Tippins
.
<EOS>
does
right
or
wrong
in
marrying
a
brave
woman
<EOS>
(
I
say
nothing
of
her
beauty
)
,
who
has
saved
his
life
,
with
a
wonderful
energy
and
address
;
whom
he
knows
to
be
virtuous
,
and
possessed
of

;
whom
he
has
long

,
and
who
is

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
,

,
"
says
Podsnap
,
with
his
temper
and
his
shirtcollar
about
equally
rumpled
;
"
was
this
young
woman
ever
a
female
waterman
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Never
.
<EOS>
But
she
sometimes
rowed
in
a
boat
with
her
father
,
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
General
sensation
against
the
young
woman
.
<EOS>
Brewer
shakes
his
head
.
<EOS>
Boots
shakes
his
head
.
<EOS>
Buffer
shakes
his
head
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
now
,
Mr.
Lightwood
,
was
she
ever
,
"
pursues
Podsnap
,
with

rising

those
hair
-

,
"
a
factory
girl
?
"
  
"
<EOS>
Never
,
But
she
had
some
employment
in
a
paper
mill
,
I
believe
.
<EOS>
"
 
General
sensation
repeated
.
<EOS>
Brewer
says
,
"
Oh
dear
!
"
<EOS>
Boots
says
,
"
Oh
dear
!
"
<EOS>
Buffer
says
,
"
Oh
dear
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
All
,
in
a
rumbling
tone
of
protest
.
  
<EOS>
"
Then
all
I
have
to
say
is
,
"
returns
Podsnap
,
putting
the
thing
away
with
his
right

,
"
that
my
gorge
rises
against
such
a
marriage
---
that
it
offends
and
disgusts
me
---
<EOS>
that
it
makes
me
sick
---
  
and
that
I
desire
to
know
no
more
about
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
"
Now
I
wonder
,
"
thinks
Mortimer
,
amused
,
"
whether
you
are
the
Voice
of
Society
!
"
<EOS>
)
  
<EOS>
"
Hear
,
hear
,
hear
!
"
<EOS>

Lady
Tippins
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Your
opinion
of
this
msalliance
,
honorable
colleague
of
the
honorable
member
who
has
just
sat
down
?
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Podsnap
is
of
opinion
that
in
these
matters
there
should
be
an
equality
of
station
and
fortune
,
and
that
a
man
accustomed
to
Society
should
look
out
for
a
woman
accustomed
to
Society
and
capable
of
bearing
her
part
in
it
with
---
an
ease
and
elegance
of
carriage
---
  
that
.
"
<EOS>
Mrs.
Podsnap
stops
there
,
delicately
intimating
that
every
such
man
should
look
out
for
a
fine
woman
as
nearly
resembling
herself
as
he
may
hope
to
discover
.
  
<EOS>
(
"
Now
I
wonder
,
"
thinks
Mortimer
,
"
whether
you
are
the
Voice
!
"
<EOS>
)
  
<EOS>
Lady
Tippins
next
canvasses
the
Contractor
,
of
five
hundred
thousand
power
.
<EOS>
It
appears
to
this
potentate
,
that
what
the
man
in
question
should
have
done
,
would
have
been
,
to
buy
the
young
woman
a
boat
and
a
small

,
and
set
her
up
for
herself
.
<EOS>
These
things
are
a
question
of
beefsteaks
and
porter
.
<EOS>
You
buy
the
young
woman
a
boat
.
<EOS>
Very
good
.
<EOS>
You
buy
her
,
at
the
same
time
,
a
small
annuity
.
<EOS>
You
speak
of
that
annuity
in
pounds
sterling
,
but
it
is
in
reality
so
many
pounds
of
beefsteaks
and
so
many
pints
of
porter
.
<EOS>
On
the
one
hand
,
the
young
woman
has
the
boat
.
<EOS>
On
the
other
hand
.
<EOS>
she
consumes
so
many
pounds
of
beefsteaks
and
so
many
pints
of
porter
.
<EOS>
Those
beefsteaks
and
that
porter
are
the
fuel
to
that
young
woman
's
engine
.
<EOS>
She
derives
therefrom
a
certain
amount
of
power
to
row
the
boat
;
that
power
will
produce
so
much
money
;
you
add
that
to
the
small
annuity
;
and
thus
you
get
at
the
young
woman
's
income
.
<EOS>
That
(
it
seems
to
the
Contractor
)
is
the
way
of
looking
at
it
.
  
<EOS>
The
fair
enslaver
having
fallen
into
one
of
her
gentle
sleeps
during
this
last
exposition
,
nobody
likes
to
wake
her
.
<EOS>
Fortunately
,
she
comes
awake
of
herself
,
and
puts
the
question
to
the
Wandering
Chairman
.
<EOS>
The
Wanderer
can
only
speak
of
the
case
as
if
it
were
his
own
.
<EOS>
If
such
a
young
woman
as
the
young
woman
described
,
had
saved
his
own
life
,
he
would
have
been
very
much
obliged
to
her
,
would
n't
have
married
her
,
and
would
have
got
her
a
berth
in
an
Electric
Telegraph
Office
,
where
young
women
answer
very
well
.
  
<EOS>
What
does
the
Genius
of
the
three
hundred
and
seventy
-
five
thousand
pounds
,
no
shillings
,
and
nopence
,
think
?
<EOS>
He
ca
n't
say
what
he
thinks
,
without
asking
:
<EOS>
Had
the
young
woman
any
money
?
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
says
Lightwood
,
in
an
uncompromising
voice
;
"
no
money
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madness
and
moonshine
,
"
is
then
the
compressed
verdict
of
the
Genius
.
<EOS>
"
A
man
may
do
anything
lawful
,
for
money
.
<EOS>
But
for
no
money
!
<EOS>
---
Bosh
!
"
  
<EOS>
What
does
Boots
say
?
  
<EOS>
Boots
says
he
would
n't
have
done
it
under
twenty
thousand
pound
  
<EOS>
What
does
Brewer
say
?
  
<EOS>
Brewer
says
what
Boots
says
.
  
<EOS>
What
does
Buffer
say
?
  
<EOS>
Buffer
says
he
knows
a
man
who
married
a
bathing
woman
,
and
bolted
.
  
<EOS>
Lady
Tippins
fancies
she
has
collected
the
suffrages
of
the
whole
Committee
<EOS>
(
nobody
dreaming
of
asking
the
Veneering
for
their
opinion
)
,
when
,
looking
round
the
table
through
her
eyeglass
,
she
perceives
Mr.
Twemlow
with
his
hand
to
his
forehead
.
  
<EOS>
Good
gracious
!
<EOS>
My
Twemlow
forgotten
!
<EOS>
My
dearest
!
<EOS>
My
own
!
<EOS>
What
is
his
vote
?
  
<EOS>
Twemlow
has
the
air
of
being
ill
at
ease
,
as
he
takes
his
hand
from
his
forehead
and
replies
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
disposed
to
think
,
"
says
he
,
"
that
this
is
a
question
of
the
feelings
of
a
gentleman
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
gentleman
can
have
no
feelings
who
contracts
such
a
marriage
,
"
 
flushes
Podsnap
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pardon
me
,
sir
,
"
says
Twemlow
,
rather
less
mildly
than
usual
,
"
I
do
n't
agree
with
you
.
<EOS>
If
this
gentleman
's
feelings
of
gratitude
,
of
respect
,
of
admiration
,
and
affection
,
induced
him
(
as
I
presume
they
did
)
to
marry
this
lady
---
"
  
"
This
lady
!
"
<EOS>
echoes
Podsnap
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sir
,
"
returns
Twemlow
,
with
his
wristbands
bristling
a
little
,
"
you
repeat
the
word
;
I
repeat
the
word
.
<EOS>
This
lady
.
<EOS>
What
else
would
you
call
her
,
if
the
gentleman
were
present
?
"
  
<EOS>
This
being
something
in
the
nature
of
a
poser
for
Podsnap
,
he
merely
waves
it
away
with
a
speechless
wave
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
say
,
"
resumes
Twemlow
,
"
if
such
feelings
on
the
part
of
this
gentleman
,
induced
this
gentleman
to
marry
this
lady
,
I
think
he
is
the
greater
gentleman
for
the
action
,
and
makes
her
the
greater
lady
.
<EOS>
I
beg
to
say
,
that
when
I
use
the
word
,
gentleman
,
I
use
it
in
the
sense
in
which
the
degree
may
be
attained
by
any
man
.
<EOS>
The
feelings
of
a
gentleman
I
hold
sacred
,
and
I
confess
I
am
not
comfortable
when
they
are
made
the
subject
of
sport
or
general
discussion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
to
know
.
"
<EOS>
sneers
Podsnap
,
"
whether
your
noble
relation
would
be
of
your
opinion
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mr.
Podsnap
,
"
retorts
Twemlow
,
"
permit
me
.
<EOS>
He
might
be
,
or
he
might
not
be
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
.
<EOS>
But
,
I
could
not
allow
even
him
to
dictate
to
me
on
a
point
of
great
delicacy
,
on
which
I
feel
very
strongly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Somehow
,
a
canopy
of
wet
blanket
seems
to
descend
upon
the
company
,
and
Lady
Tippins
was
never
known
to
turn
so
very
greedy
or
so
very
cross
.
<EOS>
Mortimer
Lightwood
alone
brightens
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
asking
himself
,
as
to
every
other
member
of
the
Committee
in
turn
,
"
I
wonder
whether
you
are
the
Voice
!
"
<EOS>
But
he
does
not
ask
himself
the
question
after
Twemlow
has
spoken
,
and
he
glances
in
Twemlow
's
direction
as
if
he
were
grateful
.
<EOS>
When
the
company
disperse
---
by
which
time
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Veneering
have
had
quite
as
much
as
they
want
of
the
honor
,
and
the
guests
have
had
quite
as
much
as
they
want
of
the
other
honor
---
Mortimer
sees
Twemlow
home
,
shakes
hands
with
him
cordially
at
parting
,
and
fares
to
the
Temple
,
gaily
.
     
<EOS>
POSTSCRIPT
,
IN
LIEU
OF
PREFACE
.
 
<EOS>
When
I
devised
this
story
,
I
foresaw
the
likelihood
that
a
class
of
readers
and
commentators
would
suppose
that
I
was
at
great
pains
to
conceal
exactly
what
I
was
at
great
pains
to
suggest
:
namely
,
that
Mr.
John
Harmon
was
not
slain
,
and
that
Mr.
John
Rokesmith
was
he
.
<EOS>
Pleasing
myself
with
the
idea
that
the
supposition
might
in
part
arise
out
of
some
ingenuity
in
the
story
,
and
thinking
it
worth
while
,
in
the
interests
of
art
,
to
hint
to
an
audience
that
an
artist
(
of
whatever
denomination
)
may
perhaps
be
trusted
to
know
what
he
is
about
in
his
vocation
,
if
they
will
concede
him
a
little
patience
,
I
was
not
alarmed
by
the
anticipation
.
  
<EOS>
To
keep
for
a
long
time
unsuspected
,
yet
always
working
itself
out
,
another
purpose
originating
in
that
leading
incident
,
and
turning
it
to
a
pleasant
and
useful
account
at
last
,
was
at
once
the
most
interesting
and
the
most
difficult
part
of
my
design
.
<EOS>
Its
difficulty
was
much
enhanced
by
the
mode
of
publication
;
for
,
it
would
be
very
unreasonable
to
expect
that
many
readers
,
pursuing
a
story
in
portions
from
month
to
month
through
nineteen
months
,
will
,
until
they
have
it
before
them
complete
,
perceive
the
relations
of
its
finer
threads
to
the
whole
pattern
which
is
always
before
the
eyes
of
the
story
-
weaver
at
his
loom
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
that
I
hold
the
advantages
of
the
mode
of
publication
to
outweigh
its
disadvantages
,
may
be
easily
believed
of
one
who
revived
it
in
the
Pickwick
Papers
after
long
disuse
,
and
has
pursued
it
ever
since
.
  
<EOS>
There
is
sometimes
an
odd
disposition
in
this
country
to
dispute
as
improbable
in
fiction
,
what
are
the
commonest
experiences
in
fact
.
<EOS>
Therefore
,
I
note
here
,
though
it
may
not
be
at
all
necessary
,
that
there
are
hundreds
of
Will
Cases
(
as
they
are
called
)
,
far
more
remarkable
than
that
fancied
in
this
book
;
and
that
the
stores
of
the
Prerogative
Office
teem
with
instances
of
testators
who
have
made
,
changed
,
contradicted
,
hidden
,
forgotten
,
left
cancelled
,
and
left
uncancelled
,
each
many
more
wills
than
were
ever
made
by
the
elder
Mr.
Harmon
of
Harmony
Jail
.
  
<EOS>
In
my
social
experiences
since
Mrs.
Betty
Higden
came
upon
the
scene
and
left
it
,
I
have
found
Circumlocutional
champions
disposed
to
be
warm
with
me
on
the
subject
of
my
view
of
the
Poor
Law
.
<EOS>
My
friend
Mr.
Bounderby
could
never
see
any
difference
between
leaving
the
Coketown
"
hands
"
exactly
as
they
were
,
and
requiring
them
to
be
fed
with
turtle
soup
and
venison
out
of
gold
spoons
.
<EOS>
Idiotic
propositions
of
a
parallel
nature
have
been
freely
offered
for
my
acceptance
,
and
I
have
been
called
upon
to
admit
that
I
would
give
Poor
Law
relief
to
anybody
,
anywhere
,
anyhow
.
<EOS>
Putting
this
nonsense
aside
,
I
have
observed
a
suspicious
tendency
in
the
champions
to
divide
into
two
parties
;
the
one
,
contending
that
there
are
no
deserving
Poor
who
prefer
death
by
slow
starvation
and
bitter
weather
,
to
the
mercies
of
some
Relieving
Officers
and
some
Union
Houses
;
the
other
,
admitting
that
there
are
such
Poor
,
but
denying
that
they
have
any
cause
or
reason
for
what
they
do
.
<EOS>
The
records
in
our
newspapers
,
the
late
exposure
by
The
Lancet
,
and
the
common
sense
and
senses
of
common
people
,
furnish
too
abundant
evidence
against
both
defences
.
<EOS>
But
,
that
my
view
of
the
Poor
Law
may
not
be
mistaken
or
misrepresented
,
I
will
state
it
.
<EOS>
I
believe
there
has
been
in
England
,
since
the
days
of
the
Stuarts
,
no
law
so
often
infamously
administered
,
no
law
so
often
openly
violated
,
no
law
habitually
<EOS>
so
ill
-
supervised
.
<EOS>
In
the
majority
of
the
shameful
cases
of
disease
and
death
from
destitution
,
that
shock
the
Public
and
disgrace
the
country
,
the
illegality
is
quite
equal
to
the
inhumanity
 
---
and
known
language
could
say
no
more
of
their
lawlessness
.
  
<EOS>
On
Friday
the
Ninth
of
June
in
the
present
year
,
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Boffin
(
in
their
manuscript
dress
of
receiving
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Lammle
at
breakfast
)
were
on
the
South
Eastern
Railway
with
me
,
in
a
terribly
destructive
accident
.
<EOS>
When
I
had
done
what
I
could
to
help
others
,
I
climbed
back
into
my
carriage
---
nearly
turned
over
a
viaduct
,
and
caught
aslant
upon
the
turn
---
to
extricate
the
worthy
couple
.
<EOS>
They
were
much
soiled
,
but
otherwise
unhurt
.
<EOS>
The
same
happy
result
attended
Miss
Bella
Wilfer
on
her
wedding
day
,
and
Mr.
Riderhood
inspecting
Bradley
Headstone
's
red
neckerchief
as
he
lay
asleep
.
<EOS>
I
remember
with
devout
thankfulness
that
I
can
never
be
much
nearer
parting
company
with
my
readers
for
ever
,
than
I
was
then
,
until
there
shall
be
written
against
my
life
,
the
two
words
with
which
I
have
this
book
:
---
The
End
.
<EOS>
September
2nd
,
1865
.
   
<EOS>
